title: IsBad: Imperceptible Sample-Specific Backdoor to DNN With Denoising Autoencoder
authors: Xiangqi Wang, Mingfu Xue, Kewei Chen, Jing Xu, Wenmao Liu, Leo Yu Zhang, Yushu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computing
abstract: The backdoor attack poses a new security threat to deep neural networks (DNNs). The existing backdoor often relies on visible universal triggers to make the backdoored model malfunction, which is not only usually visually suspicious to humans but also catchable by mainstream countermeasures. We propose an imperceptible sample-specific backdoor that the trigger varies from sample to sample and is invisible. Our trigger generation is automated through a denoising autoencoder that is fed with delicate but pervasive features (e.g., edge patterns per image). We extensively experiment with our backdoor attack on ImageNet and MS-Celeb-1 M, which demonstrates a stable and nearly 100% (i.e., 99.8%) attack success rate with negligible impact on the clean data accuracy of the infected model. The denoising autoencoder-based trigger generator is reusable or transferable across tasks (e.g., from ImageNet to MS-Celeb-1 M), whilst the trigger has high exclusiveness (i.e., a trigger generated for one sample is not applicable to another sample). Besides, our proposal backdoored model has achieved high evasiveness against mainstream backdoor defenses such as Neural Cleanse, STRIP, SentiNet, Fine-Pruning, BDMAE, and BTI-DBF.

title: 3D vessel centerline extraction via vascular morphology driven adaptive deep reinforcement tracking
authors: Jingliang Zhao
abstract: Accurate vessel centerline extraction in medical images has important clinical value for preoperative diagnosis and intraoperative intervention of vascular diseases. However, due to the irregular vascular contour, severe stenosis, and large variation of vascular scale, accurate 3D vessel centerline extraction is very challenging. This study aims to develop a new deep reinforcement learning (RL) framework for 3D vessel centerline extraction. The proposed framework consists of three steps. 1) A novel adaptive state with vascular scale perception is introduced, which allows the tracker to focus on vessel-relevant areas and finally improves the accuracy of small vessels. 2) With the updated state, a spatial attention embedded deep reinforcement tracker predicts the tangential vector and step forward. 3) To safely pass through abnormalities areas, a vascular morphology based policy gradient is introduced, which encourages the tracker to move forward while getting as close to the centerline as possible. On a highly challenging 3D vessel dataset with 100 CTA scans, our method obtains mean centerline overlap of 95.26%, which outperforms four state-of-the-art centerline extraction methods. The proposed method is very fast and accurate, hence, it can provide a valuable tool for doctors in preoperative and intraoperative intervention of vascular diseases.

title: Hierarchical Cross-Consistency Network based Unsupervised Domain Adaptation for Pathology Whole Slide Image Segmentation_supp1-3624582.pdf
authors: Chun-Rong Huang
abstract: Goal: Pathology images collected from different hospitals often have large appearance variability causedby different scanners, patients, or hospital protocols. Deep learning-based pathology segmentation models are highly dependent on the distribution of training data. Therefore, the models often suffer from the domain shift problem when applied to new target domains of different hospitals. Methods: To address this issue, we propose a hierarchical cross-consistency (HCC) network to hierarchically adapt models across pathology images of various domains with three consistency-based modules, the consistency module, the pair module, and the mixture module. The consistency module enhances the prediction consistency of each target image under various perturbations. The pair module improves consistency among different target images. Finally, the mixture module enhances the consistency across different domains. Results: The experimental results on pathology image datasets scanned using three different scanners show the superiority of the proposed HCC network compared to state-of-the-art unsupervised domain adaptation methods. Conclusions: The proposed method can successfully adapt trained pathology image segmentation models to new target domains, which is useful when introducing the models to different hospitals.

title: Lossy Beyond Diagonal Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces: Modeling and Optimization
authors: Yiyang Peng, Hongyu Li, Zheyu Wu, Bruno Clerckx
abstract: Beyond diagonal reconfigurable intelligent surface (BD-RIS) has emerged as an advancement and generalization of the conventional diagonal RIS (D-RIS) by introducing tunable interconnections between RIS elements, enabling smarter wave manipulation and enlarged coverage. While BD-RIS has demonstrated advantages over D-RIS in various aspects, most existing works rely on the assumption of a lossless model, leaving practical considerations unaddressed. This paper thus proposes a lossy BD-RIS model and develops corresponding optimization algorithms for various BD-RIS-aided communication systems. First, by leveraging admittance parameter analysis, we model each tunable admittance component based on a lumped circuit with losses and derive an expression of a circle characterizing the real and imaginary parts of each tunable admittance. We then consider the received signal power maximization in single-user single-input single-output (SISO) systems with the proposed lossy BD-RIS model. To solve the formulated challenging optimization problem, we design an effective algorithm by carefully exploiting the problem structure. In particular, an alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) framework is custom-designed to deal with the complicated constraints associated with lossy BD-RIS. Furthermore, we extend the proposed algorithmic framework to more general multiuser multiple-input single-output (MU-MISO) systems, where the transmit precoder and BD-RIS scattering matrix are jointly designed to maximize the sum-rate of the system. Finally, simulation results demonstrate that all BD-RIS architectures still outperform D-RIS in the presence of losses, but the optimal BD-RIS architectures in the lossless case are not necessarily optimal in the lossy case, e.g. group-connected BD-RIS can outperform fully- and tree-connected BD-RISs in SISO systems with relatively high losses at BD-RIS, whereas the opposite always holds true in the lossless case.

title: Patch Matter : Dual Modality Patch Contrastive for Non-stationary Radio Signals
authors: Jie Su, Yuting Jiang, Yuheng Ye, Zhenyu Wen, Taotao Li, Shibo He, Xiaoqin Zhang, Rajiv Ranjan
abstract: The emergence of abundant non-stationary radio signal (NSRS) data presents significant opportunities for applications in wireless communications, radar systems, remote sensing, and healthcare. While deep learning models have shown promise in capturing sequence dependencies, deriving generic and fine-grained representations of NSRS data remains challenging due to its complex, dynamic nature and the scarcity of labeled data. The NSRS data are often frequency-sensitive and exhibit minuscule inter-class distances, posing significant challenges for precise classification. To address these issues, we propose a novel Dual Modality Patch Contrastive (DMPC) framework. This framework leverages a stochastic patching paradigm for diverse local pattern extraction and a time-frequency cross-view optimization for frequency-sensitive feature mining. Furthermore, an Attentive Patch Aggregation (APA) mechanism enhances fine-grained inference under few-shot conditions through patch-level feature voting. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in addressing the unique challenges of NSRS data.

title: Automated Parameterization of Errors in Additive Manufacturing Parts for Data Feedback in Digital Manufacturing Systems
authors: Cesar A. Peña, Cristhian I. R. Jaimes, Aldo Pardo
abstract: Closed-loop manufacturing is an advanced production approach that requires data integration at all levels of the system architecture to support decision-making within the processes involved, thereby improving manufacturing efficiency. One of the main barriers to its full implementation is the lack of interoperable and automated inspection systems capable of detecting errors and enabling data feedback, with the potential for integration into closed-loop control systems. This article presents an integrated approach for the dimensional and geometric inspection of parts produced by additive manufacturing, combining a UR5e collaborative robot with a machine vision system. The proposed solution features an open architecture, is low-cost, and can operate directly in the production environment, reducing human intervention during the measurement process. The system performs both dimensional and geometric inspections on the same machine, leveraging the robot’s communication interfaces, control capabilities, and sensors to feed acquired data into a process control algorithm. Two evaluation strategies are presented: the first, based on machine vision, performs dimensional measurements and introduces a novel approach for parameterizing errors in printed corners using area-based analysis and linear regression; the second, based on the UR5e, performs contact-based inspection of geometric characteristics such as circularity, parallelism, and perpendicularity. The system achieved a standard deviation of 0.0378mm and can generate indicators such as the Filling Quality Index (FQI), Non-Printed Area Index (NPAI), and Unnecessary Printed Regions (INR). The proposed integrated architecture enables automated inspections with high precision and minimal human intervention, provides valuable data for quality control, and overcomes limitations of external metrology stations, with potential for future integration into automatic compensation schemes within digital manufacturing chains.

title: Fully Decentralized Data Distribution for Large-Scale HPC Systems
authors: Ruibo Wang, Mingtian Shao, Wenzhe Zhang, Huijun Wu, Jiaxin Li, Lihua Yang, Di Ma, Yiqin Dai, Kai Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: For many years, in the HPC data distribution scenario, as the scale of the HPC system continues to increase, manufacturers have to increase the number of data providers to improve the IO parallelism to match the data demanders. In large-scale, especially exascale HPC systems, this mode of decoupling the demander and provider presents significant scalability limitations and incurs substantial costs. In our view, only a distribution model in which the demander also acts as the provider can fundamentally cope with changes in scale and have the best scalability, which is called all-to-all data distribution mode in this paper. We design and implement the BitTorrent protocol on computing networks in HPC systems and propose FD3, a fully decentralized data distribution method. We design the Requested-to-Validated Table (RVT) and the Highest ranking and Longest consecutive piece segment First (HLF) policy based on the features of the HPC networking environment to improve the performance of FD3. In addition, we design a torrent-tree to accelerate the distribution of seed file data and the aggregation of distribution state, and release the tracker load with neighborhood local-generation algorithm. Experimental results show that FD3 can scale smoothly to 11k+ computing nodes, and its performance is much better than that of the parallel file system. Compared with the original BitTorrent, the performance is improved by 8-15 times. FD3 highlights the considerable potential of the all-to-all model in HPC data distribution scenarios. Furthermore, the work of this paper can further stimulate the exploration of future distributed parallel file systems and provide a foundation and inspiration for the design of data access patterns for Exscale HPC systems.

title: High-Resolution and Multiple-Tone Microwave Frequency Measurement Based on Predefinable Optical Frequency Combs Utilizing a Dual-Polarization Dual-Drive Mach–Zehnder Modulator
authors: Xinhai Zou, Xin Wang, Lingjie Zhang, Chao Jing, Yali Zhang, Zhiyao Zhang, Shang Jian Zhang, Yong Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: A high-resolution and multiple-tone microwave frequency measurement (MFM) method is proposed based on predefinable optical frequency combs (OFCs) using a dual-polarization dual-drive Mach–Zehnder modulator (Dpol-DDMZM). Two OFCs with predefinable spectrum shape are generated by electro-optic modulation (EOM) and mixed with the microwave signal under test (SUT) through photonic mixing with a single Dpol-DDMZM simultaneously, in which two minimum frequency components are generated mapping from SUT and used for SUT frequency recovery, respectively. The relative position between SUT and comb teeth can be determined with the power difference of the above two minimum frequency tones. In the proposed method, wideband and high-resolution are simultaneously guaranteed due to the combination of wideband photonic-assisted microwave photonic mixing and hyperfine electrical analysis. Moreover, it also enables multiple-tone measurement relying on the unique frequency-to-frequency mapping (FTFM) relationship between the SUT and the mixing frequency components. In the proof of concept, MFM is experimentally demonstrated up to a 40-GHz frequency range with a 10-kHz measurement error, and a two-tone MFM is also successfully implemented. More importantly, the proposed method features a reconfigurable measurement range just using a single Dpol-DDMZM and automatic frequency recovery with a frequency discrimination algorithm, which makes the measurement simple and compact.

title: End-to-End Evaluation of the Int5Gent Platform: Integrating 5G Enabling Technologies in a Holistic Service to Physical Layer Platform
authors: E. Kyriazi, P. Toumasis, G. Katsikas, L. Papadopoulos, V. Charlaftis, C. Meysmans, J. Brenes, D. Diakakis, I. Mesogiti, W. Wasko, R. Munoz, D. Larrabeiti, Z. S. He, E. Dayan, I. Garcia-Mila, J. P. Fernandez-Palacios, C. Manso, C. Miralpeix, L. Korsic, J. M. Fabrega, O. Segou, I. Avramidis, E. Theodoropoulou, G. Lyberopoulos, J. Sterle, G. Torfs, C. Vagionas, D. Klonidis, G. Giannoulis, H. Avramopoulos, D. Apostolopoulos
abstract: The Int5Gent approach integrates advanced technologies across the data plane, control plane, and application layers to enable high-capacity, low-latency, and flexible network solutions for demanding vertical applications in beyond 5G (B5G) networks. Focusing on edge computing, Sigma-Delta over-Fiber (SDoF), Digital Radioover- Fiber (D-RoF), Analog Radio-over-Fiber (A-RoF), millimeter-wave (mmWave) backhaul, and GPU-enabled processing, it supports Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven use cases such as realtime video analysis and critical communication for Public Protection and Disaster Relief (PPDR). The platform demonstrators show: a) real-time human detection and AI inference at 15 frames per second (fps), showcasing network resiliency and integration of A-RoF with D-band transceivers for high-speed video transmission and b) the system's ability to monitor critical infrastructure (railway), using edge-based processing for safety- critical applications and dynamic transport slicing for operational needs. Both demonstrators validated the platform's ability to orchestrate and optimize resources in real-time, offering scalable, resilient solutions for future 5G deployments.

title: Incremental DRL-Based Resource Management for Dynamic Network Slicing in an Urban-Wide Testbed
authors: Haiyuan Li, Yuelin Liu, Hari Madhukumar, Amin Emami, Xueqing Zhou, Yulei Wu, Xenofon Vasilakos, Shuangyi Yan, Dimitra Simeonidou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Multi-access edge computing provides localized resources within mobile networks to address the requirements of emerging latency-sensitive and computing-intensive applications. At the edge, dynamic requests necessitate sophisticated resource management for adaptive network slicing. This involves optimizing resource allocations, scaling functions, and load balancing to utilize only essential resources under constrained network scenarios. However, existing solutions largely assume static slice counts, ignoring the re-optimization overhead associated with management algorithms when slices fluctuate. Moreover, many approaches rely on simplified energy models that overlook intertemporal resource scheduling and are predominantly evaluated through simulations, neglecting critical practical considerations. This paper presents an incremental cooperative Multi-Agent Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (MADDPG) algorithm for resource management in dynamic edge slicing. The proposed approach optimizes long-term slicing benefits by reducing delay and energy consumption while minimizing retraining overhead in response to slice variations. Furthermore, we implement an urban-wide edge computing testbed based on OpenStack and Kubernetes to validate the algorithm’s performance. Experimental results demonstrate that our incremental MADDPG method outperforms benchmark strategies in aggregated slicing utility and reduces training energy consumption by up to 50% compared to the re-optimization approach.

title: Leveraging YOLO Models for Enhanced Object Detection and Recognition in E-Commerce
authors: G Kalyan Chakravarthi, Raghvendra Kumar, Ssvr Kumar Addagarla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Visual object detection and recognition is playing a vital role in many majorities of the e-commerce platforms now-a-days. Especially after the COVID-19 pandemic era, most of the developing nations are moving towards digitalization, and internet usage is rapidly increasing day by day. The growing significance of purchases through e-commerce platforms has led to increased popularity, where the adoption of various Artificial Intelligence techniques, such as real-time visual product detection and recognition, remains a key challenge in addressing customer needs. This paper focuses on visual object detection and classification using different deep learning models like YOLOv8, YOLOv9, and YOLO-NAS, utilizing Google's Open Image Dataset with five distinct classes and a custom-curated dataset containing four classes from popular Indian e-commerce platforms. These models have been thoroughly tested using various performance metrics, including Recall, Precision, mean average precision, and Fl-Score, with the YOLOv9m model achieving a 97.8% mAP on the custom dataset. Further, our fine-tuned YOLOV9m model was cross-validated using various unseen e-commerce images for detection and classification, which provided promising results.

title: Model-Centric Data Validation: A Feedback-Loop Approach to Dynamic Quality Control
authors: Rajesh Gangavarapu, Ohm Hareesh Kundurthy, Arshiya Shirdi, Srinivas Vikram, Jaya Eripilla, Anil Kumar Jonnalagadda
abstract: Ensuring constant data quality has been preceded by the growing dependence on data-driven systems, especially in dynamic settings where distributions of data change with the passage of time. A model-oriented data validation system is outlined in this paper and includes the feedback loop mechanism to provide a constant monitoring, evaluation, and improvement of the quality of the data in use. Our approach in contrast to classical, and more common static validation schemes, utilizes the validation measures and internal representations as well as model stability performance measures to sense anomalies, drift and inconsistency in arriving data streams. The feedback loop does not only allow self-refinement of thresholding and validation rules but also ensures self-supervised quality control without loss of the system activity. The experimental findings in various areas such as industrial sensor applications, financial transactions, and healthcare data show that the offered framework enhances both the quality of the model and the quality of the decision made through pre-emptive filtering or flagging low-quality data. Such a model-sensitive feedback framework provides an intelligent and extensible data maintenance channel in dynamically changing machine learning platforms.

title: AI-Assisted Robotic Systems for Brain Tumor Biopsy Procedures
authors: Vijayhari Karambelkar, Pradnya Borkar, Amrita Paul, Kirti H. Wanjale, Girish Gadre, Jahid Ali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: One field of medicine undergoing transformation with the application of artificial intelligence (AI) in robotic systems is neurobiology. The development and use of artificial intelligence-assisted robotic devices in brain tumours biopsy procedures is examined in this article. Difficult and very delicate procedures, brain tumours biopsies must be carried out with great care and accuracy to ensure the patient is safe and the tissue is correctly obtained. Traditional biopsy techniques are prone to errors made by individuals, variations in competence, and difficulty reaching certain tumours locations. Since they increase accuracy, reduce running time, and make the whole process safer, AI-powered computer systems might be a decent approach to address these challenges. AI algorithms in the robotic systems can examine pre-surgery imaging, such as MRI and CT scans, and real-time figure out where the cancer is, what form it is, and what adjacent structures are. The robotic arm can therefore make decisions depending on the appearance of the tumour and move rather accurately. The technology also enhances visualization and supports decision-making by means of artificial intelligence-driven image analysis and predictive analytics. These characteristics let clinicians conduct biopsies with less danger of difficulties and greater faith. By monitoring and real-time process modification, AI-assisted systems may also aid enhance outcomes after surgery, therefore creating even more opportunities for future usage in neurosurgery. The most recent technical developments, clinical research, and probable advantages of artificial intelligence-assisted robotic systems in brain tumours biopsies are discussed in this article. It highlights their ability to transform neurosurgery by increasing patient accuracy and efficiency of treatments.

title: A Customizable and Adaptive Audio System with Enhanced Sound Quality using DSP Processor
authors: S Archana, S A Ajay Nath, A V Arun
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Audio systems play a crucial role in today’s developing world, enhancing communication, entertainment, productivity, and overall experience in various fields. This project explores the integration of the BD37534FV-E2 audio processor, a Class D amplifier, and an Arduino Nano to develop a customizable, efficient, and user-friendly audio system. The design aims to enhance audio control, improve power efficiency up to 90 percent, and provide a flexible platform for various audio applications. The combination of hardware and software allows for unique features, expandability, making it a valuable project in the field of audio systems.

title: Enhancing Energy Efficiency in Embedded Machine Learning Systems via Neuromorphic Architecture
authors: Kassem AL-Attabi, Neha Tyagi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: As embedded systems are increasingly used in edge computing applications, the demand for machine learning (ML) capabilities has increased. CPUs and GPUs are traditional computing architectures, but their power consumption and memory constraints often limit their performance. Embedded machine learning systems can be made more energy-efficient by using neuromorphic architectures. With neuromorphic computing, low-power, high-performance computation is achieved using spiking neural networks (SNN s). Our approach reduces energy consumption without compromising accuracy by combining approximate computing with neuron sensitivity analysis via backpropagation. Using datasets such as MNIST, Fashion-MNIST, and the ASL Alphabet, neuromorphic systems are validated as being more energy-efficient, latency-free, and scalable than conventional systems. Intel's Loihi and NM500 hardware implementations have demonstrated that neuromorphic models consume over an order of magnitude less energy than GPUs and CPUs. As ML devices become more intelligent and sustainable, neuromorphic architectures have significant potential.

title: Hybrid Sentiment-Based Labeling for Automated Fake Review Detection in Marketplaces
authors: Eka Praja Wiyata Mandala, Sarjon Defit, Gunadi Widi Nurcahyo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: The increasing use of review systems on marketplace platforms has led to the emergence of deceptive behaviors, particularly the generation of fraudulent reviews that mislead consumers and damage sellers' reputations. This study proposes a hybrid sentiment-based method for automatically labeling and detecting fake reviews. The process begins with text preprocessing-normalization, cleaning, and stemming-of Indonesian-language reviews, followed by translation into English to leverage two prominent sentiment analysis tools: VADER and TextBlob. A key contribution of this study is the introduction of VADERBLOB, a technique that merges outputs from both tools by assigning labels based on consensus or, in case of disagreement, selecting the label with the higher polarity score. This approach effectively detected 28 % of reviews as fraudulent and produced a more coherent label distribution compared to individual methods. Evaluation results demonstrated an accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0. 6 0 \%}$</tex>, precision of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 3. 5 7 \%}$</tex>, recall of 82.98 %, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex>-score of 83.27 %, indicating the model's reliability for initial labeling. However, implementing this hybrid approach also presented specific challenges, including inconsistencies in sentiment interpretation between VADER and TextBlob due to contextual nuances, and potential translation artifacts affecting polarity scores. Addressing these issues required careful calibration of thresholds and validation logic to ensure classification robustness. These findings suggest that the combined sentiment-based method has significant potential for enhancing the accuracy of fake review detection, thereby contributing to a more trustworthy e-commerce environment.

title: Predicting ESG disclosure in SMEs: a Neural Network Approach
authors: Giacomo Di Tollo, Gianni Filograsso, Graziella Pacelli, Gerard Zekaj
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Despite their economic importance, SMEs, face unique challenges in sustainability reporting due to the voluntary nature of ESG disclosure, inconsistencies in reporting practices, and the lack of external assurance, making traditional methods unapt to grasp the components of these reports. Our study aims to build a Neural Network approach to assess whether some indicators of the business’ operational aspect may be used to predict Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) disclosure among SMEs. To capture the depth of ESG-related content, a text-mining analytical approach has been used to quantify ESG disclosure, based on a modified $\boldsymbol{t}$-idf (term frequency-inverse document frequency) weighting scheme, leading to a dataset of 84 SMEs across the EU, including the UK, Norway, and Switzerland, covering the period from 2019 to 2022.

title: DrugTrace: Microwave-based Narcotics Detection System using RF Signature
authors: M S Devika, G Govinda Pai, Adil Kabir, S Adithyan, K S Sreekanth, Reshma Lakshmanan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: In the present scenario, detecting illegal substances such as narcotics is very important in our security systems nowadays. This paper focuses on creating a strong and effective detection system using microwave technology. Using diverse dielectric properties of different materials, this system can identify narcotics by their specific RF signatures. The paper mainly includes designing, simulation, and fabrication of an antenna that is well optimized for both the transmission and reception of RF signals. Then we evaluate the electromagnetic responses to differentiate narcotics from other substances. The simulated data are used to confirm the accuracy and dependability of the system, ensuring a minimal rate of false detections. In addition, experimental validation was performed using a Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) to verify the performance of the fabricated antenna and analyze its S parameters. This paper presents the combination of electromagnetic theory and antenna design to propose a potential innovation in effective narcotic detection. High frequency structure simulator (HFSS) software was used to model and simulate antenna parameters for designing, transmitting, and receiving signals. The results aim to improve safety protocols in key locations, such as airports, cargo facilities, and public areas.

title: Lightweight Learning Chat Bot Using Sentence Embeddings for Contextual Similarity Matching
authors: Prahlad Gaitonde, Kumar Satyam, Kiran Kolavil Puleri, Krishnaraj Chadaga, Rajesh Mahadeva, Jimcymol James
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This paper presents a minimal chat bot that uses sentence embeddings to demonstrate the core concept of semantic similarity in Natural Language Processing (NLP). Its purpose is not to compete with state-of-the-art systems in performance but to serve as an illustration showing why chat bots appear to “understand” and where that illusion breaks under the weight of simple string-matching techniques. This paper examines the inadequacy of string-based matching for user intent recognition and introduced vector-based similarity as a conceptual framework for contextual relevance. It gives an educational bridge between naïve pattern matching and deeper semantic alignment.

title: Website Traffic Forecasting using Machine Learning
authors: K Vinay Kumar, Bhanu Vakiti, Boine Abhinaya, Nallathati Deepika, Sheelam Malasri, K Shruthi
abstract: The accurate prediction of website traffic needs to be achieved because it supports server optimization while enhancing user satisfaction and operation strategy development through data analysis. Server congestion issues become preventable through effective forecasting methods that reduce system downtimes and increase performance speed. SARIMA uses the Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average model for web traffic prediction by understanding data patterns with trends and cycles as well as seasonal components. The forecasting accuracy of the model gets measured through quantitative criteria consisting of Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) that combine both precision and reliability elements. A lower error measurement indicates superior predictive abilities which allow organizations to better schedule their content delivery systems and scaling operations and digital marketing initiatives. Experimental findings validate SARIMA as an appropriate method for digital platform user activity modeling because it demonstrates its value in resource planning while enhancing service delivery.

title: Sign-Based Encryption-Enabled Reliable Data Communication for Mobile Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Rahmy Rehyadd, Preeti Rani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: MANET allow wireless communication between mobile nodes that are self-configuring and infrastructure-less. As a result of their decentralised structure and dynamic topology, MANET pose major security challenges due to their high flexibility and suitability for deployment in mission-critical environments. A framework integrated with sign-based encryption (SBE) and hyperelliptic curve cryptography (HECC) is proposed to ensure reliable, secure, and efficient data transmission in MANET. We propose a trust-based routing scheme, energy-efficient clustering, and a multipath data transfer scheme using RNS and PSSS encodings. Moreover, the system makes use of Modified Discrete Particle Swarm Optimisation (MDPSO) to enhance cluster formation and reliability. A performance metric for validation is throughput, packet delivery ratio, and energy consumption. This protocol is more reliable, energy-efficient, and secure than existing protocols, making it suitable for resource-constrained and adversarial MANET.

title: Lightweight Error-Correction Code Encoders in Superconducting Electronic Systems
authors: Yerzhan Mustafa, Berker Peköz, Selçuk Köse
abstract: Data transmission from superconducting electronic circuits, such as single flux quantum (SFQ) logic, to room-temperature electronics is susceptible to bit errors, which may result from flux trapping, fabrication defects, and process parameter variations (PPV). Due to the cooling power budget at 4.2 K and constraints on the chip area, the size of the error-correction code encoders is limited. In this work, three lightweight error-correction code encoders are proposed that are based on Hamming(7,4), Hamming(8,4), and Reed-Muller(1,3) codes and implemented with SFQ logic. The performance of these encoders is analyzed in the presence of PPV. The trade-offs between the theoretical complexity and physical size of error-correction code encoders are identified.

title: An Adaptive Voltage Control Method for Z-Source and Quasi-Z-Source DC-DC Converters
authors: Shamim Mohammadsalehian, Gerry Moschopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a control strategy for a family of DC-DC quasi-Z-source converters ($\mathbf{q Z S C}$) that makes the DC bus voltage between the Z-source network and the transformer almost immune to input voltage and load variations. As renewable energy resources like solar panels become more widely used, power converters are essential to interface them with larger systems such as nano-grids and microgrids. The proposed control method, by varying the zero-voltage states of Z-source converters and implementing closed-loop control, maintains a fixed switching frequency, resulting in improved efficiency. In addition, the converter operates with fully ZVS turn-on and ZCS turn-off for all full-bridge switches. Without a fixed DC link, the converter’s design must accommodate a wide range of switching frequencies, complicating the design and control of the switches. Simulation results validate the method, demonstrating significant improvements in efficiency and stability under various conditions.

title: Clustering-Informed Retrieval-Augmented Generation for LLM-Based Log Anomaly Detection
authors: Jielun Zhang, Fuhao Li, Hongyu Wu, Venkataramani Kumar
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) empowers large language models (LLMs) to perform context-aware reasoning by retrieving relevant examples at inference time. In log anomaly detection, the quality of retrieved examples is crucial to classification accuracy, especially when the retrieval pool is constrained either due to computational limits or storage considerations. In this work, we study how different retrieval sampling strategies affect LLM performance and propose clustering-informed methods based on K-Means. Specifically, we introduce centroid-based, edge-based, and hybrid strategies that aim to enhance the semantic diversity and coverage of retrieved contexts. Extensive evaluation has been conducted on OpenStack logs using Granite3.2:8B and Mistral-Nemo:12B hosted locally. The evaluation results demonstrate our methods consistently outperform baseline methods across F1 and accuracy. Our observation also highlights the importance of retrieval structure in RAG pipelines and demonstrates the value of clustering-aware example selection for LLM-based log anomaly detection.

title: DermAI: A Deep Learning-Based Mobile Application for Multi-type Skin Cancer Detection
authors: Gobi Ramasamy, Nisha Varghese, Elangovan Sivalingam, Selvakumar Ramachandran
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: The significance of early skin cancer detection for effective prevention and treatment is underscored by the limitations of traditional manual diagnostic methods used by dermatologists. Leveraging Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and the HAM10000 dataset, this research aims to automate skin cancer classification through dermatoscopic image analysis. The primary objective of the research is an accurate classification system identifying seven specific skin cancer types. The novelty is the deployment of the classification system using a Mobile Application - DermAI. The trained CNN model, spanning 10 epochs, achieved remarkable precision, peaking at a 97.90 percentage test accuracy during the 7th epoch. Evaluation metrics like the confusion matrix confirm its reliability in categorizing lesions, minimizing misclassifications, and validating its efficiency as a diagnostic tool. Transforming the model into TensorFlow Lite format enables seamless integration into mobile platforms, optimizing computational resources. This allows users to access prompt skin cancer classification via an Android application, fostering accessibility to preliminary assessments. Early identification facilitates timely medical intervention, a crucial factor in enhancing prognosis. Through CNNs, TensorFlow Lite, and mobile deployment, this research strives to bridge technology and healthcare accessibility, empowering individuals to proactively manage their skin health based on classification results and initiate timely discussions with healthcare professionals.

title: Design of an ALU with Vedic Multiplier for Enhanced Efficiency
authors: G. Vincent Herbet, Magthelin Therase L, E. Anna Devi, R. M. Joany, G. Jegan
abstract: High-speed multiplication is an essential need in contemporary digital arithmetic, especially in domains such as digital signal processing, cryptography, and embedded systems. Conventional multipliers, i.e., array and Booth multipliers, have the disadvantage of increased latency due to sequential and intricate calculations. This paper discusses a high-performance hierarchical 8x8-bit Vedic multiplier based on the Urdhva-Tiryagbhyam sutra, which supports parallel multiplication to reduce critical path delays. The system proposed breaks down the multiplication process into 2x2 and 4x4 Vedic multiplier modules, combined with cascaded adders to compute the final 16-bit product. Verilog-based implementation uses modular, half-adder-based 2x2 units, interim 4x4 blocks, and optimized 6-bit, 8-bit, and 10-bit adders for aggregation of result efficiently. In contrast to traditional multipliers, this method includes lower latency, improved resource utilization, and enhanced scalability, which are highly amendable for FPGA/ASIC implementations. The suggested architecture improves computational efficiency, providing quicker arithmetic operations within time-sensitive digital systems.

title: A Deep Learning Approach Using a Hybrid BERT-Transformer Model for Analyzing Digital Media
authors: S. Seethalakshmi, U. Marimuthu, Anju Mohan, K.S. Alakumarimuthu
abstract: The rise of digital media has transformed the nature of political discourse in India, with satire, parody, and sarcasm becoming powerful tools for public expression. Platforms like Twitter, Instagram, Reddit, and YouTube have enabled the proliferation of user-generated content (UGC) that blends humor with political critique. This research explores the dynamic landscape of political parody in India by leveraging a Hybrid BERT-Transformer deep learning model to analyze user-generated content (UGC) from platforms such as Twitter, YouTube, Reddit, and Instagram. With the rising influence of online satire in shaping political discourse, our model aims to detect and classify satire, sarcasm, parody, and political critique within multilingual and multimodal content. A curated dataset comprising text, memes, and video transcripts was annotated and preprocessed using tokenization, translation of regional Indian languages, and sentiment labeling. The proposed Hybrid BERT-Transformer model, fine-tuned on this dataset, achieved an overall accuracy of 92.4%, outperforming baseline models such as BERT+LSTM (86.8%) and traditional SVM-based classifiers (72.1%). Evaluation metrics including F1-score (90.9%) and ROC-AUC (0.94) further validated the robustness of the model. Additionally, attention-weight-based temporal and regional analysis revealed patterns in political parody frequency aligned with major political events. This approach demonstrates the potential of deep learning for nuanced socio-political content analysis in culturally diverse contexts like India.

title: Post-Quantum Attribute-Based Encryption: a Comprehensive Survey of Lattice-Based and Hybrid Approaches
authors: Purnima, Tejaswi Khanna, Deepak Kumar Verma
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: With quantum computing, traditional methods of encryption have become insufficient. This has led to the need for a transition to more reliable and flexible encryption systems. In this context, we examine the latest approaches to attribute-based encryption ABE schemes based on lattice cryptography and hybrid ones that combine symmetric encryption with public key ABE. These systems give post-quantum security in addition to fine-grained control, adaptive policy dynamic enforcement, and multi-level hierarchical control. We examine the most significant gaps regarding revocation, multi-authority frameworks, and ciphertext-controlled policies using LWE and Ring-LWE. Text length, key management complexity, and system interoperability are practical concerns too. A comparative analysis of five schemes shows each one's strengths and weaknesses. Designating the encryption phase speeds up the key generation process, so we implemented a multithreaded structure to address some of the identified performance constraints. This worked with other researchers designing robust quantum-access-controlled systems.

title: Comparing the Benefits of a Bio-Inspired Hardware Vs. GPU for a Self-Manuvering Task
authors: Matthew Kinnison, Jamison Colter, Stephen Schlager, Steven Harbour
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: John von Neumann computing architectures impose SWaP (size, weight, and power) restrictions on unmanned systems performing autonomous navigation. This paper explores the use of neuromorphic hardware to execute compute-intensive self-maneuvering tasks with dramatically lower power and thermal budgets. Using a CNN-SNN model on the BrainChip Akida 1500 processor, we demonstrate real-time control of a lightweight ground vehicle and compare performance, latency, and power efficiency to a GPU baseline. Our research shows support for our hypothesis, however our experiment could not have been completed within the timeframe of this publication.

title: Quantifying and Mitigating Bias in GPT-Based Language Models
authors: Joy Vashisht, Manisha Vashisht
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) such as OpenAI's GPT -4 have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in generating human-like text across diverse contexts. However, their widespread adoption has raised critical concerns around inherent biases present in the generated content, especially those related to gender, race, and profession. This paper investigates the presence and nature of bias in responses generated by GPT-4 through controlled prompt testing. We introduce a prompt pair generation methodology that varies only on identity-specific variables and assess the outputs of the model on semantic similarity, polarity of sentiment, and embedding-level discrepancy measures. We carry out experiments on 100+ prompt variations using Python and OpenAI's API and find discernible patterns for word associations and tone changes. In addition, the paper delves into lightweight mitigation techniques through rephrased prompts, system role setting, and output post-processing. Our work emphasizes that while GPT -4 shows diminished bias compared to its earlier ancestors, quantifiable differences persist in role-specific and stereotype-aware settings. Our contribution is an open, replicable bias-detection framework, alongside actionable feedback to researchers and practitioners seeking to leverage LLMs responsibly within sensitive fields like health, law, and education.

title: Modelling and Optimization of Electric Vehicle Performances
authors: Hichem Mabrouki, Benbey Rachid, Mohsen Ben Ammar, Slah Farhani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The modelling of an electric vehicle using mathematical equations is a key process for optimizing its performances. By understanding the equations governing the vehicle, it becomes easier to better characterize its behaviour and identify potential issues. This also enables precise diagnostics and helps find solutions to improve the vehicle’s efficiency. The modelling of electric vehicles aims to optimize their performances by simulating their operation using equations and algorithms. It helps to better understand their characteristics, identify potential flaws, facilitate diagnostics, and enhance their overall efficiency and reliability. Once the model is validated, artificial intelligence can be used to continuously refine and enhance the vehicle’s performance. It enables real-time energy consumption adjustments, maximizes autonomy, and optimizes overall vehicle management for maximum efficiency.

title: A 4.266 Gbps/pin LPDDR4X PHY with an Integrated RISC-V Subsystem Optimized for Large Bump Pitch in 12nm FinFET Technology
authors: Marco Mestice, Johannes Feldmann, Jan Lappas, Mohammadreza Esmaeilpour, Christian Weis, Norbert Wehn
abstract: Low Power Double Data Rate 4X (LPDDR4X) is a leading memory standard for mobile applications, delivering data rates up to 4266 Mbps with minimal power consumption. However, its low 0.6V I/O supply voltage and tight timing requirements pose significant challenges to signal integrity and synchronization. This paper presents a full LPDDR4X physical interface (PHY) in GlobalFoundries 12nm FinFET technology that addresses these issues through novel output driver calibration, digitally controlled delay lines, and de-skewing clock generators. We further incorporate On-Die Termination calibration with comparator offset compensation to ensure robust I/O performance. By integrating a RISC-V subsystem, our PHY enables low-level software control of the memory interface and a fully programmable calibration and training algorithm. The measured results from the fabricated prototype confirm the effectiveness of the proposed strategies, achieving write margins of 300mV/0.61UI at 1.6Gbps and 200mV/0.38UI at 2.133Gbps. Post-layout simulations in all Process-Voltage-Temperature corners at 4.266Gbps show instead write margins of 80mV/0.57UI and 140mV/0.72UI in worst and best corners respectively. The measured output clock amplitude at 2.133GHz is 160mV differential. These findings underscore the feasibility of a LPDDR4X PHY solution that meets stringent performance and power requirements in advanced technology nodes.

title: An AI-Driven Approach for Predicting Prakriti in Ayurvedic Healthcare Using Machine Learning
authors: Sangeeta Parshionikar, Sally Tuscano, Shine Mascarenhas, Calix Gonsalves, Archana Lopes
abstract: Ayurveda is a traditional system of medicine widely used in India, it is one of the natural ways of healing and it gives major importance for the overall wellness of a person through personalized treatment of an individual according to his or her Prakriti (body Constitution). However, conventional diagnostic approaches are mostly based on subjective judgments of clinicians, resulting in inconsistent diagnosis and treatments. In this work, we introduce an AI based Ayurvedic healthcare system powered by machine learning for automatic Prakriti classification and Dosha prediction. Our suggested model is predicting prakriti using Questionnaire based assessment. We used a Random Forest Classifier to predict the Prakriti (body type) of a person from Ayurvedic questions as taken by them. The random forest algorithm increases the stability of predictions by its combination of several decision trees as well as capturing complex patterns in the data. The model is trained on an equally proportioned and well-balanced dataset with the feature SMOTE being exploited to represent the Prakriti fairly, across all its types. This consists in data preprocessing, feature selection and model evaluation to increase accuracy of prediction. This AI-based solution has the capability to transform Ayurvedic health care more standardised and scalable. AyurWellness is a web application which includes Prakriti detection, personal health tips and recommendations, Ayurvedic home remedies, multilingual support, and nearby clinic finders. It is an initiative that connects past wisdom with current advances in technology to take holistic healthcare to users all over.

title: Time-Resolved Single-Photon Counting IC for Raman Imaging
authors: Leeladhar Bodu, Tuomo Talala, Jan Nissinen, Ilkka Nissinen
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: An <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8} \times \mathbf{2 6 0}$</tex> Time-Resolved Single-Photon Conting (TRSPC) CMOS Single Photon Avalanche Diode (SPAD) sensor with integrated Time-to-Digital Converters (TDCs) is designed as an enabling component for a conceptual flash Raman imaging setup in applications such as real-time biochemical monitoring, industrial process control, and biomedical diagnostics. The system targets <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}$</tex>-point simultaneous measurements by spatial-to-temporal conversion, where a single laser pulse excites 10 sample points and the resulting Raman signals are routed through optical fibers of different lengths. This introduces fixed 30 ns delays between sample points, enabling sequential capture of all spectra on a single SPAD array without sacrificing spectral resolution or sensor area. Multipoint imaging is driven by a 1 -to-10 pulse converter with Delay Locked Loop (DLL)-controlled delay lines, while TDCs achieve 68 ps resolution for precise Time-of-Arrival (ToA) capture. Monte Carlo simulations showed mean delays and standard deviations for the 1-to-10 converter and the TDCs to be 30.8 ns and 67.7 ps, and 35 ps and 1.4 ps, respectively. Data transfer via FPGA to a PC, and digital time gating are planned to suppress fluorescence and improve SNR. The architecture offers high-throughput, fluorescencereduced Raman spectroscopy and is scalable to larger arrays for rapid, real-time imaging.

title: Limits of Large Language Models in Map Navigation and Spatial Reasoning
authors: Tomasz Les, Bartosz Sawicki
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: Although Large Language Models (LLMs) have recently shown promise in various tasks, they often struggle with problems that require consistent map reading skills and spatial reasoning. In this study, we evaluate the performance of models on both text-encoded labyrinths and simplified graphic maps. For text-based mazes, we compare full reasoning with step-by-step control and demonstrate that the latter achieves almost the same level of accuracy for small and medium maps, while significantly reducing both runtime and token usage. For graphic maps, we conducted controlled experiments on intersections, systematically varying map colours, point placements and prompt formulations. The results show that accuracy depends not only on model size (GPT-5 outperforms GPT-4o and GPT-4.1, with higher computational cost), but also on map design and prompt clarity. Higher visual contrast and human-inspired prompt extensions improve performance. These findings emphasise the cognitive similarities between humans and LLMs in spatial tasks, as well as the ongoing challenges in achieving robust navigation.

title: Cycle-Accurate ML-Based Power Modeling for RISC-V Cores Using RTL Simulations
authors: Mekala Bindu Bhargavi, Rachakonda Komal Nayan, Sri Parameswaran, Soumya J
abstract: Accurate and early-stage power modeling is critical for energy-aware design in modern processors, especially those based on the open-source RISC-V architecture. This work introduces a scalable and interpretable machine learning-based power modeling framework that enables cycle-accurate estimation at the microarchitectural level using RTL simulation data. Targeting an in-order 32-bit RISC-V core derived from the RI5CY architecture, the framework leverages switching activity traces from Verilator simulations to train lightweight decision tree regressors capable of predicting dynamic power with high fidelity. The proposed design pipeline includes structured feature extraction (e.g., toggle counts, Hamming distances) and hierarchical modeling across processor blocks such as Fetch, Decode, Execute, and Load Store (LS) Unit. Compared to state-of-the-art approaches, the proposed model achieves a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 2.06% at the full-core level, significantly outperforming prior works while reducing simulation overhead. Experimental results over ten diverse benchmarks demonstrate improved cycle efficiency, enhanced model generalization, and interpretability. These findings establish a practical pathway for integrating fast, explainable, and RTL-aligned power prediction models in early-stage RISC-V processor design workflows, bridging the gap between architectural exploration and physical power estimation.

title: A Comparative Study of Alzheimer Detection Techniques using Machine Learning and Deep Learning
authors: Donia Ammous, Ameni Dami, Yassine Ben Ayed, Fahmi Kammoun, Nouri Masmoudi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The efficacy of Deep Learning (DL) and Machine Learning (ML) techniques in identifying Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is examined in this comparative study. Through a comprehensive analysis of multiple studies utilizing diverse methodologies, datasets, and evaluation criteria, we highlight the potential of computational methods in enhancing early diagnosis and management of AD. Our findings underscore the critical role of factors such as dataset selection, model architecture, and performance metrics in advancing AD detection strategies. By providing standardized evaluation and comparison, our study offers valuable insights to guide future research and development in this crucial domain of neurodegenerative disease detection.

title: Deep Learning for Viral Genome Classification: A Comparative Analysis of LSTM and BERT Models
authors: D S Vaishali, Sanjay Raju, Chaitra Srikumar, Anchal Kumari, Biswajit Bhowmik
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: The COVID-19 crisis emphasizes the essential role of accurate viral genome identification in guiding effective public health measures and therapeutic decisions. This paper presents a comparative analysis of deep learning (DL) models, specifically Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and BERT-based transformers-for classifying genomic sequences of HIV and SARS-CoV-2. Leveraging the sequential nature of DNA data, LSTM effectively captures long-range dependencies, while BERT utilizes contextual embeddings. Experimental results show that LSTM achieves $\mathbf{9 0. 0 0}$ % accuracy, significantly outperforming the BERT-based model at $\mathbf{5 0. 5 \%}$. Evaluated on a diverse dataset, LSTM demonstrates superior recall, F1 score, and precision, indicating its robustness in detecting genetic variations. These findings suggest that while transformer-based models like BERT excel in NLP, sequence-based architectures such as LSTM are better suited for genomic classification. The results contribute to advancing artificial intelligence applications genomics, with significant implications for viral diagnostics, outbreak monitoring, and precision medicine.

title: A Computational Perspective on Cryptographic Models Using Prime Cordial Labeling
authors: Bansari Rayjada, Mahadityasinh Sarvaiya, Jekil Gadhiya
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This study proposes a new encryption strategy based on Hypercube graphs to improve cybersecurity using more modern methodologies. Due to their multi- dimensional nature, Hypercube graphs are suitable for the configuration of data encoding and encryption. The proposed idea applies Prime Cordial labeling for internode connection modeling which enhances the cryptographic complexity. Automation of the encryption sequence is achieved through the application of Row Echelon form which streamlines data processing. Further, application of some non-linear functions like exponential and floor functions increases resistance to brute force and cryptanalysis attacks. Some Modular operations are employed to hide the data sequence structure with repeating moduli enhancing disguise. The idea of combining graph labeling techniques with some sophisticated mathematical tools provides an additional layer of security as compared to the traditional alternatives. This Study focuses on demonstrating the new approach and its potency for solving problems within the cybersecurity scope while fostering the development of new secure communication channels and more advanced cryptographic instruments.

title: VGG16-Based Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Furcation Involvement Detection with Early and Late Fusion Techniques
authors: Raj Gaurang Tiwari, Tadiwa Elisha Nyamasvisva, Nurazim Ibrahim, Amit Garg, Ambuj Kumar Agarwal, Naresh Kumar Trivedi
abstract: Accurate and efficient detection of furcation involvement in dental X-ray images is crucial for timely diagnosis and treatment planning of periodontal disease. Current methods often rely on manual assessment, which is time-consuming, subjective, and prone to inter-observer variability. This research proposes a novel approach to automated furcation involvement detection using a hybrid deep learning model that combines the strengths of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Support Vector Machines (SVMs). The proposed methodology leverages the VGG16 architecture, a pre-trained CNN known for its robust feature extraction capabilities in image classification tasks. To enhance the model’s performance and address the limitations of relying solely on a CNN, SVM classifier is incorporated within a hybrid deep learning framework. Two fusion strategies are explored: early fusion, where the features extracted from the VGG16 fully connected layer are directly concatenated with the SVM; and late fusion, where the outputs of the VGG16 softmax layer and the SVM are combined. This comparative approach allows us to assess the effectiveness of each fusion technique in improving furcation detection accuracy. To assess model performance, 10-fold cross-validation is used, which reduces bias and offers a credible estimate of generalization performance. The models' diagnostic skills are assessed using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. For furcation identification, the hybrid deep learning strategy outperformed the VGG16 model in the testing. Adding the SVM classifier earlier in the feature processing pipeline improves performance, as the early fusion technique consistently beats the late one. These results demonstrate the SVM’s capacity to learn complicated decision boundaries and enhance classification accuracy in this application. The best model, based on early fusion and the SVM classifier, has 91.24% accuracy, 90.9% precision, 93.04% recall, and 91.52% F1-score. This shows that our hybrid deep learning strategy can accurately and efficiently detect furcation involvement in dental X-ray images. This automated method potentially helps doctors diagnose and treat periodontal disease early, increasing patient outcomes.

title: IoT-Based Plant-Watering Robot for Greenhouse Seedling Cultivation
authors: Putra Harapan Nazara, Arief Ika Uktoro, Teddy Suparyanto, Advendio Desandros, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Efficient and evenly distributed irrigation is a crucial factor in greenhouse seedling cultivation. However, conventional sprayers utilization is often associated with water wastage and uneven water distribution. In this study, an IoTbased automatic plant-watering robot was designed and developed, which controllable via Arduino Cloud and equipped with an automatic push button to enhance operational flexibility. The robot development was performed using prototype-based design approach. The robot was built using an ESP32 as the main microcontroller, a 12 V water pump, an L298N motor driver, and a push button used as a motion limit sensor. The results demonstrated that water usage was more efficient with the watering robot, achieving savings of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 1. 6 7 \%}$</tex> compared to the conventional sprayer method. The watering process performed by the robot was proven to be more controlled and evenly distributed, although slightly higher moisture levels were observed in the center area compared to the left and right sides. In the watering time evaluation, 2 minutes were required by the robot to match the volume of water dispensed by the sprayer in 1 minute, due to the intermittent watering pattern employed by the robot. These findings highlight potential application of the proposed technology in greenhouse seedling cultivation, thus promoting better trade-off between sustainability and economic benefits in the agriculture sector.

title: A Sensor-Integrated System for Multi-Disaster Prediction Using Fuzzy Logic and Decision Tree Algorithms
authors: N P Shafinaz, P K Harsha, P Shahana Shahin, K P Shahma, V Laila, K Jitha
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: A sensor-integrated framework for multi-disaster prediction using machine learning provides a vital system to predict disasters. The early warning alert system is based on the Arduino Uno microcontroller. There are three different sensors integrated together to collect data from the environment. A Soil Moisture Sensor measures the water content in the soil and provides alerts at low, medium, and high warning levels. Along with this, a Water Level Sensor and Vibration Sensor are integrated to detect flood levels and movements of the Earth’s surface, respectively. The data from these sensors are collected and evaluated using Fuzzy Logic and rule-based algorithms. In addition to disaster detection, the system incorporates a Dash-board Monitoring Module, implemented using Python, to store and visualize real-time sensor data for up to seven days. This feature provides disaster management administrators with a user-friendly interface to analyze environmental trends, refine predictive models, and improve response strategies. By offering historical data insights, the dashboard ensures better disaster preparedness and informed decision-making. The main objective of this system is to diligently scrutinize the intensity of the disaster and prompt alerts. Besides, the system also ensures the community engagement of locals to take part in disaster preparedness. The overall flexibility, along with lower production costs, makes the system more reliable and accessible.

title: Fault-Tolerant Character Recognition in Neuromorphic Systems Using RRAM Crossbar Arrays
authors: Fatemeh Shirinzadeh, Abhoy Kole, Kamalika Datta, Saeideh Shirinzadeh, Rolf Drechsler
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Resistive Random-Access Memory (RRAM) crossbar arrays provide a high-density, low-power platform for neuromorphic computing. In this work, we implement an RRAM-based architecture for alphabet recognition using the EMNIST dataset, where all 26 English letters are represented as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28 \times 28$</tex> binary images. Beyond ideal conditions, we study the impact of hardware imperfections, including stuck-at faults, random bit flips, and process variations, on recognition performance. To improve resilience, we evaluate two fault tolerance strategies: Triple Modular Redundancy (TMR) and Algorithm-Based Fault Tolerance (ABFT). TMR delivers strong reliability by masking faults through replication, while ABFT efficiently detects and corrects at a lower storage overhead, but at a higher computational cost. Our results demonstrate that RRAM crossbars combined with lightweight fault tolerance provide accurate, energy-efficient, and resilient neuromorphic computing, highlighting their promise for robust and efficient edge AI deployment.

title: The Case for Crowd-Sourcing Communication to BLE-Only Devices
authors: Alex Bellon, Tess Despres, Prabal Dutta, Pat Pannuto, Sylvia Ratnasamy
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: With the widespread deployment of Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) enabled devices, we are moving towards a world full of distributed, resource-constrained devices. With this growth comes the challenge of maintaining and communicating with millions of intermittently connected low-power BLE devices. While sending data from these BLE devices back to central servers has successfully been realized at scale (e.g. Apple AirTags), downlink communication is more difficult. Given the common usage of BLE-only devices in public infrastructure and other safety-critical environments, this inability to communicate with devices in a timely manner poses a barrier to realizing safe and secure ubiquitous computing. We explore the design space of providing downlink connectivity to BLE-only devices, give an overview of the challenges, and propose a system to enable downlink BLE communication.

title: Faster-than-light coordination for networked systems with quantum non-local games
authors: Venkat Arun, Vijay Chidambaram, Scott Aaronson
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: Many networked systems rely on hashing and randomized algorithms for tasks such as load balancing, thereby avoiding the need for coordination or communication among participants on each request. However, purely random routing can lead to collisions and missed opportunities for beneficial colocation. Quantum entanglement enables participants to instantly make correlated decisions without communicating. We explore how this capability can expand the Pareto frontier of achievable performance in networked systems, presenting both positive and negative results. Notably, many of these advantages can be realized using small, currently available quantum devices that can often operate at room temperature.

title: "I Apologize For Not Understanding Your Policy": Exploring the Evaluation of User-Managed Access Control Policies by AI Virtual Assistants
authors: Jennifer Mondragon, Gael Cruz, Carlos Rubio-Medrano, Dvijesh Shastri
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 Workshop on Human-Centered AI Privacy and Security
abstract: The rapid evolution of Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based Virtual Assistants (VAs), e.g., Google Gemini, ChatGPT, Microsoft Copilot, and High-Flyer Deepseek, has turned them into convenient interfaces for managing emerging technologies such as Smart Homes, Smart Cars, and Electronic Health Records. By leveraging explicit commands, e.g., prompts, which can be even launched via voice, VAs provide a very natural interface for end-users. However, the proper specification and evaluation of User-Managed Access Control Policies (U-MAPs), the rules issued and managed by end-users to govern access to sensitive data and device functionality within these VAs, presents significant challenges as this process is crucial for preventing security vulnerabilities and privacy leaks without impacting user experience. This work-in-progress study provides an initial exploratory investigation on whether current publicly-available VAs can manage U-MAPs effectively across differing scenarios. By conducting unstructured to structured tests, we evaluated the comprehension of such VAs, revealing a lack of understanding in varying U-MAP approaches. Our research not only identifies key limitations, but offers valuable insights into how VAs can be further improved to manage complex authorization rules and adapt to dynamic changes.
