Despite progress in hardware design tools, deploying applications on these platforms still requires extensive manual effort across multiple stages-operating system integration, runtime configuration, and software framework adaptation. The original Kria Robotics Stack (KRS) partially alleviated this problem by integrating the Vitis Unified Flow into the Robot Operating System to ease the development of robotics applications. The solution is more proof-of-concept, with hidden, fixed configurations enabling reproducible builds of finalized systems. However, support for changing requirements during development is limited, resulting in low productivity. This work proposes KRS Unleashed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{1}$</tex>, an architectural redesign of KRS. By reducing dependencies and modularizing the framework into three separate workspaces, it improves productivity and fosters a parallel development workflow. Further extensions for the operating system and high-level synthesis development have been realized to provide an SDSoClike development experience for System-on-Chips, supporting integration beyond robotics through standard toolchains and extensible, modular components. Case studies for matrix multiplication and the AprilTag algorithm showcase productivity gains by reducing continuous overall build times during development by up to a factor of 80 by employing reusable intermediary artifacts.

title: Comparative Study of Classification Algorithms with Application to Stroke Diagnosis
authors: Imen Degnich, Anis Messaoud
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Early and accurate prediction of cerebral vascular accidents (CVA) is essential for timely intervention and improving patient outcomes. This study investigates various classification algorithms to predict stroke. Recent advances in machine learning have shown great potential in helping with medical analysis and disease prediction. Methods including Logistic Regression, Decision Trees, KNN, Random Forests, Naive Bayes, and SVM are integrated to a medical database to evaluate their performance. Deep learning was not considered, as the dataset is small and structured; traditional machine learning models were more suitable and effective. Among these methods, SVM and Logistic Regression achieved the highest accuracy compared to others. However, after applying Principal Component Analysis (PCA), the Decision Tree algorithm provided the best accuracy.

title: A Systematic Review of Artificial Intelligence Techniques for Enhancing Search Engine Optimization
authors: Abhishek Teraiya, Haresh D. Khachariya
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) transforms search engine optimization (SEO) by enabling precise, efficient, and user-centric strategies. Using the PRISMA framework, this systematic review evaluates AI techniques—natural language processing (NLP), machine learning (ML), generative AI, random neural networks (RNNs), and others—for SEO enhancement. We compare their impact based on different parameters like ranking, click-through rate (CTR), efficiency, engagement, scalability, adoption, user satisfaction, and computational cost across on-page and off- page SEO. Findings reveal that NLP's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-40 \%$</tex> relevance boost, generative AI's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 0 - 7 0 \%}$</tex> time savings, and ML's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2 0 - 2 5 \%}$</tex> ac- curacy gains, with having trade-offs in ethics and complexity. Performance is shown on line, area, scatter, and radar maps. This paper highlights AI's SEO possibilities and guides future paths for multi-modal, ethical and inclusive solutions which direct practitioners. This review underscores AI's SEO potential and charts future directions for multi-modal, ethical, and inclusive solutions.

title: User-Based Collaborative Filtering for Rating Predictions: A Memory-Based Approach Using Movielens 100K Dataset
authors: Annaura Zyra Alifa Windutomo, Athia Zahra, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan, Jeffrey Junior Tedjasulaksana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Recommendation systems significantly enhance user experiences by providing personalized suggestions on digital platforms. This study investigates User-Based Collaborative Filtering (UBCF), a memorybased technique for rating predictions in movie recommendation systems, utilizing the MovieLens 100 k dataset. The research addresses key challenges, including the cold-start problem and scalability issues. The methodology comprises data preprocessing, similarity computation using statistical techniques, and performance evaluation through quantitative metrics such as Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). The experimental results demonstrate that UBCF achieves reliable rating predictions with a MAE of 0.743 and an RMSE of 0.927, highlighting its effectiveness in delivering accurate recommendations. However, limitations remain, particularly concerning scalability and the cold-start problem. Future work will focus on integrating hybrid models and advanced optimization methods to improve performance and address these challenges comprehensively.

title: Extended Approach for Soil and Crop Prediction Using Deep Learning
authors: B Narasimha Rao, Suman Polaki, B Satyanarayana Murthy, GVS Narayana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Traditional soil analysis methods can be time-consuming and may not provide real-time insights. This paper introduces a deep learning-based approach for soil type classification and crop recommendation, enhancing efficiency and accuracy. Utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), the system analyzes soil images to identify distinct characteristics and classify soil types. Based on the detected soil type, it further suggests suitable crops. Designed as a user-friendly application for both web and mobile platforms, the system allows users to upload soil images and receive instant classification results along with crop recommendations. The paper's success will be evaluated through classification accuracy, the relevance of crop suggestions, and user feedback on usability and effectiveness.

title: Integration of traditional control and neural networks for a water quality monitoring system
authors: Karla Yohana Sánchez Mojica, Carlos Eduardo Gómez Rodríguez, Luis Asunción Pèrez Domínguez
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: This work analyzes a water quality control system through the Composite Water Quality Index (WQI), internationally known as the Water Quality Index (WQI), using the integration of a traditional PID control and an MLP neural network. The system includes the installation of sensors and data capture to subsequently train the neural network, then the controller is calculated and simulated so that its output becomes the network input and a control is generated together that allows maintaining water quality at a setpoint of $90 \%$. The main results show that the integration is successful and a robust system is generated to maintain water quality based on the optimal values and range of the input variables (PH, turbidity, and apparent chlorine). A good coupling of the MLP with the PID is evident, and a good strategy is established to be implemented as an automated control tool, ensuring that water quality is maintained within the desired standards without the need for constant manual intervention, optimizing resources and improving the sustainability of the system.

title: Overview of the Application of Generative AI in Software Performance Testing
authors: Alina Verkholomova, Erika Nazaruka
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools and Large Language Models (LLMs) were integrated into all stages of the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC), influencing requirements gathering and analysis, design and planning, development, testing, deployment, maintenance and support, and documentation. Meanwhile, software performance testing is an essential type of software testing that ensures stable software behavior under various scenarios. This paper aims to point out the most common approaches in integrating Generative AI across the stages of software performance testing and in related software testing activities, as well as the main challenges and limitations faced by researchers. This research followed the systematic literature review approach to analyze and synthesize the existing studies on the application of Generative AI in software performance testing. Within the review, eight papers published between 2024 and 2025 in research literature databases, including ScienceDirect, SpringerLink, IEEE Xplore, and Google Scholar, were selected and analyzed. The review results reveal that the application of Generative AI is mainly concentrated in functional testing, specifically in test case generation, with a limited adoption in test scenario generation and capturing non-functional requirements. Key challenges identified include the inconsistency of generated output and hallucinations of LLMs. The findings indicate a significant research gap in applying Generative AI in the process of software performance testing.

title: AI-Driven and Time Series Approaches for Accurate Stock Market Price Forecasting
authors: Sridhar Udayakumar, E. Anbalagan
abstract: Gaining insight into the future and forecasting data and graph trends is one of the top concerns of stock market investors with the goal to make the best decisions and plans for the future. Although making accurate market predictions is difficult, a number of academics in this subject have tried to solve this problem by presenting a variety of concepts, approaches, and studies. High volatility, non-stationarity, and nonlinearity are some of the characteristics of financial time series data that have created challenges and compelled researchers to constantly seek for new and more precise models for analysis This study examined a number of time-series and AI-based stock market price prediction algorithms. The NSE and Bloomberg dataset are considered for evaluation. These data are initially evaluated by using a time series algorithms called ARIMA, SARIMA, BVAR and E-GACH. Then several ML approaches such as RF, RNN, FNN and GNB are employed for evaluation. Further, Hybrid algorithms are developed for stock price prediction. LSTM-GA, BST-LSTM, ABC-ANFIS-SVM and HyRNN some hybrid approaches utilized here for comparison. These comparison shows that the ARIMA, GNB and ABC-ANFIS-SVM has better results as 92.2% NPV, 89% accuracy and 0.01 of MSE than other algorithms which are used for comparison.

title: Enhancing Power Grid Efficiency with Machine Learning for Climate Change Mitigation
authors: Urvi Shah, Simran Kumari, Sasmita Das, Ronak Doshi, Krunal Vaghela, Vaibhav Matalia
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: An efficient power system is required for the accurate prediction of electricity used for planning and operation. Based on real-time power consumption data from the city of New York, this research compares and examines the efficacy of various machine learning models for short-term load forecasting. Machine learning models included to have the XGBoost Regressor, Random Forest, XGBoost, Decision Tree, and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network. Model performance was assessed through common error measurements that capture average absolute deviation, squared differences, and relative percentage errors. XGBoost Regressor was the model with the highest accuracy, with the lowest rate of error and the highest R2 score of 0.9987. It consistently outperform all other models. Conversely, the LSTM model had many more error measures, and it states that it is only useful to a limited extent in this context, without further tuning or hybridization. Results emphasize the utility of tree-based models in composed time-series data management for load forecasts and applications.

title: SmartDrive: A Low-Cost, Edge AI-Powered Advanced Driver Assistance System for Emerging Markets
authors: Ninad Lomte, Kshitij Palshikar, Satwik Wakankar, Sacchit Kholkute, Sumitra N. Motade
abstract: SmartDrive is a compact and cost-effective Advanced Driver Assistance System (ADAS) developed using the Raspberry Pi 4B. By integrating real-time object detection via YOLOv8, ultrasonic distance sensing, and GPS-based tracking, the system aims to enhance vehicular safety in complex and crowded traffic environments. A live dashboard visualizes camera feeds, sensor data, and system events, while actuator-controlled brake mechanisms are employed to simulate autonomous responses. SmartDrive is tailored for real-world Indian roads, highlighting the convergence of edge AI and embedded systems to promote safer, smarter mobility for everyday users.

title: Enhanced Heart Disease Prediction through Statistical Feature Engineering and Hybrid Ensemble Strategies with Machine Learning Models
authors: Phani Surya Kumar Lanka
abstract: Heart disease remains one of the leading causes of death globally, highlighting the need for accurate prediction models to support early diagnosis and effective treatment planning. This paper presents a hybrid framework for heart disease prediction that combines advanced feature engineering with multiple machine learning and ensemble techniques. Initially, three classifiers were evaluated, and based on encouraging results, the framework was extended to include seven base models: Random Forest, XGBoost, SVM, Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, KNN, and Naïve Bayes. A comprehensive feature engineering process was implemented using statistical transformations, interaction terms, and tree-based embeddings, followed by recursive feature elimination for optimal feature selection. Two ensemble strategies—stacking and voting—were applied to combine base model outputs. The stacking ensemble achieved best accuracy of 98%, significantly outperforming individual models. Experimental results confirm that the proposed approach offers a robust and scalable solution for heart disease prediction using clinical datasets.

title: Research and Application of Data Mining and Prediction Algorithms for Connected Vehicles
authors: Lu Zhang
abstract: The efficient utilization of massive spatiotemporal data in the context of the Internet of Vehicles is the core challenge for accurate prediction and dynamic control of intelligent transportation systems. In response to the spatiotemporal coupling characteristics and data privacy requirements of traffic flow, this study proposes a vehicle networking data mining and prediction framework that integrates multi-source data preprocessing, spatiotemporal joint modeling, and privacy protection. Using D-S evidence theory and DBSCAN density clustering to clean raw GPS data and identify high-frequency parking spots, a 27 dimensional feature vector is constructed that includes temporal statistics, road network topology, and POI semantics; Design a GNN-LSTM hybrid model that utilizes graph neural networks (GNN) to capture spatial dependencies in road networks, combines long short-term memory networks (LSTM) to model temporal dynamics, and introduces attention mechanisms to optimize spatiotemporal weight allocation. The experiment was validated based on a real vehicle networking dataset, and the results showed that the average absolute error (MAE) of the model in the morning rush hour scenario of a single road segment was 45.3 veh/h, which was 27.0% lower than the traditional LSTM model; The average absolute percentage error (MAPE) of regional road network prediction is 9.8%, a significant improvement of 23.7%. In addition, by optimizing model parameters through genetic algorithms and integrating partial homomorphic encryption techniques, the error amplification caused by privacy protection is controlled within 4.3% while ensuring prediction accuracy. The research results provide efficient and safe technical solutions for applications such as dynamic path guidance and congestion warning in the Internet of Vehicles, which is of great significance for improving the utilization of transportation resources and travel efficiency.

title: A Review on Digital Forensic Frameworks for Investigating Dark Web-Based Cyber Espionage
authors: Hansa Vaghela, Rachit Adhvaryu
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Sophisticated cyber-espionage operations that compromise national security, economic interests, and individuals' privacy have found shelter in the Dark Web. Successful studies on efforts to counter cyber espionage need to be sophisticated digital forensic systems that can counter the unique challenges of the Dark Web's anonymity and encryption. In this paper, existing forensic techniques, tools, and frameworks that seek to investigate cyber espionage based on the dark web are critically analyzed. We present significant issues such as evidence collection, chain of custody, attribution, and admissibility in court. We also present enhancements to existing systems, with an emphasis on incorporating the latest technological advances to make them reliable, accurate, and effective in cybercrime investigations. Our recommendations are meant to strengthen digital forensic tools and enable effective law enforcement and intelligence against cybercrime.

title: Machine Learning-Based Dynamic Load Balancing for Google Cluster Workload Traces in Cloud Networks
authors: Ravi Sankar Susarla
abstract: The optimal utilization of resources and state-of-the-art performance in cloud computing are fundamentally dependent on using dynamic load balancing techniques. This study presents a machine learning-based dynamic load balancing framework utilizing the Google 2019 Cluster Sample dataset to enhance resource allocation in cloud networks. High-performance predictions of CPU utilization were achieved through the use of Machine Learning techniques such as Random Forest Regressor and XGBoost, which produced R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values of 0.9999 and 0.9998 for each model. Load balancing decisions were derived dynamically based on predicted CPU loads compared to a defined threshold, demonstrating the system's ability to assess and maintain balance without unnecessary migrations. Additionally, K-Means clustering was applied for workload characterization, achieving a silhouette score of 0.137 across eight clusters. The performance of the proposed RF and XGBoost methodologies was examined relative to sophisticated models including LSTM, ARIMA, BI-LSTM-LSTM-GRU, and Bayesian Neural Networks (BNN), thereby showing the efficacy of the proposed methodologies with superior accuracy and speed in dynamic cloud resource management. This integrated framework not only reduces computational overhead but also outperforms traditional models in scalability and real-time applicability for modern cloud infrastructures. Future work aims to integrate reinforcement learning and adaptive scheduling for improved autonomy and scalability in real-time, distributed, and edge cloud environments.

title: ATAS-HM: Adaptive Task Allocation for Real-Time Tasks on Heterogeneous Multicore Systems
authors: Arthur Nathaniel Mwang'onda, Diana Goehringer
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: The increasing complexity of real-time applications on heterogeneous multicore systems presents significant challenges in meeting both performance and energy constraints. Existing task allocation methods often rely on static or simulation-based approaches that lack runtime adaptability and hardware validation. In this work, we present Adaptive Task Allocation Strategy (ATAS-HM), which combines offline Worst-Case Execution Time (WCET) profiling with runtime feedback-based reallocation to assign periodic real-time tasks across heterogeneous cores dynamically. Implemented on a Xilinx Zynq UltraScale+ MPSoC, ATAS-HM achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.3 \times$</tex> faster response times compared to the State-of-the-art strategy and up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \times$</tex> lower energy consumption compared to baseline methods. These results demonstrate the practical effectiveness of ATAS-HM for energy-aware, real-time task scheduling in heterogeneous embedded systems.

title: Comparative Analysis of Human-Designed vs AI-Generated USB4 Logical Layer: RTL Design and Verification
authors: Ali Ahmed Hassan, Karim Samy, Ahmed Zakaria, Ahmed Tarek, Walid Salah, Sief Hamdy Fadda, Hager Walid, Mohamed Salah Soliman
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has revolutionized the way software engineers go by their day-to-day coding tasks. However, AI impact on hardware design and verification is still a territory that is yet to be thoroughly explored [1]. While there are some research papers that explore the significant advancements in AI-driven hardware designs [2], there is a lack of comparative studies that focus specifically on how these designs compare to hardware designs fully designed by expert human engineers. For this reason, this paper presents a detailed comparative analysis between human-written and AI-generated RTL by designing and verifying the USB4 Logical Layer, an integral part of the latest USB Protocol [3]. The complexity and the lack of publicly available USB4 architectures ensures that the used AI tools are fully relying on their own generative capabilities to produce good quality RTL without the usage of any public implementations which further solidifies the outcomes of this paper. The preliminary results indicate that AI-generated designs can significantly reduce design time while maintaining high levels of accuracy. Based on the findings, the research offers practical guidelines for integrating AI into the RTL design process. These include best practices for leveraging AI tools and common pitfalls to avoid.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Models for Log-Based-Anomaly-Detection in Cloud Environments
authors: Sharie R. Nath, Sudan Jha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: log-based-anomaly-detection is crucial for maintaining the security and reliability of cloud environments. This study conducts a comparative analysis of advanced machine learning models to detect anomalies in structured log data. The study follows an experimental methodology involving data pre-processing, feature engineering, model training, and performance evaluation using standard metrics. To address class imbalance, the SMOTE oversampling technique is applied. Key models, including XGBoost, Random Forest, Isolation Forest, and Neural Networks, are evaluated based on their computational and performance efficiency using the BGL dataset. Among these, XGBoost with SMOTE oversampling emerged as the most effective, achieving high precision, recall, and scalability while minimizing false alarms. The study also highlights the challenges of log-anomaly-detection, including class imbalance, dataset generalization, and the trade-off between detection accuracy and computational cost. By balancing class distribution and integrating hyperparameter tuning, this research provides insights into optimizing log-based-anomaly-detection for real-time cybersecurity applications. Future work will focus on integrating User and Entity Behavior Analytics (UEBA) techniques to enhance anomaly detection across diverse cloud environments.

title: A Review of Using Chatbots and AI in Fintech for Marketing Strategies
authors: Hassan Ali Al-Ababneh, Raed Walid Al-Smadi, Ahmad Abdel Rahim Almestarehi, Salem A.S. Alrhaimi, Amin Khalifeh, Farah Hanna Zawaideh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The purpose of the article is to argue the role of chatbots and artificial intelligence in the fintech sector to optimize marketing strategies. Modern technologies are changing the approach to interaction with clients, allowing financial companies to use innovative solutions to increase marketing efficiency and improve customer service. Chatbots operating on the basis of artificial intelligence technologies provide personalized service, automate the consulting process, help resolve user requests in real time and significantly increase customer satisfaction. Artificial intelligence technologies, in turn, allow you to analyze large amounts of data, identify user behavior and preferences, which makes it possible to create more accurate marketing strategies, predict trends and set up targeted advertising campaigns. The key aspects of the implementation of these technologies are substantiated, including improving customer experience, increasing the efficiency of interaction and reducing operating costs. The key issues related to the ethical aspects of data use and compliance with legislation in the field of personal information protection are substantiated. The importance of comprehensive integration of technologies into business processes is conveyed in order to achieve maximum results in the marketing strategies of fintech companies.

title: Efficient Prompt Design for Resource-Constrained Deployment of Local LLMs
authors: Aisvarya Adeseye, Jouni Isoaho, Seppo Virtanen, Mohammad Tahir
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: The local deployment of Large Language Models (LLMs) is essential for privacy and latency in several domains. However, it faces significant challenges in terms of memory, power, and inference speed, particularly in resource-constrained systems such as Internet of Things (IoT) and edge computing devices. Most existing studies emphasize compression and hardware tuning, while holistic system-level optimization remains incomplete, and the role of prompt design is still underexplored. This study introduces a structured evaluation of prompt engineering strategies designed to enhance resource efficiency and accuracy in local LLMs, applied across three textual analysis tasks: theme extraction, frequency analysis, and impact analysis. Four experimental conditions were compared: Baseline, System Prompt Only (SP), User Prompt Only (UP), and System+User Prompt (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S P+U P$</tex>). Using multiple LLMs ranging from 1 B to 70B parameters, we audited tokens generated, latency, VRAM usage, hallucination rates, and other structural errors. The results show that System Prompts alone substantially reduced computational overhead, whereas User Prompts improved accuracy and task alignment. Their combination yields comprehensive improvements, maximizing both efficiency and reliability. The proposed prompt design enabled smaller LLMs to rival larger ones in efficiency and accuracy, with LLaMA-3.2, 3B with SP+UP reducing VRAM by 96%, latency by 85%, and hallucinations by 83% when compared to the 70B with Baseline. Even LLaMA-3.2, 1B proved to be a viable option, especially when VRAM size is a critical factor.

title: The Role of AI in Detecting and Predicting Mental Health Crises in Social Media
authors: Christabelle Nicola Immanuel, Cindyana, Vania Cyrilla, Meyliana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: As the population of digital citizens continues to grow, with more individuals spending their time online to share their state of emotions, thoughts, and personal experiences, social media has emerged to be a promising space to identify early signs of mental health crises. With the aim of leveraging the current widespread use of digital platforms such as social media as a means of self-expression, artificial intelligence (AI) technology offers a proactive approach in identifying early signs of various mental health issues, thereby enabling preventive measures to be taken before a crisis occurs. This paper explores previous research on how AI has been used to identify mental health conditions in social media platforms. Using a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) methodology, 25 studies were selected and were synthesized to identify 27 essential factors influencing AI implementation in this domain. These factors were then mapped across five types of analytics models, which include descriptive, diagnostic, predictive, prescriptive, and cognitive. The purpose of this study is to provide a systematic overview of research in the domain of AI-based mental health monitoring, mainly focusing on social media. This paper also explores how AI-powered analytics can support early detection and support meaningful interventions for mental health crises, contributing to SDG 3, particularly Target 3.4, by promoting mental wellbeing and improving access to mental health care.

title: HS-CBi-Gru: Network Attack Detection on smart devices using Hard Swish and Bi-Directional Gated Recurrent Unit with Capsule Network
authors: Milind Meshram, Suhasini Vijaykumar, Priya Chandran
abstract: This study presents a novel deep learning model using a bidirectional gated recurring unit with a capsule network, HS-CBi-Gru, a deep learning model for the detection of network attacks on smart devices. This proposed modified algorithm will be compared with existing deep learning algorithms, such as Deep Neural Networks (DNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Gated Recurrent Units (GRU), and Bi-Gated Recurrent Units (Bi-Gru), using the result parameters such as precision, recall, F-measure, accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, etc. We evaluated this model on UNS NB15 datasets to classify network attacks on smart devices. In terms of precision, recall, F-measure, accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and other metrics, the proposed model performs best. The novel HS-CBi-Gru deep learning model proposed performs much better than existing deep learning algorithms.

title: Affine Frequency Division Multiplexing With Generalized Index Modulation
authors: A Anoop, Christo Kurisummoottil Thomas, J.V. Bibal Benifa, S Kala
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This paper introduces affine frequency division multiplexing with generalized index modulation (AFDM-GIM), a novel transmission scheme enhancing spectral efficiency and reliability in high Doppler wireless environments. By enabling variable active subcarriers per subblock, it outperforms conventional fixed subcarrier methods. Generalized index modulation (GIM) dynamically encodes additional information alongside QAM symbols. Two detection methods, energy detection (ED) and log likelihood ratio (LLR) based detection, are introduced and compared, demonstrating the adaptability and robust performance of AFDM-GIM. Simulations under high mobility conditions show superior bit error rate and spectral efficiency compared to AFDM-IM and conventional AFDM, making AFDMGIM a strong candidate for future 6 G networks. Index Terms-Affine frequency division multiplexing (AFDM), Generalized index modulation (GIM), Spectral Efficiency (SE), bit error rate (BER)

title: CRISYS: A Novel AI-Driven System for Criminal Identification Using NLP and GANs
authors: Soubhagya Roy, Soumya Ranjan Mishra, Ayusha Sharma, Sayan Chattopadhyay, Devendra Mouli Bhattacharya, Debasmita Bhakat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The development of the Criminal Recognition and Identification System, or CRISYS, can be described as the most significant technological advance law enforcement technology has made so far. It can produce visual images of suspects based solely on descriptive text with the help of artificial intelligence. This paper explores a novel strategy that draws on NLP and GANs to transform complex facial characteristics from eye color and hairstyle to facial structure and unique features—to crisp image representations. We deeply consider the approach of parsing and interpreting descriptions into input images, the design of the model for generating images, and the ways the system may contribute to criminal investigations and other applications. Our results in this research highlight the potential that CRISYS has to increase investigation efficiency and precision while simultaneously emphasizing the critical need for ethical considerations and protective measure. This work falls under the burgeoning realm of AI criminal justice and offers a roadmap for developing responsible and powerful identification systems. Rigorous testing of the system revealed its capability to produce outputs that surpassed existing state-of-the-art models in terms of visual fidelity and descriptive accuracy.

title: Optimizing Cloud Storage Efficiency using Hybrid Genetic-Greedy Algorithm with Adaptive Erasure Codes
authors: Dharshana Shri P, Harini S, Abinaya S, Iyswarya R, Anitha R
abstract: The exponential growth of data has brought full-size challenges in corporation and management. Cloud computing, with its scalability and value-performance, has become critical for data availability and security. However, optimizing information placement in cloud storage stays vital; flawed business enterprise can increase expenses and degrade performance. To address this, the paper endorses a novel method that combines Adaptive Erasure Codes with a Hybrid Genetic-Greedy algorithm for most effective records placement in cloud garages. Adaptive erasure codes dynamically adjust their parameters based on factors such as access patterns, failure rates, and system load, enhancing storage efficiency and real-time performance. The hybrid set of rules integrates a genetic set of rules and a grasping set of rules, which refines these solutions via making locally optimum alternatives. The optimization process begins with a populace of data placement solutions, evaluating the usage of a fitness feature that considers facts to get entry to styles, garage charges, and redundancy desires. The grasping set of rules then pleasant-tunes these answers, ensuring fee-powerful data placement. Thus, the proposed approach improves the reliability and performance of cloud storage by achieving 93.87% efficiency in storage and data placement, surpassing the performance of other existing traditional algorithms in terms of speed, network stability, error rate and storage node health.

title: Hyperbolic-based cross-modal semantic remodeling network for zero-shot sketch-based image retrieval
authors: Qing Zhang, Jing Zhang, Xiangdong Su, Feilong Bao, Guanglai Gao
publish: ACM Transactions on Multimedia Computing, Communications, and Applications
abstract: The zero-shot sketch-based image retrieval (ZS-SBIR) task aims to retrieve images associated with sketches from unseen classes, bringing great convenience to the engineering field. To address the modality gap, most existing works project images and sketches into a shared Euclidean space. However, the hierarchical structure of image data makes the Euclidean space not the optimal choice as an embedding space for representing complex structured image data. Meanwhile, existing text and hierarchical models are not effective enough for addressing the problem of knowledge transfer. To address these issues, this paper proposes an original hyperbolic-based cross-modal semantic remodeling network (called HCMSN) for ZS-SBIR. Specifically, this paper proposes to extract category-level word embeddings based on BERT model, then align image features and sketches with the word embeddings using adversarial methods. Meanwhile, this paper further proposes a cross-modal retrieval feature reconstruction network for improving the informativeness and robustness of retrieval features. Moreover, this paper presents a feature projection network that maps the retrieval features to the hyperbolic space to generate the hyperbolic retrieval features, thus effectively representing the data with hierarchical structure. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the mAP@all of our HCMSN model surpasses CNN-based models by 20.9% on the Sketchy dataset, 1.2% on the more difficult TU-Berlin dataset, and 13.6% on the more challenging QuickDraw dataset.

title: One to Many: Closing the Bandwidth Gap in AI Datacenters with Scalable Multicast
authors: Sepehr Abdous, Jinqi Lu, Jiacheng Wan, Erfan Sharafzadeh, Ying Zhang, Soudeh Ghorbani
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: AI training now floods datacenter fabrics with thousands of simultaneous collectives, yet most frameworks still move data the hard way: O(N) unicasts for a group of N processors. Classic multicast could slash those bytes but has long been deemed unscalable: computing an optimal tree in an asymmetric Clos is NP-hard and group-specific rules quickly exhaust switch TCAM.

title: A Modern Edge-based Design for Cellular Roaming
authors: Tenzin Samten Ukyab, Shaddi Hasan, Sylvia Ratnasamy, Scott Shenker
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: Support for roaming in today's cellular architecture involves operating a private network that sits right next to the mainstream Internet. This network is called the IP Exchange Network (IPX) and it provides Mobile Network Operators (MNOs) with a mechanism to form roaming partnerships, resolve billing and QoS, and set up tunnels as necessary. We propose a design which we call the CPX (Consolidated IPX/IXP) where the roaming network converges with the Internet by leveraging existing edge providers to provide all the benefits that the IPX network provides. In addition to convergence, the CPX architecture provides lower latency for roaming users; in our simulation of a global CPX deployment, we demonstrate an average of 318% improvement in roaming connection latency.

title: SAM-iToF: SAM-Guided iToF Depth Recovery of Transparent and Mirror Objects
authors: Kanghui Wang, Feng Yan, Tao Yue, Xuemei Hu
abstract: Indirect time-of-flight (iToF) cameras fail catastrophically when imaging transparent and reflective surfaces, as the complex superposition of light paths violates their fundamental operating principle. Existing methods either rely on overly simplistic physical models that lack adaptability or on data-driven deep learning approaches that exhibit poor generalization. In this letter, we introduce a novel, physics-informed paradigm that synergizes the strengths of both approaches. We are the first to steer a learnable iToF forward model using powerful spatial priors from the Segment Anything Model (SAM). Our framework leverages SAM's guidance to parameterize a reflectance-transmittance mixture model, providing a physically-grounded representation of the scene. This representation is then processed by a dual-stream network, featuring a Dynamic Channel Gate (DCG) and Cross-Attention Fusion (CAF), to intelligently interpret the raw iToF signals and reconstruct a high-fidelity depth map. Extensive experiments on the MSD, Trans10K, and ClearGrasp benchmarks demonstrate that our method not only sets a new state-of-the-art but also shows remarkable generalization from synthetic mirrors to real-world glass objects, offering a robust solution to this long-standing challenge.

title: Multi-Scale Frequency VAE-GAN: A Universal Approach for Inverting Diverse Halftone Images
authors: Zhanfeng Li, Hongwu Zhan, Yinwei Zhang, ShaoJie Tang, Yunyun Shen
abstract: Inverse halftoning aims to reconstruct continuous-tone images from halftone patterns. Although many learning-based methods have achieved promising results, they often struggle to generalize across diverse halftoning schemes due to variations in noise distribution within the frequency domain. To alleviate this issue, this paper presents a multi-scale frequency-aware VAE-GAN framework that enhances the reconstruction of various halftone types. The model consists of a content synthesis module based on a variational autoencoder and a detail refinement stage using a generative adversarial network. Frequency-aware feature extraction and adaptive fusion mechanisms are employed to better capture multi-scale structures and suppress halftone artifacts. Experimental evaluations on several halftone datasets indicate that the proposed method provides consistent and visually faithful restoration, achieving competitive quantitative and perceptual metrics compared with existing approaches. While the framework builds upon prior multi-stage designs, it offers a practical and extensible solution for general inverse halftoning tasks rather than a radical architectural innovation.

title: O, S, C, L-Band 4λ 960Gb/s PAM8 Transmission over 6.2km AR-HCF with Linear FFE Only
authors: Songyuan Hu, Chao Li, Chao Yang, Yunhong Liu, Shupeng Li, Xumeng Liu, Peng Sun, Ji Wang, Zhongshuai Feng, Shunfeng Wang, Qibing Wang, Xu Zhang, Zichen Liu, Peng Li, Lei Zhang, Zhixue He, Shaohua Yu
abstract: Anti-resonant hollow-core fiber (AR-HCF) has exhibited the revolutionary potential in wide-spectrum optical transmission. We propose and demonstrate the co-transmission of O, S, C, L-band signals in a single AR-HCF. Enabled by 80Gbaud PAM8 modulated four independent tunable lasers in O, S, C, L-bands and linear equalizers, we achieve the 960Gb/s (240Gb/s/λ × 4 λ) optical interconnect over 6.2km AR-HCF at 20% FEC limit of 2.4 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2</sup>. By adjusting the laser wavelengths, the measured useful bandwidths within the 20% FEC limit are 35nm, 35nm, 30nm and 20nm in O, S, C, L-bands, respectively, which provides an upgrade solution to achieve high-capacity optical interconnects with 200Gb/s/λ and beyond.

title: Magnetically Induced Skin Stretch Enhances Proprioceptive Feedback in Prosthetics_supp1-3633082.mp4
authors: Eleonora Fontana
abstract: Proprioceptive feedback is essential for motor control and prosthetic embodiment, yet myoelectric prostheses lack naturalistic sensory input. Artificial skin stretch stimulation has emerged as a preferred method to convey proprioceptive cues, but current friction-based devices face limitations preventing integration into practical prostheses. This work investigates magnetically induced skin stretch as a non-invasive, potentially implantable alternative. We present MISS (Magnetically Induced Skin Stretch), a novel system that uses external coils to control magnets adhered to the skin, producing skin deformations that mimic subdermal implantation and evoke proprioceptive sensations. We conducted physical and psychophysical experiments, including Just Noticeable Difference and Point of Subjective Equality measurements. Eighteen participants, including five with transradial amputation, used the MISS device with a myoelectric prosthesis, where skin stretch was modulated in sync with prosthetic hand flexion. Results showed high object discrimination accuracy, with amputees performing comparably to able-bodied users. These findings demonstrate MISS as a promising proprioceptive feedback method, supporting its future integration into implantable systems.

title: Optimized Decoupling Control and Cross-Domain Validation of a V-Shaped Quadrant-Habitat Fan-Wing Vehicle — Optimized for Underwater Operations_supp1-3632716.mp4
authors: Tianzhu Gao
abstract: Multi-habitat robots can operate across diverse environments, yet mainstream platforms still depend on fixed-wing/propeller actuation and “multi-controller–multi-hardware” architectures that hinder lightweight, integrated designs. This paper proposes a fan-wing–centric aquatic cross-habitat scheme: we derive a thrust-mapping model and, via singular value decomposition (SVD), optimize fan-wing orientations to decouple propulsion from attitude; on a unified hardware platform we implement software-switchable, domain-specific closed loops with adaptive thrust allocation. An enhanced QFV prototype is validated across within-water habitats (underwater–surface–near-bottom). With optimized angles (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\theta _{1}=22.8^{\circ}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\theta _{2}=30^{\circ}$</tex-math></inline-formula>), the QFV achieves stable depth holding (RMS <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\approx 0.31\,\mathrm{m}$</tex-math></inline-formula>) and improved attitude control (RMS 123°), whereas an unoptimized configuration becomes unstable—confirming effective decoupling, increased robustness, and reliable cross-habitat transitions. The proposed fan-wing design and SVD-based workflow provide a reusable thrust-mapping/allocation reference for cross-domain robotic systems.

title: Computational Caustic Design for Surface Light Source
authors: Sizhuo Zhou, Yuou Sun, Bailin Deng, Juyong Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Designing freeform surfaces to control light based on real-world illumination patterns is challenging, as existing caustic lens designs often assume oversimplified point or parallel light sources. We propose representing surface light sources using an optimized set of point sources, whose parameters are fitted to the real light source's illumination using a novel differentiable rendering framework. Our physically-based rendering approach simulates light transmission using flux, without requiring prior knowledge of the light source's intensity distribution. To efficiently explore the light source parameter space during optimization, we apply a contraction mapping that converts the constrained problem into an unconstrained one. Using the optimized light source model, we then design the freeform lens shape considering flux consistency and normal integrability. Simulations and physical experiments show our method more accurately represents real surface light sources compared to point-source approximations, yielding caustic lenses that produce images closely matching the target light distributions.

title: Changing Laws and Regulation Strategies of Dynamic Factors of Bridges with Common Spans for Superconducting EDS Maglev Transportation
authors: Zhonglin He, Chunfa Zhao, Yang Feng, Kai Li, Jing Yang, Ruodan Yu
abstract: To obtain the design basis for the dynamic characteristic parameters of bridges commonly used in superconducting electromagnetic suspension transportation, a refined magnetic force calculation model is established to analyze the dynamic load characteristics of null-flux coils. The dynamic response laws of simply supported beams under four types of equivalent train loads are compared, demonstrating that concentrated superconducting coil load sequences provide sufficient accuracy for bridge dynamic factor analysis. Furthermore, parametric analyses are conducted to investigate the effects of vehicle spacing, bridge spans, and train formations on bridge dynamic factors, and the preferred range of common bridge spans and strategies for regulating dynamic factors are discussed. The results show that the optimal range for common bridge spans is 1.5 to 1.75 times the vehicle spacing. When the ratio of bridge span to vehicle distance is 1.5, first-order resonance of the bridge is suppressed, and the dynamic factors of first-order superharmonic resonance increases with the number of train formations. When the ratio is 1.75, it is necessary to increase the vertical fundamental frequency of the bridge to avoid first-order resonance within the range of train operating speeds. Matching a 24.3 m vehicle spacing with a 37.8 m span bridge, under a 14-car formation, both the first-order resonance and superharmonic resonance dynamic factors of the bridge are less than 1.8. This configuration represents the optimal design scheme for high-speed superconducting electrodynamic suspension systems in terms of vehicle spacing and standardized bridge spans.

title: Computing Distributed Controlled Invariant Sets for Interconnected Linear Systems with Information Structures
authors: Liren Yang, Lintao Ye
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems
abstract: Central to the safety control problem is to compute a controlled invariant set that is as large as possible within a given safe region. However, this is not an easy task for interconnected systems due to the high cost i) for computing a high dimensional controlled invariant set at the design stage and ii) for subsystems communicating with a centralized controller at runtime. These two issues may be mitigated by considering a distributed control scheme. In this paper, we consider interconnected linear systems that allow local information sharing among adjacent subsystems w.r.t certain information structures, and propose a scalable (yet weakly complete) algorithm to compute a set that can be rendered invariant by a distributed controller, i.e., a distributed controlled invariant set (DCIS). In particular, different from safety control under centralized/decentralized scheme, we focus on understanding how the information structure affects the size of the DCIS. To that end, we give a criterion to prune useless communication links that do not enlarge a DCIS, and show that our algorithm nicely preserves the strength of the information structure. Two numerical examples illustrate the efficacy of the proposed approach.

authors: Mahesh Lokhande, Sanket Sonone, Ashutosh Somsetwar, Prem Parab, Aditya Bachhav, Swati Paralkar
abstract: This necessity for effective material summary has grown in recent years as podcasts have become a most popular and rich source of entertainment and information for all the people in the world. This project introduces a complex technique designed especially for podcast summarizing in response to overcome this need. Which will improve user’s access to relevant material inside podcast episodes is the main goal of this project. The system employs cutting-edge technologies such as Text Summarization and Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) to translate summaries from English to Hindi, transcribe spoken content, and extract important information. This bilingual, inclusive approach increases the system’s sphere of use. The last stage is to use Text-to-Speech (TTS) technology to translate Hindi text summaries into spoken language. This innovative method not only satisfies the present need for efficient podcast abridgement but also serves as the remarkable contribution to the worldwide audio content consumption which will lead to the new era getting entertainment.
