title: On-Board Core Network for STIN System, Challenges, Application Paradigms and Enabling Technologies
authors: Jinze Li, Hao Qin, Xinsheng Zhao
abstract: Integrating Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN) into future communication systems is hindered by the limitations of traditional satellite architectures in terms of design rigidity, autonomous network management, and mobility management. To address these challenges, this article proposes a comprehensive On-Board Core Network (OBCN) framework. Leveraging a cluster-based architecture enabled by Software-Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Functions Virtualization (NFV), our framework incorporates a Network Function Chain (NFC) method for autonomous networking and a stateless Satellite Live Migration (SLM) mechanism for enhanced mobility management. The feasibility and performance of the framework were validated on a hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) testbed emulating a compute-constrained satellite environment. Experimental results demonstrate rapid automated network deployment via NFC in approximately 23 seconds and highly efficient user context migration and service restoration via SLM, which adds only about 1 second of overhead for 1000 users. This work provides a validated engineering blueprint for future Satellite-Terrestrial Integrated Networks (STINs), confirming that an autonomous, fully-featured OBCN is a feasible engineering reality. This advancement enables enhanced service continuity, ubiquity, and scalability.

title: Maximal Recoverability: A Nexus of Coding Theory
authors: Joshua Brakensiek, Venkatesan Guruswami
publish: IEEE BITS the Information Theory Magazine
abstract: In the modern era of large-scale computing systems, a crucial use of error correcting codes is to judiciously introduce redundancy to ensure recoverability from failure. To get the most out of every byte, practitioners and theorists have introduced the framework of maximal recoverability (MR) to study optimal error-correcting codes in various architectures. In this survey, we dive into the study of two families of MR codes: MR locally recoverable codes (LRCs) (also known as partial MDS codes) and grid codes (GCs). For both families of codes, we discuss the primary recoverability guarantees of each class of codes as well as what is known concerning optimal constructions of each class of codes. Along the way, we discuss many surprising connections between MR codes and broader questions in computer science and mathematics. For MR LRCs, the use of skew polynomial codes has unified many previous constructions. For MR GCs, the theory of higher order MDS codes shows that MR GCs can be used to construct optimal list-decodable codes. Furthermore, the optimally recoverable patterns of MR GCs have close ties to long-standing problems on the structural rigidity of graphs.

title: Tracking Control of Biomimetic Wave-Spiral Robot Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning_supp1-3632614.mp4
authors: Qiao Hu
abstract: Drawing inspiration from piscine locomotion strategies, biomimetic underwater robotic systems demonstrate enhanced operational efficiency and stealth capabilities when executing target tracking missions within dynamic aquatic environments. However, challenges related to their operational speed and control precision hinder the timely and accurate completion of tasks. In this letter, a biomimetic wave-spiral robot with dual-mode propulsion capabilities is developed, and an autonomous switching tracking control algorithm based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL) is proposed. First, the kinematic models of the fins and fin rays in both spiral and wave modes are derived, and a multi segmented splicing design is employed to produce multi-modal fins, resulting in an integrated propulsion structure compatible with both high-speed and high-maneuverability modes. Second, a tracking control system consisting of two independent DRL policy networks and an adaptive mode switcher is proposed to realize autonomous and stable tracking control. Finally, simulation and swimming pool experiments demonstrate that the wave-spiral robot equipped with the dual-mode adaptive switching algorithm significantly achieved a 95% task completion rate and an average reward of 0.85 in the target tracking control experiment. Moreover, it demonstrates a 29.5% improvement in operation time when dealing with state disturbances and dynamic targets compared with the traditional control method. This study provides a promising and robust solution for developing tracking control for multi-mode biomimetic robots.

title: Trajectory Planning for Underwater Vehicles in Obstacle-Rich Environments
authors: Haifa Souilem, Chokri Ben Salah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This work explores the challenges of trajectory planning for underwater vehicles operating in obstacle-rich environments. By generating a detailed underwater map with strategically placed obstacles, we analyze the navigation strategies employed by three distinct vehicles as they traverse from specified starting points to their respective goals. The study highlights the importance of obstacle detection and avoidance techniques in ensuring safe and efficient navigation. Through the visualization of vehicle trajectories, we demonstrate the adaptability of these vehicles in real-time scenarios, providing insights into potential improvements for future underwater navigation systems. This research contributes to the ongoing development of autonomous underwater vehicles and their applications in various fields, including marine exploration, environmental monitoring, and underwater construction

title: Unveiling the Drivers of IKEA Product Pricing: A Random Forest Analysis
authors: Abhi Desai
abstract: IKEA’s product pricing is influenced by multiple interdependent features, yet limited literature exists on quantifying these impacts through machine learning. This paper presents a data-driven approach using a Random Forest regression model to identify and rank the importance of key product attributes (e.g., dimensions, category, and designer) on pricing. Using a dataset scraped from the Saudi Arabian IKEA website, we clean and preprocess over 2,900 records and construct multiple models to evaluate performance. Among Random Forest, Linear Regression, and Decision Tree models, Random Forest demonstrated superior performance with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.79, RMSE of 65.3, and MAE of 44.6 (EUR). The results emphasize the strong influence of size and designer on pricing. Finally, we highlight how businesses can use these insights for dynamic pricing, discount optimization, and regional market adjustments.

title: Day-Ahead Residential Electric Load Forecasting Using Bi-Directional LSTM Recurrent Neural Networks
authors: Gildardo Mendoza Achee, Michelle Wilber, Mohammad Heidari Kapourchali, Masoumeh Heidari Kapourchali
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Accurate forecasting of electricity consumption in individual households over variable step-ahead horizons is essential for improving the efficiency of home energy management systems (HEMS). This paper presents a bidirectional long shortterm memory (Bi-LSTM) model for predicting a household’s energy consumption in Anchorage, Alaska, over short-term forecasting horizons ranging from one hour to a full day ahead. The proposed approach involves preparing the time series data using a sliding window method that structures the hourly dataset into sequences suitable for long short-term memory (LSTM) models, which allows the Bi-LSTM architecture to incorporate features such as hour of the day, day of the week, day of the year, month of the year, week of the year, and ambient temperature. The results demonstrate that the Bi-LSTM model effectively predicts residential electricity consumption, particularly for recurring usage patterns, while also capturing volatile fluctuations caused by intermittent, high-power appliances.

title: Transformer-Based Federated Learning Framework for Breast Cancer Prediction
authors: Chaitanya Singla, Preeti Sharma, Chander Prabha, Nitin Rakesh, Liza Gernal, Bidush Kumar Sahoo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Breast cancer represents a significant global health challenge, contributing to high mortality rates among women, which underscores the need for accurate and timely predictive models for early diagnosis. Centralized machine learning approaches raise privacy concerns due to data aggregation, limiting scalability across diverse health care environments. This study presents a Transformer-based Federated Learning (FL) framework designed for breast cancer prediction, utilizing de-centralized learning to safeguard patient data privacy. The framework incorporates Transformer architecture with self-attention mechanisms to identify complex patterns in clinical data, delivering enhanced predictive performance. The FedProx aggregation strategy is employed to improve model convergence in heterogeneous client settings. Evaluation on the Breast Cancer Wisconsin (BCW) and SEER datasets yields an accuracy of 94.12% and an F1-score of 93.45%. Comparative analysis with state-of-the-art centralized and FL-based models confirms the framework's superior performance. The findings highlight the potential of Transformer-based FL for privacy-preserving, scalable, and high-performance breast cancer prediction in clinical applications.

title: Creating and Decoding Robust and Stylish QR Codes: An End-to-end Solution
authors: Jyoti Rathi, Surender K. Grewal
abstract: This research presents a novel end-to-end (E2E) approach for developing visually appealing and scanning/decoding-robust stylized (SRS)-QR codes. The growing demand for QR codes that balance aesthetic design with functionality has driven the need for innovative approaches. The proposed method utilizes deep learning algorithms, including Neural Style Transfer (NST), VGG-19 and VGG-16 to optimize the design of QR codes while maintaining their functionality and scan reliability. Experimental results demonstrate improved decoding time compared to traditional QR code generation methods. The proposed method outperforms existing methods by offering the ability to customize QR codes while maintaining their functionality and scan reliability. The state-of-the-art technology used in this research has the capability to generate QR codes with improved decoding time compared to standard QR codes, making it valuable in various applications such as advertising, branding, and digital signage. To validate the results of the proposed method, real-world testing with a Xiaomi device is conducted. The results depict that the proposed method is 100% successful in scanning the stylized QR codes under optimal conditions. It is noted that results may vary based on the scanning device and environmental conditions.

title: Hardware-aware Gradient-based Column-wise Mixed-Precision Quantization for Compute-in-Memory Accelerators
authors: Li Zhang, Mohammed E. Fouda, Ahmed M. Eltawil, Khaled Nabil Salama
abstract: Efficient deep learning deployment, especially on the Edge, requires quantization strategies that not only preserve model accuracy but also align with hardware constraints to maximize performance and efficiency. In this work, we propose an end-to-end framework for mixed-precision quantization of convolutional neural networks (CNNs), optimized for deployment on compute-in-memory (CIM) accelerators. Our approach employs column-wise mixed-precision quantization to balance model accuracy and hardware complexity. We implement the framework using fully gradient-based algorithms, enabling efficient design space exploration. To account for hardware constraints, we integrate an analog CIM accelerator simulator into the pipeline, providing hardware metrics. Additionally, an estimator network is co-trained with the task model to supply hardware-induced gradients, eliminating the need for equation-based intermediate approximations. We validate our framework on the CIFAR-10 dataset using VGG8, VGG11, and ResNet18, demonstrating its effectiveness in optimizing both model and hardware performance achieving 50.34 TOPs/W of energy efficiency, 0.15 TOPs/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of compute efficiency and 189.25 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of area with ResNet18. Further experiments on ImageNet dataset prove its cross-dataset adaptability and confirm its ability to direct control the hardware metrics.

title: NLP-Driven Framework for Spam SMS Detection and Classification
authors: Trisha Sharma, Priyanshu Walia, Sudhir Sharma, Mayank Chopra
abstract: The growing use of mobile communication has given rise to the issue of spam SMS messages, which consistently threaten user security with potentially harmful content. This research presents a method for identifying SMS spam through the application of techniques such as Natural Language Processing (NLP), Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA), and machine learning models to detect and categorize spam messages effectively. Our approach leverages EDA to investigate spam trends and pinpoint essential message features, along with the application of a TF-IDF vectorizer for effective feature extraction. We assess a variety of classification algorithms, including Naïve Bayes and a fine-tuned Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model, and optimizing hyperparameters to improve model performance. The experimental findings indicate that the optimized LSTM model, in conjunction with Naïve Bayes and enhanced optimization techniques, achieves significant accuracy, precision, and recall in spam detection. This methodology illustrates that combining NLP-based preprocessing with optimized machine learning models is effective in creating resilient, scalable systems for SMS spam detection, and provides valuable insights. Additionally, this study enhances techniques for managing class imbalance and improving adaptability to changing spam patterns in real-time systems.

title: Optimization of Base Station Deployment Using Particle Swarm Optimization and Simulated Annealing: A Comparative Analysis
authors: M Anusree, Anna Benny, O Amrutha, Aagin K Prince, Mariya Vincent
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Efficient base station (BS) deployment is critical for optimizing coverage and minimizing interference in 5G networks. Traditional optimization methods are likely to struggle with the complexity of large-scale network planning. This paper considers applying Particle Swarm Algorithm (PSO) and Simulated Annealing (SA) to optimize BS deployment. PSO employs swarm intelligence for rapid convergence, while SA uses probabilistic movements to escape local optima. Both algorithms performance is quantified in terms of coverage, interference execution time and the number of uncovered users through MATLAB-based simulations. The results are comparative analysis, guiding the selection of the optimum algorithm to employ in highperformance 5G deployment.

title: Design and Analysis of a 2 × 2 Patch Antenna Array for 6G Applications in the 7-8 GHz Band
authors: P K Mehvin, K K Ajayan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: The $7-8 \mathrm{GHz}$ frequency range, a subset of the broader $7.125-8.4 \mathrm{GHz}$ mid-band spectrum, has emerged as a promising candidate for early 6 G deployments due to its optimal balance of coverage, penetration, and data capacity. In this paper, a $2 \times 2$ microstrip patch antenna array is designed and optimized to operate efficiently in the $7-8 \mathrm{GHz}$ spectrum. The antenna is fabricated on an FR4 Epoxy substrate (relative permittivity 4.4, thickness 1.6 mm) and utilizes a corporate feed network to ensure uniform power distribution among the four rectangular patch elements. HFSS simulations confirm that the proposed antenna resonates at 7.6 GHz, with a return loss of -30.23 dB and an impedance bandwidth of 400 MHz ($7.4-7.8 \mathbf{G H z}$), meeting the bandwidth criteria for high-speed, low-latency 6G communication. The array achieves a realized gain of 9.99 dB, confirming its suitability f or high data rate applications. These results validate the feasibility of utilizing mid-band patch antenna arrays in next-generation wireless networks, reinforcing the importance of the $7-8 \mathrm{GHz}$ spectrum in bridging the gap between lower sub- 6 GHz and higher mmWave frequencies for 6G.

title: Mesh Board with Pitched Blade Turbine Impeller to Prevent Agglomerate Formation
authors: Ippei Kaizawa, Michihiro Hakoda, Nana Tsuruta, Riku Shibahara, Ken’ichi Yano, Kenta Fukuma, Jun Kakuda, Jong Ryu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: In cosmetics manufacturing, powders with different sizes, shapes, and properties are fed into liquids and mixed to create cosmetics with various functions. However, during the powder mixing process, powders not incorporated into the liquid form agglomerates and float on the surface of the liquid, with the result that it takes a long time until the powder is completely incorporated into the liquid and the mixing is complete. In general, powder mixing is performed using a HOMO-dispersion stirring impeller with a high-shear disperser blade. However, powder mixing with a dispersion impeller is dominated by radial discharge from the stirring impeller, which makes powder incorporation into the liquid difficult, resulting in the formation of agglomerates. Therefore, a new stirring impeller must be developed to prevent the formation of agglomerates during powder mixing. The purposes of this study were to clarify the mechanisms of agglomerate formation and powder suspension, propose a mechanism to prevent agglomerate formation, and develop a new stirring impeller for HOMO-disper. Finally, powder and liquid mixing experiments were conducted. The powder mixing experimental results showed that the proposed impeller can be used for mixing without forming agglomerates, demonstrating its effectiveness. The powder mixing process is a common production process in cosmetics manufacturing, pharmaceutical manufacturing and food processing, and our proposed impeller is therefore expected to play an active role in a wide range of fields. (Abstract)

title: Robust Fault Estimation Based on Proportional Multiple-Integral Observer for Continuous-Time Switched Systems
authors: Mohamed Elouni, Mickael Rodrigues, Habib Hamdi, Bouali Rabaoui, Naceur BenHadj Braiek
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: In this article, the problem of robust fault reconstruction is addressed for a class of switching systems in the presence of disturbances. A robust Proportional Multiple-Integral (PMI) observer is proposed to achieve simultaneous estimations of the states of the system and faults. By employing the multiple Lyapunov function and Average Dwell Time (ADT) switching signal, sufficient conditions with less conservatism are derived and formulated by Linear Matrix Inequalities (LMIs) such that the corresponding error system is Globally Uniformly Asymptotically Stable (GUAS) with a prescribed $H_{\infty}$ disturbance attenuation performance. Convex optimization techniques are employed to obtain the PMI observer gains through the resolution of LMIs. Finally, a two-tank process is considered to prove the efficiency and superiority of the designed observer.

title: Performance Analysis of Power-over-Fiber Systems in 5G NR
authors: Saniya Azeem, Abhiram Suresh, Ardra Sreekumar, Ashwin Prasad, S Beema, G Ganga Lekshmi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Power-over-Fiber (PoF) is a new technology that allows for simultaneous power and data transfer, increasing flexibility and tolerance to electromagnetic interference. This study investigates 5 G Radio-over-Fiber (RoF) data transmission with PoF signals, assessing system performance over a 10kilometer fiber link utilizing QPSK, 16QAM, 64QAM, and 256QAM modulation techniques. The major performance parameter is error vector magnitude (EVM). The results show that using advanced modulation techniques improves signal integrity, decreases EVM, and increases efficiency, especially for higher-order schemes. These findings demonstrate PoF-RoF systems potential to enable next-generation wireless networks with greater capacity and dependability.

title: Virtual Influencers in the Artificial Intelligence Era: Shaping Parasocial Relationships and Perceived Homophily for Luxury Fashion Purchases
authors: Dhanya Pramod, Kanchan Pranay Patil
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Artificially, the futuristic marketing approach has seen an increase in virtual influencers, also mentioned as AI-generated influencers or computer-generated imagery. The current study assesses the influence of virtual influencers' credibility and attractiveness attributes mediated via parasocial relations and perceived homophily on followers' luxury fashion purchase behavior. To evaluate the model and hypotheses, 381 virtual influencer followers' online survey data were examined using structural equation modeling via SmartPLS. The results demonstrate that parasocial relations mediate between virtual influencer credibility (i.e., trustworthiness, expertise) and luxury fashion purchases. Also, perceived homophily mediates between a virtual influencer's attractiveness (i.e., Physical attraction, Familiarity, Likability, Similarity, Relevance) and luxury fashion purchase. The results highlight that social media followers/customers get attracted towards virtual influencers, and virtual influencers are perceived as attractive, familiar, similar, and related to customers' preferences, increasing luxury fashion purchases. These findings will help practitioners understand the virtual influencers' followers' luxury fashion purchase behavior. The study also addresses how managers creating campaigns might be affected by the findings.

title: Applying Intelligent Educational Systems in Higher Education: Pedagogical Effectiveness
authors: Arailym Ashimbekova, Andrey Bondarenko
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies into online education is progressing rapidly, encompassing adaptive modules, recommendation systems, automated knowledge assessment, and chatbots. These tools foster personalized learning, increase engagement, and improve academic outcomes. Empirical data indicate a predominantly positive impact of AI on students' achievement, motivation, and satisfaction. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of an AI-enhanced educational platform in a university setting. The experiment involved 145 second-year students at L.N. Gumilyov Eurasian National University, divided into control and experimental groups. The experimental group learned with an AI platform that offered adaptive tasks and automated testing. Quantitative and qualitative analyses revealed statistically significant improvements in the experimental group's results, confirming the advisability of using AI in the educational environment.

title: Career Advisory System Using LLM
authors: Kshitij Kiran Habbu, Ameya Arvind Pasare, Priyanka Subhash Jadhav, Shreya Khupse, Suruchi Dedgaonkar, Brajesh Lal
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: In this document, we present an AI-based career guidance system specifically for the Indian job market. This system uses large language models (LLMs) integrated with formal job matching algorithms in order to develop personalized job recommendations for users. Our approach combines static job data with geometry-based job data analysis with LLM approach to dynamic question following and response processing with the Groq API usage of the LLAMA3-70B model. The system works in two parallel tracks; the first is a job recommender which aims to direct users to relevant available positional positions based on their skills and interests and the second is a career suggester that ultimately seeks to give user the most suited careers based on their user profiles. The algorithm for matching uses a combination of both job filtration (using weighted keyword scoring, i.e., mathematical formula S = Σ(w_i * f_i)) and LLM-based semantic analysis. The evaluation shows that the system recommends relevant jobs while ensuring it handles the issues specific to the Indian job market; geographical differences, limited scope of skills and rapid technological change. This paper makes contribution to AI based career guidance and educational technology by providing an operational implementation with measurements.

title: Cradle to Gate Life Cycle Assessment Study on Green Concretes for Energy Consumption and Global Warming Potential
authors: Trupti P. Parmar, Tarak Vora
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This study aims to assess the environmental performance of concrete made with supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs), focusing mainly on two parameters; Global Warming Potential (GWP) and energy consumption. A cradle-to-gate Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) was conducted on three different concrete mixes, each incorporating distinct binder compositions. The first mix, CONPC, represents conventional concrete that uses 100% Ordinary Portland Cement (OPC). The second mix, CONFA, represents a concrete with 27% of OPC replace by Fly ash (FA), The third variant, CONBS, is a concrete made with 46% of OPC replaced by Blast Furnace Slag (BFS). The comparative results demonstrates that the alternative concrete mixes, significantly lower environmental burdens. Overall energy consumption per cubic meter of concrete is reduced by 22% for CONFA and 28% for CONBS. Overall GWP reduced by 23% and 39% in cases of CONFA and CONBS respectively. The results strongly suggests for substitution of OPC with SCMs.

title: Accurate Impedance Spectroscopy of Rechargeable Li-ion Batteries
authors: Prarthana Pillai, Krishna R. Pattipati, Balakumar Balasingam
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is a commonly used method for evaluating battery health. It involves applying a high-frequency excitation signal to the battery and analyzing the resulting voltage response to generate its impedance spectrum. Traditional EIS techniques generally treat the battery as a linear time-invariant system, assuming that, under small signal perturbations and resting conditions, the impedance spectrum reliably represents the battery’s behavior. However, this paper demonstrates that the presence of the battery’s opencircuit voltage (OCV) invalidates the LTI assumption, even when a zero-mean excitation signal is used on a fully rested battery. Specifically, we show that OCV variations introduce nonlinearity in the voltage response, significantly affecting the impedance spectrum in the low-frequency range. To address this limitation, we utilize a novel approach that helps remove the OCV’s contribution from the measured voltage response. This correction allows for a more precise impedance analysis by directly addressing the nonlinearity caused by the OCV. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated using data from a battery simulator.

title: Integrated Energy System Design for Parks Based on Optimal Scheduling in a Low-Carbon Economy
authors: Keqian Wang, Huahua Xiong, Cengceng Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: Under the current dual constraints of insufficient traditional energy sources and serious environmental pollution, the integrated energy system of the park is facing many challenges, such as the imbalance of energy supply and demand, and high carbon emissions. In this paper, we analyse the existing problems of the integrated energy system in the park, and construct an integrated energy system model covering multiple dimensions of electricity, heat and natural gas supply, as well as a carbon emission cost minimization model that takes into account the cost of purchasing electricity, purchasing natural gas, minimizing power abandonment, and operation and maintenance costs. Through well-designed simulation experiments, a typical park integrated energy system is used as a simulation example to compare and analyse the operation results of the low-carbon economy-based optimal dispatch under two different system configurations. The results show that the design of the park integrated energy system based on the optimal scheduling of lowcarbon economy has significant advantages in cost control, which can effectively reduce the cost of power purchase and operation and maintenance costs, and in the improvement of energy efficiency, it can significantly enhance the stability of the energy supply, reduce the amount of abandoned power, improve the utilisation rate of renewable energy, and at the same time significantly reduce carbon emissions and other pollutants, which is significant for promoting the low-carbon transformation of the park. It is of great significance to promote the low-carbon transformation of the park.

title: An Ultra-Low Power Bandpass Filter Bank with Input and Output Common-Mode Feedback in FD-SOI
authors: Damian Panter, Gabriel Lías Villar, Erkan Nevzat Isa, Amelie Hagelauer
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: To implement frequency sensitivity in always-on audio-frontends that predominantly utilize analog signal processing techniques, banks of bandpass filters are needed. Due to their deployment in low-voltage environments, keeping all transistors in saturation under all conditions poses a challenge. We propose a common-mode feedback concept for flipped voltage follower based bandpass filters making use of the backgate terminal in SOI technologies. It sets the operating points of the filter core, ensuring proper functionality under all process variations and a temperature range from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to 85° C. We conducted a comprehensive mathematical analysis, deriving design guidelines for the common-mode feedback loops. The bandpass filter bank with the proposed common-mode feedback concept has been simulated and verified on schematic-level achieving a total power consumption of 64.3 nW and a DR of approximately 50 dB while covering a frequency range from 44 Hz to 7.8 kHz.

title: Advanced Crop Yield Prediction Using Supervised Machine Learning Techniques and Environmental Data
authors: T. Asha Latha, Niteesha Sharma, Ravi Raju B, Bejugam Rachana, A. Varsha, Kunchala Rajesh
abstract: It is of greatest significance to forecast the amount of crop a farmer will produce for effective agriculture and decision-making. The traditional techniques are based on history and mere calculations but may be unreliable since weather, soil, etc., are always changing. In this project, in this work, machine learning has been used to enhance crop yield forecasting based on history, weather, and soil. Different models like Decision Tree, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting are experimented upon to decide on the optimal model to utilize. Among them, the best outcome is from the Decision Tree model. The calculations are also performed by the system, decide upon the key factors, and make the models optimize for enhanced performance. In this way, the farmers are able to plan effectively, utilize the resources effectively, minimize losses, and increase the harvest. We can then extend and evolve the system further with the addition of real-time data harvesting and the ability to accommodate a larger diversity of crops in numerous regions.

title: Guided by Logic, Powered by Evolution: a Fuzzy-GA Framework for Medical Referral Recommendation
authors: Rida Adila, Shintami Chusnul Hidayati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Hypertension, defined as blood pressure equal to or exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$130 / 85 \text{mmHg}$</tex>, can result from both physiological conditions and psychological stressors. Overlooking mental health issues like anxiety, depression, or chronic stress can lead to inappropriate treatment, such as unnecessary cardiology referrals. This may increase the risk of serious complications, including stroke, heart attack, or kidney failure. To address this gap, this study proposes an intelligent referral recommendation system that integrates fuzzy logic with genetic algorithm (GA) optimization. The system analyzes both physical indicators (e.g., blood pressure, age, genetic factors) and psychological parameters (e.g., anxiety levels) to determine whether patients should be referred to a cardiologist or psychiatrist. By optimizing membership functions through GAs, the system improves the decision accuracy and minimizes referral errors. Experimental validation demonstrates that the proposed framework is capable of providing more precise and context-aware medical referrals.

title: A 100nA Voltage Reference with 6.4ppm/°C Temperature Coefficient using Weak Inversion MOSFET
authors: Emmanuel Amankrah, Zakariah Mohammed, Patricia Tutuani, Randall Geiger
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: This paper presents a voltage reference design using MOSFETs in weak inversion to minimize area and power consumption in traditional voltage references while achieving a low temperature coefficient (TC). The proposed design combines the PTAT voltage and the CTAT voltage inherent in the gate-to-source voltage (Vgs) of weak inversion transistors. Simulations results indicates that the proposed reference achieves a TC of 6.4ppm/°C from -40°C to 125°C, power supply ripple rejection of -45.5 dB, while taking up a total area of 0.015mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and consuming a total power of 180nW from a 1.8V supply.

title: Enhancing Protection with NLP-Based Phishing Detection Across Diverse Communication Channels
authors: Odhuri Shiva Kumar, Kalangi Praveen Kumar, Kaluri Krishna Chaitanya, Medichalam Saiteja, Karla Abhilash, Bollipelly Pruthviraj Goud
abstract: Phishing attacks led by email and text message intrusions along with deceptive hyperlinks continue to rise because they take advantage of user trust so organizations need strong novel protective strategies beyond basic defense systems. A detection system using advanced language model RoBERTa comes with a dynamic ensemble framework to perform phishing identification across different communication platforms. Our system uses RoBERTa to read text deeply through 30 indicators that feature URL properties (domain registration age and unusual top-level suffixes and hidden IP addresses) and textual indicators (urgent phrasing, questionable sender authenticity and inconsistent formatting including excessive punctuation). A distinctive neural network accepts these indicators to enhance RoBERTa’s results thus improving its capacity to detect malicious content from benign content with enhanced accuracy. Our approach solves the problem of unbalanced training data through the creation of synthetic examples using synonym substitutions which produces an improved model reliability as it combines legitimate and phishing samples. After its training phase the system offers an interface to users for flagging incorrect outcomes or verifying correct classifications so that it develops comprehension of genuine world scenarios through real-time inputs. The principle has passed demanding tests which have generated exceptional precision and recall results while surpassing conventional methods at detecting phishing attempts specifically in emails, text messages and web links. Through the combination of language processing technology with cyber-security experience the solution delivers an advanced barrier system to protect digital systems from modern phishing strategies which it actively adapts to new threats.

title: A High-Performance Energy-Efficient Weighted Clustering Model for Mobile Ad Hoc Sensor Networks
authors: Hyba AbdulJalee, Lulwah M. Alkwai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Across dynamic and resource-constrained environments, mobile sensor networks (MASNs) are crucial for real-time monitoring. Because many nodes move around, power is limited, and topologies change frequently, maintaining energy efficiency and reliability remains a challenge. In this paper, we present a High-Performance Energy-Efficient Weighted Clustering Model for optimising clustering based on weighted metrics like residual energy, node degree, and mobility. Using this model, clusters are more stable, overhead is reduced, and network lifetime is prolonged by minimising unnecessary re-clustering and even energy distribution. Compared to existing approaches, the proposed model appears to be more energy efficient, packet-delivery-prone, fault-tolerant, and stable.

title: CBAM-Enhanced YOLO11n: A Lightweight and Efficient Model for Solid Waste Detection Compared to YOLOv9n, YOLOv10n, and RT-DETR
authors: Jordan Josdaan, Vianna Calista Tamsil, Jeklin Harefa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Humans produce over 1.4 billion tons of waste worldwide. Timely management of this waste is important, as waste that cannot be reused or recycled is most likely headed to landfills. Disposal of wastes in landfills facilities poses significant environmental and health risks that are both serious and unavoidable. This study compared four object detection models, YOLOv9n, YOLOv10n, YOLO11n, and RT-DETR, with the objective of evaluating the accuracy, inference speed, and computational cost of automated waste sorting. The models were trained using the TrashNet dataset, which contains 2,524 real-world images, categorized into 6 classes. Training was performed for 100 epochs using the AdamW optimizer, a learning rate of 0.001, momentum of 0.9, and a batch size of 16. The results of this study provide valuable insights, as RT-DETR showed the greatest accuracy, while YOLO11n provided the best overall solution with the most favorable balance of accuracy, speed of inference, and lowest computational cost. Our method of addition of the Convolutional Block Attention Module into YOLO11n increased all metrics with Precision of 93.2 %, Recall of 94.7 %, mAP <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${@} 0.5$</tex> of 96.1 %, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{m A P} {@} 0.5: 0.95$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{9 5. 4 \%}$</tex>. This result into an increase of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1. 6 \%}$</tex> in precision, a 2.7 % increase in recall, a 1.9 % increase in mAP @ 0.5, and a 1.8 % increase in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP} {@} 0.5: 0.95$</tex> from the base model, making it the most feasible and efficient model in real-world deployment.

title: Impact of Social Proof and Customer Experience on Trust in Travel Platforms
authors: Irvan Rusiadi, Lasmy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: This study explores how social proof and customer experience influence users' trust in Trave****, a leading digital platform in Indonesia that provides travel services. Social proof, such as reviews, ratings, and endorsements from influencers, plays an important role in reducing users' uncertainty and encouraging their interest in trying a product or service. Meanwhile, direct experiences such as how easy the platform is to use, how well the service matches users' expectations, and the overall impression users get also have a significant impact on trust building. This research uses a quantitative approach with an online survey method. Of the total respondents collected, there were 399 respondents who met the criteria who were active users of Trave****. The results of this study highlight that building trust is not just about having a good reputation or strong social proof. Providing a smooth, reliable and satisfying user experience is equally important. A strong combination of social proof and positive firsthand experience creates a stronger foundation for long term user trust, making it important for digital platforms like Trave**** to focus on both aspects to remain competitive and relevant in the market.

title: Development of a Telescopic Inspection and Cleaning Arm for Vessels
authors: Ahmed Moulhi, Saber Hachicha, Chiheb Zaoui, Helmi Abrougui, Wissem Karray, Habib Dallagi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a telescopic inspection and cleaning arm for vessels, designed to provide a versatile, efficient, and secure system for performing visual inspections and cleaning operations in hard-to-reach areas on board. The arm will be used to inspect the hulls of vessels, propulsion systems, and other critical components, while facilitating preventive maintenance. Thanks to its innovative design, it reduces risks for technicians and improves the efficiency of inspections, thereby contributing to extending the lifespan of on-board equipment. The geometric model of the arm and its dynamic behavior, including five degrees of freedom (three rotations and two translations), are detailed. Additionally, a PID control technique has been employed to regulate the arm’s attitude during the inspection. Simulation results demonstrate the robustness of this control method, proving the enhancement of the efficiency of the ship hull inspection process.

title: Passive Beamforming of a Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface Using SDR and LabVIEW - A Demo in an Indoor Wireless Environment
authors: K. P. Nithin Mohan, S Satheesh, S Poornima, Deepti Das Krishna
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) are gaining popularity in wireless communication networks due to their ability to manipulate the amplitude and phase of electromagnetic waves, directing them in a desired direction. This paper presents a comprehensive study on Bit Error Rate (BER) measurements under various wireless propagation conditions, focusing mainly on the impact of passive beamforming using RIS. Experiments were conducted in multipath conditions and in an anechoic chamber to minimize external interference and analyse the effects of multipath and reflection separately. Labview software and NI USRPs were used on both the transmitter (Tx) and receiver (Rx) sides. The experimental setup includes transmission and reception using horn antennas, through both direct paths and reflections off a metal surface. The metal surface is positioned in the anechoic chamber to ensure that it only reflects the signal incident from the horn antenna pointing towards it, while all other interferences are absorbed by the chamber’s absorbers. Results indicate that reflections from the metal plate in the anechoic chamber can provide an effective additional link to the existing direct line, thereby improving the received BER. Although the reflected link is longer than the direct link, at a frequency of 2.4 GHz frequency and an $\mathrm{Eb} / \mathrm{No}$ of 4 dB, the reflected link’s BER is $\mathbf{1 2. 5 \%}$ better than that of the direct link, indicating that the reflected link serves as a reasonably good signal copy even when the direct link is blocked. This also demonstrates the effective passive beamforming achieved through controlled reflection. Furthermore, configuring the entire setup within the anechoic chamber illustrates that the RIS-based reflection can steer the signal in a desired direction, achieving optimal BER at the desired angle. These findings validate the potential of RIS for enhancing the reliability of digital wireless communication.

title: FitSync: AI and Digital Twin Solution for Modern Gyms
authors: Jishnu G Varier, Noel Susan Mathew, V P Parvathy, Shon Varghese, M S Sumesh
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Modern fitness m onitoring s ystems o ften f ail to provide real-time insights or integrate sustainable practices, limiting their ability to enhance user safety and promote ecofriendly gym environments. To address these gaps, we present FitSync, an AI-driven solution that combines Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, Digital Twin (DT) technology, and sustainable energy practices to create a comprehensive fitness monitoring system. FitSync uses historical heart rate data from a single user to train an LSTM model, enabling personalized heart rate prediction and anomaly detection. A MATLAB-based Digital Twin provides a virtual representation of the user’s heart, allowing for continuous monitoring and actionable insights. In addition, a web interface visualizes heart rate trends, anomalies, and alerts, offering an intuitive platform for users and trainers. To promote sustainability, FitSync includes a miniature energy generation model that demonstrates the conversion of kinetic energy from gym equipment into usable electricity. This proof-of-concept model powers an LED, showcasing the potential for large-scale implementation to power gym facilities. While the current implementation focuses on multiple-user data and proof-of-concept energy harvesting, future work will explore real-time sensor integration and deployment on gym equipment screens for real-time alerts. FitSync represents a significant step toward creating safer, smarter, and greener fitness environments.

title: Smart Solar Battery Charging Station with Dynamic Adaptive Switching Control
authors: Dipta Paul, Md. Shahidul Alam, Riad Mollik Babu, Mohammad Maruf Hossain
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Solar energy is increasingly recognized as a vital substitute for traditional energy sources as global demand for sustainable power continues to grow. This need is especially critical in emerging nations, where many regions experience energy scarcity and remain reliant on expensive and environmentally damaging fossil fuels. To address this issue, this paper presents the design and development of an upgraded Smart Solar Battery Charging Station aimed at reducing dependency on conventional grids and delivering a cost-effective, environmentally sustainable power solution. The proposed system employs two 200-Watt photovoltaic panels to charge 48-Volt battery sets, ensuring a consistent energy supply throughout the day. A key innovation of the system is its adaptive switching mechanism, which seamlessly transitions to backup grid power during periods of insufficient solar irradiance. This feature enables continuous battery charging and enhances performance in regions with fluctuating sunlight or unstable grid access. One of the primary applications of the system is in the transportation sector, particularly for charging electric vehicles (EVs), thereby contributing to improved mobility. Beyond its direct functionality, the system promotes decentralized energy solutions, reduces carbon emissions, and enhances energy resilience-all in alignment with global renewable energy objectives. This study examines the system’s design, operation, and broader potential as a scalable and sustainable energy infrastructure for global communities.

title: A maintenance plan based on Monitoring to detect equipment failures in a mining company using machine learning
authors: Rodolfo Canelón, Felipe Rivera, Cristian Inzulza, Samira Khazmou
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: The project aims to design a condition monitoring plan for equipment in the water resources division of a private mining company in Chile, located in the Tarapacá and Antofagasta regions. This division plays a critical role in the extraction of water for production processes related to potassium nitrate, specialized fertilizers, iodine, potassium, and lithium. The initiative was triggered by previous failures in the extraction system, leading to partial production interruptions and high maintenance costs. The proposed approach includes a software architecture that supports the development of predictive models using pre-trained algorithms tailored to the operational context. Condition-based maintenance is implemented through techniques such as vibration analysis and infrared thermography, applied to submersible and centrifugal pumps, low and medium voltage electrical panels, substations, reservoirs and more than 150 km of pipelines. A hybrid model combining LSTM architectures and XGBoost decision trees was implemented to enhance the accuracy of failure detection and characterization. Offline validation of the system yielded positive results eight anomalies were detected, five electrical and three mechanical, four of which were classified as critical, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed solution.

title: A Review on Methods to Identify Influential Nodes in Complex Networks
authors: Shivangi Verma, Rahul Bhandari, Nitika Kapoor
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This is because the present study proposes a systematic review of the current methodologies of detecting critical nodes in complex networks, which continues to be predominant in network science. They consider centrality-based measures, diffusion-based approach, community-aware strategies as well as machine learning approach and evaluate their use in each network structure in terms of their strengths and limitations. Based on the results, it emerges that the approach using both topological data and dynamic signal propagation is better than just using the common centrality indexes especially in large and heterogeneous network. Such comparison is supposed to advance the existing influence identification methods, and its implications can be demonstrated in areas like viral marketing, epidemic control, and effective message passing in various networks.

title: Stability and Efficiency Enhancements in Mobile Ad Hoc Networks with Multicriteria Relay Selection
authors: Qasim Jumaa, Kusum Yadav
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The recovery of disasters and military operations requires dynamic and infrastructure-less communication environments, such as mobile ad hoc networks (MANETs). Due to challenges such as node mobility, unstable links, and limited resources, these systems often perform poorly. Our Optimised Link State Routing (OLSR) protocol proposes a multicriteria relay selection strategy that considers node mobility, energy consumption, and link reliability. The proposed MCW _ OLSR model improves network stability and efficiency by optimising multipoint relay (MPR) selection. Compared to conventional OLSR, DSDV, and SR _ OLSR protocols, it provides significantly improved packet delivery ratios, reduced packet loss, and lower delays.

title: Smart Metrology: How AI is Transforming Measurement Data Analysis
authors: Nadia Fezai, Abdessattar Ben Amor
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is deeply transforming all industrial sectors, with a particularly strong impact in the field of high-frequency metrology. Although network analyzer data analysis has historically relied on conventional statistical methods, current challenges require a major evolution. The increasing sophistication of high-frequency signals, combined with the explosion of generated data volume, now requires the adoption of more advanced analytical approaches. This technological shift not only optimizes data processing but also extracts more precise and relevant information from the measurements. High-frequency metrology is confronted with a major challenge: the analysis of growing volumes of complex data. This article proposes to exploit the potential of unsupervised learning to address this challenge. Using data generated by network analyzers, we present a methodology based on machine learning techniques to discover latent structures in the signals. Through a case study, we illustrate how this approach can enhance anomaly detection, optimize predictive maintenance, and open new perspectives for spectral analysis.

title: Hybrid Wavelet and PSO-Neural Network Model for Short-Term Load Forecasting
authors: Zaeid Ajzaahne, Kusum Yadav
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: An STLF hybrid model is developed using Wavelet Transforms (WT), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Neural Networks (NN). Improved prediction accuracy in electric load forecasting is essential to efficient power system operation. Traditional models struggle to comprehend load data, as it is often nonlinear and time-varying. Signals are decomposed using the wavelet transform (WT), and the neural network parameters are optimised using particle swarm optimisation (PSO). Compared to Backpropagation Neural Networks, this model performs significantly better than multiple linear regressions and other neural network models. We also analyze differences between weekdays and weekends to assess model performance under varied conditions. A hybrid approach improves forecasting precision and robustness, according to the findings.

title: Quantum Safe Encryption and Decryption for Securing Healthcare Data
authors: G M Laasya, D. Sai Reethika, Nasreen Begum, Balaji K
abstract: In the healthcare sector, the field of data security is, as much as ever, subjected to tremendous challenges owing to several forms of cyber-attacks, various unauthorized access points, and leaks of data. However, the techniques applied for traditional encryption very often fail to provide effective protection against brute attacks and key ingestion, resulting in profound weaknesses in storing and moving around healthcare data. This study introduces a better encryption method that combines Diffie-Hellman and AES encryption algorithm. Diffie-Hellman securely creates a shared key without sending it, reducing interception risk, while AES keeps patient data safe from hacking and unauthorized access. This study is to investigate such an encryption model in terms of performance within the hospital database, telemedicine platforms, and cloud-based health information systems.

title: An Efficient Hybrid Pseudo-Random Number Generator Based on CNTFET
authors: Qijin Zhu, Xiaowen Chen, Yu Dong, Zhichao Rui, Hengzhou Yuan
abstract: In the post-Moore era, conventional pseudo-random number generators (PRNG) struggle to meet the demands of intelligent computing and IoT due to limitations in randomness, efficiency, and security. This paper proposes a hybrid architecture PRNG and its carbon nanotube field-effect transistors (CNTFET) implementation. Firstly, this paper proposes a two-stage hybrid PRNG architecture that achieves excellent performance, strong randomness, and enhanced security. The first stage introduces a full-state jumping linear feedback shift register (LFSR), which effectively addresses the low throughput and poor randomness issues of traditional LFSRs. The second stage uses a lightweight optimized SM4 algorithm, which significantly reduces computational complexity while maintaining strong nonlinear confusion capability. For the Si-based 180 nm process node, the design achieves a throughput of 43.1 Gbps, with 9× area efficiency and 6× energy efficiency improvements over similar solutions. Secondly, implemented in CNTFET 7 nm technology, the proposed PRNG achieves significant gains. Comprehensive analysis shows a 7.9x improvement in area efficiency and a 2.2x enhancement in energy efficiency based on logic synthesis results, compared to a Si 7 nm equivalent node. The physical chip realizes a compact 0.001509 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> area and delivers a high 1422.22 Gbps throughput. Finally, NIST tests and application experiments were conducted, and the results show that:(1) The design passes NIST randomness tests, confirming its excellent randomness; (2) It achieves higher precision and lower correlation in stochastic computing, further demonstrating its superior randomness.

title: On the Instability of Nesterov’s ODE under Non-Conservative Vector Fields
authors: Daniel E. Ochoa, Mahmoud Abdelgalil, Jorge I. Poveda
abstract: We study the instability of Nesterov’s ODE in non-conservative settings, where the driving term is not necessarily the gradient of a potential function. While convergence properties under Nesterov’s ODE are well-characterized for settings with gradient-based driving terms, we show that the presence of arbitrarily small non-conservative terms can lead to instability. To resolve the instability issue, we study a regularization mechanism based on restarting. For this mechanism, we establish novel explicit bounds on the resetting period that ensure the decrease of a suitable Lyapunov function, thereby guaranteeing stability and “accelerated” convergence rates under suitable smoothness and monotonicity properties on the driving term. Numerical simulations support our results.

title: A Fault Diagnosis Model of Graph Causal Convolutional Network Driven by Multi-channel Signal Fusion
authors: Yinchuan Hou, Jian Tang, Jing Zhang, Pengfei Pang, Hao Zhang, Xinxin Li
abstract: To address the challenges of feature extraction and complex signal fusion in the fault diagnosis of rotating machinery involving multi-channel non-stationary time-varying signals, an intelligent diagnosis model based on wavelet transform and graph causal convolution network is proposed. This model jointly represents the spatial topological relationship and temporal dynamic characteristics of multi-channel time-varying signals. In the spatial dimension, the model quantifies the similarity among multi-channel signals through multi-scale wavelet decomposition to construct spatial subgraphs, and uses graph convolution to complete multi-channel feature fusion. In the time dimension, a causal convolution network is used to perform convolution operations on the spatial subgraphs of consecutive time steps to deeply explore the dynamic evolution patterns of the signals. Comparative experiments on two typical non-stationary time-varying signal datasets, show that the proposed model demonstrates significant advantages under different signal-to-noise ratios.

title: Solution Based on GUM to Solve the Curse of Dimensionality in Uncertainty Quantification: A Fresh Perspective
authors: Yiwen Zhang, Vikass Monebhurrun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is essential across various scientific and engineering disciplines, including computational electromagnetics (CEM). While commonly used techniques such as Monte Carlo simulation and non-intrusive polynomial chaos (NIPC) expansion methods provide valuable insights about UQ in CEM, they often face the curse of dimensionality, rendering them computationally expensive in high-dimensional problems. In contrast, the Guide to the Expression of Uncertainty in Measurement (GUM) is a well-established, structured and widely accepted framework for evaluating uncertainty in measurements. This paper introduces a novel approach for tackling UQ in CEM by integrating GUM principles. It is exemplified by application of UQ for specific absorption rate (SAR) calculations. By thoroughly analyzing distinct sources of uncertainty and incorporating input correlations, this method is shown to be a computationally efficient alternative to traditional UQ techniques. Leveraging the law of propagation of uncertainty, the proposed approach not only reduces computational costs but also maintains the accuracy and interpretability of UQ results.

title: Microstrip Line-Integrated Spiral Resonator-Based Planar Sensor with Truncated Ground for Precision Soil Moisture and pH Sensing
authors: Swaranpreet Kaur, Surinder Singh, M.M. Sinha
abstract: Accurate assessment of soil moisture content (SMC) and soil pH is crucial for optimizing agricultural productivity, maintaining environmental sustainability, and preserving soil ecosystem health. SMC influences plant growth and nutrient bioavailability, while soil pH regulates microbial activity, nutrient solubility and overall soil fertility. Given their significance, developing precise, efficient, and real-time sensing technologies is essential. This work introduces a novel microstrip line-integrated spiral resonator-based planar sensor with a truncated ground, engineered for high-sensitivity soil dielectric characterization. The sensor, specifically designed to operate at 2.4 GHz, is evaluated by examining its transmission coefficient (S12), with emphasis on frequency displacement and variations in S12 magnitude under loaded conditions. Experimental validation confirms that the sensor reliably estimates dielectric constant (∈ʹr) from 1 to 15 and loss tangent between 0 and 0.2. Using these parameters, it quantifies SMC within 0%-20% with a low error of ±0.8%. For pH detection, two second-order polynomial models are employed, producing outputs for acidic (pH:3-6) and alkaline (pH:8-10) ranges relative to neutrality (pH=7). Thus, rather than providing a unique pH value, the sensor effectively indicates the degree of deviation from neutral soil conditions, demonstrating suitability for precision agriculture and environmental monitoring.

title: Bi-directional Particle Filter Fusion for Fingerprinting Indoor Localization with Few Short Tracks
authors: Xiaohao Liu, Yubin Zhao, Xiaofan Li, Cheng-Zhong Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Traditional machine learning based WiFi fingerprinting localization relies on pre-collected radio maps of the environment, which requires large data set for traning. However, it is difficult and time consuming to construct such data set in completely unknown environments. In this paper, we propose a bi-directional particle filter (Bi-PF) that achieves localization with a single walking data, requiring no prior knowledge of radio maps or environmental geometry. The Bi-PF contains two phases, which are forward and backward particle filters (FPF and BPF). In the FPF, the target is collecting the ranging information from WiFi APs, base stations or BLE tags, together with IMU data. We employ a virtual map to record the target trajectory based on the IMU data. Then, the pseudo-anchors, e.g., WiFi APs, are located on the virtual map according to the target trajectory. In the BPF, we fuse the IMU data and the ranging information from anchors to track the target on the virtual map. Experimental results indicate that the average error in real-world scenarios can reach under 3 m, while simulations with high signal-to-noise ratios (SNR) achieve 1 m. Even with limited available data, its tracking accuracy outperforms fingerprint-based positioning technologies, which can provide useful location based service for users.

title: RSEV: Toward Reliable and Secure UAV-Assisted Emergency Deliveries in Internet of Vehicles
authors: Haradhan Ghosh, Debasis Das, Satya Bagchi
abstract: Traffic congestion in urban areas poses a critical challenge for timely emergency deliveries, often delaying medical supplies, rescue equipment, and disaster relief operations. UAV-assisted IoV has emerged as a promising solution, where UAVs provide aerial mobility to bypass congested roads and support real-time traffic monitoring. However, the high mobility of UAVs exposes them to impersonation, replay, man-in-the-middle, and insider attacks, which existing protocols handle inefficiently. To overcome these challenges, we propose RSEV, a lightweight authentication protocol that combines Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) with cryptographic hash functions for strong mutual authentication under low overhead. Our contributions include: (i) formal security proofs, Scyther-based verification, and heuristic analysis confirming resilience; (ii) a Python implementation demonstrating practicality; and (iii) performance gains of 57.25% in computation cost, 34.82% in communication cost, and 48.29% in energy efficiency over existing protocols.

title: Structure-Aware Dual Adversarial Autoencoder for Unsupervised Bilingual Lexicon Induction
authors: Qian Tao, Ziyan Li, Bocheng Han, Lusi Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Bilingual lexicon induction (BLI) is a core task in multilingual natural language processing (NLP) that aims to generate cross-lingual word representations between languages. However, previous works often treat words as individual and isolated entities, neglecting the topological relationships both within a single embedding space (intra-space) and across different embedding spaces (inter-space). This restriction makes it difficult to match words from distinct language pairs with diverse topological structures, especially when the assumption of isomorphism between language spaces does not hold. Additionally, the quality of word representations is often compromised by noise introduced during insufficient pre-training of models, resulting in unstable and inaccurate BLI outcomes. To tackle these challenges, we propose a novel framework, named Structure-Aware Dual Adversarial Autoencoder (SA-DAAE), which explicitly captures diverse topological structure information and improves language alignment in an unsupervised manner. In the model, two lightweight graph convolutional networks (GCNs) are first utilized to discover intra-space topological correlations within monolingual embedding spaces and then generate refined embedding representations. Next, a dual denoising autoencoder (DAE) module is introduced to remove noise from the embeddings and explore inter-space topological structures, facilitating the initial alignment of two languages into a shared latent space. To further refine the coarse-grained alignment, we design a pairwise embedding fine-tuning (PEF) strategy, which operates independently of the global isomorphic assumption and enables word-specific transformations in a fully unsupervised manner. Through extensive experiments on several datasets across fifteen language pairs, comprising both low and high isomorphic relationships, we demonstrate the generalization and effectiveness of SA-DAAE.

title: Vehicle Profiling-Aware Personalized Federated Low-rank Adaptation in IoVs
authors: Sa Xiao, Xiaoge Huang, Mu Zhou, Chengchao Liang, Qianbin Chen
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) facilitates collaborative model training while preserving data privacy in Internet of Vehicles (IoVs). However, the traditional FL faces challenges including accuracy degradation caused by multi-dimensional heterogeneity among Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs) and excessive communication overhead during training. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Vehicle Profiling-aware Federated Low-rank Adaptation (VPFLA) framework that achieves communication-efficient Personalized FL (PFL) based on CAV characteristics. A Vehicle Profiling (VP) module transforms CAV characteristics into profile vectors, which will assist the Federated Low-rank Adaptation (FLORA) module to separate global and local knowledge through LoRA with low communication overhead. Moreover, the VPFLA framework uses profile vectors and accuracy feedback to adaptively balance knowledge coordination among CAVs. Simulation results show that the proposed VPFLA achieves 95.97% accuracy with up to 99.97% reduction in communication overhead, validating its effectiveness in IoVs.

title: Mean-Shift Theory and Its Applications in Swarm Robotics: A New Way to Enhance the Efficiency of Multirobot Collaboration
authors: Guibin Sun, Jinhu Lü, Kexin Liu, Zhenqian Wang, Guanrong Chen
abstract: Swarms evolving from collective behaviors among multiple individuals are commonly seen in nature, which enables biological systems to exhibit more efficient and robust collaboration. Creating similar swarm intelligence in engineered robots poses challenges to the design of collaborative algorithms that can be programmed at large scales. The assignment-based method has played an eminent role for a very long time in solving collaboration problems of robot swarms. However, it faces fundamental limitations in terms of efficiency and robustness due to its unscalability to swarm variants. This article presents a tutorial review on recent advances in assignment-free collaboration of robot swarms, focusing on the problem of shape formation. A key theoretical component is the recently developed mean-shift exploration strategy, which improves the collaboration efficiency of large-scale swarms by dozens of times. Further, the efficiency improvement is more significant as the swarm scale increases. Finally, this article discusses three important applications of the mean-shift exploration strategy, including precise shape formation, area coverage formation, and maneuvering formation, as well as their corresponding industrial scenarios in smart warehousing, area exploration, and cargo transportation.

title: Integrated Dual Inverter for PMSM Drive Systems Under Single-Phase AC Power Supply
authors: Taiju Sakurai, Hitoshi Haga
abstract: This paper proposes a single-phase ac power supplied dual inverter integrated with a rectifier to enhance the output voltage of motor drive systems. The proposed dual inverter combines the topology of a dual inverter with a common dc bus and a four-leg inverter. The proposed configuration achieves a higher output voltage than conventional motor drive systems under an ac power supply while requiring fewer power devices than conventional dual inverters. In addition, a phase control method is introduced to suppress the modulation index at specific electrical frequencies. The proposed control method maintains a constant phase difference between the input voltage phase and the electrical angle of the motor by slightly adjusting the rotor speed reference. Experimental results show that the proposed dual inverter performs both rectification and motor drive operations, achieving a source power factor of 99.6% while controlling the rotor speed to 1700 rpm. The proposed phase control reduces the amplitude of the voltage reference by up to 55.0 % when the electrical frequency is equal to the source frequency; however, the proposed control method increases the torque ripple by 40 %. Consequently, the proposed dual inverter improves the inverter output voltage in single-phase ac power-supplied motor drive systems.

title: Blockchain in dual-distribution markets under demand uncertainty: Mitigating gray trade through penalty design
authors: Jianghua Wu, Hongya Cheng
abstract: This study examines how brand owners use blockchain technology to address the challenges posed by gray market activities under demand uncertainty. First, by utilizing blockchain's downward traceability feature, the brand can precisely track the flow and quantities of gray market products. Then, using real-time updated product information, smart penalty contracts are employed to penalize gray marketer, thereby mitigating the impact of gray market invasion. Within a dual-distribution model, we find that the retailer's gray market behavior in the low-price market harms the high-price market retailer. However, the brand may benefit from the gray market when the market size disparity is large and the proportion of loyal consumers in the high-price market is relatively low. Blockchain adoption effectively reduces the gray market scale, thus benefiting the high-price retailer, particularly when market size disparity is relatively high. Research shows that when blockchain cost and penalty fees meet certain conditions, blockchain can achieve a win-win-win situation for the brand and both retailers. Crucially, higher demand variance strengthens the brand's willingness to adopt blockchain to combat gray market. The results also show that excessive blockchain cost would reduce the brand's willingness to adopt, consumer surplus, and social welfare. However, lower demand variance or a higher proportion of loyal consumers expands the conditions under which blockchain can enhance social welfare.

title: Intelligent Condition Monitoring for Battery Cell Manufacturing Equipment: A Dynamic Dilated Transformer Approach
authors: Shantao Zhao, Zhanglin Peng, Xiaonong Lu, Qiang Zhang, Jiawen Xu, Shanlin Yang
abstract: With the rapid development of the new energy sector, production equipment for battery cells faces increasing challenges in maintaining efficiency and quality. Among these, the laser die cutting and winding machine plays a pivotal role in transforming electrode sheets into finished cells. Its performance directly affects the dimensional precision and internal structural consistency of the cells, which are critical to product quality and production-line efficiency. To tackle the challenges in monitoring and maintaining this critical equipment, we propose a time-series data-driven method based on the Transformer architecture, named multiscale dynamic dilated attention, which effectively predicts sensor offset trajectories and provides early shutdown fault warnings when correction sensors approach their operational limits. Furthermore, this model incorporates adjustable segment sizes and counts, and assigns distinct dilation rates to individual attention heads, this design enables a dynamic tradeoff among receptive field, modeling capacity, and computational cost, allowing fine-grained control over long-range dependence modeling while reducing the canonical self-attention complexity from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O(\mathit {L}^{2})$</tex-math></inline-formula> to approximately <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O(\mathit {L})$</tex-math></inline-formula>. Extensive experiments and real-world applications demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance in both prediction accuracy and practical deployment, while exhibiting excellent adaptability across diverse operating conditions.

title: Exploring Roles and Purposes in More-than-Human Design through a Reflexive Design Studio Experiment
authors: Çağlar Genç, Ferran Altarriba Bertran, Oğuz Buruk, Sangwon Jung, Velvet Spors, Juho Hamari
publish: Proceedings of the 28th International Academic Mindtrek
abstract: We are witnessing a shift towards a more-than-human (MtH) paradigm in HCI, recognizing non-human beings as interconnected in our existence, from daily life to design. While exciting MtH design works have emerged, they often rely on abstract concepts (e.g., decentering) that remain open to interpretation, leaving practical nuances underexplored. To address this, we adopted a bottom-up Research through Design approach, a Reflexive Design Studio: as a design team, we created and reflected on conceptual designs using the mushroom basket as a metaphor to explore human–non-human relationalities. From these, we articulated roles (e.g., humans as materials, non-humans as co-makers) and purposes (e.g., activism, collective survival, approximation) that illustrate how MtH design might be practiced with nuances. Relating these to theory and prior work, we contribute an exploratory framework offering generative and critical starting points for future MtH design research to test, contest, expand, and engage with MtH complexities in practice.
