title: Sociotechnical Imaginaries of Digitally Altered Minds in 2050: Functions, Citizens, and Societal Tensions
authors: Terho Ojell-Järventausta, Anatolii Belousov, Mila Bujić, Joseph Macey, Juho Hamari
publish: Proceedings of the 28th International Academic Mindtrek
abstract: Adding to the list of practices permeated by digital technologies, in recent years, domains related to altered states of consciousness (ASC) (e.g. psychedelic experiences) have also seen an increasing number of digital implementations. While implementations at the intersection of HCI and ASC mostly represent weak signals, there is a need for anticipatory research to explore the possible implications of digitally induced altered states of consciousness (DIAL). To address this, we adopted the Futures Clinique method to map out DIAL-related sociotechnical imaginaries through two futures workshops, capturing collective anticipations expressed in narrative scenarios created by participants. These scenarios were then analysed using reflexive thematic analysis, revealing common themes and relationships between them across groups and implementations. The themes were categorised into three areas: (1) the societal functions of DIAL technologies, (2) the citizen types ("Subjects") shaped by DIAL, and (3) the societal tensions and contradictions arising around their use. Additionally, to explore the relationships between these themes we used network visualisation. This work contributes to the HCI field by providing the first study of its kind to explore the collective anticipations relate to futures of DIAL through participatory workshops. Furthermore, the emergent framework offers a broader contribution to HCI by providing a blueprint for portraying the implications of emerging technologies through collaborative speculation.

title: A 22nm Coarse-Grained Reconfigurable Array with Novel Features for Machine Learning and Digital Signal Processing
authors: Waqar Hussain, Alexandra Geciova, Ralf Hekmann, Henry Hoffmann, Zohaib Hassan, Jari Nurmi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: This article presents a highly compact Coarse-Grained Reconfigurable Array (CGRA) specialized for processing Digital Signal Processing (DSP) and Machine Learning (ML) operations with an outstanding micro-architectural efficiency. The CGRA consists of high functionality Processing Elements (PEs) supported by strategically placed interconnections and bidirectional data buffers made of programmable cyclic registers. These novel features accelerate large length correlations, Fast Fourier Transforms and other DSP/ML related functions. It is a resource compact CGRA with very small dimensions, i.e., <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> PEs and synthesized using a 22nm CMOS technology. The design of CGRA has an AMBA interface making it an industry standard coprocessor for a system-on-chip. The novelty presented in this paper is an accepted United States patent.

title: Automated Text Coherence Evaluation in Academic Reports Using Transformer Based Networks
authors: Bhupathi Vishva Pavani, Thanmai Gaddam, Peeta Basa Pati
abstract: Assessing the coherence of academic reports is essential to evaluate the logical flow and organization of written content. This paper presents an approach to classify text coherence using draft papers of students in the domain of machine learning. The dataset is pre-processed using common Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques such as tokenization, stop-word and punctuation removal, and lemmatization before being applied to the proposed methodology. The methodology, employs BERT, LEGAL-BERT, RoBERTa, FastText and T5 to generate sentence embeddings, which are then given as input to the Recurrent Neural Networks, including LSTM, BiLSTM, GRU, Dilated RNN and Attention RNN models along with traditional ML models like Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine(SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Multi Layer Perceptron (MLP), XGBoost (XGB), and LightGBM (LGBM) to perform the classification task. To address class imbalance in the dataset, Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) is employed. The performance of the models is evaluated using metrics such as accuracy and F1-score to demonstrate the efficiency of deep learning and machine learning models in coherence classification. LegalBert with BiLSTM have the highest metrics with a test accuracy of 64.08%. This study aims to identify the most effective models for coherence classification, facilitating the development of automated tools for mentors to assess and enhance the logical coherence of student reports.

title: SimST: Simulation Framework for Energy-Dataflow Co-Optimization in Spike-Driven Transformer
authors: Yunhao Ma, Yanyu Lin, Wanyi Jia, Puli Quan, Mingjing Li, Zhiwei Zhong, Fengwei An, Huihui Zhou
abstract: Transformer models deliver state-of-the-art accuracy in tasks but incur prohibitive energy costs. Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) offer an event-driven alternative with sparse activations enabling ultra‑low‑power operation. Studies explore hybrid architectures combining the sparse, event‑driven dynamics of SNNs with Transformer attention mechanisms to retain performance. However, there is no systematic evaluation methodology for these Spike-Driven Transformer. In this paper, we introduce a unified evaluation flow for the Spike-Driven Transformer that integrates memory-access and compute-energy modeling across four operations in the Spiking Transformer Block (STB): Matrix Multiplication, Batch Normalization, Leaky Integration-and-Fire activation, and Residual connection. Besides, a two-level dataflow-energy co-optimization for MM in STB inference assesses inner reuse strategies (weight-, output-, and input-stationary) alongside outer loop orderings. Experiments on ImageNet-scale workloads reveal that combining inner output stationary IOS (inner output-stationary) flow with outer loop orderings OOS (outer output-stationary) minimizes energy and latency. Compared with the real hardware, only 4.6% power inconsistency of our evaluation is calculated. Our methodology establishes the first end-to-end energy-dataflow co-optimization foundation for Spike-Driven Transformers and delivers insights for the design of ultra-low-power neuromorphic accelerators.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Antenna Design and Optimization
authors: Fatma Taher, Mariam Ahmed Hafez, Mohamed Fathy Abo Sree, Sara Yehia Abdel Fatah
abstract: Machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL)-enabled artificial intelligence (AI) has revolutionized the design and optimization of antennae through data-driven, automated methods to minimize cycle times while providing optimal performance. New prospects of AI applications in antenna engineering are being discussed in this article, some of which include surrogate models, evolutionary algorithms, regression models, and hybrids. It refers to ML-optimized 5G patch antennas, AI-algorithm comparative studies, and new strategies. It also provides real-world implications of using AI in designing 5G, 6G, IoT, and medical devices based on observations. The paper ends with a remark regarding challenges and future research directions in antenna designing based on ML/DL..

title: A $28-\text{GHz}$ Monostatic OFDM-Based ISAC System on RFSoC with Real-Time Processing
authors: Yizheng Wu, Arif Rahmadian Arifianto, Vishnu Unnikrishnan, Anteneh A. Gebremariam, Liang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: This research presents the design and implementation of an Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) system with real-time processing utilizing Cyclic Prefix Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (CP-OFDM) modulation on a Zynq UltraScale+ Radio Frequency System-on-Chip (RFSoC) platform. It is the first monostatic-radar-based OFDM ISAC system implemented on an FPGA, utilizing the same OFDM waveform for communication and radar purposes. In-door measurements with hardware implementation on Programmable Logic (PL) are conducted to validate the functionality and determine the performance of the developed ISAC system, which achieves a 7.23 times of execution time boost in comparison to detection using Processing System (PS). This research demonstrates the feasibility of implementing a functional real-time OFDM ISAC system purely on hardware.

title: Insights from Amazon Reviews through Machine Learning-Aided Sentiment Analysis and NMF-based Topic Modeling
authors: Wenjie Dang, Nevena Rankovic
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: This study evaluates six machine learning models in sentiment analysis on e-commerce consumer reviews from three leading cosmetic brands. Among these, SVM, Naive Bayes and Random Forest are the most widely used conventional models in recent years, despite exhibiting certain limitations when processing sparse and non-linear text data. While gradient boosting models (XGBoost, CatBoost, and LightGBM) have demonstrated superior performance across various domains, their effectiveness in e-commerce sentiment analysis remains under-explored. To address this gap, this study compares these models to identify the most effective approach for sentiment analysis on e-commerce consumer reviews. The results indicate that SVM achieved the highest accuracy and F1 score, while CatBoost and LightGBM also exhibit robust performance under computational constraints. In addition, NMF-based topic modeling is applied to extract key product attributes that are frequently mentioned across different sentiment polarities. This combined approach not only enhances our understanding of consumer emotional responses but also provides actionable insights for product innovation and marketing strategies in the competitive beauty and personal care market.

title: Similarity Network Fusion for Multi-Omics Data Integration in Cancer Subtyping
authors: Anirban Bhar, Aliviya Jana, Lakshmi Abhigna Mattay, P. Subanaveen, Dhanush Reddy Yarkareddy
abstract: Cancer’s biological heterogeneity poses significant challenges for subtyping and personalized treatment. Multi-omics data, including gene expression, DNA methylation, and miRNA expression, offers potential for identifying distinct cancer subtypes but is often high-dimensional and incomplete. Conventional methods relying on imputation or sample exclusion risk losing critical biological information [10]. This paper proposes a robust framework using Multiple Similarity Network Embedding (MSNE) to integrate incomplete multi-omics data without imputation. By constructing similarity networks with Gaussian kernels, normalizing local neighborhoods, and fusing them into a unified graph, patient embeddings are generated via random walks and clustered using unsupervised algorithms. Evaluated on a dataset with 30% simulated missingness, the approach achieves high-quality clusters (Silhouette=0.595, NMI=0.710 for k = 3), demonstrating robustness and advancing precision oncology.

title: MDDOAI: A Model-Driven DevOps Approach to CI/CD Automation
authors: Uldis Karlovs-Karlovskis, Oksana Nikiforova, Oscar Pastor, Kristijans Vēveris
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: Since its emergence in 2009, DevOps has significantly transformed software engineering by streamlining integration and delivery workflows. While prior research has extensively examined DevOps practices and their evolution, limited attention has been given to automated generation of Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery (CI/CD) pipelines directly from high-level software architecture models. Addressing this gap, Model-Driven DevOps with AI (MDDOAI) introduces a model-to-code solution that bridges the abstraction gap between design and deployment. It leverages Atlas Transformation Language (ATL) for model-to-model transformation and Acceleo for code generation, enabling the automated synthesis of deployable CI/CD pipeline configurations. The resulting prototype demonstrates the feasibility of scalable, model-driven automation in DevOps, offering a structured foundation for future extensible and maintainable pipeline engineering.

title: FEA and Experimental Studies of MOS Microgas Sensor with Integrated In-plane Microheater
authors: Annliya Raju, Nivedhitha V Anil, T A Archana, C D Seethalakshmi, M V Akshaya, K Amala, Palash Kumar Basu, S Krishnapriya, Tony C Thomas
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Metal Oxide Semiconductor based Microgas Sensors are widely employed for detecting even a trace amount of gas, with widespread applications in detection of poisonous gases for environmental monitoring and biomedical fields. Sensing layers in microgas sensors can be suitably optimized to detect target gases. Metal Oxide Semiconductors (MOS) is a sensitive structure for gas sensing due to its superior performances. A microheating layer with an interdigitated electrode (IDE) is useful to excite and activate the sensing layer. In this work, the scope of Finite Elemental Analysis (FEA) is explored to analyse the electrical and thermal performance of the electrode and heater layers, while experimental validation ensures its accuracy. The sensitivity of the methane gas sensor was found to be optimal at $300^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, with a maximum sensitivity of $65 \%$. The sensor exhibits high sensitivity, saturation and recovery, making it an efficient tool for sensing applications. The simulation of in-plane microheater with interdigitated electrodes is performed using the software COMSOL Multiphysics.

title: LOGI-CHAIN: Blockchain Based Transparent Logistics Management
authors: Sathish Kumar A P, K. Saravanan, Monica T, Nithish Kumar K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The logistics industry faces increasing demands for secure, transparent, and efficient handling of shipment documents and compliance data across the globe. This work presents a blockchain-based architecture integrated with a decentralized private IPFS cluster storage system to ensure dynamic, privacy-preserved, tamper-proof document exchange and real time tracing of the related transactions across supply chain stakeholders. By leveraging Ethereum based smart contract, the system facilitates shipment validations, and delivery confirmations without intermediaries, while the AES encrypted documents are stored off-chain using IPFS to reduce blockchain bloat and enhance scalability. Users joining the platform automatically contribute to the storage network by hosting IPFS nodes, ensuring decentralized participation. The inclusion of end-to-end encryption using Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH) strengthens data authenticity and confidentiality during transmission. The stakeholders are allowed to connect and disconnect from the network dynamically without any centralized authority in a plug and play fashion. The system ensures immutable recordkeeping, real-time access to critical data, and improved trust among entities such as shippers, carriers, customs, and financial institutions. This approach addresses key challenges such as data traceability, secure access, and compliance reporting, offering a robust, scalable, and future-ready solution for modern logistics and cross-border trade documentation. By uniting blockchain and decentralized storage, the architecture promotes operational resilience, auditability, and seamless collaboration across the global supply chain. The work is evaluated using Ethereum based Sepolia testnet to test its integrity and standard performance metrics which demonstrates the effectiveness of the implementation.

title: Interactive Transaction Tracker to Validate Data Integrity of the Compression and Decompression Engines in Neural Camera Applications
authors: Surajit Bhattacherjee, Dipankar Pal
abstract: Data integrity is a key measure in signing-off mission-critical design modules like neural camera with compression and decompression engines. Such modules are directly associated with the safety and security of human-life in Automatic Driver Assistance System, remote surgery, security systems etc. The conventional methods namely, functional and formal verification partly fail to cover the end-to-end validation of the data path. Neural camera, signal processor, memory are independent components which interact without the knowledge of authenticity of incoming data. Different image formats with lossy and lossless compression are beyond the scope of functional verification. The proposed methodology offers a transaction tracker with metadata extractor to validate performance of neural camera network, data integrity and other criteria through entire transaction pipeline. The results show significant improvement in error detection, verification time and quality metrics compared to conventional methods. The experimental setup, results and conclusions have been derived with a special reference to automotive use-case but the same can also be implemented over any neural camera application.

title: Energy-Efficient Llama3 Acceleration on a CGLA by Offloading Computational Kernels
authors: Takuto Ando, Yu Eto, Ayumu Takeuchi, Yasuhiko Nakashima
abstract: The evolution of Large Language Models (LLMs) has led to a substantial increase in energy consumption, making energy-efficient accelerator technologies essential. We propose a method to maximize the performance of the Llama3 LLM on IMAX3, a CGRA-based accelerator. We conducted a detailed analysis of the Q3_K_S quantization method. Based on this analysis, we implemented a new custom kernel to offload the Q6_K operations to the hardware. In previous work, this operation was processed on the host CPU. This targeted optimization reduced the end-to-end latency by approximately 11%. Furthermore, an evaluation of a projected ASIC implementation showed that the absolute performance does not match that of a GPU. In contrast, our approach achieves superior power efficiency, as measured by the Power-Delay Product (PDP).

title: Stability study of autonomous underwater vehicles: design, modelling, simulation and evaluation
authors: Saber Hachicha, Chiheb Zaoui, Ahmed Moulhi, Helmi Abrougui, Anas Zaouali, Habib Dallagi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This article examines in detail the factors influencing the stability of autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs), which are essential for marine applications such as exploration, surveillance and mapping. The study uses mathematical modelling, numerical simulations and an in-depth analysis of stability criteria to optimize AUV design. The results highlight the importance of geometric configurations, stabilizers and hydrodynamic forces.

title: AI-based Management of a Hybrid Power Plant
authors: Hamadi Bouaicha, Tarek Azzabi, Issam Hemdana, Habib Dallagi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) opens up exciting opportunities in managing electrical energy for hybrid multisource power plants. It enables the optimization of production, distribution, and consumption while addressing challenges such as reliance on intermittent renewable energy sources, load uncertainty, and power system complexity. Optimal management of hybrid power systems for military sites is crucial because it improves system efficiency, survivability, and stability making the military facility more energy self-sufficient and less dependent on external utilities. Therefore, we intend by this research to suggest an optimal design and sizing of a multi-source power plant that can effectively empower a military base. For this reason, HOMER Pro software was employed not only to provide the optimal design and sizing of the hybrid power plant but also to assess the technical and economic feasibility of the suggested power system. Moreover, we studied the power management of the suggested power plant such as load forecasting, power generation and power storage scheduling, and power exchange with the commercial grid. For load forecasting, we have provided two different approaches: the first one by minutiousely combining several standards load profiles of Homer and then by defining a Machine Learning approach using Linear Regression models. Besides, for power generation management, we have provided a flowchart-based algorithm that allows a day-ahead scheduling of power generation, power storage and power exchange. Several scenarios were studied and the results were analyzed and commented.

title: Employing Deep Learning Framework using MRI for Accurate Brain Tumor Detection
authors: D Baswaraj, D Chitra, VenkataSeshaiah Banka, Shilpa Kottapally, K Rama Rao, Sajan Mathew
abstract: Brain tumors (BTs) are dangerous for adults because they rapidly produce aberrant brain cells and can cause organ failure and death. MRI is essential for finding malignant tumors. We offer a revised You-Only-Look-Once-version7 (YOLOv7) design to correctly recognize meningioma, glioma, and pituitary gland tumors in an improved brain tumor detection system. The curated data includes 2548 glioma photos, 2658 pituitary images, 2582 meningioma images, and 2500 non-tumor images. We added the Convolutional-Block-Attention-Module(CBAM) attention mechanism to YOLOv7 to improve feature extraction and highlight brain cancer-related regions. Used Spatial-Pyramid-Pooling-Fast+ (SPPF+) layer to the network's fundamental infrastructure to improve model sensitivity. With decoupled heads, YOLOv7 can quickly gain insights from a range of sources. Another feature is Bidirectional. Pyramid Network (BiFPN) speeds multi-scale feature fusion and improves tumor feature collection. The results show that our strategy is more effective than state-of-the-art tumor detection models. This paradigm could aid BT diagnosis professionals in decision-making.

title: A Deep Learning-Based Predictive Policing Model for Real-Time Crime Risk Assessment in Urban India
authors: Nishanthini S, Syed Fakruddin Albeez, G. Manikandan, Nakka Kishore Chandra Dev, Banashree Chatterjee, S. Kaliappan
abstract: The proposed solution to the increase in urban crime in India is to employ artificial intelligence to predict criminal behavior. As a result, this study presents a novel artificial intelligence-based system that uses a mix of machine learning, computer vision, and natural language processing to predict criminal activities. It uses a variety of data sources, including social media, socioeconomic factors, past crime reports, CCTV video, and others, to generate real-time forecasts of where crime is most likely to occur. The suggested solution, which merges CNN and RNN, improves the accuracy of predictions and boosts the techniques employed in law enforcement. These indicate that crime rates in high-risk regions have decreased by 15%, police response times have decreased by 35%, and the accuracy of predictions has decreased by 28%. Consequently, this technology has the ability to change the way that crime is prevented in cities across India by using a data-driven and proactive approach to policing. In addition, it will improve public safety and make better use of scarce resources.

title: Comparative Analysis of Newton-Raphson and Quasi-Newton Methods for Power Flow Solution in Monopolar DC Networks
authors: Oscar Danilo Montoya, Walter-Julian Gil-Gonz´Lez, Alejandro Garc´Es-Ruiz
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of the Newton-Raphson and Quasi-Newton methods for solving the power flow problem in monopolar DC distribution networks. Two Newton-Raphson formulations based on different Jacobian structures and three Quasi-Newton methods with constant Jacobian approximations are analyzed. These methods are validated on the DC versions of the IEEE 33- and 69-bus test systems and evaluated in terms of convergence rate, computational time, and accuracy of the power loss estimation. Simulation results show that while Newton-Raphson methods converge in fewer iterations, Quasi-Newton methods-particularly with fixed Jacobian approximations-offer lower processing times, making them suitable for large-scale or real-time applications.

title: A Novel Statistical-Dynamical Downscaling Model for Alpine Precipitation Analysis
authors: Raed Hamyd, Manish Bhardwaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Precipitation analysis is crucial in alpine regions, but data limitations and complex terrain make it challenging. Variations at fine scales are difficult to capture with traditional GCMs. This study proposes a hybrid statistical-dynamical downscaling (SDD) model that combines large-scale atmospheric classifications with high-resolution regional climate simulations to improve alpine precipitation estimates. Based on the ECHAM and RegCM outputs, the model is applied to Central Asia. Despite the lack of data in complex alpine regions, the approach captures precipitation dynamics effectively while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: A Comparative Study of Character Segmentation Techniques for ANPR: From Traditional Methods to Deep Learning Models
authors: Alok Raj, Hiren Kumar Thakkar
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Character Segmentation is an essential step in the text-based image recognition/processing area of the computer vision domain especially in Vehicle Automatic Number Plate Recognition (VANPR) operations. This process helps in dividing letters into different units from a captured image or scanned documents, which becomes input for character recognition steps. For the VANPR system, character segmentation is one of the key steps; wrong segmentation of characters can lead to the fetching of wrong vehicle information. Current challenges in character segmentation are noise and distortion of the captured image, images having to touch and overlapping characters, images of variable fonts and handwriting styles, and skewed and curved texts of the character images. These challenges have made character segmentation a very attractive topic of research lately. The models used in this area have evolved from traditional methods such as the Projection-based method in the 1990s to machine learning-based models such as Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Random Forests in the 2010s. Recent works from 2015 have focused more on deep learning-based methods such as FCN, R-CNN, and RNN, which are extensively used in the VANPR system.

title: OptiGuard: Intelligent System for Harmful Light Detection
authors: Sreeram Sivadasan, K Mohammed Rinshin, T Muhammed Anjal, S Shafankhan, K Jitha, B Femina
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: The “Intelligent System for Harmful Light Detection,” branded as OptiGuard, addresses the escalating concern of harmful light exposure stemming from prolonged interaction with digital devices and artificial lighting systems. T his research presents a robust and comprehensive solution that combines pre-cision light sensors (GUVA-S12SD and TSL2561) with advanced machine learning algorithms to detect and mitigate exposure to blue light, ultraviolet (UV), and infrared (IR) radiation in real-time. Numerous studies have established links between chronic exposure to these light types and adverse health effects such as digital eye strain, circadian rhythm disruption, sleep disorders, and long-term retinal degeneration. OptiGuard employs a high-performing Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM) model trained on real-world exposure datasets to classify harmful light levels with high precision. The system delivers personalized risk assess-ments by integrating multiple contextual factors, including user demographics (such as age and glasses usage), ambient light characteristics, and historical exposure patterns. The real-time data acquisition is managed through an ESP32 microcontroller that collects sensor data and communicates with a Flask-based Python backend. This backend handles data preprocessing, intelligent harm classification, and seamless communication with a cross-platform Flutter-based frontend. The frontend interface presents users with real-time insights, including UV, visible, and IR inten-sity levels, cumulative exposure durations, glasses detection status using Mediapipe and OpenCV, and harm-level alerts through an engaging and intuitive UI. The system architecture supports dynamic light pattern recognition and contextual awareness, enabling adaptive behavior according to varying environmental lighting conditions and user habits. Additionally, OptiGuard supports long-term data logging and visual trend analytics, allowing users to reflect on their exposure history and modify their usage behavior accordingly. Experimental validation has been conducted across diverse indoor and outdoor lighting scenarios, with consistent results demonstrating the system’s accuracy, responsiveness, and practical usability. OptiGuard is designed for both wearable and static use cases, making it versatile for individuals, workplaces, and health-conscious environments. This work represents a significant advancement over existing methods by providing an intelligent, proactive, and user-tailored solution to mitigate ocular risks, contributing to improved digital wellness in our increasingly screen-centric world. The modular architecture also opens pathways for future integration with smart home ecosystems, wearable health monitors, and AI-driven behavioral coaching tools. Overall, OptiGuard exemplifies the convergence of embedded systems, data science, and human-centric design in solving modern digital health challenges.

title: Resilient Machine Learning Ensemble (rMLe): Design, Analysis and Evaluation
authors: Youssif Alnashif, Salim Hariri, Zachary Benjamin, Steven Truong, Simon Khan, Erik Blasch
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: The recent advances in big multisource data and machine learning (ML) algorithms drive the proliferation of data-driven intelligent applications in many areas, including autonomous system coordination, decision support systems, recommender systems, market financial analysis, as well as intrusion detection and prevention systems. Many ML algorithmshave been integrated into multisource decision support applications to improve analysis performance and prediction. Due to the widespread usage of ML in critical decision processes (e.g., distributed and collaborative autonomous systems, air traffic controlapplications), there is an exponential growth in adversarial data manipulations that target the ML algorithms and consequently influence their decision process in favoring the attackers.In this paper, we present a methodology to self-protect the ML system as opposed to the traditional usage of ML system in security for a wide range of applications in commercial markets. We propose a resilient ML Ensemble (rMLe) architecture that ensures the ML system's resilient operations from ML attacks. The rMLe architecture leverages Moving Target Defense (MTD) and Data Anonymized Transformation (DAT) to change the ML algorithms and the training datasets used in the ML pipeline, thus ensuring resilience to adversarial ML attacks. Our experimental results and evaluations show that the rMLe can tolerate ML adversarial attacks with high accuracy and low false alarms.

title: Application of Transformer Models for Volcano Seismic Signals Classification
authors: Kevin Huertas, Noel Pèrez-Pèrez, Diego S. Benítez, Maria Baldeon-Calisto, Marco Herrera, Oscar Camacho
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: The detection and classification of volcanic seismic events are crucial for monitoring volcanic activity and minimizing natural disasters. Early identification of precursor seismic signals enables timely warnings, potentially saving lives in areas threatened by active volcanoes. We proposed an automatic seismic event classification method based on transformer models to maximize volcanic raw signal classification. The proposed method was trained and validated on the publicly available MicSigv1 dataset from the Cotopaxi volcano. The best model using a ten-fold cross-validation strategy achieved a mean of F1score, accuracy, precision, recall, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve scores of $0.959,0.959,0.960$, 0.959, and 0.970 in the training phase and $0.965,0.964,0.966$, 0.964, and 0.979 in the test phase, respectively. The successful classification performance in multiple metrics highlighted the effectiveness of the proposed method in capturing temporal dependencies from raw signals. This strength reduces the need for extensive feature extraction and complex preprocessing steps, improving the adaptability and scalability of the model for realtime monitoring systems.

title: Towards Achieving Vertical Reuse in SoC-Level Verification
authors: Petr Bardonek, Alessandra Dolmeta, Marcela Zachariášová, Guido Masera
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Recent trends in AI-assisted design and new approaches to accelerate overall design processes are contributing to the increasing complexity of System-on-Chip (SoC) designs. Unfortunately, advancement in verification methods has not kept pace, leading to a widening verification gap. This gap underscores the growing importance of reusing verification components. Although reusing components at the testbench level is possible, the portability of verification tests and scenarios in complex SoC integrations remains inadequate and underexplored. The Portable Stimulus Standard (PSS) aims to enhance reuse through a model-based approach, where Portable Models (PMs) capture the intent of verification tests in a significantly more abstract manner. Although transitioning to this higher level of abstraction is promising, it still entails a considerable manual burden, even when utilizing PSS. PMs connect to the Design Under Verification (DUV) via realization-layer bindings, which may vary as one moves from a module-level to a SoC-level context. The authors propose an automation approach, represented in their unique toolchain based on static analysis, that facilitates the binding of modular PMs to a top-level PM. This paper demonstrates the application of this toolchain in a full SoC integration context, using a Keccak cryptographic accelerator integrated through both loosely coupled and tightly coupled architectures as the DUV. The study illustrates that static analysis can support vertical reuse across multiple design hierarchy levels. However, as integration reaches the SoC scale, it increasingly intersects with software-driven control and structural encapsulation, necessitating additional modeling efforts. These findings define the limitations of structural automation for vertical reuse and outline directions for enhancing methodologies and tool support for SoCscale verification.

title: Secure and Decentralized Peer-to-Peer Energy Transactions using Blockchain Technology
authors: Antar Kumar Biswas, Masoud H. Nazari
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: This paper presents an optimal peer-to-peer (P2P) energy transaction mechanism leveraging decentralized blockchain technology to enable a secure and scalable retail electricity market for the increasing penetration of distributed energy resources (DERs). A decentralized bidding strategy is proposed to maximize individual profits while collectively enhancing social welfare. The market design and transaction processes are simulated using the Ethereum testnet, demonstrating the blockchain network’s capability to ensure secure, transparent, and sustainable P2P energy trading among DER participants.

title: EfficientNetB0 vs. VGG16 vs. ResNet-50: Classification of Various Skin Diseases Using Deep Learning
authors: Arijit Kumar Khanra, Mayank Kumar, Ankita Mandal, Siddhartha Chatterjee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Skin disorders are one of the most often diagnosed conditions among the mass population, but because of their visual similarity and need for specialized knowledge, it is still challenging to identify them quickly and correctly. In this work, we have built a deep learning model for the classification of skin disease using pre-trained neural network architectures such as EfficientNet B0, VGG16, and ResNet-50. The model has been trained on a selected dataset from Kaggle and other public datasets that comprise eight different classes. In our experiment, EfficientNetB0 has given the best performance in terms of accuracy, achieving a test accuracy of 97.86% and training accuracy of 99.93% with minimal loss. The results have demonstrated the feasibility and effectiveness of using lightweight pre-trained networks for dermatological image classification. This technique will help dermatologists establish accurate diagnoses, especially in remote or undeveloped areas.

title: Neuromorphic UAS Object Avoidance and Path Detection Using DroNet
authors: Brian Millikan, Lauren Reinerman-Jones, Daniel Barber
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: The use of Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) has increased in military operations, especially with the war in the Ukraine. UASs are being used for Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR), coordinated air and ground mobility, counter-UAS, attritable assets, and more. In contested environments, GPS and RF communications are often restricted or denied, driving the need for greater autonomy. Such autonomy requires navigation that includes obstacle avoidance and path finding. Current computing technology for autonomy and inference for a vast majority of neural network models uses nVidia’s Graphics Processing Unit (GPU). However, the payload on a UAS is limited and therefore, low Size, Weight, and Power (SWaP) solutions that deliver low latency, high throughput autonomy processing are desired. The present paper details neuromorphics as a viable solution to the SWaP and latency needs for UAS autonomy.

title: A Novel CNN-Based Approach for Accurate Binary Classification of Diabetes Using Clinical Data
authors: Praveen Kumar Mannepalli, Kirat Kaur, Piyush Kumar Singh, Santosh Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Millions of individuals worldwide suffer from a chronic metabolic disease called diabetes. Conventional diagnos-tic techniques frequently depend on expert interpretation and clinical testing, which can be time-consuming and necessitate a high level of medical competence. The proposed work in this manuscript provides a deep learning-based method for classifying diabetes as either healthy or unhealthy using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). A structured dataset comprising important medical parameters like insulin, glucose levels, BMI, and other pertinent biomarkers is used to train the algorithm. The CNN architecture is tuned with the right layers, activation functions, and regularization algorithms to guarantee great accuracy. The suggested model shows promise as a dependable method for automated diabetes detection with a classification accuracy of 96 % following extensive training and validation. This work offers a potential path for upcoming AI-driven healthcare solutions while highlighting the usefulness of deep learning in medical diagnosis.

title: Hardware Trustworthiness Architecture based on Resilience
authors: Francis Wolff, William McQuay, Chris Papachistou, William S. Clay
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: The trustworthiness of third-party intellectual property design blocks before and after fabricating in a foundry makes the hardware trojan detection problem challenging. The multiplicity of hardware trojans will become commonplace due to the growing complexity of integrated circuits. A trustworthiness architecture based on resilience, redaction and reliability techniques is presented.

title: Energy-Efficient FlashAttention Acceleration on CGLA
authors: Ayumu Takeuchi, Yu Eto, Takuto Ando, Yasuhiko Nakashima
abstract: Transformer-based models, including GPT, BERT, and ViT, rely on the Attention mechanism to capture long-range dependencies but suffer from quadratic complexity in computation and memory usage, limiting scalability and energy efficiency. FlashAttention mitigates these issues by reducing memory overhead via fused kernels and online softmax while preserving exact attention; however, its applicability to low-power accelerators remains unexplored. This work adapts FlashAttention to IMAX3, a coarse-grained linear array (CGLA) architecture optimized for high-throughput, energy-efficient processing. The matrix multiplication bottleneck is offloaded to IMAX3 with a blocked computation scheme and data layouts tailored to its 512 KiB on-chip memory, minimizing off-chip data transfers. Experimental results on CPU, GPU, and IMAX3 show that FlashAttention on IMAX3 achieves a 3–5× speedup over standard Attention on the same hardware. For short sequence lengths, IMAX3 outperforms an RTX 4090 GPU in energy–delay product, demonstrating its potential for low-power generative AI acceleration.

title: Epileptic Seizure Detection from EEG Signals Using a Subject-Dependent Approach
authors: Kamil Grzegorzewski, Andrzej Majkowski, Marcin Kołodziej
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: This paper presents research on the detection of epileptic seizures using the publicly available CHB-MIT dataset. The aim of the study was to determine whether there are any common, universal features that enable effective seizure detection across all 23 patients. The analyses showed that such a universal feature set does not exist. However, effective seizure detection is possible when using classifiers trained individually for each patient (subject-dependent approach). In this study, EEG signal features were extracted and selected, followed by classification using three machine learning methods: k-NN, SVM, and Random Forest. The average values of metrics such as sensitivity, precision, and F1-score ranged from 80–46%, 61–42%, and 55–48%, respectively. However, in the case of the individual (subject-dependent) approach for many patients, the selected methods achieved sensitivity and precision exceeding 90%.

title: Photonic Crystal-Based D Flip-Flops for Ultrafast Sequential Circuit Applications
authors: K R Balagopal, Nikhil Subramannian, Naveen Renny, Priya R Das, E G Anagha
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This paper introduces a simple and innovative design for an all-optical D Flip Flop (D-FF) using a photonic crystal (PC) structure. A D Flip Flop is an essential part of digital circuits, used to store and transfer data. Optical circuits, such as those using photonic crystals, offer higher speeds and smaller dimensions compared to traditional electronic circuits. Photonic crystals, with their alternating dielectric structures, create photonic band gaps (PBGs) that block specific light frequencies, essential for designing advanced logic circuits. The focus of this work is on designing an all-optical D flip-flop using photonic crystals.The design aims to create a compact, high-speed flip-flop, reducing errors and enhancing performance by utilizing photonic crystal structures with small dimensions and high accuracy. Optical computing, which uses light (photons) instead of electricity (electrons) for data processing and communication, has transformative potential in data centers. Its has several applications such as Data Storage and Retrieval, AI and Machine Learning Acceleration,, Encryption and Security in Data Centers. The proposed structure uses silicon rods in air substrate and is designed to work with the $\mathbf{1. 5 5} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m}$ wavelength commonly used in telecommunications. The design is proposed to be simple without the use of any non linear materials and acheived a contrast ratio of 10.5 dB and a low response time of 0.32 ps.

title: Aircraft Intra Wireless Communication for Cockpit Display System
authors: Peter Reji
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Aircrew in an aircraft needs to be continuously provided with real time updated information. The information includes aircraft performance data, surrounding information, potential hazards etc. Aircraft designers and manufacturers are aiming at providing real time information to the cockpit crew at a faster rate, either in visual form or as data on cockpit display system, for both fighter aircraft and commercial aircraft. This can only be achieved by incorporating the latest technology for the avionics network. Onboard networks in an aircraft, at present, have been implemented using wires. However, issues of increased weight, Electro-Magnetic Interference (EMI), installation, maintenance, modifications and increased risk of fire due to arcing and shorting of onboard cables in aircraft, has forced aircraft designers to bring in alternate technologies to tide over these problems. Accordingly wireless networks are gradually gaining relevance Wireless Avionics Intra Communication (WAIC) program is trying to harness the advantages of wireless technology for avionics. The paper proposes a wireless architecture for cockpit display system. A module which can be integrated into existing modules to support wireless communication. Testing of the proposed system was carried out using a customised module for Display Control Module.

title: The Big Cheese: Jamming Bubbles and Team Building in Global Game Jam
authors: Dustin Simpkins, Christopher Schneller, Trevor Bihl, Travis Lynn, Adam Miller
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: The Big Cheese is a satirical narrative on economic bubbles in which the player acts as a mayor who must balance the demands of their citizens with the demands of a local dairy farm, their town’s largest company and source of jobs. Gameplay revolves around players experiencing continuous demands for money and resources and will need to quickly parse information given via a news feed to help make decisions on how to allocate their limited funds based on the town’s and the dairy farm’s needs. The prototype was developed for Global Game Jam (GGJ), an annual 48-hour hackathon where a topic is revealed at the start and games are developed based upon that topic within the given time frame. The Big Cheese was developed for GGJ 2025 specifically, where the topic was declared as "Bubbles." This paper will contain a discussion of the development approach and ideation for the narrative of Big Cheese.

title: Agricultural Field Information Routing to Ad hoc Network for Field Management
authors: Parveen Ku Patra, Brojo Kishore Mishra, Biswaranjan Bhola
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Using emerging technology IoT, we can connect a huge number of physical objects and can transfer their current or functional data to the server automatically without any human intervention. As the data are unbiased in nature it is very effective for user analysis. In IoT, many sensors, actuators, and processing devices are required to get the information. And if we install these devices then challenges come in how we interconnect with them and how we transfer the data from one device to another. So again it is a very big challenge in the field of IoT and the second thing is that when we communicate in an open area most of the agricultural land is open yard. So to transfer the data in this open yard with multiple devices is again a difficult task. So because of these reasons in our proposed work, we design an ad-hoc network in which each sensor is treated as a transceiver unit, that is it can send the data to the server or receive the data from the server as well as also act as a networking device that can work as a communication agent. It means that any sensor X can connect to the other connected sensor which acts as an intermediate sensor between any new sensor and the server, the data collected by the new sensor can be sent to the server. So in the proposed work, we implemented a routing algorithm that explains how the data can transfer from one location to another location in an ad-hoc manner. The time complexity is around 20 ms and it is physically implemented and tested using 6 devices.

title: Evaluating Area-Time-Power Trade-offs in NTT Accelerators for Post-Quantum Cryptography
authors: Malik Imran, Ayesha Khalid, Ciara Rafferty, Muhammad Rashid, Máire O’Neill
abstract: This study evaluates the trade-offs between area, time, and power in an FPGA-based Number-Theoretic Transform (NTT) hardware accelerator designed for post-quantum cryptography (PQC) applications. Using CRYSTALS-Dilithium parameters as a case study, the proposed architecture integrates Cooley-Tukey and Gentleman-Sande configurations to optimize computational efficiency. A Barrett-based modular reduction enhances power efficiency, while an iterative transformation method minimizes hardware area. Performance analysis on the Artix-7 FPGA in two frequency ranges (10–40MHz and 100–250MHz) demonstrates a balanced trade-off between area-time product and power-performance-area efficiencies. The results highlight the accelerator’s suitability for energy-conscious edge computing and high-throughput cryptographic applications, making it a viable solution for PQC implementations that require optimized resource utilization.

title: Behavioral and Mental Health Analysis for Social Media Addiction Detection Using Hybrid RBF-SVM Models
authors: Irfan Abdul Karim Shaikh, Narmatha Jayachandran, Devraj Singh Chouhan, Sweta Priya, Anvesh Perada, Monika Maharishi
abstract: With the ever-increasing use of social media by teenagers, mental health providers, welfare specialists, and platform developers are increasingly worried about the prevalence of social media addiction. Thanks to ubiquitous internet access, cheap data plans, and mobile devices, these younger users—sometimes called digital naives—have unrestricted access to social media. But they don't know nearly enough about the root causes, effects, and effective mitigation tactics for problematic use. Data preprocessing, feature selection, and model training make up the three stages of the proposed approach for detecting social media addiction. To enhance the quality of the data, text preparation methods are used. To overcome the shortcomings of the conventional BoW model, a new feature selection method called BWF is introduced, which combines BoW and Word2Vec. In order to build a classifier ensemble, they first employ a domain-specific feature selection procedure and base our classifiers on RBFSVM. With a classification accuracy of 95.52%, the suggested RBFSV hybrid technique surpasses individual models. These findings prove that the model may successfully identify problematic patterns of social media use among adolescents. Insights gained from the study can help parents and platform providers develop more effective interventions to lessen the effects of social media addiction.

title: Stacked Ensemble Machine Learning Model for Anthropometric Body Fat Prediction
authors: Yash Hitesh Ganatra, Debabrata Swain, Yugandhar Manchala, Amol Bhilare, Makarand Upkare
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: In the modern era, increasingly unhealthy lifestyles have led to a rise in obesity levels. This problem now becomes a principal cause of many chronic diseases. Body Fat Percentage (BFP) is very important for accurate prediction of obesity, especially in cases like Normal Weight Disorder where metrics like BMI lose accuracy. BFP measurement techniques are unfeasible and often inaccurate. Due to this, a machine learning model has been devised to allow easy-to-deploy measurement model to be implemented for routine checks without need for expensive measurements or exposure to radiation. The model was trained on the bodyfat prediction dataset, consisting of 252 entries. This data consisted mostly of anthropometric measurements such as waist, height, abdomen and body density, which have not been used as a feature. The impact of data preprocessing, outlier removal using IsolationForest, feature engineering, feature selection, model training and ensemble methods have been discussed. The best model was stacked ensemble which showed R2 of 0.7943 and RMSE of 3.6950.

title: Exploring AI's Influence on Human Thinking: Productivity, Learning, and Cognitive Skills in the Age of XAI
authors: Patel Banshari Rahulkumar, Patel Jainee Hasmukhbhai, Patel Krish Himanshu, Pande Hemant Rameshwarkumar, Himani Trivedi
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This study analyzes the impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on an individuals cognitive, thinking behavior and making decisions. While AI improves efficiency of an individual's problem-solving, it also affects human skills such as creativity, critical thinking, and decision-making. This study explores AI tools impact on productivity, learning, and mindset across different user groups including students, professionals, and entrepreneurs. A survey has been carried out in various user groups based in order to analyze people's interaction with AI and its influence on confidence, skills, and emotions. To fetch insights, Explainable AI (XAI) techniques, viz. LIME and SHAP are implemented on the survey data. SHAP analysis reveals key drivers behind AI reliance and discomfort, such as time-saving benefits, ideation support, and peer pressure. LIME is implemented to fetch localized explanations for variations in user behavior, highlighting generational differences in task achievement and emotional response to AI. Findings show that individuals aged 25-35, especially students and employees, exhibit the highest reliance on AI, with Gen Z and Millennials experiencing the most discomfort and social pressure. These insights underscore the dual impact of AI-boosting efficiency while posing risks to human. The study advocates for responsible AI adoption that complements human intelligence.

title: Variational Autoencoders in Binary Classification of Lung Images
authors: Mahmud Isnan, Jimmy Lay, Alexander Justine Santiago, Reno Juanda, Hanmy Angel, Advendio Desandros, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: This study investigates the application of the Variational Autoencoder (VAE) model for classifying lung images obtained from chest X-ray data, with a primary focus on utilizing the encoder component of the VAE as a visual feature extractor. The VAE architecture is implemented using six different convolutional neural network backbones, namely VGG16, VGG19, ResNet50, MobileNetV2, AlexNet, and DenseNet121, to evaluate and compare their effectiveness in learning latent representations. The resulting latent vectors are used as inputs to a Multi Layer Perceptron classifier. Experimental results show that the VAE model with the ResNet50 backbone achieves the highest classification performance, with accuracy, precision, recall, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex> score all reaching 82 percent. Although the model demonstrates strong overall performance, analysis of the confusion matrix reveals that it still struggles to differentiate between normal and abnormal cases, especially in terms of sensitivity to abnormal conditions.

title: Data-Driven Control of Unified Power Flow Controller for Voltage Stability Enhancement
authors: Mohammed Ibraheem, Pirathayini Srikantha
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Voltage stability is a growing concern in power systems, especially with increasing load variability and network stress. This paper proposes a data-driven approach to control a Unified Power Flow Controller (UPFC) using a neural network trained on simulation data from the IEEE 14-bus system. The model learns to predict optimal UPFC control settings such as voltage support and shunt current. To improve resilience and scalability, we conduct a sensitivity analysis using permutation importance, which highlights the most influential features affecting voltage stability. These insights can guide feature selection when extending the approach to larger networks. Results show the model achieves high prediction accuracy and remains robust under load increases and line contingency. The method offers a lightweight, explainable alternative to conventional UPFC control strategies.

title: Geosense: a Platform for Automated Monitoring and Quality Assessment of Geospatial Web Services
authors: Guntis Mosāns, Jānis Kampars, Dāvis Immurs, Niklāvs Kadiķis, Edgars Košovojs
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: Existing solutions for geospatial web service monitoring often struggle with limited standards support and insufficient content validation. These gaps make it difficult to ensure both technical reliability and semantic accuracy in operational environments. This publication presents GeoSense, a modular platform for automated quality monitoring and content verification of geospatial web services. Motivated by these limitations, GeoSense integrates general service operational checks, static image quality assessment using structural similarity metrics, and advanced map tile comparison based on machine learning. The platform is designed to meet the requirements of OGC and INSPIRE standards, supporting both technical performance monitoring and semantic validation of map outputs. The architecture emphasizes scalability and extensibility, allowing integration of custom modules and adaptation to evolving monitoring needs. Evaluation of the core components shows that combining servicelevel metrics with automated static and dynamic image analysis improves the detection of both technical and content-related issues in geospatial services, laying the groundwork for reliable standards-based monitoring in practice.

title: Hybrid Stock Market Forecasting and Portfolio Optimization Using LSTM, ARIMA, and Modern Portfolio Theory
authors: Krishnam Raja, Uzair Shaikh, Dhiren Sidhwani, Abha Tewari
abstract: Stock market allocation optimization is a key component of financial research that seeks to maximize profits while minimizing risk. This study describes a novel approach to portfolio optimization that employs the LSTM model, the ARIMA model, and Modern Portfolio Theory (MPT). The methodology involves preprocessing historical stock data, trend prediction with the ARIMA model, portfolio allocation with MPT, and dynamic optimization with LSTM to improve predictive skills. The dataset includes a broad selection of equities from several time periods, allowing for rigorous examination. The major findings emphasize the system’s improved accuracy in stock prediction and risk management, demonstrating the possibility for integrating machine learning models with conventional finance ideas. This investigation contributes to the continued development of portfolio management strategies and demonstrates the efficacy of blended AI-driven methodologies in the financial sector.

title: A Hybrid Model for Cloud Resource Utilization Forecasting Using Machine Learning and Evolutionary Optimization
authors: Taki Alrwbaye, Sarvesh Kumar Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: To manage cloud resources efficiently, reduce costs, and improve service delivery in dynamic cloud environments, accurate forecasting is essential. The highly variable and nonlinear nature of cloud workloads often makes traditional prediction models ineffective. In this paper, Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) are integrated with evolutionary optimisation algorithms, specifically Genetic Algorithms (GAs) and Particle Swarm Optimisation (PSO), to develop a hybrid forecasting methodology. Combining GA-PSO enhances the prediction accuracy for both univariate and multivariate resource usage, with a focus on CPU and memory usage. According to experiments, FLPSONN outperforms FLGANN, FLNN, and FLPSONN in terms of mean absolute error (MAE) and percentage improvement when used with real-world cloud workload datasets. Hybrid models enable scalable and adaptive forecasting of cloud resource demands, thereby improving the efficiency and reliability of cloud service provisioning.

title: An Adaptive Density Distribution Clustering Method for Arbitrary-Shaped Datasets
authors: Chengying Wu, Qinghua Zhang, Jianming Zhan, Fan Zhao, Guoyin Wang
abstract: Density peak clustering is an effective and interpretable method for uncovering potential knowledge in unlabeled datasets with arbitrary shapes. It has been extensively studied by researchers, and a series of extended models have been proposed. The performances of these algorithms largely depend on the positions and number of cluster centers. However, accurately selecting these centers remains a challenging problem. Therefore, to address this issue, an adaptive density distribution clustering (ADDC) method based on graph theory and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-nearest neighbors is developed in this study. ADDC is a decentralized and robust clustering approach, which consists of three main components. First, an undirected neighborhood graph is constructed based on the neighbor degree defined in this article to implement a decentralized allocation strategy. Second, componentwise local density is introduced, and a new criterion for selecting density peaks is established to serve as one of the guidelines for determining the number of clusters. Third, with the neighborhood graph and density peaks, criterion-based decomposition and fusion strategies are formulated to identify clusters with multiple peaks or to detect low-density clusters without peaks. Finally, experiments and comparisons on widely used real datasets and synthetic datasets demonstrated that ADDC significantly outperforms five classical clustering methods and seven state-of-the-art density-based cluster approaches.

title: Quantum Codes Using the τ-OD MP Construction
authors: Meng Cao, Kun Zhou
abstract: In this paper, we propose an effective method called the τ-optimal defining ( τ-OD) matrix-product (MP) construction to derive infinite families of quantum codes with flexible parameters. Through this scheme, we present 100 record-breaking quantum codes, which exceed the best-known lower bounds on the minimum distances of quantum codes listed in Grassl’s online database. To this end, we need to construct infinite families of τ-OD matrices, a subclass of non-singular by columns (NSC) matrices. We begin by presenting two key results concerning matrices over general fields F with characteristic char(F) ≠ 2, which involve the construction of self-adjoint τ-monomial matrices from any invertible self-adjoint matrix. The finite field version of these results not only reveals the existence of τ-OD matrices over Fq2 for some permutation τ but also provides a general method for constructing τ-OD matrices over Fq2 for any permutation τ. We show that there exist several infinite families of τ-OD matrices over Fq2 where the permutations τ can be easily expressed. By utilizing these constructed τ-OD matrices, we present several infinite families of quantum codes with flexible parameters, many of which are record-breaking.
