title: Missing Risk Markets and Capacity Remuneration Mechanisms in Electricity-Hydrogen Systems
authors: Alessio Berdin, Laurens de Vries, Aad Correljé, Kenneth Bruninx
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Markets, Policy and Regulation
abstract: Hydrogen and derived fuels may act as long-term energy storage in climate-neutral energy systems. However, riskaverse investors will not invest in sufficient renewable electricity, back-up, electrolyzer and storage capacity if they are only remunerated for the hydrogen or electricity produced and markets for risk are missing. We develop a stochastic equilibrium model to study whether capacity markets can limit costs to consumers by restoring investments risk-neutral levels. Our results show that the efficacy of capacity markets depends on complementary instruments to ensure the availability of renewables. If riskaversion and missing markets for risk reduce renewable buildout, capacity markets in the electricity and hydrogen sectors are needed to restore the overall capacity mix and limit consumer costs. If complementary instruments lift investments in renewables, a capacity market in the electricity sector suffices. In this situation, an additional capacity market in the hydrogen sector triggers a bias toward hydrogen-fired backup capacity. This illustrates that an integrated systems perspective is required to design future energy markets.

title: Steep Subthreshold Slope Transistors for Low-Power Electronics: Evolution, Challenges, and Perspectives
authors: Rundong Jia, Chunlei Wu, Fei Liu, Qianqian Huang
abstract:
In the past few decades, the development of ICs has followed Moore’s law, and chip performance has been continuously improved based on device scaling and increased integration. However, as the device size approaches the physical limit, power tends to reach an unacceptable limit and becomes a bottleneck, limiting the clock speed of a single chip. Moreover, in recent years, with the booming development of artificial intelligence (AI) and high-performance computing (HPC) in this big data era, increasingly higher performance is required for chips. Advanced technologies, such as 3D stacking and chiplets, have been used to continuously improve chip performance, while simultaneously the power consumption of AI/HPC systems is continuously growing and has become a first-class design constraint.

Various low-power techniques have been explored in the past 20 years. New energy-efficient architectures, such as near-memory computing, computing in memory, and neuromorphic computing, are being widely investigated. Power dissipation at the circuit level can be minimized by power management technologies, such as the use of multivoltage domains, multithreshold voltages, dynamic voltages, and frequency scaling. Beyond upper-level circuit and system strategies, transistor-level design serves as a foundational research method to address power consumption challenges, and reducing the supply voltage (VDD) is one of the most effective and direct ways. From the transistor perspective, VDD is essentially determined by the voltage needed for the transition from the off state to the on state with a satisfactory on/off current ratio. A steep subthreshold slope (SS) transistor is indispensable to make a sharper transition. This article focuses on emerging transistors with a steep SS of below 60 mV/dec at room temperature that can break the fundamental physical limitations of traditional MOSFETs. They include tunneling FETs (TFETs), negative-capacitance FETs (NCFETs), and cold-source FETs (CSFETs). Their theoretical mechanisms and electronic characteristics are reviewed as well as the state of the art and future development trends. These steep-slope transistors can be further integrated with circuit- and architecture-level low-power technologies, contributing to the green and sustainable development of chips.

title: Advanced Numerical Techniques for Mitigating Electromagnetic Field Impact on the Brain: Application of an RF Source with a Silver-Glass Interface
authors: Bouali Lazhar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This study explores how electromagnetic fields from cell phones can affect the human brain and how to reduce these effects. We focused on finding materials that could act as a protective barrier between the radiofrequency (RF) source and the brain, for both adults and children. In our tests, we used a silver-glass alloy as the interface material. To understand how the electromagnetic waves interact with the brain, we used mathematical models and numerical methods, including finite element analysis and boundary calculations. We compared results with and without the silver-glass interface. The results showed that the silver-glass alloy reduced the impact of the RF waves, suggesting it could be a useful protective material. However, real-world testing is still needed to confirm these findings

title: Decentralized Energy Solutions for Rural India: Advanced Solar Management Utilizing Smart Meters and Peer-to-Peer DC Energy Networks
authors: Sandeep Roy, Pankaj Mishra, R. N Patel
abstract: Access to reliable and affordable electricity continues to pose a significant challenge in rural and tribal areas of India, where traditional grid expansion is frequently unfeasible due to geographical and economic limitations. This paper introduces a decentralized solar energy management framework that utilizes low-voltage DC micro-grids, Arduino-based smart metering, and peer-to-peer (P2P) energy sharing to fill this void. Each household is provided with an autonomous Solar Home System (SHS), linked through a local 24V DC network and monitored in real-time with custom-designed smart meters that incorporate LoRa communication modules. These meters enable ongoing monitoring of voltage, current, and SOC (State of Charge), as well as intelligent load management and dynamic energy redistribution among homes. A distributed energy exchange algorithm regulates the sharing process according to SOC thresholds, emphasizing system reliability and energy fairness. The proposed system is modeled and simulated in MATLAB/Simulink, utilizing location-specific solar irradiance data from Raipur, India. The simulation outcomes reveal enhanced energy utilization, improved battery longevity, and greater system resilience under fluctuating load and solar generation scenarios, confirming the efficacy of the decentralized P2P sharing model in rural electrification.

title: Decision Support System for Student Specialization Placement Using AHP and Preference-Based Machine Learning
authors: Achmad Fitro, Nanang Hoesen Hidroes Abbrori, Anita Safitri, Riska Dhenabayu, Renny Sari Dewi, Muhammad Febrilian Dwi Syahputra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Placing students into specialty pathways is an important decision that must consider the balance between student preferences, class quotas, and academic performance during study. This study proposes a framework that integrates the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) method in weighting with a machine learning (ML) model for optimal specialty placement for students, so that it can become a decision support system (DSS). The data are obtained from the university environment, with the final score calculated based on a combination of test results (40 %), student preferences (60 % for the first choice and 30 % for the second choice), and competency scores weighted using AHP. Three classification models, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and Neural Network, are trained to predict the most suitable specialty pathway for students' conditions. Among the three models, the Neural Network model shows the highest performance with an accuracy of 97.78 %. The final allocation system considers a maximum quota of 150 students per pathway to ensure decision-making fairness. As a result, 382 students (82 %) were admitted according to their first choice, five students (1 %) were placed in their second choice, and 63 students (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 3} \%$</tex>) were placed in a different track due to quota limitations. This approach demonstrates the effectiveness of integrating AHP and machine learning in supporting fair, transparent, and student-preference-oriented specialty placement decisions.

title: AWAAJ - A Sign Language Translator and Learning Application
authors: Kavya Ramesh Huliyurdurga, Harshita Deviprasad Khorwal, Shreya Khanvilkar, Hitakshi Arun Patil, Aasha Chavan
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Deaf-hearing communication barriers still exist in education, the workplace, and social life. This paper presents AWAAJ, a real-time, AI-based mobile app for two-way translation between Indo- Pakistani Sign Language (IPSL) and English text or voice. The system combines MediaPipe Holistic tracking and a YOLO-based hand detection module for reliable gesture recognition in different conditions. AWAAJ also has an interactive, gamified ISL learning environment featuring quizzes, progress tracking, dictionary and games to boost user engagement and retention. Preliminary user-testing with deaf users shows 82% accuracy in translation. Built to be deployed in schools and public services, AWAAJ promotes inclusive communication and accessible technology innovation.

title: Designing a Tokenomics Model for Sustainable Decentralized Science
authors: Irwansyah Saputra, Andi Saryoko, Tati Mardiana, Eni Heni Hermaliani, Indrajani Sutedja, Cahyani Budihartanti, Nanang Ruhyana, Jajang Jaya Purnama, Irfan Mahendra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: The evolving nature of scientific ecosystems demands incentive systems that can fairly and adaptively accommodate diverse forms of research contributions. Traditional reward mechanisms, which are often static and centralised, tend to overlook non-publication activities such as peer review and data sharing. In response to this challenge, this study proposes a blockchain-based scientific incentive system using a Dynamic Smart Contract approach that enables administrators to update reward policies directly without requiring contract redeployment. The system is designed with a modular architecture and integrates a key-value store to support flexible and sustainable scientific reputation tokenisation. The model is implemented using a set of simulated Ethereum smart contracts, including a separate reward policy contract and keyvalue configuration logic, without actual on-chain deployment. The system is evaluated through a two-phase conceptual simulation involving changes in reward weightings while keeping the contribution data constant. The assessment focuses on three key aspects: adaptability, fairness, and stability. The results show that the system can adjust to policy changes in real time, shifting the dominant reward from publication (526.3 tokens) to peer review (580.6 tokens) after policy revision. It maintains fairness with a Gini Index of 0.156 and demonstrates structural consistency, with total token issuance increasing from 1000 to 1999.99 without duplication or inflation. These findings indicate that the proposed dynamic contract model offers a viable foundation for developing more inclusive, transparent, and context-responsive scientific reputation systems, particularly within the emerging framework of decentralised science.

title: Improving Brain Tumour Segmentation: A study from U-Net to ResNet based Encoders
authors: Aryan Srivastava, Yash Raj Lata, Ratin Kumar, Rishi Prakash, Anand Swaroop Srivastava, Ved Prakash Dubey
abstract: The accurate segmentation of brain tumors is important for medical professionals to perform effective diagnoses. In this study we explore the impact of different encoder backbones on U-Net architecture when applied to this task. We compared a basic U-Net with two enhanced versions of U-Net where Resnet34 and ResNet-50 were used as encoder part of U-Net. Key performance metrics like Mean Intersection over Union (IoU), F1 score, precision, and recall serve as the foundation for our result analysis. The results clearly show that the model performance improves as we use more advanced encoder backbone. The basic U-Net achieved a Mean IoU of 0.8266 and an F1 Score of 0.8225. When we use a ResNet-34 based encoder, the scores improved to a Mean IoU of 0.8562 and an F1 Score of 0.8409. The best results came from the U-Net with ResNet-50 as encoder backbone, which achieved a Mean IoU of 0.8606 and an F1 Score of 0.8468. These results show that using deeper pre-trained encoders can make a real difference in how accurately we can segment brain tumors. This leads to more reliable detection, which can help medical practitioners to improve diagnoses, make better decisions and ultimately improve patient care.

title: Simopt-Power: Leveraging Simulation Metadata for Low-Power Design Synthesis
authors: Eashan Wadhwa, Shanker Shreejith
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Excessive switching activity is a primary contributor to dynamic power dissipation in modern FPGAs, where fine-grained configurability amplifies signal toggling and associated capacitance. Conventional low-power techniques – gating, clockdomain partitioning, and placement-aware netlist rewrites – either require intrusive design changes or offer diminishing returns as device densities grow. In this work, we present Simopt-power, a simulator-driven optimisation framework that leverages simulation analysis to identify and selectively reconfigure high-toggle paths. By feeding activity profiles back into a lightweight transformation pass, Simopt-power judiciously inserts duplicate truth table logic using Shannon Decomposition principle and relocates critical nets, thereby attenuating unnecessary transitions without perturbing functional behaviour. We evaluated this framework on open-source RTLLM benchmark, with Simopt-power achieves an average switching-induced power reduction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 9 \%$</tex> while incurring only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 19 \%$</tex> additional LUT-equivalent resources for arithmetic designs. These results demonstrate that coupling simulation insights with targeted optimisations can yield a reduced dynamic power, offering a practical path toward using simulation metadata in the FPGA-CAD flow.

title:
Controlling the Load Frequency of an Urban Microgrid with Firefly Algorithm Tuned PID+D
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    Controller
authors: Devanshee Patel, Hiramani Shukla, Manish Patel, Vishnubhai Patel, Ravi Bhavsar, Nikunj Patel
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: The increasing integration of renewable energy sources into modern power networks has made it increasingly challenging to maintain system stability and load frequency control (LFC). This article focuses on the study of LFC for a single area multisource microgrid system. A comparison of, proportional-integral-derivative (PID), and proportional-integral-derivative with second derivative (PID+D²) controllers is done in order to get the best frequency regulation under different load scenarios. The simulation results demonstrate how well the suitable controllers work to improve dynamic response and able to reduce the frequency deviations. The findings of the study provide valuable insights for enhancing the reliability and stability of multi-energy microgrids.

title: Research on Temperature Rise and Heat Dissipation Characteristics of Large-Capacity Dry-Type Air-Core Reactors Under Ultra-High Altitude Conditions
authors: Xuefeng Liu, Guohua Sun, Yuehua Zhang, Meng Zhang, Jingliang Xi, Yang Chao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: Currently, the altitude correction for the temperature rise limit of dry-type air-core reactors is primarily based on standards such as IEC 60076-11 and GB/T 1094.11. However, these standards do not specify an upper limit for altitude correction, and there is a lack of experimental research for conditions above 4,000 meters. This study employs a combination of simulation and experimentation to investigate the temperature rise and heat dissipation characteristics of large-capacity dry-type air-core reactors under various high-altitude environments. The results indicate: (1) The simulation model exhibits high consistency with experimental data, validating its rationality and accuracy; (2) At altitudes above 4,000 meters, the temperature rise limit should be reduced by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{0. 7 \%}$</tex> for every <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 0 0}$</tex>-meter increase in elevation. These findings provide critical technical references for engineering design and equipment development in ultra-high-altitude regions.

title: A BESS SoC Management Framework for DERMS to Provide Grid Services in Distribution Systems
authors: Ayman Uddin Mahin, Syed Qaseem Ali, Fabliha Ahmed, Geza Joos
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The integration of battery energy storage systems (BESSs) into distribution systems to provide grid services represents a significant advancement of modern power system management. However, the ability of BESSs to provide grid services involving active power injection into the grid depends on their stored energy levels. In this paper, a rule-based state-ofcharge (SoC) management framework for a distributed energy resource management system (DERMS) is proposed to effectively manage the charging of utility-scale BESSs in a distribution system. The framework takes into account the amount of energy required for service provision and plans BESS charging accordingly, ensuring they are prepared for providing the grid services. It explores three charging options: using photovoltaic (PV) systems, combining PV systems with the grid, and solely using the grid. Depending on the grid service requirements, the framework employs one or multiple options, prioritizing PV power. To assess the effectiveness of the proposed framework, a distribution system with a large number of distributed energy resources is designed, and quasi-static time-series simulations are carried out. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed framework adeptly prepares the BESSs for a requested grid service that cannot be provided by PV systems.

title: Intelligent Threat Detection in RPL-Based Military Networks: a LightGBM Approach
authors: M S Nayana, P G Navya, Nima S Nair
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This study investigates the impact of security weaknesses in military communication systems on RPL-based routing mechanisms designed for energy-constrained and unreliable networks. In tactical environments, threats such as hello flooding, reduced rank, and version-number attack identifiers pose significant risks to the critical mission operations. We introduce a security monitoring mechanism using the LightGBM model, which is a robust machine learning technique with high efficiency in handling large data. Our system accurately identified malicious traffic by $93 \%$, even in resource-poor environments. The inclusion of LightGBM in RPL-based networks significantly improves military communication security and responsiveness. Our research demonstrates the importance of machine learning for reinforcing cybersecurity resilience in military operations.

title: A Systematic Analysis on Crime Detection and Prevention Through ML Communication Techniques
authors: Saroj Kushwah, Updesh Kumar Jaiswal, Jaishree Jain, Eshank Jain, Bharat Singh, Parth Garg
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This paper surveys state-of-the-art applications of Machine Learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) based methods in crime prediction. The increasing criminal activities in urban cities require innovative solutions to enhance public safety. Crime prediction and detection systems, using ML and artificial intelligence, are one of the promising ways to alleviate this problem. Such systems are based on a vast amount of data, which might include historical crime information, social conditions, and environmental factors that can be used to predict potential criminal activities. The reviewed studies divide crime prediction technologies into two main groups: sophisticated deep learning techniques and conventional machine learning approaches. Traditional models such as decision trees, SVM, and k-nearest neighbors work well with structured and small-scale datasets. On the other hand, deep learning models, for instance, convolutional neural networks, recurrent neural networks, and long short-term memory networks outperform in the sense of catching more complex patterns from a large number of unstructured datasets. The studies have concentrated on the integration of spatiotemporal analysis, feature extraction, and data preprocessing to enhance prediction accuracy. With significant progress achieved, several issues remain, including the scarcity of good-quality datasets that are accessible to the public and the inbuilt biases found in the latter. The combination of machine learning algorithms and communication networks improves the responsiveness and scalability of crime prediction models. Further research directions will be aimed at these limitations through the development of robust, scalable models and promoting interdisciplinary collaboration. Using comprehensive crime analysis frameworks, this has the potential not only to predict but also to proactively address criminal behavior, hence optimizing resource utilization for law enforcement agencies to better enhance community safety. This abstract aggregates results from various geographical contexts, hence proving the universal value of ML-based crime prediction systems in developing proactive crime management strategies.

title: Design and Prototyping of Custom SHA-3 Instruction for CVA6 RISC-V Core
authors: Alperen Bolat, Sakir Sezer, Kieran McLaughlin, Henry Hui
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, validation, and performance benchmarking of a custom SHA-3 instruction (shatr) integrated directly into the CPU datapath of a Linux-capable RISC-V System-on-Chip (SoC). While previous research has focused on software simulations or external coprocessors, our work details the full-stack integration into the CVA6 CPU core, implemented and validated entirely on an FPGA hardware prototype. The system is proven to be robust and compatible, successfully booting a standard Linux operating system and passing the complete suite of NIST SHA-3 cryptographic validation tests. Experimental results demonstrate that the shatr instruction provides an average performance gain of 155.21x for short inputs, 157.20x for long inputs over standard ISA execution of SHA-3 workloads. This acceleration is achieved with a minimal area overhead of 3.3% in LUTs and 1.5% in registers, with no degradation to the system’s maximum clock frequency and with no added critical path latency. This work provides a concrete, hardware-proven reference for SHA-3-based cryptographic extensions in open-source RISC-V platforms, bridging the gap between microarchitectural theory and practical, system-level deployment for SHA-3 acceleration.

title: Sector-Coupled Optimization of Space Conditioning in Canada
authors: Stephen Eckstein, Ahmed Abdulla
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Achieving net-zero emissions entails decarbonizing energy use in buildings, including space heating which accounts for more than half of energy use in cold climates [1]. A number of technologies can achieve this, including electric systems that will increase demand and potentially strain the electricity grid. To guide expansion investments and policy making, this research investigates the optimum generation mix of space conditioning technologies using a sector-coupled generation expansion planning model of the electricity and building sectors in Canadian provinces.

title: Optimizer Exploration on Long Short-Term Memory Architecture for Dry Bean Soybean Price Movement Prediction
authors: Dasril Aldo, Muhammad Raafi'u Firmansyah, Wahyuni Fithratul Zalmi, Adanti Wido Paramadini, Faizal Burhani Ulil Fathan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: The volatility of agricultural commodity prices requires reliable prediction models to assist in making informed decisions in the market. This study evaluates the performance of various optimization algorithms in training Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) architectures to predict daily dry soybean prices. The dataset is from the Indonesian National Food Price Panel, covering the period from April 1, 2021, to February 10, 2025. Data pre-processing steps include missing value imputation through linear interpolation and normalization through Min-Max Scaling. The LSTM model is evaluated based on three activation functions (Tanh, ReLU, Sigmoid) and seven optimization algorithms: Adam, RMSprop, SGD, Adagrad, Adadelta, Nadam, and AdamW. The model's predictive performance is evaluated based on the metrics MAE, RMSE, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex>, loss value in the last epoch, and training time. The best results were obtained by combining the Sigmoid activation function with the Nadam optimizer, achieving an MAE of 0.011890, an RMSE of 0.022985, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> of 0.639292, reflecting highly accurate predictions with stable training and low volatility. In contrast, combinations involving the SGD, Adagrad, and Adadelta optimizers consistently performed poorly. These results highlight the importance of determining the activation function and optimization algorithm in LSTM-based price-prediction models. The proposed best configuration can be optimally used for monitoring commodity prices and for decision-support systems in agriculture. This configuration can be further improved by adding external variables such as weather conditions or government policies.

title: Smart Sensor Networks for Breast Cancer Screening and Monitoring
authors: S. Vinitha, S. Pavithra, Ramesh Chandra Aditya Komperla, Deepak Gupta, Ashish Gupta, Brijendra Gupta
abstract: Breast cancer remains one of the leading causes of cancer-related mortality among women worldwide. Early detection through regular screening significantly improves treatment outcomes and survival rates. This paper presents a novel smart sensor network architecture for breast cancer screening and monitoring, leveraging Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, machine learning algorithms, and wearable sensors. Our proposed system integrates multiple sensing modalities including thermography, ultrasound, and bio-impedance measurements to provide continuous, non-invasive monitoring capabilities. The network architecture employs edge computing for real-time data processing and cloud-based analytics for comprehensive health assessment. Experimental results demonstrate 94.2% accuracy in detecting suspicious tissue changes, with a false positive rate of 6.8%. The system also achieves significant improvements in patient comfort and accessibility compared to traditional screening methods. This research contributes to the advancement of personalized healthcare and early cancer detection through innovative sensor network technologies.

title: Convolutional Neural Network for Parkinson’s disease diagnosis using MRI data
authors: Nour El Houda Boulkrinat, Lydia Kaci, Maya Yahiaoui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease is a prevalent neurodegenerative disorder that significantly impacts millions of individuals worldwide, leading to a progressive decline in quality of life. Efficient and accurate diagnosis is important for useful management; however, current diagnostic solutions face limitations, particularly in MRI processing. Several machine and deep learning techniques have been increasingly used to imaging tasks, yielding outstanding results. In this study, we suggest a CNN model for accurate diagnostics in binary classification of Parkinson’s disease (Parkinson’s vs. Non-Parkinson). The data used to evaluate and test the proposed model consists of brain MRI scans from the NTUA dataset, on which we performed a set of preprocessing techniques, such as Gaussian Filter and Adaptive Histogram Equalization. The model outperforms existing studies and pretrained CNN models (ResNet50, VGG19, InceptionV3, and MobileNet) achieving superior performance with an accuracy of $98.7 \%$ on T1 images.

title: AI-Assisted Transformation of the Two-Hemisphere Model into Structured IT Project Backlog
authors: Oksana Nikiforova, Rihards Bobkovs, Oscar Pastor
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: This paper presents an AI-assisted approach for transforming the two-hemisphere model of IT project initiation into structured product backlog with correspondence to Agile software development. The proposed solution enables the automatic generation of IT project scope documentation and task lists based on user stories extracted from the problem domain process model, as well as create the problem domain UML use case diagram from the two-hemisphere model. By analyzing the application of the Agile SCRUM methodology to task organization, the research defines transformation rules for converting process elements into backlog items. Large Language Model is integrated into the solution to automate task generation, prioritization, and decomposition. The resulting data can be seamlessly imported into project management tools such as Jira and Leantime. Emphasis is placed on structured data representation, automated project backlog generation and tool integration.

title: Determination of operational parameters of an asynchronous electric drive with sequential reactive power compensation
authors: Vasyl Malyar, Orest Hamola, Volodymyr Maday, Ivanna Vasylchyshyn
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: Mathematical models and algorithms for calculating the characteristics and parameters of an electric drive based on an induction motor with series-connected capacitors have been developed, enabling their parameter computation and determination of limit values under automatic control. The motor model accounts for magnetic core saturation and the effect of current displacement in rotor bars. The computational speed of the programs allows real-time calculations with high accuracy.

title: Toward LIME Based Explainable Deepfake Detection:Integrating EfficientNETB4 and Multi-Attention Mechanism
authors: Swaraj Priyadarsini, Sanjukta Mohanty, Sonali Beura, Arup Abhinna Acharya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Deepfake technology poses a growing treat to digital security by generating highly realistic fake media using advanced machine learning. We suggest a deepfake detection model based on EfficientN etB4 that has a multi-attention mechanism for better feature extraction in order to combat this. Our approach incorporates data augmentation, label smoothing, per-channel standardization, and class balancing to enhance accuracy. We further optimize training using cosine decay learning rate scheduling and fine-tuning of the last 30 layers. Real and fake face photos are used to train the model, and it is assessed using a number of criteria. Additionally, Explainable AI (XAI) techniques, specifically LIME, is integrated to provide transparency in decision-making. Experimental results show a training accuracy of 98.84 %, validation accuracy of 80.27%, and test accuracy of 96.64%, confirming the model's effectiveness. LIME analysis highlights key regions influencing predictions, reinforcing the model's reliability in deep-fake detection. This approach demonstrates superior accuracy and robustness in identifying manipulated media.

title: Explainable Deep Learning for Brain Tumor Detection: Integrating DeepLabV3+ and Bayesian Optimization
authors: Anju Bala, Anu Priya Sharma, Gurleen Kaur, Hari Mohan Dixit, Shalini Kumari, Priyanka Singla
abstract: The Neuro-XAI proposed in this paper is an innovative solution to model brain tumor segmentation and classification based on MRI images to enhance the segmentation and classification accuracy as well as explainability. The architecture combines the semantic segmentation DeepLabV3+, hyperparameter tuning Bayesian Optimisation, and explainability via saliency maps. DeepLabV3+ model has a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 0.89 that outperforms baseline CNN models which have a DSC of 0.82 which can signal that the model has good segmentation capability. Further, the Intersection over Union (IoU) of tumor regions is 0.78, which has significantly improved the contouring of tumor boundary. In terms of classifications, the model shows an outstanding accuracy of 92 percent with the sensitivity and specificity reading of 0.90 and 0.94, respectively, with excellent discriminative ability between the benign and malign tumors. AUC of the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve indicates superior quality of differentiating between tumor types and provides a value of 0.95. The framework also produces saliency maps, such that the areas in the MRI images that have maximum impact on the predictions of the model can also be visualized, to meet interpretability requirements of clinical applicability. The training and validation loss continue to decline with the training loss steadily improving as time passes through 10 epochs, and it is clear the model is converged and can generalize information. In general, the Neuro-XAI framework offers not only a high-accuracy methods of tumor detection but also their clarity which opens it to possibilities of real-world settings of clinical application in the diagnosis and treatment planning of brain tumor.

title: Comparative Analysis of Climate Change Impacts on Agricultural Systems: A Systematic Review of Island vs. Non-Island Nations
authors: Shehnaz Lockhat, Pravin Kumar Bhoyar, Ritika Paul, Shanul Gawshinde, Rohit Bakshi
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This study is a systematic literature review on climate change's impact on the agriculture of island and non-island nations. It analyses the gap by evaluating 73 research papers spanning 27 years from 1998 to 2025, representing state-of-the-art literature. Methods like PRISMA, SPAR-4, and TCCM were used for careful preparation and strong research validation. PRISMA and SPAR-4 procedures were used for the strict selection of 73 papers concerning the climatic impact on agriculture. The theories, context, characteristics, and methodologies were evaluated using the TCCM approach. It was observed that a majority of studies were from Asia and the topic gained popularity in recent years (2020–2023). Artificial Intelligence, Remote Sensing, Precision Agriculture, and other emerging technologies can be used to improve climate resilience in agriculture. In conclusion, this methodical study offers several critical insights for investors, academics, and policy-makers who are tackling environmental issues.

title: Data Analytics for AI-Powered Retail Shopping Assistants
authors: Vaishnav Anand, Ferdin Shaji, Muhammed Libda M A, Sanjay Soney Varghese, Saira Varghese
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: AI-powered Shopping Assistant enhance retail experiences through personalized shopping, real-time inventory management, and predictive sales forecasting. It uses a combination of advanced data mining algorithms like Interactive Discovery of Productive Itemset (IDPI+), Fast High Temporal Fuzzy Utility Pattern (FHTFUP), and Weighted Frequent Itemset Mining using Weighted Subtrees (WSTWFIM) to uncover actionable insights from dynamic databases and optimize operational efficiency. Smarter recommendations, optimized inventory, and tailored promotions, by mining itemset, cleaning data, and identifying temporal trends, ultimately increases customer satisfaction and retailer profitability.

title: Blockchain Technology for Secure and Transparent Health Records Management
authors: Tapankumar A. Kakani, Balasubramanian Panneerselvan, Manikanta Rudrashetty, Rahul Gupta, Karim Hudani, K. Suganyadevi
abstract: Blockchain has the potential to be a game changer in the way health records are managed; it's secure, transparent and decentralized. Legacy EHR systems are plagued with data breaches, and interoperability challenges, as well as a central point of failure. Blockchain addresses these risks through its public ledger, cryptographic encoding, and consensus-driven verification, which all contribute to making health records tamper-resistant and auditable. Smart contracts automate access control so that you can share patient data with other authorized parties securely and in line with HIPAA or GDPR. The decentralized nature of blockchain also eliminates single points of failure, which mitigates the risk of hacking and unauthorized access. Further, blockchain promotes interoperation through normalization in data formats, such as Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR), and facilitates the sharing of data between institutions while preserving privacy. Scalability solutions in the form of sharding and layer-2 protocols allow large-scale medical data to be processed in a decentralized manner while new consensus algorithms (e.g., Proof-of-Stake) keep energy consumption down. Much like transportation, there are some key challenges, such as regulatory adherence and compatibility with existing systems. Still, if used properly, blockchain could serve as a transparent, secure, and patient-centric model for health record management. New developments in post-quantum cryptography, AI-platform deeds and smart contracts will continue to reinforce blockchain's contribution to disrupting healthcare data management.

title: EmotionClassNet: A Method for Emotion Detection and Classification Using DenseNet121 from Facial Images
authors: Drashti Dipeshbhai Patel, Priya Pavan Sisodiya, Om Mehulbhai Patel, Rachana S. Oza, Mayuri A. Mehta
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Emotion classification is pivotal in numerous applications such as human-computer interaction, healthcare, marketing, and many more. Several methods exist in the literature for emotion classification. However, many of them are evaluated with high-definition images. Furthermore, some of them suffer from high computational costs due to the use of large-scale pre-trained models or attention models. Additionally, only a few of them are evaluated using watermarked facial images. Watermarked images can sometimes lead to inaccurate feature extraction. Thus, emotion classification becomes a challenging task, specifically for watermarked images. Therefore, in this paper, we propose an EmotionClassNet(ECN) method for emotion detection and classification from low-definition and watermarked images using DenseNet121. The proposed ECN method has been evaluated on two different datasets: FER2013 and CK+. The FER2013 dataset contains low-definition watermarked images, while the CK+ dataset contains low-definition images without a watermark. The proposed ECN method obtains 56% testing accuracy on the FER2013 dataset and 99% testing accuracy on the CK+ dataset. The proposed method demonstrates a significant advantage in handling challenging image conditions, such as low-definition images and the presence of watermarks. It outperforms other CNN architectures in terms of classification accuracy.

title: Customized silicone Face Masks: Penetrability of Commercial Face Recognition Systems & Identification of Presentation Attacks
authors: Suraj Kumar, Krati Rastogi Gupta
abstract: Face recognition systems are increasingly vulnerable to presentation attacks, such as the use of high-quality silicone masks. These attacks can compromise the security of various applications, including access control, mobile payments, and law enforcement. To address this challenge, we conducted an empirical study to evaluate the susceptibility of commercial face recognition systems to silicone mask attacks and to develop effective presentation attack detection (PAD) techniques. We collected a new dataset consisting of 8 custom 3D silicone masks and bona fide presentations of the corresponding subjects using three different smartphones. We then assessed the vulnerability of two well-known commercial face recognition systems to these attacks and evaluated the performance of five state-of-the-art PAD techniques. Our findings demonstrate that silicone masks pose a significant threat to face recognition systems, even when using advanced commercial systems. However, we also propose effective PAD techniques that can significantly improve their security by leveraging features such as visual saliency and facial motion analysis. The results of this study have important implications for the development and deployment of robust face recognition systems in various applications.

title: Object Classification in 4D Point Cloud Data
authors: Ramesh Chandra Gollapudi, Sri Charan Darna, Jyothsna Datti, Adityanath Kurna, Sai Kumar Peddineni, Ravali Manthena
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Object classification in self-driving cars is highly dependent on timely and accurate perception of the environment. 4D point cloud data or streaming 3D Point Cloud Data, which has both spatial and temporal information, offers rich data for this purpose. Nevertheless, conventional classification frameworks tend to fail with the latency caused by processing point clouds as static snapshots, resulting in delays in decision-making and processing. In this paper, we introduce a new paradigm that classifies objects directly from streaming 3D point cloud data, which enhances real-time performance. With the exploitation of the continuous nature of the data, our method distributes computational workload across data acquisition time, avoiding peak load and enabling quicker and more efficient object classification. The primary aim of this project is to classify and visualize the 3D objects in 4D Point Cloud Data or streaming 3D point cloud data.

title: The Effect of Using Risk Factors and Data Privacy on Fintech E-Wallet Payments
authors: Farrah Ilyamarcy, Natalia Limantara
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: The e-wallet feature available on mobile devices allows users to store digital versions of their payment cards. Replacing traditional payment methods with e-wallets has become an emerging trend among consumers. With this technology, individuals are no longer required to carry physical cash or credit cards, making purchasing activities more efficient and convenient. As global internet penetration continues to grow rapidly, there has been a significant shift in consumer expectations related to digital payment solutions. Ewallets have thus gained substantial traction, with increasing numbers of users preferring digital transactions over cash handling. Despite their popularity, concerns have emerged regarding the risks associated with e-wallet usage. This study explores both the benefits and potential drawbacks of e-wallet applications from the user's perspective. Findings suggest that enhancing user awareness is essential to mitigate negative outcomes. The research examines six key factors: perceived ease of use, trust, enjoyment, cyberattacks, security risks, and performance risks. Data was collected from 246 respondents through an online questionnaire (quantitative) with PLS-SEM method, distributed via Google Forms, and calculated with Smart PLS 4. The path coefficient from User Awareness to Privacy Concern is significant (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\beta}=\mathbf{0. 3 7 1}, \mathbf{p}<\mathbf{0. 0 5}$</tex>), indicating that higher awareness is associated with stronger privacy concern (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}=71.7 \%$</tex> for PC and 16.6 % for UA) that provides academic and efficient insights to optimize data protection policies in e-wallet payments.

title: Benchmarking Deep Object Detection Models for Agricultural Pest Identification: A Case Study on Potato Crops
authors: Sri Hadianti, Dwiza Riana, Muhammad Haris, Daning Nur Sulistyowati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Accurate pest detection is a crucial aspect in the world of agriculture, especially in potato plants which are one of the largest food production in the world. This study aims to compare the performance of three deep learning-based object detection models, namely Faster R-CNN, RetinaNet, and Mask R-CNN in identifying pests in potato plants. The dataset used consists of 636 annotated images from public datasets and datasets collected directly from field conditions covering various types of common pests in potatoes. The three models were trained and evaluated using standard metrics, namely mean Average Precision (mAP), precision, recall, and inference time. The results showed that among the Faster RCNN, RetinaNet, and Mask R-CNN models, the RetinaNet model showed the highest mAP value among the three models with a presentation of 67.6 %. In terms of speed, there was no significant difference between the three models. These findings can be a reference for researchers and farmers in choosing the right computer vision model for smart agriculture-based pest management systems.

title: Evaluation of Marginal Emissions and Renewable Integration via Principal Component Analysis
authors: Ahijit Banerjee, Kelton Friedrich, James Cotton
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Electrification is a common strategy for reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, but its efficacy depends on the proper implementation of policies and the metrics used to measure emissions. The study introduces a novel methodology using principal component analysis (PCA) to assess the evolution of electric grids and the penetration of renewable energy sources to inform electrification policies. The average emissions factor (AEF) is a commonly used metric to inform grid emissions, which has been improved substantially by the marginal emissions factor (MEF). Typically, MEF values are significantly higher than AEF, with most grids’ MEF reflecting the emission factor of their primary peaking thermal generators, which are coal or natural gas. The paper focuses on four major Independent Systems Operators in North America: IESO (Ontario), AESO (Alberta), CAISO (California), and ERCOT (Texas). The findings highlight the importance of considering both MEF and the variability ratio (VR) to understand how grids adapt to increasing demand and the integration of renewables.

title: Deep learning based Classification of Heart and Lung Diseases in Healthcare Datasets
authors: Gauri Sood, Neeraj Raheja, Vineeta Gulati
abstract: Nowadays, Heart and lung diseases are the most critical health concerns globally that cause significantly rising mortality rates. Heart Diseases (HDs) often present overlapping symptoms making early and accurate diagnosis a challenging task. Despite advancements in Machine Learning (ML), many existing traditional models struggle to maintain high accuracy and generalization across multi-disease classification tasks. This made it clear that there is a need for more adaptive and improved diagnostic frameworks. Therefore, a novel Deep Learning (DL)-based model named as Independent feature-based optimized Deep Neural Network (IFODNN), is presented in response to this challenge. The model utilizes integrated clinical datasets including the "Heart Disease Dataset" and the "Lung Cancer Dataset" to classify heart and lung-related conditions. To increase the classification performance in the form of accuracy while minimizing the error probability. This proposed IFODNN model is the combination of the Independent Component Analysis (ICA) used for feature extraction, Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) used for feature selection, and an improved DNN architecture for classification tasks. The comparative analysis between several DL models is performed by utilizing measures such as accuracy, SN, F1-score, etc. The proposed model achieved SN of 98.65%, SP of 99.16%, accuracy of 96.81%, RMSE of 0.102%, and F1-score of 93.0%. The model completed the classification task in just 2.44 seconds only and also achieved a training accuracy of 96.70%. When compared to existing traditional models, the proposed IFODNN model significantly outperformed them based on accuracy, SN, and F1-score. These findings reveal that the introduced IFODNN framework is not just capable of delivering accurate predictions but it can also be served as an effective tool for clinical support in multi-disease diagnosis.

title: Deadline-Aware Interference Mitigation Accelerator Design for Automotive Radar SoC
authors: Zaheer Khan, Janne Lehtomäki, Lauri Koskinen
abstract: Advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) and autonomous driving (AD) are pushing game changing innovations in multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO) radar system on chips (SoCs). Prioritizing safety to ensure drivers and pedestrians are protected is paramount in ADAS/AD systems. As the number of vehicles equipped with radar sensors increases so does the likelihood of mutual wireless interference among these radars leading to potential performance degradation which can compromise safety of these systems. Moreover, pedestrians unlike vehicles have low reflection intensity and there can be challenging scenarios where the pedestrians crossing roads cannot be detected due to interference from other radars. Interference mitigation in MIMO radar SoCs is needed to be done in real-time and the latency deadline for such processing is no more than a few microseconds. This paper proposes a latency/resource efficient accelerator design for interference mitigation in radar data processing SoCs. Our results show that the proposed accelerator can process radar data received from multiple antennas and mitigate interference within the required SoC processing deadline. The accelerator design is also optimized to reduce multiply and accumulate (MAC) operations which decreases hardware design complexity and enables resource efficiency.

title: Digital Noise Canceller ADC
authors: Chris Otey, Kanchan Vissamsetty, Saiyu Ren
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: A Digital Noise Canceller (DNC) ADC is presented which is aimed at increasing the resolution of conventional high conversion rate ADCs. The DNC ADC architecture has a conventional first stage ADC, which is capable of operating at the desired conversion rate. To achieve the desired targeted resolution, a second stage Digital Noise Canceller (DNC) adaptive filter is implemented. The DNC adaptive filter functions to reduce the quantization noise and distortion introduced by the first stage ADC. A previous version used a Digital to Analog Converter (DAC) to convert the Most Significant Bits (MSBs) of the DNC adaptive filter output to analog for generation of the error signal by comparing to the analog input. The modified version presented here compares the digital output of the DNC adaptive filter to the digital output of the first stage ADC to generate the error signal. This eliminates the need for a DAC or analog comparator and results in an all-digital design excluding the mixed signal conventional first stage ADC. A MATLAB SIMULINK model of the DNC ADC is developed for performance assessment. Performance was evaluated with CW inputs across the NYQUIST bandwidth of the stage 1 ADC. The SIMULINK performance assessments demonstrate the addition of approximately 4 Effective Number of Bits (ENOB) to the output of an 8-bit Stage 1 ADC with a DNC adaptive filter length of 192 taps operating at 192MHz.

title: Research on the Optimization of the Smart Manufacturing Production Information Management System at Tongrun Copper Industry
authors: Bitie Lan, Jianrong Huang, Yongde Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: In response to the widespread adoption of traditional production and management models in metal wire drawing enterprises, which suffer from low digitalization and misalignment with the trend of smart manufacturing, this study innovatively applies advanced technologies such as the Industrial Internet and cloud services. A smart manufacturing production information management system was developed and implemented at Tongrun Copper Industry to interconnect electromechanical equipment on the production line. This system enables automated production data collection, intelligent early-warning inspections, and automatic equipment detection and adjustment, effectively helping the company reduce costs and improve efficiency. Based on a self-developed intelligent acquisition motherboard as the foundational unit, combined with cloud database storage technology, an integrated system for dynamic intelligent data collection, processing, and digital monitoring was established. This effectively addresses challenges in traceability and flexible adjustment of production data in metal wire drawing.

title: Accelerating Lightweight Binary Image Classification on FPGA Using Machine Learning Models
authors: Maheedhar Bh, Kamatchi S
abstract: Accurate and timely diagnosis of disease is a considerable challenge particularly in low-resource environments with limited computational resources. Existing image processing frameworks such as CPUs are too slow because they only allow limited levels of concurrency. Although GPUs provide faster performance they do so at the cost of energy efficiency. Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) are able to take advantage of both parallel execution and energy-efficient operation, making FPGAs a possible compromise between both extremes for the purposes of building efficient real-time diagnostic tools. This paper demonstrates a hardware-accelerated system to perform binary image classification for the purpose of confirming malaria detection using lightweight machine learning classification models—k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Decision Trees. The image classification pipeline is composed of conversion to grayscale followed by image binarization and finally resizing images to the hardware-optimized size for processing, providing prompt processing speeds without substantial degradation in accuracy. All learning models have been developed with Verilog HDL and deployed to ZYNQ-7 ZC702 FPGA development board using concurrent processing capabilities of the board efficiently. The final system was successfully able to classify in real-time with classification accuracy reaching 80% while remaining energy efficient. The findings in this paper demonstrate the practicality of an FPGA-based learning system as portable, low-power, real-time medical diagnostic systems for malaria detection.

title: Gap-sunlight-intrusion risk of a Moon based Earth radiation observatory
authors: Wentao Duan, Haiyan Guan, Haibing Ruan, Wei Xu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: A Moon-based Earth radiation observatory (MERO) could contribute to the better understanding of the Earth radiation budget by providing data with less non-simultaneous sampling uncertainty and higher temporal resolution as well as better Earth polar region spatial-temporal coverage. Assessing the gap-sunlight-intrusion risk is a crucial step in the MERO protection unit design and operation planning. In this study, we proposed a new method to estimate such a risk taking into account the Earth atmosphere radiative refraction and attenuation as well as the entrance pupil irradiance of the MERO, which could find the new refracted-type risky events and eliminated the included “fake” risky incidents compared to current method solely based on Sun-Earth-Moon geometric analysis. 18.6-years evaluation from Jan 2021 to Sep 2039 shows that gap-sunlight-intrusion risk annual duration ranges from 10 to 29 hours. MERO-location-effect assessment exhibits that MERO location latitudinal change (from (0°E, 81°N) to (0°E, 81°S)) would result in an annual risky duration difference ranging from 0 to 5 hours, and that induced by longitudinal MERO location change (from (80°E, 0°N) to (80°W, 0°S)) varied between 0 and 3 hours. Total risky time occupies 0.23% in the 18.6-years evaluation period (Jan 2021 to Sep 2039), which is about 2.56 times larger than that of the study only with consideration of the Sun-Earth-Moon geometry.

title: UltraLight Med-Vision Mamba for Classification of Neoplastic Progression in Tubular Adenomas
authors: Aqsa Sultana, Nordin Abouzahra, Ahmed Rahu, Brian Shula, Brandon Combs, Derrick Forchetti, Theus Aspiras, Vijayan K. Asari
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Identification of precancerous polyps during routine colonoscopy screenings is vital for their excision, lowering the risk of developing colorectal cancer. Advanced deep learning algorithms enable precise adenoma classification and stratification, improving risk assessment accuracy and enabling personalized surveillance protocols that optimize patient outcomes. UltraLight Med-Vision Mamba, a state-space-based model (SSM), has excelled in modeling long- and short-range dependencies and image generalization, critical factors for analyzing whole slide images. Furthermore, UltraLight Med-Vision Mamba’s efficient architecture offers advantages in both computational speed and scalability, making it a promising tool for real-time clinical deployment.

title: FedPDFGuard: A Federated Learning Approach for Robust Detection of Malicious PDF Files
authors: Pengyu Zhou, Daniel Chong, Honglu Jiang, Junjie Zhang, Rui Dai
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: FedPDFGuard is the first federated learning-based system for PDF malware detection. It enables decentralized model training across participants while preserving data privacy. Our evaluation shows that FedPDFGuard achieves detection accuracy comparable to centralized methods, addressing privacy concerns and improving robustness against increasingly sophisticated PDF-based cyberattacks.

title: Transformer Models for Automated Business Process Mining and Optimization
authors: Shraddha Purandare, Chanakya Kumar Jha, Tharageswari Soundarapandian, Manisha Saxena, Vinaydeep Brar, Pallavi Jha, Sanjay Patsariya
abstract: Business Process Mining (BPM) has emerged as a critical approach for analyzing and optimizing organizational workflows through event log data. Traditional process mining techniques often struggle with long-range dependencies and complex temporal patterns in business processes. This paper presents a novel framework leveraging Transformer-based deep learning models for automated business process mining and optimization. We introduce ProcessTransformer, an attention-based architecture specifically designed to capture intricate process dependencies and predict process outcomes with high accuracy. Our approach incorporates multi-head self-attention mechanisms to model temporal relationships in event sequences and employs positional encoding to preserve sequential information. We evaluate our method on three real-world datasets: BPI Challenge 2012, BPI Challenge 2019, and the Sepsis Cases dataset, achieving superior performance compared to traditional approaches including Long Short-Term Memory networks and Gradient Boosting Machines. Experimental results demonstrate that ProcessTransformer achieves an average F1-score of 0.923, outperforming baseline methods by 12.7% on next-activity prediction tasks and reducing prediction time by 34%. The proposed framework also enables interpretable process insights through attention weight visualization, facilitating data-driven process optimization strategies.

title: Optimizing Placement Legalization Utilizing Multiple Shapes of Standard Cells
authors: Seoyoung Bang, Taewhan Kim
abstract: The standard cell libraries at the advanced technology nodes are composed of cells of diverse logic functions, each of which forms a unique cell shape. Namely, for small cells, their shapes maintain single-row-height while for large cells, they adopt double-row-height to balance the horizontal and vertical I/O pin accessibility. However, this unique shape restriction of each cell type in the mixed-row-height cell libraries makes the placement legalization problem severely ineffective, creating lots of inflexibility in moving cells and resulting in considerable quality degradation. This work overcomes this legalization problem. To this ends, (1) for intensively used moderate size cells, we prepare, for each cell type, multiple cell shapes of comparable PPA (power, performance, area), precisely, one shape of single-row-height and two shapes of double-row-height where one is VDD-abut and the other VSS-abut on the top and bottom of cell boundary. Then, (2) we propose a new iterative refinement algorithm of placement legalization, which is able to dynamically select, at each iteration of cell swapping, the cell shape that is best suitable for achieving the least displacement cost, which otherwise would be unattainable, while meeting the cell non-overlapping constraint. In the meantime, through experiments with OpenCores benchmark circuits, it is shown that our method is able to simultaneously reduce the total cell displacement and HPWL by 17.1% and 10.5%, and 11.2% and 7.8% over the legalization results produced by a commercial tool and an existing state-of-the-art legalization refiner, respectively.

title: An Optimised on-Device Deep Learning Training: An fNIRS study
authors: Yunyi Zhao, Hubin Zhao, Shufan Yang
abstract: Training neural networks directly on embedded system-on-chip (SoC) platforms presents considerable challenges, primarily due to the limited computational capacity and memory resources of low-power hardware. Batch normalisation (BN), a fundamental technique for enhancing the convergence and stability of neural network training, introduces additional computational complexity through the calculation of mini-batch statistics and affine transformations. To address these constraints, we propose a hardware-efficient BN engine tailored for the AMD Versal AI Core VCK190 platform. The architecture employs a memory-mapped design that incorporates a Direct Memory Access (DMA) module, an AXI4-Lite control interface, and a tiled fixed-point compute core to ensure both performance and scalability. This implementation enables efficient execution of BN operations within embedded environments, thereby facilitating complete on-device training pipelines. Furthermore, such advancements are critical to supporting the emerging demands of on-chip training in neuroimaging applications—particularly those employing functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) sensors—where real-time, low-power computation is essential for robust and autonomous cognitive state analysis at the edge.

title: Medical Imaging with Explainable Deep Learning: Improving Clinical Diagnosis Reliability and Interpretability
authors: P. Arunachalam, Sujatha S, S. Saraswathi, S. Karkuzhali, D. Karunkuzhali, B R Celia
abstract: Clinical diagnostics relies on medical imaging to diagnose cancer, cardiovascular, and neurological issues. Deep learning (DL) has improved medical image analysis accuracy and efficiency, speeding diagnosis and improving patient outcomes. Many deep learning models are "black-box" with little transparency and interpretability, especially in essential medical applications. This research combines explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) with deep learning models in medical imaging to increase diagnostic reliability and interpretability. We discuss explainable deep learning frameworks like saliency maps, Class Activation Mapping (CAM), and attention mechanisms to understand how models make decisions by visualising which image portions contribute most to model predictions. Explainable deep learning models can close the transparency gap in medical image analysis, allowing healthcare providers to trust and comprehend the model's findings. Grad-CAM, LRP, and SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations) help improve the interpretability of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and other deep learning models. We also examine the practical consequences of these models in clinical domains including radiology, pathology, and dermatology, where proper interpretation and explanation of data are essential for informed treatment decisions. The study also addresses current issues like the model accuracy-interpretability trade-off, the requirement for large annotated datasets for explainable model training, and the integration of explainable deep learning into clinical processes. We conclude with recommendations for future study, including hybrid models that balance performance and explainability and standardised medical imaging explainability measures. This study emphasises the significance of making deep learning models for medical imaging accurate, clear, and interpretable to build trust and improve clinical diagnosis.

title: Comparison of Neural Networks with a Numerical Method for Obtaining the Inverse Kinematic of a Bipedal Robot
authors: Hernan D. Castro Murcia, Claudia L. Garzón Castro, Jorge A. Castellanos Rivillas
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: Biped robots, such as the NAO V6, face challenges in solving the inverse kinematics (IK) problem due to their complex configurations and varying environmental conditions. Traditional methods, including analytical and numerical approaches, often struggle with precision and computational efficiency, while machine learning models offer potential advantages in adaptability and generalization. This paper aims to compare and evaluate different approaches for solving the inverse kinematics problem in a biped robot, specifically focusing on numerical, analytical, and neural network-based methods. The methodology involves the development of an analytical model using Denavit-Hartenberg parameters, a numerical model based on the Conjugate Gradient Method, and a neural network approach trained on a dataset of robot configurations. The evaluation includes a comparison of the error and computational time for each method, as well as an assessment of their performance in different scenarios. The results show that while the numerical method is faster and more stable, the neural network model offers higher precision, particularly in more complex configurations like the legs, with a trade-off in inference time. The findings contribute valuable insights into the trade-offs between accuracy and computational efficiency, demonstrating that both approaches have their place in real-time applications for biped robots, especially in dynamic and reconfigurable environments.

title: Design and Experimental Verification of A 0.14-0.55V 1.9-24.2pW 22nm 3-bit Binary Search Supply-to-Digital Converter Using One-Hot Hard-Wired Topology and Supply-Dependent-Activation Buffers for Supply Sensing IoT Systems
authors: Hiroaki Kitaike, Hironori Tagawa, Kento Okamura, Wu You, Kei Awano, Jin Nakamura, Masaya Kaneko, Yuta Kimura, Hiroaki Nakamura, Shufan Xu, Kunyang Liu, Hirofumi Shinohara, Kiichi Niitsu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: In this rapidly developing society, there is an increasing demand for IoT devices. IC chips are integrated into everything and IoTs are everywhere. Among these, the supply-to-digital converter which converts the data without the stable power supply is particularly important for power-and-area limited, stable-power-inaccessible sensors such as in-body stand-alone biosensors. This paper presents a low-power supply-to-digital converter for a supply sensing-and-recording IoT system where bio-fuel cells provide both power source and sensing data. It is achieved by a hard-wired binary-search topology using supply-dependent activation buffers (SDAB) and XORs with different V thresholds. Only one path is always driven regardless of input, resulting in one-hot, driven circuit area reduction and power reduction. A simulation exhibits its feasibility with a power of 1.9-24.2 pW under 0.14-0.55 V. The footprint was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0034 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>.

title: Feasibility of Firm PV Power Generation for Residential Consumers
authors: Lies Debruyne, Cas Lavaert, Jan Cappelle
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The IEA PVPS Task 16 states that the regional conversion of variable renewable energy into firm power is technically and economically viable. This study explores the feasibility of applying this concept at the neighbourhood and household level by calculating the storage capacity needed when overbuilding and curtailing PV systems, using implicit storage. Assuming annual single-site photovoltaic generation matches annual household demand, required storage proves prohibitively high. This paper examines the impact of geographic location and load shaping on reducing household-level storage needs. Results show that the feasibility of $\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$ renewable firm power for residential consumers is highly dependent on the timing and consistency of renewable energy generation. Aggregating households and integrating wind energy as a secondary source mitigate variability in both load and production profiles, thereby lowering perhousehold storage requirements. This study provides empirical insights based on smart meter data from households with and without electric vehicles in Flanders, Belgium.

title: A Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Fault Detection and Isolation in Distribution Networks
authors: Mehrnaz Ahmadi, Hamed Aly
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The increasing integration of renewable energy sources (RES) in modern smart grids introduces challenges in fault detection, isolation, and voltage regulation. Conventional centralized control strategies often face limitations such as communication delays, scalability concerns, and vulnerability to system-wide failures. This paper proposes a fully decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework based on the proximal policy optimization (PPO) algorithm to enhance distribution system resilience. The proposed framework develops autonomous MARL agents that independently learn localized control policies for real-time fault detection, isolation, and voltage stabilization. To improve performance, adaptive reward shaping is employed to enhance fault detection accuracy, reduce false positives, and accelerate system recovery. Each PPO agent is trained with customized observation spaces, action strategies, and power flow constraints to ensure robust decision-making under dynamic grid conditions. Simulations on the IEEE 33-bus system demonstrate the proposed framework’s superior fault detection accuracy, faster isolation response, and improved voltage stability compared to conventional reinforcement learning and deep learning models, effectively enhancing grid resilience.

title: Radar Reflector Design For Improved Detection Of Cyclists
authors: Aaron Nielsen, Bart Kahler
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: This paper discusses the design and increase of bicycle detectability using an inexpensive 3D printed radar corner reflector design. Automotive radars have grown substantially in use among modern cars for collision warning and avoidance systems. While the radar return from other vehicles can be large, other road users such as bicyclists can be less detectable. Just as bicycles often employ optical reflectors to stand out when illuminated with car headlights, the detectability of bicycles can be enhanced for automotive radars by using radar reflectors. We have designed and built 3D printed corner reflector for mounting on bicycles in order to enhance their radar reflectivity. Theoretical calculations and simulations show that the detection range of a bicycle may be increased up to 75 meters based on the expected radar cross section (RCS) of a standard bicyclist for a 77 GHz radar.

title: BayNNgine: Hardware-Enabled Bayesian Neural Network Support for Dependable AI Inference
authors: Julian Hoefer, Fabian Lesniak, Annina Gutermann, Felix Wöran, Tanja Harbaum, Juergen Becker
abstract: Driven by the advent of powerful AI-based computer vision models founded on Deep Neural Networks, integrating these models into safety-critical systems is increasingly appealing. However, unlike traditional systems, AI-based models face novel challenges in achieving the required level of dependability. This includes that AI-models tend to be overconfident in their predictions and do not inherently provide a measure of failure when confronted with out-of distribution cases, incapabilities of the model, or hardware errors.To tackle these challenges, new safety standards recommend a redundancy and diversity approach, e.g., approximations of Bayesian Neural Networks, which significantly increases compute demand. To mitigate this burden, we present architectural extensions that can be integrated in modern neural processing units. By incorporating flexible stochastic modules in the data paths of the compute array and thereby keeping the data local, the need for costly off-chip memory accesses is drastically reduced. We demonstrate our approach using an open-source accelerator architecture and make our contributions openly available as well <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>. With only 1-2% of additional resources and no latency increase per redundant sample on an FPGA implementation, our approach is well adapted for resource-constrained embedded real-time systems.

title: Feminist Food Futures: Speculative Utopias for Technology-Supported Nutrition Care
authors: Daisy O'Neill, Regan L. Mandryk, Olena Pastushenko, Eva Deckers, Stephan Wensveen, Max V. Birk
