title: Optimizing Embedded Software Platforms Development: A Multi-Stage MDA-Driven Approach to Firmware Generation for Multiple Programming Languages
authors: Raphael Kunz, Lijun Chen, Stephanie Ecker, Yash Ranjan, Paritosh Kumar Sinha, Wolfgang Ecker
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a Model-Driven Architectureinspired generation methodology for auto-generating C and Rust firmware, enabling the development of complex embedded cross-language systems. The proposed approach leverages the combined power of existing software generators to generate firmware, ensuring interoperability with existing C-based systems while allowing for a gradual migration towards modern Rust-based systems. This enables an improved support of the safety features available in Rust, compared to an interfaced C-code called from Rust, which cannot provide these guarantees. The paper provides an overview of the fundamental building blocks of the approach and discusses the challenges and advantages of chaining both generators. Our Halstead measurments highlight the advantages of utilizing this Model-Driven approach in reduction of manual effort and the risk. This reduction is comparable to the results found in state-of-the-art literature, as highlighted by the comparison presented in this paper, but provides dual-language embedded code. This paper forms another building block towards generating hardware-dependent complex software platforms.

title: Performance Assessment of ANN-Based FDIRM in PV Boost Converters
authors: Mohamed Ali Zdiri, Bilel Dhouib, Baseem Khan, Hsan Hadj Abdallah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Renewable energy systems, especially those in aerospace, automotive, industrial, and medical fields, require high reliability and performance to ensure continuous and reliable operation. However, photovoltaic (PV) boost converters are vulnerable to power switch faults, such as open and short circuits (OCF and SCF), which can significantly affect system reliability and lead to false alarms. This study introduces a fault detection, identification, and reconfiguration method (FDIRM) that utilises artificial neural networks (ANN) for detecting, identifying, and compensating the switches faults. The MPPT method used incorporates an ANN-driven sliding-mode maximum power point tracking strategy (ANN-SM MPPT) for enhanced PV performance. The investigated FDIRM method uses real-time data on power, voltage, current, and duty cycle of the PV module, allowing the ANN to rapidly detect and compensate for faults using only current and voltage sensors, simplifying system complexity and reducing costs. A redundant leg is also combined into the boost converter topology to maintain PV module functionality following fault reconfiguration. In this study, the diagnostic and reconfiguration approaches of the PV boost converter are designed and implemented using hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) control managed by the dSPACE 1104 board programmed in MATLAB/SIMULINK. The simulation results confirm the high performance of FDIRM, demonstrating effective fault detection, isolation, and compensation to support autonomous and robust operation.

title: Android Malware Detection Framework Using Attention-Based Deep Learning
authors: Mayank Ashok, Rahul Katarya
abstract: The rising complexity of Android malware, characterized by polymorphism, runtime evasion, and behavior masking, necessitates more adaptive and interpretable detection mechanisms. This paper presents a comprehensive detection framework that integrates classical ensemble classifiers with an attention-driven deep learning architecture to identify malicious Android applications with high precision. The framework is trained and validated on the Kronodroid dataset, a hybrid corpus encompassing over 140,000 samples sourced from both physical devices and emulator environments. Static and dynamic features are systematically extracted and fused into a unified representation. A CNN-LSTM architecture enhanced with attention mechanisms is employed to learn spatial and temporal behavior patterns, while an Extra Trees ensemble model offers complementary insights with low inference latency. The final classification leverages a confidence-based fusion strategy that combines the strengths of both models. The proposed system demonstrates an accuracy of 99.23%, alongside significantly reduced false positive and false negative rates, highlighting its potential for real-world deployment. By balancing predictive performance with architectural efficiency, the framework provides a scalable foundation for future mobile malware defense systems.

title: A Multi-Sensor Drone Detection Framework for Securing Power Substations
authors: Si Yi, Santiago Grijalva
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Commercial off-the-shelf drones have lowered the barrier to kinetic attacks against critical infrastructure such as the electric power grid, highlighting an urgent need for costeffective aerial surveillance solutions for power substations. We present a modular Monte Carlo framework for evaluating fused multi-sensor drone detection at power substations. The simulator models RF, EO/IR, and acoustic modalities with substationspecific disturbances and fuses a single 3-D measurement per step with a Kalman filter. In a demonstration, fusion improves detection relative to single sensors while maintaining fast time-todetect. The framework’s parameters are site-tunable (disturbance probabilities, ranges, noise) to support pre-deployment trade studies and cost-aware sensor selection.

title: A 8.9 $\beta$ W 12.3-ENOB SAR ADC with <1 LSB DNL/INL for Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy in 12nm CMOS
authors: Christian Ziegler, Alexander Meyer, Fa Foster Dai, Liubov Bakhchova, Vadim Issakov
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: In this work we present an ultra-low-power differential successive approximation register (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC) for electrochemical impedance spectroscopy application. The target is measurement of complex bioimpedance of cells proliferating on a membrane inside a microfluidic channel for organ-on-chip applications. For this, a differential AC current excitation in the low frequency range is injected via a pair of electrodes, while a differential voltage is sensed for readout via another pair of electrodes. From the evaluated complex impedance of the cell layer the transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER) can be obtained. It can vary from few Ohms to several kilo-Ohms, posing challenging requirements on the Signal-to-Noise-Ratio (SNR) of the ADC in the voltage processing chain. On the other hand, differential signalling enables use of efficient techniques for differential SAR ADCs. The presented SAR ADC is implemented in a 12nm CMOS technology and dissipates <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.9 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex> including analog, digital and reference voltage supply. The prototype SAR ADC achieves a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 76 dB and an SFDR of 54.2 dB at a sampling rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$256 \text{kS} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>. The circuit occupies a core chip area of only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$545 \times 235 \mu \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>.

title: Effective Damage Data Generation by Fusing Imagery with Human Knowledge Using Vision-Language Models*
authors: Jie Wei, Erika Ardiles-Cruz, Aleksey Panasyuk, Erik Blasch
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: It is of crucial importance to assess damage promptly and accurately in humanitarian assistance and disaster response (HADR). Current deep learning approaches struggle to generalize effectively due to the imbalance of data classes, scarcity of moderate damage examples, and human inaccuracy in pixel labeling during HADR situations. To accommodate these limitations and exploit state-of-the-art techniques in vision-language models (VLMs) to fuse imagery with human knowledge understanding, there is an opportunity to generate a diversified set of image-based damage data effectively. Our initial experimental results suggest encouraging data generation quality, which demonstrates an improvement in classifying scenes with different levels of structural damage to buildings, roads, and infrastructures.

title: Primal-Dual Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based Energy Management of Microgrids with Electric Vehicles Charging Stations
authors: Ahmed Shaban Omar, Ramadan El-Shatshat
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a safe deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for the management of low-carbon energy in microgrids (MGs) that integrate renewable energy sources (RESs) and electric vehicle charging stations (EVCS). The inherent variability of RESs, combined with the high power demands of EVCS, poses significant challenges to the real-time operation of MGs, thereby necessitating advanced optimization techniques. Although DRL methodologies offer data-driven approaches to facilitate adaptive decision-making, current penaltybased strategies frequently fall short in effectively enforcing operational constraints under complex scenarios. To address these challenges, we propose a primal-dual DRL methodology utilizing the proximal policy optimization (PD-PPO) algorithm, which incorporates operational constraints directly into the policy learning framework. The MG energy management problem is formulated as a constrained Markov decision process (CMDP), which encompasses distributed generators, RESs, and the demands of EVCS. The PD-PPO algorithm guarantees stable policy updates and ensures robust constraint satisfaction without the need for penalty coefficient adjustments. Comprehensive numerical experiments based on real-world datasets for renewable energy generation and electricity demand demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed approach in achieving low-carbon objectives while optimizing MG operations.

title: On generation of adversarial sequences for recurrent neural networks in classification and forecasting
authors: Rafał Zan, Bartosz Chaber
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: One of the emerging problems associated with neural networks is their resilience to adversarial input data.This paper focuses on recurrent neural networks (RNN), like Long Short-Time Memory networks (LSTM) or Nonlinear AutoRegressive networks with eXogenous inputs (NARX). It shows how one might prepare some malicious input data to make the trained neural network produce wrong answers. This paper aims to analyze such manipulations’ impact on RNN-based networks. The article will include a comprehensive study of which gradient-based and non-gradient-based data manipulation techniques are possible.An LSTM network will be used for a classification task of a text sequence, but a similar approach might be applied to electrical signals or network traffic data. Due to the discrete nature of the sequence tokens, it covers techniques based on synonymization, token removal, or random token insertion. A technique leveraging the BERT model to search for more context-aware synonyms is presented.This paper adapts methods like Projected Gradient Descent (PGD) to generate adversarial sequences of tokens. The mentioned method allows using a gradient of the model’s loss function to discover optimal token perturbations. This article shows the results of experiments on how different word embeddings (like GloVe or Word2Vec) affect the model’s performance and accuracy.Final findings suggest that LSTM models exhibit greater resistance to subtle input changes (using synonyms) than standard RNNs but remain susceptible to more advanced attacks. The research shows that crafting an adversarial sequence of tokens is inherently more complex than crafting a malicious image data or a time series. However, it is still feasible and can result in successful model misclassification.The second part of the paper focuses on recurrent neural networks for a forecasting task. A NARX model is trained to predict the sensor readings of a simple ventilation system. The input to the model is a control signal with an electric valve states. This model is a troublesome due to its recurrent connections. An Automatic Differentiation is used for efficient calculation of the gradient with respect to the input control signal. The Forward Accumulation Automatic Differentiation presents itself as a viable option for a fast calculation of such a gradient. This derivatives might be useful at determining how the input signal have to be modified in order to change the predicted values significantly.

title: Design and Implementation of a Robotic System for Automated Page Turning And OCR-Based Text-to-Speech Conversion System
authors: Srivatsan S, Susmitha Vekkot, Rajeevlochana G Chittawadigi
abstract: The work presents a low-cost, end-to-end system for digitizing printed books and enabling intelligent voice-based interaction using OCR, semantic retrieval, and Text-to-Speech (TTS). A Raspberry Pi with a camera module captures a page of a book placed on the system, which are processed using three OCR tools: Tessract, EasyOCR, and DocTR. The extracted text is semantically indexed using the all-MiniLM-L6-v2 Sentence Transformer model. The system has a set of servo motors and moving links which enable turning of pages in either direction for the capture of the next set of images. After capturing all the pages, the users can query the system, and the most relevant response is retrieved and read aloud using Google TTS. Performance is evaluated on 10 textbook chapters using Word Error Rate (WER) and Character Error Rate (CER). Tesseract achieved the best average accuracy with WER of 8.66% and CER of 7.39%.

title: Enhancing Stock Market Price Prediction with Advanced Machine Learning Techniques: A Comparative Study
authors: Yogesh Kumar Jain, Praveen Kumar Mannepalli, Santosh Kumar, Amit Malhotra, Deepak Kumar Choudhary, Mohit Saharan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The non-linearity and intrinsic volatility of financial markets make accurate stock price prediction an important but challenging undertaking. This research proposes a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU)-based model to forecast the stock prices of Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) using 18 years of historical data sourced from Yahoo Finance, comprising features such as Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Adjusted Close, and Volume. The methodology includes data preprocessing steps such as feature selection using Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE), normalization with standard scaling, and data splitting into 70% training and 30% testing sets. The proposed GRU model was evaluated and benchmarked against existing models including Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Linear Regression (LR), and Decision Tree (DT), using performance metrics such as Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) and R2 score. Experimental outcomes revealed that the GRU model achieved the best performance with an RMSE of 0.045, outperforming LSTM (38.19), LR (8.66), and DT (5.22). The study's findings have important implications for algorithmic trading and well-informed investment choices, since the GRU model effectively captures temporal trends in stock data while minimizing prediction mistakes.

title: Improvement in harmonic reduction of multipulse rectifier for X-ray generator
authors: Khaoula Yeferni, Sana Ktata, Salem Rahmani, Kamal Al-Haddad
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The primary characteristic determining the effectiveness of an X-ray generator is the quality of the output voltage, which directly affects the quality of X-ray images. This makes the elimination of harmonics generated in the power conversion stages a critical concern. Indeed, although the integration of filtering stages can temporarily mask the harmonics, they reappear at the load level due to the high power demand. The adaptation of polyphase rectifiers at the initial stages of the X-ray generator assembly is the solution investigated in this article. In this work, a three-phase voltage of 380 V at a frequency of 50 Hz is applied to the X-ray generator, which incorporates 6, 12, and 24-pulse rectifiers. Simulation results obtained using MATLAB are presented to validate the effectiveness of this approach.

title: Secure and Energy-Efficient Load Balancing for Fog Computing in SDN Environments
authors: Taki Alrwbaye, Richa Agarwal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: In response to the proliferation of Internet of Things devices and data-intensive applications, low-latency and energy-efficient computing solutions have become increasingly important. Cloud infrastructure is relieved of this burden by fog computing, which processes data at the network edge, thereby reducing the load on the cloud. Fog environments, however, are often plagued by issues such as inefficient load balancing, high energy consumption, and security vulnerabilities. SDN-enabled fog computing infrastructures can benefit from a load-balancing framework that is both energy-efficient and secure. Tasks are intelligently distributed across fog nodes using energy-aware task scheduling, lightweight security mechanisms, and centralised intelligence from SDN controllers. Simulated experiments demonstrate that the proposed model reduces energy consumption, task execution time, and response latency while maintaining system security and load distribution. Based on these results, we can conclude that the model enhances resource utilization, sustainability, and performance in dynamic fog computing environments.

title: A Machine Learning Approach to Load Forecasting Using Extreme Gradient Boosting with Cross-Validation Technique
authors: Suruchi Shrivastava, Anamika Yadav, Shubhrata Gupta
abstract: Accurate forecasting of future electricity load has become increasingly important due to rising demand. This study focuses on day-ahead load prediction using the XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) machine learning algorithm following Short-term load forecasting approach, enhanced with k-fold cross validation for robust performance evaluation. The model depends on historical data gathered from Chhattisgarh Load Dispatch Centre, comprise the data from 25th December 2023 to 30th April 2025. The dataset is randomly allotted into training, validation, and testing set. The performance of the model on each subset is measured by standard performance metrics involving Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE). Furthermore, the projected framework is compared with previous approaches to highlight its effectiveness and potential for future applications.

title: Graph Neural Networks for Customer Churn Analysis in Subscription-Based Business Models
authors: Sagar Bhadange, Chanakya Kumar Jha, Ankit Bajaj, Ajit Sane, Manjiri Joshi, Pallavi Jha, Pranda Prasanta Gupta
abstract: Customer churn prediction is critical for subscription-based businesses to maintain revenue stability and optimize retention strategies. Traditional machine learning approaches treat customers as independent entities, ignoring the rich relational information inherent in customer networks. This paper proposes a novel Graph Neural Network (GNN) framework that captures complex customer interactions and social influences to predict churn probability. We model customers as nodes in a graph, with edges representing various relationships including referrals, shared services, and social connections. Our approach employs Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) and Graph Attention Networks (GAT) to learn node embeddings that encapsulate both individual customer features and network structure. Experiments on three real-world datasets—Telco Customer Churn, IBM Watson Churn, and Kaggle Subscription Service—demonstrate that our GNN-based model achieves superior performance with accuracy improvements of 7.3%, 8.1%, and 6.8% over traditional methods including Random Forest, XGBoost, and Multi-Layer Perceptron. The model achieves F1-scores of 0.847, 0.862, and 0.835 on respective datasets, with AUC-ROC scores exceeding 0.91 across all benchmarks. Our findings suggest that incorporating network topology significantly enhances churn prediction capabilities, enabling more effective customer retention strategies.

title: Neural Networks and Transformers for EEG- Based Neurological Disorder Detection
authors: Nikita M. Lad, Prasad Lokulwar, Girish Talmale
abstract: Epilepsy is a most common neurological condition marked by recurrent seizures, which can greatly affect both the lives of individuals and their interactions within society. The sudden and unpredictable occurrence of epilepsy seizures, hence there is a growing need for automated systems to aid in epilepsy diagnosis. Historically diagnosis involves analysing EEG signals, but recent advancements in deep learning have gained traction for their ability to automate this process without relying on manual feature extraction. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), while effective at capturing local temporal features, often struggle with modeling long-range dependencies due to their limited receptive fields, which can hinder performance in EEG signal decoding. To address this, we introduce a lightweight Convolutional Transformer architecture, termed EEG Conformer, which integrates local as well as global feature extraction into a cohesive EEG classification framework. The convolutional module is designed to extract low-level temporal and spatial features using one-dimensional convolutional layers. In parallel, a self-attention mechanism is employed to model long-range temporal dependencies by identifying global patterns within the local features. Following this, a simple fully connected classifier predicts the EEG signal categories. To improve interpretability, we implement a visualization approach that maps class activation outputs onto the brain’s topography. We validate our model on three publicly available datasets related to EEG-based motor imagery and emotion recognition tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior performance compared to existing approaches and shows strong potential as a robust baseline for general EEG decoding tasks.

title: Energy Management in a Fuel Cell based Hybrid Electric Vehicle Using Machine Learning
authors: Mohamed Charfeddine Meherzi, Nizar Brahim, Hatem Allegui, Abdelkader Mami
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper explores energy management in fuel cell hybrid electric vehicles, emphasizing energy efficiency and operational performance. The study involves the mathematical modelling of critical hybrid powertrain components, including the fuel cell, lithium-ion battery, supercapacitors, and power converters. By leveraging artificial intelligence techniques, particularly neural networks, the research proposes innovative and optimized energy management strategies. Simulations conducted in Python within the Jupyter environment evaluate the effectiveness of these strategies, aiming to enhance fuel efficiency and support sustainable mobility. Synthetic datasets are employed for model training and validation, demonstrating the potential of machine learning to deliver substantial improvements.

title: Robust Position Control of a DC Servo Using State Feedback Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Control
authors: Jim George
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: DC motors with encoder sensors are commonly used in industrial settings where precision in controlling position and quick response times are quintessential with the perspective of ensuring reliable performance amid uncertainties and disturbances. This work explores the implementation of Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Control (ST-SMC) for precise position regulation of a DC servo motor. The rotary encoder is used to measure the angular position, which gives a feedback signal when differentiated, giving the angular velocity. The control algorithms are tested on a QUBE DC servo motor platform using a Hardware-in-the-Loop (HiL) setup to evaluate real-time performance. Harmony Search Algorithm is applied to determine Best fitness which a measure of length of phase trajectory which is closed in structure. The results show that HS-tuned ST-SMC controller exhibit improved robustness by applying variation of Integral Square Error and trajectory length. This demonstrates that Harmony Search is an effective method for designing robust controllers in nonlinear motion control systems.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Pricing Strategies in Revenue Management
authors: Vinaydeep Brar, Pallavi Jha, Shravasti Jain, Sparsh Mehrotra, Atul Kumar, Chanakya Kumar Jha, Deepak Gupta
abstract: In today’s highly competitive marketplace, dynamic pricing strategies have become essential tools for maximizing revenue across various industries. Traditional static pricing models fail to adapt to rapidly changing market conditions, customer preferences, and competitive pressures. This research introduces an innovative framework leveraging deep reinforcement learning (DRL) techniques to enable automated, intelligent pricing decisions in revenue management applications. Our approach builds upon the Deep Q-Network (DQN) architecture, incorporating two significant enhancements: prioritized experience replay mechanisms that accelerate learning from critical pricing scenarios, and dueling network structures that separately evaluate state values and action advantages. These architectural improvements enable the system to effectively learn near-optimal pricing policies even in environments characterized by substantial demand uncertainty and volatility. We conduct extensive empirical validation using authentic transaction data from two major sectors: hotel reservations and commercial aviation. The experimental evaluation demonstrates that our DRL-based pricing system achieves substantial revenue gains, specifically a 12.3% improvement over conventional rule-based pricing methods that rely on fixed thresholds and heuristics, and a 7.8% enhancement compared to classical Q-learning algorithms. These results provide compelling evidence that deep learning architectures possess the capacity to extract and leverage intricate patterns in market dynamics, competitive behaviors, and customer purchasing decisions, ultimately enabling more sophisticated and profitable pricing strategies in complex, real-world revenue management scenarios.

title: A Theoretical Multilevel Adaptive Framework for Social Sustainability in Flexible Distribution Systems
authors: Bayode Andrew Akomolafe, Jessie Ma, Juan Moreno-Cruz
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Active distribution networks are critical to power system sustainability but also pose significant challenges to the flexibility and resilience of power systems due to the high penetration of renewable resources. The solution to this challenge has concentrated on the predominant quantitative methods and technocentric and econometric aspects. This paper integrates social sciences into the energy-climate research in active distribution network power systems. The paper explores a thematic review of social sustainability management theories in developing a socially conscious adaptive theoretical framework towards flexibility and resilience of Distribution System Operators (DSO)-level power systems. The adaptive theoretical framework potentially helps create a research field where social actors and systems are not decoupled from decision-making across multiple scales, where the embeddedness of the system is not taken for granted and fully captures the nuances at the nexus of systems, agents, and transition. The result highlights systems theory, agency theory and transition management theory as the core of a socially sustainable active distribution network.

title: Dementia Patients for Raspberry Pi and YOLOv5 using Machine Learning
authors: K. Kishore Kumar, P. Srinivasa Rao, G. Nithya, A. Nageswari, Shashi Kant Dargar, Amit Gupta
abstract: A brain disorder called Alzheimer's disease gradually reduces a person's ability to think and remember things. It progressively worsens until it significantly impairs the way the afflicted individual lives and contributes to society. Memory loss and trouble identifying family members are only two of the many difficulties associated with dementia, a complicated mental health condition that primarily affects the elderly. This study aims to address the urgent need for improved detection methods and support options, given that there are almost 50 million dementia sufferers globally and a severe lack of qualified caregivers in India. The primary objective of this suggested effort is to use a question-answer paradigm to identify the patients' stage of dementia. Secondly, YOLOv5, which employs CNN (Convolution Neural Network) for 95.2% accuracy.

title: Single-Cell Universal Logic-in-Memory Using 2T-nC FeRAM: An Area and Energy-Efficient Approach for Bulk Bitwise Computation
authors: Rudra Biswas, Jiahui Duan, Shan Deng, Xuezhong Niu, Yixin Qin, Prapti Panigrahi, Varun Parekh, Rajiv Joshi, Kai Ni, Vijaykrishnan Narayanan
abstract: This work presents a novel approach to configure 2T-nC ferroelectric RAM (FeRAM) for performing single cell logic-in-memory operations, highlighting its advantages in energy-efficient computation over conventional DRAM-based approaches. Unlike conventional 1T-1C dynamic RAM (DRAM), which incurs refresh overhead, 2T-nC FeRAM offers a promising alternative as a non-volatile memory solution with low energy consumption. Our key findings include the potential of quasi-nondestructive readout (QNRO) sensing in 2T-nC FeRAM for logic-in-memory (LiM) applications, demonstrating its inherent capability to perform inverting logic without requiring external modifications, a feature absent in traditional 1T-1C DRAM. We successfully implement the MINORITY function within a single cell of 2T-nC FeRAM, enabling universal NAND and NOR logic, validated through SPICE simulations and experimental data. Additionally, the research investigates the feasibility of 3D integration with 2T-nC FeRAM, showing substantial improvements in storage and computational density, facilitating bulk-bitwise computation. Our evaluation of eight real-world, data-intensive applications reveals that 2T-nC FeRAM achieves 2× higher performance and 2.5× lower energy consumption compared to DRAM. Furthermore, the thermal stability of stacked 2T-nC FeRAM is validated, confirming its reliable operation when integrated on a compute die. These findings emphasize the advantages of 2T-nC FeRAM for LiM, offering superior performance and energy efficiency over conventional DRAM.

title: Network Fiber Costing Accuracy Through Geospatial and Non-Planar Terrain Management
authors: Prashanth Bhushan, Anwesh Ponugumati, Ankush Keshkar
abstract: Telecom Network planning and construction that comes under the purview of Outside Plant Engineering is one of the most critical functions of a Telecom service provider. Accurate estimation of fiber cable length and cost management during Network planning is critical for the successful deployment of fiber networks. However, issues arise in costs and scheduled deployments due to discrepancies between planned and actual lengths leading to delays in network deployment and reduced customer satisfaction. One of the key reasons for this is the differences in topography and non-planar terrain that would result in changes in fiber estimations, splitters and the planned network topology. This can lead to significant cost overruns and project delays. This paper explores the challenges associated with these discrepancies, the importance of path creation, and proposes methods to improve estimation accuracy using the Geodesic DEM dataset. The paper proposes ways in which a 2D plan can be transformed into a 3D plan (a non-planar terrain), thereby giving a better length estimation. The authors also explore other alternative methods and the future extensions to the proposed methodology.

title: A Machine Learning Framework for Fish Selection in Sustainable Aquaculture
authors: Mohammad Kamal Uddin, Mohammad Tarek Aziz, Juel Sikder, Malokhat Saidmuratova, Temur Eshchanov, Valisher Sapayev Odilbek Uglu, Md. Badiuzzaman Biplob, Tanjim Mahmud, Mohammad Aman Ullah
abstract: For fish farmers in the real world, selecting the best fish species for aquaculture in a given aquatic environment is a very difficult issue. The main goal of this research is to develop a machine learning model that can predict the best fish species to raise in an aquatic environment and suggest many fish species with anticipated ones. In this research, we have employed a number of supervised and unsupervised machine learning models. To evaluate the model, we used a dataset of aquatic habitats for eleven different fish species. We predicted the fish species using a variety of aquatic environmental factors, including temperature, turbidity, and pH. As performance measurements, we employed accuracy, F1 score, precision, and recall. According to experimental findings, it is suggested that the Random Forest (RF) model’s prediction result exhibits an accuracy of 97.64% with good precision, recall, and F1 score for the dataset under test. Furthermore, we compare the results of the suggested model with the most advanced models, including SVC, random forest, gradient boosting, MLP, KNN, and others. The proposed model performs better than other applied models, as evidenced by its accuracy score and statistics. Finally, we applied an unsupervised ML model, K-means clustering to make recommendations of multiple species with the predicted fish species. The experimental result shows good recommendation outcomes.

title: An Optimized Neural Network driven Intelligent System for Date Fruit Classification and Analysis in Smart Agricultural Practices and Sustainable Economic Growth
authors: Maheswara Rao V V R, Silpa N, Padmaja S M, P N V Navya Sri, Vutukuri Akshaya, Shiva Shankar Reddy
abstract: Smart agricultural practices face crucial challenges in promoting sustainable economic growth, particularly in date fruit classification, where traditional methods fall short in precision, scalability, and efficiency. Further, current research highlights issues such as variability in size, shape, color, and texture across date varieties. These limitations drive the need for advanced machine learning techniques, especially neural networks, to enhance accuracy and optimize decision-making processes. This research presents an optimized neural network-driven intelligent system, leveraging advanced machine learning techniques to enhance decision-making in agriculture. It develops and evaluates various neural network architectures, including bilayer, wide, tri-layer, and a proposed optimizable neural network. Among these, the optimizable neural network achieved the highest classification accuracy. To further improve performance, feature engineering techniques such as MRMR, Chi-square, ANOVA, and Kruskal were applied, with MRMR proving most effective. Moreover, backward sequential feature selection identified an optimal set of top 18 ranked features, significantly enhancing the model's predictive accuracy and efficiency. This proposed intelligent system leverages advanced neural networks to address the complexities of date fruit classification, offering a robust framework for modern agricultural challenges while contributing valuable insights to agricultural innovation and sustainable economic growth.

title: HiFi-LLP: High-Fidelity, Low-Cost Latency Predictors with Confidence for Robust HW-NAS
authors: Shambhavi Balamuthu Sampath, Behzad Shomali, Nael Fasfous, Moritz Thoma, Judeson Anthony Fernando, Lukas Frickenstein, Pierpaolo Mori, Manoj Rohit Vemparala, Alexander Frickenstein, Walter Stechele
abstract: With deep neural networks (DNNs) increasingly deployed on edge devices, hardware (HW)-aware optimization techniques—such as HW-aware compression and HW-aware neural architecture search (HW-NAS)—have become essential. These methods rely on real feedback from the target hardware to tailor DNN architectures for efficient deployment. While the search can be parallelized, latency measurements via hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) remain a bottleneck due to their sequential nature. Recent approaches use latency predictors to replace costly HIL feedback, but challenges persist: (1) platform-specific predictors often require tens of thousands of samples, and (2) inaccurate predictions can mislead the NAS process. To address this, we introduce HiFi-LLP, a high-fidelity, low-cost latency predictor based on graph attention networks, augmented with a confidence metric. HiFi-LLP outperforms prior platform-specific predictors by up to 9 percentage points (p.p.) in the 10% accuracy bound and achieves a Spearman’s rank correlation of up to 0.996 across six devices in the LatBench dataset. We further propose a hybrid NAS framework that routes low-confidence predictions to HIL, achieving up to 8.6× speedup compared to typical NAS while maintaining a competitive Pareto front. Code is available at https://github.com/shamvbs/HiFi-LLP. <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>

title: Transformative Innovations in Organic and 2D Materials for Next-Gen Flexible and Wearable Electronics
authors: Shamim Ahmad Khan, Eswararao Boddepalli, Haider Sharif Mahdi, Sabah Abdul Wahab Sheet, Sattar Jabar Daham Wassif, K. Selvakumarasamy
abstract: The swiftly changing trends in wearable and flexible electronics call for next-generation materials to be light, energy-effective, and even environmentally friendly. Silicon-based devices, the conventional semiconductors for electronics, have now reached a limitation in flexibility and high processing costs and so-called green impacts. At that point, their attention has shifted to organic semiconductors and two-dimensional (2D) materials. Thus, the research intends to develop high-performance hybrid electronic devices based, by the synergy of organic semiconductors with 2D materials (graphene, MoS₂, and MXenes), on flexibility, scalability, and sustainability. In contrast with traditional approaches that either consider organic-focusing or 2D-materials-focusing, the present work proposes a hybrid framework integrating organic semiconductors for mechanical flexibility with high electrical conductivity present in 2D materials. The main new point is the incorporation of solution-processable organic layers with CVD-grown 2D layers for optimization of the charge transport, mechanical stability, and durability of devices. The framework would involve (i) material selection and hybridization, (ii) scalable fabrication using inkjet printing and CVD, and (iii) performance analysis across transistor, sensor, and energy storage applications. The experimental evaluations provided better than a 40% increase in charge mobility, more than over 10⁶ bending cycles of durability, and measurement accuracy always above 95% compared with theoretical benchmarks. The hybrid devices showed superior electrical and mechanical performance over standalone organic or 2D devices, with enhanced operational stability and environmental resilience. As such, transistors displayed high ON/OFF ratios, sensor showed fast and selective response, and energy devices showed increased power densities meeting the IoT and biomedical applications. The research sets up a new sustainable route for flexible and wearable electronics via hybrid organic-2D architectures. The suggested solution introduces a possible sustainable, high-throughput, and commercially viable electronics path toward future smart technologies.

title: Automatic Vehicle Control Using Visible Light Communication
authors: Abhinand Sivarajan Pillai, Naveen S, M J Jayashree
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Communication is an impartment of data through some medium. Communication is thus important, as it is a necessity for all of us to have an expression of our actions to others. It is thus vital to establish communication on crucial actions that we execute or undertake. A crucial action that needs our complete undivided attention or engrossment is while “Driving”. Most of the accidents that happen while driving is due to the communication of our actions not being invigorated. This paper presents both a proof of concept and an approach for establishing communication between vehicles in an automated scenario via light as the medium, thus circumventing the room for manual errors. Proposing here is a methodology and a scaled-down design to help achieve fully functional automatic vehicles in near future by the concept of Vehicle to Everything(V2X) using Visible Light Communication, which incorporates slowing down vehicles at accident prone areas, mitigating the problem of high beams lights of vehicles at night time, monitoring traffic signals for violation and periodic transfer of all collected data to server.

title: Pattern-Based Model-Driven UI Prototyping from Two-Hemisphere Models
authors: Kristaps Babris
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: The use of user interface patterns in software development is becoming increasingly essential due to their ability to improve consistency, usability, and development efficiency. This paper explores a model-driven approach to user interface development by automatically generating user interface prototypes from structured process and concept models of the two-hemisphere model. The study highlights the potential and challenges of using user interface patterns in this context, describes the transformation process, and presents a case application in e-commerce. An automated transformation algorithm is proposed, leveraging pattern classification, keyword extraction, and context refinement.

title: Real-Time Question Generation from Educational Video Lectures using Deep Learning
authors: Deepak Mane, Revati Nimbalkar, Shrushti Gavali, Subodh Deogade, Sampada Khopade
abstract: Student engagement and understanding could be greatly improved by automatically creating questions from live lecture audio. Using OpenAI's Whisper for speech-to-text transcription and a Flan-T5 based model to produce contextually relevant queries, we provide a novel pipeline in this study. Proposed model’ incorporation of synthetic speech technology to read the generated questions aloud is a significant innovation that makes learning more engaging and accessible, particularly for users who are visually impaired or auditory learners.With a BERTScore of 88.94%, the results demonstrate that this approach is highly effective at producing logically sound questions. Additionally, it has the benefit of voice-based delivery, which enables real-time feedback during live learning sessions.This work presents an end-to-end, voice-enabled solution for interactive learning support, which adds to the expanding field of AI-assisted education.

title: Accelerate On-Chip Artificial Neural Network Training: a Customised fNIRS Signals Processing System-on-Chip
authors: Yunyi Zhao, Hubin Zhao, Shufan Yang
abstract: During artificial neural network (ANN) training, batch normalisation (BN) techniques improve training performance algorithmically but create hardware implementation challenges. This paper aims to address this specific bottleneck within the broader challenge of on-chip training. We propose an all-onchip artificial neural network (ANN) training framework that utilises AMD’s Versal XCVC1902 heterogeneous SoC with a purpose-built batch-normalisation (BN) accelerator to overcome the two main barriers to edge computing: memory bandwidth and batch normalisation layer latency. By hardwiring batch normalisation calculation to form a hardware primitive and using fixed-point arithmetic, the design improves batch normalisation latency from tens of cycles to nine cycles, improving the efficiency of the ANN training process. The hardware-software co-design strategy demonstrates how deep processing unit cores, BN engine based on FPGA fabric, and CPUs can be orchestrated through a unifying abstraction, pointing toward application-specific SoCs that hide low-level scheduling from machine learning developers. The framework is evaluated as an application of real-time functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) signal reconstruction, where cloud off-loading is undesirable for privacy and latency reasons. Although evaluated on fNIRS, the tiled batch normalisation engine and zero-copy dataflow can be reused in any ANN training that spends a significant fraction of time in batch normalisation layers.

title: Comparative Analysis of ANNs and SNNs for Road Sign Detection in Autonomous Driving
authors: Ameny Gharby, Elyes Feki, Abdelkader Mami
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Understanding and accurately interpreting road signs are essential capabilities for autonomous driving systems, ensuring safety and efficient navigation. This paper compares two neural network models: Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) and Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs), focusing on their performance and potential for implementation on Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs). Both models were trained on a diverse collection of road sign data, with their performance evaluated based on metrics such as accuracy, precision, and energy efficiency. The findings demonstrate that while both models achieve high accuracy, SNNs excel in energy efficiency, making them a more practical choice for FPGA-based systems. These results emphasize the promise of SNNs as a competitive and energy-efficient solution for real-time traffic sign recognition in autonomous driving applications.

title: Fake News Detection based on Deep Learning using Saudien Dialect
authors: Majed Alsafyani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This study addresses the detection of fake news in the Saudi dialect of Arabic using deep learning techniques. The researchers utilize a dataset from Twitter and compare multiple models, including traditional machine learning models (SVM, Naïve Bayes), deep learning models (LSTM, CNN), and a transformer-based model, AraBERT. The results show that AraBERT outperforms the other models, achieving an accuracy of $91.6 \%$, a precision of $92.4 \%$, a recall of $90.3 \%$, and an F 1 - score of $91.3 \%$. This study highlights the effectiveness of pre- trained transformer models in handling linguistic challenges related to Arabic dialects. Future work includes exploring hybrid approaches and more diverse datasets to enhance fake news detection.

title: A Smart Adaptive Beaconing Framework Using Fuzzy Logic for Geographical-Based Mobile Ad-Hoc Network Routing
authors: Qasim Jumaa, Areena Ali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: In Mobile Ad-hoc Networks (MANETs), routing strategies must be efficient and reliable because of their dynamic topologies and infrastructure-less nature. In addition to offering scalability through location information, geographic routing protocols such as GPSR often rely on fixed beaconing intervals, resulting in either excessive control overhead or stale routing data. This paper proposes a Smart Adaptive Beaconing Framework using Fuzzy Logic (SAB-FL) that dynamically adjusts beacon intervals according to real-time network conditions, such as node mobility and residual energy. AODV routing protocol FL-AODV is enhanced with a fuzzy logic-based decision-making system that evaluates delay, energy, and stability when selecting relay nodes. In addition to improving packet delivery ratios, throughput, and end-to-end delays, the proposed framework minimises routing overhead. In dense or highly mobile environments, SAB-FL outperforms traditional GPSR and AODV protocols, providing a robust and energy-efficient geographical routing solution in MANETs.

title: 3D-Aware Latent-Space Reenactment: Combining Expression Transfer and Semantic Editing
authors: Paul Hinzer, Florian Barthel, Anna Hilsmann, Peter Eisert
publish: Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGGRAPH European Conference on Visual Media Production
abstract: None

title: An Empirical Assessment of Student Mood Profile Prediction Using Ensemble Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Prabha Chacko, Pratima Gautam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The decision-making process related to stream/subject/course selection is closely linked to one’s mood state. This study aims to conduct a comparative analysis using Ensemble Machine Learning Techniques (EMLT) to investigate the mood state of individuals based on survey responses received from the population. The sample population consisted of 457 students from diverse streams. Exploratory factor analysis was performed to understand the correlation of factors influencing the mood of the respondents. Data was collected from both male and female respondents through survey in textual format and evaluated using Python on Jupyter Notebook with Random Forest, XGBoost, and Gradient Boosting Classifiers. This research work results highlight mood state prediction and comparative accuracy of machine learning classifiers. While, various machine learning classifiers were utilized in our research however main focus was on Tree-based classifiers due to their higher accuracy. As a result, Gradient Boosting Classifier outperformed other models achieving an accuracy of $85 \%$ on test data as compared to the other two ensemble machine learning classifiers.

title: Active Fault Tolerant Control by Bond Graph Reduced Observer: Stringing Machine Study Case
authors: Rim Attafi, Chiheb Zaoui, Habib Dallagi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: To take the appropriate decision to stop or to leave it in operation, we correctly choose the industrial systems for reliable control purpose. Active fault tolerant control (AFTC) of automated systems goes to the heart of the matter. This paper treats a new methodology for AFTC based on bond graph (BG) approach modeling. We construct the BG reduced Luenberger observer to study the robust diagnosis of the stringing machine. Tests are applied on the tree compressibility parameter of the stringing machine. Our aim of the robust diagnostic is to detect, to locate and to estimate faults which affect the studied system by generating the residues equations. In order to be effective, the diagnostic system should be robust for residues generation and insensitive to faults. The results are validated by the 20Sim software for the simulation.

title: System Level Acceleration of Banded Smith Waterman on FPGA
authors: Christian Lanius, Ibrahim Burak Yorulmaz, Tobias Gemmeke
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Next generation sequencing technology enables a new wave of personalized healthcare, large scale research into genome variations and population level sequencing due to its low cost and high throughput to generate genomic reads. The alignment of the reads against references or de-novo assembly becomes a computational bottleneck for portable in-field sequencing, analysis and real-time operation. The base level alignment is performed with the Smith-Waterman or similar algorithms, and has been well studied due to its suitability for hardware implementation. Previous work is limited in its applicability due to its simplifications compared to the complete algorithm as used in state-of-the-art software toolboxes or its focus on the base operation. In this work, we show a system level assessment, implementation and integration with the reference software, highlighting how the computationally cheap backtracking step has to be hardware accelerated to reduce the amount of data transferred to the host. The hardware implementation, which is bit-level equivalent to the software reference, is made freely available online.

title: A Fuzzy Logic Controller for Real-Time Operation in LabVIEW of a Portable Chemical Reactor for Industrial Applications
authors: Jhonatan A. Rodriguez, Miyer E. Diaz R, Oscar J. Suarez, Cristhian Ivan Riañno Jaimes, Aldo Pardo Garcia
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: This paper presents automatic control strategies for a portable chemical reactor, combining classical (Tyreus-Luyben) and intelligent (PD Fuzzy) control techniques to optimize the conversion of expanded polystyrene into paint products. In the real-time operation, the PD Fuzzy controller maintained the temperature from $\mathbf{4 0}^{\circ} \mathbf{C}$ to $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ with a steady-state error of $\pm \mathbf{0. 1 8} { }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, a rise time of 580 seconds, and an overshoot of $\mathbf{1 3. 0 2 6 \%}$. In the same way, a PD Fuzzy controller maintained the level between 2 cm and 10 cm with a steady-state error of $\pm 0.01 \mathrm{~cm}$, a rise time of $\mathbf{1 4. 2 3}$ seconds, and an overshoot of $\mathbf{4. 4 3 \%}$. The results are experimentally validated through real-time monitoring using LabVIEW, confirming the robustness of both controllers against nonlinearities. These findings highlight their potential to enhance energy efficiency and product quality in chemical processes.

title: TEMPORA: Intelligent Weather Monitoring and Disaster Forecasting System
authors: P R Ashitha, Anju Vincent, S. Swapna Kumar, A T Benito, N Arjun Dev, S Asna, Bhanumathi J Menon
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Automatic Weather Stations (AWS) are crucial for real-time meteorological monitoring and disaster prediction, particularly for rainfall, landslides, and floods. Traditional AWS systems often face challenges such as high costs and inadequate spatial resolution, limiting their effectiveness for localized weather forecasts. This study proposes an enhanced AWS network that improves data granularity from $12 \mathrm{~km} \times 12 \mathrm{~km}$ to $3 \mathrm{~km} \times 3 \mathrm{~km}$, enabling more precise and timely predictions. By integrating IoT-based sensors and machine learning algorithms, the system processes real-time environmental data to forecast rain direction, landslides, and floods. A case study highlights the severe consequences of insufficient early warnings, underscoring the need for accurate, hyper-local data. The proposed solution aims to mitigate risks by delivering detailed and reliable weather predictions, enhancing preparedness for extreme weather events. This research emphasizes the importance of high-resolution environmental sensing for disaster management, agricultural planning, and climate resilience. The integration of advanced technologies in AWS networks promises to revolutionize weather monitoring, providing critical insights to safeguard communities and ecosystems from the growing threats of climate change.

title: A Hybrid Approach to Real-Time Flood Susceptibility Mapping Using Machine Learning and Open-Source Data
authors: Rajesh Reddy Vuyyuru
abstract: This paper introduces a novel methodology for generating real-time flood susceptibility maps, focusing on regions with limited access to traditional hydrological datasets. The approach integrates web-scraped information from local sources with meteorological data accessed via an open-source API. A machine-learning framework, utilizing an ensemble classifier, is employed to predict flood-prone areas. The system’s output is visualized through an interactive web application, providing critical information for disaster response and mitigation. The efficacy of the proposed methodology is demonstrated through a case study, highlighting its potential for enhancing flood preparedness in data-scarce environments.

title: Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Models for Short-Term Distribution System Load Forecasting
authors: Elias Raffoul, Mingjian Tuo, Cunzhi Zhao, Tianxia Zhao, Meng Ling, Xingpeng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Accurate electrical load forecasting is crucial for optimizing power system operations, planning, and management. As power systems become increasingly complex, traditional forecasting methods may fail to capture the intricate patterns and dependencies within load data. Machine learning (ML) techniques have emerged as powerful alternatives, offering superior prediction accuracy and the ability to model non-linear and complex temporal relationships. This study presents a comprehensive comparison of prominent ML modelsfeedforward neural networks, recurrent neural networks, long short-term memory networks, gated recurrent units, and the attention temporal graph convolutional network-for short-term load forecasting of the Energy Corridor distribution system in Houston, Texas. Using a 24 -hour look-back window, we train the models on datasets spanning one and five years, to predict the load demand for the next hour and assess performance. Our findings aim to identify the most effective ML approach for accurate load forecasting, contributing to improved grid reliability and system optimization.

title: Leveraging 3D CNNs for Robust Detection of GAN-Generated Medical Image Forgeries
authors: Sandhya L S, Ajeesh Ramanujan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Medical images play a pivotal role in today’s health sector. With the advancement of technologies, clinical images from imaging devices are communicated to doctors or radiologists in real time via the Internet. However, this makes clinical images susceptible to tampering attacks. With the emergence of adversarial network architectures, generating deepfake content has become facile. Malicious actors may manipulate medical images to make false insurance claims, provide incorrect diagnoses, or even endanger someone’s life. Adversarial network poses a serious threat as they blur the line between authentic and manipulated images, making it difficult for doctors to discern the real from the fake. This paper proposes an efficient a nd robust 3D CNN model that helps the healthcare sector to distinguish real and tampered medical images. The proposed architecture performed well with a remarkable accuracy of $\mathbf{9 2. 7 7 \%, ~} \mathbf{9 3. 7 8 \%}$ precision, and $92.60 \%$ F1 score. Furthermore, this 3D CNN model performs well when compared to the existing model. This study reveals that tampering with medical images using adversarial networks can be detected utilizing 3DCNNs.

title: Exploring AI in Kidney Tumor Detection: A Critical Analysis of Radiomics and Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Nafla Iqbal, K C Amudha, Aiswarya Mohan, V P Mohammed Sadin
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Kidney tumor diagnosis through medical imaging methods currently faces a substantial challenge since it remains difficult to differentiate clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) from oncocytomas and other benign lesions. Traditional diagnostic methods often produce inaccurate results when distinguishing between different tumor types because these methods depend primarily on radiological interpretation and invasive biopsy. Medical imaging data analysis through artificial i ntelligence (AI) technology has shown promising results through advancements in radiomics, deep learning and hybrid computational models for achieving better diagnostic accuracy. The research survey uses CT imaging as its main focus to provide a complete evaluation of the existing methods which detect, segment, and classify kidney tumors. The research paper “Distinguishing Kidney Tumor Types Using Radiomics Features and Deep Features” functions as the foundation for this evaluation. The study demonstrates a diagnostic method that enhances tumor subtype classification t hrough t he integration of human-developed radiomic descriptors with machine-extracted deep features. The research builds upon this base to evaluate multiple recent artificial intelligence techniques which include attention-based convolutional neural networks, Crayfish Optimization Algorithm optimization frameworks, fuzzy logic system enhancements, modified GoogLeNet architectures for glomerulus classification and ensemble classifiers utilizing multiple learning strategies. A critical analysis of these various methods through comparative analysis allows this survey to determine their advantages and disadvantages as well as their medical uses.

title: Hybrid Based Deep Learning Technique for Liver Tumor Segmentation using CT Images
authors: Parool Priya, Bipanshi Sharma, Anurag Rai, Shubham Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Liver cancer is the most common disease in women based on one of the latest predictions from the global cancer statistics 2020. The liver is difficult to isolate, making it even more difficult to isolate the tumor from the liver. Imaging techniques such as computed tomography (CT) after collection of liver tissue samples, liver and liver tumor samples. Differentiating between liver and tumors with calculated abdominal contrast is difficult due to the different strengths and overlap of soft tissue and shapes. Images based on shape and grayscale are not ideal. To bridge the gap in this study, this study was used in the UNET model of ResNet152 and proposes a more effective hybrid based model for liver and tumor segmentation from CT image volumes. This study evaluated region of interest (ROI) and liver segmentation, primarily using overlapping models. The liver is segmented to examine the liver according to the amount of image in the abdomen.

title: Software Managed Networks via Coarsening
authors: Pradeep Dogga, Rachee Singh, Suman Nath, Ravi Netravali, Jens Palsberg, George Varghese
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: We propose moving from Software Defined Networks (SDN) to Software Managed Networks (SMN) where all information for managing the life cycle of a network (from deployment to operations to upgrades), across all layers (from Layer 1 through 7) is stored in a central repository. Crucially, a SMN also has a generalized control plane that, unlike SDN, controls all aspects of the cloud including traffic management (e.g., capacity planning) and reliability (e.g., incident routing) at both short (minutes) and large (years) time scales. Just as SDN allows better routing, a SMN improves visibility and enables cross-layer optimizations for faster response to failures and better network planning and operations. Implemented naively, SMN for planetary sc6ale networks requires orders of magnitude larger and more heterogeneous data (e.g., alerts, logs) than SDN. We address this using coarsening — mapping complex data to a more compact abstract representation that has approximately the same effect, and is more scalable, maintainable, and learnable. We show examples including Coarse Bandwidth Logs for capacity planning and Coarse Dependency Graphs for incident routing. Coarse Dependency Graphs improve an incident routing metric from 45% to 78% while for a distributed approach like Scouts the same metric was 22%. We end by discussing how to realize SMN, and suggest cross-layer optimizations and coarsenings for other operational and planning problems in networks.

title: Programmable and Adaptive Scheduling for Distributed Systems
authors: Yuyao Wang, Xiangfeng Zhu, Ratul Mahajan, Stephanie Wang
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: Existing frameworks for managing distributed systems hard-code scheduling policies and their implementations (e.g., centralized vs. decentralized), limiting customization and hurting performance across diverse applications and workloads. We argue for an adaptive scheduling approach, where developers express policies in a high-level, framework-agnostic DSL, and a compiler generates optimized implementations based on policy semantics, workload characteristics, and execution environments. We demonstrate that our compiler-guided approach can significantly improve both scheduling quality and performance.

title: The Role of Inelastic Proton Tunneling in Generating Point Mutations and Genetic Diversity in DNA
authors: Arash Tirandaz, Vahid Salari
publish: IEEE Transactions on Molecular, Biological, and Multi-Scale Communications
abstract: A quantum threat to the fidelity of information transfer in transcription of DNA molecule, is the fluctuation of protons on the base pairs. Point mutations can arise when a hydrogen-bonded proton tunnels between donor and acceptor sites in DNA, transiently creating tautomeric forms that mispair during replication. Despite the elastic way of proton tunneling, we analyze inelastic proton tunneling accompanied by energy exchange with local vibrational/electronic modes and the environment. Within an open-quantum-system framework, we derive Born–Markov master equations for a two-state (double-well) Hamiltonian parameterized by hydrogen-bond geometry and environmental spectral properties. Quantum-chemical parameters are estimated by DFT (B3LYP/6311G, Gaussian09) with water as solvent. We examine temperature depen dence and kinetic isotope effects (H/D). It is shown show that inelastic tunneling can extend tautomer lifetimes and enhance mispairing probabilities. These results provide a quantitative route to connect microscopic proton dynamics with biologically relevant mutation pathways.

title: Scalable Deep Joint Source-Channel Coding for Multi-User Wireless Image Transmission with Diverse Bandwidth Conditions
authors: Feng Wang, Xuechen Chen, Xiaoheng Deng, Siyu Lin
abstract: In recent years, Deep Joint Source-Channel Coding (DeepJSCC) has demonstrated superior performance over traditional digital schemes in wireless image transmission tasks. However, existing DeepJSCC approaches often overlook three critical challenges in broadcast communication scenarios: bandwidth heterogeneity among users, dynamic bandwidth variations experienced by individual users, and users diverse requirements. To address these issues, we propose a scalable DeepJSCC framework tailored for broadcast communications. This framework enables users to adaptively intercept an appropriate amount of encoded data according to their bandwidth conditions or specific requirements, thereby reconstructing images with corresponding quality. Specifically, the transmitter generates a multi-layered codestream, consisting of multiple base layers for image reconstruction at different resolutions, as well as enhancement layers built upon each base layer to improve visual quality. At the receiver, users can selectively intercept the base layer stream corresponding to their desired resolution, and further receive parts of the associated enhancement layer stream. This design allows for flexible and quality-adaptive image reconstruction based on the amount of data received. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed scheme consistently achieves high-quality reconstruction across various resolutions and under diverse interception conditions.

title: Advances in Magnetic Sensing Technologies for Small Target Detection: A Review
authors: Shiyao Wang, Jizhe Zhang, Yang Li, Keyu Sun, Zhihao Mao, Sansheng Wang
abstract: Under the influence of the geomagnetic field, ferromagnetic objects exhibit magnetic anomalies. Additionally, non-magnetic or weakly magnetic metallic targets can induce eddy current magnetic fields when subjected to alternating magnetic field excitation. Magnetic detection technology provides a technical approach for detecting, identifying, and localizing objects by leveraging their magnetic characteristics. The application of magnetic technology for detecting small targets, such as unexploded ordnance and unmanned underwater vehicles, has garnered increasing attention. Notably, methods for detecting large targets, including submarines and sunken ships, differ significantly from those used for small targets. This review systematically highlights advances in magnetic sensing technologies for small target detection. It discusses typical methods and sensor systems for detecting magnetic signals generated by small targets, with a focus on comparing passive, active, and dual-mode methods. Furthermore, the review outlines data processing techniques and solutions for improving sensor response and solving target feature information. Lastly, it offers insights into the developmental trends and future prospects for magnetic detection technologies in small target applications.

title: Mitigating Practical Limitations of LQR for Optimal Control of Grid-Tied Voltage Source Inverter via LQG(MEE) Integration
authors: Sara Ibrahim, Sandro Guenter, Jiajun Yang, Salman Ijaz, Ahmed Nasr, Giampaolo Buticchi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: Although the Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) has been adopted as an optimal control strategy for some grid-connected inverters (GCI) studies, certain critical practical challenges are not addressed for real world applications such as noisy measurements, background harmonic voltage, grid impedance variations under weak grid operation, partial state availability and higher power quality. To address this gap, this paper proposes the integration of linear quadratic Gaussian minimum energy estimator LQG (MEE) control with LQR, combining optimal state estimation and feedback control to enhance the performance which in turn resulting in lower total harmonic distortion (THD) in the grid current, guaranteeing improved power quality in a three-phase GCI with an LCL filter in dq frame. In addition, this approach effectively decouples control performance from sensor inaccuracies and grid side disturbances, leading to improved harmonic attenuation, enhanced disturbance rejection, and reduced dependence on additional sensors, reducing hardware costs. To reduce the computational burden of tuning controller parameters, the sensitivity analysis has been illustrated. A simple integral action is presented to guarantee optimal set point (OSP). Then, the augmented state-space model is built by applying the separation theorem to facilitate studying stability analysis. It was validated for the linearized model and the actual nonlinear system, based on eigenvalue trajectories and Lyapunov theorem, respectively. After that, simulation and experimental results validate the performance of the suggested control scheme. A comparative analysis between the proposed method and the sliding mode control (SMC) has been investigated experimentally in this article. The experimental findings emphasize that the proposed solution not only overcomes the practical limitations of LQR but also mitigates THD in the current of the grid by 30%, even under varying operating conditions.

title: Magnet Arrangement Design and Comprehensive Analysis of a Spilt-Tooth Permanent Magnet Arc Motor Based on Poynting Theory
authors: Xiangru Lin, Shuhua Fang, Qiangren Xu, Zihan Chen
abstract: This article proposes a new split-tooth permanent magnet (PM) arc motor with dual PM excitation. The property of the slot PMs allows the motor having good over-load capacity while the flux-reversal PMs can compensate for the torque in slot-PM motors under light load. This PM combination makes the proposed motor have high torque under different load conditions. Two different magnet arrangements with different rotor poles are investigated through flux harmonic analysis to obtain higher output torque. Two optimal motor type are selected and compared with two benchmark motors that only have flux-reversal PMs. In order to analyze the torque components of the four motors, a Poynting theory-based torque calculation method is proposed, and more detailed derivation is carried out. After optimization and comprehensive torque performance comparison, the proposed motor with 5 rotor poles in a single motor unit is manufacture and tested. The finite element and experimental results validate the superiority of the proposed motor.
