authors: Morgan Kiani, Naznin Akter
abstract: In October 2024, the IEEE Industrial Electronics Society (IES) and the IEEE Guatemala Section hosted a Solar Energy Outreach Workshop at Luminarias, San Lucas Sacatepéquez. More than technical training, the program served as a catalyst for education, empowerment, and sustainable development. Inspired and guided by Dr. Morgan Kiani, a senior member of IES and a long-time advocate for community advancement, the workshop reflected her broader philosophy of outreach rooted in sustainability, empathy, and cultural understanding.

title: Pattern Reconfigurable Circularly Polarized Yagi-Uda Dielectric Resonator Antenna
authors: Yuerong Liu, Donghao Li, Yuandan Dong
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: To overcome the structural complexity and intricate feeding networks inherent in existing circularly polarized (CP) reconfigurable antennas, this paper introduces a compact dielectric resonator antenna (DRA) design with pattern reconfiguration capability based on the Yagi-Uda principle. Circular polarization is achieved through unequal-length cross-slot excitation. Two con-trollable dielectric resonator reflectors, configured as cross slots, are positioned symmetrically about the primary radiator. PIN diodes spanning these slots enable simple control of reflector states, facilitating three distinct radiation patterns at θ = 0°, +24°, and -24°. The proposed DRA exhibits a compact form factor of 0.82λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> × 0.82λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> × 0.17λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub>. Performance metrics include an overlapping impedance bandwidth of 3.4 – 3.72 GHz (9%) and an axial ratio bandwidth of 3.41–3.61 GHz (5.7%). The design demonstrates radiation efficiency exceeding -1.1 dB while maintaining stable CP radiation characteristics.

title: Beyond 1.6 Tbps silicon LAN-WDM transmitter for high-energy-efficiency transmission
authors: Xinyu Wang, Shilan Zhou, Hui Yu, Jianyi Yang, Qiang Zhang, Penghui Xia
abstract: We demonstrate an all-silicon local area network wavelength division multiplexing (LAN-WDM) transmitter with capacities of 1.6 Tbps and beyond, utilizing 8 traveling wave Mach-Zehnder modulators (TW-MZMs) with 3 dB EO bandwidths of 60 GHz and a lattice-filer-based Gaussian-like-passband 8×1 multiplexer. By using the joint linear and nonlinear equalization algorithm based on cascaded artificial neural network and maximum likelihood sequence estimation (ANN-MLSE), we demonstrate single-channel 250 Gbps four level pulse amplitude modulation (PAM4) with the corresponding bit error ratios (BER) below the 20% soft-decision forward error correction (SD-FEC) threshold of 2E-2. The aggregate bit rates of all 8 channels reach 2 Tbps and 1.6 Tbps for the PAM4 transmissions over 1 km and 10 km single mode fibers, respectively. The energy efficiency and the bandwidth density are as high as 0.18/0.143 pJ/bit and 28.9/36.2 Gbps/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> for 1.6/2 Tbps transmission. We believe the proposed SiPh transmitter has great potential in long-reach applications due to the outstanding performance and low-cost manufacturing.

title: A Novel Multi-Timescale Reactive Power Optimization Framework for Power Systems Considering the Stability Region of Grid-Forming Wind Turbines
authors: Lin Xue, Tao Niu, Zhongwen Li, Sidun Fang, Hung Dinh Nguyen, Guanhong Chen
abstract: High wind-penetration power systems require en-hanced VAR support to address voltage stability challenges, yet relying solely on conventional grid-following wind turbines (GFL-WTs) face insufficient dynamic support while adding new devices poses economic and space constraints. Therefore, this paper pro-poses a novel multi-timescale VAR optimization framework inte-grating grid-forming wind turbines (GFM-WTs) into hybrid dis-crete/continuous VAR resource coordination. First, a refined GFM-WT model with AC/DC dynamic coupling characteristics is developed, employing a continuous combination function to elimi-nate state jumps in current-limited operations. Then, to avoid vir-tual power angle and voltage instability of GFM-WT, a stability region hypersurface projection level set is constructed and the nonlinear stability constraints are replaced by a tangent convex approximation method, which can fully utilize the VAR support capability of the GFM-WTs while ensuring their stability. Third, a bi-level day-ahead and intraday optimization structure is estab-lished, incorporating a gradient-based stability region dynamic correction technique to avoid repetitive computational burdens. Finally, case studies on a modified IEEE 39-bus system validate that the proposed framework can achieve 22.34% reduction in dis-crete device switching at the lowest economic cost with 647, demonstrating enhanced voltage stability and economic viability under high renewables.

title: Language-Assisted Reconstruction for Self-Supervised Category-level 6D Object Pose Estimation with Coarse-to-Fine Correspondence Optimization
authors: Jun Yu, Yunxiang Zhang, Zerui Zhang, Wei Xu, Xiaolong Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Self-supervised category-level 6D pose estimation has emerged as a task of paramount significance within the field of computer vision. Despite recent advancements, current self-supervised methods grapple with two critical challenges. Primarily, the ability of existing networks to accurately reconstruct object models is constrained by pronounced part-level shape variations across specific categories. Additionally, the persistent many-to-one ambiguity within pixel-to-point cloud correspondences poses a significant barrier to achieving robust performance. To address these challenges, we propose a novel approach that includes a Language-Assisted Memory-Encoding Shape Reconstruction (LMR) module and a Coarse-to-Fine Correspondence Optimization (CFCO) module. In the LMR module, language descriptions are leveraged to bridge the gap between virtual and real images, thereby improving the alignment between learned representations and real-world object appearances. Additionally, a memory encoding mechanism is introduced to enhance reconstruction accuracy by capturing fine-grained shape variations. The CFCO module utilizes Hungarian matching to generate one-to-one pseudo labels at both region and pixel levels, providing explicit supervision for the corresponding similarity matrices. Furthermore, this process helps alleviate the many-to-one ambiguity to some extent, leading to more accurate correspondence learning. We evaluate our method on the REAL275 and WILD6D datasets. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our self-supervised approach outperforms existing methods and achieves new state-of-the-art results within the self-supervised framework.

title: Intelligent Handover Orchestration in Beyond 5G and Urban V2X Dual Connectivity Networks: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach
authors: Sudeb Mondal, Sawera Aslam, Daud Khan, Kyunghi Chang
abstract: The coexistence of cellular (Uu) and sidelink (PC5) interfaces in 5G Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communications introduces complex handover management challenges, particularly in urban environments with heterogeneous infrastructure comprising macro base stations and Road-Side Units (RSUs). This paper presents a Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN)-based dual connectivity controller that intelligently orchestrates handover decisions and interface selection while leveraging RSU collaboration for enhanced V2X communications. The proposed solution introduces a comprehensive 10-dimensional state representation explicitly incorporating RSU proximity, RSRP, SINR, cluster dynamics, and handover history, enabling proactive handover decisions. A sophisticated multi-objective reward function balances handover frequency against performance gains through explicit handover cost penalties and ping-pong detection mechanisms. RSUs serve as local orchestrators, predicting optimal handover timing based on vehicle trajectories and cluster formations. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the DDQN controller achieves 94.5% PDR, 13.6 ms average latency, and 0.694 interface diversity, while reducing the ping-pong ratio to only 5%. The system demonstrates real-time feasibility with only 1.5% processing overhead and 323.8 ms average step time in 50-vehicle scenarios, proving balanced performance across multiple objectives.

title: Embracing Cacophony: Explaining and Improving Random Mixing in Music Source Separation
authors: Chang-Bin Jeon, Gordon Wichern, François G. Germain, Jonathan Le Roux
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing
abstract: In music source separation, a standard data augmentation technique involves creating new training examples by randomly combining instrument stems from different songs. However, these randomly mixed samples lack the natural coherence of real music, as their stems do not share a consistent beat or tonality, often resulting in a cacophony. Despite this apparent distribution shift, random mixing has been widely adopted due to its effectiveness. In this work, we investigate why random mixing improves performance when training a state-of-the-art music source separation model and analyze the factors that cause performance gains to plateau despite the theoretically limitless number of possible combinations. We further explore the impact of beat and tonality mismatches on separation performance. Beyond analyzing random mixing, we introduce ways to further enhance its effectiveness. First, we explore a multi-segment sampling strategy that increases the diversity of training examples by selecting multiple segments for the target source. Second, we incorporate a digital parametric equalizer, a fundamental tool in music production, to maximize the timbral diversity of random mixes. Our experiments demonstrate that a model trained with only 100 songs from the MUSDB18-HQ dataset, combined with our proposed methods, achieves competitive performance to a BS-RNN model trained with 1,750 additional songs.

title: A Multi-Modal Spatio-Temporal Fusion Network with Physical-Data Driven Learning for Additive Manufacturing Fault Diagnosis
authors: Han Xu, Ruichan Lv, Bin Zi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In additive manufacturing process, the fusion of multi-source sensing signals and cross-modal interaction are crucial to improve the accuracy of fault diagnosis. Most of the existing methods focus mainly on signal time-series features, but the spatial and time-frequency features were always ignored. In this study, a multi-modal spatio-temporal fusion network (MSTNet) with a three-branch synergetic architecture is proposed. The network integrates acoustic emission (AE) and thermal modalities to achieve fault diagnosis in additive manufacturing. Firstly, a channel-enhanced Mamba (CEMamba) architecture is designed to achieve feature extraction of multi-channel frequency-space joint signals generated by continuous wavelet transform (CWT), gramian angular difference fields (GADF), and recurrence plot. The CEMamba architecture can effectively capture the multi-channel features of AE signals including spatial, time-series, and time-frequency features. Secondly, the bi-directional gated recurrent unit is introduced to capture the dynamic evolution laws of AE signals. Specially, a novel physics-based loss function is designed to constrain the physics informed neural network (PINN) for generating high-resolution thermal modalities. Finally, an adaptive and dynamic weighting mechanism during the feature fusion enables the information complementarity of cross-modal features. When tested on two manufacturing datasets of selective laser melting and laser directed energy deposition, the fault diagnosis accuracy of MSTNet achieves 99.71% and 99.55%, respectively. The scalability of MSTNet is further verified on two public datasets of CWRU and Jiangnan University bearing.

title: LAS-GP: Harnessing Large Semantic Libraries for Evolutionary Feature Construction in Symbolic Regression_supp1-3632839.pdf
authors: Qi Chen
abstract: Evolutionary feature construction has seen notable advancements in recent years. A major limitation affecting the effectiveness of evolutionary feature construction is its failure to fully leverage the large number of building blocks evaluated during the evolutionary process. In this paper, to fully utilize historical building blocks, we propose a semantic local search algorithm that operates in the semantic space using a dynamically updated semantic library. This library collects up to 10,000 trees and subtrees during the evolutionary process, with a design that adapts linear scaling and considers tree complexity to enhance both accuracy and generalization performance. To manage a large semantic library, we employ a ball tree and an instance selection mechanism, optimizing computational and memory resources. Furthermore, a positive-negative search mechanism and a semantic library-guided mutation operator are introduced to further improve the effectiveness of the semantic library in feature construction. Experimental validation on 120 datasets demonstrates that our semantic library-based genetic programming approach significantly outperforms several symbolic regression and machine learning algorithms, highlighting its superior performance.

title: Early prediction of pathologic complete response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy in breast cancer based on multimodal ultrasound and pathological image
authors: Zhuoyun Jiang, Yulong Liu, Yunqun Wang, Xueqing Zhang, Linxin Zhou, Caifeng Wan, Zhigang Zhu
abstract: Accurately predicting pCR to neoadjuvant chemo-therapy (NAC) in breast cancer patients is crucial for achieving personalized treatment strategies. pCR is defined as the absence of residual invasive cancer in the breast. To this end, we propose a dual-path GCN–Transformer network (DGT-Net) to integrate ultrasound and pathological image features for early pCR prediction. In the ultrasound pathway, DGT-Net constructed a multimodal knowledge graph to aggregate information on tumor macromorphology, blood perfusion patterns, and tissue elasticity. In the pathology pathway, DGT-Net extracted microhistological patterns and their spatial structures from hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained pathological slides. By introducing an attention score–based dynamic key-patch selection method, a pathology graph is constructed to identify highly discriminative tissue regions. Both pathways employ Transformer encoders to capture complex relationships across modalities, and the outputs are fused through a weighted soft voting strategy to produce robust pCR prediction results. This study included data from 181 breast cancer patients, and experimental results show that DGT-Net outperforms several advanced models, achieving an AUC of 0.891 and an accuracy of 86.2%. Moreover, the diagnostic performance achieved by combining multimodal ultrasound and pathological image information exceeded that of using ultrasound alone (AUC: 0.880) or pathology alone (AUC: 0.786). DGT-Net provides a reliable, non-invasive method for early pCR prediction and has the potential to support clinical decision-making in NAC regimen design.

title: A Meta-Unified Global Cyber Threat Intelligence Model for Industrial Cross-Cloud Networks
authors: Deepika Saxena, Ashutosh Kumar Singh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Industrial cross-cloud networks (ICCNs) combine services from multiple providers to support critical operations, but this diversity also creates major security challenges. Because each provider follows different protocols and safeguards, responses to cyber threats are often inconsistent and delayed, reducing the effectiveness of existing Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) systems. To address this gap, we propose a three-layered CTI framework that unifies learning and adaptation across heterogeneous clouds. The first layer implements a two-tier federated learning (FL) strategy, developing two global models: MLP-SimiFed and MLP-Non-SimiFed, within each industry cloud to manage scalability and heterogeneity. The second layer aggregates these models across distributed clouds into a Unified Global Model, strengthening collaborative defense. The third layer leverages transfer learning to produce the Meta Unified Global Cyber Threat Intelligence (MUG-CTI) model, which enables swift adaptation to emerging threats. Through test-bed simulation, MUG-CTI demonstrates superior threat management, achieving up to 20.7% and 43.06% higher accuracy, and reducing hamming loss by up to 73.8% and 98.3% compared to Federated Learning and SVM-driven methods, respectively.

title: Review of Monochromatic Ellipsometry: Emerging technologies & Up-to-date Applications
authors: Bei Zhang, Chenning Shan, Xinyun Zhu, Junlin Yi, Yi Li, Yunze He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This work presents an overview of the latest advancements in monochromatic ellipsometry, tracing its evolution from early null ellipsometry to widely commercialized rotating ellipsometry, multi-channel ellipsometry, microellipsometry, and recently developed approaches such as metasurface-based and spatially modulated ellipsometry. Instead of being regarded as an "old" technology, monochromatic ellipsometry has witnessed the emergence of numerous novel techniques over the past decade. However, these advancements are often overshadowed by the vast literature on spectroscopic ellipsometry, leaving emerging methods underrecognized and resulting in continued reliance on earlier generations of the technology. To address this gap, this work reviews the most recent advancements in monochromatic ellipsometry and their corresponding application examples. It also discusses future trends to further facilitate the adoption of monochromatic ellipsometry in academia and industry.

title: Mind AI's Mind: A Clinically Aligned Explainable AI Pipeline for Depression Diagnosis via Large Language Models
authors: Yuqi Wu, Guangya Wan, Rachael Dong, Iman Z Kassam, Brittany C Wiseman, Judith Rho, Nicole Graziano, Xihua Wang, Yanbo Zhang, Jie Chen
abstract: The rise of artificial intelligence (AI) in medical diagnostics has highlighted an essential need for transparent and interpretable systems, particularly in the field of mental health. The opaque decision-making in “black-box” AI models creates a challenge in clinical settings: they risk losing trust or causing uncritical reliance. This paradox jeopardizes mental healthcare, where skepticism or unwarranted confidence in AI can harm patient care. Effective explainability mechanisms are therefore essential not only to earn trust but to support responsible use by allowing clinicians to critically assess and verify AI-driven outputs. Thus, we propose a novel explainable AI (XAI) pipeline for automated depression diagnosis, designed to integrate both system-level and human-level interpretability. This dual approach is vital in clinical settings, as it combines rigorous statistical validation with clear, actionable insights that enhance practitioner confidence in AI-generated diagnoses. The pipeline leverages deep learning models for classification, augmented by traditional system-level XAI techniques and a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)-enhanced Large Language Model (LLM). With the integration of LLMs, the system translates abstract system-level explanations into understandable, natural language narratives. This provides a crucial cross-verification step that fosters calibrated trust: it mitigates the dual risks of under-trust, by providing a clear rationale, and over-trust, by flagging diagnostic inconsistencies within the AI models. This capability is critical for ensuring both user trust and satisfaction, as it empowers practitioners to critically assess and validate AI-driven insights. Through comprehensive human evaluations conducted by medical professionals, this approach demonstrates high alignment with clinical diagnostic indicators, underscoring the value of combining system-level and human-level explanations to make complex AI processes transparent and clinically meaningful. Validated across three diverse datasets-KangNing, EDAIC-WOZ, and CALLM-each presenting unique structural challenges from structured clinical inquiries to narrative-driven dialogues, our method bridges the gap between technical AI outputs and practitioner understanding, marking a significant advancement toward a trust-based, widely adoptable AI diagnostic tool in mental health care. By introducing a comprehensive framework for combining statistical rigor with narrative clarity, this work represents a critical step toward closing the gap between black-box AI systems and real-world clinical adoption. While our study is limited to depression diagnosis, the proposed framework illustrates a pathway toward explainable clinical AI systems. Future work may explore its adaptability to other medical contexts.

title: Hi-RQCT: Hierarchical Residual-Quantized Causal Transformer for High-Quality 3D Human Motion Generation
authors: Dongjie Fu, Tengjiao Sun, Pengcheng Fang, Yiyang Zhang, Hansung Kim
publish: Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGGRAPH European Conference on Visual Media Production
abstract: Recent advances in transformer-based text-to-motion generation have significantly improved motion quality. However, achieving both real-time performance and long-horizon scalability remains an open challenge. In this paper, we present Hi-RQCT (Hierarchical Residual-Quantized Causal Transformer), which generates high-quality lifelike 3D human motions by training a single transformer model. Hi-RQCT consists of only two main components: 1) RVQ-VAE, a hierarchical residual vector quantization variational autoencoder, which discretizes continuous motion sequences with high precision; 2) Hierarchical Causal Transformer, responsible for generating the base motion sequences in an autoregressive manner while simultaneously inferring residuals across different layers. Experimental results demonstrate that Hi-RQCT can generate smooth and continuous motion sequences up to 260 frames (13 seconds), surpassing the 196 frames (10 seconds) length limitation of existing datasets like HumanML3D. On the HumanML3D test set, our model achieves the best quantitative performance, and the generated motions also exhibit highly realistic and expressive visual quality in qualitative evaluations.

title: Modeling and Optimal Operation of Thermoelectric Microgrids with Phase-Change Material Thermal System
authors: Pablo Verdugo, Claudio Ca˜Nizares, Mehrdad Pirnia, Thomas Leibfried
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Given that the building sector takes up nearly 40% of all energy consumed worldwide and is responsible for 33% of Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions [1], the adoption of more energy-efficient solutions is critical. Thus, integrating clean-energy microgrids (MGs) with advanced thermal management systems is paramount. In this context, Phase-Change Materials (PCMs) have gained significant attention due to their potential to enhance the thermal performance of buildings, providing economical benefits. PCMs are thermal storage media that operate on the principle of latent heat storage, i.e., they absorb or release thermal energy through phase transitions while maintaining an almost constant temperature. When thermal energy is supplied, a PCM changes its physical state from solid to liquid or vice versa. Due to their significantly higher energy density compared to sensible heat storage systems, PCMs are well-suited for compact and efficient thermal management applications.

title: Interactive Visualization of Data from a Ceramic Printer
authors: Lenka Šroubová, Petr Kropík, Karel Slobodník, Jakub Racek, Michal Prokeš, Jan Rejzek
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: This project aims to develop a system for interactive visualization of data from the KEPrint ceramic 3D printer using augmented reality and extended reality (AR/XR) technologies. The printer will be equipped with sensors monitoring key operational parameters such as pressure, temperature, axis movement, and printing status. These sensor data will be transmitted to an MQTT broker, and then delivered to subscribers represented by end-user devices, including smartphones, tablets, augmented reality/extended reality (AR/XR) headsets, and servers (web servers, database servers). Users will be able to remotely view the current status of the printer, even if it is located in a restricted laboratory environment. This approach enables safe and informed access to laboratory equipment that may be inaccessible due to safety regulations, GDPR constraints, or health-related limitations.

title: Recent Advances in Deep Learning for Diagnosing and Prognosing Age Related Macular Degeneration Using Optical Coherence Tomography
authors: Bantupalli Renuka Sai, Bidush Kumar Sahoo, Om Prakash Samantray, Manish Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: One of the leading causes of blindness, particularly in elderly people, is age-related macular degeneration (AMD). In order to effectively treat this condition and avoid irreversible loss of vision, timely identification and precise classification are crucial. A non-invasive imaging method that helps diagnose and track AMD is optical coherence tomography (OCT), which produces high-resolution cross-sectional pictures of the retina. The potential of Deep Learning (DL) models to enhance AMD detection, classification, and disease progression prediction using OCT images has drawn a lot of attention in recent years. With an emphasis on model topologies, performance, and clinical application, this research examines the most recent DL methods applied to OCT scans for AMD.

title: Toward Reinforcement Learning-Based Filter Switching for Radar Target Tracking
authors: Nikolas Mizdail, Ram M. Narayanan, Anthony F. Martone, David M. McNamara
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: We propose an adaptive filter-switching framework for radar target tracking, integrating reinforcement learning to intelligently select among multiple Kalman filter models based on target dynamics. Specifically, a Deep Q-Network agent is trained to choose the most suitable filter at each timestep to minimize tracking error. The framework is evaluated on a target trajectory with distinct motion phases and maneuvers. Performance is benchmarked against the Kalman Filters used and an Interacting Multiple Model estimator. Results show that the DQN-based filter switcher achieves comparable accuracy, demonstrating the viability of learned filter selection for real-time tracking applications.

title: End-To-End Containerized Testbed for Evaluation of Next-Generation Wireless Technology Dataset
authors: Punya Satish Gouda, Varun Kowndinya Shankar Prasad, Venkataramani Kumar
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Extensive evaluation of various factors affecting affecting the quality of service (QoS), and signal strength using traditional and advanced tools is pertinent for the efficient implementation of futuristic applications. Most of the existing comprehensive evaluation tools such as virtual machines, python based virtual environments, and cloud-based virtualization suffers from limitations such as higher resource consumption, lack of full process isolation, higher time consumption, and inability to be replicated across diverse environments. To alleviate the above mentioned concerns, in this work, we proposed an end-to-end Docker container based testbed that can support multiple deployments in their isolated containers without comprising the performance, comparatively lesser resource utilization, and reduced latency. Our approach is validated on open-source dataset by using deep learning model as well as statistical tool to identify the parameters affecting the signal strength significantly. Evaluation results included in this work highlights the feasibility of our containerization based testbed for comprehensive evaluation.

title: Machine Learning and Deep Learning-Based Framework for Crop Area and Yield Estimation in Agricultural Analytics
authors: Anjali Joshi, Rahul Meghani
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This study presents a machine learning and deep learning-based framework for accurate crop area and yield estimation, with a focus on smallholder farms in India. Using predictive analytics can help to improve agricultural planning, resource allocation, and decision-making mostly. Using a complete dataset consisting of 19,689 records with 19 agronomic characteristics-including rainfall, fertilizer use, pesticide application, and crop type- investigated The approach comprised preprocessing via imputation, encoding, and scaling, then model creation utilizing both traditional and innovative techniques. Key models consisted in CNN-LSTM, Deep Recurrent Q-Network (DRQN), Hybrid Random Forest + Gated Recurrent Unit (RF+GRU), and Linear Regression as baseline. Features relationships and distribution patterns were found by exploratory data analysis (ED A). Adaptive prediction features made possible by real-time data integration from IoT sensors and satellite systems Transparency and stakeholder confidence were guaranteed by means of SHAP (SHapley Additive Explanations) ensuring interpretability. With a Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) of 0.159 for yield and 0.049 for area, the RF+GRU model proved to be the greatest performance among experimental findings, much above conventional models. The results show how well spatial and temporal learning mix to enable precision farming. Strong potential exists for this robust, scalable architecture to support crop insurance programs, maximize resource allocation, and enhance food security in resource-limited agricultural environments.

title: Fine-tuned Deep Transfer Learning based Model using VGG16 and Inception V3 for Multi-class Classification of Rice Leaf Disease
authors: Amandeep Kaur, Kalpna Guleria
abstract: Rice leaf diseases are one of the major issues that affect the growth and quality of the crop, which directly affect the farmers' income. To manage the effect of these diseases and to ensure the safety of crops, it is crucial to identify these diseases at an early stage. This research proposes an automated system for rice leaf disease detection using transfer learning models, specifically VGG16 and Inception V3. The dataset used in this work consists 2,628 labeled rice leaf images which obtained from Kaggle and used for model training and evaluation. The models were fine-tuned and tested under various hyper-parameter configurations, including batch sizes of 32,64 and number of epochs 5,10,20,30 to assess their diagnostic performance. The results demonstrate that both models are capable of accurately detecting multiple rice leaf diseases. The validation accuracy of both models improved with increased training epochs. However, Inception V3 demonstrated a more consistent and steeper accuracy gain across epochs rising from 91.21% at 5 epochs to 96.09% at 30 epochs while VGG16 showed a comparatively slower improvement, reaching only 90.23% at the same point. Automated rice leaf disease detection model is significant for precision agriculture, as the proposed system can support real-time, scalable, and non-invasive disease monitoring. By enabling earlier and more reliable diagnosis, such approaches can lead to more informed decision-making which reduced crop losses, and enhanced agricultural productivity.

title: Grid Connected Small Modular Reactors: Opportunities and Nuclear Challenges
authors: S. S. Shukla
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The flexibility of load-following features and the scalable integrability of Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) with other inverter-based resources (IBRs) have raised global interest for energy sustainability. Considering the competitive advantages of SMRs for resource optimization in the grid-connected power system, the SMRs can be effectively utilized for their technical capabilities to match the power systems’ operating constraints and commitment in the day-ahead and real-time markets. In this paper, a comprehensive mathematical framework of SMR dynamics is presented that controls nuclear reactivity for loadfollowing capability. The resilience and sustainability of grid frequency control using the load-following capabilities of SMRs are explored. The limitations of reactivity controls associated with the SMRs for unit commitment strategies are discussed.

title: Comprehensive Demographic Analysis of Pancreatic Cancer Mortality in the United States
authors: R. Susmitha
abstract: The research examines over 42,000 records of pancreatic cancer deaths in America at the statistical level and with the help of machine learning techniques, looking for trends based on the demographic and geographical factors. Deaths of aged persons between 75 and 84 came into the highest proportion (30.6%), with males making up 52.4% of the fatalities compared to those for the females 47.6%. Racial disparities appeared, with the White population consisting of 72.3% of overall fatalities and the Black population 19.6%. Geographically, California, Florida, and Texas accounted for over 10,500 fatalities, which represented greater than 25% of the national incidence. Machine learning techniques like random forests and support vector machines recorded up to 87% classification accuracies with age and race identified as key predictors of mortality. These results highlight the importance of integrating conventional epidemiological analysis with predictive modelling to inform targeted public health interventions and enhance early detection strategies for pancreatic cancer.

title: Selecting Corporate Taxpayer Audit Candidates: a Tabnet-Based Semi-Supervised Learning Approach with Undersampling
authors: Teguh Herwanto, Muhammad Haris
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: This paper introduces a semi-supervised learning approach to optimize corporate tax audit candidate selection using a sensitive, real-world dataset of 47,072 taxpayer records, with only 5.7 % positive audit cases. By integrating feature selection, random undersampling, and the TabNet architecture, our method effectively leverages both labeled and unlabeled data to address class imbalance and scarcity of positive labels. Experiments demonstrate a recall of 0.956 on the test set, surpassing LightGBM (0.721) and artificial neural networks (0.667), thus improving the identification of potential audit cases while maintaining an optimal false positive rate. The main contribution is the practical integration of these techniques for audit selection in operational environments, validated on a large-scale, sensitive dataset that reflects the real-world challenge of limited positive cases.

title: Advancing Early Breast Cancer Diagnosis: A High-Performance SVM Model with Optimized Hyperparameters
authors: Prasad S Sase, Debabrata Swain, Shailesh Kumar, Vishva Patel, Tirth Doshi, Varsha Prasad Sase
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Breast cancer considered as one of the most lethal diseases affecting women globally, with approximately 670,000 female deaths in 2022 alone. Early identification plays a vital role since the condition frequently shows no observable symptoms during its beginning phases, resulting in late discovery and diminished chances of survival. The proposed approach uses support vector machine with hyperparameter optimization to enhance model generalization and prevent overfitting. Comprehensive data preprocessing combined with effective class balancing techniques contributed to the model's robust performance. The refined SVM demonstrated exceptional accuracy of 99.1% in differentiating malignant and benign tumors, substantially exceeding the performance metrics of previous machine learning approaches referenced in the literature. These results demonstrate strong potential for computational methods to complement traditional diagnostic procedures, potentially reducing the need for invasive procedures and enabling more timely interventions to improve patient outcomes.

title: Impact Assessment of the DORA Regulation on IT Governance
authors: Aiga Kanepa, Jeļena Trokša, Andrejs Romānovs
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: The study will analyze and assess the impact of the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) regulation on information technology (IT) governance in the financial sector of the European Union (EU). The research will provide an overview of the main objectives that IT governance is intended to achieve, as well as explain the essence of the DORA regulation. The study will identify and compare the common aspects of IT governance and the DORA regulation and will analyze and assess their mutual impact. Considering the importance and specificity of the financial sector, the paper will offer insights into the impact of DORA requirements on IT governance areas such as risk management, third-party management, and oversight.

title: SIMAX: a SIMD-Based Many-Core Accelerator for Matrix-Vector Multiplication for Transformers
authors: Yue Yang, John Herrera, Aaron Stillmaker
abstract: Matrix-vector multiplication (MVM) is a computational bottleneck for transformer inference workloads at resource-restricted edge applications. Efficient MVM accelerator design is crucial to optimizing the footprint and energy overhead while maintaining accurate functionality. We present SIMAX, a scalable INT8 MVM accelerator based on a configurable 2D mesh array of lightweight processing elements with saturating accumulation and minimal control. By prioritizing density over peak throughput, SIMAX enables more on-chip memory and fewer off-chip transfers, which is beneficial for edge inference workloads. Synthesis performance values from Synopsys DC were scaled across technology nodes from 65 nm to 7 nm and validated with a 4 × 4 post-layout example in Cadence Innovus using the 45 nm NanGate PDK, SIMAX achieves over 400× speedup, 85× higher throughput-per-area, and 6× higher throughput-per-watt compared to representative CPUs and state-of-the-art accelerators.

title: On Efficient Crosstalk Predictability for Fanout Package Designs
authors: Chung-Yu Hsieh, Hung-Ming Chen, Shih-Hsien Wu, Chien-Ming Hsu, Wei-Hung Liu
abstract: With the increasing demand for fan-out package designs in various AI applications, fast feasibility analysis such as signal integrity (SI) checks has become critical. However, conventional crosstalk analysis tools are often time-consuming. To address this challenge, we propose a deep learning–based crosstalk prediction platform that leverages simulation data to train 3D-CNN and U-Net architectures. The proposed method significantly reduces analysis time while maintaining experimentally validated accuracy. Our study further investigates the effects of frequency, RDL thickness, and dielectric constant on prediction performance, demonstrating robust and consistent results across diverse design conditions. To the best of our knowledge, this work represents an initial exploration of applying deep learning to crosstalk predictability in fan-out package design.

title: Multivariate Load Forecasting for Integrated Energy Systems Based on VMD-BiLSTM-MTL
authors: Shuxin Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: Aiming at the characteristics of high volatility and high coupling of multivariate loads in integrated energy systems (IES), this paper proposes a multivariate load forecasting model based on variational mode decomposition (VMD) and bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM) multivariate load forecasting model. Firstly, Pearson correlation coefficient is used to analyze the multivariate loads and meteorological factors to select input variables, then rolling VMD decomposition is used to reduce the volatility of multivariate loads while avoiding the data leakage in the process of signal decomposition, then BiLSTM is used to construct a multitask learning shared layer to mine the coupling characteristics of multivariate loads, and uncertainty weighting is used to optimize the multitask learning loss function, and then output the multivariate load prediction results using the fully connected layer. Finally, the IES multiload data of Tempe Campus of Arizona State University is utilized for simulation verification.

title: Programmable Impulse and Random Noise Generation Circuit for Power Integrity Tests
authors: Sudabeh Fotoohi Piraghaj, Nicolas G. Constantin
abstract: A novel, fully programmable noise-generation circuit is proposed for injecting random high-voltage impulses and random noise bursts, separately or combined, directly into a regulated power supply rail. It is intended as a minimally-invasive approach for assessing the impact of power supply noise on the performance of high-reliability electronic systems. The proposed circuit is made up of a high-output-current amplifier driving a pulse transformer that may be switched in or out of the DC supply path. It addresses the challenge of injecting high-voltage impulses into a regulated power rail that exhibits a very low impedance, and its small-footprint and low-cost make it suitable for System-in-Package applications requiring embedded tests. Simulation results indicates that the proposed noise source circuit successfully injects 5V random impulses of microsecond-width and 20mV random noise bursts into a high-voltage, high-current regulated power supply rail while adding very low extra power consumption.

title: AI-Powered Robotics for Minimally Invasive Cancer Surgeries
authors: Anil Bhattad, Priya Dasarwar, Saurabh Bhattacharya, M Mounika, Vinit Khetani, Ritesh Sukhadev Dayama
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: It is a big step forward in medical technology that robots driven by AI are now being used in minimally invasive cancer treatments. The topic of this essay is the creation and use of smart computer systems that can make cancer surgeries more accurate, faster, and safer. When it comes to cancer, traditional surgery methods often involve complicated processes that can cause long healing times, big scars, and a higher risk of problems. On the other hand, minimally invasive treatments that uses AI-driven computer systems to help make smaller cuts, lower blood loss, and faster healing times look like a good option. AI systems, such as machine learning models, are used to help surgeons make decisions in real time by looking at patient data, scan results, and the progress of the surgery. When AI is added to robotic systems, it gives the surgeon more fine control over the tools, which lets them remove tumours with more skill and accuracy. In addition, these systems can have adaptable feedback features that let them keep learning and improving surgery methods based on the data and results they have collected. This article talks about a number of clinical studies, use cases, and technological advances that show how AI-powered robots can lower the risks of standard cancer surgery. We talk about the problems with integrating systems, social issues, and what this technology could do in the future. Finally, robotic surgery driven by AI is going to change the way cancer is treated by allowing a personalized method that does the least amount of harm while increasing the chances of success.

title: Implementation of Drive Signal in DC-DC Converters for Chaos Synchronization
authors: Daniils Surmacs, Sergejs Tjukovs, Romans Kusnins, Kristaps Gailis, Dmitrijs Pikulins
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: The use of chaotic sequences for secure data transmission offers a promising means of protecting information against eavesdropping attacks. Unlike the conventional approach that relies on dedicated chaos oscillators, this study explores the feasibility of utilizing switching power supplies-already integrated into IoT devices for power delivery-as built-in chaos generators, eliminating the need for additional circuitry. This approach has the potential to reduce both cost and system complexity in chaos-based secure IoT communication systems. SPICE simulations are employed to examine the feasibility of synchronizing buck converters via a chaotic drive signal implemented in the feedback loop, as well as to evaluate synchronization performance under parameter deviations. The results show that two buck converters can achieve synchronization with a high correlation coefficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(>0.9)$</tex> using a chaotic drive signal, while still maintaining the desired output voltage level.

title: Fast Distribution Grid Topology Estimation via Subset Sum
authors: Yueyao Xu, Yize Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Faced with increasing penetration of distributed energy resources and fast development of distribution grid energy management, topology identification of distribution grid becomes an important and fundamental task. As the underlying grid topology is usually unknown or incomplete to the utilities, it is becoming a fundamental task to efficiently identify the distribution grid network topology using limited measurements. A fast and accurate topology identification can help achieving the tasks of load monitoring, operation and control of power distribution system as well as outage detection. In this paper, we propose a novel and ultra-fast topology identification method. By adapting the subset sum method with a hierarchical structure, the overall grid topology can be inferred from fewer samples of smart meter power measurements. Such techniques can be applied in real time under the scenarios with fast topology change, and the proposed hierarchical algorithm is also robust against measurement noises.

title: OPAMP-Free Ferroelectric Capacitive Computing-in-Memory Accelerator for Energy-Efficient Binary Neural Networks
authors: Jingyun Gu, Can Liu, Yuqing Chen, Zhihao Shen, Wei Mao, Genquan Han, Lei He, Jiang Xu
abstract: Rapid development and iteration of AI algorithms have created an urgent need for high-energy-efficiency computing architectures. Computing-in-Memory (CIM) architectures have demonstrated distinctive advantages by eliminating redundant data transfers between processing and computing units. Conventional resistive CIM arrays experience intrinsic issues with static power consumption and voltage drops caused by current flow. Compared to resistive ones, CIM array based on ferroelectric capacitors (FeCAPs) are more energy efficient. However, previous researches show that amplifiers are necessary in FeCAP crossbar array (FCA) readout circuits and dominate the power consumption in a ferroelectric capacitive computing system. In this paper, a novel FCA-based CIM accelerator is proposed. Direct output of bitline voltage is achieved without using power-hungry operational amplifier (OPAMP). The use of two-terminal computational units also reduces the impact of finite ON/OFF ratio on the system’s parallelism and accuracy. Additionally, an FCA mapping technique designed for binary neural networks (BNNs) is presented. Based on our analysis, the proposed FCA-based CIM accelerator designed at the 180-nm process node achieves an energy efficiency of 121 TOPS/W and an inference accuracy of 82.7% on the CIFAR-10 dataset.

title: Curtailment Inversion when Encoding Rule-Based Priority Order into Distribution OPF
authors: Ali Golriz, Kankar Bhattacharya
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Encoding rule-based curtailment orders for Distributed Energy Resources (DERs), such as last-in-first-out (LIFO), into distribution optimal power flow (DOPF), can cause curtailment inversion, where DERs intended to be curtailed later are curtailed ahead of those intended to be curtailed earlier. This paper proposes a pseudo-cost encoding method that explicitly manages curtailment inversion, introducing a controlled “softness” in enforcing the order through tunable cost gaps. Wide (large step size) and narrow (small step size) cost-encoding strategies are examined to show how varying cost gaps affect inversions. The proposed method allows regulators and utilities to transparently balance strict curtailment order with networkdriven effects.

title: Towards the Design and Analysis of a Temperature-Independent Resistor Using Two-Resistor Combinations
authors: Yash Gaonkar, Patricia Tutuani, Randall Geiger
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: This paper describes an approach to designing composite resistors with small temperature coefficients by judiciously combining temperature sensitive process resistors that are available in most standard MOS processes. The temperature coefficients of the composite resistors are minimized by combining resistors with positive and negative temperature coefficients in appropriate portions to minimize the overall temperature coefficient of the composite structure. Simulation results show that in some widely used processes, Box Temperature Coefficients after trimming as low as 1 ppm/°C over a 70°C temperature range are achievable with two-resistor composites.

title: A Hybrid AI Framework for Cardiovascular Digital Twins: Integrating Data-Driven and Physics-Informed Models
authors: Marta Narigina, Amina Tihak, Andrejs Romanovs, Dusanka Boskovic, Yuri Merkuryev
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: In computational cardiology, a paradigm shift has occurred with the transition from static cardiovascular risk assessment to dynamic, customized modeling. A hybrid conceptual framework for AI-based digital twins is presented in this paper, which combines simulation models informed by physics and datadriven perception models in a synergistic way. For conditions like myocardial infarction and stroke, this strategy seeks to provide previously unheard-of possibilities for disease prediction, real-time cardiovascular monitoring, and customized treatment optimization. Key elements of the framework include graph neural networks (GNNs) for modeling vascular topology, physicsinformed neural networks (PINNs) for hemodynamic analysis, and multi-scale mathematical underpinnings. We illustrate a crucial first step toward the realization of a comprehensive digital twin that is based on physiological first <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex> rinciples a nd responsive to real-time data by validating the data-driven perception module.

title: Automated Diagnosis of Breast Cancer using Deep Learning Algorithm
authors: A. Vijayaraj, R Shai Kumar, P R Shanmugam, R. Harshavardhan, D Sakthi Kumar, R Sachin
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: A fatal condition, to stop the spread of breast cancer and preserve lives, early detection is crucial. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs), is one of the deep learning techniques, have showed significant possibilities in the initial analysis of breast cancer. Some well-known CNNs, such Alex Net-BC, VGG net and Resnet are prone to overfitting when applied to small-scale breast pathology picture datasets. When a model gets excessively specialized to the training data and achieves critically on fresh, untainted data, this is known as overfitting. This may result in erroneous diagnoses and adversely affect patient outcomes. A study was carried out utilizing the deep learning technique ResNet50 to address this issue. Convolutional neural network ResNet50 has demonstrated success in image categorization challenges. In developed work the performance of the breast pathology picture collection was tested by using ResNet-50. The performance evaluation’s findings revealed that ResNet -50 had a 97% accuracy rate.

title: Rust for Safety and Security Critical Systems
authors: Malte Munch, Marcus Lindner, Johan Eriksson, Pawel Dzialo, Per Lindgren
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Rust is a modern systems level language with built in safety features providing strong guarantees to memory safety and defined behavior. In this paper we identify challenges and opportunities for adopting Rust in the context of safety-critical systems. In particular we focus on software safety and security requirements akin to ISO 26262, IEC 61508, and ISO/SAE 21434. We discuss Rust based development in relation to commonplace C/C++ software design and validation processes. Furthermore we compare two distinct system categories: hosted and bare-metal systems and which opportunities and challenges developers face in the context of safety and security certification in each of them.

title: A hybrid genetic algorithm for green vehicle routing problem
authors: Mohamed Amine Ben Helal, Achraf Jabbeur Telmoudi, Yassine Ouazene, Nacima Labadie
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Recent research has increasingly integrated environmental considerations into fields such as logistics, intelligent transportation systems, and optimization problems, particularly the Vehicle Routing Problem (VRP). This study explores the enhancement of genetic algorithms (GAs) by proposing a hybrid approach that embeds heuristic strategies into key components of the GA framework. Specifically, the proposed hybrid genetic algorithm incorporates problem-specific heuristics into the initialization of the population, the evaluation function, and the local search mechanism. The goal is to improve the efficiency and solution quality of traditional genetic algorithms when applied to environmentally aware VRP scenarios.

title: Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Models for Crop and Weed Classification using CWD30, DeepWeed, and Rf100 Datasets
authors: Vikas Vankhede, Jagdish Raikwal
abstract: Agriculture is fundamental to human survival and plays a significant part in the global economy. The world’s population is growing, leading to increased need for food. Climate change impacts agriculture, including weed control. Weeds are undesired plants that compete with plants for nutrients and sunshine, reducing crop quality and productivity. Weeding manually can be time-consuming and labor-intensive as both crops and weeds may appear identical. Artificial intelligence approaches such as deep learning can handle the challenge of crop and weed categorization. A deep learning-based classification system has been used to classify weed and crop based on images. This paper investigates deep learning-based crop and weed categorization with five advanced models as YOLOv8, DETR, WeedGAN, SkipResNet, and ECENet+GradCAM tested on three benchmark datasets CWD30, DeepWeed, and RF100. The accuracy, average precision, and threat score of each model are evaluated. ECENet+GradCAM performs the best among them on all datasets, with accuracy of 0.97 on CWD30, 0.99 on DeepWeed, and 0.96 on RF100. Improved interpretability in precision agricultural applications is guaranteed by its improved explainability. According to the results, ECENet+GradCAM is a dependable option for precise and long-lasting weed detection because of its efficacy in practical settings. Since YOLOv8 exhibits robust real-time detection capabilities, it may be used for quick and effective weed identification. Therefore, the proposed approach provides a deep learning-based method for precise and comprehensible crop and weed categorization, maximizing performance in a range of agricultural settings and facilitating real-time and sustainable farming applications.

title: AI Relational Safety and Digital Transformation Success: The Mediating Role of Human-AI Collaborative Efficacy
authors: Sabar Aritonang Rajagukguk
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Organizations worldwide are accelerating digital transformation through generative artificial intelligence implementation, yet a large proportion of these initiatives fail to achieve intended outcomes. While technical and strategic factors have been extensively studied, psychological dimensions of human-AI collaboration remain underexplored. This study introduces AI relational safety, defined as employees' psychological safety specifically when interacting with AI systems, and examines its impact on digital transformation success through human-AI collaborative efficacy. Using structural equation modeling with data from 387 employees across five industries implementing generative AI systems, we found that AI relational safety significantly predicts digital transformation success, with human-AI collaborative efficacy serving as a significant mediator. The relationship was further influenced by the complexity of generative AI systems and the level of organizational AI maturity. These findings extend psychological safety theory to AI contexts and provide practical guidelines for creating psychologically safe environments that foster successful human-AI collaboration.

title: Baseline Adjustment and Thresholding for Improved Spectral Analysis of Ambient Synchrophasor Data
authors: Vishal Dixit, Chetan Mishra, Luigi Vanfretti, Virgilio Centeno
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: With the continued integration of inverter-based resources (IBRs), utilities face unforeseen challenges in operations, including understanding their dynamic performance. To reveal the dynamic response of grid-tied IBRs, measurement data analysis can be conducted in the frequency domain. To this end, signal processing techniques have been employed to construct spectrograms, which are time-frequency representations of a signal’s spectral information. These spectrograms contain useful features about the system’s modes and their evolution. However, with IBRs being introduced to the grid, such methods require adaptation. This paper describes a comprehensive approach for obtaining spectrograms and post-processing them for better visualization and enhancement of mode features. In particular, it is shown how, by adjusting the spectrum’s baseline and using thresholding, the resulting spectrograms make it easier to observe the dynamics of interest. The proposed methodology is tested on real PMU data.

title: Predicting Wave Power Along India’s Coast
authors: Sarthak Tilwankar, Prashant Kumar, Amit Mahajan
abstract: One of the largest sources of Renewable Energy is Wave Energy. The global gross Wave Energy resource is estimated to be more than 3TWh. With growing effects of climate change becoming abundantly clear there has been a growing demand for renewable energy. India has a large population and thus large energy needs. Since India has committed to transition to green energy, it is essential explore the potential sources of clean energy in India. Wave Power is a clean source of energy that can be harvested in India due to its long coastline. Therefore predicting Wave Power and variables it depends on is important. Machine Learning is a useful method which can be used for predicting Wave Power given the historical data of climate variables in Indian Ocean and Arabian Sea. Since LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) is one of the important Deep Learning approaches that are used to predict time series data. This study aims to predict Wave Power along Indian Coastline by predicting significant Wave Height and Mean Wave Period, using historical geospatial data of climate variables. The variables used are Sea Level Pressure (SLP), Windspeed, significant height of Total Swell and Significant Wave Height, from 1979 to 2021. The LSTM is applied on the data and predictions are made on the ports on Indian Coastlines.MSE (Mean Squared Error) is used to identify overfitting and Regularization applied to overcome it. Model output is measure using metrics like RMSE and Coefficient of Determination.

title: Automated MATLAB™-to-HLS Conversion and Exploration for DoD ASIC/FPGA Development
authors: Michael Parker, Kirk Ober, Michael Bruennert
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: While relatively new when compared to more traditional RTL design entry methods, high-level synthesis now has two decades of successful tapeouts. However, its use with MATLAB was a manual process. Many HLS designs begin as MATLAB models which must first be rewritten by hand in SystemC before they can be turned into hardwareThis paper recounts our experience using a new automated flow available in MATLAB’s HDL Coder app. With this flow, we automatically converted our MATLAB code files into SystemC modules and ran them through the Cadence<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">©</sup> Stratus™ High-Level Synthesis (HLS) tool. We also used Cadence<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">©</sup> Cerebrus™ Intelligent Chip Explorer, a machine learning tool that works with Stratus HLS, to define an exploration space and let it find the gate-level result with the very best area and power. With this approach, we ultimately exceeded the PPA results for an earlier handwritten, manually explored SystemC version of the same design.

title: The Multiple Data Model Framework to Identify Unusual Patterns or Behaviors and Proactive Intervention
authors: Aparnna Raju, S Indubala, I Krishna, S Sooraj, P S Sujith Kumar
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Conventional surveillance systems may struggle to handle dynamic threats in the age of fast urbanization and changing security paradigms since their reliance on manual monitoring is naturally prone to latency and errors. This research presents an artificial intelligence-augmented surveillance system designed for real-time anomaly identification and threat evaluation. The system extracts spatiotemporal features to classify and predict high-risk activities including unauthorized perimeter breaches, loitering anomalies, altercations, weapon brandishing, running, fighting and other suspicious behavior by combining live CCTV telemetry with modern advanced computer vision pipelines and deep learning models. It also notes non-human invasions like wild animals crossing residential or restricted areas. This method guarantees exact detection and fast response by using a hybrid DNN combines with CNNs for spatial feature encoding and LSTM networks for sequential behavioral analysis. Furthermore, enabled by low-latency alert distribution is highfidelity video stream analysis and context-aware decisionmaking. By reducing reliance on human supervision and so improving security intelligence, the modular architecture is intended for scalability and generalization across many surveillance systems, so optimizing false-positive suppression, autonomy of security operations, and proactive mitigating of threats. This AI-driven system establishes a futuristic standard for intelligent security architecture.

title: A DNN-Oriented Rapid Simulation Framework for Digital Processing-In-Memory Architectures
authors: Yirong Kan, Guangxian Zhu, Renyuan Zhang, Yasuhiko Nakashima
abstract: Processing-In-Memory (PIM) architectures show great potential in accelerating deep neural networks (DNNs). Although PIM architectures based on various memory devices have been developed, it is challenging to rapidly estimate performance of chips in the early design stage. In this paper, we propose a modular and parameterized simulation framework DDSim, for design and rapid estimation of digital PIM architectures. The proposed framework supports fast simulation of PIM architectures at three levels: chip level, tile level, and array level, providing various trade-offs between speed and accuracy. To enable rapid simulation, the framework allow users to customize the parameters of the PIM architecture with pre-synthesis logic units, instead of estimating hardware performance at the transistor level every time. In addtion, the framework is tightly coupled with Pytorch-based DNN framework to enable automatic extraction and mapping of DNN models on digital PIM architectures. We demonstrate the benchmark performance of the proposed framework on several typical DNN models to prove its ability to fast simulate digital PIM architectures.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Feature Prioritization for Battery Electric Vehicle Charging Infrastructure in Highly Polluted Area
authors: Tutur Wicaksono, Ferdinand Mahardhika, Agustinus Fritz Wijaya, Lilis Susilawaty, Glisina Dwinoor Rembulan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Air pollution remains a critical issue in developing countries, where fossil fuel vehicles significantly degrade air quality. Despite growing interest in battery electric vehicles (BEVs), adoption lags due to inadequate charging infrastructure. This study applies a machine learning approach to identify and prioritize key charging infrastructure features that can enhance BEV adoption. A sequential mixed-methods design was used, starting with in-depth interviews with 15 nonBEV users to explore essential features, followed by a survey of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1, 5 1 1}$</tex> participants for validation. A Random Forest model ranked features based on their importance across five adoptionrelated variables. Customer support, charging availability, and interoperability emerged as primary priorities, while charging speed, payment flexibility, and home charging were identified as secondary. These findings highlight the need for consumeroriented, accessible, and dependable infrastructure to support sustainable transportation transitions in highly polluted regions. Theoretically, this study advances the understanding of technology adoption by integrating behavioral insights with data-driven feature prioritization in the context of sustainable mobility.

title: Multi-Label Glioma Segmentation Post-Treatment: A 3D U-Net Approach
authors: Amel Omri, Khaoula ElBedoui, Safya Belghith
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Monitoring post-treatment gliomas is one of the most challenging tasks in medical image analysis, mainly due to the complex tissue changes caused by surgical treatment procedures. The BraTS 2024 initiative addresses this critical need by providing the most extensive collection of expert-annotated MRI data for post-treatment gliomas. Building on this opportunity, we propose a multi-label segmentation approach using a 3D U-Net architecture for post-treatment MRI analysis. Our framework aims to precisely delineate four distinct tumor sub-regions: Enhancing Tissue, Surrounding Non-Enhancing T2/FLAIR Hyperintensity, Non-Enhancing Tumor Core, and Resection Cavity. It leverages the volumetric nature of MRI data through 3D convolutions, allowing superior spatial contextual understanding and feature extraction. Preliminary results demonstrate that our framework can accommodate the inherent complexities of post-treatment tissue characteristics, with significant improvements over baseline models. Thus, it provides a solid foundation for automated post-treatment glioma monitoring.

title: Generating High-Fidelity Synthetic ECG Signals Using Deep Autoencoder Architectures
authors: Anisha Riya, Abdullah Bin Queyam
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Electrocardiogram (ECG) signals are essential for diagnosing a wide range of cardiovascular diseases, yet obtaining large-scale, high-quality ECG datasets is often restricted due to privacy, annotation cost, and clinical limitations. To address this, we present a comprehensive framework for synthetic ECG waveform generation using multiple deep learning-based autoencoder architectures. The explored models include LSTM Autoencoder (LSTMAE), Convolutional Autoencoder (CNNAE), Variational Autoencoder (VAE) and Denoising Autoencoder (DAE). These models are trained to reconstruct ECG signals and are evaluated for their ability to generate realistic synthetic ECG data. The reconstruction quality was assessed using training loss (MSE), Pearson Correlation Coefficient, and Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR). Among all models, the CNNAE reached the best performance with a Pearson correlation of 0.999966, and an SNR of 51.184 dB, followed closely by the LSTMAE. In contrast, the VAE and DAE showed relatively lower reconstruction fidelity. These results demonstrate the potential of convolutional and various other autoencoders for generating high-quality synthetic ECG signals, which can support data augmentation, privacy-preserving research, and benchmarking of biomedical signal processing algorithms.

title: Grid-Integrated Photovoltaic System for Electric Vehicle Charging Station with Dynamic Energy Management
authors: R. Tharwin Kumar, C. Christober Asir Rajan
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The rapid growth of Electric Vehicles (EVs), the increasing demand for sustainable charging infrastructure, and the pressing need to reduce dependence on fossil-fuel-based electricity are essential. Hence, this paper discusses a grid-tied Photovoltaic (PV) system for EV charging stations, focusing on dynamic energy management to maximize solar generation benefits and minimize grid strain. The system uses a high-gain Modified Luo converter to boost the PV system’s DC voltage output. Incremental Conductance (INC)-based Maximum power Point Tracking (MPPT) technique is a control method used in PV systems to ensure operation at the maximum power point under varying environmental conditions. Further, it responds quickly to dynamic weather conditions, making it particularly suitable for grid-connected and off-grid PV applications where efficiency and stability are critical. A single-phase Voltage Source Inverter (VSI), which links the PV system to the grid, receives the enhanced output of the Modified Luo converter. Additionally, an LC filter is used to reduce unwanted harmonics, smooth voltage and current waveforms, and improve power quality in power electronic systems. The proposed approach uses MATLAB/SIMULINK to model the proposed approach. The efficiency is noted to be $94.3 \%$ with a Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) of $\mathbf{2. 1 2 \%}$.

title: Exploring the Role of Feature Selection in Multi-Class Diabetes Prediction
authors: Anay Bhardwaj, Helen Terese Agalayil, Deepa Gupta, Aarathi Rajagopalan Nair
abstract: Diabetes mellitus is a prevalent global health concern, contributing to high rates of morbidity and mortality. While Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes have been the primary focus of research, diabetes encompasses various subtypes, including gestational diabetes, monogenic forms such as Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young, and secondary diabetes, which arises from underlying conditions or treatments. These subtypes present distinct challenges in terms of diagnosis, classification, and treatment. Machine learning has emerged as a transformative tool in healthcare, offering significant advancements in disease diagnosis, prediction, and classification. This study proposes a machine learning-based model aimed at classifying the broad spectrum of diabetes subtypes. We utilize advanced algorithms to differentiate between Type 1, Type 2, gestational diabetes, MODY, and secondary diabetes. The proposed model achieves an accuracy of 90% and a weighted F1 score of 0.9, indicating the effectiveness of machine learning in handling complex, multidimensional healthcare data. The results demonstrate the potential of machine learning to improve early diagnosis, optimize treatment plans, and aid in personalized healthcare strategies. This work contributes to expanding the scope of diabetes classification, emphasizing the importance of addressing less-studied subtypes and advancing medical science through the application of AI.

title: Towards Incremental MTU Upgrade for the Internet
authors: Junghan Yoon, Youngmin Choi, Juyoung Park, Daehyeok Kim, Changhoon Kim, KyoungSoo Park
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: This paper proposes a systematic approach to incrementally enabling large MTUs in the Internet. We demonstrate that increasing the MTU size significantly enhances the performance of both middleboxes and end hosts. To bridge MTU mismatches at network borders, we introduce PacketExpress gateway (PXGW), an MTU-translating gateway that dynamically adjusts packet sizes for cross-traffic. PXGW merges and splits TCP payloads on the fly and tunnels UDP packets, ensuring seamless adaptation. Also, we propose F-PMTUD, a new path MTU discovery algorithm that determines the path MTU within a single round-trip without relying on ICMP. Our preliminary evaluation shows that the PXGW prototype achieves 1.45 Tbps of packet forwarding throughput using only 8 CPU cores. After dynamic conversion, 94% of transmitted TCP packets are 9000 B jumbo frames, indicating that most flows were effectively converted into large segments, thereby demonstrating the system's efficiency and scalability. We also find that large-MTU packets, made available via PXGW, enhance end-host performance by up to 2.5X.
