title: An Adaptive Virtual Impedance-Based Closed-Loop Voltage Control Strategy for Smart Transformer-Interfacing Distribution Grid with High PV Penetration
authors: Ping Tuo, Zheng Gong, Ziyang Meng, Xiaojie Wu
abstract: The substantial increase of distributed photovoltaic (PV) systems in low-voltage distribution grids has resulted in an escalating problem of exceeding voltage upper limits due to reverse power flow. Numerous strategies have been suggested to address the issue of voltage violating the voltage upper limits. Nevertheless, the conventional approaches are essentially open-loop control methods and exhibit steady-state errors. In addition, unbalanced loads or single-phase PV can cause traditional methods to be ineffective. This article proposes an adaptive virtual impedance-based closed-loop voltage control strategy for smart transformer (ST)- interfacing distribution grid. Utilizing adaptive virtual impedance-based closed-loop control, ST can regulate the maximum bus voltage of the distribution grid at the voltage threshold without static error, hence enabling the control of other buses within the voltage threshold when reverse power flow occurs. Besides, as the proposed control strategy is implemented in the abc control coordinate system, it can still effectively regulate the maximum bus voltage at the voltage threshold in the presence of unbalanced loads or the sudden connection of single-phase PV systems. Furthermore, to ensure the stability of the system, impedance-based stability is analyzed. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified through simulation based upon real data of a radial distribution feeder and a simplified ST-interfacing distribution grid experiment.

title: Transparent Lifting Assistance Strategy for Arm Exoskeletons Using an Adaptive Torque Controller_supp2-3616399.mp4
authors: Long Cheng
abstract: In the field of the exoskeleton-assisted arm lifting, current research faces challenges such as the lack of a mature assistance strategy paradigm and relatively low torque tracking accuracy. To address these issues, we propose an adaptive torque controller based on an interaction torque model guided by a transparent assistance strategy. The torque controller is designed using the robust model predictive control algorithm, with an adaptive network-based fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) to dynamically adjust the controller parameters. The interaction torque model can estimate future interaction torques to support the model predictive controller. Moreover, the transparent assistance strategy guides the design of the interaction torque reference, ensuring the preservation of the user’s natural exertion patterns during the assistance, thereby creating the sensation of lifting a lighter object for the user. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed transparent assistance strategy effectively maintains the user’s natural exertion patterns while providing assistance. In addition, the proposed adaptive torque controller significantly enhances the torque control accuracy.

title: Beyond Bias and Error: Institutionalizing the Fifth Hand to Explain Infrastructure Project Cost Misperformance
authors: Peter E.D. Love, Lavagnon A. Ika
abstract: Cost misperformance, when final construction costs exceed a client's approved budget, continues to be a challenge when procuring infrastructure delivery worldwide. Traditional explanations often emphasize individual and organizational errors and/or biases, while overlooking the institutional contexts that shape decision-making. Our paper extends the Fifth Hand, an emergent theory of project behavior, by embedding it within a neo-institutional perspective, linking micro-level ecological rationality with meso-level organizational pressures and macro-level institutional logics. We integrate isomorphic mechanisms (e.g., coercive, mimetic, normative) with institutional logics (e.g., professional [cost control]; market [competitiveness], collaborative [risk-sharing]) to explain the recurrence and legitimacy of behavioral patterns across infrastructure projects. The Fifth Hand is thus mapped to isomorphic pressures and institutional logics, illustrating how they shape a project's cost performance. By adopting a multi-level, institutional lens, we strengthen the Fifth Hand's explanatory foundation by connecting individual and organizational decisions to broader structural and normative forces. We conclude by outlining research directions to explore how isomorphic mechanisms and institutional logics evolve across projects, interact over time, and sustain cost misperformance.

title: Temperature compensated dual-parameter sensing of lubricating oil contaminants based on Vernier effect and fiber Bragg grating
authors: Yukun Xie, Ying Liang, Zijie Dai, Yunpeng Ren, Yan Chen, Mingyang Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Lubricating oil contaminants represents a major threat to mechanical equipment, and its sensitive and accurate detection is highly demanded in faults diagnosis and health condition monitoring. Here, a fiber-optical sensor consists of Mach-Zehnder interferometer (MZI) and fiber Bragg grating (FBG) is proposed and experimentally demonstrated for simultaneous measurement of water content and wear debris in lubricating oil. A pair of MZIs constructed by misaligned welding single mode fibers is introduced to generate optical Vernier effect and enhance the detection sensitivity. The envelopes evolution of transmission spectra in response to varying concentrations of water and wear debris are measured, giving rise to the maximum sensitivities of 1.3043 dB/% and 0.0136 dB/μg‧mL<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>, respectively. Most importantly, the temperature disturbance to the dual parameter sensing performance is analyzed, which could be compensated by cascading an FBG after the sensing MZI. Hence, our developed fiber-optical sensor based on cascaded MZIs with Vernier effect and FBG paves a new way toward developing novel lubricating oil contaminants sensors and related optofluidic devices.

title: Rate-Optimal Streaming Codes over Three-Node Relay Networks with Burst Erasures
authors: Zhipeng Li, Wenjie Ma, Zhifang Zhang
abstract: This paper investigates streaming codes over three-node relay networks under burst packet erasures with a delay constraint T. In any sliding window of T + 1 consecutive packets, the source-to-relay and relay-to-destination channels may introduce burst erasures of lengths at most b1 and b2, respectively. Singhvi et al. proposed a rate-optimal non-adaptive construction when max{b1, b2} | (T − b1 − b2). We construct non-adaptive streaming codes with the optimal rate under the condition T ≥ b1 + b2 + b1b2/|b1−b2| , thereby enriching the family of rate-optimal non-adaptive streaming codes for three-node relay networks.

title: Ground-Based Cloud Type Classification for Aviation Weather Hazard Detection Using Deep Learning
authors: Marcus P. Cote, Michael E. Splitt, Steven M. Lazarus, Ryan T. White, Cecilia G. Baker
abstract: General aviation pilots who encounter hazardous weather face a heightened risk of fatal accidents compared to those in other sectors of aviation. To help avoid unplanned weather encounters, accurate information on cloud type and sky condition can enhance situational awareness and hazard recognition. Among available weather information resources, ground-based webcam networks are growing for aviation meteorology and other interests such as wildfire monitoring. These webcams can provide near real-time visual weather information to pilots, especially in regions of complex terrain where traditional weather observation methods may lack adequate spatial and temporal coverage. To harness the benefits from webcams while reducing the need for manual interpretation, transfer learning is applied using off-the-shelf convolutional neural networks on a newly constructed meteorological dataset. This dataset, consisting of more than 15 500 rigorously labeled images from public webcam networks, is categorized into nine cloud types and weather conditions relevant to general aviation. Leveraging a five-model ensemble approach with the Inception-v3 architecture, a validation accuracy of 97.1% is achieved. Dataset classes are grouped into those that are typically considered nonhazardous or hazardous to general aviation operations, and a hazard-based classification accuracy of 99.5% is attained with the ensemble model.

title: ANYA: A Noteworthy Youth Annotation Dataset for Machine Learning-Based Ergonomic Posture Analysis
authors: Chanankorn Jandaeng, Chonthicha Kongkwamcharoen, Trakan Jaiwang, Peeravit Koad, May Thu
abstract: Adolescents in limited-resource educational settings are increasingly impacted by ergonomic health problems resulting from extended computer usage and insufficient equipment. This paper presents a hybrid semi-supervised learning framework for classifying sitting postures utilizing solely webcam input, thereby obviating the necessity for wearables or specialized sensors. The framework combines expert-driven clustering with pseudo-labeling to enhance a limited collection of labeled samples into a robust training dataset. Beginning with 10 manually labeled images, four datasets were produced by augmenting with 20 pseudo-labeled instances each, utilizing various clustering methodologies. Four machine learning models—XGBoost, LightGBM, Random Forest, and Artificial Neural Networks (ANN)—were trained and assessed based on accuracy, F1-score, AUC, and training duration. LightGBM attained an advantageous equilibrium of performance and efficiency, yielding an F1-score of 0.9805 and the minimal training duration of 24.27 seconds. Although Random Forest achieved the highest F1-score (0.9856), its prolonged training duration (495.21 seconds) restricts its real-time usability. The framework exhibited significant generalization on previously unobserved student data, signifying resilience to individual postural variability and camera angles. The suggested method facilitates scalable and economical implementation in actual classrooms, providing a pragmatic solution for posture monitoring in digital learning settings.

title: Parallel Delayed Memory Units for Enhanced Temporal Modeling in Biomedical and Bioacoustic Signal Analysis
authors: Pengfei Sun, Wenyu Jiang, Paul Devos, Dick Botteldooren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Advanced deep learning architectures, particularly recurrent neural networks (RNNs), have been widely applied in audio, bioacoustic, and biomedical signal analysis, especially in data-scarce environments. While gated RNNs remain effective, they can be relatively over-parameterised and less training-efficient in some regimes [1], [2], while linear RNNs tend to fall short in capturing the complexity inherent in bio-signals. To address these challenges, we propose the Parallel Delayed Memory Unit (PDMU), a delay-gated state-space module for short-term temporal credit assignment targeting audio and bioacoustic signals, which enhances short-term temporal state interactions and memory efficiency via a gated delay-line mechanism. Unlike previous Delayed Memory Units (DMU) that embed temporal dynamics into the delay-line architecture, the PDMU further compresses temporal information into vector representations using Legendre Memory Units (LMU). This design serves as a form of causal attention, allowing the model to dynamically adjust its reliance on past states and improve real-time learning performance. Notably, in low-information scenarios, the gating mechanism behaves similarly to skip connections by bypassing state decay and preserving early representations, thereby facilitating long-term memory retention. The PDMU is modular, supporting parallel training and sequential inference, and can be easily integrated into existing linear RNN frameworks. Furthermore, we introduce bidirectional, efficient, and spiking variants of the architecture, each offering additional gains in performance or energy efficiency. Experimental results on diverse audio and biomedical benchmarks demonstrate that the PDMU significantly enhances both memory capacity and overall model performance.

title: Surrogate-Model-Driven Staged Sequential Multi-Condition Optimization Method of Permanent Magnet Vernier Motors
authors: Xiangdong Su, Zhenxiao Yin, Yujia Zhang, Zaixin Song, Hang Zhao
abstract: Permanent magnet vernier motors (PMVM) exhibit great potential in direct-drive application scenarios. As no-load and on-load performance both affect their overall operational smoothness and reliability, both conditions must be considered during optimization to meet the specific application requirements. However, the high-order harmonics of PMVM make the electromagnetic calculation more time-consuming than permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM). Therefore, in this article, a surrogate-model-driven staged sequential multicondition and multi-objective optimization (MOO) method for PMVM is proposed, aiming to comprehensively optimize the motor performance under both no-load and on-load conditions with reduced computational cost. (1) Unlike traditional methods that involve redundant calculations for both no-load and on-load cases, this article employs a surrogate model-driven staged sequential optimization strategy to sequentially optimize the noload and on-load performance. This method optimizes the on-load condition electromagnetic performance while maintaining nearoptimal no-load performance, thereby achieving multi-condition optimization with reduced computational resources. (2) The optimization results are validated using the finite element method (FEM) and PMVM prototype experimental verification. The optimization results indicate that the proposed optimization method achieves  10% reduction of the computational cost compared with the traditional surrogate-driven optimization method, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed method for PMVM optimization. The saved computational cost varies with the complexity of the motor topology. The proposed optimization method can be extended to the optimization problems of different types of motors with more complex motor topologies, considering multiple operating conditions or multiphysics optimization.

title: Comparison of Different Input Data for the Prediction of LED Solder Joints Using Artificial Neural Networks
authors: Andreas Zippelius, Zubair Mohd, Maximilian Schmid, Gordon Elger
publish: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
abstract: Scarcity of raw data is a major issue for applying data driven methods to reliability prediction, so making the best use of what is available is critical. This paper studies how different aspects of measurement data can be used best. Specifically, the reliability of the solder joint of LED packages is predicted based on Transient Thermal Analysis and Scanning Acoustic Microscopy data from a large measurement campaign. The impact of using full temporal information vs measurements at individual datapoints is investigated as well as the benefit of including the SAM data, and different ways of presenting the TTA information, either as a full curve or as expert-selected features. The impact of formatting categorical information of solder and LED package type as one-hot encoding or using embeddings is considered. Finally, the performance for Pass/Fail predictions of the best identified model with a model architecture developed on a similar dataset is compared. We identified the most relevant sources of information for predicting the behavior and the best format for the data, which helps guide the choice for future model architectures.

title: RF-MAE: A Self-Supervised Adaptive Frequency Masked Autoencoder With Radio-Frequency Signal Processing Applications
authors: Zhongyi Wen, Zhikai Zhai, Yatong Wang, Qiang Li, Wei Zhang, Huaizong Shao
abstract: Radio-frequency (RF) signal processing has seen significant advancements with the advent of deep learning, providing more accurate and efficient solutions for tasks such as signal classification and generation. However, most existing methods are heavily dependent on large labeled datasets, which are often scarce and costly to obtain in real-world RF environments. Furthermore, these approaches tend to be task-specific, limiting their ability to generalize across various RF applications. To address these challenges, this paper proposes RF-MAE, a self-supervised adaptive frequency masked autoencoder. RF-MAE leverages self-supervised learning (SSL) to capture intrinsic patterns from large-scale unlabeled RF data. Central to RF-MAE is a novel Adaptive Frequency Masked (AFM) strategy, which dynamically masks frequency components based on their energy distribution. Supported by a robust theoretical foundation, AFM ensures the model focuses on the most informative signal components, thereby enhancing generalization across RF tasks. By pretraining on unlabeled data and fine-tuning on specific tasks, RF-MAE significantly reduces the reliance on labeled datasets while improving adaptability across diverse RF signal processing tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that RF-MAE consistently outperforms traditional models, underscoring its potential to generalize across tasks and deliver superior performance in a wide range of RF signal applications.

title: Performance Analysis of Energy-Efficient Routing Protocols for Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Qasim Jumaa, Kusum Yadav
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Several applications utilise wireless sensor networks (WSN s), including environmental monitoring, healthcare, and military surveillance. Battery-powered sensor nodes are prevalent in wireless sensor networks (WSN s), making energy efficiency a significant concern. Using metrics such as network lifetime, packet delivery ratio, residual energy, and network lifetime, this paper analyses energy-efficient routing protocols for wireless sensor networks. This study proposes an algorithm for optimising cluster heads and relay nodes that utilises a modified gravitational search algorithm (MGSA-ORS). The proposed protocol is compared with existing approaches, such as LEACH, I-LEACH, and LEACH-KH. As a result of simulation results, MGSA-ORS significantly reduces the energy consumption, stability period, and throughput of networks of any size. A WSN's operational lifetime and reliability can be significantly extended with intelligent routing strategies.

title: A High Load Density Miniature Force Sensor for Probing With Robot Feet_supp1-3632679.mp4
authors: Kathryn A Daltorio
abstract: Force sensing on the end effector is crucial for mobile, legged robots to adapt to varying terrain and manipulate objects in complex environments. Since efficient legs have to be light and load bearing, force sensors need to have increased load density while still providing accurate multi-axis forces. Here, we demonstrate a low-cost solution to this problem that integrates four sets of strain gauges, analog-to-digital conversion, and data processing into a single leg of a crab-scale robot. The sensor has a tested range of $\pm$50 N for contact force and $\pm$2.5 Nm for torque, which is more than double the weight of a robot made with six such legs. Then, we demonstrate that our sensor is accurate compared to standard, bulkier force gauges and precise enough to be used to differentiate terrains and even find objects buried in sand. Importantly, the sensor has the greatest force load density of any available sensor and more than twice the torque load density of the next best option. This approach to integrating sensors into the most distal appendages can be applied to many other inexpensive end effectors including robot hands, toes, feet, and other tools.

title: Quantifying Network Dissimilarity via Augmented Networks
authors: Yuanyuan Zhang, Pei Wang, Jinhu L¨u, Tao Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Quantifying structural dissimilarities between networks is a fundamental challenge. This paper introduces a novel measure, D*, that quantifies network dissimilarity by analyzing their augmented networks. The augmented network is constructed by adding a virtual leader node that is bidirectionally connected to all other nodes. D* relies on the node distance distributions of the augmented networks, which are essentially determined by the original networks' degree distributions and sizes. This characteristic makes it a simple and robust measure, insensitive to weighting parameters, and applicable to a wide range of networks–including regular networks and networks of any size, even those containing isolated nodes. D* actually utilizes the second-order truncated shortest-path distance matrix and demonstrates superior performance compared to higher order truncations. Numerical simulations show that D* accu rately quantifies structural differences between networks while overcoming the saturation growth effect induced by increasing edge connection probabilities in random networks. The versatility of D* is further demonstrated by applying it to four distinct scenarios. Specifically, D* is effective in determining optimal correlation cutoff thresholds when constructing bio-molecular co-expression networks, in identifying disease modules in gene disease and phenotype-disease networks, in performing clustering and layer aggregation for multilayer networks, and in distin guishing networks of different categories. Our findings enhance understanding of the construction and comparison of complex network structures.

title: Multidimensional Auditable Lattice-Based Privacy-Preserving Data Aggregation Scheme in Smart Grids
authors: Kai Fan, Xuyang Ma, Guanglu Wei, Kuan Zhang, Hui Li, Yintang Yang, Lianhai Wang
abstract: The massive growth of data has brought vigorous vitality to Internet-of-Things (IoT). It has also brought new challenges, such as confidentiality privacy protection and redundant data transmission. Concerning this regard, data aggregation serves as an efficient technique to minimize the transmission frequency among massive objects in smart grid(SG). By aggregating a large amount of the same type of data while satisfying the protection of user privacy. With the advent of the post-quantum era, a good aggregation scheme must provide quantum resistance while ensuring the secure aggregation of ciphertext power data. However, the excessive overhead limits anti-quantum algorithms from being widely used in SG where resource devices are limited. Therefore, it is an important part of the current private data security aggregation technology to find a low cost and lightweight inverse quantum algorithm to achieve user data security aggregation. In this paper, we propose an improved NTRU-based cryptosystem with multidimensional coding, referred to as multidimensional coding NTRU (MC-NTRU). and use the lattice batch signature technique, which improves the efficiency of the scheme while satisfying the anti-quantum attack. Based on these, we design the multidimensional auditable lattice-based privacy-preserving data aggregation scheme(MA-PPDA) for privacy data on resource-limited IoT devices such as smart grids. In addition to this, the scheme achieves fault tolerance of the scheme by adding zeros and random numbers to the user data. The comparative study against existing approaches demonstrates that the proposed scheme not only adheres to critical security aspects including user privacy, data confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity, but also decreases both communication and computational burdens on the system. This makes our scheme particularly apt for IoT environments characterized by constrained device resources.

                    /GO Nanocomposite-Based Highly Sensitive Optical Fiber Humidity Sensor
authors: Subham Koley, Sunil K Khijwania
abstract: This research aims to develop simple and novel optical fiber relative humidity (RH) sensor that employs intensity modulation via evanescent wave (EW) absorption. Proposed sensor exploits Al₂O₃/GO nanocomposite doped thin film of nanostructured silica as the sensing cladding on a centrally decladded plastic-clad silica (PCS) fiber. This configuration is used for the first time to the best of author's knowledge for the development of optical fiber RH sensor. Comprehensive experimental investigations are carried out to establish response characteristics of the sensor. Proposed sensor demonstrates a significantly enhanced sensitivity of 0.0107 RH⁻¹ while responding linearly over a dynamic range of 14%-86% RH. In addition, fast response/recovery time, excellent reversibility, repeatability, and reliability characteristics of the sensor make it suitable for real-field applications.

title: Self-Closing Suction Grippers for Industrial Grasping via Form-Flexible Design_supp1-3632798.mp4
authors: Huijiang Wang
abstract: Shape-morphing robots have shown benefits in in dustrial grasping. We propose form-flexible grippers for adaptive grasping. The design is based on the hybrid jamming and suction mechanism, which deforms to handle objects that vary significantly in size from the aperture, including both larger and smaller parts. Compared with traditional grippers, the gripper achieves self-closing to form an airtight seal. Under a vacuum, a wide range of grasping is realized through the passive morphing mechanism at the interface that harmonizes pressure and flow rate. This hybrid gripper showcases the capability to securely grasp an egg, as small as 54.5% of its aperture, while achieving a maximum load-to-mass ratio of 94.3.

title: Cyber Security of Sensor Systems for State Sequence Estimation: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Xubin Fang, Rick S. Blum, Ramesh Bharadwaj, Brian M. Sadler
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Areas in Sensors
abstract: Due to possible devastating consequences, counteracting sensor data attacks is an extremely important topic, which has not seen sufficient study. To the best of our knowledge, this paper develops the first methods that accurately identify/eliminate only the problematic attacked sensor data presented to a sequence estimation/ regression algorithm under any attack from our attack model. The approach does not assume a known form for the statistical model of the sensor data, allowing data-driven and machine learning sequence estimation/ regression algorithms to be protected. A simple protection approach for attackers not endowed with knowledge of the details of our protection approach is first developed, followed by additional processing for attacks based on protection system knowledge. Experimental results show that the simple approach achieves performance indistinguishable from that for an approach which knows which sensors are attacked. For cases where the attacker has knowledge of the protection approach, experimental results indicate the additional processing can be configured so that the worst-case degradation under the additional processing and a large number of sensors attacked can be made significantly smaller than the worst-case degradation of the simple approach, and close to an approach which knows which sensors are attacked, with just a slight degradation under no attacks. Mathematical descriptions of the worst-case attacks are used to demonstrate the additional processing will provide similar advantages for cases for which we do not have numerical results. All the data-driven/machine learning processing used in our approaches employ only unattacked training data.

title: BioTwinXAI-Eye: A Consumer-Centric Digital Twin for Explainable and Personalized Risk Prediction of Diabetic Retinopathy and Glaucoma
authors: Jing Yang, Vijay Govindarajan, Sunil Prajapat, Ali Kashif Bashir, Theyazn H.H. Aldhyani, Fu Chenxi, Lip Yee Por, Qianjie Yang
abstract: Diabetic retinopathy (DR) and glaucoma cause preventable blindness in over 600 million people worldwide. Early detection is critical, but challenging due to limited specialist access. We present BioTwinXAI-Eye, a digital twin system that creates a virtual model of each patient’s eye health by combining retinal images, eye pressure data, OCT scans, and health indicators from consumer devices such as smartwatches and glucose monitors. Our system uses intelligent algorithms that track how diseases progress over time, and how different eye structures relate to each other. To help doctors trust the system, we include tools that explain predictions by highlighting important image regions and identifying key risk factors. Tests on 88,702 retinal images and 15,234 glaucoma patients show that our method improves accuracy by 21% compared to existing approaches. Crucially, it increased doctor confidence in AI predictions by 58% through transparent explanations. BioTwinXAI-Eye enables personalized care by continuously adapting to each patient’s unique health profile, supporting modern precision medicine goals in preventing vision loss.

title: A Generative Adversarial Network Approach for Predicting Outdoor Pollution Levels using Conditional Data
authors: G Ranjith Kumar, Deepa Jose, M Mohammed Razeetha, K Rishab Murthi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for predicting pollution parameters such as Sulfur Dioxide (SO2), Nitrogen Dioxide (NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), and Particulate Matter ($\mathbf{P M 1 0}$) with an aerodynamic diameter of 10 micrometers or less from conditional inputs such as date, city, state, and site type using conditional Generative Adversarial Network (cGAN). The preprocessing pipeline explains the cGAN architecture and training process, including an inverse scaling mechanism for output values and uses standard scaling for numerical inputs and one-hot encoding for categorical data. Training loss plots and sample outputs show how well the model’s performs.

title: Automated Short Answer Grading using Machine Learning and Deep Learning Models
authors: Akhilesh P, Amal Krishna K, Dwarapu Subham, S Karthick Bharadwaj, Manju Venugopalan
abstract: Automated short answer marking, which was recently introduced, is the next big thing in educational evaluation. It tackles scalability issues and makes the processes very efficient with its natural language processing and intelligent algorithms. Constant, real-time, and unbiased feedback is the essence of this technology, thus replacing manual grading methods. The presented model encompasses multiple BERT models including Roberta and Distil BERT for generation of word embeddings for both student answers and reference texts. Employment of cosine similarity makes the model semantically compare two responses resulting in a score between 0 and 1. DistilBERT and RoBERTa were used to create contextual word embeddings to capture the meaning of students’ answers. The embeddings of both models were combined by concatenating them, so the strengths of each model could be used in the merged representation. DistilBERT and RoBERTa were used in combination with different ML models and DL models. The model that reported the highest R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score was Linear Regression with a score of 0.91, while the best-performing DL model was BiRNN reporting a R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.80. However, it was observed that the DL models reported comparatively lower MSE and MAE values than the ML models. DL Model is more accurate in terms of absolute error, i.e., its predictions are numerically closer to the actual values on average.

title: Dynamic Channel Selection with Dominating Set Clustering for Cognitive MANET Routing Protocols
authors: Taki Alrwbaye, Rohit Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Using cognitive radio capabilities, Cognitive Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (Cognitive MANETs) enable dynamic spectrum access, allowing secondary users to take advantage of underused licensed channels opportunistically. The unpredictable availability of channels and frequent topology changes present a challenge to routing in such environments. To improve communication performance in Cognitive MANETs, an efficient routing approach is presented that integrates dynamic channel selection with dominant set-based clustering (DCA-DS). Based on a greedy dominating set algorithm, the network is organised into stable clusters, and communication channels are selected dynamically in response to spectrum availability and network conditions. With the proposed method, the network is organised into stable clusters using a greedy dominating set algorithm. Communication channels are selected dynamically according to the spectrum availability and network conditions.

title: Energy Communities Lost in Translation: The Belgian Implementation Gap
authors: Cas Lavaert, Lies Debruyne, Jan Cappelle
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Despite the 2023 implementation of EU energy community legislation in Flanders (Belgium), adoption remains limited, with only 153 communities established by late 2024. This study evaluates the economic viability of energy communities using data from 1,300 Flemish households. Two configurations are analysed: communities of households with existing PV systems and communities with joint investments in new PV. For existing PV setups, sharing surplus energy often results in higher costs for PV owners, especially under current fixed participation fees. In shared PV investments, community-level payback periods can be attractive, but individual results vary widely. Equal investment strategies lead to unfeasible returns for some, while proportional investments offer more balanced payback periods but are harder to realise. Overall, current regulatory and pricing frameworks limit the attractiveness of energy communities in practice.

title: In-Memory Computing Architecture Using Horizontally and Vertically Decoupled 10T SRAM with Multi-Layer Multiplication Units
authors: Ramesh Bhuvan Sai, Kirti S. Pande, T. K. Ramesh
abstract: Von Neumann architecture is the basic computer design model in which a computer has only one memory space for instructions and data. Computer design is therefore streamlined since it allows the sequential process of instructions with efficient execution of programs.The separation of memory and Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) in Von Neumann architecture poses serious challenges to big data and high-performance computing in terms of high latency and energy consumption resulting from continuous data relocation. In-memory computing (IMC) provides a revolutionary solution to this limitation in that it minimizes data relocation and maximizes computational effectiveness, thus representing an imperative for next-generation high-performance computing solutions. This paper presents a new IMC structure using digital static random access memory (SRAM), which simplifies multiplication and is easily extensible to different bit widths, thus enhancing efficiency. Reusing the existing cells while reducing hardware overhead by employing transmission gates, the design lowers power consumption and delay. Implemented on 45nm technology at an operating voltage of 0.5 V. These optimizations together yielded a reduction of 10.7237% in power consumption and a decrease of 2.2% in delay when compared to the existing design. The design is simple and error-resilient and provides practical advantages for low-power VLSI designs.

title: Solver-Free Data Generation for Training Neural Networks with Applications in Power Flow Analysis
authors: Fuat Can Beylunioğlu, Mehrdad Pirnia, P. Robert Duimering
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: As universal function approximators, Neural Networks (NN) can approximate any function with less than a desired error anywhere within a bounded domain. However, existing studies that train NNs to solve optimization problems based on solver-generated datasets, cannot yet produce predictions with desired accuracy. Motivated by the Universal Approximation Theorem (UAT), this paper examines the accuracy of NN prediction in relation to dataset size, problem size, and the construction of training data. Our study shows that a sufficiently large NN can produce accurate predictions when trained with very large datasets, but even so its performance is limited by the quality of the training dataset, which is traditionally obtained by the solution of optimization problems for any given input. A novel data generation approach is proposed for training NN to solve optimization problems, particularly the power flow (PF) problem. The method bypasses the need for solvers to construct datasets by directly utilizing the PF equations. Applications to IEEE test systems show that the proposed approach outperforms solver-based NNs and different optimization algorithms by a wide margin.

title: Reliable AODV Routing Algorithm Using Fuzzy Logic for Mobile Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Raed Hamyd, Lulwah M. Alkwai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: A mobile ad-hoc network (MANET) can be challenging to route efficiently due to its dynamic topology, decentralised architecture, and resource constraints. Since AODV is efficient and on-demand, it is one of the most widely used protocols. Although AODV performs well in highly mobile environments, it is plagued with frequent route failures and reduced performance. To enhance reliability and performance, this paper proposes a Mobility-Aware Adaptive Fuzzy-based AODV route discovery algorithm (MAF-AODV). In the proposed approach, multiple parameters are evaluated, including node energy, link stability, queue congestion, bandwidth, RSSI, and mobility factors. Compared to traditional AODV and other fuzzy-logic-based algorithms, MAF-AODV improves routing reliability, reduces end-to-end delays, and enhances link connectivity. Using fuzzy decision-making in dynamic MANET environments improves routing adaptive and robustness.

title: Performance Comparison of Various Multiple Beam WDM-FSO Communication Systems With Homodyne Detection Under Varying Atmospheric Conditions
authors: V P Chandhana Ranjith, S S Supriya, R D Soumitra, Joseph Zacharias
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Free Space Optics (FSO) has become increasingly significant in modern communication technologies due to the rising need for high-speed, secure communication and efficient use of the spectrum. FSO can be used in scenarios where traditional radio frequency communication or fiber optic communication is absurd or expensive. While the FSO system provides many advantages, its communication effectiveness can be impacted by various atmospheric conditions such as scintillation, fog, haze, and rain. This study aims to enhance the efficiency of the FSO module regarding channel capacity. To achieve this goal, the current research employs a hybrid strategy that integrates multiple beam techniques, erbium-doped fiber amplifier (EDFA) amplification, and homodyne detection (HD) methods within a wavelength division multiplexing (WDM) FSO system. The Gamma-Gamma model is the channel model used in this investigation, and the framework is assessed by utilizing a number of strategies, such as eight beams ($\mathrm{MB} 8 \times 8$) with different modulation techniques in the transmitter section. According to the results, using MB8 $\times 8$ has produced the best performance with a channel capacity of 16 Gbps. The Bit Error Rate (BER), Q factor, and Eye height analysis are calculated to assess the link’s efficacy.

title: Emotion Recognition in Indian Faces: Performance Analysis of Deep Learning Models
authors: Rishabh Vats, Sushama Nagpal
abstract: Facial emotion recognition (FER) is a crucial topic of study in computer vision and artificial intelligence. This study explores the application of deep learning models for facial emotion recognition using a real-world data set comprising six emotions. We used a number of cutting-edge deep learning architectures, such as ResNet101, EfficientNetB0, VGG16, and XceptionNet, and evaluated their performance using Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves. The comparative analysis of these models revealed that while all achieved satisfactory classification accuracy, EfficientNetB0 and XceptionNet consistently outperformed the other models, with micro- and macro average AUC scores exceeding 0.93. These findings highlight the strengths of current deep learning approaches in emotion recognition, suggesting opportunities for further optimization to improve classification accuracy, especially for more subtle or overlapping emotional expressions.

title: Explainable Machine Learning for Sleep Health Analysis Using XGBoost and SHAP Interpretability
authors: T. P. Pattnaik, S.R. Nayak, A.K. Jagadev, K.P. Swain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: This study investigates the application of machine learning in sleep health analytics. It focuses on classification problems relevant to the detection of sleep disorders with a view to interpretation for model predictions. Accordingly, a diversified dataset of health and lifestyle features like sleep duration, stress level, physical activities, etc., will be utilized in this work. Among several baseline machine learning algorithms, XGBoost and HPT (Hyperparameter tuning), XGBoost is coming out as a dominant performer with a view to performance evaluation. The HPT XGBoost model showed the best accuracy, with 93.2%, and good robustness across metrics such as precision, recall, and ROC-AUC compared to several baseline algorithms such as Random Forest, SVM, and Logistic Regression. Explainability is integrated using SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), which provides quantitative feature contributions at both global and individual levels and enhances model predictions' transparency and clinical relevance. This synergy between high-performance machine learning and explainable AI has incredible potential for unlocking actionable insights in healthcare, particularly in the design of interventions for sleep-related disorders such as insomnia and sleep apnea. The results highlight the importance of explainable machine learning in building trust and providing usability in real-world health analytics.

title: Enhancing Cybersecurity in Healthcare Hybrid Cloud Systems with Federated Learning and Blockchain
authors: Ganesh Kanna Jegannathan, P. Lalitha, G Thamaraiselvi, Monali Shivaji Bachhav, Vijayalakshmi Senniappan, Suganya S
abstract: The incorporation of AI in healthcare has resulted in substantial progress in disease identification, treatment, and clinical decision-making. AI-driven solutions automate numerous operations and support healthcare workers; yet, their dependence on ML models has revealed significant cybersecurity weaknesses. This increasing reliance presents significant threats to patient safety and trust, rendering cybersecurity in healthcare an essential issue. This paper presents a Hybrid FL system aimed at improving cybersecurity in healthcare environments through secure, privacy-aware inference and learning. The methodology incorporates multiple preprocessing techniques, such as data purification, transformation, and normalisation, to enhance data quality, while ACO is utilised for effective feature extraction. Comprehensive empirical research assesses the suggested system’s capacity to maintain privacy and identify malicious behaviours in collaborative learning settings. The findings demonstrate that the Hybrid FL model surpasses conventional techniques, with an impressive accuracy of 98.52%, in addition to elevated recall and F-measure metrics. These results validate the model’s efficacy in safeguarding sensitive healthcare information. In summary, the suggested methodology enhances cybersecurity in healthcare, reinforces patient confidence in AI applications, and represents a substantial advancement in the creation of secure, privacy-preserving collaborative learning frameworks.

title: Intelligent Cluster-Based Routing Framework for 5G Integrated Flying Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Rahmy Rehyadd, Deepti Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: As Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) power Flying Ad Hoc Networks (FANETs), new paradigms have emerged for next-generation wireless communication, especially in dynamic and mission-critical environments. Embedding 5G capabilities into FANETs enables ultra-reliable, low-latency, and high-throughput communication, but it is also challenging because of energy constraints, high mobility, and frequent topology changes. Based on a hybrid metaheuristic algorithm optimisation (HMAO) strategy, we present an intelligent cluster-based routing framework for 5G-integrated FANETs. A multicriteria approach is used to select cluster heads and maintain clusters, including residual energy, mobility stability, connectivity, and distance between clusters. The dual-path routing mechanism enhances network reliability and lifetime by combining predictive mobility and load balancing with congestion-aware strategies. According to simulation results, the proposed model reduces energy consumption, breaks fewer links, and improves network lifetime compared to existing RL, Random, and Optimal routing models.

title: Temporal Sentiment Analysis and Strategic Visualization of Sustainable Business Feedback From Online Forums Using NLP
authors: Ferdinand Mahardhika, Tutur Wicaksono, Glisina Dwinoor Rembulan, Guan Nan, Roland M. Simbre, Ronald L Pancho, Adulfo R Arevalo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Public discussions about sustainable business on platforms such as Kaskus, Quora, Reddit, and Twitter provide valuable insights into evolving perceptions of ecofriendly initiatives. However, the fragmented and highvolume nature of these conversations creates challenges for extracting actionable intelligence. This study addresses this gap by developing a Natural Language Processing (NLP)based analytical framework that classifies sentiment, identifies key sustainability topics, and visualizes temporal dynamics in public discourse. We manually collected and annotated 3,523 comments from 2015-2025, covering eleven topics, and trained a Support Vector Machine (SVM) with an RBF kernel (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{C} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{1 0}$</tex>). The model achieved an overall accuracy of 63 % with class-wise F1-scores of 0.74 (positive), 0.47 (neutral), and 0.53 (negative), revealing challenges in distinguishing neutral and negative sentiments. Results indicate that biodegradable materials, green energy, and circular economy dominate discussions, with notable shifts in attention over time. These findings provide organizations with a data-driven lens to align sustainability strategies with public expectations and anticipate emerging concerns.

title: Optimizing Cloud Resources for Financial Market Prediction: A Machine Learning Study on NVIDIA Stock Data
authors: Rashi Chauhan, Vamsi Viswanath Bethamsetty, Naga Raghavendra Manohar Hari
abstract: The integration of machine learning (ML) techniques with cloud computing platforms has revolutionized the domain of financial forecasting, enabling scalable and efficient predictive analytics for volatile markets. However, despite these technological advancements, challenges persist in balancing the computational demands of sophisticated models with the financial constraints of cloud-based deployments. This study addresses the dual need for predictive accuracy and cost-efficiency by proposing a cloud-optimized framework for stock price forecasting, focusing on NVIDIA’s historical data. Three models—ARIMA, XGBoost, and LSTM—were evaluated, with the LSTM model demonstrating superior predictive performance, achieving an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.918. Simultaneously, optimization strategies involving spot instance utilization and auto-scaling policies achieved a reduction of nearly 60% in overall cloud expenditure. The results confirm that intelligent resource management, combined with robust ML techniques, can deliver both high-accuracy forecasting and significant operational cost savings, offering a scalable solution for next-generation financial analytics systems.

title: Wind Turbines Fault Detection based on the Neural Networks and Real data collection
authors: Haidera Ahmidnah, Menny Elbah, Boudy Bilal, Jaleleddine Ben Hadj Slama, Hassen Mekki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The aim of this paper is to propose a method for predicting faults in wind turbines, representing a crucial step toward accurate preventive maintenance, reducing downtime, enhancing reliability, and prevent costly damages. To this end, we trained a neural network to detect faults in operational wind turbine data. Fault prediction was performed by labeling the data from 24 to 12 hours before a fault with the corresponding fault code, while all other data was labeled as data without fault (N). We selected neural networks due to their ability to learn complex patterns in data. After removing outliers, we employed a Bayesian optimization process for feature reduction and subsequently to identify the optimal network configuration. Our model successfully predicted seven types of faults 12 hours in advance with high accuracy and a strong F1-score, making it both more precise and comprehensive compared to existing models in the literature.

title: On Tree Grading of Sapota and Yield Prediction with Computer Vision
authors: Akshatha Prabhu, Pramod C, Gaurav Anantkar M S
abstract: This study presents a novel on-tree sapota fruit grading and yield estimation based on the latest computer vision methods. The study is based on an extensive dataset of 500 sapota fruit images – 250 Grade A and 250 Grade B. The image processing pipeline is based on three strong algorithms: U2-Net as coarse segmentation, GrabCut as the refinement mask step, and YOLOv8 as the accurate object detection and localization step. The Jaccard index is the baseline segmentation performance metric, and standard object detection metrics (precision, recall, F1-score, mAP) measure the accuracy of the YOLOv8 model. Results of this study show higher accuracy of sapota grading and yield estimation compared to conventional, manual methods, demonstrating a strong and effective tool for sapota cultivation and management optimization, with YOLOv8 showing high accuracy U2-Net, GrabCut, and YOLOv8 models were tested for finding the stages of fruit maturity. F1-score, Precision, and Recall were measured for the models. U2-Net gave an mAP of 0.959, YOLOv8 gave 0.983, and GrabCut gave 0.990, which indicates that GrabCut gives the highest accuracy among the three models. Additionally, GrabCut was utilized with YOLOv8 and U2-Net for other research and proved itself effective for improving refinement in segmentation to enhance the quality of classification.

title: Pothole Detection for Safer Roads Using Machine Learning
authors: Sowmya M, B S Keerthi, Fathima Fahim, Gayana V, Manasa S
abstract: Road safety is a serious issue, and the early detection of road hazards like potholes and speed breakers are crucial in minimizing accidents and reducing vehicle damage. This paper presents an enhanced pothole detection model that leverages machine learning techniques, specifically the YOLOv8 architecture. The model is designed to detect both potholes and speed breakers in real-time video streams. Advanced features, including distance estimation are incorporated to provide drivers with actionable information. By assessing the size and position of detected hazards, the system classifies them offering early warnings to facilitate timely reactions and improve road safety. The addition of speed breaker detection further enriches the system's ability to monitor and assess road conditions. This consolidated solution is of immense value for application in intelligent vehicles, road maintenance, and sophisticated driver assistance systems (ADAS), leading to safer and more efficient transportation

title: AI Implementation in Microfinance: A Systematic Review of Predictive Analytics
authors: Christopher Aditya Krisna Buwana, Meyliana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Microfinance institutions (MFIs) face struggles relating to credit risk assessment due to manually operated predictive analysis, which is prone to human bias, data limitations, and inaccuracies. These shortcomings hinder financial while also increase default risks in dynamic markets. This study aims to identify and understand the critical factors for effective AI and machine learning implementation in predictive analytics in MFIs. By conducting a systematic literature review (SLR), we analyzed 110 peer-reviewed articles sourced from international journal publications published from 2020 to 2025 and filtered titles based on the keywords “artificial intelligence” OR “machine learning” AND “microfinance institution” OR “co-operative” AND “predictive analysis”. There were 110 papers identified as relevant to the topic, and 30 were selected to extract factors through analysis. The study identified 43 critical factors, including data quality, algorithmic transparency, and regulatory compliance, categorized into 14 categories of the Smart Co-Operative Model. This study highlights that prioritizing high data integrity and clear regulatory compliance can significantly improve artificial intelligence (AI)-based decision-making, reduce loan default rates, and enhance operational resilience. These findings provide a framework for MFIs to optimize AI-driven decisions, reduce default rates, and enhance operational resilience.

title: Anomaly Detection in IoT Networks Using Machine Learning
authors: Vrushin Raval, Darshan Gosalia, Gaurav Sadarangani, Vipul Gohil
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: The fast expansion of the Internet of Things (IoT) has created major security concerns as billions of linked devices create a significant attack surface for cyber attacks. Since traditional signature-based Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) encounter problems with shifting attack patterns and zero-day threats, anomaly-based detection is a more sensible response. This paper investigates how to detect cyberattacks in IoT networks using generative deep learning methods including bidirectional generative adversarial networks (BiGAN). We trained models to detect hazards including Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) and botnets including Mirai, Okiru, and Torii using the IoT-23 dataset, which comprises over 1.8 million network flows from genuine IoT devices including Somfy door locks, Philips Hue, and Amazon Echo. Adding F1-scores up to 0.99, our generative models outperformed typical machine learning methods. In addition, utilized was a BiGAN-based approach to detect unknown attacks, with an F1-score between 0.85 and 1.

title: Sea Safe: Designing a Serious Game to Develop Awareness in Maritime Cybersecurity
authors: Emīls Laucis, Evita Roponena, Agnė Brilingaitė, Linas Bukauskas, Elizabete Citskovska, Rūta Pirta
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: The effort to shorten supply chains and optimize all business and industrial processes has not bypassed the maritime sector. The introduction of digital services and digitized processes contributes to the unified integration of port infrastructure, but poses many challenges. Cybersecurity in maritime systems is critical due to the risks posed by hybrid and digital attacks. This article contributes to the security of the entire maritime sector by creating instrumentalized workforce awareness training and assessment mechanisms in gamified environments. The work presents the design and implementation of a serious game named Sea Safe for maritime education. Initial prototype validation results demonstrate the solution's potential in early maritime workforce training as the game engaged maritime cadets through adapted scenarios.

title: Speed Control Using Active Disturbance Rejection Control Integrated with Model Predictive Control for Linear Induction Motors
authors: Mahmoud F. Elmorshedy, Seshagiri Rao Vemparala, M.S. Bhaskar, Dhafer Almakhles, Fayez F. M. El-Sousy
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Model Predictive Thrust Control (MPTC) for Linear Induction Machines (LIMs) has attracted considerable attention in recent years, particularly in its finite and continuous control set formulations. Among these, the finite-control-set MPTC (FCSMPTC) is often favored for its straightforward implementation, relatively fast dynamic response, and ability to handle nonlinear constraints. A notable limitation of FCS-MPTC is its open-loop nature, which can result in thrust tracking errors. Traditionally, an external PI controller is used to form a closed-loop structure and regulate the reference speed. However, the PI-based approach may exhibit slower dynamic response and increased thrust error under varying operating conditions. In this work, Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC) is considered as an outer-loop controller in combination with FCS-MPTC. ADRC enhance the system’s ability to handle parameter uncertainties and disturbances. The performance of this integrated control strategy is evaluated using a $3-\mathrm{kW}$ arc-type LIM model. Simulation results indicate that the FCS-MPTC with ADRC can provide favorable dynamic and steady-state behavior, suggesting potential advantages over the conventional PI-based approach under considered conditions.

title: Integration of photovoltaic generator in a medium voltage electrical grid
authors: Sabrine Soltani, Slah Farhani, Sahbi Marrouchi, Faouzi Bacha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Green energy production systems have received significant attention for their contributions to environmental conservation and economic progress. This paper focuses on the feasibility of producing electrical energy through a 30 kV grid-connected photovoltaic power system. Connection to the grid leads us to synthesise the static converters: the boost chopper regulates the voltage and performs the MPPT function, three-phase inverter is controlled by the PWM which couples it to the grid. In fact, the initial objective is achieved by utilizing an MPPT plan based on $\mathrm{P} \& \mathrm{O}$ methodology to maximize the PV power that is injected into the grid. By applying PWM control to the power inverter, the second goal can be achieved. The MATLAB-Simulink environment has been used to verify the performance of this control strategy for various static and dynamic power flow regimes. The MATLAB-Simulink environment has been used to verify the performance of this control strategy for various static and dynamic power flow regimes.

title: Consideration of Nodal Cross-Correlation in Reliability Assessment of Bulk Electric Systems with Net-zero Emission Targets
authors: Deeksha Sharma, Rajesh Karki
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: This paper investigates the importance of incorporating supply-demand cross-correlation in the reliability assessment of bulk power systems transitioning towards the netzero emission target. The growing share of renewable energy generation and electrification of automotives and home-space heating will significantly alter the supply-demand variations at the different bulk system nodes. It will, therefore, be important to incorporate the nodal variations and their correlations in composite system reliability (CSR) assessment for proper system planning and investment decisions. This paper presents a method to incorporate the nodal correlation of supply and demand in a CSR evaluation and illustrates its application on the Roy Billinton test system (RBTS). Variations in load profiles due to expected growth in electric vehicles and demand due to electric heating systems are modeled to assess their impact on bulk system reliability. The results quantitatively validate the growing need to recognize the correlations in CSR study as the decarbonization of power systems increase with time.

title: Isosceles Trapezoidal TSVs for High-Density Interconnects in 3D ICs and Crosstalk Analysis
authors: Prosen Kirtonia, Kasem Khalil, Magdy Bayoumi
abstract: With the growing adoption of chiplets and 3D ICs in the semiconductor industry, the role of their interconnects has become increasingly crucial to maintain efficient and high-performance communication between chips. Among various interconnect technologies, Through-Silicon Vias (TSVs) are the most prominent, strengthening 3D IC integration and advanced chiplet packaging. In this paper, we propose isosceles trapezoidal-shaped TSVs arranged in an offset mosaic orientation to improve area efficiency for dense nano-scale fabrication. This design achieves over 20% reduction in area consumption compared to conventional cylindrical TSVs for the same number of interconnects. In general, the TSV shape influences stress distribution and thermal management capabilities, and the orientation affects signal transmission, crosstalk, and overall area efficiency. However, the proposed architecture demonstrates outstanding transmission performance and minimal signal interference for multiple TSVs across the 0.01–50 GHz bandwidth, in addition to its remarkable area efficiency. Moreover, the trapezoidal shape is expected to have a better stress distribution and thermal dissipation compared to the triangular design. Collectively, the exploration of the novel TSV shape and pattern marks a significant step toward finding suitable and optimized interconnects for next-generation ICs and advanced chip packaging.

title: Universal Power Electronic Interface in Residential DC Microgrids
authors: Shiji S, Mini V. P, B.V Annie
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Residential DC microgrids are experiencing increased adoption due to the global shift towards sustainable energy, which incorporates photovoltaic (PV) systems and battery energy storage systems (BESS) for enhanced efficiency and system reliability. However, the efficient and flexible integration of these resources remains challenging due to variability in voltage levels, load requirements, and power quality standards. A universal power electronic interface (UPEI) is designed to optimize the integration of PV modules and BESS within residential DC microgrids. UPEI architecture employs a multi-port configuration to manage multiple input and output ports, allowing seamless power flow control between PV arrays, batteries, and residential loads. An intelligent control strategy dynamically regulates the power flow, enhances voltage stability, and maximizes energy harvesting from PV sources, ensuring efficient energy utilization across the microgrid. The UPEI also features modular scalability, enabling easy adaptation to different PV and battery capacities. A DC-DC converter topology capable of operating in six different modes has been developed, facilitating versatile and bidirectional power flow control. Moreover, the converter supports bidirectional power flow, allowing energy exchange between the source and the load in both directions. This capability makes it well-suited for integration with renewable energy systems and energy storage units. The simulation results indicate notable improvements in energy efficiency, voltage stability, and o verall system robustness compared to conventional power interfaces. The Universal Power Electronic Interface (UPEI) significantly contributes to the improved performance and reliability of residential DC microgrids, thereby advancing the development of a more sustainable and resilient energy infrastructure.

title: Explainable AI-based Framework for efficient energy exchange between Smart Grid and Smart Homes
authors: Lakshit Pathak, Mili Virani, Sarika Kanojia, Rajesh Gupta, Sudeep Tanwar
abstract: In this research work, a novel framework which makes use of Explainable AI (XAI) to facilitate efficient energy interaction between Smart Grids and Smart Homes is presented. Using SHAP and LIME methods, the proposed framework improves the interpretability of the predictions of energy consumption, which is critical in decision-making. The system employs IoT gadgets and smart meters to continuously measure energy consumption and support cost optimization and decreased pollution rates. The customary machine learning models and algorithms, though precise, do not give an approximate explanation about predictions. XAI is integrated to make these predictions more understandable rethinking household energy patterns. This allows users to better understand specific behaviors contributing to their current level of energy consumption and take actions towards reducing that waste. Using the proposed framework, we present a highly efficient, transparent, and data driven solution that enables Smart Homes to seamlessly manage energy flow with the Smart Grid to lead to decreased energy use, improved grid efficiency, and greater sustainability of the energy grid.

title: Implementing Grover’s Algorithm on NISQ Chips
authors: Reece Robertson, Colburn Riffel, Matthew Slodov, Peter Hendrickson
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: This paper explores the performance of proof-of-concept scale instances of Grover’s algorithm, analyzing execution on several fully-connected trapped-ion and pairwise-connected superconducting quantum hardware devices. Only trapped-ion devices outperformed sampling from a uniform distribution across all possible outputs.

title: Multi-Tool Static Code Analysis for Code Smell and Bug Detection: A Case Study on the Java-Design-Patterns Repository
authors: Kenny Aldi, Rheno Septianto, Ragil Yulianto, Ryeisha Taskia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Code smells are indicators of potential problems in software source code that may hinder maintainability, increase complexity, and elevate the likelihood of future defects. This paper presents a case study on the identification and analysis of code smells in the java-designpatterns open-source project hosted on GitHub. Three static analysis tools-SonarQube, PMD, and SpotBugs-were employed to provide a comprehensive evaluation of code quality from different perspectives. SonarQube offered a macro-level overview including maintainability scores and technical debt; PMD identified rule-based structural violations; and SpotBugs revealed bytecode-level runtime bugs. The analysis revealed 899 code smells, 125 bugs, and zero test coverage, highlighting critical areas for improvement. Additionally, differences among tool outputs emphasized the need for a multi-tool strategy to achieve a holistic and accurate assessment. The findings contribute to software quality assurance practices by demonstrating the complementary nature of these tools and offering actionable recommendations for refactoring and code auditing.

title: Autonomous Indoor Navigator
authors: Aleena Sojan, Cyril Thomas, Bhadra Raj, Sam Abraham Simon, Shajimon K John, Arukant A Jose
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Autonomous navigation systems play a vital role in enabling mobile robots to navigate and operate efficiently in dynamic environments without human intervention. These systems integrate various technologies, including LiDAR-based mapping, sensor fusion, localization, path planning, and obstacle avoidance, to ensure accurate and safe movement. The core components include Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) for map generation, Adaptive Monte Carlo Localization (AMCL) for real-time positioning, and the Navigation Stack (Nav2) for path planning and execution. Sensor inputs from LiDAR, encoders, and IMUs help in refining localization and odometry, while real-time obstacle detection mechanisms enhance navigation reliability.This work demonstrates a cost-effective and scalable approach to autonomous navigation, with future enhancements planned for multi-floor navigation, improved hardware integration, and product-level development.

title: CNN based multiclass brain tumor classification from MRI images
authors: Karen Nicolle Arango Valencia, María Josè Rodríguez Hernández, Cristian Alejandro Torres Valencia, Diego Fernando Ramírez Jimènez
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: This paper presents the development and evaluation of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for multiclass classification of brain tumors from MRI images, covering four categories: glioma, meningioma, pituitary tumor, and no tumor. A comparative analysis was conducted using a custom CNN trained from scratch, and two transfer learning approaches: MobileNetV2 and ResNet50 with fine tuning. Results show that fine tuned MobileNetV2 achieved the highest validation accuracy ($83.9 \%$) and best generalization. To promote clinical applicability, all models were integrated into a graphical user interface (GUI) that allows image upload, model selection, and real time prediction display with confidence scores. 0

title: Interaction Design Based on Cloud Video and Personalized Multimodal Network Model
authors: Meng Li
abstract: With the widespread application of cloud video interaction technology in remote collaboration, intelligent education and other fields, how to solve the demand for multimodal semantic fusion and personalized interaction under real-time constraints has become a key challenge. This article proposes a personalized multimodal network interaction design method based on cloud edge collaboration architecture. By constructing a three-layer system including cloud video platform layer, multimodal feature network layer, and personalized interaction engine layer, efficient processing of multimodal data and dynamic generation of interaction strategies are achieved. Research and design a dynamic cross modal attention mechanism (DCMA), which dynamically calculates modal fusion weights based on feature norm and cosine distance to solve the semantic alignment problem of heterogeneous data; Build a personalized strategy generation engine using reinforcement learning framework, incorporating user profiles, physiological indicators, and environmental parameters into the state space to achieve real-time optimization of interaction strategies. The experimental results show that the end-to-end delay of the system is stable at 180 ms in the 200 channel concurrent video stream scene, the accuracy rate of three-mode intention recognition is 95%, 12.3% higher than the traditional static fusion model, and the user personalized interaction satisfaction is 28% higher, which effectively verifies the advantages of cloud side collaborative architecture in computing resource allocation and multi-mode fusion efficiency. Further research is being conducted to achieve lightweight deployment of models and dynamic updates of edge nodes through knowledge distillation and federated learning techniques, while reducing data privacy risks while ensuring edge inference latency of ⩽ 50ms. This article provides a technical solution for highly immersive cloud video interaction systems that balances real-time performance, semantic accuracy, and personalized experience. In the future, it can be extended to complex scenarios such as virtual exhibitions and industrial inspections, promoting the engineering application of multimodal interaction technology.

title: Next-Gen Physical Design with AI
authors: Bindu P Rao, Jagadeesh Gnanasekaran, Prasenjit Ray, V Sai Prashant, Anand Kumaraswamy
abstract: The Artificial Intelligence (AI) era has significantly increased the demand for semiconductor chips, driving the need for highly optimized designs that balance performance, power, area, schedule and cost (PPASC). AI techniques can augment traditional physical design methods to achieve highly optimized designs through multi-objective exploration, data-driven predictions of outcomes, and accelerate design convergence with clustering and pattern matching solutions. This paper shows the value-add of AI techniques for recipe generation, clock parameter selection, power-performance optimization, at-scale design robustness analysis, and design convergence. Results show AI improves PPASC, design quality and resource efficiency, leading to optimally designed chips.

title: FiTBiT: FPGA File Transfer system powered by Blockchain Technology
authors: Akshay Raghavendra Kulkarni, Mohammed Niamat
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: The Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) supply chain faces several challenges, including intellectual property (IP) theft and bitstream modification. Therefore, it is essential to develop solutions that not only ensure the integrity of the FPGA supply chain but also protect FPGAs from potential attacks. While the supply chain is vulnerable at multiple stages, this paper specifically focuses on the stage where the chip’s blueprint—represented as a GDSII file—is transferred from the design house to the foundry. In this proposed research, the traditional method of transferring the design file is transformed by incorporating blockchain technology. Blockchain is used to establish trust and transparency in the supply chain, enabling the tracking and tracing of assets such as IP cores and bitstreams. Moreover, the communication channel is secured against man-in-the-middle attacks, preventing adversaries from intercepting the file. The blockchain network developed for this investigation is simulated using the Ganache user interface provided by the Truffle framework. Simulations were conducted for three different block times—60, 120, and 180 seconds—and the number of blocks mined in each scenario was recorded. Results from the simulations indicate an inverse relationship between block time and the number of blocks mined.

title: The Role Of Artificial Intelligence In IoT Data Analysis For Management Optimization
authors: Hassan Ali Al-Ababneh, Salem A. S. Alrhaimi, Mukhles M. Al-Ababneh, Nidal Ali Abbas, Amin Khalifeh, Farah Hanna Zawaideh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The key objective of the study is to substantiate the role of artificial intelligence (AI) in analyzing Internet of Things (IoT) data in order to optimize management processes. With the rapid growth of data generated by IoT devices, traditional methods of information processing are no longer able to effectively cope with the tasks of analysis and decision-making in real time. It is argued that artificial intelligence, in particular machine learning and deep neural networks, provide new opportunities for processing and interpreting this data. The use of artificial intelligence allows you to automate the processes of analyzing data from IoT devices, which in turn helps to improve the forecasting, monitoring and management of various systems, such as smart cities, industry, transport and energy. Artificial intelligence provides forecasting of resource needs, detection of anomalies in data and suggestion of optimal solutions to reduce costs and increase efficiency. The need to argue attention to data security issues and the ethical aspects of using artificial intelligence in such critical areas is substantiated. It has been proven that the proper application of AI technologies in conjunction with IoT contributes to the creation of adaptive, highly efficient and sustainable management systems, which is the key to successful digital transformation in various industries.

title: Simulink to Silicon: Deploying and Validating Neural Network-Based SoC Estimation of Batteries on ZedBoard FPGA
authors: Roshan Binu Paul, Vaishnav S Warrier, Aswin P Nair, Dayas M John, Shoba Gopalakrishnan, Neelakantan P C
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Reliable State-of-Charge (SoC) estimation of batteries is critical for validating the performance and safety of battery management systems (BMS) in electric vehicles and embedded energy systems. While traditional techniques such as Coulomb counting and Kalman filters are commonly used, they fall short under dynamic and real-time operating conditions. This paper presents an end-to-end hardware-software verification framework for SOC estimation using neural networks, modeled in MATLAB Simulink and deployed on an FPGA via HDL Coder. The implementation was validated in three stages, MATLAB simulation, HDL simulation in Xilinx Vivado, and real-time display on the ZedBoard OLED, to ensure output consistency. A comparative analysis between ReLU and linear activation functions revealed that ReLU provides superior estimation accuracy ($0.123 \%$ relative error) compared to linear ($5.58 \%$). The results demonstrate that ReLU-based designs are both efficient and reliable for system-level deployment.

title: HM2GP: A Multi-Version Task Scheduler with Extended Precedence Constraints on COTS SoCs
authors: Matthias Stammler, Fabian Lesniak, Niraj Kumar, Arvind Easwaran, Jürgen Becker
abstract: Ongoing trends of centralizing software functionality like Advanced Driver Assistance Systems in automotive vehicles have created the need for a centralized electric/electronic architecture with heterogeneous multicore processing systems on chip (MPSoCs). Standards such as ISO 26262 and ISO 21448 further necessitate measures to fulfill both real-time and safety requirements via real-time capable scheduling combined with redundancy measures.To be able to keep up with the increase in centralization and task complexity, a holistic scheduling approach is necessary. Fulfilling these standards, we propose HM2GP, a time-triggered phased execution model and scheduler for tasks with precedence constraints and arbitrary placement of execution phases. It also supports heterogeneous commercial of the shelf MPSoCs with multiple shared resources. This work provides a comprehensive framework that enables the scheduling and schedule optimization of complex task sets on centralized heterogeneous multicore platforms.
