We evaluate our work by introducing a real world case study and showing the generalization capabilities by scheduling synthetic task sets with HM2GP and related works. We observe no considerable runtime overhead compared to existing methods, while providing an extension to related works.

title: Empowering Investor Engagement: Role of Agentic AI in Financial Advisory Adoption
authors: Kanchan Pranay Patil, Dhanya Pramod
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Agentic AI is characterized by proactive autonomous decision-making, problem-solving, multi-tasking, and picking up knowledge via real-world interactions without human interventions. Agentic AI systems have capabilities to conduct transactions, monitor risk in real-time, and independently supervise compliance processes essential for the financial business. Using the Signal-Mechanism-Consequence underpinning theory as a foundation, the study proposes a conceptual framework to test empirically how agentic AI signals affect financial investors' usage of artificial intelligence in investment decision-making. The research emphasizes the key characteristics of agentic AI for investors' engagement are autonomy, accountability, explainability, fairness, anthropomorphism, and goal-orientedness. An online survey was used to conduct a cross-sectional empirical research, and 305 responses from participants/investors were gathered. The results demonstrate that agentic AI signals of autonomy, accountability, explainability, and goal-orientedness enhanced investor engagement and, consequently, the adoption of AI technology for investment decision-making. Furthermore, anthropomorphism and fairness had no impact on the investors' engagement. These agentic AI characteristics guide the development of agentic AI and highlight the fundamental needs for constructing it for investment decision-making in the financial services industry. We conclude by explaining how financial institutions can gain strategic knowledge from agentic AI research, thereby improving AI's interaction with investors and encouraging its use in financial decision-making.

title: Smart Fuzzy Energy Management System for IoT-Driven Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Qasim Jumaa, Manish Bhardwaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The dynamic topology and high mobility of Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks (VANETs), particularly when integrated with the Internet of Things (IoT), pose significant challenges for maintaining energy efficiency. Traditional energy optimization techniques often fail to balance network longevity with communication reliability, leading to increased energy consumption. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Smart Fuzzy Energy Management System (SFEMS) that leverages fuzzy logic-based decision-making for dynamic energy optimization. The proposed system employs a tri-parametric fuzzy logic optimization approach to enhance both cluster formation and cluster head selection processes. Simulation results demonstrate that SFEMS significantly improves packet delivery ratio, reduces end-to-end delay, and enhances overall energy efficiency in vehicular networks, making it a promising solution for IoT -enabled VANET environments.

title: Electrical Power Consumption Forecasting Using Wavelet and Retention Networks
authors: Jun Wei Chan, Chai Kiat Yeo
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Given the periodicity in electrical power consumption, this paper proposes a novel wavelet transform augmented retentive network model using frequency space deep learning for forecasting electrical power consumption. We apply retention in both the temporal and wavelet space to capture and model the frequency information. The proposed method consists of stacked wavelet retention layers. For each layer, wavelet transform is performed on the input, transforming the sequence into the wavelet space. Retention is applied separately for each level of decomposition to allow the definition of multiple heads to learn the different attention maps. Experiments on the London dataset show that it achieves better results than all the other baselines and also outperforms the top-performing SOTA in most accuracy metrics but uses $40 \%$ fewer parameters and only involves half the floating point operations compared to the SOTA benchmark.

title: Optimized FPGA Implementation of Audio Compression Using LPC and GOLOMB Coding
authors: Jaimy James Poovely, Raveena Judie Dolly, C V Sreyas Kumar, A Harikrishnan, Dhruvin. S. Nair, P. Thilakeswaran
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Lossless audio compression is a presently most discussed topic in the field of audio compression. Some of the lossless audio compression are TAK (Tom’s Audio Kompressor), WavPack - Supports hybrid mode (both lossless and lossy), ALAC (Apple Lossless Audio Codec) - Used in Apple devices and FLAC (Free Lossless Audio Codec) - Popular for high-fidelity music storage. Here we have proposed the modified version of the FLAC algorithm that integrates Exponential Golomb coding for enhanced residual encoding. Unlike a direct replication of the standard FLAC pipeline, our approach introduces a novel variant that aims to improve compression efficiency while maintaining audio quality and has been implemented in vivado. In FLAC structure, we can find coding techniques like Linear Predictive Coding (LPC) and Rice encoding. It has been simulated in MATLAB and Vivado. Here we have proposed an FPGA-based implementation of audio compression using Linear Predictive Coding (LPC) and Exponential Golomb coding techniques. The LPC algorithm is employed to analyze and predict the speech signal, generating residuals that are subsequently encoded using Golomb coding for efficient compression. The FPGA synthesis results in vivado shows minimal resource utilization, with LUT, FF, DSP, and I/O consumption recorded at $\mathbf{0. 4 2 \%}, \mathbf{0. 3 9 \%}, \mathbf{1 0 \%}$, and 16.67%, respectively. The simulation results, illustrated through waveform outputs, confirm the correct functionality of both LPC and Golomb encoding stages. The proposed approach achieves a balance between computational efficiency and compression performance, making it suitable for real-time embedded audio processing applications.

title: Resilient and Online Reconfiguration of Distribution Systems into Multi-Islanded Microgrids
authors: Mohammadjavad Bordbari, Fuzhan Nasiri
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Despite the increasing deployment of microgrids, distribution networks remain vulnerable to upstream failures, which can lead to widespread blackouts. This vulnerability arises from the fixed boundaries and limited adaptability of microgrids in dynamic conditions. To address this, a BreadthFirst Search (BFS)-based algorithm is proposed to identify optimal reconfiguration strategies, enabling the transformation of disconnected distribution systems into multiple self-sustained microgrids while minimizing dependence on remote switches. To achieve real-time operation, the solution is embedded in a Deep Reinforcement learning framework that learns adaptive switching policies online. A custom reward function prioritizes supply restoration and minimizes load shedding, while an exponential epsilon-greedy strategy balances exploration and exploitation during training. Simulation results on the IEEE 33bus distribution system show that the proposed method improves convergence speed, decision efficiency, and resilience, outperforming conventional learning models. The framework enables adaptive multi microgrids reconfiguration for enhanced system resilience.

title: Pneumonia Detection from Chest X-ray Images Using Various Transfer Learning Models
authors: Aicha Akrout, Amira Echtioui, Mohamed Ghorbel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Pneumonia remains a significant global health concern, posing a substantial threat to human lives due to its contagious nature and potentially fatal respiratory complications caused by bacteria, fungi, or viruses. The reliance on chest X-rays for diagnosis, although common, often necessitates expert interpretation, which can lead to delays and potential inaccuracies in treatment. This study addresses these challenges by employing transfer learning techniques to automate the detection of lung diseases, with a focus on pneumonia. Leveraging four pre-trained models: VGG-16, ResNet50V2, MobileNetV2, and InceptionV3, we conducted comprehensive experiments to evaluate their performance. Our findings reveal that the proposed model, based on VGG-16, demonstrates superior accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score, achieving impressive results: $92.82 \%$ accuracy, $93.66 \%$ precision, $92.66 \%$ recall, and an $F 1$ score of $93.00 \%$. This research underscores the potential of transfer learning in enhancing pneumonia diagnosis and treatment outcomes, offering a promising avenue for improving healthcare delivery and reducing mortality rates associated with this debilitating respiratory condition.

title: MultiPath Deep Lung Cancer Classification Network Utilizing Normal and Dilated Convolution Along with Residual Connection
authors: S Syam, K P Pushpalatha
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Technological progress in the area of artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities have transformed the landscape of diagnostic imaging with never before seen accuracy and adaptivity. Nevertheless, lung cancer remains one of the most common causes of cancer deaths; thus, there is a need for strong diagnostic tools to enhance early detection and the subsequent therapy outcome. This study proposes a Multi-Path Deep Lung Cancer Classification Neural Network (MPCNN) that integrates normal and dilated convolutions with residual connections to enhance feature extraction and classification. The network effectively captures multi-scale features, preserves spatial details, and mitigates gradient vanishing, leading to improved diagnostic accuracy. Evaluated on benchmark datasets, the proposed MPCNN achieved ($96.5 \%$) accuracy, outperforming traditional CNNs ($89.3 \%$) and vision transformers ($91.8 \%$). It also demonstrated high precision ($\mathbf{9 4. 7 \%}$), recall ($\mathbf{9 5. 2 \%}$), and an impressive $\mathbf{F - 1}$ score $(\mathbf{9 4. 9 \%})$. The proposed approach also demonstrated a high Area Under the Curve (AUC) of 0.982, indicating robust differentiation between normal, benign, and malignant nodules. These results validate MPCNN’s potential for improving lung cancer diagnostics, contributing to early detection and better clinical outcomes.

title: A Call to Arms: Motivating An Internet Measurements Observatory for Africa
authors: Semebia Y. Wurah, Nicholas Brian Anya, Theophilus A. Benson
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: Despite decades of investment and regulatory efforts, Africa's Internet ecosystem still relies heavily on infrastructure far outside the continent, routing traffic through Europe and outsourcing critical services like DNS resolution. This dependence on foreign infrastructure exacerbates the impact of subsea cable cuts and exposes a deeper problem. That is, the continent's connectivity fabric remains externally dependent and structurally fragile. Existing measurement tools fail to illuminate this reality, either by missing key components or offering insufficient visibility. We argue for a rethinking of how we monitor and support Africa's Internet infrastructure. Our vision is a purpose-built testbed that combines crowd-sourced vantage points with intentional, context-aware targeting to better capture the unique Internet ecosystem of the continent. Rather than simply retrofitting global solutions, we propose building with the realities of Africa's ecosystem in mind.

title: Low-Noise Stabilization Mechanism to Enhance the Performance of High-Gain Silicon-Graphene Photodetectors
authors: Federico G. De Geronimo, Nilton O. Renno
abstract: Silicon-graphene photodetectors have high gain which varies with the environmental conditions. We developed a stabilization circuit that mitigates this problem by maintaining the graphene operating current nearly constant. We show that prototype devices with this circuit have a 2-4x smaller dark current noise power across temperatures ranging from -5°C to 55°C, and ∼4x lower noise power under modulated laser forcing with parasitic background white light. The device responsivity remains high under the changing environmental conditions, demonstrating that the proposed stabilization circuit significantly improves performance of graphene- silicon photodetectors, enabling applications like optical tracking, alignment, and low-flux sensing.

title: Frequency Domain-DQN for Flexible Photovoltaic Power Point Tracking under Noisy Operating Condition
authors: Jiang Yuan, Ming Huang, Jieming Ma, Ka Lok Man, Zhongbei Tian
abstract: Due to the variability of environmental parameters, Photovoltaic (PV) systems frequently operate under Noisy Operating Conditions (NOC). The existing Flexible Power Point Tracking (FPPT) algorithms encounter significant challenge in misjudging the optimal voltage points under NOC. This paper presents a Frequency Domain-Deep Q-Network (FD-DQN) approach to FPPT by incorporating frequency domain analysis through the Fourier transform, which decomposes irradiance signals to capture dynamic changes caused by noise. Additionally, a novel Signal Quality Factor (SQF) is introduced to quantify noise and refine the learning process, minimizing overfitting in the presence of noisy data. By analyzing the influence of different frequency components, the FD-DQN enables more accurate tracking with fewer misjudgments. Experimental results indicate that the proposed approach achieves a minimum improvement of 5% in tracking accuracy and reduces misjudgments by around 50% under NOC, outperforming traditional methods in both simulated and experimental scenarios with fluctuating irradiance.

title: RAPID-RTX: a novel real-time radiative transfer and force field modeling framework for forest BRF simulations
authors: Zhuangzhuang Zhang, Yueyue Li, Chang Liu, Huaguo Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) radiative transfer models (RTMs) have emerged as crucial tools for quantifying uncertainties in remote sensing observations. However, most current 3D radiative transfer modeling is based on static scenes, which differ significantly from the dynamic facts of the real world. The UAV shadow and natural wind were also not considered in previous 3D RTM studies. These simplifications in the modeling caused uncertainties in the 3D radiative transfer modeling. To improve the physical realism of 3D radiative transfer modeling, enhancing the model capacity to dynamically simulate the radiative transfer process of forest scenes under physical disturbances in real-time is essential. This study proposed RAPID-RTX, a novel real-time radiative transfer and force field modeling framework for the RAPID model based on Universal Scene Description (USD) and Ray Tracing Xtreme (RTX) rendering technologies. To quantify the effects of UAV shadows and natural wind on UAV-observed forest BRFs, we used RAPID-RTX to simulate forest scenes with and without UAV shadows under multiple viewing angles, and to assess the impact of wind-induced tree movement. Results showed that UAV shadows significantly impact forest BRF, especially at viewing directions near hotspot direction. In the simple plantation scene, the maximum impact reached 83.9% in the red band and 73.7% in the NIR band, whereas in the dense forest scene (Wytham Woods 2015), the maximum impact reached 51.5% and 40.6% in the red and NIR bands, respectively. To minimize the impact of UAV shadows on UAV observed forest BRF, it is recommended that the sensor FOV is larger than 5° and the flight height is higher than 60 meters. Additionally, at wind speed levels 3 and 5 (4 m/s and 10 m/s), the maximum wind impact on forest BRFs in the red band reaches 23.8% and 28.5%, respectively, while in the NIR band the corresponding values are 26.1% and 33.3%. Therefore, we recommend avoiding remote sensing experiments when the wind speed exceeding 4 m/s.

title: Charge Trap Flash-Gated Inverter-based In-Memory Analog-to-Digital Converter for Compute-in-Memory
authors: Jonghyun Ko, Jiseong Im, Ryun-Han Koo, Sung-Ho Park, Taeho Lee, Sung Yun Woo, Jong-Ho Lee
abstract: We propose a charge trap flash (CTF)-gated inverter-based in-memory analog-to-digital converter (ADC) that achieves highly compact and energy-efficient operation for compute-in-memory (CIM) systems. By exploiting programmable threshold voltages of CTF devices, the switching voltage of each inverter can be precisely controlled, enabling a quantization scheme with only two transistors per level. Through a fine-tuning process with soft-erase operations, the switching voltages of 13 inverters were evenly mapped with 0.1 V spacing. The fabricated ADC achieved the maximum DNL and INL of 0.11 LSB and 0.14 LSB, respectively. Benchmarking based on measured and simulated data suggests that the proposed design offers potentially superior area and energy efficiency. These results indicate the potential of CTF-gated inverter-based ADCs as promising candidates for CIM architectures.

title: High-power Narrow-linewidth C-band DFB Laser Array with High-uniform Wavelength Spacing
authors: Zhenxing Sun, Shenghong Xie, Yue Zhang, Yuechun Shi, Yunshan Zhang, Zhenzhen Xu, Xiangfei Chen
abstract: We propose and experimentally demonstrate a 16-channel DFB laser array operating in the C-band, featuring high output power, narrow linewidth, low relatice intensity noise (RIN) and uniform wavelength spacing. The reconstruction equivalent chirp (REC) technique is used to introduce equivalent π phase shifts, simplify the grating process, and enhance the wavelength control accuracy. To maximize output efficiency, high-reflection (HR) and anti-reflection (AR) coatings are deposited on the rear and front facets, respectively. In addition, an asymmetric equivalent phase-shift configuration is incorporated into the cavity, which enhances the single-mode yield of the lasers and improves the precision of the wavelength spacing. A passive waveguide with light n-type doping was introduced to suppress the overlap between the optical mode and both the p-type cladding and the active region, thereby reducing carrier-induced absorption losses and significantly improving the slope efficiency of the laser. As a result, the proposed 16-channel DFB laser array operates with a channel spacing of 200 GHz and a maximum wavelength deviation of only 0.01 nm. Each laser delivers an output power exceeding 300 mW at a bias current of 1000 mA and 25 °C. The intrinsic Lorentzian linewidth is as narrow as 64 kHz, while the relative intensity noise (RIN) remains below −160 dB/Hz for bias currents above 500 mA. These results highlight the array’s strong potential for applications in optical I/O technology, free-space optical (FSO) communication, and light detection and ranging (LiDAR) systems.

title: A Robust SINS/DVL/PS Tightly Integrated Navigation Method Under Partial Beam Failure
authors: Qiantong Shao, Xixiang Liu, Xiangzhi Cheng, Guangrun Sheng, Xu Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: To address the challenge of DVL beam failure in complex underwater environments, especially under water tracking mode, a robust SINS/DVL/PS tightly integrated navigation method under partial beam failure is proposed in this paper. A new Doppler shift-based system model is modelled by incorporating the ocean current velocities into the state vector. Furthermore, to enhance system robustness under partial beam failure, a DVL fault detection and fault-tolerant strategy based on Mahalanobis distance and virtual beam reconstruction is developed to handle DVL partial beam failures. Simulation and sea experiments results demonstrate that the proposed method ensures robust navigation performance in both bottom tracking (BT) and water tracking (WT) modes. In WT mode, the positioning accuracy is improved by 66.85% compared to the LI-OC, and in BT mode, the improvement is 70.59% and 64.84% compared to LI-OC and TI-VB, respectively.

title: Repositioning Submarine Communication Cables Using Ship Waves Based on Integrated Sensing and Communication Network
authors: Wenjin Huang, Sheng Zhou, Qing Hong, Qingqing Liu, Zhenyu Shen, Liying Huang, Can Xie, Zhaohui Song, Yichang Wu, Shaoyi Chen, Zhaohui Li
abstract: An integrated sensing and communication network can be implemented with the widely laid submarine communication cables using the distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) technology, providing the capabilities of sensing acoustic signals around the cables. However, the seabed activities, ocean currents, and vessel anchor drag usually cause the position shift of cables, affecting the cable maintenance. Moreover, the precise localization of acoustic sources, including ocean seismic, marine mammals, and ship movement, also requires the accurate cable locations. Conventional methods for repositioning submarine cables, which rely on sonar and profiler technologies, often necessitate specialized vessels and equipment. Such approaches incur high operational costs and difficulties in achieving frequent cable positioning. To address this issue, this article first analyzes the ship wave pattern in DAS data, identifying the vertices of V-shaped ship wave as reliable indicators of ship movement, and thus further proposes a cost-effective repositioning method that collaboratively integrates DAS-recorded ship wave patterns and ships' Automatic Identification System (AIS) information to accurately determine the longitude and latitude of ship travelling above the cables, allowing for the deduction of the cable route. This study conducted a field test on a newly laid 1.7-kilometer submarine communication cable near Gulangyu Island, Xiamen. The experimental results demonstrate that the calculated longitude and latitude of the cable's endpoints exhibit high consistency with those specified in the construction drawings, with discrepancies of only 14.36 meters and 30.28 meters, respectively. This proposed method is applicable to the calibration of buried submarine communication cables.

title: High-Performance Serverless Computing: A Systematic Literature Review on Serverless for HPC, AI, and Big Data
authors: Valerio Besozzi, Matteo Della Bartola, Patrizio Dazzi, Marco Danelutto
abstract: The widespread deployment of large-scale, compute-intensive applications such as high-performance computing, artificial intelligence, and big data is leading to convergence between cloud and high-performance computing infrastructures. Cloud providers are increasingly integrating high-performance computing capabilities in their infrastructures, such as hardware accelerators and high-speed interconnects, while researchers in the high-performance computing community are starting to explore cloud-native paradigms to improve scalability, elasticity, and resource utilization. In this context, serverless computing emerges as a promising execution model to efficiently handle highly dynamic, parallel, and distributed workloads. This paper presents a comprehensive systematic literature review of 122 research articles published between 2018 and early 2025, exploring the use of the serverless paradigm to develop, deploy, and orchestrate compute-intensive applications across cloud, high-performance computing, and hybrid environments. From these, a taxonomy comprising eight primary research directions and nine targeted use case domains is proposed, alongside an analysis of recent publication trends and collaboration networks among authors, highlighting the growing interest and interconnections within this emerging research field. Overall, this work aims to offer a valuable foundation for both new researchers and experienced practitioners, guiding the development of next-generation serverless solutions for parallel compute-intensive applications.

title: Retrieving all-day surface downwelling longwave radiation under cloudy-sky conditions using FengYun-4A geostationary satellite data
authors: Yun Jiang, Bo-Hui Tang, Yingyun Li, Menglin Si, Zhi Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: All-day surface downwelling longwave radiation (SDLR) is essential for studying surface radiation balance and the greenhouse effect. However, estimating SDLR under cloudy-sky conditions poses significant challenges due to the reliance on accurate cloud parameters acquisition. Most existing satellite-based algorithms for cloudy-sky SDLR retrieval are limited to daytime operations, as passive satellites are unable to provide critical data, such as cloud optical thickness, during night-time data that are crucial for estimating cloud base parameters. This study introduces an all-day SDLR retrieval algorithm based on cloud top temperature (CTT) and constructs a cloud impact factor based on cloud top height to regulate the radiative forcing contribution of clouds. The newly established algorithm was validated using ground-based measurements from Atmospheric Radiation Measurement (ARM) sites. Compared to algorithms that directly utilize CTT, the new approach incorporating the cloud impact factor demonstrated higher accuracy, with a bias of ﹣1.32 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and an RMSE of 17.75 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Subsequently, datasets from the FengYun-4A (FY-4A) geostationary satellite were employed to retrieve all-day cloudy-sky SDLR with hourly resolution. Verification against Baseline Surface Radiation Network (BSRN) site measurements revealed a bias of 9.04 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and an RMSE of 28.30 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Compared to previous retrieval schemes that rely on cloud base parameters, the newly proposed algorithm can estimate all-day cloudy-sky SDLR using only cloud top parameters. This reduces the reliance on cloud base parameters, facilitating a broader application of the algorithm.

title: Cloud Energy Internet Based High Optimum Control of Residential ESS-PV Inverters in Local Power Systems
authors: Byungchul Kim, Eyad H. Abed
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Industry Applications
abstract: Alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) is effective for addressing optimal power flow convex optimization. However, ADMM significant drawback is absence of guaranteed convergence. Considering optimal power flow interactions resulting from the unstable voltage relationship among energy storage system-photovoltaic (ESS-PV) inverters, a steady state voltage security area (SSVSA) is established for these inverters. To assess the voltage security margin between the operational state and the security boundary, a voltage excursion indicator is proposed for processing optimal power flow within the local area. The proposed approach enables a fully guaranteed convergence and optimized power flow within a decentralized distributed energy management framework, systematically via multi-block ADMM handling of large-scale and distributed data via energy internet. This approach guaranteed convergence of optimal power flow via local consensus control by distributed ESS-PV systems with energy internet via all-to-all communication between centralized energy managers and inverters. Simulation results show the effectiveness of proposed approach.

title: A Sequential Doppler Offset (SDO) Method for Locating Targets Causing Azimuth Fractional Ambiguity in Spaceborne HRWS-SAR
authors: Yanyan Zhang, Akira Hirose, Ryo Natsuaki
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Advanced Land Observing Satellite-4 (ALOS-4) is a spaceborne high-resolution and wide-swath synthetic aperture radar (HRWS-SAR) that uses a variable pulse repetition interval (VPRI) technique to achieve continuous wide imaging. In some ALOS-4 images, azimuth fractional ambiguity caused by the VPRI is observed, and it differs from the usual integer ambiguity resulting from inter-channel errors in that it occurs at smaller intervals. In this paper, we propose a sequential Doppler offset (SDO) method for locating the original target (OT) that causes azimuth fractional ambiguity. First, the ratio of the interval of integer ambiguity to that of fractional ambiguity is obtained, which is used to generate SAR images with different Doppler center frequencies. Second, the coherence between the sum image of the generated images and the image with a zero Doppler center frequency is calculated. Third, some points with coherence greater than a threshold are selected based on the coherence. Finally, the final OT is obtained by detecting the filtered selected points. Some experiments are conducted based on ALOS-4 L1.2 data, and the results demonstrate that the method locates the OT accurately. In short, the proposed method provides a starting point for fractional ambiguity suppression in HRWS-SAR.

title: HCHO Sensor based on CuO@InO Hollow Spheres Film for Lung Cancer Detection: Exploration of Superior Performance in High Humidity Environments_supp1-3629123.docx
authors: Guodong Wang
abstract: Formaldehyde (HCHO), a key marker of lung cancer, is found in the exhaled breath of patients. Detecting low concentration HCHO (< 48 ppb) in highly relative humidity (RH) is crucial for HCHO gas sensors to be used in lung cancer detection. In this paper, we present a formaldehyde gas sensor based on CuO@In₂O₃ hollow sphere films, which were fabricated using a colloid template-assisted magnetron sputtering method. The characterization results indicate that the films are comprised of a single-layer, highly-ordered hollow-sphere structure, with CuO nanoparticles evenly distributed on the surface of In2O3 hollow sphere and forming a heterojunction with In2O3. The impact of CuO sputtering time on sensor performance was analyzed in detail. The sample with CuO sputtering time of 15 s exhibits the best performance. When the environment RH is 90%, 15-CuO@ In2O3 had a high response of 22.3 to 100 ppm HCHO and a 10 ppb detection limit. When the environmental RH increases from 10% to 90%, the response of sample 15-CuO@ In2O3 decreases with a decrease rate of about 27%, which is better than the decrease rate of sample In2O3 (46.9%). The sensors also have good selectivity and long-term stability, meeting the needs for detecting formaldehyde in lung cancer patients’ exhaled breath. Its superior performance is ascribed to its large specific surface area, the interface effect of CuO on the band structure, and the synergistic catalytic effect. This work offers a new approach for developing high performance diagnostic sensors.

title: DFD-Stereo: Dual-domain Feature Decoupling for Stereo Matching
authors: Zhisheng Zhu, Fuming Sun, Jing Sun, Haojie Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Accurate stereo matching under limited computational resources remains a central challenge in 3D perception tasks such as autonomous driving and robot navigation. Existing high-accuracy methods often rely on heavy architectures with significant memory and processing demands, while lightweight models typically compromise on feature expressiveness, leading to limited global understanding and detail loss. To bridge this gap, we propose DFD-Stereo, a lightweight and efficient stereo matching framework that delivers high-quality disparity estimation with reduced computational cost. The framework incorporates two key components: (1) a Decoupled Frequency-Spatial Learning (DFSL) module, which enables complementary spatial-frequency representation for enhanced global context modeling, and (2) a Stepwise Coupling Disparity Refinement (SCDR) module, which leverages multi-scale RGB-disparity fusion with Shuffle Attention to refine disparity predictions effectively. Experimental results across multiple benchmarks demonstrate that DFD-Stereo achieves superior accuracy with significantly improved efficiency, offering a promising solution for deployment in resource-constrained 3D vision systems.

title: Sensing with Mobile Devices through Radio SLAM: Models, Methods, Opportunities, and Challenges
authors: Yu Ge, Ossi Kaltiokallio, Elizaveta Rastorgueva-Foi, Musa Furkan Keskin, Hui Chen, Guillaume Jornod, Jukka Talvitie, Mikko Valkama, Frank Hofmann, Henk Wymeersch
abstract: The integration of sensing and communication (ISAC) is a cornerstone of 6G, enabling simultaneous environmental awareness and communication. This article explores radio simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) as a key ISAC approach, using radio signals for mapping and localization. We analyze radio SLAM across different frequency bands, discussing trade-offs in coverage, resolution, and hardware requirements. We also highlight opportunities for integration with sensing, positioning, and cooperative networks. The findings pave the way for standardized solutions in 6G applications such as autonomous systems and industrial robotics.

title:
Comparison of Nb
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Sn Insulation Systems with As Received and De-Sized Glass
authors: Steven T. Krave, Chris English
abstract: Epoxy cracking has been the main suspected contributor to training in Nb3Sn magnets for some time, as it leads to energy release and magnet quenching. Cracking in a superconducting composite can occur from several modes, and the likelihood of these modes is not well understood. Failure has been observed between insulation systems and the superconducting cable itself rather than within the cable or insulation. To target the behavior at the interface, samples have been fabricated and tested for Mode I fracture toughness in an adapted version of ASTM D5528. This work seeks to better characterize the fracture toughness of this interface to better understand how to model and design insulation systems.

title: Hierarchical Resource Optimization in Multi-UAV RIS-Assisted ISAC Networks with Uplink NOMA
authors: Laleh Eslami, Ghazaleh Kianfar, Jamshid Abouei, Arash Mohammadi
abstract: This paper investigates a novel spectral-efficient design for a multi-Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) system assisted by Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) within the emerging Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) framework. The proposed system leverages uplink Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) and RIS-enhanced multi-UAV collaboration to jointly serve mobile users and perform target sensing. A hierarchical double-timescale solution is introduced, combining an adaptive Affinity Propagation Clustering (APC) approach for long-term UAV deployment and user-target association, with a short-term iterative algorithm for optimizing user transmit power, UAV beamforming, and RIS phase shifts. To tackle the non-convex optimization problem, a solution is proposed, leveraging Lagrangian dual transform, fractional programming, and minorization methods. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, demonstrating significant improvements in both communication data rates and sensing information rates compared to existing benchmarks.

title: Fitts' List Revisited: An Empirical Study on Function Allocation in a Two-Agent Physical Human-Robot Collaborative Position/Force Task_supp1-3632607.mp4
authors: Nicky Mol
abstract: In this letter, we investigate whether classical function allocation—the principle of assigning tasks to either a human or a machine—holds for physical Human-Robot Collaboration, which is important for providing insights for Industry 5.0 to guide how to best augment rather than replace workers. This study empirically tests the applicability of Fitts' List within physical Human-Robot Collaboration, by conducting a user study (N=26, within-subject design) to evaluate four distinct allocations of position/force control between human and robot in an abstract blending task. We hypothesize that the function in which humans control the position achieves better performance and receives higher user ratings. When allocating position control to the human and force control to the robot, compared to the opposite case, we observed a significant improvement in preventing overblending. This was also perceived better in terms of physical demand and overall system acceptance, while participants experienced greater autonomy, more engagement and less frustration. An interesting insight was that the supervisory role (when the robot controls both position and force) was rated second best in terms of subjective acceptance. Another surprising insight was that if position control was delegated to the robot, the participants perceived much lower autonomy than when the force control was delegated to the robot. These findings empirically support applying Fitts' principles to static function allocation for physical collaboration, while also revealing important nuanced user experience trade-offs, particularly regarding perceived autonomy when delegating position control.

title: Deep Learning based Transceiver Design for Terahertz Communication
authors: Bo Che, Qi He, Zhi Chen, Tony Q. S. Quek
abstract: Terahertz communication is a pivotal candidate technology for future 6G networks. Deep learning (DL)-based transmission methods can utilize the real-time data to model channel statistics and device imperfections, presenting an effective manner to solve the modeling problems of non-ideality and channel in the terahertz band. However, there still exist several shortages hindering the development of DL-based terahertz communications, that is high system complexity, costly online retraining to fit changing non-ideality and channel conditions, and learned diagrams with high peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR). This paper proposes novel methods to address the above challenges. At first, a new regulated autoencoder (RAE) structure is proposed to fit changing conditions without online retraining. Secondly, a binary neural network (BNN) method is leveraged to reduce the receiver complexity and a lookup table based method to cut down the transmitter complexity. Lastly, a new maximum normalization method is proposed to reduce PAPR of the learned diagram. Extensive simulations are performed to verify the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

title: Bridging Competencies and Outcomes: An Empirical Study of Healthcare Quality Improvement Framework
authors: Xinyu Wei, Heng Xie, Xianghui Peng, Victor Prybutok
abstract: Healthcare organizations face increasing pressure to improve quality outcomes while managing limited resources effectively. While the National Association for Healthcare Quality (NAHQ) has developed a framework for healthcare quality competencies, the relationships between these competencies and organizational performance remain unclear. This study investigates how different quality competencies collectively and individually influence healthcare organizational performance through the lens of stakeholder theory. We integrate the NAHQ competency framework with the Baldrige Excellence Framework to develop and test a theoretical model linking quality competencies to organizational outcomes. Survey data from 152 healthcare professionals in the United States were analyzed using partial least squares structural equation modeling (PLS-SEM). Contrary to conventional expectations, the results show that neither quality leadership nor health data analytics directly improves organizational outcomes. Instead, their enabling effects work through a set of legitimacy-oriented competencies as essential mediators. Specifically, the findings reveal that the competency of quality leadership and integration significantly influences both health data analytics and legitimacy-oriented competencies. While health data analytics shows no direct effect on quality results, it significantly enhances legitimacy-oriented competencies, which in turn strongly influence quality outcomes. A series of robustness checks, including bias assessments for the survey method, construct reliability and validity checks, and control variable analysis based on healthcare professional experience levels, were conducted to validate the results. The findings suggest that healthcare organizations should focus on developing integrated quality capabilities rather than pursuing isolated improvements, as the impact of both leadership and analytics capabilities on organizational performance is primarily mediated through other operational competencies. This research contributes to healthcare quality management theory and provides practical guidance for healthcare leaders on effectively allocating resources across different competency domains.

title: Conditional Fourier neural operator for prediction of ultrafast nonlinear dynamics in optical fibers
authors: Yuanhang Zeng, Xiangyu Ma, Qingzhe Cui, Guangzhi Zhu, Xiao Zhu
abstract: Ultrafast nonlinear dynamics in optical fibers as the cornerstone of ultrashort laser pulse transmission and control is significant for the rapid development of mode-locked fiber lasers, fiber amplifiers, and fiber communication technologies. Solving the nonlinear Schrödinger equation using traditional numerical methods is very time-consuming, which greatly limits the design of experiments and real-time optimization. Deep learning technology has been introduced to predict ultrafast nonlinear dynamics in optical fibers and has achieved significant breakthroughs. However, existing deep learning-based methods mainly focus on the effective prediction of single scenarios. Moreover, the prediction accuracy of deep learning-based methods for ultrafast nonlinear dynamics in optical fibers needs to be further improved. In this study, a conditional Fourier neural operator (FNO) is proposed to predict the ultrafast nonlinear dynamics of multiple typical propagation scenarios in optical fibers accurately. A total of six independent tasks are completed by a single model of conditional FNO. The results show that the conditional FNO can predict the ultrafast nonlinear dynamics of different input pulses propagating under different fiber parameter settings with extremely high accuracy and strong generalization ability. In terms of accuracy metrics, the conditional FNO achieves state-of-the-art results. Strong generalization ability is the inherent advantage of neural operators. Our work provides an advanced and powerful generalized model for predicting ultrafast nonlinear dynamics, offering important insights into the widespread applications of deep learning in ultrafast optics.

title: Outage Analysis in Directional NTN Links With UAV Platform Instabilities
authors: Pawan Srivastava, M. P. R. Sai Kiran, Arun Kumar Singh
abstract: This paper analyzes the impact of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) platform instabilities on the outage probability of latency-sensitive directional point-to-point (P2P) links in non-terrestrial networks (NTNs, both UAV-to-gNB and UAV-to-UAV links). The proposed analytical formulation of the outage probability considers a realistic stochastic model for beam misalignment in the azimuth plane induced by platform instabilities under Rician fading channel conditions while using uniform linear array (ULA) antenna for transmit-receive beamforming. Importantly, we model the following misalignment cases resembling instabilities of various NTN UAV platforms: 1) misalignment varying at a rate faster than the channel fading and symbol duration, and 2) misalignment varying at a rate similar to or slower than the channel fading and symbol duration. Using the proposed analytical model, we show that a higher antenna order will not always result in performance gain in the presence of misalignment due to UAV platform instabilities. Specifically, when misalignment varies faster than the channel fading and symbol duration, achievable performance gain saturates beyond an antenna order of 16, irrespective of misalignment severity. Whereas, when misalignment varies at a rate similar to or slower than the channel fading and symbol duration, severe misalignment significantly degrades performance for antenna orders exceeding 8. These findings emphasize the importance of dynamic antenna array selection to optimize performance in NTNs.

title: Multi-stage Heterogeneous Decoupling Network for Lithium-ion Battery State-of-Health Estimation
authors: Qi Wang, Wentao Lyu, Qing Guo, Chengqun Wang, Zhijiang Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: As the core power source of new energy vehicles, the state-of-health (SOH) of lithium-ion batteries is directly related to the life and safety of vehicles. However, batteries have the characteristics of complex data structure, long cycle period, and high noise information, which leads to bottlenecks in the accuracy and robustness of existing SOH prediction methods. Therefore, this paper proposes a multi-stage heterogeneous decoupled network (MHD-Net) to improve the prediction performance of SOH. First, considering the complex data of SOH, this paper proposes a dynamic channel aware block (DCAB), which uses the “divide and conquer” idea and combines the dynamic gating mechanism to enhance the relationship perception ability between feature channels; secondly, a heterogeneous fusion network (HFN) is designed in the backbone part, which fully extracts deep information from longer sequences by constructing multi-granular feature subsequences and adopting a progressive fusion strategy; finally, an adaptive decoupled prediction head (ADPH) is proposed, which can highlight periodic features and suppress noise information in the frequency domain, thereby improving the prediction accuracy. To evaluate the performance of MHD-Net, we use NASA and CALCE datasets for experiments. The minimum errors of RMSE, MAE, and MAPE for the two datasets are 0.48%, 0.38%, 0.47%, and 1.06%, 0.69%, and 1.10%, respectively. The results show that MHD-Net outperforms other network models in terms of prediction accuracy and reliability.

title: RISA: Simulated Annealing-Based Algorithm for RIS Adjustment in Time-Varying Channels
authors: Ilya Burtakov, Aleksey Kureev, Evgeny Khorov
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS) is a promising technology for enhancing the performance of next-generation wireless systems. RIS operation requires accurate channel state information, which induces excessive pilot overhead due to the large number of RIS elements. To address this challenge, researchers propose blind beamforming algorithms that use Received Signal Reference Power (RSRP) obtained with various RIS configurations to determine the optimal RIS configuration. Most existing RSRP-based RIS adjustment algorithms assume quasi-static channels and are inefficient in time-varying and rich-scattering channels. This letter introduces blind beamforming algorithm called RISA, which is designed for time-varying channels. RISA adapts its parameters in real time using a Simulated Annealing approach to match the current channel state. We analyze the impact of RISA’s parameters and demonstrate its significant performance gains across mobility scenarios with high multipath fading. The obtained results show that RISA improves SNR up to 6 dB over state-of-the-art methods, even in low-SNR regimes. Also, we demonstrate its flexibility by applying it to the coverage enhancement problem of maximizing the minimum SNR.

title: The Role of Good Design in Fostering Autonomy for Individuals with Reduced Mobility in Beach Environments
authors: Ada Luz Rivera Picado, Cristal Denise Rivera Picado
publish: Proceedings of the 28th International Academic Mindtrek
abstract: The article consists on the development of a Good Product Design, whose objective is to allow an autonomous movement in the beach environment; in order to contribute to the enjoyment of the Population with Reduced Mobility. Good Design is described by three variables: Usability (accessible and safe), User Experience (evaluated by product satisfaction and versatility) and Emotional Design (universal aesthetics). These variables were assessed through ethnographic research, which included field observation, interviews, surveys, and user tests. Ultimately, the goal is to promote an inclusive culture and sustainable mobility by achieving good design that empowers users with autonomy and allows them to perform activities that contribute to their social and personal well-being in a beach setting.

title: Assessing Heating Electrification Trade-Offs Using Data-Driven Modelling for Future Grid Planning
authors: Luis Victor-Gallardo, Mariana Resener, Bradley Reinholz, Malcolm Metcalfe, Taco Niet
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Heating electrification with heat pumps is a key decarbonization strategy; however, its implementation in cold climates presents challenges to grid capacity. This paper presents a machine learning-driven framework to model neighbourhoodlevel heating demand using synthetic residential energy datasets, enabling scenario-based analysis for 2035 and 2050. We tested six machine learning models to estimate heating demand: linear regression, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, Support Vector Regression, and k -Nearest Neighbours. The Random Forest model, trained on a comprehensive feature set including temperature differential, building attributes, and HVAC characteristics, delivered the best predictive performance in terms of MAE and MSE. This model was used to simulate household-level demand and scale results to the neighbourhood level. Results indicate that replacing fuel-based heating with heat pumps reduces CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions by $25 \%$ to $73 \%$, although peak demand constraints remain critical, particularly in scenarios with electric backup heating. Cold-climate heat pumps reduce peak backup heating demand by only $5 \%$, while fuel-based backup heating peaks at $43 \%$ of the electric backup scenario, highlighting a trade-off between emissions reductions and peak demand. These findings underscore the importance of aligning electrification policies with grid decarbonization trajectories and implementing demand-side strategies, such as thermostat preheating, to mitigate peak loads. The proposed work provides a configuration-driven approach for potentially integrating detailed household-level heating models into broader planning efforts.

title: Research on Path Planning Algorithm in Autonomous Vehicle
authors: Shangjun Wang
abstract: The path planning of autonomous vehicle needs to take into account the adaptability of complex environment and real-time. This study proposes path planning strategies that integrate traditional methods and intelligent algorithms for both unstructured and structured road scenarios. In unstructured roads, a bidirectional artificial potential field method combined with a fifth order Bezier curve is constructed to improve the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm framework. By using bidirectional gravitational synergy to avoid local minima, high-order curve fitting and intelligent optimization are utilized to enhance path smoothness; Structured roads adopt a hierarchical planning architecture, with the global layer generating topological paths using a hybrid A* algorithm, and the local layer achieving dynamic obstacle avoidance through Frenet coordinate system and improved deep reinforcement learning (SQDQN). The algorithm has been validated for effectiveness in simulation and real vehicle testing, with a 9.5% reduction in path length and a 75% reduction in curvature fluctuation in unstructured scenarios; The decision delay in structured scenarios has been reduced from 180ms to 102ms, and the obstacle avoidance success rate has been increased to 97.6%. By utilizing CUDA parallel computing and model lightweight design, the algorithm is ensured to meet real-time requirements on the NVIDIA Jetson AGX Xavier platform. The research results provide theoretical support and technical solutions for the full scenario path planning of autonomous driving. In the future, we will further explore multimodal information fusion and multi-agent collaborative optimization to enhance the algorithm's generalization ability in complex traffic environments.

title: Data-Driven Irrigation Optimization: Comparative Study of ML and DL Models
authors: Rajesh Kumar Panda, Debasish Senapati, Subham Kumar Biswasaray, Rakesh Senapati, Rasmita Panigrahi, Neelamadhab Padhy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Effective management of water resources plays a vital role in achieving sustainable agricultural practices, particularly in the face of increasing climate variability and rising water scarcity. This paper examines the use of artificial intelligence approaches, particularly ML and DL for predicting agricultural water demands. A comprehensive evaluation was conducted using various models including traditional ML algorithms (Random Forest, XGBoost, SVR), deep learning architectures (CNN, RNN, LSTM) and hybrid approaches (LSTM+CNN, RF+XGB). Assessment criteria included statistical indicators like MAE, MSE, MAPE and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to determine how well each model predicted the output. Among all, the LSTM+CNN hybrid model emerged as the top performer, demonstrating superior accuracy and robustness. A multi-criteria decision-making approach using the TOPSIS method further confirmed its effectiveness. The findings highlight the potential of integrating hybrid models with smart irrigation systems to support precision agriculture and ensure sustainable water usage.

title: Methodology for assesment of induced voltage on human body in the vicinity of overhead electric lines
authors: Roman Radil, Ladislav Janousek, Milan Smetana, Maroš Šmondrk
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: The article focuses on non-thermal biological effects of the grid frequency electromagnetic field (EMF) generated in vicinity of high voltage electric overhead lines. More exactly, it deals with the assessment of voltages or charges induced on a surface of human’s body in the area near extra high voltage overhead power lines. This problematic is a part of a methodology for assessment of the intersections of cycling communications with high voltage electric overhead lines. Cyclists crossing high voltage electric overhead lines usually undergo the risk of electroshock, which might lead to the loss of concentration or acute paralysis and secondary serious injuries.

title: Power allocation Strategies in 5G: A Comparative Analysis of Water filling algorithm and Proximal Policy Optimization Algorithms
authors: Bavana B N, Sanjana Prasad, S Brahmatejo Krishna, Deepashree RajendraPrasad, Lokesh Nagesh
abstract: The advent of 5G networks has intensified the need for efficient power allocation strategies to maximize network performance while ensuring resource fairness. This work offers a comparative analysis of prominent algorithms such as: the classical Water-Filling Algorithm (WFA) and the modern Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm, a reinforcement learning-based approach. The comparison evaluates various metrics such as power allocation efficiency, throughput, and fairness achieved by each algorithm under diverse network conditions. Our study demonstrates the adaptability of the PPO algorithm in dynamic and complex environments, contrasting it with the deterministic nature of WFA. Results indicate that while WFA excels in scenarios with linear constraints, PPO outperforms in scenarios requiring higher flexibility and adaptability, achieving superior throughput and fairness. This detailed analysis provides valuable insight into the trade-offs and applicability of these algorithms, offering a robust framework for optimizing power allocation strategies in next-generation wireless communication networks. MATLAB is used to analyse this work.

title: Edge-Enabled Intelligent Framework for Cyber Threat Classification and Adaptive Anomaly Mitigation
authors: Priya Deshmukh, Varun Kowndinya Shankar Prasad, Venkataramani Kumar
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: With the evolution of advanced next-generation applications the need to meet the low-latency requirements is necessary. By processing the information at edge, it is feasible to expedite the response. However, the edge processing presents cybersecurity threats. Most of the existing works focus on resolving one aspect such as anomaly detection, or adaptive learning. However, through our work we propose an edge-enabled intelligent framework that offers three main functionalities namely threat level classification, response code prediction, and anomaly score prediction. The proposed monolithic framework is validated on open-source dataset with numerous features. Preliminary evaluation results highlight the significance of our framework.

title: Wearable Robotics for Post-Stroke Motor Rehabilitation: Challenges and Opportunities
authors: S. R. Kanetkar, Monali Gulhane, Sanjay Badjate, Nitin Rakesh, Sanket Karade, Akhil Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Rehabilitation after a stroke is very hard because getting back to normal brain functions is so complicated. Even though traditional methods work, they are often limited by the resources that are available and the physical demands they put on both patients and providers. Wearable robots have come up as a potential way to get around these problems. It offers new ways to speed up healing through personalized and automatic treatment. This essay looks at how wearing robots can be used to help people who have had a stroke recover their movement skills. It talks about both the problems that exist and the chances that could come up. Exoskeletons and soft robotic suits are examples of wearable robots that can help patients in ways that are perfectly tailored to their needs. Not only do these devices support muscles that aren't working as well, but they also help the brain change by requiring repeated movement practice, which is important for healing. Many problems keep them from being widely used, even though they have many benefits. Technical problems like the need for a lot of customization, the longevity of sensors and motors, and the ease of use of interfaces are big problems. Potential home-based recovery methods could cut down on healthcare costs by a lot and make life better for people who have had a stroke. Wearable robots could completely change the way stroke therapy is done, making it faster, easier to get to, and more tailored to each person's needs. This could be done by solving the problems listed and bringing together experts from different fields.

title: Improved CEEDMAN Based Signal Decomposition and PCNN with Transfer Learning for Motor Imagery Classification
authors: Sumanta Kumar Mandal, Ajay Kumar Jena
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Motor imagery classification is the process of identifying and differentiating various imagined movements that a patient is thinking about without performing them by analyzing brain signals. The traditional motor imagery classification model struggles to capture the signal with high-frequency noise, which leads to limited accurate signal decomposition. To overcome this limitation, this conference paper proposes a novel model for MI classification based on EEG signals by introducing an advanced CEEMDAN technique in the preprocessing step for signal decomposition, where a thresholding IMF and IMF selection process is used in this proposed system. Subsequently, the PCNN with transfer learning was employed for classification and training of the preprocessed signals to provide the final label predictions for motor imagery classification.

title: Efficient Nail Disease Diagnosis Using Deep Neural Networks for Predicting Abnormalities
authors: Nirupama Dora, Sachikanta Dash, Aparna Baboo, Soumya Ranjan Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: These research investigations recommended the introduction of a more efficient nail diagnosis technique basing itself on Deep neural networks in situations involving different abnormalities associated with nails. In this research we have used three models ResNet101, VGG16, and InceptionV3 for the prediction of nail disease from collected image datasets. The model finds prediction from three deep learning algorithms, and we compare their predictions and find that the ResNet101 model performed best. The nail disease dataset downloaded from Kaggle repository consists of classified image data divided into a training (80%) and a test (20%) set. The model extracts patterns from these images to detect 17 classes of nail diseases. The best model, ResNet101, got an accuracy of 99.94%, F1 score of 99.94%, precision of 99.94%, and recall of 99.94%. This model thus outperforms the individual models and traditional techniques. The performance was evaluated by observing the model performance. In the table below, the displayed accuracy numbers confirm the categorization of nail conditions, thus proving its utility. The recognition accuracy of models against each state of nails is provided in the tabular representation. These findings present evidence of the versatility of our proposed approach, which can deal with several nail-related problems having diverse characteristics. Further exploration and improvement of precision is the alternative mode of interpretation. Expanding dataset, model parameter amelioration, and addressing class imbalances were emphasized in the paper to improve model accuracy and robustness.

title: Challenges and First Lessons Learned for NIS2: Directive Implementation in Banking Sector
authors: Aleksandrs Ivaščevs, Artūrs Parfjonovs, Liene Augustāne, Raitis Eglītis, Jana Bikovska
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: This article reveals the initial challenges and lessons learned in the implementation of the NIS2 Directive within the banking sector in the European Union (EU), focusing on essential banks in Latvia: Swedbank, SEB, Citadele, and Luminor. To conduct the study a mixed methodology was applied, including literature review, comparative regulatory analysis, and an expert interview with an information security manager. Findings show that the NIS2 Directive introduces stricter requirements for cybersecurity, governance, and incident reporting across the EU. The study confirms the hypothesis that banking sector experiences fewer obstacles for NIS2 implementation because of alignment to the prior legislation frameworks in which the requirements overlap in comparison to NIS2 (e.g., DORA, GDPR, and PSD2). In addition, analysis points out that the fragmented transposition across EU member states generates compliance inconsistencies, operational inefficiencies, and resource constraints. Key obstacles include divergent reporting requirements, lack of harmonization with national laws (e.g., Latvia's National Cybersecurity Law), et al. To ensure effective and efficient compliance with NIS2 Directive few of the recommendations are establishing centralized oversight mechanism across the EU, enhancing bank and regulators collaboration within the process of national legislation development, and promoting industry-wide best practice sharing.

title: Explainable SCADA Hybrid IDS: Gaps and Hypothesis
authors: Heinrihs Kristians Skrodelis, Andrejs Romanovs, Arnis Lieknins
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: Industrial control systems (ICS) and supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) networks face increasing cyber risk as IT/OT convergence, remote access, and IIoT expand the attack surface. Signature-based intrusion detection systems (IDS) offer high precision on known threats but limited zero-day coverage, while anomaly-based IDS generalize to novel behaviors at the cost of false positives and opaque decisions. We hypothesize that an explainable hybrid IDS-running a signature engine in parallel with an ML-based anomaly detector, fusing alerts, and attaching operator-oriented explanations via explainable AI (XAI; e.g., SHAP values)-can improve operational usefulness. We outline a lightweight taxonomy, a reference pipeline, a qualitative gap matrix, and a concise evaluation plan designed to be testable on public ICS datasets. This positions a practical path toward higher coverage with actionable, human-centered alerts.

title: A Multimodal Graph-Based Machine Learning Approach for Depression Detection
authors: Michael S. Ramirez Campos, Alvaro D. Orjuela-Cañón
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: Depression is a common mental disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. Psychological assessments remain the most commonly used diagnostic tools. However, this reliance highlights the opportunity to explore alternative approaches based on the use of machine learning models. This study explores a multimodal graph-based machine learning approach that combines electroencephalography (EEG), voice signals, demographic information, and psychological test results to detect depression. Two sets of graphs were generated using different combinations of features. The graph2vec model was then employed to generate embeddings for each graph set. Seven machine learning algorithms were trained using the embeddings as feature vectors. The results demonstrate competitive performance compared to those reported in the literature, achieving F1-scores above 0.95 while relying on less complex methods. The methodology employed and the results obtained are promising, highlighting the potential of graph-based approaches for performing multimodal classification tasks. However, there are limitations mainly related to associated with computational resources that should be analyzed in greater detail.

title: A Review on p - Tribonacci Numbers, its Golden Ratios and Q - Type Matrices: Novel Approaches to Secure Encryption and Image Security
authors: Fatema Barbhaya, Shruti Rajdev, Gautam Hathiwala, Karri Sanjay Kumar
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: In the era of information technology, the concerns related to cybersecurity regarding the transmission of large volumes of data are of utmost priority. In this aspect, the necessity of a strong and more secure encryption-decryption algorithm would play a dominant role. For developing various types of encryption-decryption algorithms, which could be based on the key type, like symmetric and asymmetric, or their functionality, like block ciphers, or based on their mathematical foundations, like ECC (Elliptic Curve Cryptography) - based algorithms, the utility of a recurrence relation in developing an algorithm has proved to be extremely beneficial. Fibonacci sequence, Lucas sequence and Pell's sequence are some of the standard sequences that are defined by the recurrence relation, and several of their cryptographic applications have been proved to be computationally very efficient in terms of security and time complexity. In this paper, we do a review on the possible cryptographic applications, that can be developed based on the p - Tribonacci numbers which are a generalized form of Tribonacci numbers and its associated Q- type matrix, for enhancing the encryption algorithms which involves ECC and the matrix, for a fixed value of p, also how we can enhance the encryption algorithm for digital image security, particularly under the hyperchaotic system, to calibrate security and time complexity.

title: The Optimization for New Electricity System Innovation Demands Identification
authors: Rongjie Song, Chongfeng Yan, Haiyan Yuan, Huazhong Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: Innovation demands identification is crucial for power grid enterprises in managing technological innovation and resource planning. Traditional methods face challenges in capturing implicit demands and adapting to rapid external changes, such as policy shifts and technological advances. To address this, we propose a comprehensive framework for innovation and efficiency demand analysis, tailored to the dynamic needs of power grids. The system extracts innovation demands by building a keyword library and analyzing enterprise needs, focusing on future technological trends in core grid specialties. We also introduce a demand filtering framework and a GNN-based optimization method, incorporating external factors to enhance demand prioritization. This technical report supports lifecycle management of technological innovation, enabling grid operators to align with evolving market and policy trends for more sustainable and efficient grid operations.

title: The Basic Engagement Zone in 3-D
authors: Alexander W. Denton, Donald Kunz, Isaac E. Weintraub, Alexander Von Moll
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: This paper presents a three-dimensional extension of the Basic Engagement Zone (BEZ) as a spherically capped cone, representing a threat’s risk region for a fixed speed target aircraft. The threat is modeled as having a reachability region dictated by a sphere of fixed radius. The resulting three-dimensional BEZ shape at a fixed altitude is also analyzed, offering enhanced understanding for aircraft survivability.

title: Techno-Economic Feasibility and Analysis of Hybrid Renewable Energy Microgrids for a University Campus
authors: Salah S. Alharbi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This study investigates the technical, financial, and environmental feasibility of implementing a reliable and costeffective hybrid microgrid system at the Al-Baha University campus. The methodology of this research is to evaluate the renewable resources availability, economic viability, and environmental sustainability. Based on the real measured data of the site weather and load profile, various configurations of grid-connected with photovoltaics (PV), wind turbine (WT), and battery (BAT) storage systems are optimized and examined according to the net present cost (NPC) and levelized cost of energy (LCOE) aspects. Among these configurations, the PV/WT/Grid system obtains the optimal microgrid design with the least NPC of 25.5M${\$}$, lowest LCOE of $\mathbf{0. 0 5 6 7}$, and highest renewable fraction penetration of $\mathbf{7 3. 6 \%}$, offering no unmet load and $\mathbf{0 \%}$ capacity shortage. The findings reveal that the proposed hybrid microgrid system with PV and wind energies promotes the most feasible and economically beneficial design for university load demands, addressing the challenges of energy obstacles.

title: On Enhancing the Security Against Memory Disclosure Attacks
authors: Prokash Ghosh, Gaurav Kumar, Sohan Lal, Satyadev Ahlawat, Virendra Singh
abstract: Main memory is a critical component for storing computational data across various applications, including highly sensitive information such as banking transactions, encryption keys, and authentication credentials. However, memory systems are susceptible to side-channel attacks, making it imperative to implement effective countermeasures against unauthorized data extraction. Additionally, counterfeit memory controllers and memory devices pose a significant security risk, as they can facilitate data leakage even in the presence of conventional encryption mechanisms. Traditional security solutions, such as AES encryption integrated into memory controllers, provide strong cryptographic protection; however, they introduce substantial latency and area overhead. This paper presents a novel security countermeasure that ensures secure communication between the memory controller and the memory device by employing XOR-based encryption and decryption at both ends. The proposed technique remains secure even in the presence of unauthenticated memory components, preventing unauthorized data access. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves a high level of security (2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">512</sup>) while significantly reducing area overhead and incurring no additional access latency.

title: Machine Learning and IOT-Based Predictive Analytics for Smart Grid Load Balancing and Demand Forecasting
authors: K. Senthil Kumar, P. Dass
abstract: Optimizing load balancing within smart grids becomes increasingly challenging due to the growing energy demands and the adoption of renewable energy sources. The non-dynamic energy consumption patterns make it harder for traditional forecasting tools, including ARIMA and regression models, so advanced predictive analytics becomes necessary. A hybrid deep learning system that links XGBoost technology with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) functions as an effective approach to generate precise load forecasts. This model achieves better prediction results by combining historical energy measurement data with current weather variables and its learning algorithms, which adapt over time. The data verifies a prediction accuracy rate of 96.3% utilizing this model. The MAE reached 2.45 kW, and the RMSE reached 3.12 kW above other existing approaches. The model optimizes the performance of networks and enhances prediction accuracy for customer demands while controlling energy utilization. It aims at implementing reinforcement learning technology for developing adaptive grid control systems. The system creates essential groundwork for intelligent energy optimization to be used in smart grids of the next generation.

title: Tailored Voice Activation for Enhanced Accessibility
authors: S. Annapoorna, V. Indu, Bh Manushree, B. Venkatesh, B Rishitha, M Ratnapriya
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Speech recognition technology has revolutionized human-computer interaction by enabling seamless voice-based communication. Our work focuses on Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) and Natural Language Understanding (NLU) to improve transcription accuracy and multilingual accessibility. The system integrates dataset annotation, speech-to-text conversion, and transcription evaluation using state-of-the-art models. It supports data preprocessing, model training, and evaluation of transcriptions to ensure robustness and efficiency. Our proposed work leverages pre-trained models such as Whisper and XLM-R for high-quality speech processing across different languages and dialects. Additionally, it includes dataset management, common voice dataset processing, and a web-based interface for interaction. The implementation aims to enhance accessibility, improve speech recognition accuracy, and facilitate research in language processing. The system can be extended to various real-world applications such as voice assistants, automated transcription services, and multilingual communication platforms.

title: Steane and Iceberg Code Implementations on Toffoli Gates
authors: Colburn Riffel, Reece Robertson, Matthew Slodov, Peter Hendrickson
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: The capacity of current leading trapped-ion and superconducting quantum computers to perform Toffoli gates protected by the Steane [[7], [1], [3]] and Iceberg [[2m, 2m 2, 2]] codes was analyzed. The trapped-ion device achieved near−break-even fidelity under the Iceberg code, but the superconducting device failed to meaningfully complete the Toffoli gate under either code.

title: Early Diagnosis of Inter-Turn Faults in Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors During Start-Up Phase
authors: Yacine Maanani, Qingsong Wang, Kamal Al-Haddad, Aimen Acil Maanani
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The goal of this research is to identify and simulate inter-turn short circuit issues in permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM). For permanent magnet synchronous machines (PMSM), a catastrophic stator failure is one of the primary causes of motor failures, and it can swiftly develop into, early interturn short-circuit (ITSC) faults are among the most difficult and significant issues to identify. Nevertheless, this subject is underrepresented in the technical literature. When it comes to transitory analysis, this underrepresentation is much more important. However, with today’s computer capabilities, Combining the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) with the use of advanced timefrequency methods might close this gap. Short-Term Fourier Transform (STFT). To bridge this gap, this study closely examines the diagnosis of early-stage ITSC during PMSM start-up. The first part of the work alters the PMSM inter-turn short circuit fault, which results in the identification and thorough characterization of a family of ITSC-related harmonics that haven’t been previously discussed in the literature.
