title: Enhanced Machine Learning Techniques of PCOS Hormonal Prediction
authors: Vijaya Bharathi Manjeti, Sowmya Sri Gorrepati, Sai Srikar Machiraju, Rohita Gottumukkala, A Bhagavan Venkata Sri Sai Apuroop., S. Gopal Krishna Patro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: PCOS is a frequently occurring hormonal condition in females, characterized by disrupted ovarian function, often leading to irregular periods, excessive androgen levels, weight gain, acne, and fertility issues. Its development is influenced by factors such as hormonal imbalance, insulin resistance, genetics, inflammation, and lifestyle. In this study, machine learning techniques were applied to predict PCOS using the most relevant clinical, hormonal, and lifestyle features. Out of 41 available attributes, the top 18 effective features were selected based on their impact. The data was preprocessed through imputation, scaling, and class balancing using SMOTEENN. Various Bagging-based ensemble models—including SVM, KNN, Decision Tree, and Logistic Regression—were developed and evaluated. Among these, the Bagging + KNN model delivered the best performance with an accuracy of 97.36%, demonstrating its strong potential for early PCOS detection.

title: Optimization and Application of Intelligent City Algorithms Based on 5G Communication Technology
authors: Borong Xu
abstract: With the deep integration of urbanization and information technology, the demand for real-time communication and efficient decision-making in smart cities is becoming increasingly urgent. 5G communication technology, with its high bandwidth, low latency, and large connectivity characteristics, has become the core support for breaking the bottleneck of traditional urban management models. This study proposes a 5G based hierarchical collaborative architecture and algorithm optimization scheme to address the issues of insufficient collaborative efficiency, delayed real-time response, and complex heterogeneous resource scheduling in distributed systems in smart cities. The aim is to build an efficient and reliable urban intelligent management system. A distributed topology recognition algorithm has been developed, which utilizes static configuration and dynamic signaling diffusion mechanism to achieve real-time perception and update of urban infrastructure topology. The topology update delay is controlled within 50ms, and signaling overhead is reduced by 89%. Propose a cross layer collaborative resource scheduling algorithm that integrates reinforcement learning and edge caching technology, increasing system resource utilization by 38% and reducing emergency business bandwidth allocation latency to 19ms. Construct a three-level collaborative decision-making architecture of "end edge cloud", with edge node inference latency stable within 22ms and cloud model prediction error controlled at 3.2%, achieving an organic combination of local rapid response and global optimization. Experimental verification shows that this architecture is significantly better than traditional solutions in both simulation and field environments, with a 20.5% reduction in overall network energy consumption and a 63% increase in edge computing power utilization. It provides efficient solutions for scenarios such as vehicle road collaboration and smart energy. The research results have deepened the integration theory of 5G technology and smart cities, broken through the performance bottleneck of traditional centralized architecture, and provided a technical paradigm for the large-scale deployment of city level real-time systems. Future research will focus on optimizing robustness in extreme scenarios, privacy protection technologies for cross departmental data collaboration, and improving green communication energy efficiency, promoting the evolution of smart cities towards greater resilience and sustainability.

title: Hybrid FOC-DTC Controller for Optimized Speed and Torque Regulation of PMSM
authors: Austin Johns, Kumaravel S, Vishnu M
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel hybrid Field-Oriented Control (FOC)- Direct Torque Control (DTC) controller for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSM) to leverage the strengths of both strategies while mitigating their drawbacks. The hybrid controller dynamically switches between FOC and DTC based on real-time error which is a difference between reference and actual motor speeds, using a blending logic, ensuring adaptive control under varying operational conditions. Simulation studies are performed in MATLAB/Simulink ${ }^{\circledR}$, and performance analyses are conducted under different load torque and speed variation scenarios. Results show that the hybrid controller effectively combines the rapid dynamic response of DTC with the smooth and efficient steady-state control of FOC. Compared to the standalone FOC or DTC control, the proposed hybrid controller shows improved rise time, reduced torque and current overshoots, minimized current THD and torque ripple across transient and steadystate conditions. This research highlights the potential of hybrid control strategy for next-generation drives, especially in applications such as electric vehicles and industrial automation

title: A Reduced Component Triple-Gain Seven-Level Inverter for Fuel Cells: Design and Implementation
authors: Md Tariqul Islam, Xiaodong Liang, Md. Ahsanul Alam
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Renewable energy sources require the reduced component inverters for their reliable and efficient interface with power grids. This paper presents a single-source-based triplegained inverter designed for fuel cell energy conversion systems. It uses eleven switches, three capacitors, and four diodes to generate seven-level AC voltage with a total harmonic distortion (THD) of $\mathbf{1 2. 6 8 \%}$. Its total component count is less compared to the conventional neutral point clamped (NPC), and flying capacitor (FC) multilevel inverters. It features self-balancing of the capacitor voltage, improving the output voltage quality. A Proportional-Integral (PI) controlled dc-dc boost converter is utilized for the initial boost-up and regulation of fuel-cell generated low voltage. The feasibility of the proposed system is tested through simulations, followed by a lab-scale hardware prototype. Dynamic load testing confirms the suitability of the system for changing load environment.

title: Explainable Machine Learning for RSSI to Distance Conversion
authors: Achref Gadhgadhi, Yassine Hachaïchi, Hassen Zairi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative approach to Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI)-based distance estimation by integrating explainable machine learning techniques. The study introduces a novel regression model that enhances the accuracy and reliability of distance measurements while maintaining model interpretability. Experimental results using a dataset of RSSI measurements demonstrate the model’s effectiveness, achieving a high coefficient of determination ($R^{2}$) and low mean squared error (MSE). This research provides a valuable contribution to the field of indoor localization, offering a cost-effective and robust solution for various applications such as navigation, asset tracking, and proximity detection.

title: Performance Evaluation of Flan-T5 in CGLA based Accelerators
authors: Yu Eto, Takuto Ando, Yasuhiko Nakashima
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) impose significant computational and energy demands, posing challenges for deployment on edge devices. To address this, we explore the feasibility of executing Flan-T5 an instruction tuned encoder decoder LLM on IMAX3, an in memory accelerator based on a Coarse Grained Linear Array (CGLA). By leveraging existing custom instructions and hardware kernels originally developed for LLaMA v2 models, Flan-T5 inference was successfully achieved on IMAX3 without requiring any modification to the hardware instruction set or the high level inference workflow.To the best of our knowledge, this is the first implementation of Flan-T5 on a CGLA based accelerator. Although IMAX3 does not currently outperform CPUs or GPUs in execution speed or power efficiency, our analysis identifies critical system level bottlenecks particularly in host accelerator coordination and memory bandwidth that limit scalability. These findings highlight the architectural generality of quantized kernel designs across structurally distinct LLMs and provide a valuable foundation for future work on energy efficient LLM deployment using reconfigurable accelerators.

title: Your network doesn't end at the NIC
authors: Raj Joshi, Saksham Agarwal, ChonLam Lao, Minlan Yu
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: Modern ML workloads increasingly rely on direct communication between host devices—such as GPUs, NVMe SSDs, and DRAM—spanning intra-host and inter-host networks. However, today's intra-host network lacks hardware-level primitives for routing across heterogeneous interconnects, hindering efficient use of alternative paths and leading to sub-optimal performance under failures or congestion. Furthermore, the inter-host network treats the NIC as the endpoint, with intra-host interconnects like PCIe running oblivious to inter-host network protocols. This prevents leveraging multiple paths for communication between host devices across different servers. To address these limitations, we propose expanding the datacenter network layer to encompass the intra-host network, making intra-host devices first-class network endpoints. Our scheme envisions hardware-level routing and forwarding across multiple intra-host interconnects and makes intra-host devices visible to the inter-host network. This unified approach provides a principled foundation for robust, efficient peer-to-peer communication between storage and compute hardware devices in AI datacenters.

title: Web3Agent: Automating On-Chain Operations via Natural Language Interfaces
authors: Sizheng Fan, Tian Min
abstract: Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have enabled the emergence of intelligent agents capable of performing complex multi-step tasks across various domains. In parallel, the growth of Web3 has introduced a decentralized web infrastructure, yet remains largely inaccessible to non-technical users due to operational complexity, fragmented information, and security risks. In this paper, we present Web3Agent, an AI agent system that integrates LLM-based interaction with blockchain environments to enable language-driven on-chain operations. Web3Agent automatically decomposes user instructions into structured workflows, dynamically queries blockchain data and APIs, and performs multi-step operations such as asset transfers, token swaps, and smart contract execution. Web3Agent incorporates real-time inspection, error handling, and interaction transparency across its operation log, and flow visualization components. We evaluate the system and perform ablation study with customized dataset in a simulated environment, demonstrating its feasibility in orchestrating complex Web3 tasks and highlighting implications for agent-based abstraction in decentralized systems.

title: Flow-Aided Flight Through Dynamic Clutters From Point to Motion_supp1-3632608.mp4
authors: Peng Lu
abstract: Challenges in traversing dynamic clutters lie mainly in the efficient perception of the environmental dynamics and the generation of evasive behaviors considering obstacle movement. Previous solutions have made progress in explicitly modeling the dynamic obstacle motion for avoidance, but this key dependency of decision-making is time-consuming and unreliable in highly dynamic scenarios with occlusions. On the contrary, without introducing object detection, tracking, and prediction, we empower the reinforcement learning (RL) with single LiDAR sensing to realize an autonomous flight system directly from point to motion. For exteroception, a depth sensing distance map achieving fixed-shape, low-resolution, and detail-safe is encoded from raw point clouds, and an environment change sensing point flow is adopted as motion features extracted from multi-frame observations. These two are integrated into a lightweight and easy-to-learn representation of complex dynamic environments. For action generation, the behavior of avoiding dynamic threats in advance is implicitly driven by the proposed change-aware sensing representation, where the policy optimization is indicated by the relative motion modulated distance field. With the deployment-friendly sensing simulation and dynamics model-free acceleration control, the proposed system shows a superior success rate and adaptability to alternatives, and the policy derived from the simulator can drive a real-world quadrotor with safe maneuvers.

title:

authors: Mengdan Chen, Wenjie Li, Peng Wan, Tao He, Shulin Sha, Yun Wei, Fazheng Zhang, Zhipeng Sun, Daning Shi, Caixia Kan, Mingming Jiang
abstract: Machine vision in automatic obstacle avoidance systems must be capable of precisely detecting circumstances, which necessitates the use of photodetectors with multi-signal reception capabilities, high sensitivity, and rapid reaction. However, the current method uses avalanche diodes or liars, which have a limited response wavelength range and high consumption, making it difficult to deal with complicated situations. Herein, we demonstrate self-powered broadband organic-inorganic hybrid photodetectors (OIHPDs) consisting of MXene@PEDOT:PSS hybrid organic film, Sb<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Se<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> crystal, and n-type GaAs wafer. Due to the high crystalline quality of Sb<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>Se<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> and the high mobility of the organic layer and suitable band structure, the OIHPD achieves broadband response spectra up to 1060 nm with the highest responsivity of 63 mA/W at 940 nm and a fast rise/fall time of 260/250 μs at zero bias. Encouragingly, multi-band and high-precision automatic obstacle avoidance is achieved by employing the OIHPD as the opticalelectric transducer into a driving system. This research demonstrates that state-of-the-art broadband OIHPDs can hasten the transfer of photodetector applications from the lab to the intelligent driving industry.

title: MEIO-Net: A Motion-Aware Early-Exit Inertial Odometry Network for Efficient Pedestrian Dead Reckoning (PDR)
authors: Xuehang Sun, You Li, Yan Wang, Hongji Yan, Xuanxuan Zhang, Sikang Liu, Xueli Guo, Zhichao Wen
abstract: In various pedestrian motion scenarios, data-driven pedestrian dead reckoning (PDR) methods have demonstrated strong localization performance, significantly enhancing system adaptability and robustness. However, most existing deep learning models have high computational costs. This makes them difficult to deploy on energy-constrained mobile devices for long-term use. Current lightweight PDR networks adopt a single-input-single-output structure. Although effective in complex dynamics, this design becomes redundant in low-dynamic conditions such as static or slow walking. To address this challenge, we propose a lightweight network architecture named Motion-aware Early-exit Inertial Odometry Network (MEIO-Net). The model adopts a multi-exit design and incorporates a dedicated training scheme. Displacement covariance is used to assess motion difficulty. An early exit mechanism is then introduced to adaptively adjust the inference depth based on dynamic complexity. With a slight improvement in accuracy, MEIO-Net significantly reduces computational cost across multiple datasets. In the self-collected data set, it achieves a 48.9% reduction in FLOPs compared to state-of-the-art lightweight models. In typical simple pedestrian motion scenarios, the computational cost of the proposed model is reduced by 50.5%–80.5%. Ablation studies further confirm that MEIO-Net can flexibly terminate inference according to the intensity of the pedestrian motion. These results demonstrate its strong generalizability and practical potential for real-world deployment. Code and dataset are available at: https://github.com/SunXuehang/MEIO-Net.git.

title: Human Radar Cross Section Measurements in a Bio-Radar Scenario using a 5.8 GHz Continuous-Wave Radar
authors: Beatriz Soares, Álvaro Frazão, Susana Brás, Daniel Albuquerque, Ming Shen, Pedro Pinho
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Bio-Radar (BR) systems measure physiological activity by using the micro-Doppler effect to detect signal reflections from the human body. The quality of the received signal is influenced by several factors, most notably the Radar Cross Section (RCS) of the subject, which becomes especially complex in close-proximity conditions. To optimize BR system performance, this paper investigates the radio channel propagation in short-range conditions, focusing on RCS variations at close distances. The study was conducted using a Continuous-Wave (CW) radar system operating at 5.8 GHz, with measurements taken in an anechoic chamber. Ten human subjects with varying characteristics were analyzed. The findings demonstrate that RCS fluctuates with distance, exhibiting oscillatory behavior at short-range distances, with values ranging between −45 dBsm and −20 dBsm. They also reveal a correlation between RCS measurements and the extraction of vital signs, identifying specific conditions under which vital sign detection is significantly compromised. Additionally, the data indicate that male subjects tend to have higher RCS values than female subjects.

title: Cross-Modal Information Aggregation Network With Feature Enhancement for Pansharpening
authors: Lihua Jian, Yuanyuan Chen, Gemine Vivone, Yuxuan Zheng
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Pansharpening is a vital process that aims to obtain high-resolution multispectral (HRMS) images by fusing panchromatic (PAN) and low-resolution multispectral (LRMS) images. With the advancement of deep learning (DL), data-driven pansharpening methods have been developed extensively, demonstrating superior performance compared to traditional approaches. However, most current DL-based studies still struggle to effectively preserve spectral properties and adequately capture spatial details, and fail to comprehensively integrate complementary information across modalities, leading to suboptimal results. To address these challenges, we propose an innovative cross-modal information aggregation network (CMIAN) with feature enhancement for pansharpening. The CMIAN comprises three core components: a feature enhancement (FE) module that enhances feature representation of both modalities through a simplify-and-enhance approach, a cross-modal feature aggregation (CMFA) module that aggregates intra-modal features based on the characteristic differences between MS and PAN images, and a cross-modal information reconstruction (CMIR) module that adaptively balances large-scale features and local details of PAN images, and performs image reconstruction to yield desirable pansharpening outcomes. Experiments on the QuickBird, WorldView-2, and WorldView-3 datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of our proposed CMIAN. On the WorldView-3 dataset, for instance, our CMIAN outperforms the second-best method by 5.95% in MPSNR and 9.41% in SAM.

title: Multi-weather GPR Image Registration and Localization Based on Adaptive Hyperbolic Receptive Fields
authors: Beizhen Bi, Liang Shen, Yuwei Chen, Pengyu Zhang, Xiaotao Huang, Tian Jin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Ground-penetrating radar (GPR) , as a sensor for mapping and localizing subsurface features, has gained significant attention in robotic localization for complex environments. However, varying weather conditions change the subsurface dielectric constant, which weakens the registration correlation between real-time images and maps, thereby compromising localization stability. We design an image registration framework for localizing ground penetrating radar (LGPR) in multi-weather. Specifically, we first propose an adaptive hyperbolic receptive field that aims to significantly enhance the robust features in the GPR images, while improving both discrimination capability in map and reliability for image registration. Then, an image alignment module is introduced to eliminate the time-delay blurring problem caused by the variation of dielectric constant under multi-weather conditions. The proposed method was evaluated on three distinct datasets (simulated, publicly available, and self-constructed), demonstrating significant improvements in registration and localization performance. The average correlation coefficient on simulated data achieved a enhancement from 0.3796 to 0.7406 compared with baseline, validating the effectiveness of feature enhancement. Furthermore, measured datasets exhibited 15% higher average registration and localization accuracy than baseline. These results demonstrate that the method provides a reliable guarantee for the stable operation of LGPR systems in complex environments. The datasets will be released at: https://github.com/Eazin-bz/dataset_AHFT.git.

title: EIRM-RL: Epistemic Integrity Risk Monitoring Inspired Safe Reinforcement Learning for Trustworthy Autonomous Navigation
authors: Yuanyuan Zhang, Yingying Wang, Weisong Wen
abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has shown great potential for autonomous navigation within internet of things (IoT) environments, where various and changing uncertainties pose significant challenges for safe, real-world deployment. Existing safe RL methods typically employ heuristic constraints while neglecting the combined impact of multiple uncertainty sources, reducing robustness and interpretability. Drawing on concepts from global navigation satellite system (GNSS) integrity monitoring, this paper proposes an epistemic integrity risk monitoring reinforcement learning (EIRM-RL) framework to enable trustworthy autonomous navigation under uncertainty. EIRM-RL extends the GNSS protection level concept to RL by utilizing an assembled world model that quantifies and incorporates sensor noise, systematic bias, and epistemic uncertainty. Furthermore, the framework continuously monitors a dynamic epistemic risk probability, which is incorporated into policy optimization as an adaptive safety constraint via Lagrangian duality. This method enables the agent to proactively avoid hazards and effectively balance safety and performance, even in highly uncertain environments. Extensive experiments demonstrate that EIRM-RL achieves superior success rates, collision avoidance, and robustness compared to state-of-the-art safe RL methods, while maintaining high efficiency.

title: Experimental validation of slot Effects in 2D Axial Flux motors via Conformal Mapping
authors: Giovanni Landi, Luca Sani, Antonino Musolino
abstract: This paper presents an analytical and experimental investigation of the magnetic field distribution in the air gap of a single-stator, single-rotor axial flux permanent magnet (AFPM) machine under no-load conditions. To simplify the problem, the model is rectified using quasi-3D modeling techniques at the machine’s mean radius. A quasi-static analytical Fourier based formulation is developed to describe the magnetic field produced by a classical North-South permanent magnet array. In addition, the influence of stator slotting on the air-gap field waveform is assessed through the Schwarz–Christoffel conformal transformation, enabling an accurate representation of slot-induced distortions. The resulting methodology provides a clear analytical framework for evaluating and quantifying harmonic distortion in the field distribution due to geometric discontinuities. To validate the model, experimental measurements are performed using a custom-designed four-degree-of-freedom scanning test bench equipped with a three-axial Hall-effect sensor capable of capturing detailed field profiles across the air gap. The comparison between analytical results, finite element method (FEM) simulations and experimental results demonstrates good agreement, confirming the reliability of the proposed approach for AFPM machines.

title: Multimode Fiber Imaging with Bit-plane Encoding: Improving Fidelity and Speed
authors: Mengyao Zhang, Wei Jin, Jinhua Mou, Shanshan Li, Jiaxing Gao, Cunkai Lou, Yifan Qin, He Zhang, Yu Zhang, Zhihai Liu, Chenxu Wu
abstract: High-performance natural scene image transmission via multimode fiber (MMF) represents a substantial challenge. Conventional MMF gray imaging system relies on the visual persistence phenomenon of the digital micromirror device (DMD), causing redundant capture time and loss of bit-depth information. We introduce bit-plane encoding to extract eight speckles from gray targets at different bit-planes, thereby constructing a speckle cube to enrich the captured information. Our self-designed HySpeckNet model enhances the connections among high-dimensional features within speckle cubes. As a result, the average structural similarity index (SSIM) on the ImageNet dataset improves from 0.586 to 0.617, representing a 5.3% increase compared to traditional methods. Notably, gray image reconstruction can be approximately achieved using only two high-order speckles, resulting in a transmission speed about 11.76 times faster than traditional gray image restoration method. Our research sets the stage for the practical transmission of complex image information via MMFs.

title: Res-UNet-GRU: A Data-Driven Near-Field Sensing Approach in ISAC-based Low-Altitude Networks
authors: Hongjia Huang, Shiyao Zhang, Weijie Yuan, Zhongbin Wang, Shuqiang Xia, Tony Q. S. Quek, Hyundong Shin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: The rise of the low-altitude network (LAN) has driven the demand for situational awareness in dynamic environments, where integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) serves as a key enabler. To meet these requirements, ISAC systems increasingly employ high-frequency carriers and large-scale antenna arrays, thereby making near-field propagation effects non-negligible. However, existing studies have primarily focused on static near-field targets, which limits their applicability in dynamic LANs. In response to this limitation, we investigate a near-field ISAC system in which a ground-based ISAC transceiver simultaneously communicates with multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and exploits their signal echoes for joint sensing. Specifically, we aim to estimate the angle of arrival (AoA), distance, and velocity of each UAV to support mobility-aware operations. Given the substantial number of parameters to be estimated, conventional methods such as maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) or matched filtering incur prohibitive computational costs. To address this issue, we propose Res-UNet-GRU, a neural network that integrates a residual UNet (Res-UNet) with a gated recurrent unit (GRU) to facilitate the aggregate estimation of location and motion parameters. The proposed network can estimate the UAV state without requiring exhaustive search or complex optimization, making it well-suited for high-mobility LANs and providing a foundational perception layer for future artificial general intelligence (AGI)-driven autonomous systems. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed Res-UNet-GRU consistently achieves the lowest mean squared error (MSE) in estimating AoA, distance, and velocity parameters across all signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) levels compared to benchmark deep learning (DL)-based estimators.

title: An Explainable Machine Learning Framework for IOPS Degradation Modeling and Slot-level HDD Layout Optimization
authors: Yi-Ju Liao, Jen-Yuan Chang
abstract: This study presents an interpretable machine learning framework for diagnosing and mitigating input/output operations per second (IOPS) degradation in hard disk drives (HDDs) through slot-aware placement optimization. The framework integrates decision trees (DT), which provide model transparency, with neural networks capable of capturing nonlinear patterns, thereby enabling the identification of complex interactions between HDD performance and structural slot characteristics. A series of 36 slot-reassignment experiments (12 slots × 3 vendors × 1 trial each), conducted across 12 physical positions and involving three HDD vendors (Seagate, HGST, and WD), demonstrate consistent IOPS recovery, achieving an average maximum improvement of 23.3 % without hardware modification. The proposed approach facilitates proactive, data-driven drive placement planning and presents a scalable solution for improving system reliability and sustainability in large-scale data center environments.

title: Digital Twin-Based Virtual Sensing for Real-Time Process Monitoring of Marine Reciprocating Natural Gas Compressor Packages
authors: Xiang Li, Xiaoying Zhang, Jiatong Ling, Jian Zhou, Hang Zhang
abstract: Marine reciprocating compressor packages are critical in offshore oil and gas production but face inherent challenges for process monitoring due to explosion-proof requirements and limited onboard sensing. Many key process variables, such as flow rates and stage-wise efficiencies, remain unmeasured in practice, hindering comprehensive and accurate real-time monitoring. This study proposes a digital twin-based virtual sensing approach that integrates process mechanism modeling with real-time data streams to infer unmeasured variables from limited measurements and reconstruct package-level operating states. A full package-level process mechanism model was established in HYSYS, incorporating compression, heat exchange, and recycle control modules, and further generalized through a cascaded-stage modeling strategy that supports scalable deployment across packages with different configurations. A DT framework was constructed to couple the model with real-time sensor inputs, enabling continuous model updating, virtual-physical synchronization, and visualization through a service platform. Validation on a two-stage marine compressor package shows that predicted data closely match operating and design values, with MAPE typically <2% for compressor metrics, heat exchanger water flow MAPE≈1.4–1.5%, and recycle flow MAPE≈9.6%. Additional testing on a small-scale compressor package confirms the scalability of the cascaded-stage modeling approach and the DT system, maintaining flow-prediction errors within 5% while requiring only minimal interface configuration and parameter adjustment for direct deployment across packages. These results indicate that the proposed method can effectively extend monitoring capability beyond limited sensor coverage, providing a practical pathway for DT-enabled monitoring and supervisory optimization of marine reciprocating compressor packages.

title: Uncovering the Dark Patterns of Phishing Emails: An Eye-Tracking Analysis
authors: Seeung Oh, Yebin Bae, Isaiah Abraham Thompson, Youngjae Im
abstract: Phishing emails are a representative form of dark patterns that visually deceive users and exploit psychological vulnerabilities. This study employed eye-tracking to empirically examine which features in phishing emails are most frequently overlooked. Two commonly encountered phishing categories—emails requiring immediate user action and those prompting account registration—were tested using prototypes modeled after Netflix and Adobe. Each email contained six widely recognized deceptive cues: fake sender address, generic greeting, urgent language, fake hyperlink, brand imitation, and false source assumption. Among these, brand imitation and urgent language received the least visual attention. These cues showed significantly lower fixation duration, fixation count, and revisit count. Paired t-tests revealed that these two cues were statistically less attended than the others (p < .001). Survey responses and heatmaps further confirmed the low detection rates for brand imitation and urgency cues. The findings suggest that visual trust cues (e.g., brand logos) and urgency-based persuasion techniques are particularly effective at bypassing user scrutiny. These results underscore critical perceptual blind spots and highlight the need for improved training and detection systems that incorporate human-computer interaction (HCI) perspectives, addressing subtle visual and psychological manipulation strategies beyond conventional technical indicators.

title: Enhancing Agricultural Decision Making with an AI-Powered Crop Recommendation Engine
authors: Sobhana Behera, Shubhasri Pradhan, N. Toyaad Kumar Reddy, Brojo Kishore Mishra, Manas Ranjan Patra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The agricultural sector faces growing challenges in optimizing crop selection due to fluctuating climatic conditions, soil variability, and limited access to expert agronomic guidance. This paper presents an AI-powered crop recommendation engine designed to assist farmers and policymakers in making data-driven decisions tailored to local environmental conditions. The suggested system makes use of a collaborative machine learning technique that combines Random Forest, XGBoost, and support vector machine (SVM) classifiers to forecast the best crops based on input characteristics like rainfall, temperature, humidity, pH, nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium content. A soft voting mechanism combines predictions from the individual models to improve accuracy and robustness. The system is further enhanced with a location-aware weather integration layer that dynamically fetches environmental parameters based on the user's geographic coordinates via a RESTful API interface. Extensive experimentation was conducted using a benchmark agricultural dataset, and the ensemble model achieved an accuracy of 98.5%, outperforming individual classifiers. The model is encapsulated within a Flask-based API, enabling real-time deployment for web and mobile applications. Results demonstrate that the proposed system offers high precision and reliability, making it a practical tool for precision agriculture. By providing farmers with intelligent crop recommendations, the engine aims to enhance yield potential, resource efficiency, and overall agricultural sustainability.

title: Efficient Interpolation Techniques and Realization Structures for Continuously Variable Bandwidth Filters
authors: T C Jayasree, T Bindima, Avya Vijayan, K P Navya, M K Mehnas, K Sravana
abstract: Arbitrary-bandwidth digital filters are essential in a wide range of applications in signal processing. This paper presents a comparative study of four low-complexity implementation structures for continuously variable bandwidth finite impulse response filters, utilizing two widely used interpolation methods, such as Lagrange interpolation and Hermite interpolation. The fractional delay filters (FDFs) designed using each of the interpolation methods are evaluated for their performance in realizing continuously variable bandwidth filters (CVBFs). The hardware utilization results obtained by synthesizing the different structures on a Kintex-7 FPGA device establish the fact that the CVBF involving the FDF designed using Hermite interpolation method and realized using Newton structure provides the lowest implementation complexity against slight performance degradation, compared to other design methods and realization approaches. The CVBF, designed using Lagrange interpolation, and realized using the Farrow structure, provides the best performance but at the cost of increased hardware utilization.

title: Agri-Detect: A Transfer Learning Framework for Scalable Disease Diagnosis in Staple Crops
authors: Sangita Mondal, Saini Saha, Sudipta Dinda, Roshan Kumar, Nabanita Das, Bikash Sadhukhan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Plant diseases pose a significant threat to global food security, causing substantial yield losses and economic instability. Traditional detection methods, which rely on manual inspection, are labor intensive, time consuming, and ineffective for large-scale monitoring. This study addresses these challenges by integrating deep learning with drone-based multispectral imaging to develop a scalable, real-time crop disease detection system. Three pretrained CNNsInceptionV3, MobileNetV2, and VGG16-were fine-tuned using a hybrid dataset of drone-captured and publicly available images of rice, wheat, and maize. InceptionV3 emerged as the top performer, achieving accuracies of $96-99 \%$ across crops and excelling in distinguishing subtle disease patterns through multiscale feature extraction. MobileNetV2 offered a favorable speed-accuracy trade-off ($\mathbf{9 6 - 9 8 \%}$ accuracy), which is ideal for resource-constrained environments, whereas VGG16 lagged due to its rigidity in handling field variability. The optimized models were deployed in Agri-Detect, a Flask-based web application enabling farmers to upload images for instantaneous disease diagnosis. Case studies on Ethiopian wheat farms validated the system’s adaptability, achieving $\mathbf{9 9. 3 \%}$ accuracy for stripe rust. This research bridges AI innovation with agricultural practices, offering a proactive, farmer-centric solution to mitigate crop losses.

title: Classification of Path Planning Algorithms for Autonomous Mobile Robot Navigation In Dynamic and Unknown Environments
authors: Syrine Akermi, Helmi Abrougui, Khaled Nouri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Most of the research now is focused on how to find the optimal path and navigate through dynamic environments. The purpose of this paper is to review a classification of path planning algorithms for autonomous mobile robot navigation in dynamic and unknown environments. The classification shows that we can consider some properties according to the type of environment, algorithm, and completeness: whether it is static or dynamic, local or global, and classic or heuristic. Also, we introduced relevant representative references explaining the navigation of the mobile robot in different cases, citing some of the most used path planning algorithms that show interesting and robust results to find the optimal solutions.

title: Analysis of Factors Influencing Used Car Prices Based on Regression Model
authors: Pratap Kumar Chamupaty, Prasant Kumar Pattnaik, Biswajit Das
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: This research paper is trying to analyze key factors influencing variations in used car prices by employing multiple linear regression models. It uses data exploration and multiple linear regression analysis on 1000 random samples over the period 2020–24 and four most important variables from Kaggle website for further study. These factors includes age, distance covered or mileage, brand category and seller types. On study we have found that the brand category, age and distance covered have significant impact over the prices of used car whereas the seller type has least impact. It is expected that these findings are quite helpful to the buyers for having a more informed selections and to the car dealers in crafting pricing strategy and managing inventory levels. The findings of this research will be helpful in exploring more factors those have an impact over pricing of used cars and able to refine the existing model for better use of buyers and sellers.

title: Stealthy Virtual Channel Blocking: A Hardware Trojan Attack on NoC in Tiled Chip Multicore Processors
authors: Josna Philomina, Rekha K James, Daleesha M Vishwanathan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Tiled Chip Multicore Processors (TCMPs) rely on Network on Chip (NoC) architectures for efficient intercore communication, with Virtual Channels (VCs) playing a vital role in managing congestion and optimizing data flow. This paper presents a novel Hardware Trojan (HT) that subtly degrades system performance by tampering with the credit-based flow control mechanism. The impact of HT is evaluated using both synthetic traffic and real application benchmarks under varying attack probabilities. Experimental results show that in synthetic traffic, HT can increase packet latency by 25% and reduce throughput by 12%. When evaluated with real benchmarks, the HT causes a 20% increase in packet latency, a 29% reduction in throughput, and a 20% drop in Instructions Per Cycle (IPC), demonstrating substantial performance degradation. These findings show that even minor alteration of credit signals can cause major performance issues, stressing the need for strong hardwarelevel security in NoC systems.

title: DeepRetina: An Automated Framework for Diagnosing Retinal Pathologies Using Optical Coherence Tomography and Deep Learning
authors: D Anil Kumar, Chandra Mohan Rakoti, Saroj Kumar, Sudheer Babu Punuri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The increasing prevalence of retinal diseases ne-cessitates accurate and automated diagnostic tools to support clinical decision-making. This study introduces DeepRetina, a fine-tuned InceptionV3-based deep learning model, designed to classify Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) images into four categories: Normal, Choroidal Neovascularization (CNV), Dia-betic Macular Edema (DME), and Drusen. DeepRetina enhances the standard InceptionV3 architecture by incorporating three pairs of fully connected layers with ReLU activation, batch normalization, and dropout to refine feature representation and improve classification accuracy. The model was validated on the OCT19 dataset, achieving a remarkable classification accuracy of 99.76%, highlighting its potential as a reliable diagnostic assistant. By automating the analysis of OCT images, DeepRetina reduces clinicians' workload, facilitates early detection, and minimizes the risk of vision loss for patients. This approach underscores the efficacy of advanced deep learning techniques in revolutionizing retinal disease diagnosis.

title: Predictive Machine Learning Approaches for Microbial Evolution
authors: Livpreet Kaur, Paras Jain, Vishan Kumar Gupta, Anupriya, Harvinder Singh, Jaishree Meena
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Microbial evolution is a complex process which is driven by different types of mechanisms, like genetic mutations, horizontal gene transfer, mobile genetic elements like plasmids and phages, gene duplication and amplification, insertion sequences and transposable elements, coevolution within microbial communities, and bacterial parallel evolution. The rapid mutation rates of microbes are both challenging and opportunistic, particularly in the fields of medicine and biotechnology. To combat these mutation rates, predicting microbial evolution has become critical. Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) have emerged as powerful tools that can be used to study large genomic datasets, identify the patterns of evolution, and predict mutations. Adaptive Laboratory Evolution (ALE) studies, particularly in E. coli, have contributed significantly to enhance the predictive models by interconnecting environmental stress conditions with genomic changes. Different frameworks have further increased our understanding by predicting gene gain or gene loss at systems level, giving us a better explanation of microbial diversity and evolution. By combining AI models with multi-omics data, researchers can predict microbial responses to certain environmental changes. This paper dives deep into the role of AI and ML in studying and predicting microbial evolution, and its applications in various fields.

title: Blockchain-Based E-Procurement System Enhancing Data Security Within Ethereum Smart Contracts
authors: Abdelmonem Najjari, Najiba Tagougui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The rapid adoption of blockchain technology in e-procurement systems has revolutionized digital transactions, offering transparency, immutability, and decentralized control. However, despite these advantages, smart contract vulnerabilities pose significant security risks, potentially undermining the integrity of procurement processes. This paper explores the development of a blockchain-based e-procurement system designed to enhance data security while mitigating smart contract vulnerabilities. By integrating advanced cryptographic techniques, formal verification methods, and secure coding practices, the proposed system aims to strengthen transactional security and ensure trust in procurement operations. The study further outlines real scenario test cases designed to evaluate the functionality, security, and reliability of the smart contracts and system components within the Ethereum based procurement model. Our findings suggest that a well-architected blockchain-based e-procurement framework can significantly enhance data security and improve overall trust in digital procurement ecosystems.

title: DERs Role in Canada’s Energy Transition: Barriers and Pathways in British Columbia and Ontario
authors: Missree Vachhani, Anshul Goyal
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Electric Power Systems (EPS) face mounting challenges, including rapid load growth, aging infrastructure, and increasing reliance on non-dispatchable renewables-all while ensuring reliability amid climate change. Distributed Energy Resources (DERs), such as energy storage, demand response, and localized renewable generation, offer crucial solutions to enhance grid flexibility, resilience, and sustainability. End-toend DER strategy implementation requires rethinking market frameworks, adopting emerging technologies, and accelerating grid integration while catering to the regional energy security, equity and sustainability needs. This paper presents a comprehensive review of the deployment of DERs in two provinces of Canada, namely British Columbia (BC) and Ontario. Firstly, the DER potential in both provinces is introduced, detailing current policies, regulations, and deployment status. Secondly, the challenges associated with DER adoption are examined. Finally, based on comparative analysis and discussion, recommendations and pathways are provided to accelerate DER adoption.

title: Deep Learning-Based Price Prediction of Cryptocurrencies Targeted at Financial Institutions
authors: Raed Hamyd, Madhusudana Kamballi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: For financial institutions seeking to manage risks and optimise investments, accurate price prediction is crucial due to the volatility, decentralisation, and rapid price fluctuations of cryptocurrency markets. In this paper, we present a deep learning-based model for forecasting the prices of Bitcoin, Litecoin, and Dash, which utilises LSTMs and GRUs to model complex time-series dependencies. A multivariate indicator and interdependencies between currencies are used in the proposed model to enhance predictive accuracy by leveraging historical price data and multivariate indicators. The SAM-LSTM architecture integrates self-attention mechanisms and multiple LSTM modules tailored to different variable groups, refining feature extraction and forecasting. A number of key metrics, including MSE, RMSE, MAE, and MAPE, demonstrate that the proposed model consistently outperforms traditional LSTM models. In addition to its ability to forecast both short-term and long-term trends, the model has the potential to be a reliable decision-making tool for institutions.

title: Support Vector Machine Classification of Data Dependency Graphs
authors: John Musgrave, Anca Ralescu
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Support Vector Machine approaches provide efficient classification in data sets with high dimensionality. In prior studies we have presented classification results in a high dimensional metric space constructed from data dependency graphs. These features were demonstrated to be tied to ground truth class labels, and therefore correlated to operational semantics. The dimensionality of the metric space is derived from the quantity of isomorphically unique data dependency graphs within the data set. While successive refinement can reduce the dimensionality and search space, dimensionality at the most coarse-grained level remains very high. We present results from Support Vector Machine classifiers and show high classification accuracy with low false positive rates using features correlated to operational semantics. We train classifiers on the Kaggle 2015 Microsoft Malware data set using a linear SVM classifier (One-vs-Rest and One-vs-One), SVM classifier with RBF kernel, SVM classifier with polynomial kernel, and an SVM classifier with custom kernel based on computing the pairwise Hamming distance. This study obtains a total accuracy of over 93% for a multi-class classification problem using a Linear SVM (One-vs-Rest) classifier. The Linear SVM classifier has the lowest false positive rate and high precision, with 6 of 9 classes having precision above 90%, high F1 scores, and a ROC AUC of 0.98. Non-linear SVM kernels show a decrease in total accuracy which indicates linearity in the associated feature space. The classifier was trained on features correlated with binary operational semantics which are demonstrated to be tied to ground truth class labels.

title: Exploring GenAI-Based Voice Assistants as Social Companions in Old-Age Homes
authors: Kanchan Pranay Patil, Vijayakumar Bharathi. S
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: There are greater opportunities for ageing service providers to incorporate Generative Artificial Intelligence and Large Language Models to offer personalized care for older adults, becoming social companions in old-age homes. Using affordance theory and stereotype content model theory as the guiding theories, this study investigated how technological affordances of AI-powered voice assistants affect their usage for older people's care by mediating voice assistants' perceived competence and perceived warmth. This research's primary data comes from an online survey of 178 respondents comprising senior citizens, family members, and caregivers of old age homes. Findings suggest that AI voice assistants' personalization, interactivity, and anthropomorphism significantly increase perceived warmth. While performance expectancy and effort expectancy significantly increase perceived competence. However, social presence did not influence perceived warmth significantly. Perceived warmth and competence positively affect workers' use of AI-powered voice assistants for care for older adults. The findings have practical value for senior care non-profit organizations and the healthcare sector that use AI voice assistants for personalized senior care.

title: QR-Code Guided Autonomous Medical Assistant Robot for Indoor Hospital Environments
authors: Vimudha Mhadeshwar, Noopur Shaligram, Priyanshu Lathi, Chaitanya Yenge, Manoj Kumar Shukla, Sameer Sayyad, Jyoti Bali, Archana Kanwar
abstract: This paper presents a QR code-based autonomous navigation system for a mobile robot operating in an indoor hospital environment. It enables efficient, contactless delivery of medical supplies based on QR code to mark the destination addresses, such as the patient beds or pharmacy stations. The system leverages an RGB camera, LiDAR, and ROS2’s Nav2 stack, incorporating SLAM, AMCL, and OpenCV with PyZbar for QR code detection. Even in dynamic conditions, the robot achieves high detection accuracy and maintains localization error within 5 cm. This approach reduces human workload and is scalable for multi-robot deployment in smart hospitals.

title: Augmented Reality in Industrial applications
authors: Petr Kropík, Jan Matoušek, Jakub Racek, Lenka Šroubová
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to demonstrate the design and implementation of methods for interactive visualization of dynamic spatial data in augmented and mixed reality (AR/XR) using Microsoft HoloLens 2. The visualized data encompasses not only robot work zones and sensor data, but also a plethora of additional information pertaining to the devices and the environment. Data can be measured or generated dynamically. The development of software modules facilitates the real-time viewing and interaction with data by users. The emphasis is placed on efficient data transfer between physical devices and augmented reality (AR) headsets, integration of gesture control, and development of ergonomic user interfaces customized for industrial applications.

title: Cloud-Based Solutions in Healthcare Systems: A Systematic Review of Current Practices and Future Directions
authors: Binayak Padhy, Brojo Kishore Mishra, Bibudhendu Pati, Ritunsa Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Cloud computing has emerged as a pivotal technology in the transformation of healthcare systems worldwide. Its ability to provide scalable, flexible, and cost-effective infrastructure has led to significant advancements in how healthcare institutions store, manage, and share clinical data. This systematic review examines current practices in the application of cloud-based solutions across various domains within healthcare, including electronic health records (EHRs), telemedicine, remote patient monitoring, and clinical decision support systems. The review synthesizes findings from peer-reviewed studies published between 2015 and 2025, sourced from major scientific databases such as PubMed, IEEE Xplore, and ScienceDirect. The analysis highlights not only the benefits of adopting cloud technologies-such as improved data accessibility, enhanced interoperability, and operational efficiency-but also underscores persistent challenges related to data privacy, regulatory compliance, and system integration. By identifying prevailing methodologies, key trends, and technological gaps, this paper aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the current landscape and propose directions for future research and implementation.

title: From Ops to Experience: AIOps-Enabled MLOps with Identity-Aware and Customer-Informed Pipelines
authors: Satbir Singh
abstract: As machine learning (ML) systems become central to enterprise applications, the need for scalable, secure, and user-responsive operational frameworks has intensified. While MLOps has emerged to standardize ML lifecycle management, most current implementations lack intelligent automation, identity-awareness, and mechanisms for incorporating real-time customer feedback. This leads to operational inefficiencies, security vulnerabilities, and reduced model relevance over time. To address these limitations, we propose a novel MLOps framework that integrates AIOps for anomaly detection and self-healing, IAM for policy-based access governance, and customer-informed feedback loops for continuous model adaptation. The architecture is designed for SaaS-based multi-tenant environments and includes unified observability through a telemetry bus. We evaluate the framework using a simulation-based case study in predictive maintenance, tracking key metrics such as Mean Time to Recovery downtime reduction, access anomaly detection, and user satisfaction. Results show over 50% improvement in recovery time, measurable security gains, and increased responsiveness to end-user needs. This study demonstrates the value of combining automation, security, and user-centricity in production-grade ML operations.

title: Multi-Hop Clustering with Mobility Awareness for Reliable Safety Message Transmission in V ANETs
authors: Kassem AL-Attabi, Shweta Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: A combined Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) and K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN) classification algorithm is used in the study to manage big data within healthcare systems. Healthcare data has grown rapidly, making traditional data processing techniques insufficient. A proposed framework uses HDFS's distributed capabilities to store and process data efficiently, while KNN provides accurate patient classification. In order to develop and implement the system, Java was used on the Eclipse platform, Hadoop was tested, and benchmark datasets were used to evaluate the system's performance. Using HDFS and KNN together improves both data management scalability and classification accuracy, providing a viable solution for real-time healthcare decision support.

title: Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Control for Improved Trajectory Tracking in Lower-Limb Rehabilitation Exoskeleton
authors: Houssem Ben Hadj Mbarek, Imen Saidi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper presents a robust and innovative control strategy for lower limb exoskeletons, based on the Super Twisting Sliding Mode Control (STSMC) technique. By combining the robustness of conventional sliding mode control with a continuous control action, STSMC effectively eliminates the chattering phenomenon, ensuring precise trajectory tracking and enhanced patient comfort. Simulation results have demonstrated the robustness and effectiveness of this control approach in the presence of system disturbances and uncertainties, confirming its potential to improve the performance of medical

title: Transformer-Based End-to-End ECM Parameter Inference for Online Battery Voltage Prediction
authors: Donguk Kim, Jinhyeong Park, Insu Baek, Tae-Hoon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel hybrid modeling framework, Transformer-based Equivalent Circuit Model(TECM), for accurate and generalizable voltage prediction of lithium-ion batteries under real-world operating conditions. The Transformer encoder is designed to infer optimal ECM parameters from driving profile sequences, enabling real-time voltage estimation across various battery states and operating conditions. To validate the proposed approach, extensive experiments were conducted using HIL-based driving simulation data from seven battery packs with different aging levels, and large-scale online BMS data collected over one year from 28 electric vehicles. Five ECM configurations (1, 3, 5, 7, and 9-RC) were evaluated to investigate the effect of model complexity. Across all configurations, T-ECM significantly outperformed the random-search baseline in terms of mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) and prediction variance, with particularly notable improvements observed in low-order ECMs, which are well-suited for real-time applications. The proposed T-ECM framework offers a scalable solution for data-driven battery modeling.

title: Diabetic Retinopathy Application Research and Artificial Intelligence for Enhanced Patient Care
authors: Donia Ammous, Fahmi Kammoun, Nouri Masmoudi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) plays a growing role in the medical field, particularly in the detection and treatment of diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s and diabetic retinopathy. Advances in AI, particularly in machine learning and computer vision, enabling rapid and accurate analysis of large medical data sets.In the specific context of diabetic retinopathy, AI presents significant advantages. Machine learning algorithms can be trained to automatically detect retinal lesions, facilitating early and accurate diagnosis. In addition, AI can predict the evolution of diabetic retinopathy, evaluate the effectiveness of treatments and support clinical decision-making.

title: Integrating Support Vector Machines and Deep Learning for Evaluating Ethics and Social Responsibility Among Students in Higher Education
authors: R. Melba Kani, Dr. Angel Phelsy, Kotte Amaranadha Reddy, Dr Manvendra Singh, Srinivasa. K, Dr. Ratan Sarkar
abstract: The rapid development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become the prediction of student performance a significant concern within the education industry. Traditional methods frequently reveal limitations in accuracy, interpretability, or ethical foundation, particularly in the circumstances of subjective assessments or sensitive information. Our research presents a reliable system that utilises deep learning for feature extraction using a hybrid BERT-LSTM architecture, in combination with Support Vector Machines (SVM) for classifying student performance. Subjective assessments are analysed for sentiment, whereas objective data is processed with the Apriori algorithm to identify significant patterns in academic conduct. Our methodology incorporates an ethical design grounded in ALTAI rules, guaranteeing equity, transparency, and confidentiality. The suggested framework attained exceptional results: an accuracy of 97.86%, an F1-score of 97.78%, and an AUC-ROC of 99.20%, surpassing established baseline models such as Random Forest and conventional SVMs. These enhancements not only demonstrate technical excellence but also have practical implications for early student intervention and academic change. Our methodology offers a harmonious integration of accuracy, clarity, and accountability, establishing a standard for forthcoming AI-based educational instruments. This research substantially advances Educational Data Mining by integrating sophisticated analytics with ethical foresight, facilitating sustainable and socially responsible academic decision-making.

title: Satellite Image Classification Using Different Deep Learning Models for Indian States
authors: Dibya Ranjan Patra, Subarnabindu Pani, Kumar Janardan Patra, Tapas Kumar Choudhury, Kartick Swain
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This study introduces a geotag-independent approach for classifying Indian states using only visual features from satellite imagery, without relying on any spatial metadata such as latitude or longitude. The core objective is to accurately categorize regions based on distinctive visual elements like terrain, texture, vegetation density, water bodies, road networks, and urban layouts present in raw satellite images. Four deep learning models were evaluated that are Custom CNN, MobileNetV2, InceptionV3, and ConvNeXt-Tiny. Among these, a Transformer-enhanced MobileNetV2 achieved the highest performance with 97.58 % accuracy, 0.95 precision, 0.97 recall, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{F1}$</tex>-score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${0. 9 7}$</tex>. To further boost performance, Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) was applied for hyperparameter tuning, yielding a final model with 99.32 % accuracy, 0.98 precision, 0.99 recall, and an F 1 -score of 0.99. Additionally, a soft voting ensemble method was employed to enhance consistency across models. The findings demonstrate that accurate regional classification is feasible using solely image-based features, making this approach valuable for applications in remote sensing, disaster response, environmental monitoring, and national security, especially in contexts where geolocation data is unavailable or restricted.

title: Contour Based Tracking v.s. Hough Transform Based Tracking: A RC Car Experiment
authors: Manasvini Kandikonda, Chirayu Nilesh Chaudhari, Janya Billa, Manitha P. V.
abstract: For autonomous navigation of remotely controlled (RC) cars, real-time perception and path planning algorithms are used. Although traditional vision-based approaches for autonomous navigation, such as contour detection or Hough transforms, can be computationally inexpensive approaches for obstacle detection and lane tracking. This paper examines the comparison of contour-based tracking and Hough transform-based detection for vision-based autonomous navigation of a Raspberry Pi based RC car. The benefits of using both methods are examined for stability of trajectory, robustness to curve paths, and environmental noise. Based on the findings of this study, while the contour-based method is robust to irregular-shaped obstacles, the contour-based method did not perform stable lane tracking and was sensitive to environmental noise. In contrast, the Hough transform-based method enhanced stability of the trajectory and dampened oscillations to external environment conditions. Overall the authors of this paper support that the Hough transform is a better approach for real-world autonomous navigation since it showed smoother path-following performance with less computational cost.

title: AI and Data Science for Predictive Maintenance in Industry 4.0
authors: Babasaheb Jadhav, Tejashree Jadhav, Tanaya Ganguly, G Sunil Goli, P Jyothi, Karthikayen A
abstract: Under Industry 4.0, predictive maintenance has been a key requirement in reducing downtime and maximizing asset performance across sophisticated industrial systems. The proposed research suggests an integrated AI-based framework combining conventional machine learning (ML) techniques (Random Forest, SVM) with deep learning (DL) architectures (CNN, LSTM) and XAI methods like SHAP to ensure transparency and stakeholder confidence. Preprocessed time-series Sensor data from industrial machinery was used to train prediction models for malfunction detection and estimating the remaining useful life (RUL). Real-time deployment was implemented using edge computing to reduce latency and facilitate timely decision-making. Results showed that the LSTM model provided the best performance with 91% precision, 88% recall, and 82.1% RUL accuracy. When combined with SHAP, the model had high accuracy (90% precision, 87% recall) and provided better interpretability. Our work emphasizes the interpretability-latency trade-off since the XAI-enhanced model exhibited a marginally higher latency (110 ms). Nevertheless, the paradigm was successful in providing accurate, real-time, and interpretable predictions. The drawbacks are added computational overhead and the requirement for large-scale labeled data. Follow-on work will prioritize minimizing XAI latency, making data more efficient, and evaluating federated and privacy-preserving learning approaches. This system improves the transparency and trustworthiness of AI applications in industrial predictive maintenance.

title: Explore Hybrid Quantum-Classical Models for Enhanced Image Recognition
authors: Madhav Sharma, Hukam Chand Saini, Samiksha Agarwal, Pushpendra Kumar Sikarwal, Shalini Chaudhary
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: The integration of quantum computing with classical device gaining knowledge of has the ability to revolutionize photograph popularity through leveraging the blessings of every paradigms. Hybrid quantum-classical fashions employ quantum computing functionality for highdimensional computation and superposition on the identical time as leveraging classical deep analyzing frameworks for function extraction and optimization. This paper explores the structure, advantages, worrying situations, and future recommendations of hybrid quantum-classical fashions in photograph recognition. We talk how quantum circuits may be embedded into convolution neural networks (CNNs) and have a look at average performance improvements as compared to classical models. Experimental results and simulations showcase the feasibility of hybrid strategies in improving photo category responsibilities

title: “I'd love a microchip in my brain because there would be no homework.” – School Children Reimagine the Future of Education with Emerging Technologies
authors: Priyanka Sebastian, Sumita Sharma, Netta Iivari, Marianne Kinnula, Charu Monga, Aakash Gautam
publish: Proceedings of the 28th International Academic Mindtrek
abstract: Emerging technologies like virtual reality, robots, and Generative AI are positioned as transformative forces in shaping the future of education. However, there is a lack of understanding of children's perspectives on these technologies’ impact on their education as well as the role they see technology playing in the future. To address this, we conducted workshops with Finnish 12-13-year-olds to explore their visions for future of education and learning. Our findings reveal a significant desire for change in the children's visions for their future education, with classrooms that are more interactive, egalitarian, and exam-free, emphasizing engagement and creativity. Children re-envision the evolving role of human teachers in collaborating with AI and robots. This study contributes by bringing children's voices into discussions on societal impacts of emerging technologies.

title: ESFY: A Gamified Digital Phenotyping System for Self-Monitoring of Psychological Distress
authors: Jana G. Zakai, Sultan A. Alharthi
publish: Proceedings of the 28th International Academic Mindtrek
abstract: Psychological distress among youth is rising at alarming rates, yet many cases go undetected until they become severe. Early self-detection and monitoring is critical for timely intervention, but traditional approaches often fail to engage young people effectively or operate at scale. To address this gap, we developed ESFY: Expert System for Youth, a gamified system that leverages digital phenotyping for early identification and continuous self-monitoring of psychological distress. Our work followed a two-stage process: first, we designed the ESFY system by integrating key insights from the prior work; and second, we evaluated the system through a mixed-method user study with (n = 36) participants. ESFY identifies and interprets behavioral and device-derived digital phenotypes that may signal emotional distress, while its gamified design aims to foster sustained engagement and proactive self-care. Initial evaluation results suggest that the system is both usable and promising as a tool for self-monitoring of psychological distress.

title: CraterSense: Efficient and Robust Crater-Based Lunar Localization System with Structure-Aware Sparse Transformer
authors: Xiaoyi Lin, Tao Li, Baocheng Hua, Lin Li, Chunhui Zhao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Crater-based localization, which estimates spacecraft position by matching observed lunar craters with global catalogs, is critical for autonomous lunar surface navigationdeep-space navigation. However, traditional geometric matching approaches are highly sensitive to detection noise and computationally intensive, limiting their suitability for real-time onboard applications, particularly in lost-in-space (LIS) scenarios where no prior pose estimate is available. We propose CraterSense, a lightweight and robust localization system that integrates a multi-scale crater detection module with a novel identification framework. By abstracting crater layouts into sparse structural images, visual representations that encode only the centers and diameters of the craters, CraterSense reformulates crater identification as a classification task. This abstraction fundamentally improves robustness to detection errors and allows efficient joint optimization of detection and identification and enables efficient end-to-end learning without reliance on prior pose information. To effectively process these texture-free and geometrically sparse inputs, we introduce CATSformer, a compact Vision Transformer that combines convolutional stems, token selection, central attention, and structural position embedding. Experiments on two representative lunar regions demonstrate that CraterSense achieves up to 98.2% identification accuracy, strong robustness to perturbations, and low-latency inference, supporting real-time deployment in planetary missions. This work provides a structure-aware solution for crater-based localization, achieving high precision and onboard autonomy without prior pose information bridging the gap between high precision and operational autonomy in deep-space exploration.

title: Lessons from Deploying Learning-based CSI Localization on a Large-Scale ISAC Platform
authors: Tianyu Zhang, Dongheng Zhang, Ruixu Geng, Xuecheng Xie, Shuai Yang, Yan Chen
abstract: In recent years, Channel State Information (CSI), recognized for its fine-grained spatial characteristics, has attracted increasing attention in WiFi-based indoor localization. However, despite its potential, CSI-based approaches have yet to achieve the same level of deployment scale and commercialization as those based on Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI). A key limitation lies in the fact that most existing CSI-based systems are developed and evaluated in controlled, small-scale environments, limiting their generalizability. To bridge this gap, we explore the deployment of a large-scale CSI-based localization system involving over 400 Access Points (APs) in a real-world building under the Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) paradigm. We highlight two critical yet often overlooked factors: the underutilization of unlabeled data and the inherent heterogeneity of CSI measurements. To address these challenges, we propose a novel CSI-based learning framework for WiFi localization, tailored for large-scale ISAC deployments on the server side. Specifically, we employ a novel graph-based structure to model heterogeneous CSI data and reduce redundancy. We further design a pretext pretraining task that incorporates spatial and temporal priors to effectively leverage large-scale unlabeled CSI data. Complementarily, we introduce a confidence-aware fine-tuning strategy to enhance the robustness of localization results. In a leave-one-smartphone-out experiment spanning five floors and 25, 600m2, we achieve a median localization error of 2.17 meters and a floor accuracy of 99.49%. This performance corresponds to an 18.7% reduction in mean absolute error (MAE) compared to the best-performing baseline.
