title: Magnetically Induced Skin Stretch Enhances Proprioceptive Feedback in Prosthetics_supp4-3633082.mp4
authors: Eleonora Fontana
abstract: Proprioceptive feedback is essential for motor control and prosthetic embodiment, yet myoelectric prostheses lack naturalistic sensory input. Artificial skin stretch stimulation has emerged as a preferred method to convey proprioceptive cues, but current friction-based devices face limitations preventing integration into practical prostheses. This work investigates magnetically induced skin stretch as a non-invasive, potentially implantable alternative. We present MISS (Magnetically Induced Skin Stretch), a novel system that uses external coils to control magnets adhered to the skin, producing skin deformations that mimic subdermal implantation and evoke proprioceptive sensations. We conducted physical and psychophysical experiments, including Just Noticeable Difference and Point of Subjective Equality measurements. Eighteen participants, including five with transradial amputation, used the MISS device with a myoelectric prosthesis, where skin stretch was modulated in sync with prosthetic hand flexion. Results showed high object discrimination accuracy, with amputees performing comparably to able-bodied users. These findings demonstrate MISS as a promising proprioceptive feedback method, supporting its future integration into implantable systems.

title: EGRESS: A Methodology for Eliciting Goals for Requirements Engineering of Secure Systems
authors: Martin Span, Gabe Salinger, Jeremy Daily
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Systems Engineering
abstract: Currently, the systems engineering body of knowledge does not appropriately address secure system design considerations prior to a preliminary architecture being available for the system under design. Methods and techniques exist for completing security analysis on systems in which some architecture definition is complete. However, there exists a gap in methods to elicit early system security requirements, leading to deficient security considerations in the conceptual design phase of complex cyber physical systems. The EGRESS method introduced in this work fills this need. It builds upon best practices from MBSE, Systems Thinking, Systems Theory, and Systems Security standards to offer a user-friendly approach to generating early system goals addressing system security. Utilizing EGRESS maximizes the system design trade space to achieve a system that is secure by design, specifying goals forming the baseline of further security requirement elicitation throughout the system design process.

title: DPCA-Net: Dual-Prototype Consistency Alignment Network for Robust Multimodal Few-shot Action Recognition
authors: Xiaohui Zhao, Xiangyu Meng, Qiyang Li, Xingwang Cai, Deyin Ma, Xiaohu Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Few-shot action recognition seeks to recognize novel actions with limited labeled examples. While dual-modal approaches incorporating video and textual modalities offer enhanced semantic context, existing methods often rely on naive feature fusion strategies, failing to capture deep semantic correlations across modalities and limiting generalization. We propose DPCA-Net, a dual-modal metric learning framework that constructs a unified dual-prototype consistency alignment space. DPCA-Net explicitly models distributional, structural, and metric consistency across modalities to enhance prototype quality and similarity estimation. It integrates three core components: (1) Frame-wise Text-guided Modeling (FTM), which uses conditional prompt learning to embed video frame-level visual features into the textual space, achieving structural consistency; (2) Dual-Modal Metric Learning via dual-path Dynamic Time Warping (Dual-DTW), jointly aligning visual and cross-modal prototypes to ensure metric consistency; and (3) Distribution Consistency Mapping (DCM), which leverages Maximum Mean Discrepancy and cosine similarity to align support-query distributions and reinforce representation robustness. Extensive experiments on three benchmark datasets show that DPCA-Net consistently outperforms prior methods. It surpasses CLIP-FSAR by 1.3%–2.7%, achieving 89.7% (1-shot) on Kinetics and 99.12% (5-shot) on UCF-101. These results highlight the effectiveness of consistency-driven prototype alignment for robust and generalizable cross-modal few-shot action recognition.

title: HG-SFDA: HyperGraph Learning Meets Source-free Unsupervised Domain Adaptation
authors: Jinkun Jiang, Qingxuan Lv, Yuezun Li, Yong Du, Junyu Dong, Sheng Chen, Hui Yu
abstract: Source-Free unsupervised Domain Adaptation (SFDA) aims to classify target samples by only accessing a pre-trained source model and unlabelled target samples. Since no source data is available, transferring the knowledge from the source domain to the target domain is challenging. Existing methods normally exploit the pair-wise relation among target samples and attempt to discover their correlations by clustering these samples based on semantic features. The drawbacks of these methods include: 1) the pair-wise relation is limited to exposing the underlying correlations of two more samples, hindering the exploration of the structural information embedded in the target domain; and 2) the clustering process only relies on the semantic feature, while overlooking the critical effect of domain shift, i.e., the distribution differences between the source and target domains. To address these issues, we propose a new SFDA method that exploits the high-order neighborhood relation and explicitly takes the domain shift effect into account. Specifically, we formulate the SFDA as a hypergraph learning problem and construct hyperedges to explore the deep structural and context information among multiple samples. Moreover, we integrate a self-loop strategy into the constructed hypergraph to elegantly introduce the domain uncertainty of each sample. By clustering these samples based on hyperedges, both the semantic feature and domain shift effects are considered. We then describe an adaptive relation-based objective to tune the model with soft attention levels for all samples. Extensive experiments are conducted on Office-31, Office-Home, VisDA, DomainNet-126 and PointDA-10 datasets. The results demonstrate the superiority of our method over state-of-the-art counterparts. Our code is avaliable at https://github.com/OUC-POVA/ HG-SFDA.

title: Point Evolution Hierarchy Network for Weak Single-point Human Parsing
authors: Sanyi Zhang, Xiaochun Cao, Long Ye, Zhanjie Song, Guo-Jun Qi, Jie Zhou
abstract: Sparsely single-point human parsing aims at segmenting the human body into fine-grained categories via weak point-level labels (e.g., point-level, scribble-level, or image-level, etc). The point-level label, especially single-point supervision, can simultaneously preserve spatial positions as well as take light annotation time, which is particularly advantageous in alleviating the human labeling burden. However, how to obtain satisfactory parsing performance under limited sparse point annotations is challenging, which requires further investigation. In this paper, we propose a novel end-to-end Point Evolution Hierarchy human parsing Network (PEHNet) for fine-grained human parsing task that just leverages single-point supervision. Motivated by the concept of a divide-and-conquer strategy, we partition all pixels into three distinct groups, i.e., single-point labels, pseudo-region labels, and unlabeled pixels, then optimize each group with suitable mechanisms. To expand the coverage of single-point labels, we introduce a point dissemination module that generates high-quality pseudo-region labels. Furthermore, the point-level spatial position information inherently preserves the structural characteristics of the human body. Inspired by this hierarchical property, we devise a point-level human hierarchy-wise constraint that guides the prediction probabilities to align with the inherent hierarchy of the human body. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed PEHNet outperforms state-of-the-art parsing methods on two popular human parsing benchmark datasets (LIP and ATR) and one semantic segmentation dataset (Pascal VOC 2012).

title: Large Language Model-Based Framework for Explainable Cyberattack Detection in Automatic Generation Control Systems
authors: Muhammad Sharshar, Ahmad Mohammad Saber, Davor Svetinovic, Amr M. Youssef, Deepa Kundur, Ehab F. El-Saadany
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The increasing digitization of smart grids has improved operational efficiency but also introduced new cybersecurity vulnerabilities, such as False Data Injection Attacks (FDIAs) targeting Automatic Generation Control (AGC) systems. While machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models have shown promise in detecting such attacks, their opaque decisionmaking limits operator trust and real-world applicability. This paper proposes a hybrid framework that integrates lightweight ML-based attack detection with natural language explanations generated by Large Language Models (LLMs). Classifiers such as LightGBM achieve up to $95.13 \%$ attack detection accuracy with only 0.004 s inference latency. Upon detecting a cyberattack, the system invokes LLMs-including GPT-3.5 Turbo, GPT-4 Turbo, and GPT-4o mini-to generate human-readable explanation of the event. Evaluated on 100 test samples, GPT-4o mini with 20 -shot prompting achieved $93 \%$ accuracy in identifying the attack target, a mean absolute error of 0.075 pu in estimating attack magnitude, and 2.19 seconds mean absolute error (MAE) in estimating attack onset. These results demonstrate that the proposed framework effectively balances real-time detection with interpretable, high-fidelity explanations, addressing a critical need for actionable AI in smart grid cybersecurity.

title: Accelerating CRYSTALS-Kyber and Dilithium via a Single Montgomery Reduction ISE on RISC-V
authors: Ryan Bevin, Ayesha Khalid, Malik Imran, Máire O’Neill
abstract: CRYSTALS family of Kyber key encapsulation mechanism and Dilithium digital signature algorithm are the first post quantum cryptography schemes standardized recently by the National Institute of Standards and Technology; numerous endeavours to accelerate them via instruction set extensions using the RISC-V instruction set architecture have been reported. Many of them focus on accelerating the costly Number Theoretic Transform and its inverse, either solely on CRYSTALS-Kyber or as part of greater lattice-based cryptography improvements. In this work, we demonstrate that by only one unified tightly coupled Instruction Set Extension for the Montgomery reduction operation, we improve the NTT/INTT cycle counts of CRYSTALS-Kyber by 1.69x/1.47x respectively and by 2.12x/2.36x in CRYSTALS-Dilithium respectively while costing a minimal additional hardware overhead on the Ibex RISC-V core implemented on an AMD Xilinx Artix-7 xc7a35tcsg324-1 device. Additionally, we also benchmark the NTT/INTT ISE in CRYSTALS-Kyber evaluating diminishing returns vs. the additional hardware cost induced.

title: Autism Detection and Child Development Tracking System
authors: Jenil Joshy, P D Kavya, Parthiv Sailesh, Resmi K Rajan, M S Sreya
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) affects physiological responses, emotions, and behavior, requiring effective monitoring for early intervention. This study presents a multi-sensor system integrating physiological, behavioral, and motion analysis for ASD tracking. The system uses a MAX30102 heart rate sensor for HRV monitoring and a GSR sensor for stress detection, triggering alerts for abnormal patterns. A webcam-based emotion recognition system analyzes facial expressions and attentional responses, with an audio cue and motorized camera ensuring continuous tracking. A GY45 3-axis accelerometer detects falls and atypical movement patterns. Sensor data is processed via Arduino-based acquisition and Python deep learning models, enabling real-time alerts. By combining multimodal sensing and AI, this system enhances ASD monitoring and child development tracking, supporting both clinical and research applications.

title: The Intersection of Artificial Intelligence and Human Creativity: Can Machines Truly Understand and Replicate Artistic Expression?
authors: Reepu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: In this study, AI’s ability to mimic artistic creation in the visual arts, music, and writing is explored. From experiments, we analyzed four AI algorithms that include: GANs, CNNs, RNNs, and LSTM. At a first, GANs obtained the visual quality at around $78 \%$ while the consistency in the styles was not stable. A study on CNNs proved that the model achieved an $85 \%$ accuracy in classifying artistic styles and therefore the model’s efficiency in art analysis. There was also a slightly better performance of LSTMs with $78 \%$ of coherence in generated text while RNNs had $72 \%$; the models also produced text that was deeper in emotion as compared to the input. Analyzing the results, it can be concluded that AI is capable of creating as well as interpreting artworks with moderate accuracy; however, it stumbles when it comes to mimicking all the shades of humans’ emotion and style. This paper helps to shed some light on the subject of the arts in which AI is already present and both opportunities and challenges therein. Further studies are required to optimise these algorithms and to understand AI’s impact on the creative professions.

title: AI-driven Energy Efficiency Analysis of real-world data in Wireless Cellular Networks
authors: Preetjot Kaur, Meenakshi Malhotra
abstract: As mobile data is growing rapidly and there is a huge surge in the deployment of base stations, especially fifth-generation networks, it becomes crucial to reduce the carbon footprint along with the CAPEX/OPEX costs. This problem demands focus not only due to its environmental impact but also due to the high energy costs faced by MNOs. Though several advancements were made in this field by previous researchers, there remains a gap in the employment of Metaheuristic techniques to optimise the parameters of base stations. This paper deals with the dynamic optimisation of the Energy Efficiency (EE) of wireless cellular networks by utilising nature-inspired techniques on real-time data. A real-world dataset from Kaggle has been used in this work to optimise EE by adjusting the parameters such as throughput, signal strength and latency of 3G, 4G, LTE and 5G networks through the Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO) technique. This AI-driven approach analyses the performance of several wireless cellular networks based on several key parameters and shows how GWO successfully achieved a 92.3% enhancement over the overall EE. Therefore, green communication could be achieved by utilising such nature-inspired optimization algorithms to achieve scalable solutions.

title: Beyond Red Flags: The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Enhancing Financial Fraud Detection
authors: Ambar Kusumaningsih, Ika Diyah Candra Arifah, Dian Anita Nuswantara, Insyirah Putikadea, Hapsari Shinta Citra Puspita Dewi, Erta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Traditional red flag approaches are increasingly inadequate for detecting modern financial fraud, which often involves complex and adaptive schemes. This study explores the potential of Artificial Intelligence (AI)specifically Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning (DL), and Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)-to enhance fraud detection beyond conventional methods. Guided by the Fraud Hexagon theory, a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) using the PRISMA framework was conducted across four databases: Scopus, IEEE Xplore, SpringerLink, and ScienceDirect. From 500 initial articles, 85 publications (2015-2025) were selected based on relevance, full-text availability, and thematic alignment. Python-assisted text mining and topic modeling revealed key trends and advances in AI-driven fraud detection. Results show that AI offers notable benefits in accuracy, adaptability, and real-time response. Additionally, Explainable AI (XAI) emerges as a critical component for transparency and compliance with regulatory standards. However, challenges remain, including algorithmic bias, ethical concerns, and data privacy issues. This study contributes a multidimensional analysis of AI applications in financial fraud detection, addressing both technical methodologies and ethical considerations-areas often overlooked in previous reviews. The findings suggest that hybrid AI models, when combined with strong governance frameworks, represent a promising direction for future audit and fraud prevention systems.

title: Machine Learning Based DDoS Defense to Detect Stealthy Attack Networks
authors: Sanjeev Kumar, Rajiv Singh, Kapil Kumar, Manju Khari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks are critical cybersecurity attack, disturbing networks and responsible for monetary harms. To unravel this issue, authors present an AI-based DDoS Detection System, which analyzes packets moved in a network and uses machine learning approaches to differentiate between normal and abnormal events. The system is developed on a DDoS problem-specific data-source, a common reference data-source with diversity of genuine traffic profiles. The model can successfully identify the attack profile and irregular behaviors by leveraging the significant features in it. Consistency with few false positives is upheld by leveraging accuracy, precision, recall and detection rate to evaluate efficiency. This usage of AI advances against-the-clock threat identification and resolution, delivering a real time and scalable security approach. The experimental results represents that the combined method deploys an effective and accurate approach in detecting DDoS attacks and supports in the development of intelligent intrusion detection systems. This paper deploys to the improvement of the security of the Internet, due to network can be subject to proactive DDoS attack avoidance and a user always provides its service.

title: Pharmaceutical Automation: Leveraging Robotics and AI for Future Innovations
authors: Muneeruddin Mohammed, Zeeshan Ahmed Mohammed, Shanavaz Mohammed, Abul Ehtesham, Mujahedullah Syed
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This review paper explores the transformative integration of smart robotics in the pharmaceutical industry through advanced automation and artificial intelligence (AI). It critically examines the range of robotic systems employed in pharmaceutical manufacturing, including articulated robots, collaborative robots (cobots), SCARA robots, Cartesian robots, and autonomous mobile robots (AMRs) in the context of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient (API) research, laboratory automation, packaging, and biotherapy processes. The study delves into how these technologies, combined with AI applications such as machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), computer vision, and collaborative AI, are revolutionizing production efficiency, quality control, and operational safety. Furthermore, the paper highlights key challenges related to regulatory compliance, technical integration, cost management, flexibility, and ethical considerations. By analyzing current advancements and future trends, this review provides industry professionals and researchers with strategic insights into leveraging AI-powered automation to drive innovation, ensure product quality, and maintain regulatory standards in pharmaceutical manufacturing.

title: A Novel Magic Square Enhanced One-Time Array Adjustment for Enhanced Power Performance under different Shading Conditions
authors: Kapil Khatri, Mirza Mohammad Shadab
abstract: This paper suggests an innovative magic square-based Photovoltaic array rearrangement algorithm that aids in uniformly distributing shadowing effects throughout the array. The novel approach discussed in this paper reduces voltage and current losses caused by diode conduction. Performance analysis using simple shadowing pattern models shows that the algorithm performs better than the traditional total cross-tie (TCT) rearrangement for the frequently tested shadow arrangements. Partial shadowing can reduce the output of photovoltaic arrays and activate bypass diodes, a problem that can be addressed by cross-tying modules within rows and rearranging their positions

title: Comparative Study of Mobilenet and Densenet for Chest CT Scan-Based Lung Cancer Image Classification
authors: Umi Khultsum, Annida Purnamawati, Eka Rahmawati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Lung cancer remains a major cause of cancerrelated mortality worldwide, highlighting the need for accurate and efficient diagnostic tools. This study presents a comparative analysis of two convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures-MobileNet and DenseNet121-for classifying lung cancer images derived from chest CT scans. A total of 720 labeled images were obtained from the Kaggle repository, evenly distributed across three categories: benign, malignant, and normal. Prior to model training, images were preprocessed through resizing and normalization. The dataset was split into training (80 %), validation (10 %), and testing (10 %) subsets. Both models were evaluated in terms of classification accuracy and inference time. The experimental results show that MobileNet achieved a classification accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5. 8 3 \%}$</tex> with an average inference time of 1.89 seconds per image, while DenseNet121 attained 87.50 % accuracy with an inference time of 3.50 seconds. These findings demonstrate that MobileNet is better suited for real-time and resourceconstrained medical environments. The research emphasizes the potential of lightweight CNN models for supporting automated diagnostic systems in clinical practice. Future work should explore cross-validation, dataset expansion, and the incorporation of Transformer-based models to enhance performance and generalizability. This study contributes to the ongoing development of intelligent and efficient lung cancer detection tools using deep learning approaches.

title: Smart Vehicle Tracking System Using GPS and IoT for Real-Time Monitoring and Alerts
authors: Pushpa Rani Juvvala, Pandarinath Potluri, Srinu Vasarao Parnandi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: In the era of smart transportation, ensuring vehicle security and optimizing fleet management have become increasingly important. This research presents the design and implementation of a Smart Vehicle Tracking System that integrates Global Positioning System (GPS) technology with the Internet of Things (IoT) to provide real-time monitoring and alert services. The proposed system captures and transmits vehicle location data using a GPS module and microcontroller, which is then sent to a cloud-based IoT platform via GSM or Wi-Fi communication. Users can access live tracking information and receive instant alerts in cases of route deviation, over speeding, or geofence breaches through a mobile or web interface. The system is designed to be scalable, low-cost, and energy-efficient, making it suitable for applications in public transport, logistics, and private vehicle monitoring. This approach enhances safety, supports efficient route planning, and aids in theft prevention, thereby contributing to the development of intelligent transport systems.

title: Combining SSA Optimization with a Hybrid CBA-XGB Framework for Short-Term Load Forecasting
authors: Zijie Qin, Pan Zeng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: Short-term power load forecasting plays a crucial role in ensuring the stable operation of the power system and the optimal resource allocation. However, the non-stationarity, nonlinear characteristics, and noise interference of load sequences make it difficult for traditional prediction methods to capture their complexity, thus reducing the prediction accuracy. Meanwhile, deep neural networks are susceptible to gradient vanishing and gradient explosion, which further constrains the prediction performance. To this end, this paper constructs a hybrid model SV-CBA-XGB with parameters optimized by Sparrow Search Algorithm (SSA), which firstly realizes the multiscale decomposition of the original load sequence by SSA-seeking optimal Variable Difference Modal Decomposition (VMD); subsequently, an integrated CNN-BIGRU-Attention (CBA) model consisting of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BIGRU), and Attention is used to perform deep feature extraction and time-series modeling of highfrequency complex components, and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) for efficient prediction of low-frequency smooth components. The experimental results show that SV-CBA-XGB significantly outperforms both the single model and the traditional hybrid method in terms of prediction precision and reliability.

title: Auto Tunning PI Controller with Reinforcement Learning Applied to Continuous Microalgae Culture
authors: Santiago Diaz-Bernal, Claudia L. Garzón-Castro, Efredy Delgado-Aguilera, Gianfranco Mazzanti
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: Continuous microalgae cultures are nonlinear, time-varying bioprocesses. To regulate the output of interest (biomass) by manipulating the control variable (dilution rate), researchers have proposed numerous control strategies capable of withstanding parameter variations and disturbances. This work adopts reinforcement learning (RL) to auto tune a PI controller under changing internal and external plant conditions. A policy gradient agent with a neural network containing an LSTM layer was trained online in a simulated nonlinear environment. Twentyfive random seeds were evaluated to estimate the statistical robustness of the learning process. The plant model combines Monod and Contois sub models for a continuous culture of Chlorella vulgaris. The best agent delivered consistent tracking and control in nominal and perturbed scenarios, outperforming a conventional PI controller under similar conditions. These findings indicate that RL based tuning is a viable strategy for improving the robustness and adaptability of bioprocess control systems.

title: A Robust, Fully Integrated $30.5-33.2 \text{GHz}$ and $34.3-36.8 \text{GHz}$ Frequency Synthesizer in SiGe-BiCMOS for Space Applications
authors: Frank Herzel, Seyyid Dilek, Jakub Jablonski, Falk Korndörfer, Corrado Carta, Gunter Fischer
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: A fully integrated low-noise phase-locked loop (PLL) frequency synthesizer in SiGe-BiCMOS technology is presented. Two parallel tuning loops for fine and coarse tuning of the voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) are used to obtain a constant loop dynamics, resulting in a phase noise spectrum fairly independent of the PLL output frequency. A low in-band phase noise floor is achieved by a differential phase-frequency detector (PFD) followed by an integrated active loop filter using only SiGe-HBTs as active devices. A low VCO gain is obtained by combining varactor switching and inductor switching in the VCO, resulting in 16 subbands. The subband selection is achieved by an automated frequency calibration (AFC) loop using two Schmitt triggers. In order to obtain a stable subband selection loop, the AFC block is triggered by the coarse tuning voltage in conjunction with an overdamped coarse tuning loop. By monitoring this tuning voltage under X-ray irradiation, total ionizing dose (TID) effects on the SiGe-HBT based VCO frequency are quantified. The VCO frequency change is below 0.2% up to a total dose of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \text{Mrad}\left(\text{SiO}_{2}\right)$</tex>. This procedure offers a built-in self-test method for PLLs with little hardware overhead.

title: Impact of photovoltaic technologies on optimal sizing of PV system
authors: Nadia Mars, Mahmoud Chaabani, Lassad Houcine, Abdurrahman Zaafouri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper investigates the application of a new meta-heuristic technique named hippopotamus optimization to dedicate the optimal size of the off grid photovoltaic (PV) system with two PV panel technologies: polycrystalline and monocrystalline. The stand-alone generation system comprises PV panels and a battery storage system (BSS). The objective function for this optimization problem is to minimize the unavailability and cost of the proposed stand-alone system with different kinds of PV panels. However, the optimum sizing cannot be accomplished without considering and covering the system reliability and constraints. The effectiveness of HO algorithm is investigated, and its performance is compared with that of the Particle swarm optimization algorithm. The simulation results reveal the validity and superiority of $\mathbf{H O}$ technique in determining the optimal sizing of a PV generation system with a higher convergence rate, lower annual cost and LPSP than the PSO technique and it show that polycrystallinePV solar/battery systems are more suitable for the proposed location than monocrystalline-PV solar/battery systems, due to economic, technical, and environmental conditions.

title: Deepfake Technology in India: Challenges, Misuse Trends, and Policy Recommendations
authors: Jay Singh, Rudrajyoti Das, Snehasish Pradhan, Animesh Ojha, Hitesh Mohapatra, Soumya Ranjan Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Deepfake technology poses unprecedented challenges to India's cybersecurity, legal frameworks, and societal trust. This paper analyzes India's current policies, detection capabilities, and regulatory gaps in addressing deepfake misuse, contrasting them with global benchmarks like the EU's AI Act and China's Deep Synthesis Regulations. While India relies on outdated laws like the IT Act, 2000, and fragmented detection tools, the EU and China enforce strict transparency mandates and multi-modal detection systems. The study proposes a multi-stakeholder framework for India, combining legal reforms, indigenous AI solutions, and public-private collaboration to mitigate risks.

title: Enhancing Pavement Crack Classification with Bidirectional Cascaded Neural Networks
authors: Taqwa I. Alhadidi, Asmaa Alazmi, Shadi Jaradat, Huthaifa I. Ashqar, Ahmad Jaber, Mohammed Elhenawy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Pavement distress, such as cracks and potholes, is a significant issue affecting road safety and maintenance. In this study, we present the implementation and evaluation of Bidirectional Cascaded Neural Networks (BCNNs) for the classification of pavement crack images following image augmentation. We classified pavement cracks into three main categories: linear cracks, potholes, and fatigue cracks on an enhanced dataset utilizing U-Net 50 for image augmentation. The augmented dataset comprised 599 images. Our proposed BCNN model was designed to leverage both forward and backward information flows, with detection accuracy enhanced by its cascaded structure wherein each layer progressively refines the output of the preceding one. Our model achieved an overall accuracy of $87 \%$, with precision, recall, and F1-score measures indicating high effectiveness across the categories. For fatigue cracks, the model recorded a precision of 0.87, recall of 0.83, and F1-score of 0.85 on 205 images. Linear cracks were detected with a precision of 0.81, recall of 0.89, and F1-score of 0.85 on 205 images, and potholes with a precision of 0.96, recall of 0.90, and F1-score of 0.93 on 189 images. The macro and weighted average of precision, recall, and F1-score were identical at 0.88, confirming the BCNN’s excellent performance in classifying complex pavement crack patterns. This research demonstrates the potential of BCNNs to significantly enhance the accuracy and reliability of pavement distress classification, resulting in more effective and efficient pavement maintenance and management systems.

title: ReAD: ReRAM-Based Computing-In-Memory Design and Optimization by AC-DC Mixed Signal
authors: Guanyu Chi, Ing-Chao Lin
abstract: Computing-in-Memory (CIM) technology, particularly Resistive Random-Access Memory (RRAM) crossbar, has shown promise in addressing the limitations of traditional architectures by integrating computation directly within memory arrays. However, a critical challenge remains the presence of unused word lines in the crossbar array, which leads to low resource utilization and inefficiencies. In this paper, we propose a novel circuit design that mitigates the influences of low utilization due to unused rows by introducing the alternating current (AC) signal into the system. At the end of each bitline, peripheral circuits—including amplifiers, a filter array, and envelope detectors—are combined to distinguish each operation effectively. We applied LeNet5, VGG8, and ResNet to three datasets: CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and MNIST. Experimental results demonstrate that during the neural network inference, the accuracy of our work drops by less than 1% for all tested workloads when the variation is as high as 10%. Among them, LeNet5-MNIST shows the highest tolerance, with an accuracy loss of less than 1% when variation is up to 30%. Moreover, the proposed scheme achieves an energy efficiency of 136.89 TOPS/W and delivers 5.77×, 32.75×, and 188.88× improvements in throughput, EDP, and ED<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>P, respectively, which can enable intelligent functionalities for area-/energy-constrained edge computing devices.

title: Features and Applications of Floating-Point FPGAs
authors: Michael Parker, Jody Forland
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Legacy generations of FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array) devices were optimized for fixed-point operation. Significant resource utilization, power consumption, and processing bandwidth penalties have long been associated with using them for floating-point implementations. FPGA suppliers have changed this paradigm by including hardened floating-point Digital Signal Processing (DSP) blocks in their devices and by expanding support tools to ease the burden of implementing floating-point algorithms in these devices. The result is a massive increase in the floating-point capability of FPGA based solutions, with performance in excess of 40 Teraflops theoretically possible in the latest devices. Understanding the possibilities created by this new capability, and methods by which to capitalize on them in future applications, is high value for engineers working in DSP. Broadening knowledge of the silicon features, operating modes, and related design tools is critical to enabling wide scale use of the technology. This paper details the state-of-the-art in floating-point FPGA hardware and support tools, and provides an assessment of each with the goal of facilitating further adoption. Applications in which floating-point FPGAs represent a critical advantage are presented along with implementation and simulation examples to demonstrate tool flow and achievable performance.

title: Ransomware Threat Detection Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Anchal Singh, Simar Preet Singh, Deepika Sharma, S. Gopal Krishna Patro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: In today's digital world, harmful software poses a significant threat to computer systems and networks. Ransomware is a type of malware (malicious software) that locks users' files and demands money to unlock them. Hackers use this attack as a medium to earn money in unethical manner from the users. Thus, growing usage of such attacks can cause serious harm to social economy. Several approaches have been designed to analyse ransomware attacks. Traditional detection methods often rely on predefined signatures, making it difficult to recognize new and evolving threats. The paper focuses on detection of ransomware threats using machine learning approaches and proposes Optimized Decision Tree (ODT) machine learning approach. Machine learning enhances security by analysing behavioural patterns, allowing early detection before serious damage occurs. Machine learning approaches like Decision Tree (DT), XGBoost, and proposed approach are considered in this work for predicting file encryption behaviour, network communication pattern, and system anomalies. These approaches aid in detecting normal and potential security threats, raising the detection level of improper attempts at encryption. The results shows that ODT model optimized better with hyperparameter tuning and features has a high accuracy (success rate of 99.4%) for threat detection. The ODT approach is highly effective for identification of security threats in real-world ransomware attacks.

title: Modelling and Simulation of a Quadruplex Coil PMSM Drive for Position Control System of Launch Vehicles
authors: Sankaranarayanan R, Anish Gopinath, Annie B V, Mini V P
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: A Launch vehicle is an inherent part of any space exploration mission. A Launch Vehicle is a rocket powered space transport system used to send payloads such as satellites and other space probes in to their intended orbits.Position control of the Launch Vehicle is very critical as any deviation may result in the loss of trajectory of the Launch Vehicle which will adversely affect the mission. The main components of the position control system are Actuators and Control electronics. An Actuator is a combination of motor, position sensor, a mounting mechanism, and a rotary to linear converter. Electro Mechanical Actuators are widely used considering their advantages such as maintainability and serviceability. In Launch Vehicle applications, Quadruplex Coil Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (PMSM) based position control systems are used. For high power applications PMSM based drive is invariably used considering its numerous advantages.Torque ripple is a matter of concern in PMSM as it produces oscillations and resonance which are undesirable. In the position control of launch vehicles where no errors are permitted, such oscillations cannot be afforded as it may adversely affect the trajectory of launch vehicles and the entire mission.This paper discusses in detail the modelling of the PMSM drive with various control methods for reduced torque ripple and improved efficiency for the position control system of Launch Vehicles. Models are developed in MATLAB/Simulink. Open loop, closed loop FOC models with PI controllers developed and results are analysed for various load torques.

title: Machine Learning-Based Obesity Prediction Using Behavioural, and Lifestyle Factors
authors: Ayush Bhardwaj, Bhavya Chhabra, T. Preethiya
abstract: Obesity is a multifaceted and increasing health problem linked with severe chronic diseases such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome. Proper classification of obesity levels using personal health information can help in early detection and focused prevention. In this research, a cascade machine learning architecture integrating Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and Artificial Neural Network models for multi-class obesity prediction is proposed. The method dynamically chooses the classifier depending on confidence levels: high-confidence instances are processed by Logistic Regression for performance, medium-confidence instances by Random Forest for strength, and low-confidence instances by a neural network for greater depth of learning. The model was trained and tested on a structured dataset with behavior, lifestyle, and anthropometric attributes. After preprocessing and normalization, the hybrid model exhibited competitive performance in all obesity classes. Performance metrics like accuracy, confusion matrix, receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, and precision-recall analysis ensured the robustness of the system. This cascaded classification approach identifies a potential direction for constructing intelligent and resource-sensitive predictive systems in health informatics.

title: Optimization of Goods Delivery Forecasting Using GRU and LSTM Algorithms with Attention Mechanism
authors: Modesta Binti Husna, M. Bagus Andra, Lia Mazia, Eni Heni Hermaliani, Ida Zuniarti, Instianti Elyana, Nurmalasari, Anton, Nita Merlina, Hilman F. Pardede
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Accurate predictions of the increase in goods delivery production are crucial for improving operational efficiency in the logistics industry. The advancement of deep learning algorithms, such as GRU (Gated Recurrent Unit) and LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory), enables more accurate predictions based on time series data. This study aims to optimize the prediction of goods delivery production using GRU and LSTM algorithms, while incorporating the Attention-SE Block to enhance model performance. The data used includes the period from January to December 20172023, obtained from Kominfo, processed with a timestep of 12 and two variations of epochs (50 and 100). The models tested include GRU, LSTM, and a hybrid LSTMGRU model, with evaluation using RMSE, MAE, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> scores. The results of the study show that the GRU and LSTM models performed well, with low RMSE and MAE. The GRU model with 100 epochs yielded the best performance without the Attention-SE Block, with an RMSE of 0.0758, MAE of 0.0583, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> score of 0.8554. On the other hand, the application of the Attention-SE Block in the LSTM-GRU model showed a significant improvement, with an RMSE of 0.0525, MAE of 0.0393, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> score of 0.9306, making it the most accurate model.

title: Clinical Voice Data Collection and Analysis for Parkinson’s Disease Diagnosis
authors: Seema Gaba, Harpreet Kaur
abstract: Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is a progressive neurological disorder that significantly affects motor functions, including vocal abilities. Early detection plays a crucial role in managing the disease and improving patient outcomes. In this study, we present a comprehensive analysis of voice-based biomarkers for the diagnosis of Parkinson’s Disease, derived from clinically validated voice recordings. The dataset was collected from two reputed medical institutions: Shriman Hospital, Jalandhar, and KIMS Hospital, Secunderabad, ensuring a diverse and representative sample population. Each participant, both PD patients and healthy controls, was asked to perform standardized speech tasks in a controlled environment. High-quality voice recordings were obtained and processed to extract 22 distinct vocal features, including measures of frequency perturbation (jitter), amplitude perturbation (shimmer), noise-to-harmonics ratios, and non-linear dynamic features such as D2, RPDE, and PPE. These parameters are known to reflect the phonatory and articulatory impairments commonly observed in PD patients. The study not only describes the data collection protocol in a clinical setting but also provides a detailed statistical analysis of the extracted features to highlight their diagnostic significance. By comparing the vocal profiles of PD and non-PD individuals, we identify key acoustic markers that distinguish between the two groups. This paper aims to contribute a high-quality, clinically validated voice dataset and demonstrate its potential for developing accurate, non-invasive diagnostic models using machine learning techniques.

title: Model Predictive Path Tracking with Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance for Mobile Robots
authors: Rishabh Changwani
abstract: Efficient trajectory tracking is critical for autonomous mobile robots operating in dynamic environments. This study presents a model predictive control (MPC)-based approach for path tracking, integrating an artificial potential field (APF) method for real-time obstacle avoidance. The system employs both single-input single-output (SISO) and single-input multiple-output (SIMO) control models, optimizing navigation accuracy while adhering to kinematic constraints. Comparative simulations evaluate MPC against conventional PID controllers, demonstrating superior stability and adaptability. Results highlight the advantages of predictive control in generating feasible trajectories with minimal error, paving the way for improved autonomous navigation strategies.

title: Adversarial and Backdoor Threats in Autonomous-Vehicle and Embodied-AI Systems
authors: Muhammad Shafique, Muhammad Abdullah Hanif, Amira Guesmi, Nandish Chattopadhyay, Bassem Ouni
abstract: Deep-learning models are central to every stage of both autonomous-driving and embodied-AI pipelines. Given the safety-critical nature of these platforms, their machine-learning components should be subjected to rigorous evaluation for adversarial and backdoor vulnerabilities. Different pipeline blocks are vulnerable to distinct categories of adversarial attack, depending on their function. For example, perception modules are exposed to physical patch–based adversarial attacks and stealthy backdoor triggers, whereas planning and control modules are susceptible to trajectory-perturbation and command-injection attacks. In this paper, we first present the autonomous driving and embodied-AI systems pipelines. We then highlight the threat surfaces associated with every machine learning and deep learning-based block, survey state-of-the-art attack methods, and review the corresponding defense strategies. Finally, we present some case studies to highlight how selected attacks and defenses perform in real-world environments.

title: Leveraging AI for Improved Performance in Quick Commerce Retail
authors: Vijayakumar Bharathi. S, Kanchan Pranay Patil
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This study applied the resource-based theory of the firm and research on artificial intelligence (AI) in organizations to investigate the contribution of AI-specific resources (tangible, intangible, and human) in quick-commerce retail firms. The research developed a theoretical model to empirically validate the linkages between the capabilities of AI, such as learning, integration, and reconfiguration, to augment quick-commerce performance. The research applied the Dynamic Capability View theory to examine how AI enables agility in sensing, seizing market opportunities for quick-commerce retailers. Given the high-velocity innovation-intensive environment, the study also explored how AI can augment the reconfiguration of resources quickly in analyzing customer expectations. Data was sourced through a structured questionnaire from 273 respondents employed in the quick-commerce industry. Structural equation modeling in the SmartPLS 4.0 software was used for data analysis. The study found that AI capabilities can significantly enhance the dynamic capabilities of the quick-commerce industry. The study emphasized the importance of continuous learning, innovativeness, and adaptability to sustain competition and gain a competitive advantage in the industry.

title: In-Silico Based Teratogenicity Prediction of $\beta$-Lactam Antibiotics Using 1D-CNN by Simulated Annealing
authors: Vioni Maryeta Gradiela Marpaung, Isman Kurniawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: β-lactam antibiotics are among the most widely used classes for treating infections caused by Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. Despite their therapeutic effectiveness, the environmental persistence of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta$</tex>-lactams poses significant ecological and toxicological risks, particularly teratogenic effects on aquatic organisms such as zebrafish (Danio rerio), a widely accepted vertebrate model in toxicological studies. While in silico predictive approaches such as Quantitative Structure-Toxicity Relationship (QSTR) models have been employed to estimate the toxicity of these antibiotics, their predictive accuracy remains a challenge. To address this, the present study successfully developed a 1D-Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN) model optimized using the Simulated Annealing (SA) algorithm to predict the teratogenicity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta$</tex>-lactam compounds with higher accuracy and generalization capability. Among several optimization schemes evaluated, Scheme 1 -featuring alpha of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.85,50$</tex> inner iterations, and the Adam optimizer. This demonstrated the best overall performance, achieving the highest test set <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{2}$</tex> value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 7 1}$</tex> outperforming <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> baseline. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\overline{r_{m}^{2}}$</tex> value of 0.819 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta r_{m}^{2}$</tex> value of 0.081 this result indicates robust predictive reliability and supports the integration of SA as an effective metaheuristic for fine-tuning CNN hyperparameters in regression-based toxicological modeling. Overall, this SAoptimized 1D-CNN approach presents a promising, cost-effective, and reproducible in silico tool for environmental risk assessment of pharmaceutical contaminants. Future studies are encouraged to incorporate more diverse datasets and additional molecular or biological descriptors to further enhance model robustness, applicability, and predictive precision across a broader spectrum of toxicological endpoints.

title: A Power-Efficient Analog Integrated Neural Network for Multiple Sclerosis Disease Detection
authors: Vassilis Alimisis, Konstantinos Cheliotis, Vasileios Moustakas, Anna Mylona, Andreas Papathanasiou, Paul P. Sotiriadis
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: In this work, a current-mode, power-efficient analog integrated artificial neural network architecture is presented. The high-level architecture consists of circuits that operate in the subthreshold region, such as the Gaussian function circuit, Euclidean distance circuit, analog multiplier and a current comparator. The proposed artificial neural network is tested on a multiple sclerosis disease detection classification task. The total power consumption is equal to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$734 n W$</tex> and achieves a mean accuracy of 96.71%. The proposed classifier is implemented and tested using the Cadence IC Suite for both schematic and layout design, in a TSMC 90 nm CMOS process. Both Monte Carlo and corner analysis are performed to confirm the robustness of the proposed design. Additionally, post-layout results are compared with both software implementations and existing analog hardware solutions in terms of power and efficiency.

title: Stochastic Planning of a Campus Microgrid Considering Practical CHP and Market Constraints
authors: Masoud Hajian Foroushani, Mostafa Farrokhabadi
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a stochastic planning framework to determine the optimal sizing of BESS and PV for campus microgrids based on realistic data obtained from the University of Calgary campus microgrid. This grid-connected microgrid includes a combined heat and power (CHP) plant and a 400 kW solar photovoltaic (PV) system. Driven by campus mandates for efficiency, reliability, and sustainability, the planning framework studies and identifies the optimal investment scenario for upgrading the existing PV capacity and incorporating a battery energy storage system (BESS). The practical framework integrates the operational intricacies of the CHP plant and the modeling complexities of the Alberta electricity market, including the pool price and the nonlinear transmission and distribution fees (T&D). By considering various stochastic scenarios regarding electricity price, load growth, and gas price, the study develops a daily optimization approach to consider the intricacies of the electricity market, formulating the optimization framework as a mixed-integer linear programming stochastic problem. Reported key performance metrics include the net present cost (NPC) and the saving-to-investment ratio (SIR) over the planning horizon. Results support investing in distributed energy resources (DERs) to reduce the supplied cost of energy.

title: A Fast Volumetric Capture and Reconstruction Pipeline for Dynamic Point Clouds and Gaussian Splats
authors: Athanasios Charisoudis, Simone Croci, Kit Yung Lam, Pascal Frossard, Aljosa Smolic
publish: Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGGRAPH European Conference on Visual Media Production
abstract: We present a fast and efficient volumetric capture and reconstruction system that processes either RGB-D or RGB-only input to generate 3D representations in the form of point clouds and Gaussian splats. For Gaussian splat reconstructions, we took the GPS-Gaussian regressor and improved it, enabling high-quality reconstructions with minimal overhead. The system is designed for easy setup and deployment, supporting in-the-wild operation under uncontrolled illumination and arbitrary backgrounds, as well as flexible camera configurations, including sparse setups, arbitrary camera numbers and baselines. Captured data can be exported in standard formats such as PLY, MPEG V-PCC, and SPLAT, and visualized through a web-based viewer or Unity/Unreal plugins. A live on-location preview of both input and reconstruction is available at 5–10 FPS. We present qualitative findings focused on deployability and targeted ablations. The complete framework is open-source, facilitating reproducibility and further research.

title: TerraSegNet: Bilateral Axial Attention Network for Remote Sensing Image Segmentation in Diverse Environmental Monitoring Applications
authors: Bagus Setyawan Wijaya, Rinaldi Munir, Nugraha Priya Utama
abstract: Semantic segmentation is crucial for environmental monitoring by enabling precise land cover mapping and change detection from satellite imagery. Although recent advances in deep learning have significantly improved segmentation performance, most existing models are designed for specific tasks. They are often trained on single-source satellite imagery, which limits their adaptability. To overcome these limitations, we propose TerraSegNet, a lightweight bilateral network that separates the extraction of spatial detail and semantic context through a dual-path architecture. The model integrates convolutional axial attention in the context path to capture long-range dependencies efficiently while maintaining compatibility with convolutional backbones. We evaluated TerraSegNet on four different remote sensing tasks using five publicly available satellite imagery datasets: cloud detection on SPARCS (Landsat 8) and WHUS2-CD+ (Sentinel-2), photovoltaic panel segmentation on PV08 (Gaofen-2), paddy rice mapping on Plot-Rice v1.0 (Sentinel-1), and ground terrain classification on AIR-PolSAR-Seg-2.0 (Gaofen-3). All training is performed independently per dataset without cross-domain transfer learning, ensuring a fair evaluation of in-domain performance. TerraSegNet achieves mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) scores of 0.8608, 0.9364, 0.9617, 0.7777, and 0.9207 on SPARCS, WHUS2-CD+, PV08, Plot-Rice v1.0, and AIR-PolSAR-Seg-2.0, respectively. These results outperform baselines and demonstrate its effectiveness for various environmental applications.

title: TORM: Transparent Objects Reconstruction and Manipulation With Multi-View Segmentation_supp1-3632680.mp4
authors: Qiyuan Qiao
abstract: Transparent objects are common in daily life and industry, necessitating that robots be able to perceive and manipulate them. The physical properties of reflection and refraction pose challenges for accurately reconstructing the 3D geometry of transparent objects. Conventional methods, which rely on simultaneous estimation of background ambient light and complex refraction fields, lack robustness in real-world scenes, thereby impeding robotic grasping performance. To address this issue, this paper proposes TORM, a novel framework for robust reconstruction and manipulation of multiple transparent objects. TORM focuses on semantic information from transparent objects and employs multi-view segmentation masks to constrain a self-supervised multi-object deep marching tetrahedra (DMTet-Multi) 3D fitting process. To mitigate the risk of the geometry representation getting stuck in suboptimal solutions during multi-transparent-object reconstruction, we design a novel loss function that prevents marching tetrahedra from crossing boundaries. By applying a connectivity determination strategy to the fitted mesh, transparent objects can be processed in parallel by a grasp perception network, predicting the end-effector configuration for grasp tasks. Real-world experiments demonstrate that TORM achieves an 88.8% grasping success rate in multi-transparent-object grasping tasks. The code and dataset are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/arclab-hku/torm</uri>.

title: A Compute-in-Memory Decoding Architecture for Posit-to-Floating-Point Conversion
authors: Jae Hyung Ko, Byung-Soo Kim, Taeho Hwang, Kyu Hyun Choi
abstract: Modern computing systems are increasingly adopting low-precision floating-point formats to reduce memory overhead, particularly in large-scale applications such as large language models and scientific computing. Low-precision formats, however, are vulnerable to reduced numerical accuracy and provide only a limited dynamic range. The posit format, which incorporates a variable-length regime structure, has gained attention for providing higher precision and a broader dynamic range compared to conventional low-precision floating-point representations. Despite such advantages, conventional computing architectures are still based on IEEE 754 floating-point arithmetic, where achieving parallel and efficient posit-to-floating-point decoding remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a Compute-in-Memory (CIM) architecture for posit-to-floating-point conversion that leverages the inherent parallelism of memory arrays to perform concurrent conversion of multiple posit values in a fixed number of cycles with negligible hardware overhead. The architecture implements key modules for posit decoding through bitwise in-memory logic operations, extending the state-of-the-art PIM microarchitecture to enable a wider range of micro-operations. Experimental results based on RRAM crossbar simulation demonstrate an average improvements of 3.3× and 5.04× in throughput and energy efficiency, respectively, compared to a baseline CMOS decoding architecture.

title: Multimodal Deep Feature Fusion Network-Assisted Optimization of Microstrip Antenna Geometry Design
authors: Changlun Gao, Shaoqiu Xiao, Baoxin Lei, Yanyan Tian, Xudong Zhang, Han Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a novel microstrip antenna geometry optimization method leveraging a multimodal deep feature fusion network (MDFFN). By deeply fusing the multimodal features from antenna images and their geometric parameters, MDFFN enables efficient prediction of the antenna electromagnetic (EM) response, replacing the traditional time-consuming EM simulation method. For three typical antennas, MDFFN achieves Mean Square Error (MSE) of 0.120, 0.012 and 0.389, along with Coefficient of Determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) values of 0.978, 0.999 and 0.977 in EM response prediction. It significantly outperforms Gaussian Process Regression (GPR, MSE: 1.505, 1.794, 1.311; R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.878, 0.908, 0.932) and Fully Connected Neural Network (FCNN, MSE: 0.716, 1.153, 1.455; R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.930, 0.898, 0.916), which are based on single-geometric parameterized modeling. A complete antenna design framework is further constructed. Through experimental validations, it is verified to achieve automated optimization of antenna geometric parameters, providing an efficient solution for antenna design.

title: Recognizing Human Postures Using Two Versions of Dedicated Transformer Network
authors: Esther L.A. Ekemeyong, Teresa Zielinska, Atsuo Takanishi
abstract: This paper proposes a method for human posture classification using two specialized Transformer architectures. The broader goal is to leverage recognized posture sequences to infer complex human actions, like distinguishing ‘sitting down’ from ‘standing up’, for applications like human–robot interaction and intelligent interface systems. While Transformers excel in NLP and image tasks, their potential for 3D skeleton-based posture classification remains underexplored. State-of-the-art action recognition methods often rely on deep, resource-intensive networks struggling with viewpoint variability and temporal inconsistency, and requiring large annotated datasets. To address these limitations, we introduce two lightweight, effective transformer variants: the Central Posture Transformer (CPT) and Isolated Attention Transformer (IAT). CPT uses a central posture mechanism to identify and emphasize the most representative frame within a sequence via contextual attention, enhancing interpretability and efficiency. IAT decouples spatial and sequential attention, first modeling joint relationships before integrating temporal dynamics, improving modularity and robustness. These design choices distinguish our models from standard transformers, which compute attention uniformly across all input tokens. Evaluated on the customWUT-20 dataset and publicPKU-MMD benchmark, IAT achieves top accuracy on WUT-20 (0.9981 for 12-frame sequences and 0.9963 for 8-frame sequences), while CPT excels on PKU-MMD (0.9573 and 0.9349). Both outperform baselines such as Ts-CNN, IndRNN, and PoSeqTNet by over 3% in most settings. Qualitative results show CPT’s discriminative posture extraction and IAT’s robustness to temporal resolution changes. Overall, our models achieve high accuracy, computational efficiency, and generalizability across datasets, making them well-suited for real-time human-centered applications in constrained or diverse environments.

title: Uniform Mechanical Loading Can Test for Nonuniform Loading Durability
authors: Nick Bosco, Martin Springer
abstract: In this work, we present a method to evaluate the equivalency between any module mechanical loading conditions. The method is developed to address the specific failure mode of glass fracture and is based on Weibull analysis and weakest link theory. It considers the varying stress profile across the module to calculate the probability of glass fracture, which is used as the metric of equivalency. An idealized nonuniform loading scheme is employed to demonstrate the method and introduce the concept of the equivalent uniform load factor: a factor applied to the maximum pressure of the nonuniform load to obtain the equivalent uniform load value. It is demonstrated that this factor is less than unity for all nonuniform load cases considered, including snow and various characters of wind loading. These significant results suggest that uniform loading may be reliably, and practically, employed to evaluate photovoltaic module glass for nonuniform loading durability.

title: Turnkey Automated Design of Handset Antenna Systems for Enhanced Cellular and SATCOM Performance Based on Internal Multiport Method
authors: Wenrui Zheng, Yunlai Yang, Yan Wang, Can Ding, Hui Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Designing multi-antennas with multiple functions covering all the bands in a compact handset platform presents substantial challenges in impedance matching, decoupling, and radiation pattern synthesis, especially under user interaction and integration constraints. This paper proposes a turnkey design framework based on the internal multiport method (IMPM), which leverages scattering matrix formulations to enable matrix-based evaluation of antenna performance without manual analysis or mode identification. By integrating this model into the NSGA-III evolutionary algorithm, the entire antenna configuration is optimized holistically as a package, including feeding port placement, reactive load tuning, and shorting control. Different from conventional designs that focus on a single or limited number of antenna elements, the proposed framework automatically synthesizes a four-antenna cellular system and a dual-antenna satellite system on the same platform. Both states share the same hardware and can be reconfigured using only five switching points. The cellular state supports 2×2 and 4×4 MIMO operation across 0.69 to 4.2 GHz, while the satellite state achieves wide-beam endfire radiation in the n256 band with a 4.6 dB gain improvement. Prototypes were fabricated, and measurements demonstrated close agreement with simulations, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: A Quadrotor with a New 3-DOF Hybrid Manipulator for Pipeline Maintenance: Design, Modeling, and Task-Space Control
authors: Ezeldin N. Moustafa, Mitsuhiro Kamezaki, Shota Miyake, Shigeki Sugano
abstract: Aerial manipulation has attracted growing interest due to the increasing demand for unmanned systems capable of performing complex tasks in hazardous or hard-to-reach environments, such as pipeline maintenance. Existing aerial manipulators often employ serial or parallel arm architectures, each with inherent limitations: serial arms offer a wide workspace but compromise stability, while parallel arms enhance stability but are restricted in orientation control and workspace range. To address these challenges, this paper presents a new aerial manipulator that integrates a quadrotor with a compact 3-DOF hybrid parallelogram-based arm and a dual-tool end-effector. The design achieves efficient task-space reachability through a cantilevered structure and improved stability via fixed-base actuation. It also enables decoupled orientation, allowing independent and precise control of the end-effector’s direction to meet task-specific requirements. Comprehensive kinematic and dynamic models are developed, and a closed-form inverse kinematics solution is derived to ensure accurate task-space positioning and motion execution. To ensure robustness under disturbances with fast convergence, smooth control signals, and reduced chattering, a hybrid control scheme is proposed that combines a backstepping controller with an adaptive disturbance estimation for position tracking, together with an adaptive fast terminal sliding mode controller featuring a singularity-free sliding surface and a continuous super-twisting reaching law for attitude and manipulator joint tracking. The controller is based on a systematic derivation approach that enables fast computation and low implementation complexity. The modeling and control framework is implemented and validated in MATLAB Simulink and Simscape, and a prototype is developed for deployment in real-world aerial manipulation scenarios.

title: Implicit Neural Representations for Codebook Configuration in RIS-aided Communication Systems
authors: Huiying Yang, Jiahe Wang, Zihan Jin, Jiangbo Dong, Rujing Xiong, Robert C. Qiu, Zenan Ling
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) is envisioned as a key enabling technology for 6G wireless communications. By configuring the reflection beamforming codebook, RIS focuses signals on target receivers to enhance signal strength. In this paper, we investigate the codebook configuration for both continuous-phase and 1-bit RIS-aided communication systems. We formulate an implicit relationship between user coordinates and the optimal codebook from the perspective of electromagnetic wave propagation mechanisms, and introduce a novel learning-based method, implicit neural representations (INRs), to solve this implicit coordinates-to-codebook mapping problem. Our approach requires only user coordinates, avoiding reliance on explicit channel models. For continuous-phase RIS, we introduce a phase normalization technique to address the periodicity and global phase offset challenges inherent in phase representation. Additionally, for the practical 1-bit RIS scenario, we formulate the codebook configuration as a multi-label classification problem and propose an encoding strategy to reduce codebook dimension, thereby improving learning efficiency. Experimental results from both simulated and real-world datasets demonstrate significant advantages of our unified method across both continuous and 1-bit codebook configurations. The datasets and code are available at: https://github.com/HUSTGSNeRF/Codebook_Inr.

title: H-plane Bent Horn Antenna-Integrated Handheld Probe for Compact Dual-Modality Thermoacoustic/Photoacoustic Imaging
authors: Shengli Fan, Lin Huang, Yulong Guo, Yijie Huang
publish: IEEE Journal of Electromagnetics, RF and Microwaves in Medicine and Biology
abstract: Integrated thermoacoustic (TA)/photoacoustic (PA) dual-modal imaging offers complementary contrast by simultaneously mapping dielectric properties and optical absorption of biological tissues, holding considerable clinical promise. To facilitate clinical adoption, there is a pressing need for compact, user-friendly handheld probes. In this work, we present a novel handheld integrated dual-modal probe designed around a custom H-plane bent rectangular horn antenna. A key innovation lies in the system-level integration of a miniaturized microwave source (37 cm × 32 cm × 10 cm) and a compact laser module (60 mm × 34 mm × 26 mm), resulting in a fully portable imaging platform. This system uniquely combines TA imaging for mapping tissue dielectric properties with PA imaging for delineating vascular morphology. The core antenna (34 mm × 17 mm × 90 mm, 84 g), specifically engineered for this probe, operates in the 5.8–6.0 GHz band. Experimental characterization demonstrated a spatial resolution of 1.31 mm for TA imaging and 0.75 mm for PA imaging. The dual-modal capability was successfully validated using tissue-mimicking phantoms containing fine black sutures (0.1 mm diameter) and saline-filled targets (1 mm diameter). Finally, clinical potential was confirmed through in vivo imaging of a human finger. These results collectively affirm that the developed handheld TA/PA probe, based on a compact and novel H-plane bent horn antenna design, represents a significant step forward for clinical applications such as vascular diagnostics, finger joint assessment, and Image-Based Hyperthermia Guidance.
