title: Efficient Power and Resource Allocation for NOMA-Enabled V2X Communication Networks
authors: Javed Akhter, Ranjay Hazra, Pratap Khuntia, Shubhra Sankha Sarma
abstract: Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication plays a vital role in Internet of Things (IoT)-driven intelligent transportation systems (ITS), enabling the real-time exchange of information among vehicles, infrastructure, and networks. To address the increasing demands for capacity, reliability, and latency in dense vehicular environments, this paper investigates an efficient power and resource allocation framework for NOMA-enabled V2X communication to maximise the energy efficiency (EE) of the system, while maintaining the QoS of vehicular groups (VGs) and Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) users. To achieve this, we divide the problem into three sub-problems and employ the Dinkelbach technique to solve the EE optimisation. The Concave-Convex Procedure (CCCP) and Lagrange Multiplier technique are used to find the optimal power of VGs and V2I users. A weighted bipartite matching algorithm is used for the spectrum reuse matching problem. Furthermore, the computational complexity of the proposed algorithm is analysed to assess its practical feasibility. The system performance is evaluated in terms of EE under varying path loss exponents, VG transmit power levels, and the number of VGs. System fairness is evaluated in terms of Jain’s Fairness Index (JFI). The simulation results show that the proposed scheme improves in terms of EE while ensuring that the QoS requirements of both VGs and V2I users are met. The proposed scheme is also compared with existing schemes in terms of EE.

title: A Noise Reduction Method for Shipborne Atom Gravimeter Based on SVMD-SdrSampEn
authors: Chunfu Huang, An Li, Fangjun Qin, Jingshu Li, Guoheng Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: High precision marine gravity field construction is the basis of gravity aided inertial navigation, which requires gravity measurement with high precision and resolution. Shipborne atom gravimeter dynamic measurements satisfythese characteristics, but the output sequenceisseriously disturbed by vibration noise, so noise reductionshould be carried out. We propose a noise reductionmethod, in which the sequenceis decomposed into different frequencydominatedmodes by successive variational modedecomposition (SVMD), and the mode is judged as signal or noisedominatedby spacedependent recursive sample entropy(SdrSampEn). Then the Savitzky-Golay(SG)filter is used to smooth thesignaldominatedmode, and singular spectrum analysis (SSA) is used to extract weak useful signal from the noise dominatedmode, and the denoised sequenceis reconstructed. The noise reduction performance of the proposedmethod was verified bytwo groups of dynamic measured data of atom gravimeter, which improved at least 38.3% compared to existing methods. The method was applied to the accuracy evaluation of atom gravimeter survey line, and the sub-mGal internal and external coincidence accuracy are obtained.

title: Quantitative Gait Analytics Reveal Atrial Fibrillation-Specific Patterns in Balance and Mobility: Implications for Fall Prevention
authors: Sona M. Al Younis, Herbert F Jelinek, Wael Almahmeed, Kinda Khalaf
abstract: The distinctive implications of arterial fibrillation (AFib) on gait and balance patterns, especially in older frail adults and post-operative cardiac rehabilitation patients, remain largely underexplored. In this work, we studied a frail, post open-heart surgery cohort (52 normal, and 25 AFib elderly patients) and identified novel AFib-specific spatiotemporal and balance control markers by integrating instrumented treadmill analytics with principal component analysis (PCA) techniques. Using clinical gait protocols and instrumented analytics, we captured gait balance changes in frail elders with and without AFib, deriving robust markers of temporal control, bilateral support, and postural symmetry/dynamic stability. Compared with the normal group, AFib patients exhibited longer stride/step times (+0.30 seconds/+0.15–0.16 seconds; Cohen d=0.77–0.79), lower cadence (−14.92 steps/min; Cohen d=−0.84) and slower velocity (−0.24 Km/h; Cohen d=−0.6), with a modest shift toward longer left stance/shorter left swing (~±2.66; Cohen d≈±0.59); These significant differences reflect temporal instability characterized by loss of cadence regularity, longer step-to-step timing and reduced dynamic stability, which results in greater reliance on double support/phase asymmetry, mechanisms linked to elevated fall risk in frail older adults. The AFib group also demonstrated stronger inter-parameter correlations, reflecting compensatory or rigid gait performance, while the balance analysis revealed differences in single-limb support and increased postural asymmetry in the AFib group. Single limb support line, gait length line, and anterior/posterior positioning were also significantly different (PC1= 28.4%, PC2=23.0%), suggesting rigid and less adaptable control strategies. Compared to prior studies, which typically included clinical scales or global mobility indices and reported general mobility/frailty measures, this study transports AFib gait and balance research results beyond descriptive reports to streamlined, quantitative biomarkers targeting modifiable fall-risk mechanisms. Our findings emphasize the need for timely quantitative gait and balance assessment in frail and postoperative adults, towards devising precise personalized cardiac rehabilitation inclusive of gait and balance training and providing a basis for future fall prediction models.

title: Magnetic noise analysis and suppression of nanocrystalline spindle-shaped magnetic shielding cylinder
authors: Zhenkai Zhao, Xueping Xu, Wei Liu, Yi Liu, Lei Wang
abstract: Nanocrystalline magnetic shields provide near-zero magnetic environments essential for the ultra-sensitive operation of spin-exchange relaxation-free (SERF) atomic magnetometers, enabling precise measurements such as magnetocardiography (MCG) and magnetoencephalography (MEG). To enhance sensitivity, this study introduces a magnetic noise (MN) model tailored for a spindle-shaped magnetic shielding cylinder (SMSC), incorporating the effects of structural anisotropy. Additionally, a segmented dynamic demagnetization method is developed, accounting for the anisotropic magnetization characteristics of nanocrystalline materials. The proposed approach effectively improves both magnetic shielding performance and noise suppression.

title: A Multi-View Multi-Timescale Hypergraph-Empowered Spatiotemporal Framework for EV Charging Forecasting
authors: Jinhao Li, Hao Wang
abstract: Accurate electric vehicle (EV) charging demand forecasting is essential for stable grid operation and proactive EV participation in electricity market. Existing forecasting methods, particularly those based on graph neural networks, are often limited to modeling pairwise relationships between stations, failing to capture the complex, group-wise dynamics inherent in urban charging networks. To address this gap, we develop a novel forecasting framework namely HyperCast, leveraging the expressive power of hypergraphs to model the higher-order spatiotemporal dependencies hidden in EV charging patterns. HyperCast integrates multi-view hypergraphs, which capture both static geographical proximity and dynamic demand-based functional similarities, along with multi-timescale inputs to differentiate between recent trends and weekly periodicities. The framework employs specialized hyper-spatiotemporal blocks and tailored cross-attention mechanisms to effectively fuse information from these diverse sources: views and timescales. Extensive experiments on four public datasets demonstrate that HyperCast significantly outperforms a wide array of state-of-the-art baselines, demonstrating the effectiveness of explicitly modeling collective charging behaviors for more accurate forecasting.

title: BiConformer: EEG-Based Cognitive Load Assessment Using a Bidirectional Convolutional Transformer Network
authors: Xu Yan, Yuhang Shi, Tingting Zhang, Xin Chen, Yi Mao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Cognitive load assessment through electroencephalography (EEG) signals represents a crucial research frontier in brain-computer interface development. To systematically investigate the effects of cognitive load on neural activity, we developed the N-back Task EEG Dataset (NTED) comprising four distinct levels of cognitive load. Traditional convolutional networks struggle to model temporal features in EEG signals due to their unidirectional architectures, while Transformer-based approaches tend to overlook local details when capturing global relationships. Additionally, existing methods generally lack effective modeling of cross-channel spatial correlations. To address these challenges, we proposed a novel Bidirectional Convolutional Transformer Network (BiConformer) that integrates three serial core components: a Bidirectional Convolutional module that extracts local contextual features through past-future signal analysis, a Channel-Spatial Attention module that adaptively adjusts channel relationships, and a Transformer-based module that captures global contextual dependencies. Extensive experiments conducted on NTED and two public datasets demonstrate that BiConformer achieves superior performance compared to existing state-of-the-art models. Importantly, we found that BiConformer, using only a small number of prefrontal channels, achieved high classification performance that significantly outperformed other compared methods, demonstrating its robustness in data-scarce scenarios.

title: Joint Computation Offloading and Server Deployment for Secure Multi-UAV MEC Networks: A Hierarchical Interactive Learning Approach
authors: Chao Fang, Yanxiang Feng, Yikang Yang, Tao Wu, Xiaoling Li
abstract: In the realm of multiple Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-assisted Mobile Edge Computing (MEC), a key challenge is the coupling between UAV deployment and ground users' (GUs) computation offloading. Malicious aerial eavesdroppers can intercept offloaded data, endangering GUs' privacy. However, most existing MEC secure computation schemes rely on UAVs' trajectories and communication resources, neglecting the collaboration between GUs and UAVs. As such, this paper jointly optimizes computation offloading and UAV deployment in multi-UAV-assisted MEC with an eavesdropping UAV, aiming to minimize system computation cost. We first model the strongly coupled elements using a multi-leader multi-follower Stackelberg game, with UAVs as leaders and GUs as followers. By carefully designing utility functions, we prove both GU-level and UAV level subgames to be exact potential games (EPGs) with Nash equilibrium (NE). Then, a novel hierarchical interactive learning (HIL) algorithm is proposed to reach the Stackelberg equilibrium (SE). The GUs adopt offloading strategies via the best response (BR) theory, and the UAVs learn deployment strategies from the strategy probability vector and GU feedback. Finally, simulation results show that our HIL algorithm outperforms benchmarks, featuring fast convergence, lower system computation costs, and more edge offloading GUs in various scenarios.

title: Fed-Reputed: Reputation-Aware Client Selection in Hierarchical Federated Learning for Consumer Electronics
authors: M.A. Moyeen, Kuljeet Kaur, Anjali Agarwal, S. Ricardo Manzano, Marzia Zaman, Nishith Goel
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across distributed consumer devices without requiring raw data to be centralized—an essential feature for privacy-critical applications such as biomedical monitoring and mobile health diagnostics. However, real-world deployments often face challenges in client selection, especially in the presence of misbehaved clients. Straggler clients with poor connectivity or low resources delay convergence, while malicious clients pose threats to model integrity by injecting poisoned updates. These problems are amplified in dynamic, heterogeneous environments such as those involving consumer biomedical devices. To address this, we propose Fed-Reputed, a reputation-aware client selection framework tailored for Hierarchical Federated Learning (HFL). Unlike existing reputation-based approaches that suffer from herding effects, cold-start limitations, and imbalanced classification datasets, Fed-Reputed integrates a modified Bellman equation within a Deep Q-Learning framework. This formulation guides client selection using an Imbalanced Classification Markov Decision Process (ICMDP), leveraging both device capability and historical behavior. Extensive simulations using MNIST and FMNIST datasets under varying percentages of straggler and malicious clients demonstrate that Fed-Reputed achieves up to 50% higher global model accuracy and 1.7 times faster convergence compared to state-of-the-art selection methods. Moreover, it significantly improves the detection of misbehaving clients without sacrificing fairness or scalability. These results highlight the potential of Fed-Reputed to advance secure, scalable, and personalized Federated Learning in health-sensitive consumer environments.

title: Synthetic Malware at Scale: Malicious Code Generation with Code Transplanting
authors: Guangzhan Wang, Diwei Chen, Xiaodong Gu, Yuting Chen, Beijun Shen
abstract: Malicious code detection is one of the most essential tasks in safeguarding against security breaches, data compromise, and related threats. While machine learning has emerged as a predominant method for pattern detection, the training process is intricate due to the severe scarcity of malicious code samples. Consequently, machine learning detectors often encounter malicious patterns in limited and isolated scenarios, hindering their ability to generalize effectively across diverse threat landscapes. In this paper, we introduce MalCoder, a novel method for synthesizing malicious code samples. MalCoder enlarges the quantity and diversity of malicious instances by transplanting a set of malicious prototypes into a vast pool of benign code, thereby crafting a diverse array of malicious instances tailored to various application scenarios. For each malware prototype, MalCoder treats it as an incomplete code fragment and crafts its preceding and subsequent contexts through right-to-left and left-to-right code completion respectively. By leveraging GPTs with various sampling strategies, we can instantiate a large number of code samples bearing the malware prototype. Subsequently, MalCoder masks the original prototypes within the transplanted samples and fine-tunes an LLM code generator to reconstruct the original prototype. This process enables the model to seamlessly transplant malicious code fragments into benign code. During inference, MalCoder can automatically insert malicious fragments into benign samples at random positions, transforming benign code into malicious code. We apply MalCoder to a large pool of benign code in CodeSearchNet and craft over 50,000 malicious samples stemming from 39 malicious prototypes. Both qualitative and quantitative analyses show that the generated samples maintain key characteristics of malicious code while blending seamlessly with benign code, which helps in creating realistic and varied training data. Additionally, by using the generated samples as augmented training data, we witness a remarkable surge in malicious code detection capabilities. Specifically, the F1-score experiences a significant increase compared to utilizing only the original prototype samples.

title: Integrated Spatiotemporal Multiscale-Multiphysics-Uncertainty Simulation for Controlling Variability in RRAM Devices_supp2-3633067.pdf
authors: ZHIHENG HUANG
abstract: Resistive random access memory (RRAM) is a leading candidate for next-generation nonvolatile memory and neuromorphic computing. However, its performance is limited by inherent switching variability and uncertainties in spatiotemporal multiscale materials and processes. This study integrates multiphysics and multiscale modeling with uncertainty quantification (UQ) to systematically address these limitations and reduce uncertainties. UQ identifies critical inputs that govern key performance metrics, including the on/off ratio, forming voltage, and power consumption, reducing their statistical distributions with the probabilities of reliability analysis over 92%. The phase field model captures the morphological evolution of conductive filament (CF) and, by incorporating a second-order time derivative for ion diffusion, reveals the impact of morphological fluctuations governing RRAM behavior. Drift diffusion simulations further demonstrate that bilayer structures confine CF fractures to the HfO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> layer through interfacial constraints. This modeling framework provides a systematic approach to mitigate variability and improve the design and reliability of RRAM devices.

title: Fast 3D Partial Boundary Data EIT Reconstructions using Direct Inversion CGO-based Methods
authors: S. J. Hamilton, P. A. Muller, V. Kolehmainen, J. Toivanen
abstract: Objective: To develop, and test, a fast image 3D reconstruction method for partial boundary data electrical impedance tomographic absolute and time-difference imaging. Methods: Two complex geometrical optics based methods are presented: Calerón's method which employs a linear Fourier transform, and the texp method which makes use of a tailor-made nonlinear Fourier transform. The methods are tested on simulated and experimental data, and their reconstructions compared to reference reconstructions from standard linear difference imaging and total variation regularization. Results: The proposed methods provide good localization of targets, for both absolute and time-difference imaging, when large portions of the domain are inaccessible for measurement, e.g., stroke monitoring. Conclusion: The proposed algorithms require no iteration and provide informative absolute or time-difference images exceptionally quickly in under 2 seconds for complicated domain shapes. The algorithms perform well under high levels of noise and incorrect domain modeling. Significance: As most medical applications of electrical impedance tomography are limited to partial boundary data, the development of partial boundary algorithms is highly desirable. While iterative schemes have been used traditionally, their high computational cost can make them cost-prohibitive for applications that need fast imaging.

title: Reimagining Extended Reality (XR) Innovation: A Critical Study of the Finnish Ecosystem
authors: Janset Shawash, Mattia Thibault, Juho Hamari
publish: Proceedings of the 28th International Academic Mindtrek
abstract: Extended Reality (XR) ecosystems globally face persistent fragmentation and adoption challenges despite significant technological advances and investment. Finland, with demonstrated strengths in XR-enabling technologies, presents a compelling case of ecosystem development within a small innovation economy context. Through 15 semi-structured interviews with 18 ecosystem actors across public, private, and cultural sectors, analyzed using thematic analysis guided by innovation ecosystem theory and interpretive institutionalism, this study identifies six ecosystem archetypes and five key structural dimensions. Findings reveal two critical tensions: the gap between piloting and sustained implementation, and the conflict between scalability pressures and local value creation. The study shows that ecosystem survival depends heavily on informal "Ecosystem Connector" roles and "Invisible Intermediary" functions that compensate for structural deficiencies. This critical analysis contributes to innovation ecosystem theory by demonstrating how small innovation economies rely on relationship-based coordination and multi-archetype individuals rather than formal platform orchestration.

title: Performance Exploration of High Gain Antenna for Terahertz Applications
authors: Vismaya Vijayan, Titto Anujan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: High-gain dipole antennas in the terahertz (THZ) frequency range ($0.1-10 \mathrm{THZ}$) need to be constructed and optimised for new applications in high-speed communication, imaging, and sensing. This study examines the performance of a high-gain dipole antenna with same substrate and various dipole materials in order to increase efficiency, impedance matching, and radiation characteristics. Full-wave electromagnetic simulations are used to investigate the effects of different material properties including conductivity, permittivity, and loss factors. To determine the optimal material combinations, critical performance metrics including as gain, bandwidth, radiation efficiency, and return loss are evaluated. The results show how crucial material selection is for decreasing losses and improving antenna performance at THZ frequencies. The findings provide vital new information for developing practical and useful THZ antennas for next-generation wireless and sensor technologies.

title: Analysis and Detection of Autism Spectrum Disorder Using Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Parul Dubey, Pushkar Dubey, Nitin Rakesh, Sumit Prasad, Srijan Pateriya, Krupali Dhawale
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental condition that affects communication, social interaction, and behavior. With growing interest in AI-driven healthcare, machine learning techniques offer promising solutions for early and accurate ASD detection. However, conventional diagnostic methods are often subjective, time-consuming, and inconsistent, especially across varying age groups. The need for scalable, data-driven approaches remains critical for improving diagnostic precision. This study utilizes three publicly available non-clinical datasets from the UCI Machine Learning Repository, covering ASD screenings for adults, children, and adolescents. Multiple machine learning models—Logistic Regression, SVM, KNN, Naïve Bayes, ANN—and a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) were implemented for classification. The CNN architecture was designed to capture abstract behavioral patterns effectively across age groups. The novelty of this study lies in the cross-age, model-wise comparison using identical preprocessing and evaluation pipelines. Model performance was assessed using accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. The results demonstrate that the CNN model outperformed all others, achieving up to 99.53% accuracy, highlighting its robustness and effectiveness for ASD detection across diverse demographics.

title: Numerical Methods for Generating I-V Curves for Solar Cells while Considering the Three-Diode Model
authors: Oscar Danilo Montoya, Juan Diego Pulgarín Rivera, Carlos Andrès Torres-Pinzón
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: The accurate modeling of photovoltaic (PV) cells is critical for optimizing performance and reliability in solar energy systems. This study focuses on the three-diode model, an advanced representation that captures multiple recombination mechanisms, including trap-assisted and depletion-region effects. Due to the nonlinear and transcendental nature of the model’s current-voltage (I-V) equation, analytical solutions are intractable, requiring robust numerical techniques. This work implements and evaluates five classical root-finding algorithms (the bisection, false position, Secant, Newton-Raphson, and Halley methods) to solve this equation and reconstruct I-V and power-voltage ($\mathbf{P}-\mathbf{V}$) curves under standard testing conditions. Simulation results show that Halley’s method offers the best performance in terms of speed and convergence, while bracketing methods provide superior robustness. The findings support the informed selection of methods for high-fidelity PV modeling and real-time applications.

title: Memristor Differential Pair Ternary Weight Neural (TWN) Network Architecture
authors: Yi Zhu, Dinesh Pamunuwa, Roshan Weerasekera
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Matrix multiplication is a computationally intensive task, and existing neural network training approaches often require substantial energy and time due to frequent data movement between memory and processing units in traditional von Neumann architectures. This inefficiency has prompted growing interest in alternative computational paradigms. In this work, we present the design and implementation of a ternary-weight memristive architecture employing memristor differential pairs for image classification tasks. The proposed system utilizes weight columns composed exclusively of ternary values (−1,0, and 1), thereby significantly reducing programming complexity and time. Simulation results demonstrate that, relative to full-precision implementations, the proposed architecture achieves enhanced computational efficiency while maintaining a classification accuracy of 96%, underscoring its potential for future edge computing applications.

title: A Deep Learning Framework for Verilog Autocompletion Towards Design and Verification Automation
authors: Enrique Dehaerne, Bappaditya Dey, Sandip Halder, Stefan De Gendt
abstract: Innovative Electronic Design Automation (EDA) solutions are crucial for meeting the design requirements of increasingly complex electronic devices. Verilog, a hardware description language, is widely used for the design and verification of digital circuits and is synthesized using specific EDA tools. However, writing code is a repetitive and time-intensive task. This paper proposes a deep learning framework for training a Verilog auto-completion model along with a dataset of Verilog code files and snippets from open-source repositories. The framework involves integrating models pretrained on general programming language data and finetuning them on a dataset curated to be similar to a target downstream task. This is validated by comparing different pretrained models trained on different subsets of the proposed Verilog dataset using multiple evaluation metrics. These experiments demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves better BLEU, ROUGE-L, and chrF scores by 9.5%, 6.7%, and 6.9%, respectively, compared to a model trained from scratch. This validates our framework, which has already inspired more recent related works.

title: Computer-Aided Detection of Milia Skin Condition in Infants from Dermoscopic Image Using Pre-Trained CNN
authors: Stephanie Noronha, Niva Naik, Mayuri A. Mehta, Shailja Alpeshbhai Patel
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Milia in infants is a skin rash characterized as small, yellow, and white superficial cysts. It commonly occurs on the face in fifty percent of infants and also on other parts of the body. Early diagnosis of milia is required in infants as milia may affect the infants' skin with permanent injury or damage. In recent years, deep learning has led to substantial advancements in medical image processing, which helps dermatologists detect dermatological diseases more precisely and in less time. However, very few methods are available for the computerized detection of milia. This paper offers a novel approach for Computer-Aided Detection of Milia in Infants (CAD-MI). The proposed CAD-MI approach detects the presence/absence of milia in infants from a dermoscopic image. Its performance is tested with various pre-trained CNN models including Inception V3, VGG-16, AlexNet, and ResNet50 under various experimental settings. In addition, it is evaluated by considering low-resolution and blurry dermoscopic images to show the effectiveness. It exhibits high performance in classifying milia and normal skin condition from dermoscopic image with a classification accuracy of 93%. Thus, the proposed CAD-MI exhibits reliable performance in detecting milia in infants with improved diagnostic accuracy.

title: Vehicular to Vehicular Communications-Based Low-Profile Antenna Array
authors: Deven Patanvariya, Rajendrakumar Patel, Yogesh Solunke
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This paper introduces a compact, dual-layer microstrip patch antenna and its corresponding array, specifically designed for vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication within the Dedicated Short-Range Communications (DSRC) band at 5.9 GHz. The single antenna element achieves a bandwidth of 500 MHz, while the array configuration offers a bandwidth of 340 MHz. To ensure optimal impedance matching and enhanced performance, a Wilkinson power divider is employed in the array design. The proposed antenna and array exhibit gains of 6.84 dBi and 9.36 dBi, respectively, with radiation efficiencies exceeding 95%. Comprehensive range estimations have been conducted across various environments, demonstrating the suitability of these designs for reliable V2V communication in intelligent transportation systems.

title: Brain Disease Detection Using Image Processing and Machine Learning: A Review
authors: Neha Rai, Vikas Sakalle
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The combined approach of image processing and machine learning has drastically change the analysis and diag-nosis of brain diseases, offering unprecedented precision and efficiency in medical imaging. This review presents various methodologies of brain tumor identification which uses image processing and machine learning as well. Effective use of image processing techniques plays a critical role in isolating relevant patterns from complex brain images obtained through modal-ities like MRI, CT scans. With the advancement in machine learning algorithms, specifically deep learning models, enhance diagnostic accuracy without dependent on the feature extraction. The synergy between these technologies has enabled automated systems capable of early detection, reducing human error, and aiding clinicians in decision-making. However, challenges remain in terms of data standardization, analysis of models to be used for particular case as their is a need for large datasets with proper annotation. This review emphasizes the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration and the potential of emerging techniques to address these challenges.

title: A Novel Multidimensional Approach for Enhancing Aromatic and Medicinal Plant Classification Using Texture and Chemical Composition Features with Deep Learning
authors: Shareena Elavumchalil Moideen, D Abraham Chandy
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This work combines texture analysis and chemical composition profiling to compare the properties of aromatic and medicinal plant species. The combination of texture features, extracted using the Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM), and four chemical composition features, such as alkaloids, flavonoids, tannins, and saponins, is utilized. Initially, we analyzed the statistical properties of these combined features using the similarity matrix, Euclidean distance, and cosine similarity, revealing insights into the diversity and similarity across species. Boxplots and feature correlation analysis offer a deeper understanding of how texture and chemical characteristics interact in species classification and clustering. These findings provide new insights into plant identification and classification, based on multidimensional data. Finally, we developed a deep learning model for leaf image classification using the ResNet50 architecture. The performance characteristics using texture features alone and both texture and chemical features are analysed. The model trained on both types of features achieved significantly higher classification accuracy compared to models based solely on texture data. This approach offers a more reliable and comprehensive tool for plant identification, with potential applications in agriculture, pharmaceuticals, and botany.

title: Performance Analysis of Machine Learning Algorithms for Predicting Cryptocurrency Trends
authors: Kassem Al-Attabi, Devanand Ramachandran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: A strong demand has emerged for predictive models that enable investors to make informed decisions in volatile cryptocurrency markets. A variety of machine learning algorithms are analysed in this study in order to predict the price trend of major cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, Ethereum, Litecoin, Ripple, Nem, and Stellar, using Support Vector Machines (SVMs), Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), Deep Learning (DL), and an enhanced Proposed Model. Preprocessed Yahoo Finance data was used to train and evaluate these models using RMSE, MAE, and R2. To improve model performance, advanced techniques such as GridSearchCV were employed. The proposed model consistently outperforms traditional models across different cryptocurrencies, particularly in the cases of Nem and Stellar, according to the results. A tailored machine learning approach can improve trend prediction in the highly dynamic and speculative crypto market.

title: Design and Comparative analysis of High-Frequency Multiplying Delay Locked Loop (MDLL) with Phase Detector Comparisons
authors: Deeksha K M, Latha P
abstract: A Multiplying Delay-Locked Loop (MDLL) with low jitter and high Frequency is presented in this paper. It is intended for high-precision Time-to-Digital Conversion (TDC) or any other high-performance applications, such as wireless communication, radar systems, and others. Better current matching between charging and discharging is ensured by the charge pump (CP) and phase detector (PD), also the comparison of the Phase Detector is done and have obtained best architecture for the desired operations and applications, where the reduce phase noise of the Reference clock is also archived. The multi-phase clock's resolution is increased by an improved Voltage Controlled Delay cell structure (VCDL). In cadence virtuoso, which was made using a 45nm CMOS Technology.

title: A Novel Layout-Circuit Co-Design Framework for Radiation Hardening in Nanoscale Technology
authors: Aobo Cui, Eleonora Vacca, Luca Sterpone, Sarah Azimi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Electronic components in space are vulnerable to radiation-induced Single-Event Effects (SEEs). This work proposes a mitigation methodology combining layout- and circuit-level analysis with targeted hardening. First, radiationinduced charge deposition through the device stack is characterized and converted into equivalent transient current pulses, yielding Single-Event Transient (SET) profiles for the given technology and topology. These profiles drive circuitlevel fault injection to identify sensitive nodes, which are selectively hardened via layout modifications. Applied to a 15 nm 2:1 multiplexer, the approach improves SEE resilience with minimal delay, power, and area penalties. The hardened design increases the error threshold current by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.69 \times$</tex> and reduces SET duration by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 39 {\%}$</tex>.

title: An Enhanced Multimodal Sentiment Analysis Model Based on Capsule and GRU Deep Neural Network for Predicting Consumer Purchase Behavior Pattern
authors: M Krishna Kishore, Subhani Shaik, Bhavani Sankar Panda
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Analysing multimodal sentiment Analysis data for exploration on industrial growth and social media is crucial to inducing consumer behavior and purchasing strategies. Based on CapsNet and GRU, this paper describes a DNN for consumer purchase prediction by capturing text, image, and meta-information from social platforms. CapsNet can extract spatial and hierarchical features, and GRU can capture sequential sentiment patterns. The model combines Amazon and Flipkart product reviews while resolving class imbalance and fine-tuning parameters to improve performance. Results from experiments indicate that the model outperforms LSTM and CNN-RNN models in accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score and AUC of 0.992, 0.982, 0.985, 0.987, and 0.99, respectively. This model has the potential to improve sentiment Analysis, minimize marketing expenditures, and optimize customer experience, thus making this a solution that is promising for e-commerce.

title: Leveraging Machine Learning Techniques for Proactive Regulatory (RegTech) Compliance in Financial Landscape
authors: Godavari Modalavalasa
abstract: Financial institutions require Regulatory Technology or RegTech as their essential tool to handle regulatory compliance challenges while operating in digital finance systems. The application of innovative technological solutions via regulatory technology accelerates the quality and speed of compliance operational performance. This research paper evaluates all aspects of RegTech solutions designed for financial industry regulatory compliance and discusses the implementation of AI and machine learning approaches in detail. Accounting for its special implementation an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) model detects fraudulent credit card activity within European dataset. The model shows outstanding results through its 97.86% accuracy combined with 99.9% precision and recall and F1-score and 1.00 AUC from the ROC curve verification. The proposal advocates solutions to existing obstacles through developing standardized international protocols and scalable system modules and AI and IoT-based sector-transformation strategies. The research demonstrates that academic institutions and businesses need stronger partnerships to achieve practical applications while investigating how new technology will affect regulatory compliance in the long run. Research outcomes from this study will allow future developments of RegTech automation technologies that fight fraud and transform banking procedures.

title: Integrated Electroforming of Memristor Cells in Crossbar Arrays
authors: Ricardo Heinen, Jonas Zoche, Ralf Wunderlich, Stefan Heinen
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Memristive devices based on the valence change mechanism, employed in crossbar arrays for analog vec-tor-matrix multiplication, require an electroforming step to activate resistive switching. In this work, an array topology and the required circuitry for on-chip electroforming are presented. Measurements demonstrate successful electroforming of targeted devices, while isolating the rest of the array and preserving the voltage limits of CMOS access transistors. This integrated solution eliminates the area and hardware overhead of conventional electroforming with external circuitry.

title: A Highly Reliable Radiation-Aware SRAM Design for Aerospace Applications
authors: Pushpa Raikwal, Sateesh Kourav
abstract: In this manuscript, a Soft Error-Aware Radiation Hardened 12T (SARH-12T) SRAM cell has been proposed for space applications. It can withstand against single event upset (SEU) and shows fast recovery by including two pairs of stacked PMOSs (P1, P5 and P2, P6) in pull up network and two NMOSs (N2 and N3) in pull down networks along with 6T SRAM cell. The proposed SARH-12T is compared with already existing radiation hardened cells, RHRD-12T SRAM, RSP-14T SRAM and RHD-12T SRAM cells. It proved itself more reliable against SEU, highly stable at various modes of operations and faster than other referred cells. The read static noise margin (RSNM) of the proposed SARH-12T is 150.98%, 93.93%, and 113.33% improved, hold static noise margin (HSNM) is 11.91%, 12.72%, and 4.377% improved and write static noise margin (WSNM) shows 38.82%, 31.11, and 36.25% improvement than RHRD-12T cell, RSP-14T, RHD-12T cell respectively. Additionally, the proposed RH-12T cell shows fast recovery time of 47.05%, 43.75%, and 18.18% as compared to RHRD-12T, RSP-14T, RHD-12T cell respectively. The SARH-12T is designed using Spice at 65-nm CMOS technology at 1V of supply at the operating temperature of 27°C.

title: Development of AI-Powered Exoskeletons for Mobility Impaired Patients
authors: Pratik Patil, Priya Dasarwar, Saurabh Bhattacharya, Sridhar Reddy Surukanti, G. M. Vaidya, Chandrashekhar Ramesh Ramtirthkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The creation of exoskeletons driven by AI has a huge potential to help people who have trouble moving around and improve their quality of life. The personal robotic devices, which use advanced sensor technologies and artificial intelligence, can completely change the lives of people with a wide range of conditions, such as spinal cord injuries, stroke, and neurodegenerative diseases. The goal of AI-driven exoskeletons is to improve both physical and mental health by letting people move around on their own again. This essay looks at the design, usefulness, and effects of exoskeletons driven by AI. It focusses on how machine learning methods can be used to improve movement patterns and adjust to the user's needs. The AI system looks at real-time data from sensors built into the exoskeleton. This lets the motor functions be changed on the fly to improve balance and walking. This study also looks into the problems that come up when trying to make these kinds of systems, like how long the batteries last, how comfortable the users are, and the need for individual customization. Exoskeletons have been shown to help with physical therapy and make patients more independent in clinical trials and case studies. In addition, the paper talks about the future of AI exoskeletons, focussing on how ongoing progress in AI, robots, and biomechanics will make these devices more useful and easy to use. As new technologies are developed, AI-powered exoskeletons could change the way therapy is done and help people with movement problems stay mobile for a long time. This could be a step towards more inclusive healthcare solutions.

title: A New Control Strategy for Three-Phase Inverters with Maximum Power Injection Under anUnbalanced or Two-Phase Grid
authors: Mokhtar Abbassi, Abdelkarim Aouiti, Faouzi Bacha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: In three-phase photovoltaic (PV) generators connected to the grid without a neutral, ensuring energy quality is crucial especially in networks affected by unbalanced grid voltages. Such conditions typically lead to double-frequency power fluctuations, exacerbating ripples in active and reactive power as well as in the DC bus voltage. These issues can result in power shortages or even grid disconnection.To address these challenges, this paper introduces an advanced control approach specifically designed for PV system inverters connected to the grid. The proposed method is capable of injecting maximum active power even in a two-phase system. To validate the effectiveness and performance of the proposed control scheme, simulations have been conducted. The obtained results demonstrate that the injected current remains balanced, exhibits a sinusoidal waveform with low Total Harmonic Distortion (THD), and ensures stable active power under various fluctuation scenarios, including the disconnection of one phase.

title: Thermal-EXAMINER: IP Extraction from MAGIC Logic-in-Memory Using Thermal Side-Channel Attacks
authors: L. Pfeifer, A. Weiler, J.S. Haas, R. Leupers, J.M. Joseph
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Memristors have become an important post-CMOS technology that enables new computing paradigms such as logic-in-memory (LIM) with MAGIC. It employs binary switching states to implement basic logic functions. These new processing paradigms come with new hardware security challenges. In this paper, we investigate how the netlist of confidential IP, implemented using LIM, can be reverse engineered using a thermal side-channel. We propose a recovery algorithm, which iteratively recommends thermal side-channel attacks to run until the full netlist is recovered. We show how this attack can recover most of the ISCAS85 benchmarks in less than 900 iterations.

title: An AI-based Energy Management System For The Grid Integration of Energy Storage and Hybrid Devices
authors: Srikanth D, G Durga Sukumar, R Ramanjan Prasad, K Vishnu, Koorapati Rajashekhar
abstract: The paper titled "An AI-Based Energy Management System for the Grid Integration of Energy Storage and Hybrid Devices" investigates artificial intelligence’s role in regulating and enhancing the power production of combined energy systems. These systems integrate various energy generation sources like solar and wind, alongside other renewables or traditional forms, to create a more stable and efficient energy solution. Nevertheless, this integration also brings about challenges in controlling and harmonizing the outputs from these diverse sources. Artificial intelligence steps in here, with AI controllers within an energy management system fine-tuning energy distribution in grid-linked hybrid systems. The AI controller navigates these complexities to ensure optimal utilization of each energy source. Incorporating energy storage units is crucial to this system. They are pivotal in smoothing out the fluctuating nature of renewable energies, thus delivering an uninterrupted electricity supply to consumers. The suggested design underwent testing through MATLAB simulations across different operational conditions. The outcomes affirm the system’s capability to handle hybrid systems’ energy production effectively, guaranteeing a dependable electricity provision.

title: $300 \text{mV}-V_{D D}$, nw-Power, ST-DIGOTA Using I/O Devices in FinFET Technology
authors: Alexandra Matos, Ricardo Machado, Pedro Toledo, Miguel Coelho, Rafael Ferreira, Rafael Martins, Boyapati Subrahmanyam, João P. Oliveira, Luis B. Oliveira, José Soares Augusto
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: This work presents an optimized design of a nano-Watt Schmitt Trigger-based Digital Operational Transconductance Amplifier (ST-DIGOTA) implemented using high voltage devices in 16 nm CMOS FinFET technology. To address the dominant leakage currents that impact ultra-low-power circuits in advanced nodes, I/O devices are employed for the first time in a DIGOTA design as a design strategy to reduce the power consumption. The proposed circuit operates at a 0.3 V supply while driving a 350 pF capacitive load, achieving 6 nW power consumption and a DC gain of 50 dB within a compact <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$130 \mu m^{2}$</tex> layout area. Compared to prior 16 nm DIGOTA implementations, this represents a significant power reduction while preserving similar gain. Unlike previous state-of-the-art sub-nW OTAs that target only small capacitive loads (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<10 \text{pF}$</tex>), this work demonstrates nanowatt-level operation at large capacitive loads, highlighting its suitability for energy-constrained biomedical and IoT applications where bandwidth requirements are modest.

title: Modified Energy Management System for Virtual Power Plant Applications
authors: Ismail Aboelhassan, Radwa Almetwally, Yuwei Jin, Shuang Xu, Liuchen Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The rapid growth in renewable energy resources (RES) is reshaping power systems technically and economically by influencing the grid stability and electricity prices. As a result, the implementation of advanced strategies such as virtual power plants (VPPs) are crucial for optimal electricity net profit and ensuring a stable system. This paper proposes a day-ahead optimal scheduling using a rule-based energy management system (REMS). By explicitly integrating market price fluctuations into the decision-making algorithm, the proposed method optimizes energy production, storage, and trading strategies to maximize profitability. Compared with traditional energy management systems (TEMS) that typically prioritize operational stability over economic performance, the proposed method brings higher profit potential to VPPs while maintaining system constraints. The proposed adaptive rule structure emulates optimal scheduling behavior without the computational complexity of mathematical programming, making it suitable for both day-ahead scheduling and real-time market participation. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated using the IEEE 33-node distribution network.

title: AI-Driven Predictive Analytics for Optimizing Organ Donation Matching
authors: V.H. Karambelkar, M Sudhakar, K. Gavhale, Deepak Suresh Asudani, S. V. Haarshith Reddy, Gousoddin Imamoddin Shaikh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Organ transplants can save lives, but only if organ donors and receivers are a good match. Traditional ways of matching organ donors with recipients take a long time and rely on limited clinical data, which can cause problems like late matches and less-than-ideal organ use. This study shows a new AI-powered predictive analytics system that can help find the best organ donors and recipients by using machine learning models to guess which pairs will be the best matches based on many factors. The model uses a lot of different types of data, like medical background, organ match, region, and patient-specific factors, to predict how likely it is that the transplant will go well. The framework finds trends in big, complicated datasets using advanced methods like decision trees, random forests, and neural networks. It then gives real-time advice on where to put organs. Anonymized data from hospitals and organ donation agencies are used to train and test the prediction model. This makes sure that it meets ethical standards and increases speed at the same time. Our data show that waiting times have gone down significantly, organs are being used more efficiently, and the success rate of transplants has gone up. The AI-based method looks like it will not only make the current system for organ donation better, but it will also open the door to new ideas in personalized medicine and transplant care in the future. Real-time data integration can make this system even better by making it flexible enough to change to changing patient needs and medical situations. Overall, the study shows how AI could change the field of organ donation, which would improve patient results and make better use of healthcare resources.

title: Hardware-Software Co-Design for Efficient LLM Inference on PCIe-Based FPGAs Using Coarse-Grained Systolic Arrays
authors: Yun-Nan Chang
abstract: Inference of large language models (LLMs) requires extensive matrix-multiplication operations that place heavy demands on both compute and memory resources. Traditional systolic arrays (SAs), typically built from scalar multiply-accumulate processing elements (PEs), exhibit low compute density and high routing overhead when scaled to support the large matrix dimensions of transformer-based models. To address these limitations, we present a hardware-software co-design approach that introduces a coarse-grained "Big PE" architecture for FPGA acceleration. Each Big PE performs a complete 4 × 4 matrix multiplication per clock cycle using sixteen parallel multipliers and local accumulators, significantly reducing inter-PE communication and flip-flop usage. We implement a 2×32 array of these Big PEs on a Xilinx Alveo U55 FPGA and tightly integrate the design into the open-source Llama2 inference framework using an XDMA PCIe–AXI bridge. Experimental evaluation with an 8-bit quantized TinyStories-15M LLM shows more than 2.15× improvement in token processing speed during the prompt stage compared to a CPU-only baseline, with no degradation in output quality. Under a fixed budget of 4,096 DSP multipliers, our SA reduces the cycle count for 64 × 64 matrix multiplication from 190 to approximately 120 cycles and cuts total flip-flop usage from 194,560 to 45,056. These results highlight the benefits of hardware-software co-design in deploying LLM inference on resource-constrained FPGA platforms and suggest promising directions for optimizing on-chip memory hierarchies and enabling multi-FPGA scalability.

title: Optimized Renewable Energy Integration for EV Charging with Boost Integrated Luo Converter and SALP Swarm ANN MPPT Control
authors: R. Tharwin Kumar, C. Christober Asir Rajan
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: As the demand for Electric Vehicles (EVs) continues to rise, integrating efficient charging solutions powered by RES, particularly Photovoltaic (PV) systems, becomes increasingly vital. However, its intermittent and nonlinear nature requires advanced control strategies to maximize energy harvesting and ensure reliable charging performance. To address these challenges, this work proposes an optimized renewable energy integration framework that combines a high-gain Boost Integrated Luo Converter with a Salp Swarm Optimization (SSO) enhanced Artificial Neural Network (SALP-ANN) based Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) controller. A MPPT controller based on an SSO-ANN is used to optimize energy extraction from the PV system. A Proportional Integral (PI) controller regulates the bidirectional DC-DC converter to ensure stable operation and enhanced energy management. The system’s performance is rigorously considered using MATLAB simulations, demonstrating its ability to provide rapid and flexible EV charging solutions. Notably, the SSO-ANN MPPT controller achieves a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of $\mathbf{1. 5 2 \%}$. This research underscores the transformative potential of hybrid renewable energy systems in optimizing energy management practices for EV charging, particularly in urban environments.

title: Fuzzy Segmentations Fusion for Skin-line Detection in Mammographic Images
authors: Karim Kalti, Asma Touil
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel approach based on segmentations fusion to accurately detect the breast skin-line in mammographic images. The segmentation used methods are the Breast Skin-Line Segmentation with transition Points Detection (BSTPD) method and the Iterative Fuzzy Breast Segmentation (IFBS) method [1]. Given the inherent ambiguity associated with breast skin-line detection in mammographic images, we chose to leverage fuzzy theory for the fusion process. To enhance the precision of breast skin-line pixel extraction, we geometrically estimate the membership functions based on the offset separating some particular transition points defined on the intensity profile of the breast pixels. The complementarity of the individual results of the considered segmentation methods justified the use of a disjunctive operator to obtain the final segmented breast image. The performance of the proposed approach was assessed using the Mammogram Image Analysis Society (mini-MIAS) database. Both qualitative and quantitative evaluations prove the reliability of our method and its ability to overcome the limitations of each individual segmentation method.

title: Kidney and Kidney Tumor Segmentation from 3D CT Scan Using SAM-2 Model
authors: Pawankumar Navinchandra, Yashesh P. Patel, Vijay S. Singh, Mayuri A. Mehta
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Segmenting kidney tumors from 3D CT scans is vital for early diagnosis and treatment. The conventional methods for kidney tumor segmentation rely on medical imaging and traditional image processing. The crucial challenges of conventional methods are the requirement of manual annotation, which is time-consuming and prone to human error. Modern machine learning and deep learning-based methods automate the segmentation process. Deep learning-based methods excel in multilabel segmentation, yielding more accurate results than machine learning-based methods. However, these methods require large annotated datasets, are task-specific, and lack generalization across various imaging conditions. Hence, this paper proposes a new method for kidney and kidney tumor segmentation using a transformer-based Segment Anything Model 2 (SAM-2) model. The performance is analysed against the encoder-decoder-based DeepLabv3+ model. The KiTS23 dataset is utilized to assess segmentation performance. Evaluation metrics such as loss and Intersection over Union (IoU) are used for comparison. The experimental results show that the SAM-2 outperforms DeepLabv3+, leading by 6.91 % in IoU during training, with improvements of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1. 2 8 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{0. 9 9 \%}$</tex> in training and validation loss, respectively.

title: Adaptive AI Systems for Real- Time Vital Sign Monitoring
authors: Nitin N. Jadhav, Deepak Suresh Asudani, P. A. Deshkar, Gandloju Sravanthi, Patil Dipesh Madhukar Monika, Netaji Gangaram Achwalkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Adaptive AI systems have changed real-time vital sign tracking by making it possible to do accurate, ongoing, and personalized health checks. Advanced machine learning algorithms and monitor technologies work together in these systems to track and analyses vital signs like temperature, heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen levels in real time. Unlike traditional static monitoring systems, adaptable AI systems use data sources to change tracking limits and recognition methods in real time. This makes sure that they are as accurate as possible for all patient types and conditions. Integrating flexible AI into vital sign monitoring has many benefits, such as making it easier to spot problems early, making better decisions, and being able to adjust actions. By constantly learning from new data, these systems can change to each patient's unique health profile. This lets doctors make more accurate guesses about when a patient's health will get worse and act on them more quickly. These systems also allow for online patient tracking, which means that nurses don't have to be with patients all the time. This is especially helpful in critical care settings and for managing long-term illnesses. This essay looks at how flexible AI systems have been created and how they are used in vital sign tracking. It focuses on how these systems affect healthcare delivery, patient safety, and business efficiency. Important problems like data protection, computer bias, and system stability are also talked about, which helps us understand how to get past these problems so that they can be widely used. It is looked at how real-time data integration, cloud computing, and edge computing can improve system performance and scaling. This makes a case for the future of AI-driven tracking in a variety of healthcare settings.

title: Research on Data Cleaning Techniques in Power Data Quality Monitoring
authors: Min Chen, Ying Li, Fei Huang
abstract: With the acceleration of the digitalization process of smart grids, the quality of power data directly affects the reliability of grid operation and the accuracy of decision-making. In response to the problems of low detection accuracy and poor repair efficiency in traditional data cleaning techniques for processing multi-source heterogeneous power data, this study proposes an intelligent data cleaning framework that integrates an improved isolated forest algorithm and an adaptive BP neural network. By constructing attribute correlation grouping strategies and improving the Isolation Forest algorithm to jointly partition strongly correlated attributes in power data, the anomaly detection rate was increased from 88.2% to 89.7%, and the AUC value was optimized to 0.93 ; The adaptive BP neural network dynamically adjusts the learning rate based on gradients, reducing the root mean square error of data repair by 18.3% and decreasing the number of training iterations by 53%. At the same time, a collaborative architecture of edge computing and cloud is designed to ensure that the processing time of a single piece of data is stable within 12.7ms, meeting the real-time monitoring needs of the power grid. In the UCI standard dataset and actual substation data testing, the detection and repair performance of this framework is significantly better than traditional methods and classical machine learning schemes. The research results provide an efficient solution for power data quality monitoring, and in the future, the adaptability of algorithms in complex working conditions can be further improved by integrating density sensing mechanisms and deep learning models.

title: Exploring Blackhole Attacks and Security Countermeasures by Using RPL in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Ayasha Malik, Veena Parihar, Unnati Sharma, Om Prakash Suthar
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are extensively utilized across various applications due to their capability to collect and transmit data from remote or hard-to-reach areas. Nevertheless, their fundamental limitations render them susceptible to multiple security threats. Among these threats, the blackhole attack represents a considerable danger, wherein a malicious node deceitfully claims to provide the shortest path to a destination and discards all intercepted data packets, impairing the network's operation. WSNs consist of numerous small sensor nodes or motes, which can be randomly deployed in diverse environments. These nodes communicate using a low-power wireless communication medium, as they are significantly constrained in terms of resources. Due to these limitations, nodes within WSNs must collaborate to form a multi-hop network, allowing data to be transmitted across several nodes to reach the sink node. Such radio communications are vulnerable to various attacks. A prevalent Denial of Service (DoS) attack in WSNs is the Blackhole Attack, which engages in the routing process to receive packets from neighbouring motes, only to discard them instead of forwarding them to the intended destination. This type of attack is typically challenging to detect and defend against. In this study, various security schemes have been examined, and through simulations conducted on Contiki's network simulator Cooja, the effects of the Blackhole attack on ContikiRPL (Routing Protocol for Low Power and Lossy Networks) have been analyzed, focusing on performance metrics such as average power consumption, packet reception count, expected transmission count, and hop count.

title: Dual-Timescale Caching and Offloading Optimization for Semantic Edge Computing
authors: Xiaojing Chen, Jia Xu, Wei Ni, Zhijin Qin, Dusit Niyato, Yanzan Sun, Shunqing Zhang
abstract: Effective resource allocation is crucial to the efficiency of semantic edge computing (SEC), especially when faced with constrained energy, radio and computational resources. The unique characteristics of SEC, e.g., the demand of multi-task execution and the finite cache capacity of edge servers (ESs), have brought new challenges to the optimization of resource allocation. This paper presents a new dual-timescale deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based resource allocation algorithm aimed at minimizing the long-term average cost of SEC systems. Specifically, cache configurations are learned in the large timescale using Binary Particle Swarm Optimization (BPSO). In the small timescale, task offloading and computation strategies are distributively determined at local devices through Multi-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization (MAPPO), reducing signaling overhead and offering scalability and reliability. Simulations show that the proposed algorithm reduces the system cost by 33.8% compared to the benchmarks, and can adapt to both latency-sensitive and energy-sensitive tasks by fine-tuning the weighting coefficient.

title: A Novel Phase Calibration Method for Airborne P-, L-, and S-band SAR Tomography Based on Weighted Phase Gradient Autofocus
authors: Longxiang Wang, Wei Xiang, Hongjun Song, Heng Zhang, Mingjie Zheng, Jili Wang, Fengli Xue, Zhanyang Ai, Yunkai Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Airborne Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) Tomography (TomoSAR) technology facilitates the extraction of three-dimensional (3D) information of target scatterers. However, phase screens induced by radar platform trajectory errors causes TomoSAR defocusing, which adversely affects the accuracy of the forest vertical structure retrieval. Additionally, the phase screens exhibit space-variant characteristics, which significantly degrade the calibration performance estimated by traditional phase gradient autofocus (PGA). This paper proposes an improved phase calibration method synthesizing unconstrained optimization model and weighted PGA (WPGA), which effectively address the above challenges. Firstly, the SAR data stack is segmented into multiple subareas by assuming that phase screens are space-invariant within each small area, which reduces complexity and improves computational efficiency. Secondly, a WPGA method synthesizing the scatterer heights derived from an unconstrained optimization model is proposed to estimate the phase screens. Simulation experiments are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed phase calibration method. Furthermore, the full-polarization SAR data stacks acquired by the BorTomoSAR campaign are used for tomographic focusing analysis. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method accurately estimates the phase screens at the P, L, and S bands, providing a efficient solution for the forest vertical structure retrieval.

title: Transparent Lifting Assistance Strategy for Arm Exoskeletons Using an Adaptive Torque Controller_supp1-3616399.pdf
authors: Long Cheng
abstract: In the field of the exoskeleton-assisted arm lifting, current research faces challenges such as the lack of a mature assistance strategy paradigm and relatively low torque tracking accuracy. To address these issues, we propose an adaptive torque controller based on an interaction torque model guided by a transparent assistance strategy. The torque controller is designed using the robust model predictive control algorithm, with an adaptive network-based fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) to dynamically adjust the controller parameters. The interaction torque model can estimate future interaction torques to support the model predictive controller. Moreover, the transparent assistance strategy guides the design of the interaction torque reference, ensuring the preservation of the user’s natural exertion patterns during the assistance, thereby creating the sensation of lifting a lighter object for the user. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed transparent assistance strategy effectively maintains the user’s natural exertion patterns while providing assistance. In addition, the proposed adaptive torque controller significantly enhances the torque control accuracy.

title: Improve Dynamic Voltage Build-Up Control Based on Power Boundary Analysis for PM-A Reluctance Starter/Generator in MEA
authors: Di Liu, Wubin Kong, Lufan Ren, Zirui Liu, Zimin Li, Hengyang Liu, Zhiqiang Wang, Jun Yang
abstract: In more electric aircraft, dynamic voltage build-up (VBU) during the transition state is the key to connecting the starter/generator (S/G) function, but an unreasonable VBU process will lead to slow VBU or even VBU failure. To optimize the VBU and avoid failures, this article proposes an improved dynamic VBU control based on power boundary analysis. First, the dynamic VBU two boundaries are divided: 1) the first boundary, where magnetic field power balances power generation, and the VBU can continue; and 2) the second boundary, where it exceeds power generation, exhausting the power of capacitors and causing the voltage to drop to 0 V, resulting in VBU failure. Then, based on the above boundary constraints, the dynamic components that determine the voltage are constrained and compensated, improving the control method of VBU and avoiding VBU failure. Finally, experiments conducted on a permanent magnet-assisted reluctance S/G system verify the accuracy of the analysis. Compared with the traditional method, the proposed method effectively improves the dynamic performance of the VBU and can shorten the original VBU time by more than 1/2, reducing it by tens of milliseconds, which provides space for compressing the startup time of the engine.

title: Ruggedized Embedded Ultrasound Sensing in Harsh Conditions: eRTIS in the wild
authors: Dennis Laurijssen, Wouter Jansen, Arne Aerts, Walter Daems, Jan Steckel
abstract: We present eRTIS, a rugged, embedded ultrasound sensing system for use in harsh industrial environments. The system features a broadband capacitive transducer and a 32-element MEMS microphone array capable of 2D and 3D beamforming. A modular hardware architecture separates sensing and processing tasks: a high-performance microcontroller handles excitation signal generation and data acquisition, while an NVIDIA Jetson module performs GPU-accelerated signal processing. eRTIS supports external synchronization via a custom controller that powers and coordinates up to six devices, either simultaneously or in a defined sequence. Additional synchronization options include bidirectional triggering and in-band signal injection. A sealed, anodized aluminum enclosure with passive cooling and IP-rated connectors ensures reliability in challenging conditions. Performance is demonstrated in three field scenarios: harbor mooring, off-road robotics, and autonomous navigation in cluttered environments, demonstrates that eRTIS provides robust sensing in situations where optical systems degrade.

title: Integrated Spatiotemporal Multiscale-Multiphysics-Uncertainty Simulation for Controlling Variability in RRAM Devices_supp1-3633067.pdf
authors: ZHIHENG HUANG
abstract: Resistive random access memory (RRAM) is a leading candidate for next-generation nonvolatile memory and neuromorphic computing. However, its performance is limited by inherent switching variability and uncertainties in spatiotemporal multiscale materials and processes. This study integrates multiphysics and multiscale modeling with uncertainty quantification (UQ) to systematically address these limitations and reduce uncertainties. UQ identifies critical inputs that govern key performance metrics, including the on/off ratio, forming voltage, and power consumption, reducing their statistical distributions with the probabilities of reliability analysis over 92%. The phase field model captures the morphological evolution of conductive filament (CF) and, by incorporating a second-order time derivative for ion diffusion, reveals the impact of morphological fluctuations governing RRAM behavior. Drift diffusion simulations further demonstrate that bilayer structures confine CF fractures to the HfO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> layer through interfacial constraints. This modeling framework provides a systematic approach to mitigate variability and improve the design and reliability of RRAM devices.

title: Human-Robot Shared Control Strategy Based on Operator Intent Prediction with Bayesian Filtering
authors: Shiliang Shao, Weimin Hu, Xianyu Shi, Guangjie Han, Ting Wang, Chunhe Song, Chuxi Fang
abstract: Robots are increasingly integrated into daily life as consumer electronics. Leveraging the Internet of Things, humans can remotely control robots that function as edge devices to perform various tasks. With advances in artificial intelligence, robots have acquired a certain level of intelligence and autonomy, enabling them to predict human intentions and assist decision-making processes. This study aims to enhance human–robot interactions by proposing an operator intent prediction (OIP) method based on Bayesian filtering. The OIP method integrates data from multiple observation sources and dynamically adjusts the target transition matrix, enabling real-time updates of the prediction probabilities for each target. Consequently, robots can accurately identify the fluctuating intentions of the operator and respond promptly. To seamlessly integrate human intent with robotic intelligence, a shared control strategy for decision-making based on intention prediction is proposed. This strategy introduces a dynamic shared control weight function that adjusts human and robot contributions in real time according to changes in the predicted probabilities of target intentions. This adaptive approach ensures robust performance in complex and unstructured environments. The proposed method was rigorously evaluated using multiple performance metrics, demonstrating its effectiveness and advantages in enhancing human–robot interactions, improving decision-making efficiency, and enabling robots to provide more intelligent and responsive assistance. In addition, we conducted physical experiments in real-world scenarios to further validate the effectiveness of our method.

title: FastPillars: A Deployment-friendly Pillar-based 3D Detector
authors: Sifan Zhou, Xinyu Zhang, Xiangxiang Chu, Bo Zhang, Ziyu Zhao, Xiaobo Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: The deployment of 3D detectors strikes one of the major challenges in real-world self-driving scenarios. Existing BEV-based (i.e., Bird Eye View) detectors favor sparse convolutions (known as SPConv) to speed up training and inference, which puts a hard barrier for deployment, especially for on-device applications. In this paper, in order to tackle the challenge of efficient 3D object detection from an industry perspective, we devise a deployment-friendly pillar-based 3D detector, termed FastPillars. Specifically, aiming to compensate the geometric information loss of pillar encoding. First, we design a novel lightweight Max-and-Attention Pillar Encoding (MAPE) module specially for enhancing small objects. Second, we propose a simple yet effective backbone design for pillar-based 3D detection, enhancing pillar representations. We construct FastPillars based on these designs, achieving high performance and low latency without SPConv. Extensive experiments on two large-scale datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of FastPillars for on-device 3D detection regarding both performance and speed. Specifically, FastPillars delivers real-time state-of-the-art accuracy on Waymo Open Dataset with 1.8 × speed up and 3.8 mAPH/L2 improvement over CenterPoint (SPConv-based). Code will be opened soon in: https://github.com/StiphyJay/FastPillars.

title: Learning Invariant Grasping Features via Scene Prototypes and Structure Priors in Robotic Manipulation_supp1-3630002.mp4
authors: Xinyan Liang
abstract: Most existing robotic grasp detection methods can achieve high accuracy in one single domain, but due to the differences in data distribution and object categories among different datasets, the accuracies of these methods decrease significantly in other domains. To solve this problem, we propose a novel domain-invariant grasp detection network with scene prototypes and structure priors to extract robust grasping features. First, a universal prototype guidance strategy, which models the hidden domain scenes and obtains universal scene prototypes based on their similarities, is designed to distinguish foreground objects from background in different domains. The structure perception enhancement method based on structure priors is then constructed to carry out fine-grained modeling of foreground regions and capture more detailed local information. In addition, we also design repulsive constraint regularization to assist the training process to alleviate the issue of similar prior distribution in vector space. Extensive comparative experiments are conducted on four public datasets and the results show that the proposed method achieves significant improvements of detection accuracy under cross-dataset scenarios. As a plug-in module, it could improve the generalization of existing grasp detection approaches by a large margin. Real-world robotic grasping experiments are also deployed to verify its effectiveness.

title: Data-Driven Power Flow Linearization via Hybrid Regression and Classification for Accurately Enforcing Network Constraints
authors: Zhenfei Tan, Xiaoyuan Xu, Han Wang, Zheng Yan, Mohammad Shahidehpour
abstract: This letter proposes a novel power flow (PF) linearization method for accurately enforcing network constraints in optimal dispatch problems. Unlike conventional linearization methods that focus on reducing PF solution errors, the proposed method aims to enhance the decision feasibility of network constrained dispatch problems modeled with linear PF equations. A data-driven framework based on hybrid regression and classification is developed to determine coefficients of the linear PF equation. This problem is equivalent to minimizing a weighted sum of the root-mean-square error and hinge loss, which compels the linear PF model to enforce network constraints accurately. Simulations with various system scales verify that the proposed PF linearization method outperforms existing ones in terms of decision feasibility and optimality.

title: A Maintainability Framework to Ensure the Software Quality in Object-Oriented Programming
authors: Siti Rochimah, Tiara Rahmania Hadiningrum, Bella Dwi Mardiana, Daniel Oranova Siahaan, Rizky Januar Akbar, Ary Mazharuddin Shiddiqi
abstract: In recent years, there have been significant challenges in the attempt to improve modular structure and code reusability in software development. Software developers should ensure that refactoring not only addresses code smells and provides tangible improvements to software quality metrics. Although metric-based approaches allow for objective and systematic measurements, they have limitations. They cannot ascertain the effectiveness of refactoring techniques in terms of readability, code maintainability, and their impact on system performance and developer productivity. This study proposes mathematical formulations for five key metrics: Modularity (MMo-1-G, MMo-2-S), Analysability (MAn-2-S), Reusability (MRe-1-G), and Testability (MTe-1-G).
