These metrics were used to evaluate and verify the effectiveness of refactoring in improving module separability and code reuse rate. The proposed model is presented in mathematical notation to link the concepts of modularity and reusability with the corresponding refactoring implementation. Case studies were conducted by applying this formulation to various refactoring techniques aimed at addressing specific types of code smells. Based on the metrics analysis conducted on 17 types of code smell with 3 refactoring techniques, the results demonstrate an improvement in MMo-1-G by 11.46%, MMo-2-S by 0.8%, MAn-2-S by 1.2%, MRe-1-G by 0.82% and MTe-1-G by 3.07%. These findings demonstrate that the proposed formulation can be effectively applied to evaluate code quality changes after refactoring and provide more objective insights into code improvement decision-making.

title: A Sea Surface Temperature Prediction Method Based on Spatiotemporal Scale Fusion and Multi-Factor Correlation Mining
authors: Jun Fanghang, Chenhao Zhang, Bo Peng, Yun Zhang
abstract: This study proposes a novel method for sea surface temperature (SST) prediction based on spatiotemporal scale fusion and multi-factor correlation mining, aimed at enhancing the accuracy of SST forecasts. The ocean is a critical component of the Earth’s climate system, and SST significantly impacts ecosystems and global climate change. However, existing prediction models struggle with the complexities of multi-scale dynamics and nonlinear interactions in the ocean.In this research, we designed a network structure that captures and integrates information across various spatiotemporal scales, explicitly modeling the dynamic dependencies between SST and key factors such as salinity, ocean currents, and wind fields. By employing multi-task learning and attention mechanisms, the model facilitates effective interaction among these factors, improving prediction accuracy and robustness.Experimental results indicate that the proposed method significantly outperforms traditional models when validated using the Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS) dataset, achieving remarkable enhancements in prediction accuracy. The model demonstrates superior performance across different forecast horizons (e.g., 24 hours, 48 hours, and 120 hours), underscoring the importance of multi-factor interaction and spatiotemporal scale fusion. This study contributes not only by providing a new predictive framework but also by offering valuable theoretical support and practical applications for further marine science research and resource management.

title: Enhancing O-Band PAM Performance With a CNN At Equal Complexity to an FIR Filter
authors: Amir Omidi, Shen Li, Zibo Zheng, Ming Zeng, Wei Shi, Leslie A. Rusch
abstract: Multiple-level intensity-modulation with directdetection (IM/DD) is a cost-effective solution for increasing capacity within data centers and other short haul links. Conventional equalizers, typically based on linear filtering, are designed under Gaussian noise assumptions; amplified IM/DD links have non-Gaussian statistics. Neural network (NN) solutions can adapt naturally to both standard (Gaussian) and amplified (non-Gaussian) IM/DD systems. In contrast to previous research, we examine neural network implementations that incur no increase in complexity over simple, finite impulse response filtering. Comparing standard filtering with our NN solution, our experiments with a silicon photonic modulator in the Oband show gains from 0.25-0.75 dB in Q-factor across multiple wavelengths and fiber lengths. For example, a net rate of 100 Gb/s (post-KP4-FEC overhead) can be achieved at 1300 nm over 3.4 km. We achieved additional gain with a modified four-level constellation adapted to channel statistics. The same-complexity NN solution can be used for amplified IM/DD systems employing low-cost integrated semiconductor optical amplifiers (SOAs), such as metro/5G fronthaul links, and emerging multiplexing architectures with a shared laser and SOA.

title: Glucose-Insulin System Dynamics in Type-I Diabetes Patient based on RO-TADF Approach
authors: Akshaya Kumar Patra, Smitta Ranjan Dutta, Alok Kumar Mishra
abstract: This research introduces the concept of a Remora Optimization–Tilt Acceleration Derivative with Filter (RO-TADF) control strategy for Artificial Pancreas (AP) systems to regulate Blood Glucose (BG) in Type-I Diabetes Mellitus (TIDM) patients. The key problem addressed is the unstable and nonlinear glucose–insulin dynamics that challenge precise insulin dosing under varying meal and activity disturbances. Existing control approaches such as PID, fuzzy, sliding mode, and predictive controllers exhibit limitations in robustness, noise suppression, and stability. To overcome these, the proposed RO-TADF approach integrates the Remora Optimization Algorithm (ROA) for adaptive gain tuning and filtering to enhance convergence, accuracy, and uncertainty handling. This study fills the research gap by providing an intelligent, optimization-based fractional control design for dynamic biomedical applications. Simulation results show approximately 20% improvement in system accuracy, robustness, and stability compared with existing methods. The key message highlights RO-TADF’s capability to maintain normoglycemia (70–120 mg/dl) with enhanced reliability, making it a promising solution for real-time AP implementation.

title: Primal-Dual iLQR for GPU-Accelerated Learning and Control in Legged Robots_supp1-3632610.mp4
authors: Lorenzo Amatucci
abstract: This paper introduces a novel Model Predictive Control (MPC) implementation for legged robot locomotion that leverages GPU parallelization. Our approach enables both temporal and state-space parallelization by incorporating a parallel associative scan to solve the primal-dual Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) system. In this way, the optimal control problem is solved in <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {O}(\log ^{2}(n)\log {N} + \log ^{2}(m))$</tex-math></inline-formula> complexity, instead of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {O}(N(n + m)^{3})$</tex-math></inline-formula>, where <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$n$</tex-math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$m$</tex-math></inline-formula>, and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N$</tex-math></inline-formula> are the dimension of the system state, control vector, and the length of the prediction horizon. We demonstrate the advantages of this implementation over two state-of-the-art solvers (acados and crocoddyl), achieving up to a 60% improvement in runtime for Whole Body Dynamics (WB)-MPC and a 700% improvement for Single Rigid Body Dynamics (SRBD)-MPC when varying the prediction horizon length. The presented formulation scales efficiently with the problem state dimensions as well, enabling the definition of a centralized controller for up to 16 legged robots that can be computed in less than 25 ms. Furthermore, thanks to the JAX implementation, the solver supports large-scale parallelization across multiple environments, allowing the possibility of performing learning with the MPC in the loop directly in GPU. The code associated with this work can be found at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/iit-DLSLab/mpx</uri>.

title: AniMer+: Unified Pose and Shape Estimation Across Mammalia and Aves Via Family-Aware Transformer
authors: Liang An, Jin Lyu, Li Lin, Pujin Cheng, Yebin Liu, Xiaoying Tang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: In the era of foundation models, achieving a unified understanding of different dynamic objects through a single network has the potential to empower stronger spatial intelligence. Moreover, accurate estimation of animal pose and shape across diverse species is essential for quantitative analysis in biological research. However, this topic remains underexplored due to the limited network capacity of previous methods and the scarcity of comprehensive multi-species datasets. To address these limitations, we introduce AniMer+, an extended version of our scalable AniMer framework. In this paper, we focus on a unified approach for reconstructing mammals (mammalia) and birds (aves). A key innovation of AniMer+ is its high-capacity, family-aware Vision Transformer (ViT) incorporating a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) design. Its architecture partitions network layers into taxa-specific components (for mammalia and aves) and taxa-shared components, enabling efficient learning of both distinct and common anatomical features within a single model. To overcome the critical shortage of 3D training data, especially for birds, we introduce a diffusion-based conditional image generation pipeline. This pipeline produces two large-scale synthetic datasets: CtrlAni3D for quadrupeds (about 10 k images with pixel-aligned SMAL labels) and CtrlAVES3D (about 7 k images with pixel-aligned AVES labels). To note, CtrlAVES3D is the first large-scale, 3D-annotated dataset for birds, which is crucial for resolving single-view depth ambiguities. Trained on an aggregated collection of 41.3 k mammalian and 12.4 k avian images (combining real and synthetic data), our method demonstrates superior performance over existing approaches across a wide range of benchmarks, including the challenging out-of-domain Animal Kingdom dataset. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of both our novel network architecture and the generated synthetic datasets in enhancing real-world application performance. The project page with code and data can be found at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://animerplus.github.io/</uri>.

title: Highly Sensitive Flexible Strain Sensing Systems Based on HfSe₂–Carbon Nanomaterial Composites for In Situ Tension Monitoring in Advanced Chain-Link Structural Interconnects
authors: Jian Wang, Xuewei Shi, Xiaoyang Bi, Alamusi Lee, Xueli Dong, Chenxing Xiang, Kexu An, Hansheng Liao, Kaiming Hu, Ning Hu
abstract: Mining chains operating in adverse underground environments and experiencing elevated coal transportation volumes are susceptible to critical failures including overloading, chain jamming, and fracture due to their role as essential transmission components. Real-time chain strain monitoring systems provide continuous assessment capabilities and early warning of potential failure events. Conventional strain sensors employed for tension monitoring exhibit significant limitations including insufficient sensitivity, excessive power requirements, and substantial dimensional constraints. In this investigation, we have synthesized strain sensors specifically engineered for downhole applications by leveraging the exceptional properties of graphene and HfSe₂. The integration of HfSe₂ into graphene-based composites resulted in the formation of heterointerfaces, which enhanced the sensors' sensitivity and linearity. These sensors demonstrate superior performance characteristics, including enhanced gauge factor (GF=22.8) within the linear strain range of 0–2000 με, exceptional linearity (RL²=0.98), ultra-low detection threshold (100 με), and minimal power consumption (2.05 mW), while maintaining measurement accuracy across extreme thermal conditions (0°C-60°C). The acquired strain signals underwent Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) analysis, with subsequent application of a Butterworth filter to attenuate high-frequency components and mitigate environmental noise interference. The developed graphene/HfSe₂-based strain sensor substantially enhances monitoring precision and operational safety, presenting significant implementation potential for advanced mine intelligence systems.

title: Computational Electro-optic Frequency Comb Spectroscopy
authors: J.J. Navarro-Alventosa, A. Aupart-Acosta, V. Durán
abstract: Computational techniques have gained significant traction in photonics, enabling the co-design of hardware and data processing algorithms to drastically simplify optical system architectures and improve their performance. However, their application in optical frequency comb spectroscopy remains considerably underexplored. In this work, we introduce a non-interferometric approach to frequency comb spectroscopy based on dynamically tailored electro-optic modulation. The core of our method is a reconfigurable electro-optic comb generator capable of producing a sequence of known comb spectra to interrogate a spectroscopic sample. Instead of recording spectrally resolved or interferometric data, our system captures a set of integrated optical power measurements-one per probe comb-from which the sample's spectral response is computationally reconstructed by solving an inverse problem. We present the theoretical foundations of this method, assess its limitations, and validate it through numerical simulations. As a proof of concept, we demonstrate the experimental reconstruction of several spectral signatures, including a molecular absorption line at 1545 nm. For these results, we use numerically computed spectra and experimentally measured power values, all acquired within 10 milliseconds. Finally, we discuss potential extensions and improvements of the method, as well as its integration into chip-scale spectroscopic systems.

title: Modeling Coupled Epidemic-Information Dynamics via Reaction-Diffusion Processes on Multiplex Networks with Media and Mobility Effects_supp1-3632506.pdf
authors: Xiu-xiu Zhan
abstract: To better capture real-world epidemic dynamics, it is essential to develop models that incorporate diverse, realistic factors. In this study, we propose a coupled disease-information spreading model on multiplex networks that simultaneously accounts for three critical dimensions: media influence, higher-order interactions, and population mobility. This integrated framework enables a systematic analysis of synergistic spreading mechanisms under practical constraints and facilitates the exploration of effective epidemic containment strategies. Our results show that both mass media dissemination and higher-order network structures contribute to suppressing disease transmission by enhancing public awareness. However, the containment effect of higher-order interactions weakens as the order of simplices increases. We also explore the influence of subpopulation characteristics, revealing that increasing inter-subpopulation connectivity in a connected metapopulation network leads to lower disease prevalence under moderate disease transmission rates. Furthermore, guiding individuals to migrate toward less accessible or more isolated subpopulations is shown to effectively mitigate epidemic spread. These findings offer valuable insights for designing targeted and adaptive intervention strategies in complex epidemic settings.

title: Bayesian Filtering of Biochemical Analyte Dynamics with Bacterial Sensors
authors: Florian Anderl, Mladen Veletić, Ilangko Balasingham
abstract: Whole-cell, population-based bacterial sensors can be engineered to measure molecular analyte concentrations. Luminescent reporter systems provide an easily measurable optical signal in response to analyte exposure, enabling readout of the aggregate response of the bacterial population. Traditionally, bacterial sensor responses are compared against calibration curves to estimate analyte levels. However, many applications require tracking analyte dynamics over time, which is challenging due to intrinsic molecular noise, population heterogeneity, and the unknown number of cells contributing to the measured luminescence. The stochastic nature of this problem motivates a Bayesian approach, where prior knowledge can be systematically incorporated into inference. In this work, we investigate bacterial sensing within a statistical framework and propose a Sequential Monte Carlo method to infer the posterior distribution over latent system variables. Specifically, we employ a Rao–Blackwellized particle filter to jointly infer analyte dynamics and population cell dynamics from aggregate luminescence measurements. We validate our method on synthetic simulation data and show that the proposed inference is feasible, though associated with relatively high estimation variance. We anticipate that the method is directly applicable in experimental settings.

title: Resilient Fusion Localization of Onboard Heterogeneous Sensors Against Random Disturbances and Covert GNSS Spoofing Attack
authors: Jinfeng Zhang, Zhen Zhang, Yuezhong Zhang, Shumin Huo, Yabin Peng, Yupeng Zhang, Shaoxun Liu
abstract: Automotive sensors operating in complex environments face both random disturbances (e.g., object occlusion, adverse weather) and deliberate attacks such as Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) spoofing. Traditional localization methods primarily address inherent errors and observation biases caused by random disturbances, but they struggle to effectively counter covert GNSS spoofing simultaneously. To resolve safety challenges from both random disturbances and covert GNSS spoofing attacks in vehicular localization, a resilient localization method for onboard heterogeneous sensors in complex environments is proposed. Firstly, a resilient fusion localization architecture based on onboard heterogeneous sensors is established. Subsequently, building upon this framework, a dynamic optimization method for Kalman filter noise matrices is designed based on an improved Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm. The approach achieves real-time awareness of random disturbances and enables dynamic correction of noise matrices. Simultaneously, a multi-dimensional localization error quantification metric encompassing spatial and temporal dimensions is established, and a resilient fusion methodology for heterogeneous sensors is proposed. The ablation experiment results show that under random disturbance and covert GNSS spoofing attacks, the localization error of the proposed method is reduced by 12% and 75%, respectively. Meanwhile, comparative experiments with multiple methods validate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method.

title: Flexible AirLink RF Coil: A Wireless Signal Enhancement Solution for MRI
authors: Yushu Xie, Haoqin Zhu, Feiyang Lou, Xiaotong Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Objective: This study aims to develop a flexible AirLink coil, namely a inductively coupled wireless resonant array, to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and parallel imaging performance for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), when used in conjunction with commercial radiofrequency (RF) receive coils. Methods: The AirLink coil was designed as an array of 10 single-loop resonators, integrated with detuning circuits to ensure operation in the receive mode only. Electromagnetic simulations were conducted using the finite integration technique (FIT) to analyze the B1− field enhancement by a single AirLink loop. Phantom and in vivo experiments were performed to compare four reception configurations: AirLink coil + commercial array coil, commercial array coil alone, AirLink coil + body coil, and body coil alone. Evaluation metrics included SNR, noise correlation matrix, inverse g-factor map, and B1+ field map. Results: Electromagnetic simulations confirmed that the single AirLink loop enhanced the local B1− field. Phantom imaging showed that the AirLink coil, when used with a commercial array coil or a body coil, notably improved the SNR in local region. The AirLink coil had a negligible impact on the overall decoupling performance of the commercial array coil. In parallel imaging acceleration experiments, the AirLink coil demonstrated superior noise suppression in its covered regions compared to using the commercial array coil alone. In vivo imaging with the prefrontal cortex as the region of interest (ROI) showed improved imaging quality similar to phantom imaging, with stable RF transmission efficiency and no need for scanner parameter adjustments. Conclusion: The AirLink coil notably enhances SNR in ROIs while maintaining high parallel imaging performance and clinical compatibility. Its flexible design, low cost, and parameter-free adjustment features make it an efficient localized imaging optimization solution for routine MRI, with broad clinical application potential.

title: Threat Modeling for O-RAN Cyber Risk
authors: Dimitri A. Dessources, Alexandra Greene, Samuel Appiah-Mensah, Joseph Bull, David Simpson, Nishith D. Tripathi, Eric w. Burger, Jeffrey H. Reed
abstract: The vision to accelerate the commercialization of Open RAN (O-RAN) creates many opportunities for more flexible and cost-effective networks and use cases, but also presents security challenges. Prioritizing security as a critical component of this commercialization, rather than “good enough” protection, is paramount. Splitting the Radio Access Network (RAN) into different, disaggregated functions creates a larger attack surface. As O-RAN drives network component disaggregation and deployments shift from single-vendor to multi-vendor configurations, clear responsibility for asset protection is not just beneficial—it is foundational. Without well-defined roles, the complexity of securing critical infrastructure increases, leading to potential gaps, inefficiencies, and heightened risk exposure. A transparent framework ensures accountability, streamlined security coordination, and effective risk mitigation, making it possible to fortify resilience while enabling innovation and collaboration across diverse vendors. Various single-vendor deployments may use different frameworks to evaluate their security protocols. Shifting to multi-vendor deployments may cause new or existing security risks to emerge due to gaps between different security testing frameworks used throughout the Fifth Generation (5G) O-RAN lifecycle. Due to this potential for security gaps, we offer a Responsible, Accountable, Supports, Consulted & Informed (RASCI) chart as a starting point for what should be a multi-stakeholder series of engagements, which ultimately leads to an objective clarity of assigning risk responsibilities. We also review some of the threats to 5G O-RAN as described by two popular 5G threat modeling frameworks, MITRE’s 5G Hierarchy of Threats ™ (FiGHT) Framework and O-RAN AllianceWorking Group (WG) 11 Threat Modeling and Risk Assessment Technical Report, that are most affected by unclear risk responsibilities, and detail how our suggested risk responsibility framework would help secure against these threats.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Transmission and Distribution Optimal Power Flow Problems for the Integration of Distributed Energy Resources
authors: Samuel M. Muhindo, Hanane Dagdougui, Antoine Lesage-Landry, Hussein Suprême
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive review of coordination methods for addressing large-scale transmission and distribution optimal power flow (TDOPF) problems involving distributed energy resources. With distinct objectives, each transmission and distribution system operator (TSO/DSO) independently seeks to solve its own optimal power flow (OPF) instance. First, iterative methods are reviewed, in which the central OPF is solved recursively by decomposing the full problem into smaller, more manageable sub-problems or by replacing peripheral portions of the network within the central OPF with reduced equivalent grids. Generally, the convergence to an optimal solution of the full problem when all sub-OPFs are coordinated is not guaranteed as iterative methods repeat procedures until the changes in control variables of the central OPF are minimal. Second, sequential methods are reviewed, in which the central OPF is solved sequentially in a fixed, nonrepeating procedure by considering previous results. Achieving a fair balance between TSO and DSO interests in sequential methods might adversely affect the performance of a largescale central OPF. The advantages and the limitations of the two coordination methods are presented based on the operation mode of TSO-DSO network. Future research opportunities for coordination methods of TSO-DSO network are drawn using the Kron reduction method and mean-field games.

title: Bio-inspired Algorithm for the Tuning of a GPI Controller Implemented in a Solanum tuberosum Crop Inspector Robot
authors: Álvaro Pulido-Aponte, Claudia L. Garzón-Castro
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Conference on Applications of Computational Intelligence (ColCACI)
abstract: Recently, Solanum tuberosum potato production has generated unfavorable impacts on health, the environment and the global economy. This is due to the high demand for tuber and the inappropriate use of agrochemicals on crops. The use of mobile robots for the inspection of soil variables could suggest a more efficient management of these chemical inputs. However, there are still gaps in the development, implementation and automatic control of these agricultural robots. In terms of process control, strategies associated with Active Disturbance Rejection, such as Generalized Proportional Integral (GPI), have been developed. The latter is a promising option of high robustness and performance for robot tracking of desired trajectories. However, the good performance of this type of controller depends on correct parametric tuning. In response to this need, the objective of this work was to determine the optimal parameters of a GPI controller implemented in a S. tuberosum crop inspector robot. For this purpose, a multi-objective optimization problem was formulated that sought the simultaneous minimization of both tracking error and control effort. Subsequently, a methodology based on the Multi-Objective Particle Swarm Optimization algorithm was implemented, resulting in a set of 18 non-dominated solutions, each with its respective parameterization. The results showed an improvement in trajectory tracking of up to $23 \%$ over other tuning. Thus, suggesting the effectiveness of this Bio-inspired algorithm to explore the solution space effectively.

title: Multi-Robot Systems: Shared Understanding of the Unknown Environment Through Swarm SLAM
authors: R Balaji, Lloyd Lawrance Noronoha, Amit Kore, Sachin Karadgi, Shridhar Doddamani, P S Hiremath
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs) are increasingly deployed in dynamic industrial environments for collaborative tasks. Existing AMRs often rely on centralized map management, introducing a single point of failure and limiting scalability. These systems require the sharing of entire maps, which results in communication overhead. This paper proposes a decentralized framework for real-time map merging, enabling Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) for individual AMRs. The framework employs selective data sharing, communicating only new or updated features between robots. This reduces computational load and communication overhead, preserving mapping accuracy. Efficient alignment techniques address discrepancies in orientation, scale, and reference frames, ensuring proper map integration. This approach empowers AMRs with SLAM capabilities to operate autonomously, improving system robustness and adaptability to individual robot failures. Simulations using ROS2 validate the proposed framework in various configurations.

title: Intelligent Wind Power Forecasting Using Deep Learning and Big Data Technologies
authors: Hyba AbdulJalee, Shireesha Gorgilli
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: - Wind power is an attractive renewable energy source because it reduces carbon emissions and dependence on fossil fuels. Due to the wind's unpredictable and variable nature, it remains challenging to forecast wind power accurately. Using deep learning techniques and big data, this paper aims to improve wind power forecasting accuracy. A novel forecasting model is proposed using an Enhanced Deep Convolutional Neural Network (EDCNN), combined with Demand-Side Management (DSM) strategies. Models that incorporate historical and real-time meteorological data capture the complex spatial and temporal dynamics of wind behaviour to provide more reliable and scalable forecasts. According to comparisons with existing models, the proposed model performs better, particularly in predicting various seasons more accurately. As a result of this research, wind energy can be used more efficiently, and grid operations and energy planning can be optimised.

title: Adaptive Control of Unmanned Surface Vehicles in Dynamic Marine Environments with Time-Varying Parameter Estimation
authors: Sami Souissi, Chiheb Zaoui, Saber Hachicha, Mohamed Boukattaya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper addresses the trajectory tracking of an Unmanned Surface Vehicle (USV) using a double-loop adaptive technique to handle unknown ocean currents and disturbances. An outer loop estimates ocean current velocity using a back stepping approach, while an inner loop compensates for disturbances and unknown dynamic parameters through adaptation laws. The designed inner loop generates an enhanced thrust for each USV propeller, facilitating the convergence of the real and virtual velocities of the USV. Lyapunov stability theory is used for formulating the control stability analysis and computation of the adaptation laws for the overall system. Simulations on the Cyber Ship II model demonstrate the controller’s ability to accurately track the desired trajectory. The results of these simulations provide evidence that the proposed controller performs successfully in achieving the desired trajectory tracking objectives.

title: A Low Noise Signal Conditioning Circuit for Neural Signal Acquisition
authors: V Milner Paul, Shuma Adhikari, Loitongbam Surajkumar Singh, Tony C Thomas, Caren Babu
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Neural signals, such as action potential and neural spikes require precise amplification and noise suppression for accurate acquisition. In this work, a low noise signal conditioning circuit is designed to allow detection of neural spikes from the human body. The range of signals is in microvolts which demands a proper signal conditioning system to amplify the signals and further process it. Here, a preamplifier is properly designed with sufficient gain to amplify the signal and remove the noise. This is followed by a bandpass filter capable of filtering signals, specifically from 300 Hz to 11 KHz and the proposed signal conditioning circuitry could achieve a pass band gain of $\mathbf{4 1 . 3 6 ~ d B}$. Additionally, the design is validated for stability in terms of gain and phase margins. The circuit could achieve an SNR of $\mathbf{5 6 . 0 5 ~ d B ~ a t ~} \mathbf{3 0 0 ~ H z}$ and drops to 40.97 dB at 11 KHz with input noise applied. Its low-voltage operation and broad specification range make it suitable for diverse biomedical applications, ensuring reliable neural recording for brain studies.

title: High-Entropy LFSR-Based Random Number Generator (RNG) for Hardware Security
authors: Sonia Akter, Shelby Williams, Prosen Kirtonia, Kasem Khalil, Magdy Bayoumi
abstract: In this highly interconnected modern communication era, all secure communication, such as robust encryption and decryption, authentication is strongly dependent on secure key generation, thus random number generators (RNG). Among many RNG designs, Linear Feedback Shift Register (LFSR) based Pseudo-Random Number Generators (PRNGs) are often considered unsuitable for being central components in high-security applications due to their deterministic behavior and shorter cycle length. However, LFSRs are easy to implement and resource-efficient. In this work, a unique approach to using LFSRs for a robust Random Number Generator (RNG) design is proposed for security-sensitive applications. The proposed design utilizes a dynamic selection of feedback polynomials with unpredictable run time, reseeding, and jitter from ring oscillators (ROs) to enhance randomness quality. The design is evaluated through several statistical test suites, for example, NIST SP800-22, NIST SP800-90B, and other randomness tests with near-ideal entropy values. The proposed high-entropy RNG is synthesized on a Spartan-7 FPGA, demonstrating less hardware usage and comparable power consumption. The synthesis result in the Synopsys design compiler also shows high scalability in the advanced technology nodes. Lastly, the proposed RNG design provides a balance between randomness quality and resource efficiency using an LFSR as the main component.

title: Evaluating Representative Days Selection for Capacity Planning with Variable Renewable Options
authors: Matheus F. Zambroni de Souza, Adrien Prigent, Sophie Pelland, Steven Wong
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Capacity planning models are necessary to study pathways to meeting decarbonization goals and meeting load growth. As these models are computationally costly, representative days are frequently used to reduce the problem size. The choice of representative days becomes even more important as variable renewable energy sources like wind and solar are increasingly becoming a part of the electricity mix. Ultimately, the set of selected days will vary based on the method used and number of days chosen. In turn, the outputs of the planning model can vary based on the set of days used - this work focuses on quantifying this variation. First, this paper introduces some existing methods for set selection, weighing additional considerations required when addressing variable renewables and regional variations. A series of metrics is then proposed for comparing the outputs of the planning models from different representative day sets. Finally, they are applied, in PyPSA, to Canada’s Maritime provinces as a $\mathbf{2 5}$-year grid planning problem and compared to a 365-day approach. Results indicate that there are a wide range of near-optimal solutions with contrasting generation mixes, and that capacity planning would be better informed by generating results over multiple sets of representative days, rather than a single set.

title: Prototype of a Serious Game to Teach the Specification of Flexible Non-Functional Requirements
authors: Franklin Parrales-Bravo, Ronaldo Aguirre-Aguirre, Ronny Gomez-Peñafiel, Manuel Reyes-Wagnio, Roberto Tolozano-Benites
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Recently, a methodology called “Fuzzy Representation of Unbounded and Imprecise Terms” (FRUIT) has been proposed, which offers a flexible approach to define and validate non-functional requirements (NFRs) in natural language. This article addresses the development of a Serious Game to teach Software Engineering students at the University of Guayaquil the identification of linguistic variables and linguistic values when defining NFRs under the FRUIT methodology. In it, we present the design, development, and evaluation of a didactic educational tool (Serious Game) built for that purpose. The game incorporates feedback, helping students correctly identify variables and linguistic values in defining NFRs. The serious game has been evaluated by contrasting two groups of students, one using the video game and the other learning on a blackboard, obtaining quite similar results when it comes to improving the specification of NFRs, but offering the advantage of learning in a more interactive and engaging environment.

title: Performance Evaluation of MAGIC-ReRAM Arithmetic Circuits for Low-Latency In-Memory Computing
authors: Saeideh Nabipour, Fatemeh Shirinzadeh, Kamalika Datta, Abhoy Kole, Saeideh Shirinzadeh, Rolf Drechsler
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: In-memory computing (IMC) with Resistive Random Access Memory (ReRAM) crossbars has emerged as a promising solution to overcome the von Neumann bottleneck by enabling computation inside memory arrays. This paper presents a unified benchmarking of multi-bit arithmetic circuits in the MAGIC logic style, encompassing seven adder and three multiplier architectures with operand sizes from 8 to 64 bits. Through a proposed parallel mapping methodology, we achieve latency reductions of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$26.3 \times$</tex> for adders and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$361 \times$</tex> for multipliers relative to state-of-the-art designs, realized through efficient crossbar-level utilization with modest hardware overhead. Our evaluation shows that Brent-Kung (BK) adders are most latencyefficient for larger sizes, while Serial Prefix (SE) adders excel for smaller ones and also offer superior hardware efficiency. In addition, Dadda multipliers achieve the lowest total latency, whereas array multipliers provide the best hardware efficiency among multipliers. By systematically quantifying the trade-offs between latency and memristor count, this work offers a detailed design-space exploration of arithmetic units for ReRAM-based IMC, yielding practical insights for future high-performance, memory-centric architectures.

title: A 50 Gbps Reference-Less NRZ Full-Rate Bang-Bang CDR with Automatic Frequency Acquisition in 130nm SiGe:C BiCMOS Technology
authors: Mohammed Iftekhar, Babak Sadiye, Wolfgang Mueller, J. Christoph Scheytt
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a reference-less, full-rate NRZ clock and data recovery (CDR) circuit with bang-bang phase detector (BBPD). The CDR uses a new method of automatic frequency acquisition by deliberately detuning the nominal frequency of a voltage controlled oscillator (VCO) using a permanent offset voltage modulation during PLL operation. This modulation extends the acquisition range beyond the inherent acquisition range of a conventional bang-bang CDR (BBCDR). In addition to the offset voltage modulation, an offset current modulation is applied to the integral branch of the CDR, allowing for automatic frequency acquisition over the entire VCO tuning range. The prototype CDR is fabricated and measured using a 130nm SiGe:C BiCMOS process and achieves an acquisition range of 49.05 to 52.3 Gbps. The recovered clock is measured at 51.56725 GHz with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$201 \text{fs}_{\text {rms }}$</tex> clock jitter, and the recovered data tolerates the applied jitter with a bit error rate (BER) <10-12 in accordance with the data rate and jitter tolerance specifications of the OIF CEI-56G-VSR standard. The CDR core dissipates 245mW from a 3.3V supply voltage, resulting in a Figure of Merit (FoM) of 4.68 mW/Gbps.

title: Multi Graph Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network with Low Depth Paring Encryption Algorithm and Attribute Based Controlled Collaborative Access Control Scheme for Enhancing Cyber Security In IoT*
authors: S. Sathyakala, E. Anbalagan
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) is a new technology that makes it easy and advantageous to share data with other devices via wireless networks or the cloud. But as the IoT environment evolves, IoT systems are becoming more vulnerable to cyberattacks, which may result in security flaws and malevolent invasions. Various algorithms are used for the detection of intrusions but it often yield low recognition accuracy because due to their failure to effectively handle the massive and novel intrusion data classification with high security. So, deep learning based Multi Graph Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network (MGCRNN) is developed in this study to detect the cyber-attacks in IOT network. Initially, the network features during data transmission is collected and it is pre-processed using Median Absolute Deviation Normalization (MADN) and Low Rank Matrix Decomposition (LRMD) for normalization and Missing Value Imputation to enhance its quality. Following that, the dimension of the pre-processed data was reduced using the Curvilinear Component Analysis (CCA) algorithm. The reduced dimension data is then categorized using MGCRNN to detect cyber-attacks. Following attack detection, a homomorphic-based Low Depth Paring Encryption Algorithm (LDPEA) is created to protect data from malicious hackers and securely store it in a cloud server. Then, to access the data from the cloud server, Attribute based Controlled Collaborative Access Control Scheme (ACCACS) is created. The proposed model validates robust presentation with an accuracy of 98.7%, precision and recall of 98.1% and 99% specificity, highlighting its exceptional capability in distinguishing cyber-attacks from benign activities.

title: Performance Evaluation and Simulation of LoRa Satellite LPWAN Communication with High Payload
authors: Puput Dani Prasetyo Adi, Nasrullah Armi, Tjahjo Adiprabowo, Andriana, Dani Ramdani, Samsinar, Fransiska Sisilia Mukti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: This research shows the Performance Evaluation of LoRa which should be used for Small Payload and Sensor data, but given the challenge of High Payload. High Payload is a big problem for small bandwidth devices such as LoRa, Sigfox, and NB-IoT. While the performance of LoRa can transmit images as far as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 ~ k m}$</tex> in Line-of-Sight (LoS) conditions, and also antennas that can be conditioned with the right height to avoid diffraction signals from the Fresnel Zone area in terrestrial communication conditions, In this research, an approach to LoRa on NonTerrestrial Communication or Satellite Communication is carried out. which can be optimized to hundreds of km distance. this research finds the right method gap point in carrying out LoRaWAN-based satellite communication research. from the simulation obtained the Success Rate on LEO SF7 is 5.5 %, decreasing to 3.2 % on LEO-SF12. With LEO-SF7 Goodput of 719.3 bps, while LEO-SF12 is only 17.7 bps, with payloads of 58 to 65. Broadly speaking, the larger the payload, the greater the Time-on-Air, and also the possibility of packet loss, packet error, or delivery ratio (%) will decrease.

title: Research on the Construction of a Source Network Load Storage Collaborative Optimization Platform Based on Intelligent Algorithms
authors: Bin Zhang, Qian Guo, Junxian Ma, Shihao Zhang
abstract: With the large-scale integration of renewable energy and diversified load development in the new power system, the coordinated optimization of source grid load storage faces challenges of multi time scale uncertainty and complex constraints. This study proposes a method for constructing an intelligent algorithm driven collaborative optimization platform. By integrating digital twins, knowledge graphs, and cloud edge collaboration technologies, a four layer closed-loop architecture of "perception modeling optimization execution" is constructed to achieve deep coupling and dynamic interaction between physical systems and virtual spaces. At the algorithm design level, a hierarchical optimization framework combining Improved Particle Swarm Optimization (IPSO) and Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) with Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) is adopted to solve the collaborative problem of global planning and real-time adjustment within the day. The system's economy and robustness are improved through multi-objective optimization and data augmentation mechanisms. Experimental verification based on IEEE 30 node extended system shows that the proposed platform reduces comprehensive scheduling costs by 12.2% compared to traditional methods in conventional daily scenarios, and the renewable energy curtailment rate decreases from 11.2% to 4.6%; The peak power gap in extreme weather is reduced by 63.6%, and the frequency deviation is controlled within ± 0.12Hz, significantly better than the national standard requirements. The research results have broken through the efficiency bottleneck of traditional centralized control, providing an engineered technical path for collaborative optimization of multi-source heterogeneous resources through precise modeling of digital twins, knowledge graph reasoning, and cloud edge collaborative distributed deployment. Future research will focus on modeling energy storage life loss, fine load prediction, and cross regional multi microgrid collaboration mechanisms, promoting the platform's deepening application towards low-carbon and intelligent directions.

title: Augmented Analytics in Business Intelligence Enhancing the ETL Process with Machine Learning
authors: Randy Permana, Sarjon Defit, Gunadi Widi Nurcahyo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Business Intelligence (BI) is a framework for analyzing business activities that consists of three main layers: Data Source, Data Warehouse, and Data Presentation. Meanwhile Augmented Analytics (AA) provides Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) capabilities in the traditional analysis process. In this research, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A A$</tex> is achieved through the use of Machine Learning clustering at the Data Source and Data Warehouse layers, where Machine Learning Clusters will accelerate the ETL (Extract, Transform, and Load) process. Through the application of Cluster Algorithm, a multidimensional data model will be formed through the division of data based on two clusters. The first cluster will be used to accommodate data features that fall into dimensional groups, and the second cluster will accommodate features that fall into fact groups in the multidimensional model. The results of this research based on testing of several datasets used, the Cluster Algorithm is able to perform ETL activities faster without having to use integration tools and understanding SQL Query. So that analytics activities will be quickly carried out without having to wait for Data Analysis to do data modeling.

title: SkillSync - Bridging the Gap Between Your Skills and Industry Expectations
authors: Ranjit Kaur, Vansh Mahajan, Animesh Kumar, Aryan Thakur, Mohit Kumar Gond, Gursimran Singh
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: This research aims to provide individuals with a platform that helps them make an analysis of their professional standing. The tool proposed in this research should help the individuals find the suitable jobs based on their current skill-set and as well as suggest them new skills that they can acquire and add to their resume along with learning resources. The proposed system shall make use of Natural Language Processing/ PDF parser tools to extract user skills from the Individual's resume and store them as user metadata. Based on this data as well as data gathered from job listings on numerous sites the system shall be able to make job recommendations to the user using machine learning measures like Cosine similarity. The proposed system is an improvement over the existing tools in the sense that users shall also be able to input their desired job role and company and get suggestions about the specific skills that the said company may give preference to while hiring new employees. The users shall also be able to get recommendations about certifications that they can take up to further enhance their knowledge. This can help the user gain a competitive edge over other candidates while applying for a job.

title: A Transformer-Integrated CNN Approach for Tomato Leaf Disease Identification
authors: Rojalin Mallick, Manas Kumar Mallick, Debahuti Mishra
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Early identification of tomato leaf diseases is vital for protecting crop health and boosting yield. This study proposes a hybrid model that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with Transformers to classify tomato leaf diseases with high accuracy. Using a dataset of 20,680 images sourced from Kaggle, the model leverages CNNs for detailed feature extraction and Transformers for capturing global context. This integration allows the system to recognize both local patterns and broader image features effectively. The model achieved impressive results, with an accuracy of 98.76%, precision of 99.10%, recall of 98.95%, and a mean Average Precision (mAP@50) of 98.90%. Compared to traditional CNN-based models, the Transformer-enhanced approach demonstrated notable improvements across all performance metrics. These outcomes highlight the model's effectiveness and reliability in automated disease detection. Its adoption can support timely diagnosis, helping farmers manage crop health proactively and enhance overall agricultural productivity.

title: Labelling and Counting of Bolts after Segmentation in a Multi Bolt Environment
authors: G. Ramesh Chandra, C. Nanda Kishore, P. Anudeep, V. Siddhardha, M. Sreya, A. Mallika
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: For structural evaluation and monitoring, identification of exact number of bolts is a must. This paper proposes method for counting bolts in multi-bolt environment after image segmentation. The drone images are used to locate the bolts by means of semantic segmentation with CNNs, and post-processing is carried out to give each detected bolt a proper label and count. The bolt counting system, which is made in Python using OpenCV and Google Colab, operates without needing any manual interaction and thus is able to perform highly efficient and scalable enumeration of the bolts in large structural assessments. The suggested approach is effective for accurate bolt detection and counting, as evidenced by its accuracy of 0.8571 and mean Average Precision (mAP) of $\mathbf{0. 6 4 8 3}$.

title: Performance Impact of Caches, Interrupt Strategies and Communication on SoC Lookaside Acceleration
authors: Alperen Bolat, Sakir Sezer, Kieran Mclaughlin, Henry Hui, Fatih Kurugollu
abstract: Lookaside Accelerators (LAAs) present a compelling approach to enhancing system performance by offloading computational workloads from general-purpose CPUs, offering substantial potential for next-generation accelerated computing. However, the effectiveness of LAAs is heavily dependent on system architecture, particularly in mitigating communication overhead and inefficiencies that can hinder anticipated performance gains. This study investigates the key factors contributing to communication overhead in LAA-enabled architectures, analyzing their collective impact on performance. Specifically, we evaluate critical architectural considerations, including cache hierarchy, data-sharing mechanisms, and communication strategies such as interrupt-driven versus polling-based interactions.To assess these factors, we implement an LAA using an emulated design on an FPGA integrated with ARM CPUs within an AMD MPSoC platform. Through extensive evaluation, we analyze the performance implications of varying data sizes offloaded from an embedded ARM core to the accelerator. Our findings highlight the significant impact of data sizes of workload tasks, the influence of shared memory access patterns, and the trade-offs associated with different design considerations on the communication performance of accelerators. Additionally, this research characterizes communication overhead structures and provides optimization insights for accelerator design, ultimately targeting to enable higher performance in SoCs and MPSoCs with embedded acceleration technologies.

title: Design and Implementation of UVM-based Verification Framework for Deep Learning Accelerators
authors: D. Ragavi, S. Varni, M. Megarnisha Begum, M. Lavanya, N. Divyadharshini
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: The increasing demand for real-time artificial intelligence (AI) applications has propelled the need for efficient and reliable Deep Learning Accelerators (DLAs). However, verifying the functional correctness of these complex hardware architectures poses significant challenges. This paper presents a Universal Verification Methodology (UVM)-based verification framework tailored specifically for DLAs. The proposed framework ensures systematic, reusable, and scalable verification of key computational modules such as convolution, matrix multiplication, pooling, and activation functions. It incorporates directed and random stimulus generation, functional coverage analysis, and a scoreboard-based result validation mechanism. Furthermore, advanced UVM features including sequences, transactions, monitors, and agents are integrated to ensure modularity and compliance with industry standards. Error injection strategies are embedded to assess the robustness of the design under adverse conditions. The simulation is carried out using Vivado and Verilator tools, demonstrating the effectiveness of the framework in identifying design flaws and ensuring coverage closure. This work contributes towards enhancing the reliability and verification efficiency of DLAs in safety-critical AI systems.

title: Enhancing Network Intrusion Detection Systems Using Machine Learning and Software Engineering Principles
authors: Thomas Fajar Nugraha, Suharyadi, Devis Rabertra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Traditional Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) frequently face challenges in adapting to evolving cyber threats because of their dependence on static rules and restricted contextual awareness, particularly in dynamic cloud environments. This study presents a robust, production-ready Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) that combines deep learning with modular software engineering principles to improve detection accuracy and operational maintainability. The solution utilizes a hybrid CNN-LSTM model, which is trained on actual HTTP/S Load Balancer logs from Google Cloud Platform (GCP) infrastructure within the Pelindo environment, gathered over a one-month duration in July 2025. The model utilizes CNN layers to identify local attack patterns, such as recurrent access to sensitive files (e.g.,. env), and LSTM layers to capture temporal dependencies in multi-stage attacks, facilitating a thorough understanding of threats. The system employs a scalable, real-time architecture: Logstash manages log ingestion and preprocessing, the deep learning model conducts inference, and Kibana facilitates interactive visualization and alerting for operational monitoring. Experimental results indicate outstanding performance, with an accuracy of 99.995%, an AUC of 0.99997, perfect recall (1.0) for malicious activities (zero false negatives), and a single false positive among 19,142 benign requestseffectively reducing alert fatigue while maintaining thorough threat coverage. This study connects advanced machine learning research with practical system deployment by providing a cloudoptimized, maintainable, and interpretable NIDS framework. The design demonstrates significant potential for crossplatform adaptability via log schema normalization, facilitating the development of a cloud-agnostic anomaly detection engine suitable for AWS, Azure, or on-premises systems.

title: Matrix-Vectorized Canonical Signed Digit Quantized Neural Networks for Efficient Forward Pass Simulation
authors: Maria Khan, Jari Nurmi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Quantized neural networks (QNNs) reduce computational cost but typically rely on multiplications, which limits their efficiency. Canonical Signed Digit (CSD) representation eliminates the need for multipliers through signed shifts. We present a matrix-vectorized Python framework for efficient batch forward-pass evaluation of CSD-QNNs, achieving near-lossless accuracy (absolute errors 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-5</sup>, MSE 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-10</sup>) and robustness across 8 - 16 bit quantization, while highlighting hardware potential for shift-and-add implementations in FPGA/ASIC deployments.

title: SMART: Semantic Mapping and Analysis for Regional Terrain Using Multi-Scale U-Net and TOPSIS
authors: Rashmi Sonth, Navrati Saxena, Abhishek Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Accurate land use classification is crucial for effective urban planning, but it remains a difficult task due to diverse landscape patterns, variations in satellite imagery, and the challenge of precisely defining boundaries. In this paper, we present a deep learning framework designed for land use classification and suitability modeling. Our approach uses a multi-scale U-Net architecture enhanced with Transformer blocks to achieve high-quality semantic segmentation of both urban and rural landscapes. The framework operates on a patch-wise segmentation strategy with over-segmentation-based feature extraction to address feature imbalance and boundary ambiguity. Additionally, the Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) is employed to compute suitability scores, using dynamic feature weighting derived from a Random Forest model. The system was evaluated on a real-world dataset of over 10,000 image tiles across 10 object classes. Our framework improves segmentation accuracy by an average of $\mathbf{2 9 . 8 \%}$ over a baseline CNN model, with specific gains in critical urban categories such as Buildings ($+\mathbf{4 8 . 1 1} \%$), Roads ($+\mathbf{5 8 . 6 4} \%$), and Structures $(\mathbf{+ 1 7 2 . 9 4 \%})$. Evaluation metrics include Pixel Accuracy, Intersection over Union (IoU). Comparative analysis highlights sharper boundary delineation and more interpretable suitability rankings than conventional approaches. Our method offers a scalable and data-driven solution for sustainable urban development.

title: Analysis of a Chaotic Oscillator Signal Using the Quaternion Short-Time Fourier Transform
authors: Łukasz Makowski
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: Chaotic oscillators provide a promising foundation for PUFs that can enhance authentication in IoT devices. The highly dynamic nature of these circuits, however, calls for detailed analysis of their output signals. Quaternions, as a multidimensional number system, are well suited to this task. In this work, a real-valued signal from a chaotic oscillator is embedded into quaternions through orthogonal components and analyzed using the QSTFT with right-multiplied exponential kernels. The practical outcome is a validated Python toolkit that enables QSTFT analysis and supports future extensions toward efficient implementations and security applications.

title: Evaluating Rapid Makespan Predictions for Heterogeneous Systems with Programmable Logic
authors: Martin Wilhelm, Franz Freitag, Max Tzschoppe, Thilo Pionteck
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Heterogeneous computing systems, which combine general-purpose processors with specialized accelerators, are increasingly important for optimizing the performance of modern applications. A central challenge is to decide which parts of an application should be executed on which accelerator or, more generally, how to map the tasks of an application to available devices. Predicting the impact of a change in a task mapping on the overall makespan is non-trivial. While there are very capable simulators, these generally require a full implementation of the tasks in question, which is particularly time-intensive for programmable logic. A promising alternative is to use a purely analytical function, which allows for very fast predictions, but abstracts significantly from reality. Bridging the gap between theory and practice poses a significant challenge to algorithm developers. This paper aims to aid in the development of rapid makespan prediction algorithms by providing a highly flexible evaluation framework for heterogeneous systems consisting of CPUs, GPUs and FPGAs, which is capable of collecting real-world makespan results based on abstract task graph descriptions. We analyze to what extent actual makespans can be predicted by existing analytical approaches. Furthermore, we present common challenges that arise from high-level characteristics such as data transfer overhead and device congestion in heterogeneous systems.

title: Enhancing Insulator Inspection: A YOLO and DETR Approach to Image-Based Defect Detection
authors: Dominika Pacek, Zuzanna Krawczyk-Borysiak
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: This paper addresses automatic defect detection in electrical insulators from photographs using two deep learning models: You Only Look Once (YOLO) and Detection Transformer (DETR). The study evaluates models that can be trained and tested on consumer-grade hardware, using the Insulator Defect Image Dataset (IDID). Results show that deep learning provides an effective solution for this task, with YOLOv9s achieving the highest performance (95.1% F1 score and 86.41% mAP50 on the test set).

title: Real-Time Critical Threat Detection Using DroneEmbedded YOLOv8 Object Detection System
authors: Amal Habibi, Zied Hajaiej
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Drones have become indispensable tools across various domains, including surveillance, military operations, and hazardous environments monitoring. Their ability to operate effectively in high-risk areas while ensuring the safety of human operators makes them invaluable for real-time threat detection. This study presents the development of a droneembedded system designed to detect critical threats, such as fires, explosions, and landmines, using advanced object detection algorithms. A comparative analysis of one-stage and two-stage detection approaches identified YOLOv8 as the optimal choice due to its superior balance between accuracy and speed, crucial factors for real-time applications. Experimental results demonstrate the system’s strong performance across key metrics, including precision, recall, and inference speed, confirming the robustness and suitability of YOLOv8 for realtime critical threat detection.

title: Cloud Computing Models and Management: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Henrihs Gorskis, Maija Anspoka, Jānis Laganovskis, Artūrs Rubenis, Rinalds Miezītis
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: The paper compares public, private, and hybrid cloud computing models, analysing security, costs, integration, and management. It examines IaaS, PaaS, SaaS, and CaaS models, GDPR requirements, and cost optimization strategies. The significance of cloud governance and cloud management is emphasized for the effective, secure, and cost-efficient utilization of cloud environments. This paper aims to optimise and balance the security and financial aspects of using cloud computing services.

title: A Modified RoCoF-Based Frequency Control Strategy for Grid Forming Wind Turbine Power Plants in 100 % Renewable Energy Systems
authors: Aaqib Manzoor, Dhiraj Khadka, Zakir Hussain Rather, Hao Wang, Suryanarayana Doolla
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The shift towards renewable-dominated grids introduces significant challenges for frequency stability, primarily due to the displacement of conventional synchronous generators and their associated inertia. Rate of Change of Frequency (RoCoF)based control strategies have emerged as viable solutions for fast frequency response in inverter-dominated systems. This paper proposes a modified RoCoF-based frequency control strategy for Type-4 grid-forming based wind turbine power plants operating in a $100 \%$ renewable energy integrated grid. The proposed control scheme enhances frequency response of the system by improving both the frequency nadir and the RoCoF during contingency events. A detailed simulation study is conducted on the modified IEEE 39-bus test system to assess the effectiveness of the control approach. The performance of the proposed strategy is compared against conventional RoCoF-based control and $\Delta \mathbf{f}$ based frequency response methods. Comparative analysis reveals the effectiveness of proposed control approach.

title: Power Efficient Attention Acceleration on CGLA
authors: Ayumu Takeuchi, Yasuhiko Nakashima
abstract: With the rapid expansion of generative AI, Transformer models have become widely adopted, but their internal Attention mechanism poses a bottleneck due to its quadratic complexity in both computation and memory. FlashAttention has emerged as an efficient algorithm that reduces memory access and enables faster computation while maintaining exact numerical output. However, its implementation has been limited to GPU platforms. In this work, we propose a power-efficient realization of FlashAttention on IMAX3, a linear array-based Coarse-Grained Reconfigurable Array (CGRA) that we refer to as Coarse-Grained Linear Array (CGLA) accelerator. By adapting the block-wise computation and memory layout of FlashAttention to the resource-constrained IMAX3 architecture, we demonstrate that efficient Attention computation is possible in a broader range of hardware environments. Our implementation achieves 4–5 times speedup over naive attention, reduces memory usage, and preserves numerical accuracy. Moreover, Energy-Delay Product (EDP) analysis reveals that FlashAttention on IMAX3 outperforms NVIDIA RTX 4090 for short sequence lengths, highlighting its competitiveness in power efficiency.

title: A Method for Incorporating Frequency Nadir Limits in Power System Restoration Planning
authors: Xiangyu Zou, Ilyas Farhat, John W. Simpson-Porco
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Power system restoration following a blackout involves a sequence of actions to recover the network. Restoration planning must take into account the dynamic impacts of each restorative action to ensure that they do not compromise the system’s security. In this work, we construct a frequencyconstrained mixed-integer linear program (MILP) to find fast and dynamically secure restoration plans. We present a novel frequency nadir prediction method that uses the unique knowledge of the magnitude and timing of electrical disturbances during restoration. The predictions are used to introduce frequency nadir constraints, which are linearized through a receding-horizon solution approach to the MILP. A case study simulated in MATLAB and PSS/E illustrates the effectiveness of the proposed frequency prediction and optimization methods.

title: Lesion-Based Diabetic Retinopathy Detection Using Hybrid Deep Learning Models
authors: Keerthana BS, Karthik R Kammar, Jhansi BS, J Rama Rao, Gnaneswari Gnanaguru
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) is a leading cause of vision impairment globally, necessitating early and accurate detection for effective intervention. This review critically examines the lesion-based paradigm for DR detection, which aligns closely with clinical diagnostic practices by identifying and analyzing retinal lesions such as microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton wool spots. Emphasizing the limitations of end-to-end models, the review explores hybrid deep learning architectures—combinations of CNNs, RNNs, Transformers, ensemble strategies, and traditional machine learning classifiers—that enhance lesion detection accuracy, robustness, and interpretability. It evaluates foundational segmentation models like U-Net, advanced architectures such as EfficientNet and Swin Transformer, and various feature fusion and attention mechanisms. The paper also surveys major public DR datasets, discusses performance metrics for both segmentation and grading, and highlights ongoing challenges including subtle lesion detection, annotation scarcity, and model generalizability. Future research directions underscore the potential of explainable AI, multi-modal learning, and federated frameworks to advance clinically viable and scalable DR screening solutions.

title: Towards Winter Peaking Grids
authors: Yarib Suárez Granados, Kelton Friedrich, James Cotton
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: While province-wide electricity demand currently peaks in the summertime due to air-conditioning loads, decarbonization efforts are prompting a shift toward electrified home heating, which introduces new challenges for grid reliability. By leveraging smart-meter high resolution electricity consumption data at local levels, alongside historical weather data, the areas that would benefit from targeted demand response and conservation programs for peak winter demand can be identified. Additionally, the expected electrical consumption of these regions can be estimated as a function of temperature for electrical demand forecasting.

title: Dynamic Fuzzy Control for Robust Trajectory Tracking of the Pelican Robot in Dynamic Environments
authors: Khouloud Guesmi, Imen Saidi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Trajectory tracking in dynamic and unstructured environments presents significant challenges for robotic systems, particularly in terms of accuracy and robustness. Traditional Proportional-Derivative (PD) controllers, even with gravity compensation, face limitations when dealing with uncertainty and non-linearity. This paper investigates dynamic fuzzy control as a robust alternative to enhance trajectory tracking performance, specifically for the Pelican 2-DOF manipulator. A comparison between dynamic fuzzy control and PD control with gravity compensation is conducted, focusing on performance under unpredictable conditions. Simulation results demonstrate that dynamic fuzzy control outperforms PD control in terms of trajectory tracking accuracy, particularly in dynamic and uncertain environments. The fuzzy controller offers greater flexibility and adaptability, making it more effective in environments subject to external disturbances and variations. The paper concludes by highlighting the advantages of dynamic fuzzy control for trajectory tracking in unstructured environments and proposes future research directions for real-world validation and application in robotic manipulators.

title: YOLO-Powered Detection of Helmets and Number Plates for Enforcing Safety on Wheels
authors: Nithish Reddy, Radha Reddy, Rajesh Mahadeva
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Road safety is becoming an increasingly important issue, particularly in a country like India, where two-wheelers are a common mode of transport. A major concern is that many riders do not wear helmets, which can lead to serious injuries or even death in the event of an accident. This paper proposes an intelligent system that automatically recognizes riders not wearing helmets and saves their images and vehicle number plates using a combination of computer vision and deep learning. This system uses the YOLO object detection algorithm to locate riders, helmets, and number plates in real-time video streams. A custom-trained optical character recognition model is then used to extract and recognize the characters on the plate. All recognized number plates are stored in a CSV file, from which we can send fines to the corresponding riders.

title: Transforming Carbon Credit Trading Through Tokenization: A Blockchain-Based Approach to Sustainable Finance
authors: Rushil Kalola, Priyank Makwana, Kishan Makadiya
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: The integration of blockchain technology in carbon credit markets has emerged as a transformative solution to address inefficiencies in traditional trading mechanisms. This paper explores the role of tokenized carbon credits, decentralized trading platforms, and smart contracts in enhancing transparency, trust, and efficiency within voluntary and compliance-based carbon markets. By analyzing various blockchain-enabled carbon credit projects, including KlimaDAO, AirCarbon Exchange, and other decentralized initiatives, this research highlights the advantages of digital s regulatory uncertainty, scalability issues, and market adoption barriers are also examined. The findings suggest that blockchain-based carbon credit systems can significantly reduce fraud, increase liquidity, and support global sustainability goals. However, the success of these innovations depends on the development of standardized frameworks, cross-sector collaboration, and regulatory integration. This study provides insights into the evolving landscape of blockchain-driven carbon markets and proposes strategies for enhancing their effectiveness in combating climate change. tokenization, automated verification and decentralised governance models.

title: Real-Time Predictive Analytics in Streaming Data: Merging Data Science with Cloudless Computing
authors: Satya Manesh Veerapaneni, Srinivas Chippagiri, Milankumar Rana, Vijayakumar. Krishnapillai, Harshini Gadam
abstract: The ample increase in real-time data made by the IoT devices, social platforms, and industrial systems require scalable, low-latency predictive analytics solutions. The existing cloud-centred systems tend to create delays, network bandwidth perspective, and security issues which create a challenge in the components of the time-sensitive apps. In this current paper, a new Real-Time Predictive Analytics in Streaming Data paradigm is presented by incorporating the latest data science-related methodologies into cloudless computing approaches like edge and fog computing. The described model relies on the dynamics of lightweight machine learning algorithms and distributed engine stream processing in order to carry out localized, on-device analytics and minimizes the dependency on the concentration of cloud infrastructure. We test the system on real-world streaming data and show orders-of-magnitude improvement in latency, throughput and accuracy of prediction when compared with conventional cloud-based solutions. The findings support the findings in the combination of data science and decentralized computing Toomer data science and decentralized computing to facilitate real-time, scalable, and privacy-preserving decision-making in dynamic environments.

title: ecoAIware: Exploring Public Awareness of Generative AI’s Environmental Footprint Through Participatory Data Physicalizations
authors: Anniek Jansen, Supraja Sankaran
publish: Proceedings of the 28th International Academic Mindtrek
abstract: Generative AI is becoming increasingly accessible to non-expert users. However, these technologies consume substantial amounts of environmental resources, often sourced non-sustainably. This environmental impact remains largely invisible to users, and it is unclear how aware the public is of these environmental costs. The intangible nature of generative AI, like other cloud-based technologies, suggests that awareness of these hidden environmental impacts may be limited. To explore and increase public understanding, we propose ecoAIware, an interactive demonstration using participatory data physicalizations (PDPs). These PDPs represent electricity and water consumption, CO2 emissions, and individuals’ perceptions of the importance of the societal and environmental impacts of generative AI. By embodying these metrics, we aim to engage and inform users in a tangible, interactive way. ecoAIware can spark critical reflection and discussion while also serving as a tool for gathering data on public awareness, thus contributing to the growing discourse on generative AI’s environmental footprint.
