title: Multi-Scale Dilated Window Attention Transformer for Grade Prediction of Zinc Concentrate
authors: Cheng Peng, Hao Luo, Zhaohui Tang, Weihua Gui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Accurate grade prediction of zinc concentrate is crucial for optimizing the flotation mining process. Traditional methods face challenges, including inconsistencies between froth feature capture and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis sampling times, non-stationary sequences, and asymmetric error costs, which hinder practical applications. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a multi-scale dilated window attention Transformer (MSDWT) model. The model aligns froth feature sequences with zinc concentrate grade values and applies Z-score normalization to remove non-stationarity. The model incorporates temporal information through a hybrid encoding mechanism and accelerates inference using root mean square normalization (RMSNorm). By integrating information across multiple time scales using multi-scale dilated window attention layers and applying an asymmetric loss function, the training process is effectively optimized. Experimental results show that, compared to existing typical models such as Transformer, Enc-Dec+RNN, STS-D+LSTM, MSFT, and NST, the RMSE was reduced by 22.6%, 12.4%, 11.0%, 9.9%, and 9.3%, respectively.

title: CasFly : Causal Chain Tracing Across Fragmented Edge Data for IoT Healthcare
authors: Anshita Gupta, Sudip Misra
abstract: Data fragmentation across IoT healthcare devices makes identifying and tracing causal health events challenging. In this work, we propose CasFly, a decentralized, on-the-fly causal chain tracing protocol for healthcare event sequences. We design a specialized data structure, Temporal Probabilistic Health Graph (TPHG), to dynamically trace event dependencies across heterogeneous healthcare devices. When a device detects an anomalous parameter at the edge, it queries its local TPHG to identify the most probable temporal precursors. We propose incremental chain formation at each of the devices using LaVE Algorithm, a Lag-aware Viterbi Expansion Algorithm. The algorithm transmits data only when new causal paths are identified, thus reducing the latency of the dependency path construction. CasFly operates device-to-device by expanding the chain until no further expansion is possible. Finally, the chain is returned to the initiating device for visualization and analysis. We observe that on emulated IoT hardware, TPHGs load in < 0.1 s and full chains develop in ≤5 s using ∼170MB RAM. TPHGs reduce storage by ∼97.6% versus Conditional Probability Tables. As compared to PCMCI+, LaVE improves macro AUPRC by ≈18% and reduces log-loss by ≈8%, with similar AUROC. These results indicate that on-the-fly chain construction supports real-time monitoring and clinician interpretation of probable cross-device event sequences.

title: A Novel Generalized Capacitive Coupler Model With Application to Unilateral Compensated Capacitive Power Transfer Systems
authors: Zhihao Guo, Xiaohui Qu, Cheng Li, Yundi Li, Jinghang Liu, Chi K. Tse
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: Unilateral compensation offers a promising solution for the compact and lightweight design of wireless power transfer systems. Inspired by unilateral compensated inductive power transfer (IPT) converters designed from the generalized transformer model, this brief proposes a generalized capacitive coupler model for capacitive power transfer (CPT) converters. By introducing an additional design freedom, the proposed model offers more flexible compensation network design than traditional T- or Π-type model, while establishing a unified analytical framework. Subsequently, a family of unilateral compensation networks is readily derived on the basis of this model, with advantages of near unity power factor, flexible load-independent constant-voltage (CV) or -current (CC) output, soft switching and so on. Finally, a 100 W CPT prototype with LLL-None(N) unilateral network is built to verify the analysis.

title: VOCALoco: Viability-Optimized Cost-aware Adaptive Locomotion_supp1-3632604.mp4
authors: Stanley Wu
abstract: Recent advancements in legged robot locomotion have facilitated traversal over increasingly complex terrains. Despite this progress, many existing approaches rely on end-to-end deep reinforcement learning (DRL), which poses limitations in terms of safety and interpretability, especially when generalizing to novel terrains. To overcome these challenges, we introduce VOCALoco, a modular skill-selection framework that dynamically adapts locomotion strategies based on perceptual input. Given a set of pre-trained locomotion policies, VOCALoco evaluates their viability and energy-consumption by predicting both the safety of execution and the anticipated cost of transport over a fixed planning horizon. This joint assessment enables the selection of policies that are both safe and energy-efficient, given the observed local terrain. We evaluate our approach on staircase locomotion tasks, demonstrating its performance in both simulated and real-world scenarios using a quadrupedal robot. Empirical results show that VOCALoco achieves improved robustness and safety during stair ascent and descent compared to a conventional end-to-end DRL policy.

title: OwlSight: A Robust Illumination Adaptation Framework for Dark Video Human Action Recognition
authors: Shihao Cheng, Jinlu Zhang, Yue Liu, Aoran Xiao, Zhigang Tu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Human action recognition in low-light environments is crucial for various real-world applications. However, the existing methods overlook the full utilization of brightness information throughout the training phase, leading to suboptimal performance. To address this issue, we propose OwlSight, a biomimetic framework with whole-stage illumination enhancement to interact with action classification for accurate dark video human action recognition. Specifically, OwlSight incorporates a Time-Consistency Module (TCM) to capture shallow spatiotemporal features meanwhile maintaining temporal coherence, which are then processed by a Luminance Adaptation Module (LAM) to dynamically adjust the brightness based on the input luminance distribution. Furthermore, a Reflect Augmentation Module (RAM) is presented to maximize illumination utilization and simultaneously enhance action recognition via two interactive paths. Additionally, we build a large-scale dataset Dark-101, which comprises 21,030 dark videos across 101 action categories, significantly surpassing the existing datasets (e.g., ARID1.5 and Dark-48) in scale and diversity. Our method establishes new state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance across all benchmarks, achieving Top-1 accuracies of 99.27% on ARID (a 2.0% improvement), 94.85% on ARID1.5 (a 5.36% improvement), 48.24% on Dark-48 (a 1.56% improvement), and 53.85% on Dark-101 (a 1.72% improvement), demonstrating its superior effectiveness in challenging dark video environments.

title: 3D Trajectory and Pickup/Drop-Off Strategy for UAV-Enabled Delivery: Trade-Off Between Time and Energy Minimization
authors: Kisong Lee, Sung Ho Chae
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: In this paper, we explore the rigorous mathematical modeling of an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-enabled parcel delivery to optimize a three-dimensional (3D) trajectory and pickup/drop-off strategy. Taking into account practical considerations including the avoidance of no-fly zones (NFZs) and the weight restrictions of the UAV, our goal is to jointly optimize the pickup and drop-off indicators, lengths of time slots, and horizontal and vertical trajectories, with the objective of minimizing the weighted-sum of completion time and energy consumption. To address the nonconvexity of the formulated problem, which involves mixed-integer nonlinear programming, we first apply a successive convex approximation to transform the nonconvex problem into a convex one for optimization variables. Moreover, we utilize a penalty convex-concave procedure to maintain the binary nature of integer variables. Finally, for the relaxed convex problem, we propose a low-complexity algorithm that derives the suboptimal UAV strategy iteratively. The simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy in establishing 3D trajectories for specific objectives and completely avoiding NFZs while maintaining the binary nature of the pickup and drop-off indicators. Furthermore, the comparative study provides insight into the trade-offs between time-minimization and energy-minimization strategies, offering the flexibility to choose the most suitable approach based on the specific service requirements and objectives.

title: A Comprehensive Survey on Data Distillation: Techniques, Frameworks, and Future Directions
authors: Qaiser Razi, Somya Singh, Riya Priyadarshini, Vikas Hassija, GSS Chalapathi
abstract: The increased adoption of machine learning techniques has led to exponential growth in data generation and utilization. This growth has necessitated efficient storage, processing, and utilization of this data, which presents critical challenges, particularly in resource-constrained environments such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and edge devices. Data distillation has emerged as a promising solution that reduces dataset size while preserving essential information and optimizing computational resources. This survey provides a comprehensive analysis of data reduction techniques, covering methodologies such as knowledge distillation, coreset selection, hyperparameter optimization, and generative modeling. We further explore various data distillation learning frameworks, including performance, gradient, parameter, and distribution matching, highlighting their effectiveness in different data modalities such as images, graphs, and text. Furthermore, we examine the implications of data distillation in key areas such as continual and federated learning, privacy preservation, security, healthcare, IoT applications, and edge computing. By enabling lightweight models with minimal computational overhead, data distillation facilitates real-time inference and decision-making on edge devices, making it highly relevant for low-power, bandwidth-limited environments. Data distillation offers numerous advantages in improving model efficiency, reducing training costs, and enhancing privacy. However, data distillation faces numerous challenges related to scalability, computational complexity, and information retention. This survey identifies these challenges and outlines potential future research directions, providing insights for researchers seeking to leverage data distillation for scalable and efficient machine-learning applications.

title: ASAP-ML: Antibiotic Susceptibility and Antibiogram Prediction with Machine Learning Methods
authors: Doruk Topcu, Ebru Akc¸apınar Sezer
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a global health problem that poses a threat for now and poses an even greater threat for the future. Since the discovery of the first antibiotics, pathogens have developed different mechanisms of resistance against antibiotics. Today, the technology to understand the mechanisms of AMR and their genomics is more competent than ever. This paper provides a wide range of information about using genomic data combined with machine learning for predicting antibiotic resistance and proposes a multi-model approach ASAP (Antibiotic Susceptibility and Antibiogram Pre diction) for creating antibiograms. In this work, 10 different machine learning models, including Convolutional Neural Network, Nearest Neighbor, Random Forest, XGBoost, CatBoost, Naive Bayes, Support Vector Machines, Light Gradient Boosting Machine, Gradient Boost, and Logistic Regression, have been tested, evaluated, and compared for their predictive capabilities. For data preprocessing, different methods of feature extraction through n-gram encoding have been tested. For the evaluation of the models, accuracy, recall, precision, and F1 scores are used. Experiments show that models can predict the antibiotic resistance of a given pathogen sequence with up to 0.99 accuracy and 0.90+ macro average recall. The best performing model for this work has been XGBoost with 0.99 accuracy, and the least predictive model has been Naive Bayes with 0.89 accuracy. Our proposed method results shows that machine learning with gene sequences are promising tools to improve the current manual antibiogram creation, maintenance process and can provide healthcare professionals with valuable insights for less empirical antibiotic prescribing

title: Dynamic Backbone Optimization of YOLOv10 for Real-Time Object Detection in UAV-Based Search and Rescue Missions
authors: Aditya Mishra, Modigari Narendra, Aryan Sinha, Aakash Kumar
abstract: Real-time object detection in unmanned aerial vehicle based Search and Rescue missions requires a critical balance between accuracy, speed, and the computational constraints of edge devices. YOLOv10 provides a powerful baseline, but operational efficiency greatly depends on the backbone architecture and its performance. In this study, an evidence-based framework is set, which would help search and rescue practitioners to pick the most appropriate model configurations according to their specific mission profiles and hardware capabilities.We conducted a fully empirical study to understand how to select a model from 8 different backbones, including different versions of EfficientNet, GhostNet, MobileNet, ResNet50, and Swin, across the five YOLOv10 variants from Nano to X-Large on the Search and Rescue Dataset. The results map a clear performance landscape where models are categorized into distinct groups based on the trade-off between inference speed, accuracy, and computational load. For the edge deployment with high constraints, the YOLOv10-Nano with MobileNet backbone achieves the best compromise, at which it exhibits a very high inference speed of 80.5 FPS with 0.3945 mAP@0.5:0.95 accuracy. For server environments with low or no constraints, YOLOv10-XLarge with EfficientNetV2M attained the highest performance of 0.4898 mAP with 29.3 FPS. Yolov-medium with the EfficientNetV2Mbackbone achieved a very good tradeoff between accuracy and speed, with a map@50:95 score of 0.4791 with close to 54 frames per second. Our work highlightshts new light on the trade-offs between speed, accuracy, and complexity of models for more effective and resource-aware object detection systems, thereby speeding up rescue operations.

title: A Lightweight Physics-Informed Neural Network for Sim-to-Real of Biped Robot_supp1-3632659.mp4
authors: Yan Liu
abstract: In this paper, we present a low-cost, easy-to-implement sim-to-real framework for biped locomotion that narrows the reality gap using only simulation data, without motion-capture or additional real-world measurements. First, a walking policy for the BRUCE robot is trained in Isaac Gym via reinforcement learning. Next, we develop a compact, physics-informed neural network (PINN) grounded in Euler-Lagrange structure and augmented with an LSTM to predict simulator forward dynamics. Trained solely on simulation trajectories, the PINN forecasts next-step joint angles and velocities of the simulated robot given the physical robot's current state and control inputs. During hardware deployment, and consistent with a whole-body control architecture, these predicted states serve as reference joint states while the policy outputs provide feedforward torque commands; a feedforward-plus-feedback torque controller then computes the executed joint torques, thereby reducing the sim-to-real gap. Experiments on BRUCE demonstrate that our method better reproduces simulated behavior and attains higher tracking accuracy than direct policy transfer. Furthermore, the dynamics predictor runs at 1 kHz on embedded hardware, showing superior real-time performance relative to existing learning-based models.

title: Allosteric Rate Control of Chaos Governs Reaction Rate Kinetics
authors: Tjeerd V. olde Scheper, Alex Silverthorne, Holly Tonks, Karl Morten
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Objective: Models of metabolic systems have been encapsulated by reaction rate theory, stochastic reaction models, and dynamic flux estimation, amongst others, based on the foundation of Michaelis-Menten kinetics. The limitations of these approaches are well understood and can be summarised as the sole dependent relation with substrate concentration, the encapsulation of rate in a single relevant scalar, and the subsequent lack of functional control that results from the steady-state assumption. Methods: The Rate Control of Chaos (RCC) is a nonlinear control method that has been shown to be effective in controlling the dynamic state of nonlinear oscillators based on the concept of rate limitation of the exponential growth in chaotic systems. The method is extended with allosteric properties into Allosteric Rate Control of Chaos (ARCC) to allow robust control of the enzymatic process. Results: ARCC fully replicates the Michaelis-Menten kinetics as well as allosteric control. The emergent dynamics is insensitive to perturbations and noise but susceptible to regulatory adjustments. This method adapts the control parameters dynamically in the presence of a substrate and a ligand, and permits introduction of energy relations into the control function. Conclusion: The ARCC method more closely resembles biochemical properties of enzyme mediated reactions and removes the need for quasi-steady-state assumptions and allows the modelling of complex dynamic metabolic systems. Significance: The dynamic nature of the control enables the modelling of the entire complex dynamics of metabolic systems as a large scale free system, potentially addressing metabolic disorders and explain the behaviour of metabolic control.

title: ClothMate: Leveraging Grasp-Fling Consistency for Generalizable and Data-Efficient Garment Flattening_supp1-3632758.mp4
authors: Jiaxiang Luo
abstract: We present ClothMate, a general framework for flattening garments of various categories from arbitrary configurations. Prior end-to-end methods are often limited in data efficiency. To address this, ClothMate introduces an intriguing observation: in garment flattening, grasping the same point pair typically results in a consistent fling response, regardless of the current state of the garment. Building on this insight, we adopt a two-stage paradigm: first learning point- wise fling responses under a canonicalized and aligned configuration, then generalizing to arbitrary states via point-to-point projection. This explicit decoupling of state estimation and action prediction mitigates challenges arising from infinite-DOF dynamics and severe self-occlusion, enabling the model to better capture common interaction patterns, thus improving data efficiency to support a broader range of garment categories. Additionally, we propose a novel static pick-and-stretch dual-arm flattening strategy that refines the outcome by heuristically stretching around adaptively selected key points. Compared to the state of the art, ClothMate is trained and evaluated simultaneously on five garment categories, using only 15% of the total data that baselines would require for separate training on all five categories, while achieving higher coverage (91.5% vs. 85.0%) and fewer steps (4.7 vs. 7.0). The code, dataset and trained models are available here.

title: Integrated Sensing and Communications Framework for 6G Networks
authors: Hongliang Luo, Tengyu Zhang, Chuanbin Zhao, Yucong Wang, Bo Lin, Yuhua Jiang, Dongqi Luo, Feifei Gao
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel integrated sensing and communications (ISAC) framework for the sixth generation (6G) mobile networks, in which we decompose the real physical world into static environment, dynamic targets, and various object materials. The ubiquitous static environment occupies the vast majority of the physical world, for which we design static environment reconstruction (SER) scheme to obtain the layout and point cloud information of static buildings. The dynamic targets floating in static environments create the spatiotemporal transition of the physical world, for which we design comprehensive dynamic target sensing (DTS) scheme to detect, estimate, track, image and recognize the dynamic targets in real-time. The object materials enrich the electromagnetic laws of the physical world, for which we develop electromagnetic property sensing (EMPS) scheme to estimate the electromagnetic coefficient of objects. Besides, to integrate these sensing functions into existing communications systems, we discuss the interference issues and corresponding solutions for ISAC cellular networks. Furthermore, we develop an ISAC hardware prototype platform that can reconstruct the environmental maps and sense the dynamic targets. With all these designs, the proposed ISAC framework can support multifarious emerging applications, such as digital twins, low-altitude economy, internet of vehicles, marine management, deformation monitoring, etc.

title: CardioMind: Deep Learning Framework for Stress Detection Using IoT Devices
authors: Lynn El Arwadi, Layal Abu Daher
abstract: Chronic stress significantly affects cardiovascular, psychological, and immune health, and contributes to conditions such as hypertension and depression. Recent advances in wearable technology, such as electrocardiogram (ECG) sensors, have enabled continuous, non-invasive monitoring of physiological stress responses. This paper introduces CardioMind, a lightweight deep learning model designed for real-time stress detection using ECG data. It processes short ECG segments to extract heart rate variability (HRV) features across the time, frequency, and non-linear domains. To improve generalization across individuals, we propose subject-specific baseline normalization based on resting states. The model was trained and evaluated on the WESAD dataset, a widely used benchmark for wearable stress detection. CardioMind achieved strong performance across subjects, reaching an average accuracy of 90.8% using leave-one-subject-out validation. Its low resource requirements and real-time processing make it a strong candidate for integration into Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled wearable devices for early stress detection and mental health support. To the best of our knowledge, CardioMind is among the first models to integrate robust HRV-based features with subject-specific normalization in a lightweight architecture suitable for real-world, wearable deployment.

title: Small Packets, Big Challenges: Enhancing Reliability in High-Speed, Low-Latency Inter-FPGA Communication
authors: Vida Sobhani, Jialan Zheng, Tobias Gemmeke
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Multi-FPGA systems are increasingly popular for low-power, accelerated, rapid, and high-fidelity modeling. However, their performance is often limited by FPGA-to-FPGA communication, which demands reliable, high-speed, and lowlatency links. Existing high-speed links are typically optimized for large-packet throughput, often overlooking the tight latency and bandwidth requirements of small packets. Achieving both low latency and acceptable effective bandwidth for small packets at high line rates is particularly challenging, as even moderate error rates can cause conventional approaches, such as Automatic Repeat reQuest (ARQ), to collapse under frequent retransmissions. This work addresses the latency-bandwidth trade-off for smallpacket traffic at high line rate by designing a customized serial link in an FPGA-cluster for accelerated neuroscience simulations. The design leverages a hybrid reliability architecture along with co-optimization of reliability, link, and physical layers. The reliability layer combines ARQ with the short block code <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R S(31,27)_{2^{5}}$</tex>. The RS coding mitigates burst errors caused by the decision feedback equalizer required for high line-rate transmission, thereby improving the ARQ performance. The link and physical layers are designed with minimized latency and bandwidth overhead. The experimental results on two interconnected Alveo U200 boards show that the implemented link achieves 23.73 Gbps effective bandwidth with a router-to-router latency of 148 ns using 28G NRZ transceivers. To our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of a high-speed, reliable, and low-latency serial link optimized for small-packet traffic, highlighting a pathway toward more scalable and high-performance FPGA-based computing platforms.

title: Permission Manager: A Web-Based Tool for Application Permission Analysis and Privacy Protection
authors: G. Sekhar Reddy, Ramesh Babu Pittala, G.L Anand Babu, Srinivas Sangepu, Rithika Kulkarni, Bathoju Narsimha Chary, Aitla Vinay Krishna, Yenumula Sai Ram
abstract: With the increasing sophistication of digital environments, users are more likely to download apps without necessarily being aware of the extent of permissions they provide. This in many cases results in unintended disclosure of sensitive information. Current permission management tools are either platform-specific for mobile, transparent, or do not give actionable information regarding app behavior. To improve on these limitations, this paper presents Permission Manager, a web-based application permission analysis and privacy guard. In contrast to other mobile-based solutions, our system is not OS-specific and provides wider accessibility and device-independent analysis. The software enables users to analyze apps based on a comparison of app names and permissions against a pre-filled database, graphically clustering apps by levels of security risk. It also includes functionality like permission comparison, usage tracking, background activity, data leak alarm, and suggesting revoking of dangerous permissions or uninstalls of suspiciously malicious apps. By concentrating on informative visualizations and database investigation, Permission Manager enables users to enhance their privacy impact perception capabilities for the apps installed by them. This solution is a marked advancement over previous systems in providing an enterprise-class, web-based, and feature-rich platform to facilitate user awareness and control in application security.

title: Enhanced Fault Detection in SRAM-Based FIFO Buffer using MARCH Test Algorithms for MBIST Architectures
authors: Modugu.Krishnaiah, S. Tamilselvan
abstract: In modern digital systems, the memory is the most crucial one in all applications, particularly for signal processing applications, image processing, and networking architectures. This memory process will not be sufficient in all applications; it's producing more error in data writing and reading operations. The error correction and identification methods are also lagging in most cases due to inefficient architecture and testing methods. Thus, this paper analysis an error correction method with a built-in technique called Memory-Built-In Self-Test (MBIST). Methodologies, especially those utilizing MARCH test algorithms, have demonstrated efficacy in identifying both permanent and intermittent errors with hardware overhead. This study provides a thorough comparative analysis of various MARCH test cases, including MARCH X, MARCH C-, MARCH A, MARCH Y, and MARCH B, in relation to SRAM-type FIFO buffers. The efficacy of each test is evaluated based on fault coverage, hardware overhead, testing efficiency, and power consumption. The proposed MBIST structure operates within an FPGA-based NoC environment, its implemented using Verilog HDL and synthesized with Xilinx Vivado on an Artix-7 FPGA. Experimental results demonstrate that MARCH B provides higher level of fault coverage with optimized hardware usage, whereas MARCH X and MARCH Y achieve a balance between efficiency and power consumption. This study improves MBIST implementations, ensuring efficient memory testing with minimized latency and resource constraints, making it suitable for high-performance computing applications.

title: Promoting Creative Thinking in Economics Instruction Through Learning Management Systems
authors: Jun Surjanti, Mohamad Arief Rafsanjani, Luqman Hakim, Retno Mustika Dewi, Putri Ulfa Kamalia, Heny Musfidah, Milenia Ariyati Izza
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: 21st-century education emphasizes the development of creative thinking skills among prospective economics educators through the use of Learning Management Systems (LMS). This study addresses the challenge of limited lecturer utilization of LMS with Single Sign-On (SSO) in higher education institutions. The research aims to describe the growth of creative thinking based on pre-test and post-test results in the Instructional Material Development course, focusing on divergent and convergent thinking dimensions. This qualitative descriptive study involved 110 students from the 2024 cohort of the Economics Education department at a higher education institution in Indonesia. Total sampling was employed as all students in the class actively participated in the learning process under investigation. The analysis was conducted by comparing pre-test and post-test scores using divergent and convergent indicators. The improvement in students' creative thinking was measured separately for each dimension and analyzed using percentage increases. The findings indicate that integrating LMS into the Instructional Material Development course positively influences students' creative thinking. The highest divergent thinking scores were observed in the pre-test, while the highest convergent thinking scores appeared in the post-test. Overall, LMS-based learning was effective in fostering both divergent and convergent aspects of creative thinking. It is recommended that LMS integration be further optimized in the Instructional Material Development course to enhance creative thinking skills among prospective educators.

title: Predicting the Increase in Peak Demand on the Electrical Grid in Ontario due to the Electrification of Space Heating using Air Source Heat Pumps
authors: Vincent Wey, Kelton Friedrich, James Cotton
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: In this study, the increase in peak electrical demand and change in annual greenhouse gas emissions due to the electrification of space heating is estimated for the province of Ontario, Canada.

title: Explainable Brain Tumor Classification Using Grad-CAM and a Transfer Learning Approach
authors: Manan Khatri, Manmita Sahoo, Sameer Sayyad, Vivek Warke, Javed Sayyad
abstract: The complex structure and indistinguishable visual differences of brain tumors poses a significant challenge in medical diagnostics. This study presents a novel deep-learning based approach for automating the classification of brain tumors through transfer learning with ResNet50 architecture. A pre-trained convolutional neural network model is fine-tuned on a labeled dataset of brain MRI images to classify tumors across four major types. The preprocessing and augmentation techniques are used to enhance the model generalization. Thus, ResNet50 achieves a high classification accuracy of 92%, demonstrating the efficiency of transfer learning in medical image analysis. The another evaluation metrics reveals that the proposed approach is a promising tool for clinical decision support systems. Additionally, the visualization of critical regions of the MRI scans has been illustrated using Grad-CAM, which contributes to the model’s prediction, providing transparency and aiding clinical insights.

title: Determinants of Degree Completion in Financial Engineering at Riga Technical University
authors: Natalja Budkina, Andrejs Matvejevs, Oksana Pavlenko
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: This study analyses factors influencing the likelihood of a student successfully obtaining a degree in Financial Engineering bachelor's program at Riga Technical University (RTU). Statistical and econometric methods, including correlation analysis and logistic regression, are employed to estimate the significance of various factors such as first-year academic results, financial situation, secondary school performance, participation in extracurricular activities while studying at university, and geographical origin. Using data from 2009 to 2024, we identify the main determinants behind the likelihood of graduating from Financial Engineering. One of the significant findings is that students from outside the capital show a significantly higher completion rate than those from Riga, which points to the importance of such factors as motivation, adaptability, and financial constraints. Factors decreasing graduation likelihood include insufficient prior mathematical proficiency, poor performance during the first study year, and financial difficulties, which often lead to dropouts. Conversely, strong academic performance in the first year increases the probability of completing the program. Gender and student mobility programs are also evaluated for their potential impact. The results imply that increasing targeted financial help and offering more comprehensive academic support could improve graduation rates. The findings may be helpful for university administrators to reinforce student support mechanisms, particularly for at-risk groups. Performing the conducted analysis with data on other study programs can further contribute to understanding the factors that might help achieve higher academic success among university students and help RTU refine its educational strategies.

title: Real Time Trade Settlement for the US Market
authors: Debarshi Chakraborty, Chung-Sheng Li, Rajdeep Mazumder
abstract: The US market recently moved to a T+1 settlement cycle, which is quite a big step forward, but the real goal here is achieving real time settlement - basically T + 0 or instant settlement - with the ultimate goal of achieving real-time (T+0) settlement, which could significantly enhance the efficiency and stability of U.S. financial markets. This paper proposes a complete solution for instant trade settlement in the US market. Our approach involves using technologies like Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) and Blockchain and combining them with intelligent automation using Agentic Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Large Language Models (LLMs) for their analytical power. The system being detailed here is built around a private, permissioned blockchain setup. This approach gives us immutable record keeping and atomic settlement capabilities through smart contracts. What this means is that tokenized securities and cash can be transferred instantaneously. When it comes to Agentic AI, this technology is being looked at to handle various tasks autonomously. Tasks like pre trade validation, managing real time liquidity, optimizing collateral, and dealing with post trade exceptions. These capabilities collectively aim to reduce both operational and counterparty risks. As for LLMs, these will work as intelligent interfaces for monitoring and reporting. They will handle regulatory compliance automation and improve market insights using natural language processing. This whole integrated framework being proposed should help drastically cut down counterparty risk, boost liquidity, reduce operational costs, and make things more transparent and auditable. This paper also tackles some key challenges - regulatory alignment, interoperability issues, scalability concerns, and cybersecurity aspects. This provides a realistic roadmap for where U.S. financial market infrastructure might head in the future. This work introduces a comprehensive framework that brings together permissioned distributed ledger technology, autonomous AI agents, and large language models to streamline regulatory processes. The result is a real-time (T+0) settlement system specifically designed to meet the demands of institutional trading in the U.S. financial markets.

title: Optimization of Renewable Energy Resources in Smart Grids: Review of Techniques and Objectives
authors: Kory Melchior, Hamed Aly
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Smart grids have received much attention in recent years as a promising concept for the future of power networks. A smart grid involves increasing data collection and processing to improve power quality and potentially increase dependability of renewable energy sources. Increased data availability provides a better opportunity for advanced energy management and scheduling techniques for non-dispatchable sources. This paper serves as a review of optimization techniques used in literature to improve grid stability, minimize losses and lower operating costs. Single and multi-objective optimization techniques can be applied in a variety of problems to tune power electronics and dispatch available energy sources.

title: Enhancing Financial Forecasting with a Hybrid LSTM-Graph Neural Network Model
authors: Chinnakamanam Ranjith Kumar, Bhawani Sankar Panigrahi, Abdul Sattar, Puttagunta Karthikeya, A Para Brama Reddy, Biswajit Brahma, Shibani Tripathy, S. Gopal Krishna Patro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Forecasting stock prices is inherently challenging due to the dynamic and intricate nature of financial data. This research introduces an innovative model that integrates Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks with Graph Neural Networks (GNN), addressing limitations of standalone approaches. Unlike conventional methods that separately analyze temporal patterns or interrelationships among stocks, this hybrid model processes both dimensions concurrently. This dual capability significantly enhances prediction precision and establishes a fundamental stock market information to validate its effectiveness. By combining the strengths of LSTM in capturing temporal dependencies and GNN in modeling relationships between stocks, the hybrid model achieves notable improvements over traditional machine learning and individual models. Experimental results demonstrate superior performance, evidenced by reduced Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) values, as well as higher R2 scores, underscoring its accuracy and reliability. This model offers promising applications in domains such as financial forecasting, algorithmic trading, and portfolio optimization. By addressing both the temporal and relational complexities of stock data, the proposed approach sets a new benchmark for predictive analytics in the financial sector. Its ability to provide more accurate forecasts not only supports better decision-making but also opens avenues for further advancements in predictive modeling and financial technology.

title: Radar Yolo: Resolving Radar Ambiguities With a Tracker
authors: Terell L. Dale, Tod M. Schuck, Ram M. Narayanan
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Range Doppler aliasing creates an inherent trade-off between unambiguous maximum range and Doppler when designing pulse Doppler radar systems. Current approaches to address this trade-off involve commanding several waveforms with different pulse repetition frequencies to ensure measurements are made with the desired maximum unambiguous range and Doppler. However, this approach has the obvious drawback of consuming a limited radar timeline and compute capacity, which can be intolerable for real-time applications. This paper proposes an augmented proposal distribution for Monte Carlo importance sampling-based, multi-sensor measurement adaptive track initiation procedure for the labeled multi-Bernoulli filter that enable efficient and scalable resolution of range Doppler aliasing via the recursion of the random finite set based filter. A solution for a monostatic 3D measurement function is provided, and autonomous driving simulation results are shown to verify the resultant aliasing, track initialization, and localization performance.

title: Modelling the Powertrain and Aerodynamic Behaviour of a Small Electric Aircraft
authors: Lekha Dasari Murugappa, Mehrdad Kazerani
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The environmental impact of fossil fuels has driven major industries towards electrification for a sustainable future. Aviation, though contributing only 3% of global GHGs, is expected to triple emissions by 2050 [1]. Electric aircraft rely on battery packs, which require enhanced performance, reliability, and lifespan to ensure safe operation. Hence, the development of comprehensive simulation models of aircrafts is essential for studying and analyzing the battery behavior under various flight conditions. This poster presents a simulation model of the powertrain and aerodynamic behaviour of a small electric aircraft. A mathematical model representing the aerodynamic behavior is developed, which determines the thrust generated by the propeller, and computes the load torque and rotational speed (RPM) for the powertrain model, based on a real-life flight dataset [2]. The motor load torque and RPM are provided as reference inputs to the powertrain control system. The electric powertrain is modeled in MATLAB Simulink and includes two battery packs, an inverter, a permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM), and a motor control unit. The PMSM is controlled using field-oriented control (FOC), with the RPM as the reference. Proportional-integral (PI) controllers are carefully tuned to ensure accurate tracking of speed and torque profiles.

title: Merging Control in Autonomous Driving
authors: Prathit Joshi, Rolwin Pinto, S Ashwathnarayana Gowda, Sanchay Shetty, S Santhameena
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: The introduction of autonomous vehicles (AVs) into urban streetscapes requires robust systems to manage situations such as traffic merging, crosswalk interactions, and unexpected terrain. This paper proposes a hybrid paradigm combining machine learning-based prediction models and a deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based decision-making mechanism for adaptive merging control. The architecture includes pedestrian motion and user intent modeling to ensure safe navigation in dynamic traffic. Key contributions include a hybrid systems model for trajectory inference and a DRL mechanism based on the DDPG algorithm. Simulation in SUMO and real-world validation confirm the framework’s effectiveness, with $\mathbf{7 8 \%}$ pedestrian path and $\mathbf{9 4 \%}$ driver intent prediction accuracy. These findings support the proposed method’s utility in enhancing AV safety, trust, and adoption in complex urban environments.

title: LHF-NTT: Local Horizontal Folding Number Theoretic Transform Hardware Accelerator
authors: Shutao Zhang, Tobias Gemmeke
abstract: Polynomial multiplications in lattice-based cryptography (LBC) can be addressed by number theoretic transform (NTT). To accelerate NTT in hardware, the memory-based architecture is very popular, with butterfly processing elements (PEs) arranged in a 1-dimensional vector (1D) or a 2-dimensional (2D) systolic array. With the growing need to keep data secure and the potential of quantum computers, the demand for energy efficient and high throughput operation is rising. Building on the extensive research in this field, a new systolic vector architecture is proposed in this work, namely the local horizontal folding NTT (LHF-NTT). Unlike forward feeding of data among PEs in the systolic array, the proposed systolic vector locally feeds the output data of PEs back to their input. On one hand, the memory bottleneck is addressed by requiring fewer memory accesses, which also reduce energy consumption. On the other hand, this increase in computational intensity can be used to instantiate more efficient memories of fewer banks, or to increase throughput with more PEs while relying on a classic split into memory banks. The proposed LHF-NTT outperforms 1D-NTT by reducing memory accesses by at least 50% at the same throughput and PE count. In the case of 2D-NTT, the throughput can be doubled while keeping the memory bandwidth unchanged.

title: Predicting Airborne Particulate Matter Levels using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Navitha K Krishnan, J Roopa Jayasingh
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Air pollution, particularly fine particulate matter (PM), poses a significant threat to public health and environmental sustainability, worldwide. Particulate matter is a common and critical pollutant and the negative health consequences it has on people include respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, while also impacting the environment by reducing visibility, harming vegetation, and altering the climate. Existing monitoring systems have low sensitivity, precision and need comprehensive laboratory examination. Therefore, real time particulate matter monitoring and predicting strategies are needed. Machine learning (ML), which makes use of extensive datasets and complex algorithms, provides a potent substitute for monitoring and predicting PM under varying conditions. A particularly effective machine learning methodology that provides a reliable means for enhancing model performance and predicting accuracy is the Ensemble Learning method. Three ensemble learning models are examined in this paper: Random Forest, Gradient Boosting and XGBoost models for predicting PM $\mathbf{P M}_{2.5}$ levels using air quality data from the Central Pollution Control Board of India. The statistical parameters Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) and the Coefficient of Determination ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$) are used to assess the model’s performance.

title: Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Models for Breast Cancer Classification Using Statistical Testing
authors: Hemali Shah, Smita Agrawal, Parita Oza, Sudeep Tanwar
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Nowadays, cancer is a prevalent disease worldwide. Breast cancer is the top-ranked disease found in women. The advancement in breast cancer detection using machine learning assists doctors in making improved and faster decisions. Machine learning models like KNN, decision tree, SVM, Naive Bayes, are applied to the WDBC (Wisconsin Diagnostic Breast Cancer) dataset. This study aims to compare and demonstrate improved results by utilizing statistical analysis methods and feature selection techniques with various machine learning models. Statistics like mean, variance, standard deviation, and t-test are used to identify the important features for classifying benign and malignant. The analysis compares the results of various tests, such as the chi-square test, learning curve, and loss function, to evaluate the performance of machine learning models. The study shows that applying statistical tests and the chi-square feature selection technique, KNN, SVM, and Naive Bayes resulted in 100% precision and 100%specificity in classifying the data. Additionally, the paper evaluates machine learning models using a learning curve and loss function to achieve more precise classification results.

title: Design and Development of a Fractal Antenna for Material Classification
authors: Hanna Maria Thomas, Parvathy R Krishna, Parvathy V, Sreelakshmi P M, Prasanth P Menon, Reshma Lakshmanan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This work presents the design, development, and fabrication of a multi-band fractal antenna for material classification with respect to conductivity properties. The fractal geometry alters the antenna’s electromagnetic response so as to permit efficient detection of material type. In classifying, material is put on top of the antenna and variations in the $S_{11}$ parameter are analyzed to determine conductivities. A machine learning (ML) model trained on earlier-gathered data is then used to perform an automated classification of materials into insulators, electrolytes, and conductors. The method offers a non-destructive, fast, and economical option for characterizing materials, where use cases can include industrial quality control, biomedical diagnostics, and non-destructive testing.

title: From RF to Light to Spikes: A Neuromorphic Pipeline for Real-Time RF Signal Classification
authors: David Peavy, Steven Harbour, Davide Migliore, Nick Soures, Jim Stroup, Jamison Colter, Matthew Kinnison, Stephen Schlager, Eric Nichols
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: The first end-to-end RF-to-light-Spike neuromorphic pipeline utilizes RFoF, a developmental-EV Sensor, novel-SNNs, and 3U-VPX-Hardware. This architecture eliminates ADCs, FFTs, and modulators, enabling real-time RF classification. The system is faster, lower-SWaP-C, more robust for at-the-edge use cases, especially in situations where traditional systems struggle with high latency and power demands.

title: Transformer Fault Diagnosis Method Based on ACGAN and IGWO-GBDT
authors: Chao Tong, Fan Li, Zhiwei Xiong, Wenhua Ouyang, Jianhui Ye
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: Transformer fault diagnosis is essential for maintaining the stable operation of power systems. Traditional diagnostic approaches often rely on expert knowledge and face challenges such as inefficient parameter tuning and low sensitivity to minority fault types. This paper presents a transformer fault diagnosis method based on ACGAN and IGWO-GBDT to address these issues. ACGAN is first used to address the class imbalance in the fault dataset. Then, a multi-strategy IGWO is developed by incorporating a nonlinear convergence factor, dynamic weights, and a Lévy flight perturbation mechanism to enhance the efficiency of GBDT hyperparameter optimization. The average fitness value and standard deviation of IGWO on the Sphere function are both better than those of GWO, showing better convergence and stability. Experimental results show that the proposed IGWO-GBDT model achieves a diagnostic accuracy of 97.06 %, with an average recall of 96.03 %, and a minimum recall of 83% across all fault types. Compared with SSA-GBDT, WOA-GBDT, and GWO-GBDT, the proposed model improves diagnostic performance by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 8 \%}, \mathbf{1. 9 6 \%}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 9 4 \%}$</tex>, respectively, demonstrating its effectiveness and practical applicability in transformer fault diagnosis.

title: All About Nothing: Towards Zero-Cost Hardware Accelerated RISC-V Interrupt Handling in Rust
authors: Pawel Dzialo, Per Lindgren
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Micro-controllers underlying commonplace embedded systems rely on interrupt and exception mechanisms for event driven scheduling and error handling respectively. At the lowest level of the embedded software stack, the firmware implements the actions to be taken. With outsets from the RISC-V architecture and the modern systems level programming language Rust, we seek solutions leveraging hardware accelerated interrupt and exception mechanisms while at the same time being free of non-inherent overhead - thus the title All About Nothing. The paper provides a comprehensive overview of Rust low-level code generation and identifies an implementation performance gap caused by the current design of low-level abstractions. We propose both hardware and software solutions addressing and eliminating the problem: the former by implementing an additional interrupt/exception return stack in hardware, while the latter by changing the semantics of the riscv-interrupt-m interrupt attribute. As an additional observation we find the performance gap not to be unique to Rust, the problem along with proposed solutions are equally present and applicable to C/C++ as compiled with the latest GCC toolchain targeting the RISC-V architecture.

title: A (145, 128) DEC-TED BCH Decoder with Composite Field and Redundant Arithmetic
authors: Hossein Hashemi Shadmehri, Christian Lanius, Tobias Gemmeke
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: In this paper, a (145, 128) double error correcting and triple error detecting (DEC-TED) BCH decoder utilizing composite field representation and redundant arithmetic is presented. We explore the effect of the field representation by comparing area efficiency and energy efficiency for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GF}\left(2^{8}\right)$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GF}\left(\left(2^{4}\right)^{2}\right)$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GF}\left(\left(\left(2^{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{2}\right)$</tex> implementations and also <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GF}\left(\left(2^{4}\right)^{2}\right)$</tex> with redundantly represented basis (RRB) for the base-field. Both Chien search and analytical solving of the error locator polynomial (ELP) are explored. Post layout simulations in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 2 ~ n m ~ f d S O I ~ t e c h n o l o g y ~ s h o w ~ t h a t ~ t h e ~ a n a l y t i c a l ~ s o l u t i o n ~ o f ~ E L P ~}$</tex> using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\operatorname{GF}\left(\left(2^{4}\right)^{2}\right)$</tex> with redundantly represented basis (RRB) for the base-field dominates the area efficiency versus energy efficiency Pareto front.

title: Discovery of Novel Deep Learning Framework for Improved Cataract State Detection
authors: V. Anjan Bhargav, Shashikala H. K, Venkata Neelesh, N. Joshita, P. Akshay, Shruthishree S. H
abstract: One of the most prevalent conditions that distorts vision is a cataract. The most effective strategy to reduce the danger and prevent blindness is to detect cataracts early and accurately. Artificial intelligence- driven cataract detection technologies have drawn interest recently. This research proposes the automatic diagnosis of cataracts in fundus pictures using a novel deep neural network called Cataract Net. In order to train the network with small kernels, fewer training parameters, and layers, the loss and activation functions are adjusted. In comparison to other pre- trained Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models, Cataract Net has a much lower computing cost and average operating time. The Adam optimizer is used to optimize the suggested network. To train the model, a total of 491 fundus pictures—both cataract and non- cataract—are gathered and enhanced to create 612 images. Before training the model, the dataset is expanded by augmentation to prevent the over-fitting issue. With an average accuracy of 97.5%, experimental data demonstrate that the suggested method performs better than the most advanced cataract detection techniques.

title: Retail Demand Forecasting in Inventory with External Influences: A Comparative Study of Machine Learning Models
authors: Jaymin V. Soni, Chetansinh Vaghela
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Precise demand forecasts are essential to make the most of inventory and supply chain decisions in retail. This paper analyzes and compares a variety of machine learning models on the task of predicting product demand in the presence of external influencing factors including price offers, promotions, competitor prices, weather conditions, and seasonality. We used an extensive dataset of time-stamped transactions in multiple product categories, with intense feature engineering and normalization. Conventional time series models like LSTM and TCN has compared with ensemble-based machine learning models like Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM and CatBoost. Results show that tree-based models dominate sequence models, and LightGBM has the smallest RMSE (7.87) and WMAPE (4.77%) of test data in 2024. Descriptive diagnostics that include residual plots, correlation heatmaps, performance rankings confirm the efficacy of ensemble models for this problem domain. The findings suggest that hand-crafting non-linear features with the help of external sources has quite predictive power for retail demand.

title: Meta-Reinforcement Learning for Building Energy Management System
authors: Huiliang Zhang, Di Wu, Arnaud Zinflou, Benoit Boulet
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The building sector is one of the largest contributors to global energy consumption. Improving its energy efficiency is essential for reducing operational costs and greenhouse gas emissions. Energy management systems (EMS) play a key role in monitoring and controlling building appliances efficiently and reliably. With the increasing integration of renewable energy, intelligent EMS solutions have received growing attention. Reinforcement learning (RL) has recently been explored for this purpose and shows strong potential. However, most RL-based EMS methods require a large number of training steps to learn effective control policies, especially when adapting to unseen buildings, which limits their practical deployment. This paper introduces MetaEMS, a meta-reinforcement learning framework for EMS. MetaEMS improves learning efficiency by transferring knowledge from previously solved tasks to new ones through group-level and building-level adaptation, enabling fast adaptation and effective control across diverse building environments. Experimental results demonstrate that MetaEMS adapts more rapidly to unseen buildings and consistently outperforms baseline methods across various scenarios.

title: Peak Power Tracking in Solar PV Systems using ML and P&O Algorithm
authors: Athul Ranjith, Alan Vincent, M B Karthik, Naveen Johny, Naveen Jacob
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This document covers the basics of integrating PV systems with MPPT and machine learning. Over the past few years, Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques have been widely used for tracking the maximum power point. Methods such as Perturb and Observe (P&O), Random Forest, Neural Network and Linear Regression are discussed. Solar PV cells transform sunlight into electricity but are hindered by high initial cost and lower efficiency. Solar cell current-voltage characteristics change with changes in solar irradiance and temperature, which introduce uncertainties on the maximum power point (MPP). For improving the efficiency of PV system and prolong battery lifetime, a microcontroller-based MPPT system is developed to extract the optimum available power under given environmental condition. This paper is a comparison study between different MPPT Algorithms. Of all the MPPT methods, the Random Forest algorithm is recognized for providing good results. The research in this paper is about using an MPPT charge controller with a DC-to-DC buck converter and a controller. The findings show that the proposed MPPT controller enhances PV panel efficiency than traditional charge controllers.

title: Weather Prediction Using Machine Learning: A Hybrid Voting and Stacking Ensemble Approach
authors: Subarnabindu Pani, Dibya Ranjan Patra, Tapas Kumar Choudhury, Kumar Janardan Patra, Rajendra Prasad Panigrahi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: In sectors including agriculture, transportation, and disaster relief, weather forecasting is essential. Traditional numerical weather prediction (NWP) models rely on complex physical equations, but frequently difficulty with processing efficiency and prediction accuracy. Machine learning techniques have become competitive substitutes in recent years, providing increased accuracy and adaptability. A Voting-Based Ensemble Model and a Hybrid Stacking Model are two of the dual-method machine learning frameworks for weather prediction that this study suggests. Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Gradient Boosting (GB), Decision Tree (DT), Linear Regression (LR), and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) are the six different algorithms that are integrated into the voting model. The Random Forest base model is merged with Ridge Regression, J48, XGBoost, AdaBoost, Gradient Boosting, and CatBoost in the Hybrid Stacking technique. Both regression and classification tasks are used to train and assess the models. According to experimental findings, Random Forest had the best classification accuracy (88<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>) in the voting technique, while the Hybrid Stacking strategy-specifically, the combination of Random Forest and XGBoost-had the best accuracy (90%) in the voting method. The usefulness of the suggested framework in raising forecasting accuracy and resource efficiency for real-world weather prediction applications is demonstrated by validation against conventional machine learning models.

title: Explainable AI Based Meta-Learning to Enhance Patient-Specific ECG Anomaly Detection Using Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning (MAML)
authors: Jeevitha. K, Pragash. K, J. Jayabharathy
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: A vital part of diagnosing and classifying heart diseases involves the interpretation of an electrocardiogram (ECG). This study presents a new approach toward diagnosing ECGs through the combination of explainable artificial intelligence (AI) based model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML). Utilizing the PTB-XL dataset, where we developed a hierarchical classification system for heart disease severity based on five possible categories: Critical, Rare, Uncommon, Common, and Normal. We achieved robust performance across cardiac disease categories with our unique approach that utilizes a multi-layered neural network architecture and MAML meta-learning ability. The model demonstrates significant adaptability to new tasks even for small number of inputs, and provides interpretability with SHapley Additive Explanations (SHAP). Our results showed both success across every disease classification while especially showing strong performance classifying critical disease. The inclusion of explainability will offer clinically relevant information on the model's operation in clinical settings. This work helps to expand the growing area of interpretable AI in healthcare by proposing a method for classifying ECGs that provides both accurate diagnostics and clinical interpretability.

title: An Analysis of Vaccination Strategies on Epidemic Spread in a Friendship Network
authors: Nandini Sreejit Nair, Jisha Mariyam John, Divya Sindhu Lekha
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: This research enhances targeted vaccination strategies for controlling epidemics in real social networks, addressing the limitations of homogeneous mixing models. We analyze a 217 -individual weighted social network from the Australian National University, using KONECT data, where edge weights reflect friendship intensity. We apply the SI and SIR epidemic models to evaluate the efficacy of targeting individuals according to degree, strength, betweenness, and weighted betweenness centrality. The weighted betweenness centrality is the most effective strategy for controlling epidemic spread, significantly reducing peak infection rates and network connectivity. However, degree-based vaccination also showed strong performance, offering a practical balance between effectiveness and computational efficiency, making it suitable for broader applications. While degree-based vaccination is effective in slowing down the spread of the disease, weighted betweenness centrality works much more effectively to disrupt key transmission pathways, significantly reducing the size of the largest connected component and aiding in the containment of the epidemic. These findings indicate that network topology and intensity of interaction are critical in designing efficient vaccination strategies and provide grounding for useful suggestions on how to allocate resources and containment efforts in the real world.

title: Energy Saving Routing Protocol Optimisation Techniques for Mobile IoT Ad Hoc Networks
authors: Mohammed Ihsan, Jayavelan Jayabalan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Mobile IoT ad hoc networks have evolved from MANETs and the Internet of Things (IoT). A disaster zone, military operation, and remote monitoring situation requiring the use of these networks is crucial. IoT nodes' mobility and limited battery capacity pose significant challenges to energy efficiency. To improve coverage and minimise redundancy, this paper proposes zigzag routing using grid-based clustering, trust-based route selection, and grid-based clustering. In simulations, the proposed model maintains higher throughput, lower routing overhead, and better resilience in adversarial environments than existing approaches such as EECHSISSADE and the Butterfly and Ant Method. Mobile IoT networks' communication efficiency and longevity are enhanced by the proposed model, as confirmed by the findings.

title: Real-Time Fire Detection Leveraging Enhanced Convolutional Neural Networks for Improved Safety and Swift Emergency Response
authors: Hitesh Gupta, Neelu Nihalani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: This work proposes a fire detection system based on deep learning techniques that uses improved Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to maximize protection and rapid action in aiding emergency cases. Compared to conventional fire detection systems like smoke detectors and heat sensors, the proposed system outperforms in terms of fire detection accuracy and lower false alarm rates. The model is robust to the operating environment such as low light and smoke because it is trained on a variety of datasets on a large scale. Pruning, quantization and other optimization tricks are applied to achieve real-time processing without loss of precision. These results indicate that CNNs can effectively be used to detect fires and have the potential to be implemented into fields of practicality.
