title: Emotion Detection Framework for Mental Health Monitoring Using Reservoir Computing
authors: Keertan Amit Parikh, Nikunjkumar Mahida, Om Mehra, Rajesh Gupta, Sudeep Tanwar, Sahil Sawhney, Ankur Gupta
abstract: With the advancement in technology, artificial intelligence has sought to bring more personalized solutions to daily life problems. Mental health, being an essential parameter in a person’s daily routine, requires a timely monitoring that can be performed through continuous observation of a person’s emotional reactions to various different situations. To achieve this aim, we sought to develop EmoAdaptAI, a framework for effective and efficient emotion detection through the utilization of various reservoir computing techniques including LSM, ESN, LIF, and DeepESN. These models are trained on brainwave activity data simulated through inducing positive, neutral, and negative stimuli, and recorded using electroencephalogram (eeg). The models are further evaluated on various comprehensive metrics, namely, precision, accuracy, f1, recall, confusion matrix, and roc curve, through which we achieve the highest accuracy of 97% for LSM, followed by 96% for ESN, 93% for LIF, and 92% for DeepESN. Furthermore, to meet the dynamic environment of current times, the model is iteratively updated to increase its versatility by aggregating data from various edge devices and retraining the model on a central cloud server. This helps improve the model’s efficiency in different real-world scenarios.

title: Research on the Dynamic Cost Optimization Method of Data-Driven Power Transmission and Transformation Engineering
authors: Huiying Wu, Hongyi Chen, Meihua Zou, Jiayao Feng, Shijin Qiu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: With the expansion of power transmission and transformation projects and increasing requirements for investment efficiency, traditional cost estimation methods have become inadequate in addressing challenges caused by market fluctuations and complex terrain. Particularly during the “14th Five-Year Plan” period, promoting the construction of new power systems has become a crucial national strategic task. As a core component of power systems, power transmission and transformation projects face increasingly complex management environments and growing investment scales. To adapt to these changes, there is an urgent need to optimize cost management methods, enhance full-process cost control capabilities, and reduce cost management risks. To address this issue, this paper proposes a data-driven dynamic budget optimization method. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is employed for data dimensionality reduction, Random Forest algorithms are used to rank key cost drivers, and ANOVA tests are applied to analyze interaction effects. By incorporating dynamic correction coefficients for factors such as copper prices and terrain complexity, a dynamic cost optimization adjustment model is developed. Empirical analysis demonstrates that this method significantly improves cost estimation accuracy and provides robust decision-making support for project management.

title: An Artificial Intelligence and Natural Language Processing Based System for Tourism Recommendation
authors: Vishan Kumar Gupta, Anurag Shukla, Deepak Shukla, Ankit Tomar, Priyanshi Kamboj, Priyank Pandey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: This study provides fresh suggestions for enhancing trip planning through two distinct approaches, such as suggestions derived from open-ended inquiries and pertinent remarks about previously visited locations. To give passengers relevant and helpful recommendations, the system integrates advancements in a number of fields, such as artificial intelligence, natural language processing, and interaction partner filtering. In the first approach, the system analyzes the user's historical travel habits and preferences to suggest destinations that align with their interests using integrated technologies. The second method makes more precise and tailored recommendations by using natural language processing algorithms to comprehend user input for free queries. Furthermore, the system makes use of technology to continuously learn from and modify user suggestions, allowing them to evolve over time to better suit people's requirements. The conclusion of this article provides recommendations for the implementation and development of these recommendations in the travel and tourism industry, revealing their potential to improve the booking process and improve the overall tourist experience.

title: A Unified Dehazing Framework: Synergizing CLAHE and Dark Channel Prior in YCbCr Space to Optimize Quality and Latency
authors: Rio Andika Malik, Yuhandri, Agung Ramadhanu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Real-time image dehazing is crucial for the reliability and safety of computer vision systems. Despite its effectiveness, the Dark Channel Prior (DCP) algorithm has drawbacks in areas with high contrast or low light levels, which frequently result in noise and colour distortion. To address these issues, Contrast-Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalisation (CLAHE) is commonly used. The best use of CLAHE as a pre-processing step to support the dehazing algorithm or as a post-processing step to improve the final image, is still an unresolved and unquantifiable design conundrum that presents a crucial trade-off between final perceptual quality and haze estimate accuracy. By methodically assessing CLAHE placement within a DCP dehazing framework that operates in the YCbCr colour space, which isolates brightness for targeted enhancement, this study finds a solution to this challenge. We performed a quantitative frame-by-frame analysis using a special dataset of foggy videos shot in West Sumatra and verified with meteorological data BMKG. Although both setups operate similarly averaging between 4.0 and 4.1 frames per second, they have somewhat different effects on image quality. In comparison to the pre-processing method (average: 5.85), the post-processing setup consistently obtains improved NIQE ratings (average: 5.26), suggesting a more statistically natural and architecturally crisper result. A softer image with poorer overall clarity is suggested by the preprocessing pipeline's marginally higher BRISQUE ratings (average: 54.6 vs. 56.4). This study offers convincing empirical proof that post-processing is the best option for applications that value accuracy and maximum visual detail. A fundamental framework for optimising dehazing systems for important realworld situations is provided by this work.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Spectrum Sensing for Cognitive Radio IoT
authors: Dhiya Mary Thomas, G Krishnanjana, Hari Krishna K, Lakshmi V S
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: The rapid growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) requires the efficient use of spectrum. Cognitive Radio (CR) technology can resolve this critical issue of spectrum scarcity in IoT networks. CR based IoT enables IoT devices to detect and utilize vacant spectrum bands, thereby providing dynamic spectrum access. This is achieved mainly through the use of spectrum sensing techniques, which identifies spectrum holes. Even though different spectrum sensing methods are available in literature, energy detection based spectrum sensing is suitable for resource constrained IoT networks due to simplicity and other desirable characteristics. In this work, the theoretical performance analysis of energy detection spectrum sensing is first carried out in terms of SNR, probability of detection and probability of false alarm, followed by the experimental evaluation using software defined radio (SDR) transmitter and receiver. Finally, a simple prototype of CR-IoT network is developed by transmitting temperature data through LoRa protocol and simultaneously receiving the data by an intended receiver and an SDR to detect unutilized spectrum. In general, this approach paves the way for the next generation of intelligent and self-optimizing IoT networks by addressing the growing demand for connectivity in an increasingly crowded spectrum environment.

title: A 4-W Ka-Band High-Efficiency 0.15 μm GaAs Stacked Power Amplifier Design
authors: Mehmet Batuhan DİNÇ, Mustafa Berke Yelten
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: This paper introduces a two-stage 4 W Ka-band power amplifier (PA) operating between 23 and 28 GHz. Designed using commercially available <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.15 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> GaAs pHEMT technology, the PA features a stacked FET topology to increase output power without expanding the chip area. This paper presents the first demonstration of a high-power GaAs power amplifier with a saturated output power of 4 W in the Ka band, utilizing a stacked-FET architecture and parallel combining. With an 8 V power supply, the simulated PA achieves a saturated output power of 4 W by combining eight stacked-FET cells. The PA has a large-signal gain of 22 dB and power-added efficiency (PAE) of 33 % at 25 GHz, while its chip area is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.86 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. To the best of the authors' knowledge, the simulated PA has the highest PAE among the simulated GaAs PAs reported in the Ka band and achieves a saturated output power greater than 2 W.

title: Secondary Control of Shunt-Constructed Grid-Type Converter Based on Consistency Algorithm Strategy
authors: Liuming Jing, Changbin Hu, Teng Feng, Liu Han, Zhaozheng Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart Energy and Smart Grid (SESG)
abstract: In order to realize the fast coordinated control of power and frequency of multiple energy storage units of grid-type storage in an islanded microgrid, and to eliminate the errors generated by the primary control of the microgrid. Therefore, this paper proposes a secondary control strategy for shunt-connected grid-configuration-type energy storage converter based on consistency algorithm. Firstly, based on the theory of VSG grid-configuration type control, the primary control model of gridconfiguration type control based energy storage converter is constructed, and through the distributed consistency algorithm, the information interaction between energy storage converters is utilized to coordinate the frequency and power allocation of multiple shunt-connected energy storage converters to realize the accurate tracking of power and frequency. Finally, the microgrid system is built based on MATLAB/Simulink simulation platform for simulation verification. The simulation results show that the strategy can effectively improve the power quality of the microgrid without relying on the central controller, which enhances the robustness of the system.

title: ReTiDe: Real-Time Denoising for Energy-Efficient Motion Picture Processing with FPGAs
authors: Changhong Li, Clément Bled, Rosa Fernandez, Shreejith Shanker
publish: Proceedings of the 22nd ACM SIGGRAPH European Conference on Visual Media Production
abstract: None

title: Towards Trustworthy AI: A Review of Ethical and Robust Large Language Models
authors: Md Meftahul Ferdaus, Mahdi Abdelguerfi, Elias Loup, Kendall N. Niles, Ken Pathak, Steven Sloan
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are advancing rapidly and promising transformation across fields but pose challenges in oversight, ethics, and user trust. This review addresses trust issues like unintentional harms, opacity, vulnerability, misalignment with values, and environmental impact, all of which affect trust. Factors undermining trust include societal biases, opaque processes, misuse potential, and technology evolution challenges, especially in finance, healthcare, education, and policy. Recommended solutions include ethical oversight, industry accountability, regulation, and public involvement to reshape AI norms and incorporate ethics into development. A framework assesses trust in LLMs, analyzing trust dynamics and providing guidelines for responsible AI development. The review highlights limitations in building trustworthy AI, aiming to create a transparent and accountable ecosystem that maximizes benefits and minimizes risks, offering guidance for researchers, policymakers, and industry in fostering trust and ensuring responsible use of LLMs. We validate our frameworks through comprehensive experimental assessment across seven contemporary models, demonstrating substantial improvements in trustworthiness characteristics and identifying important disagreements with existing literature. Both theoretical foundations and empirical validation are provided in comprehensive supplementary materials.

title: Towards an Agentic Workflow for Internet Measurement Research
authors: Alagappan Ramanathan, Eunju Kang, Dongsu Han, Sangeetha Abdu Jyothi
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: Internet measurement research faces an accessibility crisis: complex analyses require custom integration of multiple specialized tools that demands specialized domain expertise. When network disruptions occur, operators need rapid diagnostic workflows spanning infrastructure mapping, routing analysis, and dependency modeling. However, developing these workflows requires specialized knowledge and significant manual effort.

title: Provision of Secondary Reserve from Photovoltaic and Wind Power Sources via Interconnections among Balancing Areas
authors: Chiyori T. Urabe, Joao Gari da Silva Fonseca, Tomoya Takeuchi, Masaki Imanaka, Kazuhiko Ogimoto
abstract: The penetration of Renewable Energy (RE) power generation has been steadily increasing to achieve carbon neutrality. Increases in RE power generation require more secondary reserve (SR) that responds to fluctuations in RE power outputs to balance electricity supply and demand. For power systems with high RE penetration, evaluating the impact of SR provision via interconnections is crucial. This study examines whether SR provision from RE power via interconnections can mitigate the challenges of maintaining supply–demand balance in power systems with high RE penetration. In this paper, we present a novel methodology for evaluating SR provision from RE power via interconnections through simulations, considering both operating costs and RE power curtailment in the assessment. Using this methodology, we conduct a comprehensive analysis of the effects of SR provision via interconnections based on the current specifications of a nationwide power system and its balancing areas (BAs). Twenty cases are examined using a demand–supply analysis tool to investigate different configurations of SR provision and interconnection usage of SR exchange. The resulting impacts on system operating costs and RE power curtailment are characterized in detail, bringing further significance to the study. We found that the SR provision from RE power via interconnections reduced the total operating costs and curtailment of RE power output. The flexible usage of interconnections for SR exchange reduces the operation of thermal power units with high fuel costs in each BA, allowing SR provision from thermal power units with lower fuel costs and from RE power sources in other BAs. The analyses demonstrate that SR provision from RE power via interconnections reduces RE curtailment by approximately 40 % and operating costs by around 2 %, highlighting its effectiveness in power systems with high RE power penetration. Therefore, the SR provision from RE power via interconnections contributes to maintaining supply-demand balance in power systems.

title: A Comprehensive Analysis of the MOSFET Model
authors: Yuan Taur
abstract: In this article, the solutions to the commonly known MOSFET equations are thoroughly analyzed. It is shown that while the popular 2ψB condition (see Fig. 3 for the definition of ψB) is on the low side for defining the threshold voltage, it serves for delineating the upper bound of the subthreshold region in which analytic solutions exist. Based on that, an explicit analytic expression is derived for the MOSFET saturation voltage. For general bias conditions, Ids-Vds characteristics (source-to-drain current versus source-to-drain voltage) are generated numerically to check the errors of those taught in the textbooks. Moreover, the concept of “threshold voltage” is investigated by examining the Qi-Vgs characteristics (Qi is the inversion charge per gate area, Vgs is the gate-to-source voltage) of an undoped double-gate MOSFET as a function of temperature. An unambiguously defined threshold voltage emerges when the electron thermal energy is diminished.

title: A Periodic Scheduling Method for Dual-Arm Cluster Tools Considering Wafer Priority and Residency Time Constraint_supp1-3629134.pdf
authors: MengChu Zhou
abstract: This study investigates a scheduling problem involving dual-arm cluster tools (CTs) that simultaneously handle two types of wafers, considering both wafer priority and residency time constraints. The two types of wafers have their own processing routes and processing times at each step. To fully utilize the resources of the CTs, we use the fewest processing modules (PMs) to produce one type of wafers with maximum productivity, and use the available PMs to produce the other type of wafers. Based on this, we introduce a swap sequence for scheduling a dual-arm robot, which is simple to implement and supports periodic operations. Without affecting the priority wafer production, we provide the necessary and sufficient conditions for scheduling a CT that processes two types of wafers, and present the optimal PM configuration. A high-performance algorithm is developed to determine an optimal periodic schedule, with its practicality and feasibility illustrated through several examples.

title: Agreement-free Encryption Tunnel in Public Safety Communication
authors: Xinyang Bai, Ping Dong, Xiaoya Zhang, Yuyang Zhang, Wenxuan Qiao, Hongke Zhang
abstract: Traditional key agreement-based encryption mechanisms in public security communications struggle to address increasingly sophisticated network attacks and real-time threats due to infrequent key updates and exposure risks. To overcome these limitations, this study proposes a Chaotic Encryption-based Tunneling Method (CETM) at the network layer. CETM integrates a six-dimensional (6D) hyperchaotic system with the AES-256 algorithm, leveraging the system’s extreme sensitivity to initial conditions to generate high-strength key sequences, eliminating the need for traditional negotiation. A self-synchronizing key update mechanism is also introduced, allowing both parties to update keys automatically without network transmission, thereby eliminating the risk of key leakage. The proposed system demonstrates strong complexity and randomness, as validated by multiple chaotic metrics including the Lyapunov exponent, Shannon entropy, correlation coefficient, permutation entropy, and key space. The generated keys pass both the SP800-22 and FIPS 140-2 tests, meeting established security standards. Performance evaluations across local, cloud, and satellite environments show that CETM significantly outperforms conventional methods in terms of bandwidth efficiency, latency, jitter, and packet loss.

title: Optimizing VM Performance Monitoring on Commodity x86 Platforms With PMU Passthrough
authors: Jian-Hao Chen, Shih-Wei Li, Yu-Hsun Wang
abstract: Modern processors expose hardware performance monitoring capabilities through Performance Monitoring Units (PMUs). Profiling tools leverage these PMU facilities to analyze program execution. As the computation is increasingly shifting to virtual machines (VMs), commodity hypervisors like KVM have implemented virtual PMUs (vPMUs) to expose these capabilities to VMs. However, we found that KVM's current vPMU implementation introduces substantial overhead, leading to inaccurate measurements. This overhead stems from frequent VM exits caused by PMU access and sampling interrupts, as well as the complexity of emulation. To address this, we develop Direct vPMU (D-vPMU), a novel set of passthrough mechanisms for Intel x86 platforms running KVM. D-vPMU enables VMs to access the physical PMU and handle interrupts directly, thereby eliminating the virtualization overhead that currently plagues vPMU solutions. D-vPMU delivers better profiling accuracy and performance while strictly maintaining the security and isolation boundaries between guest and host PMU contexts.

title: A Semantic Representation Framework for Diverse DAS Noise Suppression Using Spatially Adaptive Discriminative GAN
authors: Junhan Chen, Hongbo Lin, Jijin Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) technology has been gradually applied to vertical seismic profile (VSP) exploration. The random noise and optical noise with different distributions in DAS seismic records significantly intensify the complexity and spatial non-uniformity of seismic noise, thereby causing instability in the suppression of multi-type noise by deep learning denoising models. To address the challenges in DAS noise suppression, we construct an implicit semantic representation framework to extract fine-grained semantic features from DAS-VSP data, thereby guiding a spatially adaptive generative adversarial network (SA-GAN) to accurately remove multi-type noise while preserving weak seismic signals. Specifically, we construct a category semantic extractor (CSE) to map DAS data into the semantic space, mining the exclusive semantic features of various types of noise by learning their manifold structures. The learned semantic features are introduced into the discriminator, and fine-grained feature discrimination is carried out for different types of noise to form a semantic-spatial interactive adversarial constraint. Meanwhile, the semantic information identified by CSE is embedded into the generator, thereby achieving the adaptive enhancement of directional features of multi-type noise. Additionally, gradient angle loss that reflects the spatial characteristics of seismic wavefield is introduced to jointly supervise the training process of SA-GAN. SA-GAN is tested on the synthetic and field DAS records, and the results show that SA-GAN can accurately suppress DAS noise and improve the recovery ability of weak seismic events.

title: STAGE: Spatial Transformation-Aware Geometric Encoding Empowered Transformer for Multimodal 2D Object Detection
authors: Xiaohong Cao, Yangjie Wei, Shuwei Huo
abstract: High-security intelligent perception systems increasingly rely on heterogeneous sensor fusion, where complementary data from cameras, radars, and LiDARs can significantly enhance multimodal object detection. However, substantial modality discrepancies in resolution, spatial scale, and coordinate systems pose critical challenges for effective cross-modal fusion and spatial alignment. Particularly in dynamic environments with severe viewpoint variations, geometric offsets and semantic misalignments between modalities can substantially compromise detection reliability. To address these limitations, we propose spatial transformation-aware geometric encoding (STAGE), a 2D detection framework that achieves efficient multimodal fusion through three-stage progressive fusion, ensuring spatial consistency and orientation alignment while enhancing detection robustness and deployment flexibility. First, we design a geometric position encoding mechanism based on complex rotational representations, which extends the traditional 2D sinusoidal encoding method and enhances the model’s perceptual adaptability to rigid spatial transformations and viewpoint rotations. Then, in the attention computation module, spatial relative position feature similarity and rotational scale factor are introduced to further improve geometric selectivity and orientation awareness in cross-modal fusion. Experiments on the nuScenes dataset demonstrate that our STAGE achieves a detection mAP of 33.3%, with fewer parameters to meet lightweight deployment requirements.

title: A Framework for Improving Social Inclusion Using Network Analysis and IoT-Based Contact Tracing
authors: Saverio Giallorenzo, Emanuele Sinagra, Angelo Trotta, Loris Vergolini, Andrea Zanellati
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Social isolation poses critical challenges, with profound implications for performance, mental health, and general well-being. We present a framework to quantitatively measure social inclusion and suggest actions to increase the integration of isolated individuals. Specifically, we address the problem of detection and mitigation of social isolation in educational contexts – a pressing concern where the fundamental role of peer relationships contributes to determining student health and academic success. To tackle this challenge, we employ affordable, off-the-shelf IoT devices for reliably detecting face-to-face social interactions. On the detected network, we employ network analysis techniques, particularly PageRank and Betweenness centrality, to propose a novel algorithm that infers social inclusion levels and recommends sustainable interventions aligned with natural interaction patterns, thus ensuring sustainable integration. Our approach addresses the growing need for evidence-based, scalable solutions implementable across diverse educational environments without substantial infrastructure investment. We validate the framework through a real-world case study in a primary school, demonstrating the effectiveness of our methods in identifying socially isolated students and providing actionable insights for their social integration, offering an affordable tool for addressing one of education's most persistent challenges.

title: Rethinking Secure Resource Allocation: When NOMA Meets Finite Blocklength
authors: Junteng Yao, Ming Jin, Tuo Wu, Cunhua Pan, Maged Elkashlan, Chau Yuen, George K. Karagiannidis, Octavia A. Dobre
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: The allocation of secure resources in non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) systems has gained significant recognition as a vital research focus in the realm of the Internet of Things (IoT). Previous studies have overlooked the security challenges associated with integrating NOMA with finite blocklength (FBL) transmission. Therefore, this paper examines a secure downlink NOMA system utilizing FBL transmission, which includes a base station (BS), a near user, a far user, and an external eavesdropper. We develop an optimization problem with the objective of maximizing the near user’s effective secrecy throughput, considering the secrecy rates, decoding error probabilities (DEPs), and effective secrecy throughput for both users. Notably, by meticulously defining the DEPs of the users as optimization variables, the monotonicity and concavity of these DEPs in relation to the blocklength, transmission power, and transmission rate can be established effectively. The problem is divided into two sub-problems focusing on the essential conditions for the secrecy rate of the near user, especially in scenarios where successive interference cancellation (SIC) is unsuccessful. These sub-problems are addressed using the block coordinate descent (BCD) algorithm and an exact penalty method. For comparison, the BCD algorithm is also applied to solve the optimization problem using the orthogonal multiple access (OMA) scheme. Numerical simulations confirm the effectiveness of our proposed approaches in improving secure resource allocation when NOMA is combined with FBL transmission.

title: Compilation Framework for Dynamically Reconfigurable Array Architectures
authors: Anish Vipperla, Narayanan Murugan, Ali Akoglu, Chaitali Chakrabarti
abstract: This paper presents a compilation and scheduling framework for high-performance mapping of computationally-intensive kernels on Dynamically Reconfigurable Array Architectures. We showcase the framework for Domain Adaptive Processor (DAP) - an array accelerator designed for signal processing and communication workloads that has near-ASIC energy efficiency. DAP consists of an array of homogeneous Processing Element (PE) clusters, where each PE cluster consists of heterogeneous PEs capable of executing Very-Long-Instruction-Word (VLIW) instructions. We introduce a virtual Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) and a sequential assembly to low-level micro-code conversion mechanism. The proposed work includes optimization techniques that transform the low-level micro-code into compact VLIW instructions resulting in an average instruction count reduction by 1.8x and a significant increase in PE utilization. In addition, we demonstrate rate-aware software-based pipelining of the VLIW code resulting in an improvement in throughput by up to 15x for linear algebra and signal processing kernels. Further, we propose a scheduler that is capable of automatically resolving data dependencies between the threads at the micro-instruction level and accurately schedule custom dataflows overcoming the limitations of fixed mapping and scheduling schemes used in traditional CGRA compilers. These contributions together, provide a compilation flow for dynamically reconfigurable array architectures leading to an improvement in ease of programmability and productivity while ensuring low-level implementation flexibility for performance-critical applications.
