title: Multimodal Thermal and Depth Imaging for Back Acupoint Localization in Massage Robots
authors: Xinxin Zheng, Yulong Cui, Yourong Chen, Chaoxiang Chen, Bin Jiang, Liyuan Liu
abstract: Accurate localization of human acupotints remains a fundamental challenge in the development of massage robot systems. While deep learning algorithms leveraging the classical Transformer architecture have improved recognition accuracy, a notable gap still exists between current performance and the robustness needed to handle complex lighting conditions and individual variability. To fill this gap, this paper focuses on the scenarios involving low-light conditions and subjects wearing close-fitting clothing. To address this issue, the paper proposes an acupoint localization algorithm tailored to the scenario by employing multimodal data fusion techniques that intergrate thermal imaging with depth map information. The algorithm is based on YOLOv8 and has been architecturally improved, referred to as YOLOv8-TCC. Specifically, a dual-branch parallel backbone network architecture is designed, incorporating the Channel Prior Convolutional Attention (CPCA) module to enhance multimodal feature representation. Next, a Cross-Modal Feature Fusion (CTF) module is introduced to facilitate information integration, while a dynamic template alignment approach is proposed to accommodate variations in body shape and posture. Experimental results show that the YOLOv8-TCC method achieves higher accuracy compared to the traditional single-modal model under varying lighting conditions. With the introduction of the CTF and CPCA modules, the average precision at Intersection over Union (AP@0.75) increased by 2.8% and 0.8%, respectively. Moreover, the success rate under the clinically meaningful 0.5 cun constraint (SR@0.5 cun) reached 95%. It is worth mentioning that our method remains effective when subjects wear light and close-fitting clothing. The proposed method exhibits strong generalizability and scalability, offering an accurate and efficient solution for practical applications.

title: Robust Position Tracking Control of Electro-Hydraulic Actuators: Elimination of Velocity Measurements
authors: Sule Taskingollu, Alper Bayrak, Erman Selim, Enver Tatlicioglu, Erkan Zergeroglu
abstract: This work presents a robust backstepping type controller formulation for the position tracking control of engineering systems actuated via electro-hydraulic actuators (EHAs). Specifically, a robust controller that does not require accurate knowledge of the system parameters and uses only position measurements is proposed. A filtered based approach is applied to remove the velocity dependency of the controller formulation. Stability of the closed loop system and the uniform boundedness of the tracking error signals are ensured via Lyapunov based arguments. The overall performance of the proposed method is illustrated, initially through physics-based MATLAB/Simscape studies, and then experimentally on a 1 degree of freedom (dof) EHA test-bed and a 2 dof robotic arm.

title: Squeeze-and-Excitation-Enhanced CNN for Robust DOA Estimation in Interfered Environments
authors: Yang Chen, Jie Ding, Rui Wang
abstract: In the field of array signal processing, accurate direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation remains a critical challenge in noisy and dynamic environments. This paper proposes a convolutional neural network (CNN) enhanced with a squeeze and excitation (SE) attention mechanism for robust DOA estimation. The network integrates the SE mechanism into the convolutional backbone, enabling adaptive recalibration of channels across the real, imaginary, and phase related components of the received signal. By selectively emphasizing channels that encode physically meaningful inter-element phase differences and suppressing those dominated by noise, the network improves angular discrimination and resolves closely spaced sources in low SNR and interference prone environments. Extensive simulations show that the proposed method outperforms conventional approaches, achieving high DOA estimation accuracy and robustness in challenging scenarios involving correlated sources, limited snapshots, and array position errors.

title: Velocity2DMs: A Contextual Modeling Approach to Dynamics Marking Prediction in Piano Performance
authors: Hyon Kim, Emmanouil Benetos, Xavier Serra
abstract: Expressive dynamics in music performance are subjective and context-dependent, yet most symbolic models treat Dynamics Markings (DMs) as static with fixed MIDI velocities. This paper proposes a method for predicting DMs in piano performance by combining MusicXML score information with performance MIDI data through a novel tokenization scheme and an adapted RoBERTa-based Masked Language Model (MLM). Our approach focuses on contextual aggregated MIDI velocities and corresponding DMs, accounting for subjective interpretations of pianists. Note-level features are serialized and translated into a sequence of tokens to predict both constant (e.g., mp, ff) and non-constant DMs (e.g., crescendo, fp). Evaluation across three expert performance datasets shows that the model effectively learns dynamics transitions from contextual note blocks and generalizes beyond constant markings. This is the first study to model both constant and non-constant dynamics in a unified framework using contextual sequence learning. The results suggest promising applications for expressive music analysis, performance modeling, and computer-assisted music education.

title: A Model Reduction Approach for Discrete-Time Coupled Systems With Input Delays Via Bivariate Fundamental Matrices
authors: Ai-Guo Wu, Shi-Long Shen, Jie Zhang, Jie Mei
abstract: In this paper, the model reduction approach is investigated for discrete-time linear coupled systems with input delays. For this purpose, a new class of fundamental matrices is presented for state response analysis of this kind of systems. In order to characterize the effect of all initial values, this new fundamental matrix is defined in terms of two independent variables, and thus is called the bivariate fundamental matrix. Besides, some interesting properties of bivariate fundamental matrices are provided. According to the derived state response expression, two particular changes of state variables are constructed to transform the considered coupled input-delayed system into an input-delay-free system. Further, a state feedback controller is designed to stabilize the considered system based on the obtained input-delay-free system. In addition, by using the properties of bivariate fundamental matrices, the characteristic equation of the resulting closed-loop system under the designed controller is explored. The derived results reveal that the designed control law can entirely compensate the input delays, and thus stabilize the considered system.

title: Equity Aware Peer-to-Peer Energy Trading Market to Mitigate Energy Poverty: A n LLM - RL Agentic Workflow
authors: Qianyi Ma, Zifa Liu, Xiao Liu, Ziqing Zhu, Siqi Bu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Markets, Policy and Regulation
abstract: Disadvantaged communities lack access to local clean energy sources, which may push them further into energy poverty (EP) during the low-carbon energy transition process. However, traditional methods struggle to accurately evaluate EP and conduct targeted policy intervention. To fully leverage existing resources and reduce the consumption of public funding, this paper proposes an equity-aware peer-to-peer (P2P) market clearing mechanism to mitigate EP. It utilizes the cross-subsidization effect and assists disadvantaged communities in the peer matching process. To facilitate targeted assistance, a novel Large Language Model - Reinforcement Learning (LLM-RL) agentic workflow is developed. An LLM policy intervention agent converts user intent into numerical bidding range, identifies communities in EP and allocates initial carbon allowance. To further lower participation barriers for disadvantaged communities, the P2P trading problem is reformulated as a Markov Game. To adapt to the frequently updated EP signal generated by LLM agent, the RL agents serve as traders for intelligent bidding. Then a cooperative augmented Proximal Policy Optimization (CAPPO) algorithm is introduced to reduce conflicts of bidding strategies and solve the problem. Simulation studies on 99 census tracts with in Florida, United States demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a 19.57% improvement in energy equity.

title: Destination-Constrained Linear Dynamical System Modeling and Filtering in Set-Valued Frameworks
authors: Xiaowei Yang, Haiqi Liu, Fanqin Meng, Xiaojing Shen
abstract: Directional motion towards a specified destination is a common occurrence in physical processes and human societal activities. Utilizing this prior information can significantly improve the prediction and filtering performance of system models. This paper focuses on the reconstruction and state filtering of a linear dynamic system model with destination constraints in the set-valued framework. We treat destination constraints as inherent information in the state evolution process and employ convex optimization techniques to construct a coherent and robust state model. This model effectively captures the influence of destination constraints on state evolution at each time step. To enhance the continuity of the target trajectory generated by the process model, we design an optimal weight matrix for the reconstructed model. Furthermore, we propose a destination-constrained set-valued filtering algorithm, which ensures that the center of the estimated bounded ellipsoid consistently satisfies the destination constraint. Finally, simulation experiments verify its superiority over unconstrained and other state-constrained filtering methods under the set-valued framework.

title: Analyzing Behavioral Intention in Digital Government Adoption: A Comprehensive Systematic Review
authors: Yulianto, Arief Setyanto, Ema Utami, Dhani Ariatmanto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: This study presents a systematic review of the key factors influencing the adoption of digital services and technologies, particularly in the context of digital government. The primary focus is on user behavior and public adoption intentions towards these services. The findings indicate that performance expectations, perceived ease of use, social influence, and trust are important determinants in driving adoption. The two most widely used theoretical models in this analysis are the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT). This second model identifies that perceived usefulness and ease of use are the dominant drivers, while social influence also makes a significant contribution. Based on these observational findings, it is recommended that future research adopt a quantitative approach combined with a qualitative approach within a hybrid model framework to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the dynamics of digital technology adoption.

title: Analysis of the Influence of Changes in Profile Visits, and Accounts Reached Mediated by Total Content Shared on the Level of Atmauv Brand Engagement on the Instagram Platform
authors: Vanessa Juanto Yozuar, Sfenrianto S.kom. M. Kom
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: This research focuses on the influence of changes in profile visits and accounts reached which are mediated by total content shared on the level of Atmauv brand engagement on the Instagram platform. This research aims to see the interaction between the amount of content uploaded, profile visits, and account reaches with social media engagement in the context of social media marketing. This approach will be carried out by combining quantitative research regarding case studies, data obtained from interaction metrics and audience engagement data. Then it was carried out using an approach using statistical calculations using quantitativebased research by looking at the perspective of surveying social media users on the Instagram platform, to comprehensively see the dynamics that occurred, not only from the case study perspective. The results indicate that profile visits have a significant impact on social media engagement. At the same time, accounts reached do not have a significant effect, either directly or through the moderation of total content shared. Additionally, the moderation of content volume does not strengthen the relationship between the independent variables and engagement. These findings provide valuable insights for the Atmauy brand and industry players to design more effective digital marketing strategies by improving the quality of interactions and the relevance of content on social media.

title: Secure Multi-Party Computation using Paillier HE and Simulated BBM92 QKD: A Hybrid Quantum-Classical Approach
authors: Karthik Raj S, Debarupa Mandal, Gayathri M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Secure Multi-Party Computation (MPC) facilitates cooperative computation on confidential data. Homomorphic Encryption (HE) offers primitives to compute on encrypted data, but protecting the communication channel with classical key exchange is increasingly exposed to quantum attackers. This work outlines a hybrid model where Paillier HE supports secure additive aggregation, while BBM92 QKD simulation generates quantum-resistant keys for AES-GCM, which in turn protects inter-party communication of HE ciphertexts. The model takes advantage of Paillier HE for secure additive aggregation and simulated BBM92 QKD protocol for generating information-theoretically secure symmetric keys, as opposed to keys obtained from traditional protocols such as Diffie-Hellman. These keys protect the exchange of intermediate homomorphically encrypted values among parties with AES-GCM. We outline the system architecture, Python library-based implementation (Qiskit, phe, cryptography), and simulation results proving the feasibility and improved security against quantum eavesdropping over a fully classical solution. The framework efficiently calculates aggregate sums while maintaining input confidentiality and guarantees communication security that withstands simulated eavesdropping attacks on the quantum channel.

title: Exploring the Role of Metaverse in Education: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Rakhi Shukla, Priyanka Bhaskar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The aim of this research paper is to enhance the current knowledge regarding the incorporation of the metaverse into education by offering a thorough review of existing literature, pinpointing both opportunities and challenges, and guiding future research and practices in this swiftly changing domain. Data for this study were collected from the SCOP database, focusing on “Metaverse in Education.” The research utilized the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRMA) framework to integrate available global literature and studies. The methodology involved conducting systematic literature reviews followed by bibliometric analysis to evaluate performance and perform science mapping analysis. The results help in deepening our comprehension of the Metaverse's impact on education and its potential future directions. The Metaverse has demonstrated considerable abilities to support teaching across various fields, such as engineering, medicine, nursing, and chemistry. Furthermore, it can be efficiently employed to instruct various subjects and specialties in online educational settings, including admissions processes, industry visits, training initiatives, internationalization activities, and customized courses for students with disabilities. It lays the groundwork for educational institutions, policymakers, and researchers to investigate further applications of the Metaverse in education. While this study suggests possible educational uses of the Metaverse, there remains the possibility for greater integration to maximize its worldwide potential. The Metaverse is promising as a budget-friendly approach for delivering education on a large scale in the future. The paper discusses the application of the metaverse in education, using bibliometric analysis. It is among the first studies to evaluate the metaverse, virtual reality (VR), and augmented reality (AR), examining their benefits, drawbacks, and current applications. Additionally, it identifies potential areas for future applications emerging from this analysis.

title: Trailblazing NanoComm through Advanced Architectures and Efficient System Designs
authors: Shamim Ahmad Khan, Eswararao Boddepalli, Haider Sharif Mahdi, Sabah Abdul Wahab Sheet, Sattar Jabar Daham Wassif, R Saravanakumar
abstract: Today nanoscale communication systems are nearly half simple-to-using technology changes, allowing nanodevices to interact freely and effortlessly with one another in numerous applications, such as biomedical sensing, environmental monitoring, or high-performance computing. The present study highlights three main developments: miniaturization of devices, energy efficiency, and scalable network architectures. The ultra-compact and efficient devices are developed by using the latest transistors, like FinFETs and Tunnel FETs, alongside novel nanomaterials, such as graphene and carbon nanotubes. The study integrates bio-inspired energy harvesting mechanisms, including piezoelectric and triboelectric nanogenerators, for the purpose of achieving sustainable and self-powered networks. Including techniques that use adaptive transmission, their new framework, supported by molecular and electromagnetic communication paradigms, reduces energy by 50 percent while increasing throughput by 55 percent. These network architectures can be optimized using hierarchical and hybrid models towards enhanced scalability and adaptability with AI-based SDN. The experimental model suggests advanced cryptographic protocols coupled with quantum encryption to solve security issues along the reliable and secure commutation lines. The performance evaluation indicates that molecular communication achieves very good energy efficiency (<10 pJ/bit), while the newly emerged technologies based on quantum principles improve speed and security for future computation applications. The proposed framework enhances reliability, low latency, and energy efficiency, thus setting the stage for disruptive nanoscale networks. Finally, this paper concludes with the assertion that the integration of innovative devices and a sustainable communication approach that has been presented here are necessary steps toward scalable and energy-efficient nanoscale communication systems that meet the demand of future technologies.

title: NeuroSync: AI-Enhanced EEG for Sharper BrainDrone Control
authors: Almabrok Essa, Ava Bruner
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: In recent years, the concept of controlling devices using only the mind has been an area of extensive research, particularly in advanced technologies such as brain-computer interface (BCI) based drone control. A key challenge in this field is the classification of electroencephalography (EEG) signals, which are often difficult to interpret due to their low signal-to-noise ratio and interference from various artifacts. Several classification techniques have been developed, typically based on predefined features extracted from EEG band power distributions. However, EEG classification remains complex, as it is highly influenced by experimental conditions and the specific neural responses being analyzed. To address this issue, we introduce a (NeuroPCA-RF) technique designed for EEG/BCI classification and optimization to enhance BCI performance in drone control applications. The NeuroPCA-RF approach focuses on improving signal clarity, minimizing noise, and distinguishing neural patterns associated with different commands. It emphasizes two-stage learning: unsupervised feature reduction and ensemble-based supervised learning. This advancement contributes to the broader development of BCIs for assistive and autonomous systems.

title: Transmission-Level Disaggregation of Distributed PV Power Using Data-Driven Methods
authors: Hediyeh Safari, Claudio Cañizares, Maurice Dusseault, Daniel Sohm, Elyas Ahmed, Ismael El-Samahy
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: The growing integration of Photovoltaic (PV) systems into distribution networks has limited visibility for system operators. Most small-scale PV installations, particularly behind-the-meter systems, are not monitored, making them effectively invisible to utilities [1]. Unregistered rooftop installations or decommissioned systems that may not be recorded can lead to significant gaps in utilities’ records, as observed through interactions with utility partners. This lack of visibility impedes the ability of network operators to ensure proper power flow, system operation, and efficient management of local energy resources. This highlights the need for improved methodologies to gauge and integrate these systems more effectively, especially at the transmission feeder level, where feeders cover large geographic areas [2], which is the main focus of the current poster.

title: Design of Adaptive Active Filter Using Operational Transconductance Amplifiers in 65nm CMOS
authors: Serdar Alan, Tugba Haykir Ergin
abstract: This paper presents the design and post-layout simulation of an adaptive active filter employing Operational Transconductance Amplifiers (OTAs) in a 65 nm CMOS technology. Conventional op-amp-based active filters are often limited in high-frequency applications due to bandwidth constraints, phase distortion, and integration challenges. In contrast, OTA-based architectures provide enhanced tunability through voltage-controlled transconductance (g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf>), enabling dynamic control over key filter parameters such as center frequency, bandwidth, and gain. The proposed filter adopts a Gm-C topology, wherein OTAs replace passive resistors, thereby enabling low power consumption and compatibility with deep submicron CMOS processes. The filter’s frequency response is dynamically reconfigurable via the transconductance ratio (g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m1</inf>/g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m2</inf>) and capacitor ratio (C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>/C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), supporting both low-pass and high-pass operation within a unified architecture. Importantly, maintaining a constant g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf> ratio facilitates center frequency tuning without distorting the transfer function, offering a robust and flexible solution for adaptive analog front-end systems. Simulations demonstrate a DC gain of 3 V/V and a -3 dB bandwidth of 700 kHz when driving a 15 pF capacitive load. The design exhibits high linearity, low systematic offset, and resilience to process variations and device mismatches. These attributes make the proposed filter a promising candidate for low-power, high-frequency applications such as biomedical instrumentation, wireless transceivers, and software-defined radio platforms.

title: Domain Adaptation for Remote Sensing Scene Classification using Deep Feature Extraction and Granulation combined with ELM classifier
authors: Neeta Sharma, Ravi Sindal, Saroj K. Meher
abstract: The supervised classification of remote sensing (RS) images is dependent on a large number of labeled samples, and the sample labeling techniques are costly and time intensive. This issue can be solved with domain adaptation (DA) methodologies, which worked efficiently with very few labeled samples. In the framework of DA, labeled data from a domain called "source" are utilized to design the classification model for a domain called "target" having a few labeled samples. Here, we proposed a classification model in DA framework using an effective feature pre-processing technique combined with extreme learning machine (ELM) classifier. We have carried out feature pre-processing in two steps that better captures the essential feature information content and contributed to improvement in the classifier performance. In the first step of feature pre-processing, the deep features of the data set are extracted by a pre-trained convolutional neural network (CNN) followed by fuzzy granulation. Deep feature extraction outputs prominent features, and granulation aligns the feature space of both source and target domain. For the classification, ELM is used as the base classifier which is quick to train. We have evaluated the efficacy of the model using RSSCN7 and UC merced as target and source data sets, respectively, with overall accuracy, kappa coefficient, computation time, precision, recall, dispersion score, and F1 score.

title: Impedance-Frequency Characteristics of Surface Dry EEG Electrodes Using an Agar-Based Phantom
authors: Lubomir Trpis, Maros Smondrk, Veronika Wohlmuthova, Branko Babusiak
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: A proper conductivity at an electrode-skin interface is necessary to achieve in biosignal acquisition. Therefore, this paper focuses on the contact impedance of dry EEG electrodes. Two Special Golden Alloy electrodes and one Special Conductive Polymer electrode from g.tec medical engineering GmbH (Austria) were used. For comparison, a Wet Adhesive Ag/AgCl electrode was also tested. An artificial electrode-skin interface was designed to allow repeatability and consistent measurement conditions. To compute the impedance magnitude and phase, a frequency band from 0.5 Hertz to 1100 Hertz was examined using a harmonic signal generator with an amplitude of 5 Volts. The resulting impedance-frequency characteristics showed that dry electrodes had moderate to strong resistive-capacitive behavior, which may cause problems in higher frequency biosignal acquisition (e.g. electroencephalogram). However, the results also revealed that the impedance magnitude of the Special Golden Alloy electrodes reached comparable values with the wet adhesive Ag/AgCl electrode in mostly frequencies. The measurement procedure is repeatable, allowing the comparison of various electrode types in the future. Additionally, it is recommended to design a proper in vivo measurement protocol.

title: A Comparative Study of Algorithms for School Timetable Generation
authors: Oksana Nikiforova, Aleksejs Ivanovs, Karina Andžāne, Guntis Petrovskis, Alisa Mamikova, Jānis Kaġis
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: The school timetabling problem (STP) is a wellknown combinatorial optimization challenge that involves assigning a set of events, such as classes, teachers, rooms, and timeslots, while satisfying a complex set of constraints. Due to its nature, a wide range of algorithmic approaches have been developed to address this problem, including exact methods, heuristics, and metaheuristics. This paper presents a comparative study of several prominent algorithmic techniques used for school timetable generation, including constraint programming, genetic algorithms, simulated annealing, and tabu search. Each algorithm is evaluated based on expressiveness, adaptability, and practicality. Experiments are conducted on publicly available datasets and real-world school scheduling scenarios in Latvia. The results highlight the strengths and limitations of each approach and provide practical insights into their applicability for different types of school environments. Recommendations are provided for selecting appropriate algorithms based on specific problem characteristics and institutional requirements.

title: Anomalous Human Activity Detection in Dense Crowds Using Pose, Motion, and Emotion Features
authors: Amani Daldoul, Najiba Tagougui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The detection and localization of anomalous activities in dense crowd scenes are critical for ensuring public safety and enhancing surveillance systems. However variability in human behavior make this task particularly difficult. This paper presents a framework for detecting anomalous human activities in dense crowd scenes by integrating pose estimation, motion analysis, and emotion recognition. The system employs YOLOv8 for real-time person detection and 2D pose estimation, Lucas-Kanade optical flow for motion vector extraction, and DeepFace for emotion recognition. Anomalies are identified through DBSCAN clustering of spatial-temporal features and validated against emotion-based contextual cues. Experimental results on the UCF Crime, Avenue, and ShanghaiTech datasets demonstrate robust performance, achieving an F1-score of 88.5 and localization IoU of 76.3. The implementation emphasizes occlusion handling through multi-frame tracking and emotion consistency checks.

title: Photovoltaic System Integration with Green Hydrogen: Towards an Innovative, Sustainable and Carbon-Free Solution
authors: Dalila Hidouri, Yosr Bridaa, Adnen Cherif
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper presents a 1200kw solar renewable energy system with integrated green hydrogen storage, aimed at optimizing the production and management of clean energy. The approach is based on the use of photovoltaic generators to generate solar energy, coupled with a 100kw proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolyzer to produce green hydrogen from excess electricity. The hydrogen produced is stored in gaseous form, which can later be used to generate electricity or as a fuel in industrial and transport applications. The system offers an effective solution to overcoming the intermittency of solar energy, and ensures the development of more sustainable solutions to guarantee a cleaner, more environmentally-friendly energy transition. This work explores the modeling and simulation of the system, analyzing its performance and role in a sustainable, low-carbon energy framework. The simulation indicated that the energy obtained from the photovoltaic panels could produce almost 200 kg of green hydrogen per day via electrolysis, enough to power around a hundred electric vehicles every day, with a range of 250 km.

title: Optimizing Compute Express Link Link Layer Using Adaptive Packing-Mode-Selection Algorithm
authors: Ibrahim Hassan Ibrahim Mohamed, M. Watheq El-Kharashi, Mohamad AbdelAziz, Mahmoud El-Tahawy, Mohamed Abdel-Salam
abstract: This paper presents an adaptive packing algorithm for the CXL link layer, designed to dynamically switch between No Packing, 5-Slot, 10-Slot, and Full Packing modes based on real-time traffic intensity. The objective is to optimize the trade-off between bandwidth utilization and latency. Our methodology employs a threshold-based monitoring system to select the optimal packing mode every evaluation window. Results validated against both synthetic and real-world GPU trace workloads show the adaptive algorithm achieves an average bandwidth utilization of 54.9% and an average latency of 3.5 clock cycles. This represents a 174.5% improvement in bandwidth utilization compared to static no packing and a 48% reduction in latency compared to a static Full Packing baseline (Intel’s CXL 3.0) under variable traffic conditions. The primary contribution is a dynamic, hardware-efficient mechanism that autonomously optimizes CXL link layer performance across diverse traffic patterns, enhancing efficiency in memory-intensive applications like AI and high-performance computing.

title: Integrating Advanced Sensors, Transformer-Based Machine Learning and Edge Computing for Proactive Environmental Management
authors: Anbazhagan. A, Avinash. A, Pradeep Kumar K, Keerthivasan. M, Yogesh K
abstract: User-friendly method to maintaining vehicle health and tracking mileage. Actual management of industrial wastewater is crucial for environmental fortification and regulatory compliance. Old monitoring methods, relying on periodic sampling and laboratory analysis, often consequence in delayed finding of contaminants, hindering timely replies to environmental standard violations. This paper recommends a real-time monitoring system that continuously measures essential water quality constraints such as temperature, pH, conduction, nitrate, and ammonia by means of advanced sensors. Information is transmitted in real-time to a cloud-based platform, enabling instant detection of non-compliance and enabling prompt interventions. Transformer-based machine learning representations are employed to predict future water quality trends and detect anomalies, promoting a proactive method to wastewater management. The integration of edge computing progresses system responsiveness by managing data closer to the source, decreasing latency, and providing instant alerts to regulatory authorities and plant operators upon detecting violations. By joining real-time data collection, predictive modeling, and automated reporting, this system aims to development the efficiency, accuracy, and responsiveness of wastewater monitoring, ultimately supporting better environmental management and confirming adherence to regulatory standards

title: Fault Detection Method for AC Microgrid Based on Phase Angle Comparison
authors: Mahesh Ahuja, Ebha Koley
abstract: In a microgrid with multiple distributed generators (DGs), fault detection becomes challenging due to the diverse fault characteristics of DGs and their control strategies. The control mechanisms of DGs influence fault current magnitudes and dynamics, leading to variations in fault responses across the microgrid. This inconsistency complicates the fault detection process, making traditional protection methods less effective in accurately identifying and isolating faults. An event detection technique based on the integrity of the secured line model is proposed in this paper. The approach concentrates on the mathematical model of the secured line rather than examining the specific fault characteristics of DG. The constraints of the model are used to define a physical quantity, and the model's integrity is evaluated by examining its variation trend in the event of faults. The integrity of the line model is ascertained using the reference voltage, and this technique can serve as the foundation for pilot protection. The method's insensitivity to DG’s fault characteristics is confirmed by simulation.

title: Consensus Representation for Multiview Clustering Based on Concept Factorization
authors: Mutyala Sirisha, AC Priya Ranjani, Ghufran Ahmad Khan, Zulfikar Ali Ansari, Shahin Fatima, Shadab Siddiqui, Mousmi Ajay Chaurasia
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: In this era of rapidly expanding data, clustering of multi-view data is significant scenario for illuminating the data underlying structures. The variability between various perspectives is often overlooked. This research presents an innovative multi-view clustering strategy to tackle this challenge. It uses concept decomposition theory to use the inherent data information. By using manifold learning, the inherent geometry of the data representation is maintained. The intrinsic geometry of the data representation is preserved through the use of manifold learning. Additionally, the smooth regularization component is used to lessen view overfitting, and the correlation criterion is used to learn the common shared structure from a range of data points. In the end, we aggregate every single variable. An adaptive optimization method based on multiplication techniques is developed to obtain the best solution for the suggested model. Additionally, extensive studies on real-world datasets demonstrate that the suggested approach performs better in terms of clustering than the most advanced clustering techniques.

title: SiGe BiCMOS Process Design Kit for Cryogenic High-Frequency Applications
authors: A. Datsuk, A. Balashov, P. Ostrovskyy, M. Yazici, C. Wipf, F. Vater, G. Popken, T. Thönes, S. Selvam
abstract: Cryogenic process design kits (PDKs) are essential for advancing the design of integrated circuits operating at extremely low temperatures, particularly at high-frequencies. This work presents the development and validation of a PDK for a 0.13 μm SiGe BiCMOS process that includes cryogenic models for MOSFETs, heterojunction bipolar transistors (HBTs), and polysilicon resistors. Each component has been characterized at both room temperature and cryogenic temperatures at 4 K to ensure accurate performance prediction. The PDK incorporates modifications to address key phenomena such as tunneling currents and temperature-dependent effects for HBTs, as well as non-linear resistance behavior for polysilicon resistors. Validation was performed by measuring a variety of monolithically integrated circuits including CMOS and HBT ring oscillators, HBT low-noise amplifiers. All fabricated ICs were tested at cryogenic temperatures and compared with simulation. The results confirm the accuracy and reliability of the PDK, supporting its application in cryogenic electronic systems and advancing the capabilities of high-frequency SiGe BiCMOS technology.

title: TinyRadio: Tiny Neural Networks for Fingerprinting Radio Frequency Signals
authors: Mabon Ninan, Ryan Evans, Logan Reichling, Nirnimesh Ghose, Boyang Wang
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Research studies have shown that deep neural networks can effectively classify Radio Frequency signals, such as modulation classifications and radio fingerprinting. However, these neural networks are complex, which often consist of millions of parameters and consume high memory. This makes it challenging to deploy these neural networks on wireless devices. In this paper, we leverage an automatic pruning algorithm, which can automatically remove less important filters on each layer in a neural network. We conduct evaluations over two real-world datasets for modulation classifications and radio fingerprinting. Our experimental results show that: (1) our method can significantly reduce the number of parameters in a neural network for RF classifications (over 98.19% parameter reduction rate); (2) our method can outperform pre-defined pruning algorithms in previous research; (3) our pruning is compatible with other neural network compression technique (e.g., quantization), which can be leveraged to further reduce model size; (4) our pruned neural networks are extremely small (0.25 MBs) and can effectively perform RF classifications on embedded devices (Nvidia Jetson) and FGPAs (Xilinx ZCU104 board) with real-time inference (0.41 milliseconds per I/Q frame).

title:
A Machine Learning System for Early Detection and Prediction of PM
                    <sub>10</sub>
                    Levels to Enhance Public Awareness
authors: Tectonia Nurul Silvani, M. Yoka Fathoni, Tanzil Aziim, Elsa Maulida
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Air pollution, particularly particulate matter (PM10), poses significant threats to public health and environmental quality in Pontianak, Indonesia. This study develops a machine learning-based system for the early detection and prediction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PM}_{10}$</tex> concentrations to enhance public awareness and enable proactive environmental management. Utilizing historical air quality data, meteorological parameters, and temporal features, the predictive performance of Random Forest (RF) and Artificial Neural Network (ANN) models was evaluated. The system architecture incorporates data preprocessing, real-time monitoring, and predictive modeling, supported by an intuitive user interface for public dissemination of alerts and forecasts. Experimental results indicate that the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R F}$</tex> model achieved marginally superior performance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{RMSE}=0.33$</tex>, MAE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.18$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=\mathbf{0. 9 0}$</tex>) compared to the ANN model (RMSE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=\mathbf{0. 3 4}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{MAE}=0.19, \mathrm{R}^{2}=0.89$</tex>). The RF model is recommended for realtime alert systems due to its effectiveness in capturing rapid concentration fluctuations, while the ANN model's stability is suitable for long-term trend analysis. The proposed framework demonstrates the feasibility of artificial intelligence in environmental monitoring, with potential for expansion to multi-pollutant modeling and community-oriented tools, thereby contributing to public health protection and informed decision-making.

title: HyPPA: PPA-Aware Hierarchical RTL Generation and Evaluation of RISC-V Cores Using Hyperparameter Tuning
authors: Mohamed Badawy, Jiulong Wang, Vijaydeep Yadav, Nguyen Anh Vu Doan, Paritosh Kumar Sinha, Wolfgang Ecker
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: Register-Transfer Level (RTL) generators for complex intellectual property (IP), such as RISC-V processors, leverage specialized sub-generators to produce diverse implementations of submodules. These sub-generators create numerous design variants, each impacting synthesis and physical design outcomes, particularly power, performance, and area (PPA). Navigating this expansive design space to identify optimal configurations poses a significant challenge. This work proposes a framework that enables designers to select optimal submodule combinations while efficiently evaluating their PPA implications. It substantially reduces the effort required compared to exhaustive synthesis and physical design of each core variant. By employing optimization algorithms such as Optuna, HEBO, and Ax, our approach systematically selects and assesses submodule combinations to optimize design outcomes. Experimental results show significant improvements in PPA compared to the worst case, with a 74% increase in maximum frequency, a 48% reduction in power consumption, and a 26% reduction in area. Additionally, the design space exploration (DSE) achieves time savings of at least 50% while yielding designs within 1.2% of optimal PPA metrics (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 8 8} \times$</tex> optimal frequency, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 0 0 6} \times$</tex> optimal power, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 0 0 1} \times$</tex> optimal area). These outcomes highlight the effectiveness of integrating flexible RTL generation with automated, physicallyaware submodule selection for efficient design space exploration in complex IP core implementations.

title: Data-Driven Damping Ratio Estimation and Stability Assessment for VSC-Based Power Systems
authors: Zhengliang Fu, Weitao Yao, Zhi Jin Justin Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Power systems based on voltage-sourced converters (VSCs) enable large-scale integration of renewable and alternative energy resources. However, the high-depth penetration of VSCs gives rise to small-signal stability challenges due to their control interactions and the variations of system operating points. In the technical literature, small-signal stability of VSCbased power grids is typically assessed using transfer function or state-space models that are linearized around one operating point. These models often require internal system information and/or measurements that are not available in practice, and they need to be updated when the operating point changes. To tackle these issues and facilitate stability assessment of VSC-based grids, a data-driven approach that predicts the system damping ratio is proposed. This approach only needs a reduced set of measurements and is applicable across varying operating points. The effectiveness and accuracy of the proposed data-driven method is verified based on time-domain simulation studies.

title: Gate All Around Tunnel Field Effect Transistor for Future VLSI Applications
authors: Sanjeet Kumar Sinha, Sweta Chander
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: A detail simulation study of gate all around (GAA) Tunnel-Field-Effect-Transistor (TFET) is reported in the manuscript. The optimization of different parameters of TFET device with SELBOX structure based on the transfer characteristics and noise spectral density is performed. The impact of acceptor as well as the donor type trap with Gaussian concentration of $1 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{~cm}^{-2}$ was observed on electrical characteristics and different figure of merits (FOMs). The proposed ARCH-shaped GAA TFET exhibits high oncurrent $7.66 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~A} / \mu \mathrm{m}$ as well as the low-off current of $3.71 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~A} / \mu \mathrm{m}$, where as the device sub-threshold-slope (SS) of $26 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{dec}$. At low and high frequency the influence of donor as well as acceptor traps on the spectral density of noise $\left(\mathrm{S}_{\text {ID }}\right)$ of the device is found negligible. Further analysis has been carried out by observing the significance of gate tunneling on the noise spectral density of proposed device structure. Since gate tunneling is responsible for the leakage in the device, the $S_{I D}$ of the noise increases when gate tunneling was incorporated. The ARCH-shaped GAA TFET exhibit a better performance in current ON/OFF ratio ($\mathbf{1 0}^{\mathbf{7}}$).

title: Low-power, Energy-efficient, Cardiologist-level Atrial Fibrillation Detection for Wearable Devices
authors: Dominik Loroch, Johannes Feldmann, Vladimir Rybalkin, Norbert Wehn
abstract: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a common arrhythmia and major risk factor for cardiovascular complications. While commercially available devices and supporting Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms exist for reliable detection of AF, the scaling of this technology to the amount of people who need this diagnosis is still a major challenge. This paper presents a novel wearable device, designed specifically for the early and reliable detection of AF. We present an FPGA-based patch-style wearable monitor with embedded deep learning-based AF detection. Operating with 3.8 mW system power, which is 1-3 orders of magnitude lower than the state-of-the-art, the device enables continuous AF detection for over three weeks while achieving 95% accuracy, surpassing cardiologist-level performance. A key innovation is the combination of energy-efficient hardware-software co-design and optimized power management through the application of hardware-aware neural architecture search. This advancement represents a significant step toward scalable, reliable, and sustainable AF monitoring.

title: Mathematical Model of a Saturated Synchronous Motor in Orthogonal d-q Axes as an Element of a Microgrid
authors: Oksana Hoholyuk, Petro Gogolyuk
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: A mathematical model of a saturated non-salient-pole synchronous machine has been developed in the orthogonal d–q axes for transient and steady-state analysis. It accounts the nonlinearity of the magnetization characteristic of the main magnetic circuit of the core, the mutual cross-coupling between the d and q axes, and active power losses in the core. The model is formulated in Cauchy normal form and considers the mutual influence of all features of the synchronous machine and elements of the power supply system (microgrid) in the physical phase coordinates a, b, c.

title: FPGA-Based Hardware Accelerator for LWE Encryption and Decryption with TFHE Scheme
authors: Najmi Azzahra Feryputri, Infall Syafalni, Nana Sutisna, Nur Ahmadi, Rahmat Mulyawan, Trio Adiono
abstract: Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) allows computations on encrypted data, ensuring data confidentiality. This paper presents an FPGA-based accelerator for Learning With Error (LWE) encryption and decryption in the Torus FHE (TFHE) scheme. The design processes plaintext in parallel and supports larger sizes sequentially, where the number of bits in plaintext is 8 bits to 64 bits. The proposed method maps the input to the torus domain by several modules such as fpToTorus32, modToTorus32, bitTotorus32, and accumulator as well as the pseudo-random number generator (PRNG). Implemented on a PYNQ-Z1 FPGA, the proposed design outperforms existing reference software in speed while maintaining low resource utilization and power consumption. Experimental results show that the proposed encryption achieves up to 42× speed up and the proposed decryption achieves up to 10× speed up compared to the reference software running in an AMD Ryzen 7 processor with 16GB memory. The results highlight the potential of FPGA acceleration for efficient and practical homomorphic encryption.

title: Optimizing Wheat Price Forecasting and Reporting through Data Pipelines, Machine Learning, and Automation
authors: Mohamed Wassim Mandhouj, Imen Mejri, Safa Bhar Layeb
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper investigates the critical importance of wheat procurement strategies in countries heavily reliant on imports, such as Tunisia, where wheat imports are exclusively managed by the government entity, the Office of Cereal. Given the significant impact of price fluctuations on national budgets due to large import volumes, optimizing procurement strategies is essential. This study highlights the pivotal role of Free On Board (FOB) and freight prices in determining the final Cost and Freight (CNF) prices. The research begins with the collection and processing of FOB and freight price data, which is stored in a cloud-based dataset. A data pipeline is then developed to ensure continuous access to updated information. Machine learning models, including Random Forest and Support Vector Machines (SVM), are employed to forecast FOB prices. These forecasts, combined with freight data, are integrated into an interactive Power BI dashboard for data visualization and actionable insights. To further streamline access to updates, an automated reporting system using Power Automate is implemented, enabling the distribution of the latest information via email. This study demonstrates the effectiveness of combining machine learning, interactive visualizations, and automation to enhance procurement strategies and provide stakeholders with timely, data-driven insights for navigating the complexities of the global wheat market.

title: IoT-Enabled Cloud Monitoring of Grid-Connected Variable-Speed Wind Energy Systems
authors: Mahdi Hermassi, Saber Krim, Mohamed Ali Hajjaji, Mohamed Faouzi Mimouni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: This paper presents an IoT-enabled monitoring system for grid-connected variable-speed wind energy systems. The proposed system integrates Internet of Things (IoT) technologies to enable real-time monitoring of essential performance parameters, including active power output, DC bus voltage, and system efficiency. Collected data is transmitted to the ThingSpeak IoT platform via HTTP communication protocols, where it is stored, visualized, and analyzed for remote accessibility. This approach enhances the monitoring and management of wind energy systems, ensuring optimal power generation, predictive maintenance, and fault diagnostics. The results demonstrate the potential of IoT in improving scalability, reliability, and operational efficiency of renewable energy solutions.

title: Robotization And Control Systems In Digital Marketing
authors: Hassan Ali Al-Ababneh, Hayel Ababneh, Atalla Fahed Alserhan, Salem A.S. Alrhaimi, Amin Khalifeh, Farah Hanna Zawaideh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: The article is devoted to defining the key aspects and specifics of robotics and control systems in digital marketing of modern companies. In the context of rapid technological progress, process automation is becoming an integral part of business strategies aimed at improving the effectiveness of marketing campaigns and managing customer interactions. It is substantiated how the use of robotic systems, such as chatbots, artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms, helps companies personalize offers, improve service quality and optimize advertising costs. One of the key aspects of the work is the implementation of control systems that allow you to track customer behavior, conduct analytics and adjust marketing strategies in real time. This provides greater flexibility and accuracy in decision-making, which helps improve results. The challenges and risks associated with the implementation of these technologies are formed, including issues of data privacy, security and the need to comply with legal regulations. It is argued that the successful use of robotics and control systems in digital marketing requires the integration of advanced technologies, flexibility in management and constant updating of knowledge to achieve competitive advantages in the market.

title: A Comparative Study of Sampling Methods for Imbalanced Credit Card Fraud Detection
authors: Shweta Ganesh, Ameya Anoop, Dhriti Reddy Kourla, Krishnaraj Chadaga, Jimcymol James, Rajesh Mahadeva
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Credit card fraud is a major issue worldwide, leading to huge financial losses and undermining consumer confidence in online transactions. One of the biggest challenges in detecting this kind of fraudulent activity is that transaction datasets are usually unbalanced; there are much fewer fraudulent transactions compared to legitimate, valid ones. In addition to this, fraud tactics keep changing, which makes traditional detection systems based on fixed rules less effective. In this paper, we use a machine learning model that uses logistic regression to predict fraudulent credit card transactions. To address the problem of class imbalance, we incorporate a few resampling techniques in the preprocessing steps, these include random oversampling, random under sampling, and cluster centroid sampling. Our main goal is to assess how these techniques affect model training and prediction performance, particularly improving the evaluation metrics such as recall, precision, and overall accuracy. The experiment shows that performing random oversampling improves the model performance significantly as it gives the best balance between precision and recall. This study exhibits how important preprocessing strategies are for improving fraud detection in practical situations. Overall, this research highlights the necessity of using resampling techniques with machine learning models as a way to deal with heavily imbalanced datasets. In the future, more advanced methods of deep learning and reinforcement learning can be taken up to further enhance the fraud detection capability while also making sure it is scalable, protects security and adapts well for real-time application.

title: Sentiment Analysis on Social Media Using Discrete Hopfield Networks Optimized by Black Hole Algorithm and Enhanced BERT*
authors: L. Mahalakshmi, E. Anbalagan
abstract: Sentiment analysis on social media identifies user’s emotions by analysing text to classify opinions as positive, negative, or neutral. A lexicon based embedding with Optimized deep learning method was employed for sentiment analysis on social media text. Initially the inputs are gathered from social media. Then the text is pre-processed using five different pre-processing techniques such as tokenization, lowercase conversion, Punctuation Removal, deleting stop words, and stemming. The original text's quality is enhanced by using these pre-processing techniques. Following that, Sentence Part Enhanced-Bidirectional Encoder Representation from Transformer (SPE-BERT) is used to transform words into vector form. Next, the NNMF (Negative Matrix Factorization) is applied to decrease the feature vector's dimension. To predict user sentiment on social media, a deep learning-based Discrete Hopfield Neural Network (DHNN) technique is employed. Hyper-parameters like dropout rate and weight decay are optimally chosen using the Black Hole Optimization Algorithm (BHOA) to improve the DHNN's performance. Simulation analysis shows for dataset 1, the accuracy is 96.1%; for dataset 2, the accuracy is 98.9%; and for dataset 3, the accuracy is 97.4%. The suggested methodology exactly analyses user attitudes for better understand and capitalize on public sentiment, strengthen promotional efforts, and boosting customer participation.

title: The Impact of LLM Assistance on User Spam Detection
authors: Alexis Morales Flores, Jay Jhaveri, Aditya Sharma, Sarthak Rege, Imani Munyaka
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 Workshop on Human-Centered AI Privacy and Security
abstract: Prior research has extensively examined how everyday users detect spam emails, revealing a consistent need for additional support through features such as automatic detection, secure email tools, and labeling mechanisms. However, with the emergence of large language models (LLMs), it remains unclear how these tools impact users’ decision-making in the context of spam detection. In this study, we investigate the role of LLMs as decision-support tools and their impact on users’ ability to identify spam. We conduct a user study in which participants (N = 295) respond to a total of four emails—two spam and two legitimate (ham) messages. Our findings suggest that prior educational efforts around spam awareness may have positively influenced user decision-making. However, the results also highlight users’ tendency to cognitively offload the task of spam detection onto external tools like LLMs, underscoring the continued need for contextual support to reinforce accurate detection and reduce user vulnerability.

title: Large Multimodal Model-aided Scheduling for 6G Autonomous Communications
authors: Sunwoo Kim, Byonghyo Shim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: Recently, large language models (LLMs) have gained significant attention for their ability to generate fast and accurate answer to the given query. These models have evolved into large multimodal models (LMMs), which can interpret and analyze multimodal inputs such as images and text. With the exponential growth of AI functionalities in autonomous devices, the central unit (CU), a digital processing unit performing AI inference, needs to handle LMMs to effectively control these devices. To ensure seamless command delivery to devices, the CU must perform the scheduling, which involves resource block (RB) allocation for data transmission and modulation and coding scheme (MCS) index selection based on the channel conditions. This task is challenging in many practical environments in 6G, where even small user movement can cause abrupt channel changes. In this paper, we propose a novel LMM-based scheduling technique to address this challenge. Our key idea is to leverage LMM to predict future channel parameters (e.g., distance, angles, and path gain) by analyzing the visual sensing information as well as pilot signals. By exploiting LMMs to predict the presence of reliable path and geometric information of users from the visual sensing information, and then combining these with past channel states from pilot signals, we can accurately predict future channel parameters. Using these predictions, we can preemptively make channel-aware scheduling decisions. From the numerical evaluations, we show that the proposed technique achieves more than 30% throughput gain over the conventional scheduling techniques.

title: TFDCNet: Two-stage multimodal fusion and fine-grained convolutional space propagation network for depth completion of outdoor scenes
authors: Sihan Chen, Hui Chen, Shuqi Liu, Yige Zhao, Wanquan Liu
abstract: Outdoor depth acquisition is a challenging task due to the factors such as high complexity and sensitivity to light variation which result in sparse point cloud density and make difficulties in image reconstruction. This research is an attempt to address these issues and suggests the use of RGB image guidance for depth completion of sparse laser point clouds. The presented research work involves three stages. Firstly, to overcome incomplete or inaccurate completion caused by unclear information corresponding RGB image and depth image, a guided convolutional module and a two-stage attention mechanism based on feature fusion strategy are proposed. The strategy uses lightweight network models to improve the completion accuracy. Secondly, a completion method based on the fine-grained convolutional space propagation network is proposed to preserve the original depth value and refine the depth map. This scheme addresses the issue of losing the original depth value due to the noise while fusing two different information input modes of RGB image and depth map. Finally, in order to test the depth completion performance of TFDCNet, evaluation is performed by using the KITTI dataset. Experimental results reveal that TFDCNet shows improved completion accuracy by 8.36% in the selected scenarios comparing with the state-of-the-arts.

title: A Visual Annotation-Free Method That Rivals Fully Supervised Methods for Grounded Multimodal Named Entity Recognition
authors: Jia Yang, Jianfei Yu, Zilin Du, Wenya Wang, Li Yang, Rui Xia, Boyang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Grounded Multimodal Named Entity Recognition (GMNER) aims to extract named entities, their types, and corresponding visual objects from image-text pairs. However, existing GMNER methods rely on costly multimodal annotations, limiting their scalability in real applications. To address this issue, we propose a visual annotation-free framework that leverages text-only NER data and a Zero-shot Entity Visual Grounding (ZeroEVG) approach. ZeroEVG consists of three modules: (1) Candidate Object Generation, which pre-selects visual object candidates; (2) Entity-Object Matching, which determines whether an entity has a visual presence; and (3) Entity Visual Localization, which employs a variant of GradCAM to identify bounding boxes for groundable entities. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets show that our visual annotation-free framework achieves competitive performance with fully supervised multimodal approaches, and even surpasses some of them under the same backbone on both GMNER and EVG tasks.

title: Deep Learning-Based Energy Consumption Modeling in Smart Buildings
authors: Raed Hamyd, Surbhi Saroha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: Energy consumption modelling has become increasingly important with the proliferation of smart buildings. In traditional statistical methods, variables such as occupancy, weather, and appliance behaviour are not taken into account, resulting in incorrect predictions of nonlinear and dynamic energy usage patterns. In traditional statistical methods, variables such as occupancy, weather, and appliance behaviour are not taken into account, resulting in incorrect predictions of nonlinear and dynamic energy usage patterns. Sensor data was collected from a commercial building in Klang Valley, Malaysia, for training and evaluating the model. Several data preprocessing techniques were employed to enhance the model's reliability, including normality testing, missing value imputation, and standardisation. For validation, RMSE, MAE, and MAPE metrics were used. The proposed model demonstrates superior prediction accuracy, supporting sustainable building practices, enhancing energy management, and reducing costs.

title: Dynamic Enhancement Network with Probability Switch for RGB-T Tracking
authors: Huan Wang, Haomin Chen, Pengcheng Du, Pengju Si, Baofeng Ji, Leipo Liu, Chenqi Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The complementary nature of RGB and thermal infrared (TIR) modalities empowers RGB-T tracking to deliver exceptional performance across diverse scenarios. However, existing approaches suffer from two fundamental limitations: 1) Fixed features fusion architectures exhibit insufficient adaptability to complex environments, and 2) multi-domain features processing inadequately exploits intra-modal information and neglects cross-modal complementary relationships. To address these challenges, we propose a novel RGB-T tracking algorithm called DSTrack. This framework introduces a dynamic switch mechanism that adaptively selects optimal model configurations based on scenario characteristics, enabling structural flexibility for complex environment adaptation. Besides, we propose a multi-domain enhancement network that synergistically combines intra-modal and inter-modal enhancement modules. The intra-modal component employs a tri-domain enhancement strategy (channel, spatial, and frequency domains) to amplify discriminative target features, while the inter-modal module establishes complementary cross-attention links to compensate for single-modal deficiencies. Experimental results show that DSTrack achieves the best performance on four publicly available RGB-T tracking benchmark datasets.

title: Towards Effective and Efficient Non-Autoregressive Decoders for Conformer and LLM-Based ASR Using Block-Based Attention Mask
authors: Tianzi Wang, Xurong Xie, Zengrui Jin, Mengzhe Geng, Jiajun Deng, Zhaoqing Li, Shoukang Hu, Shujie Hu, Guinan Li, Mingyu Cui, Helen Meng, Xunying Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems often rely on autoregressive (AR) Transformer decoder architectures, which limit efficient inference parallelization due to their sequential nature. To this end, non-autoregressive (NAR) approaches aim primarily to achieve significant decoding speedup while the maintaining recognition accuracy that is comparable to AR baselines. This paper proposes a novel NAR block-based attention mask decoder (AMD) that effectively improves decoding efficiency while maintaining ASR accuracy, and also offering flexibility in balancing the performance-efficiency trade-off on both Conformer and large language model (LLM)-based ASR systems. The proposed AMD performs parallel inference within contiguous blocks of output labels while maintaining monotonic left-to-right prediction between blocks. A one-pass beam search algorithm is designed to dynamically fuse Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC), AR decoder, and AMD probabilities. Experiments are conducted on normal speech LS960 and DBank elderly speech across: a) The Conformer encoder-decoder ASR system with filterbank input features; b) its integration with WavLM features; and c) further advancement by integrating an LLM-based decoder. On the LS960 task, the proposed AMD empowered tripartite decoder achieves decoding speedup ratios of up to 1.44x, 1.55x, and 2.31x under the three model configurations over the CTC + AR baselines, without statistically significant WER increases. When operating with real-time factors (RTFs) comparable to the baselines, the tripartite decoder produces statistically significant WER reductions of 0.19%, 0.62% and 0.13% absolute (4.3%, 16.3%, and 3.8% relative). Similar improvements are also obtained on the DBank task, where the tripartite decoder accelerates decoding by up to 1.38x, 1.64x and 1.61x without statistically significant WER increase, and yields statistically significant WER reductions of 0.46%, 0.38% and 0.41% absolute (1.8%, 1.8%, and 2.0% relative) when operating with RTFs comparable to the CTC + AR baselines.

title: MobiLLM: Enabling On-Device Fine-Tuning of Billion-Sized LLMs via Server-Assisted Side-Tuning
authors: Liang Li, Xingke Yang, Wen Wu, Hao Wang, Tomoaki Ohtsuki, Xin Fu, Miao Pan, Xuemin Shen
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing
abstract: On-device fine-tuning of large language models (LLMs) has attracted a lot of attention because of its tailoring personalized models while retaining user data locally on the mobile device. However, it faces significant challenges due to prohibitive memory requirements and slow training speeds. In this paper, we propose MobiLLM, a novel scheme enabling memory-efficient LLM fine-tuning on a single mobile device via server-assisted side-tuning. Particularly, MobiLLM strategically offloads backpropagation computations to an edge server while allowing the resource-constrained mobile device to retain merely a pretrained backbone model with frozen parameters during finetuning. It constructs a backpropagation bypass via parallel adapters decoupled from the backbone. During forward propagation, the device employs low bitwidth quantization for transmitting intermediate activations to the server to reduce communication overhead. The advantage of MobiLLM lies in: 1) confining training data strictly to the mobile device, and 2) eliminating on-device backpropagation while overlapping local computations with server execution. Collectively, MobiLLM ensures the data never leaves the local mobile device while significantly reducing mobile memory and computational burdens. We implement MobiLLM on several popular mobile devices, including NVIDIA Jetson Xavier NX and CPU-only laptops. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that MobiLLM can enable a resource-constrained mobile device to fine-tune billion-sized LLMs, achieving up to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> memory reduction and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.3\times$</tex-math></inline-formula> faster convergence as compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Towards High-Quality Novel View Synthesis From Nonuniformly Distributed Input Views
authors: Libo Sun, Jiatong Xia, Lingqiao Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Novel view synthesis is a crucial task in the field of visualization and computer graphics. Although current methods, such as neural radiance fields (NeRF), have proven versatile for novel view synthesis, they often assume that input views are uniformly distributed in space. This means that each view captures a portion of the real-world scene, with each area being equally represented in the input views. In contrast, real-world scenarios involve randomly captured images with an uneven spatial distribution of input views, where some views of the scene are observed more frequently than others. This discrepancy poses significant challenges for current methods, underscoring the need to address the issue of nonuniformity in practical applications. To tackle this challenge, we propose a new dataset and an effective approach. Our extensive dataset comprises diverse scenes, capturing images in various real-world environments. Unlike previous novel view synthesis datasets, which have uniform or near-uniform input view distributions, our dataset effectively reflects the nonuniform distribution of images in real-world settings. Additionally, we introduce a simple yet effective method that significantly enhances the performance of current techniques under nonuniform conditions without modifying their pipelines. We anticipate that our data and method will serve as a valuable source of inspiration for future research in this area. The data and code will be made publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/JiatongXia/nonuniform.git</uri>.

title: Development Status of the HTS SECAS Conductor for a Full-Size Test Sample
authors: L. Muzzi, M. Bombardieri, E. Cacciotti, G. Celentano, S. Chiarelli, G. Colombo, V. Corato, A. della Corte, G. De Marzi, A. Di Zenobio, A. Formichetti, R. Freda, F. Maierna, M. Marchetti, A. Masi, L. Merli, R. Righetti, M. Seri, S. Turtù
abstract: The ENEA Superconductivity Laboratory, in collaboration with the industrial partner TRATOS Cavi, is continuing the development activity of the high-current / high-field SECAS Cable-in-Conduit conductor, based on stacked REBCO tapes and a segmented, sector-shaped Cu former. The test outcome of various prototypes, carried out at 77 K and self-field in the previous years, have clarified important aspects of the manufacturing process and cable performance, and identified the key aspects of the processing steps. The industrial manufacturing process is consequently being developed, and partly applied for the manufacture of full-size samples, to be tested in the SULTAN facility. The conductor is designed to operate at 4.5 K, with a current of 60 kA and at a field of 18 T (as required by the EUROFusion DEMO development plan). Different layouts have been probed, either based on 4 mm-wide, or on 12 mm-wide tapes, but maintaining the same total superconductor cross-section, to verify the impact on AC losses and on tape mechanics. Two of these layouts are being assembled into a single SULTAN sample, made of two legs connected by a bottom joint. The sample will also be equipped with fiber optic sensors, to demonstrate quench detection capabilities. The main results of the development activities, based so far on tests carried out at 77 K and self-field of short cable lengths, are presented and commented in this work.

title: An Efficient Measurement Method For Fabric Defect Size Based On Multi-Light-Source Computer Vision
authors: Shangyan Zhang, Jian Zhou, Jun Xiang, Ruru Pan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Defects are inevitable on fabric surfaces during the weaving process, and their size is the primary criterion for fabric quality rating. Existing methods primarily rely on computer vision under a single lighting condition to isolate defect pixels from the background, enabling defect contour localization for size measurement. However, due to limited illumination, the shallow features of certain defects remain weak and difficult to detect, even for human observers, thereby compromising the accuracy of the measurement. Moreover, adaptability to the complexity and diversity of fabric defects is constrained by reliance on a single method. To address these challenges, a multi-algorithm collaborative measurement system is proposed, which is supported by an image acquisition platform equipped with multiple illumination sources and designed to decouple and adapt to complex defect measurement tasks. The system, designed for production line deployment, acquires images via alternating flashes from multiple light sources, simulating human vision and enhancing defect saliency to provide high-quality inputs for parallel localization algorithms. Tailored algorithms corresponding to each illumination source consist of training and testing phases for deployment. During training, a normal hyperplane is constructed from fabric images under diffuse illumination, serving as the baseline for defect localization, while the other illuminations assist in detecting defects that diffuse illumination cannot capture, enabling complementary measurement. To evaluate the accuracy of size measurement, the proposed E<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ϵ</sub> is defined as the ratio of the absolute error between the predicted and actual defect dimensions in the warp or weft directions to their sum. Experimental results demonstrate that the system achieves a size measurement error of 0.16, which is lower than that of existing methods, validating its effectiveness. Additionally, the system is adaptable to fabrics of various specifications and can calculate defect sizes in real time on the production line for practical applications.

title: Thrust Ripple Suppression Strategy Based On Quasi Resonant Extended State Observer for PMSLM
authors: Luda Qiao, Jinhua Du, Fengzhen Liu, Zhe Yang, Yao Wang
abstract: Due to the influence of cogging force and end force, permanent magnet linear synchronous motors (PMLSM) suffer from serious thrust ripple. The thrust ripple seriously affects the control performance, greatly limits the application of PMSLM. This article proposes a thrust ripple suppression method based on quasi-resonant controller-based active disturbance rejection control and deadbeat predictive current control. Quasi-resonant active disturbance rejection control is used to optimize the current instruction, which improves the system's ability to suppress periodic disturbances compared with linear active disturbance rejection control. Quasi-resonant deadbeat predictive current control is used to improve the current loop bandwidth in current control circuits. Compared with traditional DPCC, it enhances robustness through targeted interference compensation. This method not only accurately estimates thrust ripple and optimizes current commands, but also improves the performance of the current loop and enables the timely compensation for thrust disturbances. Therefore, this method maximizes the suppression of thrust ripple. Finally, the theoretical analysis was conducted on the stability and parameter tuning of the proposed QR-ADRC-DPCC thrust ripple suppression method, and the comparative experiments were performed to verify its effectiveness.

title: Protecting Your Powerpoint Presentations: Camera Shooting Resilient Watermarking
authors: Heng Wang, Hongxia Wang, Haozhong Yang, Zhenhao Shi, Xinyi Huang
