publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: With the widespread adoption of digital office systems, electronic documents have become the primary medium for information storage and dissemination. However, PowerPoint (PPT) documents are vulnerable to unauthorized photography during presentations, leading to potential sensitive information leakage and copyright infringement. Traditional document security measures, such as password protection and access control, fail to prevent offline photography attacks, while existing digital watermarking techniques face challenges due to PPT's dynamic characteristics and cross-channel distortion. To address these issues, this paper proposes a camera shooting resilient watermarking for PowerPoint presentation. The scheme first selects the master layout backdrop as the watermark carrier according to PPT's compositional features, enabling globally consistent watermark deployment without interfering with document editing functions. By systematically analyzing distortion characteristics during camera-shooting, we identify an optimal frequency band for watermark embedding. Furthermore, a cost-constrained adaptive embedding strategy is adopted to enhance watermark robustness while maintaining imperceptibility. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed solution effectively resists interference in various complex photography scenarios, providing a viable approach for protecting PPT documents.

title: A Survey on Binary and Ternary Neural Networks and Their Realization in Compute-in-Memory for Edge Intelligence
authors: Dahoon Park, Hyungdong Park, Inguk Yeo, Jiyun Kim, Sunghyun Lee, Suhak Lee, Hyunseob Shin, Sung-il Pae, Deliang Fan, Jaeha Kung, Kon-Woo Kwon
abstract: Deep learning has achieved remarkable success across a wide range of applications, such as language modeling, computer vision, recommendation systems, and robotics. However, the growing size of models and their increasing computational demands pose significant challenges, particularly for resource-constrained devices. A promising approach to address these challenges is extreme quantization, exemplified by binary and ternary neural networks. These techniques significantly reduce model size by quantizing weights and activations to 1 bit or 1.58 bits, while simplifying computation, making them well-suited for efficient deployment in resource-limited environments. This paper presents a comprehensive review of extreme quantization techniques, organized into three key areas: (1) a comparative analysis of quantizing only the weights (e.g., binary weight networks, ternary weight networks) versus quantizing both weights and activations (e.g., binary neural networks, ternary neural networks), along with a discussion of the progress and trade-offs of their approaches; (2) an examination of how extreme quantization, initially applied to convolutional neural networks, has been extended to Transformer architectures; and (3) an overview of compute-in-memory architectures optimized for binarization and ternarization, including designs based on advanced bit-cell technologies.

title: DiffMoECom: Diffusion Mixture of Experts for Channel-Adaptive Semantic Image Communications
authors: Xiangdong Tian, Danlan Huang, Zhixin Qi, Xinyi Zhou, Ting Jiang, Zhiyong Feng
abstract: This letter presents a novel generative semantic communications framework for wireless image transmission, designed to excel in dynamic channel conditions and at low signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). The proposed framework, dubbed DiffMoECom (Diffusion Mixture-of-Experts Communications), leverages a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture integrated with prompt learning to dynamically select optimal channel adaptation strategies by activating the most relevant prompt experts. A Joint Source and Channel Coding (JSCC) backbone is employed to transmit the low-frequency components of the source image. Furthermore, we introduce a range-space inversion mechanism, which projects the coarse JSCC output into a noisy latent space. This facilitates faithful semantic reconstruction of high-frequency details through conditional diffusion-based null space compensation. Extensive experiments across various fading channels and SNR conditions demonstrate that our method consistently surpasses state-of-the-art DeepJSCC and generative approaches, achieving superior performance in distortion metrics with competitive inference efficiency.

title: PDE Modeling and Shape Control for the Flexible Tube of a Bronchoscope Robot
authors: Yuhua Song, Zhiji Han, Lifeng Zhu, Jinfeng Li, Cheng Wang, Gao-Jun Teng, Aiguo Song
abstract: For the issue of lung nodule biopsy, this study investigated an intervention robot system based on bronchoscopy. The flexible tube of the bronchoscope robot has a planar arc structure, which cannot be described using classical second-order string and fourth-order Euler-Bernoulli beam models. This article obtains the partial differential equation (PDE) model of the flexible tube by analyzing the force and energy changes of the cables, using the Cosserat beam model, and combining strain vectors and rotation matrices. Further, based on the dynamic model of the system, specific control strategies are developed for the tension applied to the head of the flexible tube and the motor driving the cables, enabling the flexible tube to achieve the desired position and shape, thereby guiding the movement of the bronchoscope robot. Finally, based on the self-developed bronchoscope robot system, the effectiveness of the proposed methods is validated through comparative experiments.

title: Programmable Digital Optical Frequency Combs Assisted Transceiver for Covert Communication
authors: Yaoping Wu, Jincong Hu, Hui Yang, Lianshan Yan, Xihua Zou
abstract: A fully programmable digital optical frequency combs (DOFC)-assisted covert communication scheme is proposed and demonstrated, addressing the challenges associated with the high complexity of analog cloning and synchronization. In this scheme, flexible DOFC are cost-effectively cloned through meticulous design, while fast synchronization is achieved via cyclic shifting, leveraging the excellent reconfigurability and recoverability of digital binary sequences. In experiments, the narrow spectrum is replicated by unique DOFC and subsequently concealed within additive white Gaussian noise. Transmitted mixed signals, with different signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs), are efficiently recovered by cloned DOFC. For the 7% forward error correction limit, 201 comb lines achieve the maximal system processing gain of 21 dB from a low SNR (-15.49 dB @min.). The system tolerates high-order modulation formats and achieves 3× capacity enhancement. The proposed approach improves spectrum utilization and offers a simple, large-bandwidth, and high-security solution.

title: A Deep Learning Framework for Fine-Grained Sea Fog Visibility Classification Using Forward-Scattering Sensor Data
authors: Mengyang Shi, Qinyou Hu, Yuezhao Wu, Zhe Ma
abstract: The occurrence of sea fog leads to a sharp reduction in visibility, posing threats to maritime navigation and port operations. Existing visibility classification methods are predominantly developed for land scenarios, where the categorization of fog conditions remains coarse and is difficult to directly apply to the complex maritime environment. The scarcity of sea fog visibility datasets further exacerbates this challenge. To address these issues, this study proposes a fine-grained sea fog visibility classification network, M-ConvNeXt, designed for multi-level and real-time assessment in support of maritime safety. First, a frequency-domain perturbation strategy was developed to enhance sample diversity and improve model robustness. Then, an adaptive inverted residual block with channel attention was introduced to better extract fine-grained features of sea fog images across different categories. In addition, a maritime visibility image dataset covering six levels was constructed. Experimental results demonstrate that M-ConvNeXt achieves high accuracy and delivers robust performance in fine-grained sea-fog visibility classification, with an average accuracy of 94.59%. This represents improvements of 8.06% over the baseline ConvNeXt-T, 6.83%, 5.97%, and 5.96% over CNN-based ResNeXt, ResNet50 and EfficientNet-B0 respectively, and 2.56% over Swin-Transformer.

title: When Light Bends to the Collective Will: A Theory and Vision for Adaptive Photonic Scale-up Domains
authors: Vamsi Addanki
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: None

title: Ultralightweight CNN Model Applying Categorical Focal Loss Function and Data Augmentation for Alzheimer’s Disease Classification
authors: Wided Hechkel, Rim Missaoui, Abdelhamid Helali
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a major public health threat due to its nature as a progressive neurological disorder. Consequently, the early detection of the disease, can significantly enhance patient care and therapy. Whereas, Artificial intelligence (AI) applications demonstrated its ability to boost patient outcomes and support healthcare professionals. Nowadays, many researches have been carried out using Deep learning (DL) techniques to predict and classify AD. This paper presents an ultra-lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture in order to predict and classify AD’s patients using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) 2D scans. The proposed network applies Categorical Focal Loss (CFL) function and Data Augmentation (DA) in order to enhance the performances. Moreover, despite that the model presents a low complexity and a compact number of parameters, it achieves a strong evaluation metrics. Hence, the obtained accuracies result in $98.59 \%$ for training, $97.19 \%$ for validation and $97.11 \%$ for test. Regarding the trade-offs between the results and the simplicity of the design, the proposed network performs better than the others.

title: Modeling Gen Z Engagement in Gamified Ecommerce: a Partial Octalysis-Based Informatics Approach
authors: Azmil Chusnaini, Reizano Amri Rasyid, Yusak Anshori, Hafid Kholidi Hadi, Muhammad Fachmi, Ratih Amelia, Nadia Nur Thahirrah, Fresha Kharisma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: This study investigates the influence of gamification elements on user engagement and purchase intention among Generation Z consumers in Indonesia. Using the Octalysis framework as a foundation, three dimensions Development and Accomplishment, Social Influence and Relatedness, and Scarcity and Impatience were examined through structural equation modeling. The research involved 200 female respondents aged 17 to 18 who actively use Shopee, a major online shopping platform. Findings indicate that all three gamification elements significantly enhance user engagement. In turn, user engagement has a positive direct impact on purchase intention and serves as a mediating factor between gamification and consumer behavior. The results emphasize the importance of tailoring gamified experiences to align with the motivational drivers of Generation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{Z}$</tex> in digital commerce. This study contributes to the theoretical understanding of gamification and offers practical implications for online retailers aiming to increase user retention and conversion. Suggestions for future research are also discussed.

title: Integrating Local LLMs and Multi-Agent Intelligence for Personalized Eldercare
authors: K S Sruthi Sai Prabha, S Sandhiya, S Sajithra
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: With the global population of older adults expanding, there is a growing need for cognitive systems to aid independent living by enhancing emotional wellness, offering real-time support, and monitoring health. Present solutions are often cloud-based and lack an ability to sense emotion, or offer disconnected voice interactions and safety features. This paper presents ElderEase, a modular AI platform that is designed for offline, personalized eldercare. ElderEase runs on a multi-agent architecture, allowing for voice-based dialogue with emotion recognition through facial analysis and voice input, real-time sensors, and coordination among caregivers. ElderEase implements a number of open source tools such as Whisper, Vosk, SeamlessM4T, LangChain, Coqui TTS and SQLite for completely local processing on edge devices that ensure private, secured, and low-latency in service. ElderEase is capable of delivering empathetic care in a highly resourceconstrained environment.

title: A Comparative Analysis of OCR Models for Key Information Extraction from Invoices
authors: Aeshala Sadha Shiva, Vivin Chandrra Paasam, Nanavala Meghana, Y. Vijayalata
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Extracting structured data from scanned invoices is a growing need across digital operations. Traditional OCR (Optical Character Recognition) systems, although widely used, often fail to extract text cleanly and meaningfully in noisy or skewed images. This research presents a preprocessing-enhanced OCR pipeline, combined with a Named Entity Recognition (NER) model, to benchmark OCR accuracy based on downstream tasks. Using EasyOCR, PyTesseract, and PaddleOCR, we evaluate precision, recall, and F1-score through a fine-tuned RoBERTa token classifier. PaddleOCR achieved the highest F1-score of 0.958, outperforming the rest. Our work proposes an efficient method to evaluate OCR outputs not only on text accuracy but also on their ability to extract semantic information—a practical perspective for real-world automation systems.

title: Engineering Smart Wearable Devices with AI for Cardiovascular Health Monitoring
authors: Shantanu Kulkarni, Monali Gulhane, Kalpana Malpe, Nitin Rakesh, Ajay Pednekar, Akhil Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The application of artificial intelligence (AI) in smart technology has revolutionized healthcare, particularly in the aspect of monitoring heart health. The paper dwells into designing intelligent wearable gadgets that use AI algorithms so as to monitor and control heart conditions in real time. These gadgets, such as fitness trackers, phones, and biosensors, continuously collect physiological data from the individual, including heart rate parameters, blood pressure, ECG, and oxygen saturation levels. The AI engine embedded in these gadgets scrapes through these data to detect outliers, generate predictive analyses, and dispatch customized health alerts. Such systems can recognize early cardiac problems such as arrhythmia or hypertension, thereby offering timely treatment while reducing the risk of permanent damage. To make matters better, AI models also allow for continuous learning from an individual's health data, which leads to better prediction accuracy and more adaptive monitoring. Also, the research has studied the main bottlenecks, with hardware issues such as the privacy of data, the accuracy of the AI models, and the possibility of interfacing them with healthcare systems for real-time medical intervention. This essay stresses how important it is for people from different fields to work together when creating these devices, which use AI, sensor technology, and better healthcare practices to make things better for patients. It's possible that smart tools could play a big part in chronic disease management and preventive care. As they get better, personalized tracking and control of cardiovascular health will get even better.

title: Voice Pathology Detection Using Convolutional Neural Network and Data Augmentation
authors: Ibrahim Missaoui, Walid Toumi, Zied Lachiri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Detecting and identifying voice disorders, which frequently result in diminished vocal quality, is essential for effective treatment and improved patient outcomes. This paper focuses on developing a Deep Learning-based approach to identify voice pathologies. The proposed approach combines the use of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with data augmentation techniques. Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) are utilized as input features to the CNN model to perform binary classification of voices (normal or pathological). Experiments were conducted using two types of voice recordings from the Saarbrücken Voice Database (SVD), including vowels and sentences. The evaluation results demonstrate the superiority of our approach in in terms of accuracy for pathological voice detection compared to SVM appraoch and KNN techniques.

title: Predicting Emotional Well-Being of Gen Z from Social Media Activity Using LSTM: A Deep Learning Approach to Digital Behavior Analysis
authors: M. Gibran Rifka Pramudia, A'imatul Mustafidah, Bilqis Jauharah Ummah, Bima Setyo Nugroho, Hujjatullah Fazlurrahman, Dhiyan Septa Wihara, Fajar Wahyudi Rahman, Achmad Kautsar, Nadia Asandimitra Haryono
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: This study investigates the use of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), a deep learning model, to predict emotional well-being based on social media activity. Trained on user-generated content from platforms like Instagram, Twitter, and TikTok, the model classifies six emotion categories. Results show strong performance in detecting dominant emotions (happy, neutral), though performance declines for minority classes (fear, disgust) due to data imbalance and overlapping features. These findings highlight the potential of AI in monitoring mental health and reinforce social media's role as a reflection of emotional patterns, particularly among Generation Z.

title: Emotion Extraction from ECG and GSR Signals Using BiLSTM Networks
authors: Ch. Raga Madhuri, Girivenkata Saitej Neelaiahgari, Vanapalli Satya Sumanth
abstract: Emotions significantly influence human behaviour, decision-making, and communication, making their accurate recognition essential for various applications. This study introduces a novel approach for emotion extraction from electrocardiogram (ECG) and galvanic skin response (GSR) signals using Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks. Unlike conventional emotion recognition methods that rely on facial expressions or self-reports, our model utilizes physiological signals to capture emotional states with high precision. ECG provides insights into cardiac activity, while GSR reflects changes in skin conductance, both serving as reliable indicators of emotional responses. By leveraging advanced signal processing techniques and deep learning algorithms, the model effectively identifies intricate patterns within these biosignals, enabling accurate emotion classification. Experimental validation demonstrates the model’s effectiveness in distinguishing between different emotional states, surpassing traditional methods. This research contributes to affective computing and human-computer interaction (HCI) by enhancing the capability of intelligent systems to recognize and respond to human emotions, paving the way for applications in mental health monitoring, driver assistance systems, and adaptive user interfaces.

title: Deep Learning-Driven Audio Sentiment Analysis for Security and Threat Detection
authors: Nafla Iqbal, Nirmal Mathew Pradeep, Nitin Menon, Rohini K M, Mariya Vinson
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Online verbal abuse and offensive content present significant challenges to maintaining a safe digital environment. Automated detection and classification of harmful speech can enhance community safety by identifying abusive interactions in real-time. This study explores an AI-powered web application that detects verbal abuse in audio content, incorporating advanced language modeling approaches, such as sentiment analysis and keyword detection, to improve Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) performance. The system comprises three key components: text processing, offensive language detection, and notification mechanisms. It converts spoken content into text, analyzes words for offensive language, and automatically sends email alerts to relevant au-thorities when sensitive content is detected. This approach fosters healthier and more inclusive online inter-actions by proactively mitigating risks and reducing exposure to harmful content. Future advancements may include multilingual support, contextual awareness, and adaptive learning models to enhance detection accuracy across diverse communication platforms.

title: Optimized Crop Disease Detection with Image Processing and Machine Learning Through Data Driven Analysis
authors: P Ramesh Naidu, Dankan Gowda V, Disha Pathak, Pratiksha Meshram, Srinivas D, Supriya Devi
abstract: Precisely identifying crop diseases is a key to achieving high agricultural productivity as well as reduction of agricultural yield losses. Conventional practices in detection of crop diseases are laborious, time-consuming and most of the times not efficient, particularly in extensive farming. This study investigates the adoption of machine learning model in conjunction with image processing techniques to optimise the issues of crop disease detection. The suggested method will use data-driven analysis to achieve a higher accuracy level of the disease classification process through the use of high-resolution images of the crops and highly developed machine learning models. The proposed methodology relies on the pre-processing, feature extraction, and the training of the machine learning model after which it is intensively evaluated based on the performance that is determined by accuracy, precision, and recall. Experimental findings show that there is great increase in terms of detection accuracy over traditional systems. The results indicate that image processing and machine learning can be an important step on the way to alter agricultural practice, allowing the farmers to have a more effective model of disease detection, which would be more scalable. The paper has concluded by mentioning the possible future developments and wider uses with regard to automating agriculture.

title: Rakshak: An AI-Powered SOS System with Offline and Indoor Emergency Response Capabilities
authors: Sorbojit Mondal, Ricky Dey, Rupam Saha, Piyush Goneka, Nabanita Das, Bikash Sadhukhan
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Rakshak is an AI-driven emergency response system designed to overcome the limitations of traditional safety applications, particularly in poor network conditions and indoor environments where GPS is unreliable. By integrating Wi-Fi-based indoor positioning, offline emergency communication, anonymous incident reporting, and AI-driven assistance, Rakshak provides a comprehensive and reliable safety framework. Utilizing advanced signal processing, Rakshak achieves a positioning accuracy of 3.2 meters, significantly improving upon conventional models (5-10 meters). Its multi-channel communication architecture ensures $94.6 \%$ message delivery reliability, even in low-connectivity scenarios, making it a robust solution in emergency situations. The anonymous reporting system maintains user privacy while achieving a $93 \%$ verification rate, allowing effective incident documentation without compromising confidentiality. Built with Flutter for cross-platform development, Flask for backend architecture, and MongoDB for database management, Rakshak integrates machine learning for incident classification and chatbot-based guidance. Experimental results highlight its $71 \%$ faster emergency signal transmission, $67 \%$ improved battery efficiency, and high reliability under heavy user loads. By setting new benchmarks in emergency response systems, Rakshak ensures reliable personal safety solutions in both connected and disconnected environments.

title: AI-Driven QoS Management in Wireless Sensor Networks: Enhancing Energy Efficiency and Network Performance
authors: Banu Partap Singh, Ashu Taneja
abstract: The dynamic rise of Internet of Things (IoT) applications preconditioned the use of Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) when the Quality of service (QoS) management and energy efficiency are the most significant issues. In this paper, the QoS management framework based on AI was introduced; the framework is based on the implementation of the Reinforcement Learning (RL) and energy-efficient concepts allowing to optimize both the network performance and the energy consumption in the WSNs. The framework automatically adapts to real-time network conditions and triggers optimal routing, energy savings and real-time response to network dynamics. The outcome of the simulation results demonstrates that the suggested AI-based paradigm is substantial in advancement of QoS measurements. Particularly, there is 30 percent utilization and life extension of networks, 30 percent economization of the amount of energy expended on a per-packet basis, and a 26.67 percent lesser end-to-end delay than with conventional applications. Also, it raises the throughput by 20%, which proves that the AI model can enhance the speed of data transfer. The fact that AI framework can scale well within a large network and the capability of consistently improving the performance of the network parameter is hopeful about using the AI framework in large-scale deployment of IoT. Nonetheless, these advancements have not solved all the problems, in particular, the computational complexity of AI algorithms in low-resource nodes and the environmental effect due to node mobility and interference. The future research will be conducted to cope with these problems to create lightweight artificial intelligence models and enlarge the system robustness to make them applicable in real situations. Conclusively, the suggested AI-based QoS management scheme has a high potential of providing major benefits in terms of energy efficiency and network performance that makes it an opportune method to be used in IoT and WSN applications in the future.

title: A Comprehensive Machine Learning Strategy for Detecting Autism Spectrum Disorder Through Ensemble Model
authors: Simantika Ray, Suneeta Mohanty, Prasant Kumar Pattnaik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The neuro developmental disorder of Autism Spectrum Disorder(ASD) is mostly identified during early childhood. Identifying ASD promptly is crucial through careful observation, assessment and analysis of a child's development in order to provide necessary care and assistance to help him realize his full potential. While many previous studies have focused on diagnosing ASD in adults, early detection remains paramount despite the disorder's incurable nature. In this study, a predictive ASD model for a toddler dataset was presented that utilizes ensemble learning methods such as voting. This approach complements conventional learning methods. The predictive analysis of ASD is carried out in two stages. Firstly, ASD diagnosis is conducted utilizing a set of classification algorithms including Random Forest (RF), Decision Tree (DT), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Bernoulli Naive Bayes (NB) and Radial Basis Function (RBF) based Support Vector Machine (SVM) on the dataset of toddlers. To enhance the performance of the ASD prediction model, in the second stage, the voting ensemble learning approach was used in conjunction with three classifiers at a time from the above base learners. The findings show that our proposed prediction models based on ensemble technique outperform basic Machine Learning (ML) approaches regarding accuracy, recall, F1 score and precision, making them more useful for early-stage ASD diagnosis in toddler datasets. The ensemble model consisting of RF, SVM,NB exhibits highest accuracy of 98.10% with recall, F1 score and precision of 97.89<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>, 98.58% and 99.29% respectively.

title: Impact of Public Opinion on Financial Markets: Leveraging AI for Sentiment Analysis
authors: Subhra Prakash Panda, Bidush Sahoo, Bibudhendu Pati, Tanmay Mukherjee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: The financial market is significantly influenced by public emotions, which also influence stock prices and investment choices. While AI-powered sentiment analysis integrates social media insights, financial news, and microblogs, conventional analysis has been restricted to quantitative data. With the addition of sentiment data, the financial indicators enable the AI models to anticipate more accurately and help them choose the best trading strategies. This study suggests a sentiment-aware financial forecasting model (SAFFM) that integrates real-time public sentiment with stock market data to improve stock prediction accuracy. Using actual Infosys (INFY) stock data from October 2023 to March 2024, we also perform a detailed compari-son of SAFFM with a baseline traditional model. According to ex-perimental results, SAFFM exhibits reduced absolute prediction errors and more closely matches actual price movements hence indicating that when it comes to market prediction, sentiment-aware models perform better than conventional methods. To optimize financial insights, further efforts will concentrate on improving interpretability and expanding multimodal sentiment analysis.

title: Classification of Retinopathy of Prematurity Through Fundus Images Using Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: Dhanu Das, Sanidhya Sinha, R. Murugan
abstract: Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is a retinal disorder primarily affecting premature infants, posing a significant risk of blindness if not detected and treated promptly. The condition arises from abnormal blood vessel development in the retina. Current diagnostic practices rely on manual examination by ophthalmologists through fundus images, which is resource-intensive and prone to variability. With advancements in deep learning, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), machine learning approaches have shown potential in medical image analysis. In this research, we propose a CNN-based automated diagnostic system for classifying ROP stages using retinal fundus images. The model was trained on a large dataset and evaluated based on classification accuracy. Results demonstrate high accuracy in detecting advanced ROP stages, reducing human error in diagnosis. Future work will focus on enhancing early-stage detection, integrating clinical parameters, and deploying the model in real-world clinical settings.

title: Review of Topological Data Analysis for Multimodal Geospatial Applications
authors: Erik Blasch, Paul T. Schrader
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Geospatial developments include a rich history of sensing, theory, and exploitation. One recent innovative development is the use of topological data analysis (TDA) for multimodal geospatial exploitation. Within the last 25 years, topological data TDA has been developed and been applied to many applications involving one dimensional time series data and two-dimensional imagery. This review paper highlights the recent trends and opportunities to explore TDA for a variety of geospatial applications. The review is to provide an organization of the current developments and expand the possible opportunities in future research, analysis, and deployment of TDA to geospatial information systems. The paper seeks to exhibit the developments that extend TDA from specialized geospatial targets towards increasing situational awareness for aid in disaster relief, climate change detection, and near horizon operational analytics.

title: Efficient Operating Room Scheduling for Pediatric Surgery: A Case Study
authors: Adnen El-Amraoui, Mariem Belhor
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET)
abstract: Operating Rooms (ORs) are critical resources in hospitals, playing a key element in ensuring efficient healthcare delivery. Optimizing OR scheduling is important to improve hospital operations, minimize costs and enhance patient satisfaction. While multiple strategies have been proposed in the literature, the issue of reducing surgical overtime, particularly by minimizing the maximum completion time of all scheduled tasks (makespan, $C_{\max }$), remains insufficiently explored. This paper focuses on managing surgical overtime effectively to ensure timely surgery starts throughout the workday. To address these challenges, we propose a new optimization model for OR scheduling, solved using CPLEX and validated with real data from a Pediatric Surgery Department of a Tunisian hospital. The results demonstrate a significant improvement over the manual scheduling approach of the hospital.

title: Hybrid Ensemble Learning Model based Evaluation of Victim Compensation
authors: Manoj Ram K S, Thanyamitraa S, Harini A, Mahathi T, Doffny Pranussha, Elakkiya R
abstract: The JusticeComp-Net framework is designed to evaluate the Victim Compensation Scheme, using a hybrid ensemble learning model. By integrating structured judicial records and unstructured court transcripts, the system leverages transformer-based NLP models, gradient boosting, and meta-classifier stacking to predict compensation outcomes accurately. The model underwent rigorous evaluation using various machine learning techniques, including ResNet-152, XGBoost, CatBoost, and Gradient Boosting, ensuring high reliability in legal case predictions. The results demonstrate that JusticeComp-Net achieves an accuracy of 96.88%, significantly outperforming traditional machine learning approaches. Key performance indicators such as F1-score (96.1%), Precision (95.7%), and Recall (96.5%) validate the effectiveness of the model. Additionally, SHAP-based explainability ensures legal transparency in compensation prediction. Sentiment analysis using LSTM with attention mechanisms further refines verdict inclination assessments. The findings reveal compensation disparities based on case types, highlighting areas for legal reform. This research contributes to the intersection of law and AI, facilitating fairer compensation distribution. Future extensions may include real-time legal database integration and policy-oriented AI frameworks to enhance victim support mechanisms.

title: Game Theoretic Strategies for Latency Reduction in Fog-Cloud Integration
authors: Nutan Mahapatra, Ritik Kumar Singh, Soumik Dehury, Saion Kumar, Sujata Swain, Anjan Bandyopadhyay
abstract: Fog-Cloud integration is a promising paradigm for supporting low-latency, high-throughput applications in the era of the Internet of Things (IoT). By leveraging the proximity of fog nodes to end-users and the computational resources of cloud data centers, this architecture can effectively handle latency-sensitive tasks. Game theory provides a robust framework for modeling and solving strategic interactions among distributed network entities. This paper explores game-theoretic strategies for optimizing latency reduction in fog-cloud integration. We analyze cooperative, non-cooperative, and hybrid game-theoretic approaches to resource allocation, task offloading, and service provisioning. Our findings suggest that well-designed game-theoretic models can significantly improve latency while ensuring fairness and efficiency in resource utilization.

title: Edge-Cloud Synergized Digital Twin Framework for Real-Time Decision Intelligence in Industry 5.0-Driven Smart Cities
authors: P. Janaki Ramal, E. Anbalagan
abstract: Time-sensitive frameworks handling complex urban systems must exist to support the quick manufacturing expansion of Industry 5.0. The study creates an Edge-Cloud Synergized Digital Twin Framework which serves as its base to increase smart city operational performance by enhancing situational perception through this proposed method. The system expansion capabilities are enabled by its design features which allow real-time operation along with minimal reliance on web resources. This model demonstrates superior results in its primary operation aspects through precision and both latency and system update velocity according to established benchmarks. The model enables users to finish their tasks 22% faster during 145 ms processing time. The design outperforms existing models because it integrates advanced adaptability with optimized resource management capabilities which automatically receive updated systems. A practical deployment of the developed approach connects cyber-physical systems to serve as a smart urban administration platform that delivers efficient operation.

title: An Explainable AI Approach to Heart Disease Prediction with Ensemble Methods on Imbalanced Data
authors: Mohd Arshad, V. R. Vimal, A. Hyils Sharon Magdalene, Machanuru Suresh Babu, Mohanraj S, Bazani Shaik
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) rank among the leading causes of death globally, accounting for over 17.9 million fatalities annually. Timely diagnosis and accurate prediction of heart conditions are crucial for reducing mortality rates and improving patient outcomes. This research presents an explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) framework that employs ensemble learning methods to predict heart disease from datasets with imbalanced classes. The study incorporates advanced preprocessing techniques, including outlier management, Box-Cox transformation, and SMOTE-based oversampling. Three ensemble classifiers—XGBoost, Extra Trees, and AdaBoost—were trained and fine-tuned using GridSearchCV. Evaluation metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC-ROC indicated that both XGBoost and Extra Trees achieved perfect scores (100%) across all measures, while AdaBoost showed a slightly lower test accuracy of 91.5% and an AUC of 0.98. Analysis of the confusion matrix revealed that XGBoost and Extra Trees had no misclassifications, demonstrating perfect sensitivity and specificity. Additionally, SHAP visualizations were used to interpret the model predictions, highlighting features like Chest Pain, Ca, and Thal as having the most significant impact on the results. Overall, the Extra Trees model was favored for its high accuracy and reduced computational demands, emphasizing the effectiveness of explainable ensemble approaches in enhancing early detection and building clinical confidence in AI-based heart disease prediction.

title: Predicting Dynamics of Tensegrity Structures Using Physics-Informed Neural Networks
authors: Youyun Xu, Haruku Aono, Muhao Chen, Jing Qin
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Tensegrity structures, defined by a self-stabilizing network of continuous tension and isolated compression, are widely studied in both natural sciences and engineering due to their lightweight efficiency and scalability. Traditional differential equation solvers, such as the Finite Element Method (FEM), require domain discretization through meshing and often face challenges with mesh refinement, particularly for sophisticated geometries and high-dimensional problems. Recently, Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) have emerged as a promising mesh-free and data-driven alternative. In this paper, we apply PINN to solve the dynamical equations governing tensegrity structures. By minimizing the residuals of the governing equations along with measured data and initial condition losses, we train a neural network to predict the nodal coordinates over time. Our numerical experiments on the T-bar and lander tensegrity datasets demonstrate that the proposed method can predict complex tensegrity dynamics with high accuracy.

title: Communicating and Assessing Digital Trust: Insights from Financial Institutions
authors: Julija Saveljeva, Tatjana Volkova
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: Increasing reliance on ICT third-party providers has made the evaluation of their digital trustworthiness a core component of organizational resilience in the financial sector. This study, based on the Baltic banking industry survey, examines how digital trust is communicated and which organizational capabilities support its assessment. Four categories of information sources are considered: technical and architectural documentation, reputation-based evidence, external feedback, and blockchain usage as an advanced indicator of transparency. The results indicate that higher capability maturity is associated with broader use of these sources, while advanced transparency indicators appear to play a distinctive reinforcing role in capability development. The findings highlight the importance of complementing established documentation and reputation sources with more sophisticated transparency signals to strengthen internal assessment routines. Practical implications include prioritizing such indicators when seeking to enhance ICT third-party evaluation practices.

title: Modern Healthcare and Free Space Optics: Opportunities, Challenges, and Applications
authors: Ritu Gupta, Lalit Kumar, Virender Mehta, Kadambari, Aayush Shrivastava
abstract: Today, patient care is of the highest importance, and it appears that many people are eager to discuss patient supervision and share patient data. The idea of the wireless-connected future hospital (WCFH) and the several criteria for its wireless connectivity has been covered in this essay. Many healthcare facilities still do not commonly accept even more fundamental services like voicemail or electronic mail. We still have a lot to learn about how communication services are used in the provision of healthcare. However, despite frequent discussions and large investments in information technology, communication systems receive very little attention. This article discusses the different components of a communication system as well as the core notion of Free Space Optical (FSO) communication systems can be the chosen method of communication service and interface mode in health care.

title: Machine Learning Techniques to Detect Cardiovascular Diseases Using ECG Data
authors: Kunal Kumar, Sukant Kishoro Bisoyi, Raju Kumar Baitha, Sruti Rekha Prusty
publish: 2025 International Conference on Next Generation of Green Information and Emerging Technologies (GIET)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an automated technique to identify cardiac diseases by applying machine learning on digitized electrocardiogram (ECG) records. ECG represents an essential method for assessing the electrical and muscular activity of the heart but still requires laborious interpretation, which necessitates experienced personnel. Therefore, the challenges suggest that our proposed method extracts the essential parts of cardiac signals (P, QRS and T waves), and then transforms the ECG's paper record into 1-D digital signal. For example, the digitizing process starts off by splitting up the paper records into 13 leads and then applying smoothing techniques such as thresholding and scaling to convert the signal into binary images. This makes it fit for proposing dimensionality reduction techniques, such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA), to reduce the dimensions of the dataset while retaining the key features. The signals are classified using machine learning models-k-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Logistic Regression, and also a Voting-Based Model Ensemble Classifier. All these models are evaluated for accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score to verify normal heart functioning or detect conditions such as myocardial infarction and arrhythmias. Such an automated approach reduces the necessity of manual ECG interpretation and improves the accuracy of diagnosis. This system provides a scalable and reliable solution for the early identification of cardiac diseases by successfully processing and analyzing the ECG signals, resulting in better health care outcomes.

title: ChiselTrace: Typed Behavioral Debugging in Chisel Through Signal Dependency Tracing
authors: Jarl Brand, Casper Cromjongh, H. Peter Hofstee, Zaid Al-Ars
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: While modern HDLs such as Chisel (Constructing Hardware In a Scala Embedded Language) significantly improve the process of design entry, debugging these designs is often problematic, because the tools that aid debugging operate on translated code rather than the original HDL. Furthermore, engineers often resort to manual waveform debugging, undermining productivity gains promised by such a language. We present ChiselTrace, an open-source tool for Chisel that is capable of (dynamic) program slicing and automatic signal dependency tracing, allowing faults to be more easily traced back to their root cause. Where prior work focuses on data-flow analysis at the (compiled) Verilog level, ChiselTrace functions at the Chisel source level. Contributions include: modifications to the Chisel library to enable post-simulation analysis; a library capable of dynamic program slicing and dependence graph generation; and a front-end dependency graph viewer. We demonstrate debugging capabilities by tracing an injected fault in the ChiselWatt processor back to the source. We observe that using ChiselTrace's dynamic program dependence graph, the number of lines of code relevant to the fault path is reduced significantly. Project repository: https://github.com/jarlb/chiseltrace

title: Neuromorphic RF Signal Characterization and Feature Extraction
authors: Howard Yanxon, Lauren Reinerman-Jones
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: Neuromorphic computing offers a promising approach for real-time Radio Frequency (RF) signal processing under strict Size, Weight, and Power (SWaP) constraints, particularly beneficial in Electronic Warfare (EW) and Electronic Intelligence (ELINT) applications for small platforms. This paper introduces a dual-task framework leveraging Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) on Intel’s Loihi 2 to perform RF signal classification and temporal feature extraction or parameter regression. Conventional Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) are first trained and convert them into Loihi-compatible SNNs. Our deployed SNN models achieve classification accuracy and regression performance comparable to Graphics Processing Unit (GPU)-based ANNs, while offering up to 10x lower latency and 4x reduced power consumption. These results demonstrate the practical advantages of neuromorphic processors for SWaP-constrained, real-time RF signal analysis in mission-critical environments.

title: Modelling of Chaotic Phenomena in an Electric Arc Furnace System
authors: Piotr Witkowski, Radosław Roszczyk
publish: 2025 26th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering (CPEE)
abstract: The paper presents a mathematical model of complex nonlinear phenomena occurring in an AC electric arc furnace system, which exhibits chaotic dynamics in the initial stages of steel smelting. The use of the hybrid Cassie–Mayr model and the Chua’s circuit allowed modelling changes in the electric arc conductance, which are the result of unpredictable changes in the arc length due to the behaviour of plasma in a chaotic electromagnetic field. Due to the generation of subharmonic vibrations in the arc furnace system, it is of great importance to develop an appropriate model that would allow for a better understanding of these complex phenomena that negatively affect the power system. The dynamics of the electrical characteristics of arcs contribute to the generation of a wide spectrum of electromagnetic interferences that cause asymmetry, non-sinusoidal and oscillations of current and voltage values in the arc furnace power supply system. The obtained results can be helpful in research leading to the reduction or complete elimination of chaotic vibrations in the considered system.

title: HandSpeak: A CNN-Based Deep Learning Framework for Sign Language Recognition
authors: Banala Saritha, G Purnachandrarao, Bandi Meghana, Digwala Srivardhan, Siddula Venkatesh, Rabul Hussain Laskar
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: In the modern era, sign language plays a vital role in facilitating communication for hearing and speech-impaired individuals. However, a communication barrier still exists between sign language users and the general population. In this work, we propose a real-time sign language recognition system HandspeakNet, a deep learning framework using a convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture. The objective is to classify hand gestures corresponding to sign language alphabets with high accuracy using image data. The system is trained and tested on American sign language datasets, demonstrating significant potential for use in assistive technologies and human-computer interaction. The proposed system achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 5 \%$</tex> improvement in recognition accuracy over current state-of-the-art methods.

title: Deployment of renewable energy resources for energy justice and poverty mitigation
authors: Uchenna Godswill Onu, Eliane Valenca Nascimento de Lorenci, A.C. Zambroni de Souza, Pedro Paulo Balestrassi, Ursula Eicker
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: Rural settlements are key to the global food supply due to arable lands. Rural electricity access in developing countries is threatened by low power demands and poverty. Agriculture and agro-industries can mitigate poverty and boost power demands, ensuring economic sustainability. Most rural grids cannot support industrial loads due to design constraints. This study presents a methodology that evaluates the grid’s hosting capacity for industrial loads, and defines a sustainable solution based on the integration of distributed renewable energy resources to adapt the grid to industrial demand. The methodology was applied to a case study in Nigeria using the IEEE 34 bus system. Solar PV and storage were integrated at proposed sites, restoring system voltages. Solar PV and pumped hydro storage were found to be the most cost-effective solutions. Three potential pumped hydro sites were identified along the Cross River in the Nigerian case study. There was a mismatch between daily and yearly ratings of energy devices due to seasonal variation in renewable generation. A storage dispatch model is needed to harness excess generation for sustainable energy, food, and water access.

title: ATCM: A Method for Land-Water Classification from Satellite Images Using MobileNetV2
authors: Om Mehulbhai Patel, Drashti Dipeshbhai Patel, Mayuri A. Mehta, Rachana S. Oza
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Land-water classification from satellite images is helpful in several applications. Several methods have been proposed for land-water classification in the literature. However, they have a few limitations, such as higher computational power and negligible use of pre-processing steps. Moreover, only a few methods accurately classify different types of landforms. These limitations hinder the deployment of such models in real-time or low-resource environments. To overcome the limitations mentioned above, this paper proposes Aqua-Terra Classification using MobileNetV2 (ATCM) from low-resolution satellite images. To improve the quality of the satellite images, the proposed ATCM method entails several preprocessing steps. In this experiment, a CNN model is tested against several other CNN models. MobileNetV2 is found to have the highest accuracy due to its lightweight architecture and efficient feature extraction capabilities, so it is selected for integration into the proposed ATCM method. The ATCM method obtains 96.2% testing accuracy on the pre-processed satellite images.

title: A Continuous Indian Sign Language Production System from Isolated Signs
authors: Suvajit Patra, Arkadip Maitra, Soumitra Samanta
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Smart Computing and Communications (ICSCC)
abstract: Indian Sign Language (ISL) is a low-resource language, and the scarcity of well-annotated continuous datasets significantly restricts the development of robust applications for sign language recognition, translation, and production. The lack of such resources limits research advancements and the deployment of real-world ISL-based technologies. The primary objectives of this paper are: 1) To develop a sign language production (SLP) system that translates spoken language sentences into Indian Sign Language while incorporating proper co-articulation for natural and fluent signing, 2) To create a Synthetic Indian Continuous Sign Language (SynICS) dataset, which can serve as a valuable resource for future ISL translation research. To evaluate the effectiveness of our approach, we employ an off-the-shelf sign language translation (SLT) model for back-translation, assessing whether the synthetic signs can be reliably converted back into meaningful text. We train this model on the SynICS dataset and evaluate real-life videos from the iSign dataset. Our results are highly promising, achieving a BLEU-4 score of 17.56, with the translated sentences semantically matching the ground truth. These findings demonstrate the potential of synthetic continuous ISL data, generated from isolated signs, to improve Indian SLT task. The SLP system and the generated dataset will be publicly available on https://cs.rkmvu.ac.in/~isl/sl_gen.

title: Fingernail Images as Disease Indicator Through Transfer Learning Xception
authors: James Neil B. Mendoza, Amy Lyn M. Maddalora, Albert A. Vinluan, Gladys N. Abrina, Bouzeed S. Boukhazeem, Dorothy G. Buhat-Mendoza
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology Research and Innovation (ICITRI)
abstract: Machine learning is powerful, but deep learning is better in image classification. Disease detection can also be made simpler if non-invasive analysis, like the case of fingernail condition, is used as a disease indicator. This study is an experiment of a CNN transfer learning model in the form of Xception for classifying fingernail images to find possible abnormalities associated with a health condition. Fourteen (14) classes of fingernail, including healthy nails, were used as input to the architecture using Google Colab, Python, under T4 TPU. Running for 38 epochs, the captured. h5 file (168 MB) includes Adam optimizer and other hyperparameter tuning. Evaluation results show that Precision at 94.3, Recall at 94.23, F1-Score at 94.19, and Test Accuracy at 94.23, proving the model's excellent classification power on fingernail abnormalities. The model is ready for a possible integration in the development of a fingernail analysis web application for disease detection.

title: Enhanced Android Malware Detection Using a Hybrid Analytical Framework
authors: Veeramachaneni Nirosha, A. Hrishikesh, B. Ramcharan, B. Vamshi, M. Arvind
abstract: As the dominant mobile platform, Android supports essential infrastructure and personal devices in industries like finance and healthcare, catering to diverse user needs. However, its open-source framework introduces significant security risks. Cybercriminals exploit weaknesses in system permissions, API calls, intents, cryptographic signatures, and manifest files to jeopardize device functioning and private information. The ever-evolving Android malware landscape necessitates advanced and adaptable detection techniques. Traditional machine learning (ML) models, while widely used, face challenges in generalization due to their reliance on specific datasets. Additionally, the rapid evolution of malicious software often renders conventional methods ineffective for real-time threat mitigation. The Hybrid framework is a new deep learning (DL) framework for Android malware detection that is presented in this study. Through the integration of Vision Transformers (ViTs) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), the framework leverages insights from multiple Android malware datasets, enhancing detection efficiency and robustness. The weighted average ensemble strategy employed in Hybrid Framework significantly boosts accuracy and adaptability, outperforming existing techniques. With this hybrid approach, the model achieves an impressive detection accuracy, offering a more effective and scalable a way to protect Android ecosystems from changing online threats.0

title: Ultrasound Image Enhancement Using Modified ESR-GAN
authors: Himanshi Borad, Dhvani Maktuporia, Chirag Chauhan, Mayuri A. Mehta, Dheeraj Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 Artificial Intelligence and Smart Technologies for Sustainability Conference (AISTS)
abstract: Enhancing ultrasound images is an essential but difficult task for precise disease diagnosis. Hence, the enhancement of ultrasound images has been the focus over the last ten years. However, the existing techniques have several limitations, including inadequate noise reduction, insufficient detail preservation, loss of edge definition, difficulty in understanding intricate patterns, and low model accuracy. Hence, this paper proposes a novel technique to enhance ultrasound images using a modified Enhanced Super-Resolution Generative Adversarial Network (ESR-GAN) to overcome the aforementioned limitations. The proposed technique preserves minor details while reducing noise in low-resolution ultrasound images. Its effectiveness has been evaluated using metrics such as Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM), and Mean Squared Error (MSE). These metrics are computed by comparing the generated ultrasound images with the corresponding high-resolution ground truth images. The average PSNR obtained is 65.89 dB, the average SSIM obtained is 0.985, and the average MSE obtained is 0.02. These are compared with the results of ESR-GAN. Comparatively, the proposed technique achieves 24.11% higher PSNR, 8.48% higher SSIM, and 4.54% lower MSE. This implies that the proposed technique achieves a better image quality than conventional methods.

title: Multi-Core Acceleration of K-Means: A Process-Level Parallelization Strategy for High-Dimensional Clustering
authors: Vishnu Vardhan Baligodugula, Abdallah Aldosary, Fathi Amsaad
publish: NAECON 2025 - IEEE National Aerospace and Electronics Conference
abstract: This paper presents a parallel version of the K-means clustering algorithm to address processing of large high-dimensional datasets with reasonable computational efficiency. Our approach uses multiprocessing to distribute calculation tasks among various CPU cores, reducing execution time significantly at the cost of reduced clustering quality. We evaluate our approach on the MNIST dataset and compare performance metrics with typical sequential K-means implementations. Results attain up to 3.5x speedup on multi-core systems with negligible clustering accuracy degradation. The proposed method has particular potential for those applications where there is a requirement for real-time clustering of high-dimensional data streams.

title: Prediction of PCM-Based Battery Pack Thermal Performance Using a Physics-Informed Neural Network
authors: Mohammmad J. Ganji, Martin Agelin-Chaab, Marc A. Rosen
publish: 2025 IEEE Electrical Power and Energy Conference (EPEC)
abstract: A physics-informed neural network (PINN) framework is developed to predict the transient thermal behavior of a lithiumion battery pack embedded in a paraffin phase change material (PCM) with copper mesh and pipe inserts. The PINN is trained to adhere to the governing heat transfer physics of the battery-PCM-copper domains while fitting sparse temperature measurements, enabling high-fidelity prediction of temperature distributions without relying on extensive sensor data for an experimental approach or an extensive mesh for a numerical approach. Two models were trained simultaneously to capture the PCM and copper domains, demonstrating the interaction among the battery heat generation boundaries, PCM latent heat absorption through enthalpy change, and thermal conduction through the copper inserts. Validation against experimental measurements across various discharge rates demonstrates that the model can accurately reproduce temporal temperature profiles, including the cell surface temperature and the minimum PCM temperature deep within the pack, with root-mean-square errors below $1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Notably, the PINN predicts thermal behavior even at locations where direct instrumentation was infeasible in previous research, highlighting its ability to monitor and detect detailed internal thermal states without being limited by instrumentation or meshing requirements. The results underscore the potential of PINN-based approaches for efficient, real-time modeling of battery thermal management systems that involve phase change and high conductive material domains.

title: SparHiXcel: A Cost-Effective Sparsity-Aware Convolutional Accelerator
authors: Amirhossein Zarei, Shervin Vakili
abstract: High-efficiency deep learning (DL) hardware accelerators are essential for deploying DL technologies in resource-constrained applications. This paper presents a novel, scalable, and cost-effective sparsity-aware hardware accelerator for convo-lutional neural networks (CNNs), specifically designed for FPGA platforms. Combined with a new matrix compression technique, the accelerator effectively exploits unstructured sparsity in con-volutional filters to improve resource utilization and accelerate processing speed. It also incorporates a distributed partial result reduction mechanism, offering cost-effective reduction circuits. Experimental results demonstrate that, in selected configurations, the proposed accelerator achieves average processing time reductions of 38.8%, 38.7%, and 35.4% for the convolutional layers of 70% sparse ResNet18, VGG16, and EfficientNetV2-S, respectively. The results also highlight the accelerator’s excellent energy efficiency when computing highly-accurate pruned models.

title: The PAE Cell: A Novel Multiple Outputs Logic Cell and Technology Mapping for eFPGA
authors: Ryo Iwasaki, Kenshu Seto, Masahiro Iida
publish: 2025 IEEE Nordic Circuits and Systems Conference (NorCAS)
abstract: We propose a novel multi-output logic cell, the PAE Cell (Programmable AND Element Cell), for eFPGA IPs, which can significantly reduce configuration memory requirements. The PAE Cell is constructed by combining multiple PA circuits capable of efficiently implementing AND and NOT gates in an AND-Inverter Graph(AIG), and it provides logic expressiveness equivalent to that of a LUT with the same number of inputs, while requiring fewer configuration bits. Furthermore, we propose a graph-matching-based two-stage technology mapping method tailored to the diverse internal structures of the PAE Cell, enabling efficient technology mapping to PAEs. Evaluation using the MCNC and EPFL benchmarks demonstrates that, compared to a 4-LUT, the proposed method can achieve up to approximately 13% average reduction in the number of cells and reduce configuration memory by about half. On the other hand, in large-scale arithmetic circuits, we observed a tendency for the number of cells to increase, indicating the need for future work on optimizing cell and routing architectures for specific applications.

title: Decoding and Analysis of Matter Network Traffic Using Virtual Environment
authors: Ruslans Sudniks, Ilya Kalinins, Andis Supe
publish: 2025 66th International Scientific Conference on Information Technology and Management Science of Riga Technical University (ITMS)
abstract: This research aims to analyse and compare the Matter protocol versus other IoT-related protocols to highlight similarities, advantages and compatibility regarding hardware and software. We demonstrate the decoding of the Matter network traffic using virtual devices and Wireshark. A comparative analysis is performed between Matter integration over Thread and Wi-Fi networks. The proposed environment provides a basis for testing the OpenThread Border Router, Matter security mechanisms, and cluster analysis.

title: DyEKF: Dynamic Protection of Approximate NoC Communications Against Hardware Trojan Attacks
authors: Hamza Amara, Cédric Killian, Daniel Chillet, Emmanuel Casseau
abstract: Multiprocessor System-on-Chip (MPSoC) architectures rely heavily on Network-on-Chip (NoC) for efficient inter-core communication. However, large volumes of exchanged data lead to higher latency and bandwidth usage. Approximate communication in NoCs has emerged as a promising solution to address these challenges by tolerating a degree of data inaccuracy for specific application domains. Nevertheless, this tolerance opens new vulnerabilities, particularly to Hardware Trojan (HT) attacks within Intellectual Property (IP) cores or NoC routers. In this article, we address these vulnerabilities and propose a dynamic protection mechanism tailored for approximate NoC communications. We first analyze the threat posed by HT-induced flit drops and demonstrate their severe impact on the system performance. We then introduce DyEKF, a dynamic protection technique that leverages an Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) to reconstruct dropped flits, minimizing the need for retransmissions. Experimental results show that DyEKF significantly mitigates the impact of HT attacks on the CIFAR-10 database used as an example, achieving up to 2x reduction in retransmission request rates compared to data reconstruction with linear interpolation methods, while maintaining comparable application quality.

title: Lost in Translation: The Search for Meaning in Network-Attached AI Accelerator Disaggregation
authors: Jaewan Hong, Yifan Qiao, Soujanya Ponnapalli, Shu Liu, Marcos K. Aguilera, Vincent Liu, Christopher J. Rossbach, Ion Stoica
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: Datacenters often underutilize expensive AI accelerators (GPUs, TPUs, etc). A natural solution is disaggregation, where servers borrow network-attached accelerators on demand. However, current approaches to disaggregation suffer from a semantic translation gap: as computation descends the software stack, critical application knowledge—like model structure or execution phases—is lost. This forces an undesirable choice between low-level, general-purpose systems that are semantically-blind and inefficient, and high-level, single-workload systems that are efficient but not general.

title: Leveraging Certificate Transparency to Mitigate Downgrade Attacks
authors: Hyunsoo Kim, Myungbin Hwang, Taekyoung Kwon
publish: Proceedings of the 24th ACM Workshop on Hot Topics in Networks
abstract: Despite the widespread adoption of TLS to secure many protocols such as the web, DNS, and email, downgrade attacks remain a significant vulnerability—particularly when clients opportunistically fall back to unencrypted communication. To address this, we propose leveraging Certificate Transparency (CT) as a verifiable source of truth regarding a server's security capabilities. Specifically, we introduce a custom X.509 certificate extension that explicitly declares a server's supported protocols, ports, and TLS versions. This information enables clients to detect downgrade attacks. To assess the feasibility of our approach, we conducted a measurement study of DNS-over-TLS, DNS-over-HTTPS, and SMTP servers. Our results show that the vast majority of certificates are already logged in CT logs. Building on this, we propose a CT oracle that aggregates data from all CT logs to provide a reliable and comprehensive view of certificates.

title: Development and Validation of a Formal Model and Prototype for an Air Traffic Control System
authors: David Geleßus, Sebastian Stock, Fabian Vu, Michael Leuschel, Atif Mashkoor
abstract: None

title: Non-Clairvoyant Makespan Minimization Scheduling with Predictions
authors: Evripidis Bampis, Alexander Kononov, Giorgio Lucarelli, Fanny Pascual
abstract: We revisit the classical non-clairvoyant problem of scheduling a set of n jobs on a set of m parallel identical machines where the processing time of a job is not known until the job finishes. Our objective is the minimization of the makespan, i.e., the date at which the last job terminates its execution. We adopt the framework of learning-augmented algorithms and we study the question of whether (possibly erroneous) predictions may help design algorithms with a competitive ratio which is good when the prediction is accurate (consistency), deteriorates gradually with respect to the prediction error (smoothness), and not too bad and bounded when the prediction is arbitrarily bad (robustness). We first consider the non-preemptive case and we devise lower bounds, as a function of the error of the prediction, for any deterministic learning-augmented algorithm. Then we analyze a variant of the Longest Processing Time first algorithm (with and without release dates) and we prove that it is consistent, smooth, and robust. Furthermore, we study the preemptive case and we provide lower bounds for any deterministic algorithm with predictions as a function of the prediction error. Finally, we introduce a variant of the classical Round Robin algorithm, the Predicted Proportional Round Robin algorithm, which we prove to be consistent, smooth, and robust.

title: Abstraction in Action: Designing Avatar Representations for Reflective Movement Practice
authors: Saliha Akbas, Kemal Kuscu, Terry Eskenazi, Asim Evren Yantac
publish: Proceedings of the 28th International Academic Mindtrek
abstract: None

title: Zero-Shot Interpretable Image Steganalysis for Invertible Image Hiding
authors: Hao Wang, Yiming Yao, Yaguang Xie, Tong Qiao, Zhidong Zhao
abstract: Image steganalysis, which aims at detecting secret information concealed within images, has become a critical coun termeasure for assessing the security of steganography methods, especially the emerging invertible image hiding approaches. However, prior studies merely classify input images into two categories (i.e., stego or cover) and typically conduct steganalysis under the constraint that training and testing data must follow similar distribution, thereby hindering their application in real-world scenarios. To overcome these shortcomings, we propose a novel interpretable image steganalysis framework tailored for invertible image hiding schemes under a challenging zero-shot setting. Specifically, we integrate image hiding, revealing, and steganalysis into a unified framework, endowing the steganalysis component with the capability to recover the secret information embedded in stego images. Additionally, we elaborate a simple yet effective residual augmentation strategy for generating stego images to further enhance the generalizability of the steganalyzer in cross dataset and cross-architecture scenarios. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our proposed approach significantly outperforms the existing steganalysis techniques for invertible image hiding schemes.

title: RemoteCare: AI-Driven Multimodal Predictive Framework with Blockchain for Personalized Remote Patient Monitoring in IoMT
authors: Chigozie Athanasius Nnadiekwe, Simeon Okechukwu Ajakwe, Jae Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
abstract: The Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) enables continuous health monitoring but still faces challenges in achieving personalized predictions and ensuring secure, tamper-proof data integrity. We present RemoteCare, an AI-driven multi-modal framework that fuses synchronized physiological and network data for dual-task learning, simultaneously performing personalized health state classification (Normal, Warning, Critical) and cyberattack detection in IoMT traffic. Unlike conventional population-based thresholds, RemoteCare dynamically adapts alerts to each patient’s baseline, thereby minimizing false alarms and enhancing clinical reliability. A hybrid CNN–GRU–LSTM architecture jointly captures spatial and temporal dependencies across heterogeneous signals, while SHAP-based explainability provides transparent, patient-specific insights into the features influencing each prediction. To guarantee auditability, all predictions are immutably recorded on the PureChain blockchain integrated with IPFS, ensuring decentralized and tamper-proof storage. Evaluated on the WUSTL-EHMS-2020 dataset (Enhanced Healthcare Monitoring System), RemoteCare achieved 99.7% accuracy for health classification and 96.0% for intrusion detection, with negligible false alarms and efficient inference suitable for real-time deployment. By unifying multimodal prediction, personalization, interpretability, and secure logging, RemoteCare establishes a trustworthy framework for early intervention, patient-specific risk assessment, and clinician-oriented decision support in remote healthcare.

title: Ultra-miniature Optical Fiber Accelerometer Based on a 3D Microprinted Proof Mass-Integrated Fabry-Pérot Micro-interferometer
authors: Peng Wang, Taige Li, Shangming Liu, Xin Cheng, Hwa-Yaw Tam, A. Ping Zhang
abstract: In this paper, we present an ultra-miniature optical fiber accelerometer based on a micrometer-scale fiber-top Fabry-Pérot (FP) micro-interferometer. Using an in-situ 3D microprinting technology, a proof mass-integrated FP micro-interferometer has been directed printed on the end-face of a standard single-mode optical fiber. The acceleration can then be monitored via measuring the induced change in the FP cavity length by a laser interferometric readout scheme. Experimental results revealed that such an optical fiber-tip FP interferometric (FPI) accelerometer can achieve not only a wide bandwidth with a flat frequency response of up to 10 kHz but also a low limit of detection, i.e., a noise-equivalent acceleration of 145.05 μg/√Hz. This ultra-small optical fiber-tip FPI accelerometer provides a new solution for high-frequency, high-precision acceleration monitoring in space-constrained applications.

title: Machine Learning boosts robust ocean color retrieval in complex atmosphere and ocean systems: taking coastal Forel-Ule Index mapping as an example
authors: Ruofei Liu, Dingcheng Ye, Jinzhao Xiang, Binyu Wang, Shenglei Wang, Rongjie Liu, Yanlong Chen, Wee Cheah, Keunyong Kim, Tingwei Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate satellite ocean color retrieval in complex atmosphere-ocean systems faces significant challenges. Traditional algorithms relying on remote sensing reflectance (R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rs</sub>(λ)) are hindered by considerable uncertainty or invalid values due to imperfections in or the failure of atmospheric correction. This study addresses these limitations by leveraging Machine Learning (ML) to explore Rayleigh-corrected reflectance (R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rc</sub>(λ)) data towards accurate Forel-Ule Index (FUI) retrieval in the complex atmosphere-ocean environment of the China adjacent seas. First, satellite-ground matchups were constructed with 1,005 in-situ FUI data and quasi-synchronized Moderate-resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rc</sub>(λ) images (0 < Aerosol Optical Thickness < 0.39). Then, machine learning algorithms, including Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Regression (SVR), and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), were compared to identify the optimal one (XGBoost) to construct the FUI retrieval model (XGB-Rrc), with median absolute percentage difference (APDm) and R² of 20.0% and 0.74. Independent validation demonstrates that the new model (APDm = 16.7%) outperforms the existing one (CIE-Rrs, APDm = 50.0%), especially over turbid waters (FUI ≥ 15). Further test over turbid estuaries and bays confirms the general global applicability. Finally, the daily and monthly FUI data products with 1 km spatial resolution for China adjacent seas from 2003 to 2023 were derived from 35,546 MODIS R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rc</sub>(λ) images. The new product shows a 10% (7%) increase in percentage of valid data for daily (monthly) time series, with notable improvements of 17% (24%) in coastal waters (within 20 km from coastline), when compared to R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rs</sub>(λ)-derived FUI products. Both the high accuracy and complete spatio-temporal coverage help revealing short-term FUI variability after a heavy rainfall and long-term FUI changes missed by R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rs</sub>(λ)-derived products. The proposed approach may provide some insights for retrieving other ocean color parameters and contribute to high-accuracy remote sensing retrievals in complex atmosphere-ocean systems.

title: Key in the Pocket: Intelligent Key Recovery with Genetic Algorithm in Correlation-enhanced Collision Attacks
authors: Jiawei Zhang, Jiangshan Long, Changhai Ou, Kexin Qiao, Fan Zhang, Shi Yan, Debiao He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: By introducing collision information, the existing side-channel Correlation-Enhanced Collision Attacks (CECAs) performed collision-chain detection, quickly filtered out candidates unsatisfying collision conditions and extracted a part of optimal candidates for further process, thereby rapidly and significantly reducing the key candidate space and the difficulty of key recovery. However, they are still limited by disadvantages such as serial implementation, complex parameter settings and lack of intelligence, resulting in a low success rate of key recovery. To address these issues, we first present a Collision Detection framework with Genetic Algorithm (CDGA), which exploits Genetic Algorithm to detect the collision chains and has a strong capability of global searching. Secondly, we theoretically analyze the performance of CECA, and bound the searching depth of its output candidate vectors with a confidence level using a data-driven hypothesis test that provides confidence bounds for Gaussian leakages and an approximation based on Central Limit Theory (CLT)for non-Gaussian cases, which facilitates effective and stable population initialization.
